THE GARDEN OF HEALTH, Containing the sundry rare and hidden virtues and
properties of all kinds of Simples and Plants, together with the manner how
they are to be used and applied in medicine for the health of man's body,
against diverse diseases and infirmities most common amongst men.

Gathered by the long experience and industry of WILLIAM LANGHAM, Practicioner
in Physic.

Imprinted at London.

15^^.

To the Reader.
IN this book are contained very many and strange effects and operations of
all sorts of simples, gathered by the long experience and travail of the
Author, so that for variety of things therein handled, it may be compared with
any that are written of the like argument. All which simples with their uses
are easily known, being plainly described in this book, and are gotten
without any great cost or labor, the most of them being such as grow in most
places, and are common amongst us. But for thy better direction, thou shall
understand (good Reader) that all the simples (except Oak, which being omitted
in the right place, is set in the end of the book) are set down in order of
the Alphabet, so that thou may without any difficulty find them by the
titles of the pages: and to every simple is annexed a brief Table of the
effects thereof. There are moreover two general Tables: the one at the
beginning of the book, containing all the simples in order, with numbers
directing to the several places where they are to be found: the other at the
end setting down the names of the diseases and other operations, having those
simples which afford any remedy for the same, added unto them in order so
plainly, as thou can not err therein.

A Table of all the Simples contained in this Book.

The Garden of Health, containing a description of all sorts of Simples, with
their several virtues and properties.
Abracock. ( See Peach idem.) Acatia,
ACatia stops the Laske, and the terms, and sets the loose matrix in the
natural place being drunk with red wine. 2 It is good to be laid to serpigo
or wild fire, all inflammations and hot tumors, wheales, and hot blisters of
the mouth, and with eye medicines to heal inflammations, blastings and
swellings of the eyes being applied. 3 It makes the hair black being often
washed with the water wherein it has been soked: The leaves and tender crops
of Acatia do settle and strengthen members that are out of joint, if they be
bathed in a hot bath, or stewe made with the broth thereof. 4 Being ground with
vinegar, it abateth the pusshes of the lepry. (See Sloes.) 5 In plasters it
helps swellings, and humors in the eyes wonderfully, drink it for the
flixe, seethe it in the water of decoction of Pomegranates, or in vinegar, and
drink it to kill worms. 6 Use it in a pessary to stop the flowers, to stop
fluxes, use subfumigatio^s thereof, or else drink it. Seed distilling use
Acatia. 7 It helps the holy fire, apostumes and wounds of the eyes, it
stops the terms, it heals creeping sores, the falling of the matrix, it
stays vomiting, and strengthens the stomach, and cease pain. (See Sloes.)

Ach 7 Blisters 2 Blasting 2 Eyes apostume 7 swollen 2. 4. 7 Flixe 1. 5. 6
Flowers to stop 1. 6. 7 Hair to be black 3 Holy fire 7 Inflammations 2 Joints
out 3 Lepry 4 Matrix loose 1 Mouth blisters 2 Pusshes 2. 4 Reins running 6
Seed distilling 6 Stomach weak 7 Swellings 1 Tetters 1 Vomiting 7 Wheales 1
Wildfire 1 Worms 5
Acorus, or Gladen.
Drink half a spoonefull of the powder of the Root with white wine, and use
it as much in thy pottage to heal the elfe cake and hardness of the side. 2
Stamp the root and streine it with some Rue and Mints in Ale, and make possets
therewith, and drink the ale of them to expel urine. 3 The broth of the root
procures urine, is good for the pains of the side, liver and breast, the
gnawing of the guts, drawings together or burstings, and for women's griefs as
Iris is, it wastes away the milte, and helps the strangurie, and the bitings
of serpents. 4 Drink a scruple of the root against all inward bruises with
four ounces of honied wine. The root is much used among preservatives and
Treacles. 5 The broth is good against the swellings of the stones, and all
hardness and gathering of humors being sodden in wine and laid to. 6 The
juice drives away the darkness of the eyes. 7 The root punned with a little
Verdigreice, a little of the root of great Centorie and a little honey, draws
forth all kinds of thorns, splints, and broken bones. 8 The root mixed with
vinegar and applied, does consume and waste cold tumors and swellings. 9 The
juice rubbed on the place, drives away and kills the stinking worms, and
mothes called Cimici. 10 Half a dram of the seed taken with vinegar wastes
and cures the hardness of the milce. 11 For the griefs of the liver and
milte, bruise one pound of Acorus, and steep it three days in vinegar, then
seethe it to the one half, then streine it, and put honey to it, and seethe it
again till the vinegar be consumed, and take of this Oximel daily in the
morning with the decoction of Acorus. 12 If any bear Acorus about them, they
shall not have the bloody flixe, nor the crampe. 13 Seethe Acorus in water and
use for the plurisie, the griefs of the chest or breast, and of the liver or
milte, the strangurie and painful making of water. 14 Stamp the root and
seethe it in water to the third part, and drink thereof three days, it does
wonderfully bring forth the urine, and heals the strangurie.

Note that the same root or herb is not to be used in Agues. Calamus
Aromaticus, or the root of Asarabacca may supply the want of it. (See in their
places.)

15 For the stitch in the side drink powder of it with a draught of Malmesie.
16 Toothache apply a piece of the root to the tooth that aketh. 17 For venom
or poison drunk, stamp Gladen that grows on hie ground and Dragons, and
drink it with wine. 18 To dry up wounds and to heal them up with clean
flesh, although the bone be bare, apply powder of the root with honey. 19 For
the dropsy in the belly and feet, and to kill worms, stamp a good quantity
of the root and streine it in white wine and drink it. 20 Flux to stop,
seethe bramble berries in water of the decoction thereof and use it, but if
thou have an ache, bathe in the decoction of it, or wipe thee over with cloth
weeted therein.

21 Iaundies, bath in the decoction of Gladen and Ciclamen, or stamp them and
drink them with water and cover thee to sweat. 22 Flowers to cause, make a
pessary of the root, and anoint it with oil de Bay or common oil, and cast
thereon powder of Wallwort, and put it in all night till it provoke it to
bleed. 23 Pricks and bones to draw out, stamp the root and apply it. 24
Drink it to heal bruisings. 25 Boil it in water or ale, and streine it with
honey, and boil it again, and scum it, and drink it warm in the mornings two
hours before meat to purge watrish humors, and for the dropsy. 26 The
conserve thereof made with the pappe of the roots, two or three times so much
honey or rather sugar, comfort the stomach, and nourishes and loses tough
phlegm downewardes marueilously, and is good for the sickness of the brain,
and sinews, and all diseases coming of phlegm, and opens the natural
course and the terms. 27 Stamp the root of Gladen, and drink it with stale
Ale, and the juice of Fumiterie morning and even fifteen days, and use this
ointment therewith, stamp snayles, and Red dock roots, and boil them with
Barrowes grease, and put thereto brimstone and Mercury ana, and anoint any
skab therewith, and be whole though it be of seven years continuance. 28 To
bring down the flowers seethe Gladen roots in strong vinegar or wine and
receive up the fume thereof into the matrix closely, etc. it never fails, and
therefore beware that you be not with child. 29 Face evil colored distill
the roots of Acorus, and of Turnips in a limbeck, and drink thereof five
ounces before meat fifteen days. 30 Stingings of serpents, apply powder of
the upper parts with wine. 31 To dissolve impostumes under the ear, boil the
roots and stamp them with salt, and apply them. 32 Belly bound, drink the
juice with the yolke of an egg hot as may be suffered. 33 Milt griefs,
drink it with wine, sight to clear put in the juice.

Belly bound 32 Blood flux 12 Bones to draw out 23 Brain griefs 26 Breast
griefs 3. 13 Bruises inward 4. 24 Burstings 3 Crampe 12 Dropsy 19. 25. Ear
impostume 31 Eyes dark 7 Elfe cake 1 Face evil colored 29 Phlegm 26 Flowers
to cause 22. 28 Flux 20 Guts gnawing 3 Humors watrish to purge 25 Iaundies 21
Liver griefs 3. 11 Milte griefs 11. 33 Milte hard 10 Mothes to kill 9
Plurisie 13 Poison drunk 17 Pricks to draw out 23 Serpents biting 3. 30

Strangurie 3. 13. 14 Teeth ache 16 Terms to open 26 Tumors to waste 8 Urine to
expel 2. 3. 14 Wounds to heal 18
Adders tongue.
ADders tongue, stamp it with Swines grease, and apply it to all swellings,
inflammations, ringwormes, and shingles, and to heal all wounds and cuts with
speed. 2 It is singular good to heal wounds both inward and outward, and for
all burstings and ruptures being sodden in wine and drunk. 3 Sees it in
water, and drink it against all hot fevers, inflammations of the liver, and all
inward and outward heates. 3 Stamp it with swines grease, and use it to all
burning and spreading sores, hot swellings and impostumes, and the holy fire.
4 Apply it to a wound either green or dry to heal it speedely, drink the
decoction of it to heal al inward wounds and al other griefs. Apply it to the
new ruptures of children, and bind it hard with a trusse. 5 Sees it with
Sallet oil while it is green, and so it helps both swellings and sores,
wounds, etc. 6 Being wrapped in Virgins wax, and put into the left ear of a
horse, it causes him to fall as if he were dead, but being taken out, he
rises again.

Apost. 3 Bursten 2. 4 Cuts 1. 5 Fevers hot 2 Holy fire 3 Horse 6 Hot griefs
2 Infla^mations 12 Liver hot 2 Ring worms 1 Shingles 1 Sickness general 4
Sores 3. 4. 5 Swellings 1. 3. 5 Wounds 1. 5
Agarike. ( See Larch tree.) Agnus castus.
AGnus castus is a singular good remedy for all such as would live chaste: for
it withstandeth all filthy desire to lechery, it dries up the seed of
generation, whether it be taken in powder or decoction, or that the leaves be
strawed in the bed to sleep upon, and therefore is called chaste, clean, or
pure. 2 The seed drunk dissolueth all windiness in the stomach, intralles,
bowels, and matrix, and all other parts of the body, and opens and cures
all hardness and stopping of the liver and milte, and is good in the
beginnings of dropsies, one ounce being drunk with wine. 3 Taken by itself,
or with Peneroiall, it provoke terms, and so it does, put in as a pessarie.
4 Some mix it with oils and ointments that are made to heat, mollify, and
heal the hard and stiff members that are waxen dead, sleepie, benommed or
wearied, it cures also the clifts and chops of the fundiment and great gut
being laid to with water. 5 Agnus castus drives all venomous beasts from
where it is scattered or burned. 6 It heals all venomous bitings being
applied, or the seed thereof drunk. 7 It helps hardness, stoppings,
apostumations, and ulcers of the matrix, if women sit in the decoction or broth
thereof. 8 The leaves with butter do dissolve the swellings of the coddes
being applied. 9 A branch or rod thereof carried in the hand, defends the
bearer from chafing and weariness. 10 The seed drunk increases milk. 11
With vinegar and oil, it is good for the frenzy and letargie. 12 The leaves
sodden in wine and honey, heal the ulcers and sores of the mouth and gummes.
13 For satyriasis or standing of the yard, eat the seeds thereof, or seethe
it in wine, and plaster it to the reins and secret parts. 14 Agnus castus
sodden in vinegar with Fenell, is good against the dropsy. 15 Sodden in salt
water with Sage and Smallage, and the hinder part of the head washed therewith,
helps the letargie. 16 Being either drunk or carried about one, it takes
away lust. 17 A plaster thereof applied, helps the head ache that comes
of evil humors. (See Tutsan.)

Beasts venomous to drive away. 5 Bitings venomous 6 Chastity to cause 1 Cods
swollen 8 Dropsy 14 Frenzy 11 Fundament chapt 4 Head ache 17 Letargie 11. 15.
Liver stopped 2 Lust to abate 16 Matrix sores 7 Members benommed 4 Milk to
increase 10 Milte stopte 2 Mouth sores 12 Stomach windy 2 Terms to provoke 3
Wearines to preserve from 9 Yard standing 13
Alecost, Costmary, or Maudlinwort.
ALecost, Costmary, or Maudlinwort, either alone or with Persnipseedes boiled
in wine and drunk, cures the gripings and torments of the belly or guts, and
the flixe. 2 The conserve of the leaves made with sugar, does warm and dry
the brain, and open the stopping thereof, and helps reumes and distillations
taken in quantity of a bean. 3 Used in meats, as Sage and other herbs,
especially in sallads and sawses (for the which it is excellent) it yeldeth a
proper sent or taste: Alecost and Maudlin be of equal virtues, they comfort
the stomach. 4 The juice drunk kills worms both small and great: it is good
for the cold mother, it strengthens ye stomach, whether it be drunk or
applied, and stays vomiting. 5 The herb strawed or burned drives away
serpents, and is good against their poisons. 6 Being sodden in wine and drunk,
it is good for them that have drunk Opium, or other venomous things, and for
biting of serpents, especially one dram of ye powder of the root thereof
taken in wine, with the like weight of the seeds of wild Persnips. 7 It has
the nature of Feuerfue in all things, and it is good for women to sit in the
decoction thereof to provoke sweat, and to draw down the terms, and avoid
the pain that comes by retention of them. 8 The same stamped and applied
takes away hardness and swelling in any place. 9 The flowers of Maudlinwort
sodden and drunk, kills great worms in the belly, causes sweat, and
opens the obstructions of the liver, milte, kidneis and bladder. The herb
sodden in water is good for the hardness and swelling of the belly and matrix.
10 The flowers sodden in lee, and the head washed therewith, takes away the
skurfe and skab thereof, and kills lice: the flowers laid among clothes,
defends them from mothes. 11 Stamp the herb with Melilote, and apply it
but once to cuts of veins to heal them: eat the powder thereof with honey
for the griefs of the mouth. 12 It heals the greefes of the breast and
lungs, it breaks impostumes, draws evil humors from the head, and is good
for the stomach. 13 Use it to draw evil humors from the eyes, and for the
griefs of the breast, lungs, stomach, and reins. (See Feuerfue.)

Belly ache 1 Bladder stopped 9 Brain griefs 2 Breast griefs 12. 13 Cuts 11
Flixe 1 Flowers stopped 7 Hard swelling 8 Hardness 8 Head griefs 12. 13 Impost.
12 Kidneis stopped 9. 13 Lice 10 Liver stopped 9 Lungs griefs 12. 13 Milt stopped 9
Mother cold 4 Mothes 10 Mouth griefs 11 Obstructions 9 Poison 5 Serpents 5
Skab and skurfe 10 Stom. griefs 3. 4. 12 Swellings 8 Sweat to cause 7. 8 Vain
cut 11 Venom 5 Vomiting 4 Urine stopped. 9 Worms 4. 8 Wounds 11
Alehoofe, Ground Iuie, Gilrumbith ground or Tudnoore.
Stamp thereof, and put it into the ears to take away their noise and
sounding, and deafness. 2 For pain in the soles of the feet, prick the
leaves and bind them thereto to have present remedy. 3 The juice put into the
nose does purge the head. 4 For dalling and giddiness in the head, dip silk
or wool in the juice thereof with vinegar, and apply it. 5 For all pain in
the head, stamp the leaves with the white of an egg, and apply it. 6 Seethe
it in wine and drink it to expel poison, urine, terms, and the Iaundies, and
to open all obstructions of the liver and milte: the water thereof does the
like. 7 The leaves sodden in wine or water gargarised, helps the
exulcerations and griefs of the jaws and mouth, and wash the secret parts
of women, and all skabs therewith. 8 The juice thereof is very good to cleanse
fistulaes and such like, toothache. 9 Boil it with ginger in wine and hold
thereof in thy mouth. 10 Eyes web, stamp the herb, flowers, and roots of
Dasie one handful, Alehoofe somewhat more, and streine it with Ale or Beer,
and then drink thereof. 11 Emerods, stamp Dasie roots, Persley, and Alehoofe
with fresh grease, and put thereto a little Turpentine, and apply it. 12 The
juice of Alehoofe and of Mouse-eare put into the nose purges rhewme
exceedingly, and takes away the tooth ache. 13 Seethe the juice of it with
honey to help any thing that covers the sight. 14 Mix the juice with honey
and oil of Roses, and anoint the temples therewith and foreehead for the head
ache, or mix the juice of it with a third part of oil, and put it blood warm
into thy ears, to help the head ache, or stamp it with the white of an Eg,
and apply it all night to thy forehead. 15 Mouth griefs, take honey one
spoonefull, vinegar two spoonefull, water three spoonefulls, seethe them, and
put thereto some juice of Ground Iuie, and powder of Myrrh, and wash
therewith. 16 Teeth ache grievous, anoint them with the juice and pour thereof
into the ear on the same side. 17 Wash a handful of Alehoofe and dry it,
then stamp it and streine it with one spoonefull of thick cream, and anoint
therewith burnings, and skaldings, inflammations, and all hot griefs. 18 Head
turning or giddie, apply the juice with vinegar. 19 Meigrim, anoint the
forehead and nostrels with the juice vinegar and oil, or stamp the leaves
with the white of an egg, and apply it. 20 Eyes white spots, put in the juice.
21 Burn white Coprose and dissolve it in the juice, and put three drops into
the deaf ear morning and evening daily. 22 Seethe it with Swines grease, and
anoint all aches therewith. 23 Tetters or Ringwormes, mix the juice of Ground
Iuie with vinegar and Alom, and anoint therewith and be whole. 24 Frenzy and
want of sleep, stamp Ground Iuie and seethe it in water, and stamp it with
Lettuse and vinegar, and apply it to thy head and thou shall sleep. 25 Head
ache, put the juice of Alehoofe into the nose and be whole. 26 Ears deaf,
dissolve burnt Coprose in the juice thereof, and put three drops thereof into
your ear at morn and even daily. 27 Ears deaf drop in the juice. 28 Nose
stinking, put in the juice of Iuie leaves. 29 Ears dull, distill the juice
with wine and use it. 30 Liver pains, drink powder of Iuie and Endive. 31
Hand dried up or withered, anoint it against the fire with oil of Senuie
seeds, or of Colewort seeds, and boil Danewort and Alehoofe a long time in
wine, and foment therewith blood warm a long time, and then apply the herbs.
32 Fluxes general, boil Alehoofe and Cheruile in water, and wash thy feet
therewith, if it mend thee not, thou shall dye.

Ache general 22 Ears deaf 1. 21. 26. 27. 29. Emerods 11 Eyes spots 20 Eyes
web 10 Feet soles pain 2 Fistilae 8 Frenzy 24 Fluxes general 32 Hand
withered 31 Headache 14. 25 Head giddie 4. 5. 18 Head to purge 3 Hot griefs
general 17 Iaundies 6 Liver stopped 6. 30 Meigrem 19 Milte stopped 6 Mouth griefs
7. 15 Nose stinking 28 Poison to expel 6 Rewme 12 Ringwormes 23 Sight 13

expel 6
Alkakengie.
ALkakengie, red Nightshad, or Winterchery, the leaves are cold as Morell, and
as good for all such griefs as Morrell serves for, as Morrell it self
outwardly, but not to be eaten. 2 The fruit opens the stopping of the liver
and kidneis, cleanses the bladder, and provoke urine. 3 And therefore very
good against the Iaundies, the ache of the reins and bladder, and provoke
urine, and helps the sharpness of the urine, and is good for the gravel and
stone. 4 The juice of it and of Morrell is pressed out, and when it is dried,
it is kept in the shadow for all purposes aforesaid. The juice of the berries
dried in the shadow, is good for ye dropsy, the stone, and stopping of ye
urine. (See Morrel.)

Backe-ache 3 Bladder stopped 2 Dropsy 4 Gravel 3 Liuerstopt 2 Stone 3. 4
Reins stopped 2 Urine hot 3 Urine stopped 2. 4
Allder.
ALlder is good against impostumes and swellings in the throat, and kernels, or
almonds under the tongue evil as well as the shales or green pills of
Walnuts, it dies black color. 2 The leaves be much used against hot
swellings, ulcers, and all inward inflammations. 3 The same are good to be put
into the shoes of them that are surbated and weary, to mitigate the heat and
pain. 4 The green leaves with their dew in the mornings, are good to be
strawed in chambers to void fleas, the chamber being first swept. The bark
with old iron put into water, makes black as ink. The wood never rotteth in
water nor in moist ground, but rather turns into stone. 5 The juice of the
bark is good for a burning. 6 The juice of black Allder which is yellowe,
being steeped in wine or beer and drunk, causes to vomit vehemently, and
cleanses the stomach. 7 The same boiled in vinegar and holden in the mouth,
swageth tooth ache, and cures skurfe and fretting sores being applied. The
leaves cause kine to give good store of milk, if they eat them, for they are
good fodder.

Black to color 4 Burnings 5 Coloring 2 Feet sore 3 Fleaes 4 Impostumes 1
Inflammation 2 Kernels 1 Milk to cause 7 Mouth sores 1 Skurfe 7 Sores 7 Stomach
clensing 6 Surbated 3 Swellings 2 Teeth-ache 7 Throat swollen 1 Vomit to cause 6
Weariness 3
Alysander.
ALysander the seeds drunk alone, or with honied water provoke terms,
dissolueth wind and griping in the body, it warmeth the members that are taken
with shaking, and is good for the strangurie. 2 The root breaks and
expels the stone, provoke urine, and is good for the pain in the reins,
and ache in the sides. The seeds is of like virtue with the seeds of garden
Persley, and in all things more convenient and better then common Persley. 3
Alysander dries sores without any grief, and makes ripe such as be hard. 4
The seeds provoke terms and urine, and are good against stopping of the
breast, and shortness of breath, stamp Alysander, and apply it to stop blood.
5 For the chollike, drink powder of the seeds of Alysander, Persley, and
Fennel. To provoke urine, heat Alysander on a tyle stone, and apply it to the
privy parts, and so it voydeth the pain.

Blood to stop 4 Breast stopped 4 Breath short 4 Chollike 1. 5 Flowers stopped 1
Palsy 1 Sores 3. 4 Shaking 1 Stone 1 Strangury 1 Urine stopped 1. 2. 5
Windiness 1
Allgood.
ALlgood, or wild Mercury, taken in meats or brothes, does soften the belly,
and provoke to the stool: the green herb stamped and applied, heals old
sores and green wounds, and kills and brings forth worms engendered in
the same. 2 The juice of the root with vinegar kills skabbes, and takes
away the filthy spots of the skin. 3 The same is good against venomous
bitings: for worms in the ears and spots in the eyes, put in the juice. 4
Face deformed, seethe the root in water, and wash therewith, but beware it
come not near the eyes. Belly bound, (See Mallows.) 5 To heal a kanker,
stamp Mercury, and apply it: wartes to kill, rub them with the juice of it. 6
Eyes bruised, apply the juice with the white of an egg. (See Borage.) 7
Headskald, use the juice with other medicines. Wild tetters, fry it with oil
Olive and hard Soap, and anoint therewith.

Belly bound 1 Bitings venem. 3 Bruses 6 Ears worms 3 Eyes bruised 6 Face
deformed 4 Head skalde 7 Kanker 5 Skabs 2 Skin cleansing 2 Sores 1 Spots 3
Tetter 7 Venime 3 Wartes 5 Worms 1 Wounds 1
Alleluya, Clauer Sorrel, or Sorrel de Boys.
IT is good for sick and feeble stomakes, for it dries and does strengthen
the stomach, and causes appetite. 2 It is good for stinking sores, and mouths
being washed therewith. 3 It is good for them to eat of it that have the
bursting of the guts. 4 The distilled water thereof quenches thirst,
comfort the heart and liver, and is good for all hot diseases and
inflammations. 5 With Alom it is good for all wounds, fistilaes, and sores of
the mouth: it is good for all the hot griefs that the Pomegranate is good
for, and the juice is good to be put into all cooling ointments. 6 Boil it
with the flowers, and by it self in honied water or wine, and drink it to
swage the hot burning and fretting of the bowels, or seethe it in water, and
take it with a glister for the same purpose. 7 The same drunk in time
convenient, stops the whites. 8 The flowers or leaves sodden in oil and
applied, does ripen hot apostumes and swellings, and other tumors, and
breaks them, and sometime does dissolve them clean. 9 Wash thy head with the
decoction thereof, and apply the herb unto thy forehead for the swimming and
giddiness or turning thereof. 10 The seeds and leaves sodden in wine and
drunk, helps the diseases of the sides, the falling sickness, the dropsy,
the strangurie, both in men and women, and purges the humors menstruall. 11
Three dragmes thereof drunk with wine, does help all venomous bitings, and
will not suffer any venom to come within the body, and so it helps both
tertians and quartaines. 12 It prevails much against poison or venom, if 25.
grains or seed be drunk: it heals wounds and kankers, it with the red
flowers or Honie-suckles may be used for Fenigreeke. 13 The leaves taken with
Oximell, is good against venomous bitings, and so is the decoction thereof with
the root being also washed withal. 14 Drink three leaves of it against ye fit
of the Fever tertian, and four leaves against the Fever quartaine with wine.
(See Trefoyle.) The leaves and roots are mixed with Treacles, Mithridates, and
Preservatives made against poison, and the plague. 15 Being roasted in a Docke
or Worte leaf, it fretteth away dead flesh of wounds, (See Sorrel, See
Aniseedes.) 16 Headache wash thy head with lee made thereof.

Appetite to cause 1 Apostume to ripen 8 Bitings venomous 11. 13 Bowels burning
6 Dropsy 10 Falling sickness 10 Fistilae 5 Flesh dead 15 Guts burst 3 Heart
to comfort 4 Headache 16 Head giddie 9 Inflammation 4 Kanker 12 Mouth sores 5
Quarteine 11. 14 Sides griefs 10 Sores stinking 2 Strangurie 10 Tertian 11. 14
Whites to stop 7 Wounds to heal 12
Almonds.
1 ALmonds taken before meat, stop the belly, and nourish but 2 little
especially blaunched. Bitter Almonds do open the stoppings of the lungs,
liver, milt, kidneys, and all other inner parts and are good against the cough,
shortness of wind, inflammation, and exulceration of the lungs being mixed
with Turpintine and licked in. 3 Almonds are good for them that spit blood
taken in with five amill. Bitter Almonds taken in with sweet wine, as Bastard,
or Muscadele, provoke urine, and cure the hardness of the same, and
painfulness in making thereof, and are good for the gravel, and stone. 4
Eat five or six bitter Almonds fasting to withstand drunkenness that day,
Apply them with oil of roses and vinegar to the headache, apply them with honey
to corrupt and spreading sores, and the bytings of mad dogs. 5 They cleanse the
skin and face from all spots, pimples, and lentiles. 6 Blaunch Almonds and
Peach kernels in hot water, and stamp them and streine out the oil, and use
it for the thickness of hearing, with tents of fine linen cloth new made
every day, and keep them in 24. hours four or five days. 7 Bitter Almonds
in a pessarie brings down the terms, with wine they are good for wheales
and little sores, the same eaten take away ache, soften the belly, cause
sleep, provoke urine, and stop vomiting of blood. 8 Drunk with water, or
licked in with honey and milk as an electuarie, as much as a hasell nut, they
are good for the liver, the cough and the windy colic. 9 Sleep to cause take
blaunched Almonds, one quart, Hempseede half a pound, thrice washed in fair
water, Dates 16. stamp them together with one ounce of Poppyseede bruised, and
steep them in good ale three or four hours, then seethe it and streine it,
and drink thereof. The gum drunk is good against vomiting of blood with
vinegar, it heals the skirfe and skab of the skin, drunk with sweet wine,
or Malmesey, it helps the stone. 10 Sweet Almonds do increase the substance
of the brain, cause pleasant sleep, and scour the passages of the urine and
are good for lean folk, the oil of them is good for a dry cramp. 11 The oil
of bitter Almonds is fittest for the worms, running and deafness of the
ears. Almonds eaten with figs cleanse the breast and lungs, and do help
shortness of wind. Almond milk is temperate in hot diseases. 12 Almond
cawdels comfort the principal parts of the body, and cause sleep. Almond
butter is delicate for a stuffed breast. 13 Almond milk will cut, cleanse and
scour gross humors, and may be made in the decoction of hens, partridges, or
chickins, to strengthen nature, or with cold herbs, as Cycory, Endive, Violet
leaves, etc. to cause sleep. 14 To cleanse the reins stamp Almonds with fine
Venice Turpentine clean washed, and eat it for the colic, strangury, and
stone: quench gold, silver, steel, or flints in Almond milk, wherein is put
powder of Rice, and drink it to stop the flixe. 15 Almond brothes or
cullisses, help shortness of breath, the cough, griefs of the lungs, liver,
milt, and kidneys. With Almonds and amill is made march pain, fitter for sick
folks then for night bankets. 16 Almonds in meats are good for a raw
stomach, the iliake and the stone: The juice of bitter Almonds is good for the
sciatica. 17 The oil is good for the griefs and ache of the ears, head,
hips, and kidneys. 18 Stamp one pound and strein them with a pint of water
warm, and as much white wine, and half an ounce of Camphire, and one pynt of
Magerom water, and keep it in a close glass, and wash the face therewith for
the heat thereof. 19 Put oil of roasted Almonds into a red onyon and roast it,
strein it, and put three drops into the ear cold as often as need is against
deafness. For the blooddy flixe, seethe Germander in red wine, and drink it
often daily, and eat parched Almonds after it. 20 For the Sciatica fill pigs
cleyes with Almonds and burn altogether on a hot stone, and mix the powder
with Vnguentum Genistae, and anoint therewith. 21 Stamp one pound of blaunched
Almonds, and streine them with a pottell of Muscadell, and the yolks of eight
eggs newlaid, and put in good store of Sugar, and seethe it a walme or two, and
take thereof four spoonefuls morning and evening to help the consumption. 22
For the stone drink two ounces of oil of Sweet Almonds, with as much Aqua
vitae. 23 To make oil of Almonds or of Nuts, blaunch them, and put them into a
pot full of holes in the bottom, and set it over a pot of seething water, and
streine out the oil and use it. 24 Use Almonds in medicines for the cough and
the lungs, and for the heat of the plague, consumptions, and weakness of the
back. 25 Matrix to cleanse, stamp Bitter Almonds and put them in as a pessary,
the same in like sort helps the mother. To stop a flux seethe Almonds in
honey till they be black, and eat them. 26 Stamp Almonds with their skins,
and make thereof Almond milk with water of hulled Barley sodden, and eat it
with Sugar, and powder of the ryndes and scorches of a Pomegranate for the
blooddy flixe. 27 For the cough of children blaunch Sweet Almonds and dissolve
them in Fennel water, and distill them through a limbeck, and put Sugar to it,
and boil it till it be thick, and let them eat it. 28 For the burning sores
of the matrix in women with child, stamp Sweet Almonds and boil them in
water with the marow of an ox, and put a little meal to it, and anoint
therewith cold, and after wash with the decoction of myrtels. 29 For the
griefs of the head and neck, mix oil of sweet Almonds three ounces, with
meal of March mallows an ounce and an half, and a sufficient quantity of
wax: make it an ointment at the fire, and anoint therewith warm. 30 For the
cough and shortness of wind of cold cause in children, anoint their breasts
with the oil of Almonds and of Lillies mixed together. 31 For heart burning
eat seven or eight Almonds. 32 For worms in children put in a suppositer of
bombast dipped in oil of Bitter Almonds, for their cough and reume, give them
milk of blaunched Almonds well sodden in Fennel water. 33 For the swelling of
their nauill after cutting of it, seethe Spike celtike in oil of Almonds, and
a little Turpentine and dip well therein and apply it. For the ruggedness,
roughness and hardness of the skin and chaps of their lips and hands,
anoint with oil of Sweet Almonds.

Of the use of Oils dissolve Sugar in water of Violets, Roses, or Cynamom, and
put thereto a drop or two of some oil that you mean to try, and make tables
either square or round thereof, and minister them artly.

Oil of Almonds or of Nuts, blaunch them, Almonds. Nuts.
and put them into a pot with holes in the bottom, and set it over a vessel
of seething lyquor, and press out the oil, the press must have two strong
cheeks, and between them two plates of iron, hot, but not burning, and the
Almonds in a bag of canuas, but if the things to be pressed be of a dry
substance, they must be sprinkled with Aqua vitae and first made hot in an
earthen pan, as take Almonds iiii.li. do off the pills with a knife, stamp
them well in a marble mortar, and sprinkle them with the best Aqua vitae, and
Rose water of each an ounce, and heat it so that your hand may not be holden
in it, and then press out the oil into a porringer, and wash it if you will
in an earthen pan, with rain water till it be white, this clears and
beautifieth the skin in any place. Take Almonds x.li. cleansed well, powder of
red Sanders six ounces, Sanders. Cloves.
Cloves one ounce, White wine four ounces, Rose water three ounces, let them
lie close beaten in a mortar well covered ten days beating them over once
every day, then heat it and press out the oil as before, it causes a
comely, red, and beautiful skin. Take Sandrac, white Mastick ana three
ounces, Sandrac.
gum Dragagant two ounces, whites of new laid eggs two ounces, scraped Almonds
vi.li. beat them well together, and cover them close six days, beating it,
and stirring it about once every day, then heat it, and press out the oil,
it clears the skin, and makes it white and comely, and smooth without
danger. Steep powder of Cloves, Cloves. Amber. Cinamom. Storax. Beniamine. Mace.
or Cinnamom, or Musk, or Amber, or Storax, or Beniamine, or Maces in Rose
water, until it has received their strength, and dry it again, and steep it
of new four or five times, then put thereto four times so many scraped
Almonds stamped, then press out the oil, and set it in the sun to purify
for a time. The oil of Cloves it self, has all the virtues of Balm, it
heals fresh and green wounds, it staieth the issues of blood and water in
wounds, it comfort within the natural parts, it purges melancholy blood,
it comfort the heart and head, especially it helps the giddiness of the
head, and weakness of sight, three or four drops taken fasting in a spoone
with some pleasant syrrop, dainty thing, or wine, with the broth or cullis of
a Capon, it helps the colic and suffocation two or three drops taken at
once. In tables or lozinges taken morning and evening, strengthens the head,
and stops reume, it heals wounds without stitching.

Aloes.
ALoes purges cold flegmatike and chollerik humors, especially from the
stomach, and is the chief of all purging medicines which for the most part
do hurt the stomach. 2 But this does comfort, cleanse, and dry up and drive
forth all superfluous humors two drams thereof being taken with water, or
with Cinnamom, Ginger, Maces, Cubebs, Galingale, Aniseeds, and such like
spices, as assuage and take away pain from the stomach, and cause phlegm to
be expulsed. 3 It is also good against the Iaundies, spitting blood, and all
other issues of blood except emerods. 4 The powder thereof strawed on new
blooddy wounds, stops blood, and heals the wounds, and laid upon old sores
it closes them up, and is excellent against ulcers of the secret parts and
fundament. 5 Boiled with wine and honey it heals the outgrowings and rifes of
the fundament, and stops the abounding flux of the emerods being laid upon
them. 6 But received into the body, it causes them to bleed and break out:
with honey it dispatcheth all dead blood of bruises. 7 It is good against all
inflammations, hurtes and skabs of the eyes, and the running and darkness of
the same. Mixed with oil of Roses and Vinegar, and laid to the forehead and
temples, it swageth the headache. Mix it with wine, and rub the head often
therewith to keep the hair from falling. 8 Apply it with wine to the sores
and pustules of the mouth, gums and throat, and the kernels under the tongue. 9
Apply it outwardly to stop bleeding of wounds, and to cleanse and heal them.
Mix powder of Aloes Cicatrine with juice of Colworts, and make pills thereof as
big as Beans, and take them to bedward three at once, to avoid all pain of the
head. 10 Temper it withoyle of Roses, to provoke sleep. Mix it with Malmesey
and apply it, to join together again the skin that covers the knop of boys
yards. 11 For agnayles cut them off and apply Aloes. For riftes and hard lumps
of the fundiment apply Aloes. Eyes skabd, bleared and itch in the corners, use
Aloes, burn it in a burning hot vessel, and stir it often with a feather
till it be all alike roasted, and so it is a good medicine for sore eyes. 12
Mix it with Dragons blood and Myrrh, to heal stinking sores and old sores.
With Myrrh it keeps dead bodies from putrefaction and corruption. Mixed with
ye white of an egg it stops bleeding both of the emerods and of any cut or
wound. 13 It is evil for them that are of a hot nature, but good for them that
are moist and cold. 14 Aloes Cicatrine is the best being bright and brittle. A
little of it tempered with Rose water, and put into the eyes that are dropping
and watery, cures them. Mixed with Saffron and Myrrh and made into pills, it
is the most excellent medicine against the plague. 15 With honey it takes away
the marks of stripes, and does cleanse sores and ulcers. It is not good to be
taken in Winter but in the Spring and Harvest. 16 The weight of a French crown
mixed with Meed, and drunk in the morning does purge choler and phlegm. The
course Aloes is to be given half an ounce at once to Horses and great beasts
tempered with ale. Drink a little Aloes with warm water to avoid vomiting.
17 For rubbing and itch by night, purge and bleed, and anoint with Aloes and
Myrrh dissolved in water of Honey. For imposts of the yard, and wind in the
bottom of the belly, let blood, and anoint with Aloes dissolved in wine: and
for the wind foment with water of the decoction of Aristolochia rotunda. 18
For the Fever quarten take Aloes often, for loss of speech in sickness mix
it with water, and role it in thy mouth. 29 For swelling of the belly, mix
Myrrh, Aloes Epatica and Saffron with the juice of Beans and apply it, or take
four penny weight of Aloes Cicatrine, with fair water first sodden and
sweetened with Sugar. Apreseruatiue, take Aloes Cicatrine two ounces, Saffron
five drams, red Myrrh four drams, make them into powder, and take thereof
three penny weight with one spoonefull of water of Scabious, and another of
water of Wormwood before meat every month once. 20 To draw an Earewig out of
the ear, put in powder of Aloes with vinegar. 21 Mix powder of Aloes Cicatrine
with white wine, and let it stand all night, then streine it, and put thereof
into the eyes to destroy the pearl and web, apply it with honey to the
griefs of the gums and the exulcerations of the yard. 22 Headache, temper two
parts of Aloes with a third part of Mastik, and some juice of Wormwood, and
make pills thereof as much as Peason, and take five or seven of them to
bedward. 23 Kanker, mix powder of Aloes, quick Lime, and Orpiment, and use it
til the dead flesh be eaten out, and then temper Ceruse with oil, and use it
til it be whole. Sores, temper Aloes with yolks of eggs and apply it: it kills
worms, in the body. 24 Liver and milt griefs, take Aloes Epatica, with the
juice of Smallage warm. 25 Worms, take powder of Aloes with honey, or mix it
with the juice of Wormwood, and strike it on a red lether three fingers broad,
and apply it to the nauill three days. 26 Warm as much Aloes Cicatrine on a
knives point as a Bean, make it into three pills with a little Red rose
water, and take it with the pap of an Apple and Sugar, and within half an
hour take a draught of possit ale to purge well: Headache and watching use
powder of Aloes with oil of Roses, or take three pills as much as Beans made
with the juice of Colworts. 27 Eyes dim and bloodshotten, apply Aloes with the
white of an egg: Eyes itch put in Aloes with Fennel water being kept in a
latin basin fifteen days. 28 Eyes ach and bloody, apply Aloes with a little
Opium and woman's milk that suckleth a boy: Stomach griefs use Aloes: Belly
bound mix Salgem Aloes; the gaul of a Bull and oil together, and anoint the
fundament to have present help. 29 Conception to cause, sit over the fume of
Aloes: Drink Aloes Epatica with Sage and Sugar, to restore the liver. Worms
to kill roast a penny weight in an Apple, and eat it fasting three mornings, or
use the powder thereof with Myrrh. 30 A powder incarnatiue to be cast into
wounds, take Myrrh three drams, Aloes four drams, Frankincense two drams and
use it, for the hicket and lothing Aloes helps the stomach above all other
things: Scab of salt phlegm anoint with Aloes, unquenched Lime and common oil.
31 Worms to kill apply a plaster of Aloes and Fenigreke on leather to thy
nauill, fundament sores use Aloes: Stomach to cleanse and to kill worms, take one
dram of Aloes Cicatrine with honey. 32 Wounds to heal use powder of Aloes
Sarcocol, and Sa^guis Draconis. Worms to kill, make pills of Aloes and powder
of Wormwood, and role them in butter, and swallow them down: Fundament fallen,
cast on powder of Myrrh, Aloes, Gauls, and Frankincense of each like much. 33
Ears deaf put a little Aloes into hot water, or white wine, and drop it in
and provoke sneesing with powder of Euphorbium: Cholick, apply a plaster of
warmed honey and Aloes. 34 Lice, Crablice, and Worms to kill, anoint with Aloes
and Rose water. Priuities ulcers, and to incarnate fresh wounds, use Aloes with
burned Dill: Eyes dull and watring, put in Aloes with Rose water. 35 Worms,
stamp Aloes with Bitter Almonds, and apply them to the nauill, or apply it with
Honey and vinegar, or Honey and an Ox gall. The juice of Broom with oil and
Aloes kills lice: Stomach pain, take every day two scruples of pills of
Aloes washed, 36 Or take Aloes washed half an ounce, Honey Rosat, three ounces,
seethe them in two pound of water to the one half, and streine it, and drink
thereof every morning two ounces: Eyes tears and itch, steep Aloes epat. in
Wine and Rose water, and wash or foment therewith. 37 Yard apostumed, anoint
with Aloes dissolved in Wine. Crablice to kill, mix powder of Aloes Ceruse with
oil of Roses or Swines greece, and anoint. 38 Head whirling noise, and pain
of the eyes, take pills made with Aloes half an ounce, Mastik x. grains, as
much as a small Bean, and take every night five of them: Eyes web, temper
powder of Aloes Cicat. with White wine, and let it stand all night, and in the
morning streine it and put it into the eye. 39 Headache great and heavy, mix
powder of Aloes, Olibanum, Mastik Ana, with vinegar and whites of eggs, and
apply it with stuphes to the temples. 40 Liver and milt stopped, take as much
Aloes as a Bean every other day with ye juice of Smallage and some Mastik or
gum Arabik, or Aniseeds. 41 Swelling of blood letting, apply Aloes with yolks
of eggs with vinegar, it kills scab and itch: with juice of Burre, being taken
inward, it helps the Gout: Ears noise, drop in a little Aloes with warm
water, and provoke sneesing with Euphorbium. 42 Worms boil Aloes with
Coloquintida and butter, and streine it, and anoint the stomach and belly
therewith against the fire, or apply Aloes with the juice of Wormwood, or red
lether to the nauill, or drink powder of Aloes and Myrrh, or of Aloes,
Myrrh, and Brimstone. 43 Face Saseflegme, mix the juice of Wormwood, and Red
Docks with Aloes and anoint. 44 Ears worms, put in the juice of Wormwood and
Horsemint with vinegar and Aloes. Belly bound anoint with the gall of a Bull or
Ox, Aloes, Salt, and oil Olive by the fire. 45 Blood to stop, mix Aloes with
Mastik, Hares hair, and the white of an egg, and apply it: Purgation, mix
one ounce of Aloes, with one dram of Turpentine, the gall of a Bull or Ox, 46
and anoint the breast to purge upward, and the nauill to purge downward, and
three fingers lower to provoke menstrewes.

Agnayles 11 Belly bound 28. 44. swollen 19. (see P.) Blood to stop 4. 9. 13. 45
Bloody flux 3 Bruses 6 Chollik 18. 33 Conception 29 Crablice 34. 37 Ears

Amaradulcis.
AMaradulcis, or Woodnightshade, the decoction thereof in wine drunk, opens
all the stoppings of the liver, and is good against the Iaundes coming of
obstruction. 2 For all inward brusings, dislocations, ruptures and hurtes, of
the inner parts, for it dissolueth the congealed blood, and brings it forth
with the urine 3 And it does cure and heal wounds and stripes. 4 Chop one
pound of the wood thereof, put it into an earthen pot, with a pottell of white
wine close covered, saving a hole in the midst of the lid, stopping it close
round about with meal and water, and seethe it to the third part or more, and
drink thereof first and last morning and evening for the Iaundies that have
continued long, and for old rotten Fevers.

Bruses 2 Bursten 2 Fevers old 4 Iaundes 1. 4 Joints out 2 Liver stopped 1. 4
Wounds 2
Amoniacum.
AMoniacum, take one dram of it to losen the belly, and to drive forth cold
slimie phlegm from the farthest parts, for shortness of breath, the stopping
of the breast, the falling evil, the gout, the sciatica, headache, griefs of
the brain, sinowes, and extreme parts. 2 Mix it with honey and lick thereof
to cleanse the breast, and cause easy spitting, or take it for the same
purpose with the decoction of hulled Barley. 3 Take a little of it at once
against the hardness and stopping of the milte, to expel a dead child, and
the urine, but being taken too much or too often, it causes one to piss
blood. 4 Steep it in vinegar, and apply it to the swellings and hardness of
the liver and milte. 5 Mix it with honey or pitch, and apply it to dissolve
hard lumpes or swellings, the knots that come of the gout in the joints and
extreme parts, and to consume all cold tumors and wennes. 6 Put it into all
ointments and plasters that are made to chafe and warm, to swage pain, to
soften and draw. 7 Apply it with oil Cyprus and Nitrum, to the Sciatica, and
upon all pain and weariness of any part. Put it into collyries and eye
medicines, to clear the sight, and avoid webs. Melt it with Assafetida wax
and oil, and apply it to the milt to make it soft and neshe. 8 For daseling
and all diseases of the eyes and head, take one dram with honey, mix it with
honey, and anoint the gout to avoid the knots thereof. 9 It heals skabs and
roughness of the face. For worms take pills thereof made with honey, and
dissolve it in vinegar, and apply it to the nauel. To make the teeth fall out,
anoint therewith and the juice of Henbane. 10 Milt griefs, apply it with
Assafetida dissolved in vinegar, and put thereto wax and powder of Cost and
of Wormwood, or only with Assafetida and wax. The perfume thereof is good for
the Litargie. 11 Make pills thereof with the juice of Wormwood and Arsmart,
and use them to kill worms in the belly. Roste the root of Monks Rubarbe,
and mix it with Amoniake, and anoint skrophules therewith, and also apply it
plasterwise.

Ache 6. 7 Belly bound 1 Brain griefs 2 Breast stopped 1. 2 Breath short 1 Cold
griefs 6 Dead child 5 Eyes dull 7 Face deformed 9 Falling evil 1 Giddiness
8 Gout 1. 5. 8 Hardness 5. 6 Headache 2 Kernels 11 Knots 5. 8 Lytargie 10
Liver griefs 4 Milt griefs 3. 10. hard. 8. 10 Sciatica 2. 7 Sinowes griefs 2
Skrophules 11 Swellings 5 Teeth to fall 9 Urine stopped 3 Wennes 5 Weariness 7
Worms 9. 11
Anemone.
ANemone, the root chewed, draws much moisture into the mouth. 2 The same
boiled in wine prepared called Passum, and laid upon the eyes, clears the
sight, and voydeth the webbs and spots. 3 The leaves and young branches boiled
with clean husked Barley, causes abundance of milk: the same put in as a
pessary provoke terms. 4 The juice of the root put into the nose purges
the brain, and skowreth away filthy sores and leapries.

Brain cleansing 1. 4 Eyes dull 1. 4 Flowers stopped 3 Headache see Brain
Leaprie 4 Milk to cause 3 Sores 4
Angelica.
ANgelica is good against all poison and venomous bitings, so that it is better
to have it and Magistrantia, Louage, Gentian, Elecampana, Aristolochia, and
Petasites, then al Arabike and foreign wares. 2 It is called the root of the
holy Ghost, and of all heal: it expels poison and rotten blood, and warmeth
the body. 3 Half a dram of the root, with one dram of Triacle drunk with
three or four spoonefull of the water thereof, and the body well covered to
sweat, and forbearing other things three hours after it, drives forth the
plague, and delivers the sick body, if no Treacle can be had, take a whole
dram of the powder of the root. 4 The root smelled unto being steeped in
vinegar, and a little of the vinegar drunk fasting now and then in the plague
time, preserves the body from the plague. 5 The water or powder of the root
delivers the body from torments coming of cold, the pluresie, ruptures,
griefs of the lunges, whereof come grievous coughes, the dropping of the
urine, the strangurye, the stopping of the flowers, swellings and windines, and
such like, and so does decoctions and potions made with the root thereof
sodden in wine or honey. 6 Put the water into hollow teeth for their ache, and
into the ears for their ache. 7 Put the juice or water into the eyes to clear
them and sharpen the sight, and to take away the webs and mystinesse: put the
juice, water, or powder into old and deep ulcers, to cover the bare bones
with flesh. 8 Apply the water to the gout, sciatica, or any ache or bruises,
to dissolve humors that are gathered together: mix the powder with pitch, and
apply it to all venomous bitings. 9 The seeds have the same virtues that the
roots have: the roots, seed or water, is excellent good against all inward
diseases: it scowreth the gatherings of the plurisie when it begins: it
helps corrupt lungs, it is good against the chollike and strangurie, it
provoke terms, it helps inflammations and swellings. 10 Drop the juice of
the root into the eyes to quicken the sight, and to cleanse them from all
filth, and put it into teeth that ache to avoid the ache. 11 The water or
powder is excellent good against rotten ulcers and kankerous sores to cleanse
and heal them: put a piece of gold into the juice of Limons 24. hours, and
drink it with a little wine and powder of the root of Angelica, to help the
plague though all hope were past. 12 The root taken fasting, or but holden in
the mouth, preserves the body from all infection of the plague or poison. 13
If any be infected, let them drink one dram of the powder straightwayes in
Winter with wine, and with water of Scabious, or of Carduus benedictus in
Summer, or with Rose water, and cover him well to sweat both for the plague
and poison. 14 The leaves stamped with Rue and Honey, are very good for the
bitings of mad dogs, serpents, and vipers, if shortly after the hurt taken, the
party drink of the wine wherein the leaves or root have been sodden. 15 For
the pestilence, any sudden pestilent ague, or too much sudden sweating, drink
half a dram of the powder of the root with one dram of Treacle, and iii. or
iiii. spoonefull of water of the root, and cover thee well to sweat iii.
hours. 16 It is good for all inward diseases, especially such as come of cold
cause, and for women in travel, it expels wind. 17 The root or seed may
be sodden in wine or water as the disease requires, and so it heals all
inward ulcers, bruses, and congealed blood, and strengthens the stomach. 18
The powder of the root is good against all swooning passions of the heart, it
is gathered in Autumn, and kept two or three years, it cleanses the lungs,
breast, guts, reins and bladder. 19 The herb sodden in water, heals all
inward wounds, strengthens the heart, and dries up all superfluous
moisture, as the dropsy and tympany. 20 It helps against vomiting and
weakness of the stomach, and being sodden with Rue, honey and wine, it
delivers from the bitings of serpents, snakes, etc. and also any prick or
wound. 21 It quenches all carnal rage of youthful lust, if one eat half a
dram of it: it has many other virtues, for the which few herbs are to be
compared unto it. 22 Toothache put in a piece of the root, breath stinking of
garlike chawe it, it may be used for like purposes as Carduus benedictus. 23
Powder of the leaf or root cleanses and heals rotten ulcers, kankers and
sores, and covers the bones with flesh, (See Blessed thistle.)

Swooning and all passions of the heart, drink two ounces of Angelica water,
with a little Cinamom water, and one scruple of powder of the root sundry
mornings.

Anniseedes.
ANniseedes dissolve windiness, belching, and blasting of the stomach and
belly, and helps their griping and torments, stops the laske, provoke
urine, and voydeth the stone, and the hycket or yexing, being taken dry or
with wine or water. 2 It cures the bloody-flixe, stops the whites, is good
for the dropsy, opens the pipes of the liver, stauncheth thirst, and is good
against all poison, and stingings of scorpions, and bitings of all venomous
beasts. 3 The seeds eaten plenteously provoke lust, and do breed milk. 4
Chewe the seeds to make the breath easy and sweet, dry the seeds and mix
them with honey, and use the same to cleanse the breast: mix them with honey
and bitter Almonds to cure the old cough. 5 Let children that be in danger of
the falling evil, use to hold the seeds in their hand, to avoid the peril
of that disease: mix the seeds with honey, vinegar and hysope, and gargle
therewith for the squyncy and swelling in the throat. 6 Bind the seeds in a
linen cloth, and smell to them to keep thee from evil dreams, starting in
sleep, and to cause quiet rest: smell to the perfume of it to cure the head
ache, put it into the ears with oil of Roses to cure their inward hurtes and
wounds. 7 Drink it with Ptisane, or clear temperate wine to open the
stopping of the reins and matrix, use it in Ptisands for the Fever quotidian
bredde of phlegm. 8 Drink it with good white wine and sugar for the chollike,
windiness of the guts, and to stop the whites. 9 Make powder thereof with
Fenell seeds, Galinggale, Spikenard, Tamarisk, Nutmegs and Cardamom, and mix
it with wheat flower water and red wine, and make cakes thereof, and bake them
and eat them daily for the running of the reins, wasting of nature, moist
dropsies coming of wind and cold, the tympany and swelling of the belly, and
be purged once a month with convenient Electuaries. 10 The same eaten or
drunk, are good for the sight, the lungs, reins, stomach and bladder. 11 Use
them in bread either broken or whole for the chollike and stone: mix powder of
Anniseedes and Cumminseedes with wax, and apply it to blackness that comes
of bruses. 12 Use to eat the seeds to heat the liver, and to help
digestion. Seethe them in wine, and drink it with Cinamom and Mastike against
grievous belchings of a cold stomach. 13 Sees them in water with Hearts
tongue, and drink it for the stopping of the liver and milte, for the dropsy
and the whites. Seethe powder of the seeds in a bag in wine, and apply it hot
to the matrix to cleanse it, and to bring down the terms. 14 Take the seeds
with Castorie for the swelling of the stomach and bowels: eat or drink the
seeds with vinegar and honey to help the strangling of the mother. 15 Seethe
them in wine, and drink it for the impostumes of the stomach, and the cough:
drink the powder of them with wine against poison, with oil of Roses it
helps the pain of the ears. 16 The fume thereof received into the nose
helps the head ache: the best of them come out of Candie, and are clean and
well smelling. 17 Anniseedes help the stoppings of the liver and milte, break
wind, cause urine and sweat, and loosen the belly. 18 Seethe one ounce with
three sticks of bruised Licoras, and two handful of Hony-suckle leaves in a
quart of water to a pint, and drink thereof fasting for phlegm and stopping of
the stomach. 19 Seethe a handful of the seeds in a quart of Malmesey with a
handful of unset Hysope, till it be thick, and spread it on a toste of bread
of Wheat with some butter, and apply it in a linen cloth to the stomach for
the cough, but for a stitch apply it without butter. 20 Drink powder of
Licoras and Anniseedes with possit ale made with Sack and Ale, for the
stuffing of the lungs every morning. Drink powder of Anniseedes and Cummin
seeds five days morning and evening with wine to help for the windiness and
chollike of the belly. 21 To purge the stomach, seethe Anniseeds and Polipody
ana three ounces in a quart of water to the one half, then streine it and
sugar it and drink it. 22 To avoid windiness, thirst, oppilation of the
liver and milte, to provoke lust, urine and terms, to clear the sight, and to
cleanse and comfort the stomach, use Anniseedes. 23 For the dropsy, fill an
old cock with Polipody and Anniseedes, and seethe him well, and drink the
broth, it helps also the chollike. 24 To increase milk, use powder of the
seeds: for windiness in the belly, drink powder of the seeds of Annise,
Fennel, and Cummin with wine first and last: for the hicket, or yexing, smell
to dried Anniseedes: 25 For the Emerods, burn the seeds and apply them with
honey: for the falling sickness, use Anniseedes and Rue in thy meats: mouth
stink, wash it with the decoction of Anniseedes: heart cardiake, mix ye juice
of Betony with Treacle, powder of Cloves, Cummin, and Annise ix days. 26
Vomiting of hot cause, eat Anniseedes fasting. Stomach slimie, and to help
digestion, in Winter eat Anniseedes upon tostes of bread dipped in wine. 27
Belly ache and chafing of the liver, and to help digestion, use Anniseedes any
way. Chollike and Nephretyke, drink powder of the seeds with the juice of
Perslie: for the dropsy, use much water in ye wine decocted with Anniseedes,
or drink powder of the seeds of Annise, Fennel, and Peony. Gout, stamp Sage
leaves with Anniseedes, and seethe them in wine, and apply it. 28 Pipes stopped,
seethe Anniseedes and Licoras in running water to the one half, then streine
it and drink it at even hot, and at morning cold. 29 A bag of Anniseede,
Salt, and Darnell, dries up rheum. 30 Stomach rising, seethe long Pepper,
Grains, Saffron, Ginger, Anniseedes and Licoras, with Sugar in good Ale till
it be thick, and drink thereof and be whole.

Apples.
APples: abhorring meat, make a syrup with the juice of sower Apples and of a
Pomegranate and Sugar and use it. Cut Apples thin as a penny, and seethe them
in a pan with Virgins wax, and eat it as hot as may be suffered to stop
the bloody flixe. 2 Mix Chalk with ye juice of Wildings or Crabs, and apply
it to take away any pain of burnings, and bledders, or blisters. 3 Roast
Frankincense in a red Apple, and apply it to the tooth ache. For horcenesse
roast a great Apple, and slice it hot into a dish of water, and eat it to
bedward, and cover thee well to sweat. 4 Stomach hot griefs, use confections
of Apples with sugar. Pare Apples and slice them and fry them with virgins
wax, and eat it hot to cure the flux diaria. 5 Cough, eat roasted Apples
with vinegar and Suger-candie. Worms, roast one penny weight of Aloes cicat. in
an Apple, and eat it three mornings. 6 Ears worm, make a ripe well smelling
Apple hollow, and apply it to the ear, and the worm will come into it.
Fluxes, apply plasters of sower Apples to the reins and navel. Fevers
continual, use bitter sweetes. 7 Bloody-fluxe, roast as much wax as a bean in
an Apple, and eat it. Seethe Apples to pap, and to vi. li. of it, put iiii.
li. of honey, and seethe to perfection and use it. 8 Eyes heat and running, cut
off the paring thick and apply the inside to bedward to help it speedely.
Cough, roast Butter, English Saffron, and as much Sugar-candie as a Nutmeg in a
great Apple, and eat such a one morning and evening. 9 Eyes to comfort,
distill a pecke of rotten Apples, and use the water. Roast iii. or iiii. grains
of Olibanum in a well smelling Apple on the embers, and eat it to break the
impostume of the plurisie, or any other with speed. 10 Seethe the inward
yellowe bark with wood, bone, or horn with Alome to color it yellowe. Face
and nose-red, distill the bloomes in Balnio Mariae, and wash with the water
morning and evening daily. Distill it when it is full blown. 11 To ripen an
apostume, roast an Apple in the embers, and mix it with butter and honey, or the
yolke of an egg sodden, and apply it. 12 For griefs of the breast and breast
bone, take out the core of a ripe Apple, and fill it with powder of Licoras,
and Galingale, or Cinamom and Honey, all well mixed together, and roast it and
pill it and eat it as often as need is. For the chincough and other like, and
for pain in the breast, roast sallet oil in a great Apple in the embers, and
apply it flat on the breast as often as need is. Liver hot, seethe the juice
of Apples both sower and sweet, with almost twice so much sugar into a syrup,
and take a little of it fasting daily with lukewarm water. 13 Apples do cool
and comfort the stomach, especially such as are sowrish, and astringent of
taste. 14 And they may be used in hot Agues, and other heates of the stomach
against thirst, but otherwise hurtful to the stomach, causing windiness and
blastings in the belly. 15 Sower Apples boiled and eaten cold after meat,
loosen the belly gently. Apples eaten before meat, do nourish very little,
because they be watrish. 16 The leaves are good to be applied to hot tumors
and apostumations in the beginning, and to wounds to keep them from evil
heat and swelling. The leaves, flowers, and buds of every Appletree, but
especially of the Quincetree, do stop and bind. 17 The tart and sower Apples
do bind, but the ripe Apples are of a contrary. They that are taken at the
spring engender choler, hurt all the synowes, and breed inflammations and hot
burnings. 18 All Apples hurt the synowes, the unripe are very noisome, if a man
eat, so that he fill himself with Apples, they engender the stone. 19 But
they are good for them that swoone, and have a weak heart. The pap of an Apple
with Rose water applied to the eyes, does quench their burning, and takes
away their redness. 20 Apples be good in winter, and provoke urine: eat them
with a little salt. 21 Tarts of Apples with Anniseedes, make a sweet breath: a
cold roasted Apple eaten to bedward, looseneth the belly. Eat Apples with
Comfects, Biskets or Carwayes after meat. 21 To keep Apples long, lay them in
honey, so that they touch not one another. Put frozen Apples into cold water,
and they will come to their own nature again.

Apostume 11 Belly bound 15. 17. 21. loose 17 Byles 11 Blisters 2 Bones to
color 10 Bloody-fluxe 27 Breast griefs 11. 12. Breath stink 21 Burnings 2
Chincough 12 Cough 5. 8. 9. 12 Ears worms 6 Eyes griefs 8 heat 8. 20
running 8 red 20 Face red 10 Fevers 7. 14 Fluxes 4. 6 Heart griefs 19 Hot
griefs 14. 16 Horcenesse 3 Impostume 9 Liver hot 12 Lothing 1 Nose red 10
Plurisie 9 Stomach hot 4. 13 weak 1 Swellings hot 15 Swooning 19 Tart 7. 21
Teeth-ache 3 Thirst 14 Voice lost 3 Vein stopped 20 Wood to color 10 Worms 5
Wounds 16
Arache.
ARache used in pottage, opens the belly. Take the seed with honied water to
open and comfort the stopping of the liver and the Iaundies. Apply the bruised
leaves to inflammations and hot swellings at the beginning, namely that Arache
of the Garden, and the wild Arache at the going away of the same swellings. 2
Apply it with honey, vinegar, and salt Peter, to the wild fire, and to the
gout: but the much use of Arache brings many infirmities. Stamp it with
honey and apply it to the gout. 3 Apply the juice to the holy fire, and other
inflammations to cease and qualify them. 4 Apply the herb to the privy
places of women to amend the evils within, and to cease the pain forthwith.
Use the herb in pottage to loosen the belly, and to cool it and assuage
diverse swellings. 5 Stamp the herb and apply it to draw out splent, prick,
or nail, and to heal the wound. Boil it with honey, and apply it to rough
nails, to loosen them without pain. 6 Seethe the seeds, and drink the broth
for shortness of breath, to expel worms, and to cause vomit. Eat the
herb for the heat of the liver. 7 Make pottage of Mercury and Arache, and
eat them often for costynesse and pinching pain of the bladder. Use pottage
of Beetes, Arache and Mercury, to be delivered of the Ague in short time. The
seeds purge the body both ways. 8 Stamp the leaves, and apply them to
kernels and freckles. Apply plasters thereof to curded milk in the breasts,
being sodden in water, and drink yt juice of Arache with thy brothe. 9 To
cause an easy vomit, and to cleanse the stomach, seethe the seeds in water
without salt, and put thereto a little oil of nuts, and eat some course
meat, and fill thy stomach, and then take the medicine, and labor a little.
The seeds stamped, sodden and drunk, takes away the Fever quartaine. The
seeds drunk with honied water, heals the Kings evil.

Belly bound 1. 4. 7 Bladder griefs 7 Breasts sore 8 Breath short 6 Fevers 7
quartaine 9 Frecles 8 Gout 2. 3 Holy fire 3 Iaundies 1 Inflammation 1. 3
Kernels 8 Kings evil 9 Liver hot 6 stopped 1 Matrix and griefs 4 Nails rough
5 Pricks 5 Purgation 7 Swellings hot 1. 4 Vomit to cause 6. 7. 9 Wilde-fire
2. 3 Worms 6 Wounds 5
Aron, or wake Robin.
ARon, or wake Robin, the virtue is in the seed, root, and leaves. Applied
with the dung of Oxen or Kine, it helps the gout in the feet. The whole
herb is good to cleanse the breast. The root is gathered and laid up as the
roots of Dragons and Sowbread. 4 The juice in a pessary provoke the terms.
For the inflammation of the ears, boil the knots and leaves in wine with
common oil, and put Cummin seed to it, and apply it plaster wise. 8 For the
Emerods and Fig in the fundament, boil it with Mulline in wine or water, and
use it. 12 For old apostumes, stamp the herb with old Swines grease, and
apply it hot. For the scrophules, stamp ye herb with Squilla, and old
Bores grease, and apply it. 16 To cleanse the face and skin, make fine powder
of the knots of it, and mix it with Rose water, and dry it in the Sun, and
do so four or five times, and then wash with the same powder and Rose water.
Powder of the seeds mixed with oil, and dropped into the ear helps the
soreness thereof. 20 The juice heals the polip in the nose. And mixed with
clean honey, it cleanses the darkness of the eyes, and sodden with oil and
applied hot, it cures the Emerods. 24 The root, especially of that kind
that has ye spotted leaves, either dry or green taken one dram at the
least, is a most present remedy against all poison and the plague: some put
thereto as much Treacle. A spoonefull or more of the juice of the herb
drunk, has the same properties. Put a little vinegar, and it will not blister
the tongue. 28 The like is to be understood of the root. 32 Take one dram
of the powder, with two drammes of sugar for the hickit or yexing, to cut
gross humors, to cleanse the lungs, to help the cough, to purge the stomach
of phlegm and melancholy. 36 The root either green or dry stamped and
taken, does mightily purge women after their childbirth. It does the like unto
cattle. 40 The juice or the distilled water has the like effect, which also
helps the swelling of ye cods, being drunk two or three ounces at once with
a little vinegar. There is no better medicine against the plague sore and
Carbuncles, then the fresh leaves stamped and applied. 44 And the same either
green or dry, does help old and rotten sores of the feet. The water and
juice purges and heals all manner of sores. The leaves and roots sodden in
wine or oil, and used in insessions, heals the Figs of the fundiment, and
the falling down of the same. 48 Some women put the leaves among their Cheese
to kill the worms thereof, and to keep it from corruption, and to make it
last long. 52 Stamp half a pound of the sodden or roasted roots, and seethe
them with i. li. and a half of honey, and use it to help them that can not
draw their breath. 56 Dangerous coughes, catharres, and reumes, griefs of the
breast, and crampes: for it ripeth and consumes all gross humors, and
scowreth all the inner parts. Sees it with Rose leaves, oil, and wine, and
Cummin, and apply it to heal the swellings of the tongue and ears. 60 Skin to
cleanse, stamp the root, and anoint therewith. Kirnels, or Kings evil,
stamp it with Bores grease, and apply it.

Archangel.
ARchangel: Emerods, cast Brimstone upon hot coals, and lay blind Nettles
thereon, and sit over the fume thereof, and do so thrice, and be whole. 2 To
heal a fistula, sees it in Wine or ale, and use the decoction, and apply the
herb. Drink the root thereof with wine and pepper, to cure the ache of the
reins. To stop the whites, sees red Archangel in drink, and drink it
morning and evening. The white is for a man. 3 Wits lost, cut the hair from
the molde of the head, and apply it, and sleep and be whole. 4 Bruise Archangel
white and red with salt, and apply it to hard wennes, botches, and apostumes.
In virtue it is much like the other nettles. The leaves of white Archangel
stamped with salt, heals bruisings, burnings, wennes, swellings, goutes and
wounds, sores and fistulaes. 5 The white flowers stamped and applied, helps
the shingles. The root stamped with salt, draws forth thorns and pricks. 6
The herb stamped with salt, helps the swelling of the throat, and the biting
of a dog, (See Nettle. Dead Nettle.)

Apostumes 4 Backe-ach 2 Botches 4 Burnings 4 Bitings 6 Bruises 4 Emerods 1
Fistula 2. 4 Mad dog 3. 6 Pricks 5 Shingles 5 Sleep 3 Sores 4 Swellings 4. 6
Venom 6 Wennes 4 Whites 2 Wits lost 3 Wounds 4
Arsemart, or Cyderach.
ARsmart, or Cyderach, stamp the green herb, and apply it to green or fresh
wounds to cool and comfort them, and to keep them from impostumation and
inflammation. The juice dropped in does the like. 2 Ears deaf, put in the
clear juice. Ears worms, drop in the juice with as much vinegar warm. 3
Liver stopped, drink two drams of Arsmart with a little vinegar. Flowers stopped,
stamp it with wine, and apply it to the matrixe: Worms to kill, stamp it
with Rue and Wormemood, and fry them with butter, or grease, and apply them to
the stomach. 4 Ears worms, put in the juice. Worms to kill, use the juice.
5 Woman's belly great, not being with child, sees Arsmart, Rue and Hysope, ana
one handful in a quart of Ale to the one half, and drink thereof first and
last. 6 Gout, mix the distilled water with the gall of an Ox, and a little
oil of Spike, and anoint therewith blood warm, and apply a blewe woollen cloth
on it. 7 Apply a handful of Arsmart weeted in water to a wound or sore, and
after bury it in a moist ground, and as it rotteth, the sore will heal
miraculously. 6 Anoint an ach with a spoonefull of Aqua vitae, and two spoones
full of the distilled water morning and evening, five or six days, to heal
it for ever.

Ach 8 Apostume 2 Belly great 5 Ears deaf 2 worms 2. 4 Flowers stopped 3 Gout
6. 8 Inflammation 2 Liver stopped 3 Sores 7 Women 5 Worms 3 Wounds 1. 7
Artichoke.
ARtichokes eaten raw, do amend the savor of the mouth. And the heads sodden
tender and boiled after with vinegar and butter, and seasoned with salt, are
greatly commended. Some eat them raw with Pepper and salt, and fine powder of
Coliander seed cast upon them. 2 Steeped, or rather sodden in wine and eaten,
they provoke urine. 3 Sodden in water and eaten, they strengthen the stomach.
4 Boil them with flesh broth, and serve them with a sawse of butter, or oil,
or salt and vinegar. 5 Boil the root after the pith is taken out in wine and
drink it, to avoid rank smell of the arm pits. 6 Steep the young shells or
nuts in strong wine and eat them, to provoke urine. Boil the root, the pith
taken out in water, and drink it to strengthen the stomach, and to confirm
the place of conception, and to make it apt to conceive men children. 7 The
first springs or tender impes sodden in good broth with butter, stays the
voluntary course of the natural seed both in man and woman. 8 It delights
to grow in earth mingled with ashes. 9 The root makes urine sweet, and
cleanses out melancholy and phlegm which abounds. 10 The root sodden in wine
to the third part and drunk after the bath, or after supper or dinner,
cleanses the urine abundantly, and purges the reins and bladder, and so
heals the stinking of the whole body. 11 To cause urine, and to help the
Gomer passion, seethe Artichokes in wine and drink it. 12 Make holes in Bays
and put in the seeds, and wrap them in doung and set them in the ground and
they will be passing well smelling and pleasant, or steep the seeds three
days.

Appetite 3. 6 Back griefs 10 Bladder griefs 10 Breath stink 1 Conception
6. 7 Gomer passion 11 Lust to cause 2. 3. 6. 7 Matrix griefs 6 Reins running
11 Stinking sweat 5. 9. 10 Stomach bad 3. 6 Urine stink 9. 10. stopped 2. 6. 9.

Ash.
ASh: milt pain, seethe the rynd in wine, and drink it fasting, six or seven
days, and anoint the place with Dealthea. 2 Ears deaf, mix the sap of
green Ash burned, Aqua vitae, and the juice of Houslecke ana one spoonefull,
with a spoonefull of the grease of an Eele that is red beneath the nauill, and
put thereof with tents into the ear. 3 Plague: distill three ounces of the sap,
with as much white wine, and drink every three hours, and at the end of
xxiiii. hours thou shall be cured. 4 Bitings or stingings of Serpents, stamp
the leaves and apply them, or drink the juice. Vomit to stop, seethe the
tender leaves in strong vinegar, then stamp them and apply them to the stomach
or belly. For wheales and blisters in the face, stamp the fresh leaves in the
midst of the spring, let them stand to mollify five days, then distill them in
Balneo Mariae, and wash therewith three weeks and be whole. 5 For the Megrim
and Toothach, mix ashes of the bark with spettle and apply it: Wind in the
guts: drink the red seed with wine. 6 Ears pain, put in the sap of burned
Ash. 7 And with the grease of an Eele, and oil of Bitter Almonds for
deafness. 8 Stomach griefs general, drink powder of the seeds of Ash,
Flax, and Cummin of each like much with hot water or hot wort. 9 Milt
griefs, seethe a bough in wine or water, and use it. 10 Green sickness,
seethe powder of the Keys with Betonie, red Sage, red Mynts, and Magerom in
running water from a pottell to a quart, and drink thereof a good draught with
Sugar warm morning and evening. 11 Blood to stop, smell to Moss that grows
at the root of an Ash tree. 12 Fever Quarten, seethe the middle bark of an
Ash with Centory, Rue, and Wormwood in water or wine a long time, then streine
it and drink it with clarified honey. 13 Milte griefs, take fair Barowes
grease and ashes of Ash, of each two pound, sees them in a gallon of running
water to the one half, then streine it, and let it stand all night, then
fleet off the grease, and streine it often, and keep it in boxes, and anoint
therewith, and seethe a good quantity of the roots of young Ash plants with as
much Wormwood in a gallon of wine, to the one half, and drink thereof at
evening hot, and at morning cold. 14 Ears sounding, bore a hole in the midst
of an Ash in May, and put a reed in it, and let it stand four or five days,
and gather the water, and receive up the fume, and also dip tents therein, and
put them into the ear: Milt hard seethe the bark in wine and drink it. 15
Matrix grinding, seethe Asshen ashes in water, and dip a cloth therein, and
apply it all over ye belly. A precious water for sores: mix fine ashes of
green Ash with fair water, and stir them often daily, and to the clearest
of it put a little vinegar and Alum, and seethe it and keep it to wash sores
withal. 16 Emerods to stop, use powder of Akorns, Ash keys, and a little Bole
Armoneak in warm broth or drink, or rere eggs. 17 To break a byle or sore
within one hour and without pain, put ashes of the inner bark of green Ash
into a clout like a nut, and moysten it in hot water, and bind it to the
place: proved. 18 Black Iaundies, drink the sap with a good draught of Ale
and some Saffron two hours before meat, and there will rise shortly blisters
all over the body, and when they are ready prick them and let the humor come
out. 19 Liver and milte griefs, stamp the inner bark of green Ash, and strein
it with white wine, and seethe it till the third part be wasted, and drink it
with Sugar Candy. 20 Ears ach and dull put in the sap. 21 Teethach and hollow,
put in Triacle, and then put in a stick of Ash burned at the end hot burning.
22 Worms, seethe the rynde of a Pomegranate, and Ash roots in wine and drink
it, the same helps the Tenasmus. 23 Milte griefs, seethe the rynd in Wine
and drink it. 24 Burnings, boil thick Cream, and the Mossie bark of an
Ash, till it come to an oil, and so keep it for that use. For the swelling of
the stomach and to cause appetite, stamp the roots of Ash and of Fennel of
each like much, and drink it with wine. 25 For the stone, drink powder of the
bark of a young Ash that bears keys in winter and summer, and use it also in
brothes. Ears deaf, put in the sap of green Ash with honey. 26 Seethe the
rynde in wine, and drink it for the torments of the milt: no Serpent will come
near the Ash tree, nor the shadow of it. 27 Ears dull and for worms in them,
put in the sap with honey three hours, then turn it down and do so often. 28
For Festers, Mermoles, sores of the yard, and all other sores, take Ash that
bears no keys for a man, but for a woman that which bears keys, burn the
bows to ashes, and with clear well water make strong lee therewith, and put
thereto a third part of strong vinegar, and anoint the sore therewith
whatsoever it be, and lay Diaculum above it, it heals all sores. 29 The bark
sodden in wine is good for all griefs of the milt. 30 The leaves and bark
boiled in wine and drunk, do open and comfort the liver and milt, and heals
the diseases of the sides, and so will they do, being boiled in oil and laid
to. 31 The leaves and bark with the tender crops taken in the same manner, are
good for the dropsey, for they purge the water: It is good for fat and gross
folks, to drink three or four leaves with wine daily to make them lean. 32
The juice of the leaves, crops, and bark drunk in wine, preserves from all
venom and venomous bitings. 33 Lee made with the ashes of the bark, cures the
white scurfe and such like roughness of the skin. 34 The seed provoke
urine, increases natural seed, and moves Venus, especially being taken with
a Nutmeg. 35 The leaves of the wild Ashtree boiled in wine and drunk, are
good against the pain of the side and the stopping of the liver, and slake
their bellies that have the dropsy. 36 Distill the bark of Ash and drink the
water for the Iaundes and the stone. If a man or beast be bitten of any
venomous beast, let them drink the juice of Ash tops with good wine if they
have no Fever, or else with wine delayed with water and stamp the young sprigs
and apply them to the biting: the same drink is good for the dropsy. 37 Milt
swollen, drink daily in a cup of Ash. 38 To become lean, drink the juice of
Ash leaves now and then with wine. 39 Leapry, anoint with ashes of the bark
mixed with water.
