Bombase.
BOmbase or Cotton: the seed swageth the cough, and is good against all cold
diseases of the breast, it augmenteth natural strength, and increases seed
of generation. 2 The juice of the leaves is good for the laske of young
children, and for the gnawing and grinding in the belly. 3 The oil of the
seed takes away freckles and spots of the face.

Belly ache 2 Breast griefs 1 Cold griefs 1 Cough 1 Face deformed 3 Freckles
3 Flixe 2 Seed to increase, strength to increase 1
Borage.
Use it in wine to cause gladness and mirth to expel sadness and melancholy.
2 Boil it with honyed water for the roughnes and hoarsnes of the throat. 3
Take that which has three branches with the root with drink for the Tertian
Fever, and that with four branches for the Quarten Fever. 4 Boil it in wine
to engender good blood. 5 Drink the juice with Sugar for the pain and giddines
of the head. 6 Use the syrup of the juice thereof with Sugar and the bone of a
Hearts heart for the panting, trembling, and beating of the heart. 7 Mix the
juice of the herb with Seen, and the syrup of Borage, and drink it morning and
evening to increase the senses, and to put away melancholy. 8 Eat the raw
flowers, or drink them with wine to cause good blood, and avoid the trembling
of the heart. 9 Use the syrup for the Kings evil. The dried flowers for one
year, serve for all purposes that the herb is for. 10 Steep the flowers in
oil, and sun it certain days, and anoint the region of the stomach and
heart therewith to comfort them. 11 Distill the water in Balneo Mariae, and
drink two or three ounces morning and evening of the water, for the griping and
swelling of the belly, and for the bloody flux, and the hardness of fetching
wind, to comfort the heart and brain, to increase the memory and wit, to purge
the blood, and to avoid the frenzy. 12 Apply the water with a linen cloth to
the venom of a spider or waspe, to take away the pain thereof. 13 Dip a red
cloth in the water and apply it to the eyes, to avoid their pain, and to
clear them. 14 The water of the flowers purges the blood and serves for all
the things that the herb is for, and much better. 15 Being drunk morning and
evening two ounces thereof, it helps all distillations of the head, burning
Agues, the Iaundes, and cools the liver, being applied with linen clothes to
ye region of the liver. 16 Burn Borage, and mix the ashes with with honyed,
and use it for the ulcers and blisters of the mouth, gums, tongue and throat,
etc. (See in Buglosse.) 17 Apoplexia, use Borage water. 18 Drink two ounces of
the juice to drive out a dead child. 19 Fever quarten, seethe Borage, Sorell,
Violets, and Mercury ana, four handfuls in fair running water, from a gallon
to a pottell, then streine it, and when it is cold, drink thereof in thy most
heat to cool thy thirst. 20 Seconds to cause, use the juice of Borage. 21
Heart stitch, of blood heat, or bruise, drink the water of Borage, and make
pottage with water, Borage and butter, and eat them morning and evening warm.
22 Heart griefs, use Borage flowers, leaves, or roots any ways: use the
flowers in brothes to refresh the body. 23 Breath stopped, seethe Borage,
Mallows and Mercury with a piece of pork, and make pottage therewith and use
them, or seethe them in wine or whey, and use them to drink. The flowers be
restoratiue. 24 Morphue, drink water of Borage and Fumeterre, of each like much
xiiii. days, and mix thine own urine with black soap and anoint often
therewith. Use it in medicines for the dropsy. 25 Bloody flux, drink three
ounces of the water fasting. Costiuenesse use it and Mercury in pottage.

Appoplexia 17 Belly bound 25 Blood clensing 4. 8. 11. 14 Bloody flixe 11. 25
Brain weak 11 Breast griefs 11 Breath strait 11. 23 Bruised 21 Consumption

Box.
Box, the lee wherein the leaves have been sodden or steeped makes the hair
yelowe being often washed therewith. It is not used in medicine. 2 Biting of a
mad dog, stamp the seed with a little Holy water, and drink it and lie down.

Hair to be yelowe 1 Mad dogs biting 2
Brake. (See Fearne.)

Bramble breer.
BRamble breer, or Blackberry: the new springs thereof do cure the hot and
evil ulcers of the mouth and throat and the swelling of the gums vuula and
almonds of the throat being often chewed. 2 Wash the mouth often with the juice
or decoction thereof to fasten the teeth. 3 The unripe fruit is good for the
same purpose. 4 The juice or decoction drunk, stops the laske, the terms,
and other issues of blood. 8 The leaves stamped and applied to the stomak,
helps the trembling of the heart, and losenesse and ache of the stomach. 6
They cure the emerods and stay back running and consuming sores being laid to.
7 The unripe fruit stops the belly, the bloody flux, and all other issues
of blood. 8 The juice of them boiled with honey, is very good against all hot
ulcers and swellings in the mouth, tongue, and throat. 9 The root is good
against the stone, and to provoke urine. 10 The leaves chewed heal the
diseases of the mouth. 11 They heal running sores of the head, and are a good
remedy for the eyes that fall down. 12 The leaves are good to be laid upon
hard swellings of the fundament, and the emerods, and ache of the stomach. 13
The juice pressed out of the leaves and branches, and dried in the Sun to a
hard lump, is good for all the diseases aforesaid. 14 The juice of the ripe
Beries is good for all the diseases of the mouth. 15 The unripe Beries stop the
belly, and so do the flowers drunk with wine. 16 The Bark of the root
breaks the stone. 17 The fruit dried before they be ripe, stop the laske and
losenesse of the belly. 18 Make balls of the unripe fruit dried with vinegar,
and dry them in the Sun, and put thereof into hot wine and it will be
vinegar. The like may be done with Mulberies, Quickenberries, green Grapes or
wild Acorus. 19 Eyes griefs, apply the juice of it with the white of an egg
and flax. 20 To draw out an apostume, stamp the leaves with Elderne leaves
ana one handful with white Mustardseede, and apply it. 21 Gout to soften,
stamp Rue, Red Breer crops, and Broom flowers ana, like much, with Gilts
grease, and boil them well together, and streine it, and anoint therewith. 22
Leapry, use the juice of the Berries, with syrup of wild Sage every morning
half an ounce.

Apostume 20 Belly lose 15. 17 Bloody flux 4. 7 Eyes griefs 19. falling 11.
Emerods 6. 12 Fluxes 7. 4 Flowers to stop 4. 7. 15 Fundament lump 12. 13 Gums
griefs 1. 8. 9. 14 Gout 21 Heart trembling 5 Head sores 11. 13 Leapry 22 Mouth
griefs 1. 8. 9. 14 Sores 6 Stomach grief 5 Stone 9. 16 Teeth loose 2. 3
Throat greefes 1. 8. 9 Vinegar 18 Urine stopped 9 Vuula 1
Bread.
BRead, plurisie mix leuened bread, butter, the decoction of Holyoke, and oil
de Bay together, and eat thereof, and also apply it before and behind. 2
Bruses and pustules of the legs, mix the pith of leuened bread with wine and
honey, and boil them together and put tallow to it, and apply it. 3 Ache,
bruise, or swelling, mix crooms of sour bread with vinegar, and Rose leaves,
and apply it to heal it. 4 Squincy, eat bread with honey, and apply plasters
thereof hot. Crampe, steep bread in vinegar as it comes hot from the oven,
and apply it hot: proved. 5 Breath stinking, toste it well and steep it in
vinegar, and eat it. 6 Megrim, toste the nether crust of a brown loaf, and
soke it in vinegar till it be soft, then heat it again, and apply it to the
temples as hot as may be suffered. 7 Stomach weak, stamp ye crooms with
Wormwood and vinegar, and apply it. 8 Stomach hot, boil clean water, and
steep therein shiuers of brown bread, till it be almost cold, and drink
thereof often iii. or iiii. days. 9 Eyes sore and bloodshot, lay a toste of
leauened bread in red wine that is not mingled half an hour, then lay it in a
fine linen cloth and apply to either eye one. 10 Felon, seethe vinegar with
the croomes of hot wheaten bread and honey, till it be thick, and apply
plasters thereof. 11 Ache in the head, arms, stomach, or else where. 12 Temper
stale brown bread with vinegar, and a little Cinamome, and Aniseedes, and
apply it with iii. or iiii. fold of linen between the skin and it to find
speedy ease. 13 Megrime, boil gray bread, and powder of Cummin in vinegar,
and when it is thick, apply thereof. 14 Plague, weete sour bread in vinegar,
and bind it to the temples, and drink water of Tormentill. 15 Stomach weak,
bake a loaf of wheat meal as it comes from the mill in the midst of the
batch, and of the cromes thereof make three spoonefull of myes, and mix it
with white vinegar, that it may be standing thick, and eat thereof with
Ginger, when thou go to bed, and drink not after it. 15 Ears worms, apply
well savoring bread as it comes hot from the oven. 16 Swelling of blood
letting, stamp white Bread crooms with wine, and apply it. 17 Wounds to heal,
apply white Bread crooms stamped with water, and the white of an Egg. 18 Head
swimming, apply the pith of Bread baked with Coliander seed. 19 Ears deaf,
bake a round lofe full of Sage, and break it in the midst, and apply it hot
to the ears iii. or iiii. times. 20 Eyes heat and swelling, seethe white
Bread and Sothernewood, and bathe therewith. 21 Squincy, put hot Bread into
honey, and apply it hot, and gargle with ye juice of Planten. 22 Stitch, toste
a piece of white leauened Bread, and spread Treacle on it, and apply it hot
with a fine linen cloth. 23 For the plurisie, and for such as are used to be
letten blood, to save them from being letten blood, and to dissolve all ill
blood. Cut fine shiuers of Rye Bread, and dry them in the wind, and when
need is, steep them four hours in strong vinegar, then seethe it and make a
plaster of it, and apply it as hot as may be suffered, it helps also the
pain of the liver and milte. 24 For all bone ache, boil a pint of white wine
with an Ox gall and scom it, and put thereto crooms of white bread, and apply
it iiii. or v. times. 25 Biting of a mad dog, apply Sauery with Bread. 26
Sinowes ache, weete Bread in milk, and apply it hot. 27 Gout in the bone,
dip hot tostes of Bread in the juice of Garlike, and apply it hot being well
stamped. 28 Chollike passion, seethe cromes of wheat Bread and powder of
Cummin in white vinegar, and apply it hot. 29 Stone to break, bake a Rye
cake, and slit it through the midst, and spread thereon Onions roasted very
tender, and apply the one to the back, and the other to the bottom of the
belly. 30 A plaster of sour bread boiled in wine, draws sores passing well
being laid to all night.

Ache 3. 11. 24. 26. 27. Apostume 30 Bitings venom. 25 Bones ache 24 Breath
stink 5 Bruses 2. 3 Chollike 28 Crampe 4 Ears deaf 19 worms 15 Eyes griefs
9. 20 Felon 10 Gout 26 Headache 11. megrim 13 swimming 18 Legs pustules 2 Mad
dog 25 Plague 14 Plurisie 1. 23 Pustules 2 Senowes ache 26 Side griefs 1. 22.
23 Squincy 4. 21 Stitch 1. 22. 23 Stomach hot 8 weak 7. 15 Stone 29 Swellings
3. 16 Wounds 17
Bentbrow, stamp it with ^ong marigolds that never flowred and streine it, and
an^^^^ with the juice with a crows feather all fleshmoles, and such like
marks.

Branne, flowers stopped, seethe it in wine or ale, and drink it, (See Wheat,
Rye, Barley, Otes.)

Brasel, make milkered with the powder of it, and steep therein Wode or Bone,
and in viii. days it will be red.

Branke-vrsine, apost. to break, seethe it with Lilly roots in wine, and
apply it with oil. Plurisie, sees it with mallows in oil of violets, and
apply it often. It causes sweat. (See Cow-parsnip.)

Broom.
Broom, the seed or flower drunk with Mulsa, purges by vomit, and also
downwards from the joints, cleanses the reins from all superfluities,
provoke urine strongly, breaks the stone in the reins and bladder, and
suffers no matter to be fixed there to a stone. 2 The flowers stamped with
honey of Roses, or with an Egrere roasted, resolves scrophules. Oximel thereof,
or of the seed, dissolueth apostumes of the milte, 3 Vomit with the seeds
often to help the gout, sciatica, and pain in the reins, use suppositers of
the powder thereof with the juice of Planten to stop the bloody flux, and
pessaries, to stop the terms or foment with water of the decoction thereof. 4
Teeth to cleanse, mix ashes of Broom branches with an eight part of powder
of burnt Alome, and temper them with water, and rub thy teeth therewith. Teeth
stinking and foul, mix the said ashes with as much burnt alom, and rub them
therewith. 5 Swelling of ye dropsy stamp young Broom, and streine it with
stale ale, and drink it first and last five days: proved. 6 Make lee of
ashes of green Broom, and red wine, and when it is clear, drink it first
and last, and the humors of the dropsy will burst out at the fingers and toes,
and the dropsy cured. 7 Gout, seethe the flowers with honey and apply it, or
make an ointment of the flowers of Capons grease, or dogs grease, and use it.
Or boil the juice of the flowers with as much honey, to the thickenesse of
honey, or an ointment, and use it for the gout: proved. 8 Sciatica, stamp the
flowers with honey, and apply it. Or use the roots steeped in vinegar and
streyned, or the branches of green Broom steeped and streyned. 9 Chollike,
drink powder of the seeds. 10 Stone and chollike, to be made in May, stamp
the buds of the flowers, and mix them with clarified May butter, and keep it
in a close vessel eight days, then seethe it and streyne it, and anoint
therewith morning and evening. 11 Dogs maungy, seethe Broom tops in bouke lee
half a day, and wash therewith, then mix black soap with bay salt,
brimstone, and fresh grease, and dress him therewith. 12 Ache in arms or
legs, stamp the flowers of Broom and Woodoose with May butter in a stone
mortar, and make them into round balls, and lay them in an earthen pot 24.
hours, then boil it well, and streyne it into an earthen vessel and none
other, and anoint therewith against the fire, till it be dried in, and then
apply a warm cloth. 13 Plurisie, drink the water of Broom flowers, and of
Roses, and anoint the grief with oil of both the same flowers. Kings evil,
to avoid the kernels of it, drink two ounces of the water of the flowers
fasting, to purge the humors downwards, and to waste and heal them without
breaking, and make an ointment of the red docke stamped with grease, and use
it. 14 Teeth black, burn green Broom, and mix the ashes with a fourth
part of burnt Alome, and rub therewith. 15 Gout to soften, stamp Rue, red
Bryer crops, and Broom flowers, of each like much, with gylts grease, and
boil them well together and streine it, and anoint therewith. 16 Put Broom
roots into a vessel of wine, beer, or ale, and drink it to keep thee
clear from all poisons. The flowers knit bones and synowes. Seethe the flowers
in the milk of a cow of one color, till it be thick, and apply it to the
legs to heal the dropsy. 17 Vnguentum Genistae, take Broom flowers, Puliol
montan, and mallows ana like much, stamp them with May butter, and set it in
a close earthen pot in hot horsedoung 20. days, then fry it and streyne it.
It is good for the gout, boneshawes and all aches, being applied cold. 18
Water of Broom cleanses the mother, liver, and milte, and helps the maras.
Powder of the rynde stops blood. 19 To kill lice, mix the juice with oil
of Raddish, or of Senuie, and anoint. 20 Gout, seethe the juice of Broom
flowers, and Scalaceli, and honey, ana like much to the thickenesse of honey, and
anoint. 21 Dropsy, seethe two gallons of fine Ale, with two good handful of
green Broom to the one half, and drink thereof fasting daily, and use no
other drink. 22 For the boneshawe and gout, seethe the flowers with wine and
oil olive, and apply it. 23 Sores of all sorts, mix good store of the
flowers with Valerian and Smallage, with May butter, and make them into balls
as much as Eggs, and lay them on shelfes to moulde throughout, then fry them
and streine them, and keep it in an earthen pot, and use it. 24 Aches, shreade
Broom flowers, Balm, and Feuerfue ana one handful, and seethe them in a
little May butter and keep it, and anoint therewith against the fire. 25 Mouth
set awrye by sickness, drink as much of the seed as thou can take up with
thy three fingers with water. 26 The water of the flowers drunk, breaks the
stone, and so does one scruple of the seed, and causes sweat. Broom stamped
with swynes grease, helps ye ache of the knees. 27 The leaves or crops, or
branches boiled in water or wine and drunk, are good for the dropsy, stopping
of the liver, milte, kidneis and bladder: for partly it purges out by the
belly, and partly by the urine, all watrie, tough, and superfluous humors: so
does the seeds taken one dram, or one dram and a half. 28 The seed is good
in all medicines to provoke urine, and break the stone. 29 The flowers with
swines grease swageth the pain of the gout. Our English broom may be used to
all effects, as Spanish Broom. Broom seeds taken one dram, or one dram and a
half with mede or wheye, purges humors from the joints both upward and
downward, and suffers no tough humors to abide in the kidneis or bladder,
and kills worms, and cleanses the stomach: the oil heals tetters. 30 The
juice of the plant or root may be dried and kept. Some steep the bruised
leaves and twigs in vinegar five or six days, and press out a juice, of
which two ounces and a half drunk, is good for the sciatica: but it were
better to mix it with oil and apply it. 31 The fresh juice of Broom rape,
does cure all new wounds, ulcers, and corrupt sores. 32 The juice pressed out
of the root and dried with a little honey in the sun, cleanses all rotten
wounds and ulcers. 33 It may be also taken out of the roots that be half
dry with oil, and will serve to all intents as the juice. 34 The same Broom
rape does scour and drive away all spots, lentiles, frecles, pimples, and
wheales, or pusshes, as well in ye face as in all other parts being often
anointed therewith. The seeds must be corrected with rosed honey, or Rose
leaves, or Aniseede, or Fenell seed.

Brookelime.
BRookelime: strangury, drink ye leaves in wine. 2 It helps also the inward
skabs of the bladder, especially taken with the root of Sperage. 3 The same
eaten with oil and vinegar, are good for the strangury and stone. 4 Fry it
with sheep suet, and apply it to bruses and swellings.

Bladder skab 2 Bruses 4 Stone and strangury 3 Swellings 4
Brian.
BRyan, stamp it and apply it three days to the knees that are swollen.

Bryony.
THe root, especially the juice thereof, does mightily purge tough phlegm,
provoke urine, cleanses the brain, breast, and inward parts. 2 The root
taken daily one dram a whole year together, helps ye falling sickness, ye
Apoplexia and Vertigo. 3 It is good in medicines against venomous bitings.
Half a dram being drunk with vinegar 30. days, heals ye milt that is stopped
and hard: and so it does being stamped with Figs and applied. 4 An Electuary
made thereof with honey, is very good against shortness of breath, ye old cough,
pain in the sides, and inward burstings and congeled blood of bruses. 5 The
same root used in a pessary, draws down the terms, seconds, and dead
births, and so does a bath of the decoction thereof, and also cleanses the
matrix from all unclean filth, if they sit over it. 6 The same stamped with
salt and applied, is good for noughty fretting sores that are corrupt and
running, especially in the legs. The leaves and fruit are good for the same
purpose applied in like sort. 7 It cleanses the skin from wrincles, frecles,
sunburning and alspots and scars being mixed with the meal of Orobus and
Fenigreeke, and so does the oil wherein the root has been sodden. 8 The
same stamped and mixed with wine dissolueth clottered blood, and all skarres,
bruises, and new swellings. It ripeneth and dissolueth clotted blood, and old
apostumes. It draws out splents and broken bones, and opens noughtie ulcers
and agnayles, that grow about the roots of the nails. 9 The fruit is good
against the itche, leaprie, and noughtie scab. 10 The first springs are very
good to be eaten in Sallads for the stomach. They provoke urine, and open the
belly. 11 The root of black Bryony is as good for all the griefs aforesaid
as the white, but not so strong: yet it preuayleth much against the falling
evil, giddiness or turnings of the head, to provoke urine and terms, to open
and waste the stopped and swollen milte. 12 And the tender springs thereof are
very good also to be eaten in Sallads to purge watrish humors and
superfluities, and to open the belly neither more nor less then the white
Bryony. 13 Bryony must be corrected with Mastike, Ginger, or Cinamom, and taken
with honey, or with the decoction of raisins. 14 Bryony sodden as Amaradulcis
being prepared, does gently loosen the belly without peril, and provoke
urine. 15 The juice of the root gathered in the spring time drunk with honied
water, drives forth gross phlegm. 16 An ointment made thereof with oil
Olive, and swines grease, is good for the palsy. 17 The oil thereof helps
all manner of deformities of the skin. So does the root with oil of Tartar,
and meal of Fenigreeke: or sodden in white wine from a quart to a pint, and
then streyned, and some Camphire put to it, and the place washed therewith every
night with a spondge. 18 The beries broken do cleanse the skin, from skurffe
and leaprie. 19 The juice of the beries baked in bread, causes plenty of
milk in nurses breasts that eat it, or used in frumentie. 20 Powder of the
beries is good for the stone. 21 The root is good for senowes that are cut to
make them supple, and to have their kindly course, especially the juice of the
root gathered in April or May, and the grief anointed therewith against the
fire, and then applied with linen cloutes. 22 For the Gout, slice the roots
thereof and of wild Dockes, and seethe them by themselves in water three
hours, then stamp them small with soote of a chimney, and the milk of a Cow
of one hue, and the urine of a fasting man, and apply it at every 24. hours
end ix. days. 23 Take Sallet oil, or for want thereof Neates foot oil two
quartes, Bryony roots clean scraped, and washed, and stamped, seethe it with
a soft fire, till it be almost half wasted, then streine it and put in another
root, and seethe it to a pint and a half, then a third root, and seethe it
to a pint, then streine it and keep it well, and anoint any ache therewith
wheresoever it be against the fire a long time. 24 Wounds growing together, put
in the powder thereof to open them. 25 Sausflegme, stamp the root with great
salt, and let it lie and rot 30. days, then streine out the juice and mix it
with vnguentum Album, Sulphur viuum, and honey of each like much, and anoint
therewith, and apply plasters thereof in the nights. 26 For all manner of
goutes, take in winter the root of Bryony, stamp it with two handful of
great salt, and let it stand so thirty days, then streine out the juice and
anoint therewith against the fire, and mix thereof with sheep tallowe
clarified together, and apply it to the sore to abate the pain quickly. 27
Seethe the roots in thine own urine, till three parts be wasted, and anoint
the ache of the reins therewith. 28 Face spots, or blemishes, anoint with the
juice of the roots. Frenzy and madness, boil the root and apply it to the
head. 29 Face wrincles, grind white wine with a little Bryony, and a dry fig,
and anoint therewith, and go till thou sweatest. 30 Wounds ache, stamp the
root with fair running water, and streine it and warm it, and apply it as
warm as may be suffered, the wound being first washed. 31 Wartes, burn the
leaves and stones, and mix the ashes with the juice, and anoint them often,
and they will fall off. 32 Breast strait, use the root of Bryony. Leapry,
mix the juice of Bryony with powder of white and black Ellebore, and honey,
and anoint. 33 Apostume general, slice it thin, and seethe it in a childs
urine, and let it stand 24. hours, then stamp it and streine it, and use it.
34 Color to be good, mix powder of the root of Viticell with Rose water, and
dip a cloth therein, and wash therewith. 35 Witchcraft to withstand, bear ye
root about thee. 36 Cramps: apply thin slices of the root. 37 Frenzy, boil
the root and apply it. 38 Headache, and want of sleep, make lee with the
ashes of Colewoort roots, Nettle roots, and Bryony roots, and wash therewith
often. Dropsy, take the juice of Bryony with honey, or use the decoction of it.
39 Strangury, use powder of ye berries of Bryony. 40 Fever quarten, stamp it
and apply it to the pulses and temples before the fit. 41 Scrophules, stamp ye
root with swines grease, and apply it. 42 Dropsy, sees it in water, and
drink it, and be whole. 43 Mother suffocate: heat an ounce of ye root in
white wine, and drink it twice a week to bedward a year together. 44
Strangury, seethe Watercresses in water, and drink it with powder of the
berries. 45 Mother rising, seethe two parts of the juice, with one part of
Sallet oil, till the juice be consumed, and annoint the place therewith where
it rises. 46 Swelling by blood letting, heat the leaves in water, and apply
them. 47 Head ache hot or cold, stamp the roots and boil them in old oil
and a little wine, and streine it and anoint therewith. 48 To avoid black
spots and skarres, boil the roots of Bryony both white and black in oil, as
long as it yeldeth any juice, and anoint therewith. 49 To cleanse and whiten
the skin and make it soft, stamp the root and apply it. 50 Teeth ache apply
the powder of it with the juice of Cheruile. 51 Paps sore, anoint with the
juice of the root.

Buckthorne.
BVckthorne, ye beries do purge downwards mightily phlegm and choler with
great force, much troubling the body, and sometimes causes vomit, and
therefore is not to be given but to them that be strong. 2 The beries before
they be ripe, soked in Alom water, make a fair yelowe color, and when they be
full ripe, they make a green color, which in France is called Vor de vessye,
in Spanish Sapgreene.

Choler and phlegm 1 Green color 2 Yelowe color 2
Bugle.
BVgle, and Sealfe Heal, bruised, drink the decoction of Bugle. It heals
all wounds both inward and outward, it opens the stoppings of the liver and
gall, and is good for the Iaundies and Fevers of long continuance. It cures
rotten ulcers and sores of the mouth and goomes being washed therewith. 2 The
green and fresh herb stamped and applied, heals wounds, galls, and
scratches, and so does the powder of the herb. 3 The juice cures the sores
and ulcers of the secret parts, being often dropped in, and so does the bruised
herb. Wounds of all sorts, stamp it with Yarrow and Sanicle, of each like
much, and strain it with wine and drink it daily. 4 Being drunk and applied,
it heals and draws out broken bones in the head, it destroys reume, and
helps head ache. 5 Wounds to heal, drink it by it self, or with
Pimpernell, and Sanicle. (See Selfe-heale.) 6 Wounds to heal without plaster,
drink Bugle, Yarow, and Fenell ana like much with wine thrice aday: but if the
head be wounded, use no Fenell. 7 Wounds of al sorts, stamp it with Yarow and
Sanicle, of each like much, and streine it with wine, and drink it daily.

Bones broken 4 Chafings 2 Fevers old 1 Gall stopped 1 Headache 4 broken 4
sores 5 Iaundies 1 Itche 2 Liver stopped 1 Mouth sores 1 Priuities sores 3 Reume
4 Skabbes 2 Sores 3 Wounds 1. 3. 5. 6. 7
Buglosse.
BVglosse, drink it with wine to help the griefs of ye lunges and the dry
cough. 2 Sees it in water and honey for the cough, and roughness of ye throat.
3 Steep it in wine and drink it with Mellicrat. to cause mirth. 4 Drink it
often in wine to purge red choler coming of heat, to help the Cardiake
passion and to avoid hurtful humors from the lungs. 5 Drink the juice with
warm water, to avoid the swelling of the feet. 6 Steep it in wine and
drink it to maintain a good memory, to comfort the heart and engender good
blood. 7 Drink ii. or iii. ounces of the distilled water, morning and evening
with Sugar for the bloody flixe, straitness of breath, and abstraction of
mind, weakness of the brain, all hot sicknesses, agues, griefs of the
liver and milte, to purge the blood, to avoid pricking of the heart and
stomach, the Iaundies, to cleanse the leapry and skab, to mittigate distilling
of the head, to cease the pain and burning of the eyes, the same being also
applied with linen clothes, and for the ringing and sound in the ears. 8
Distill the flowers in Balneo Mariae, and it is a precious water to be drunk
morning and evening with powder of pearls or Manus Christi made with pearls
to comfort the heart and brain. 9 The herb, root, and seed, or any part of
them sodden in wine and drunk, defends the heart from poison. 10 The water
or conserve of ye flowers, do strengthen the heart, and are good against
faintness and sounding, causes mirth, voydeth melancholy, purges the blood,
and is good against all hot fevers. 11 Milk to increase, bruise the seeds and
drink it with wine. 12 Bytings and stingings venomous, drink and apply the
distilled water and the leaves. 13 Eyes ache and inflamed, apply the water with
cloutes. 14 Buglosse provoke urine, quenches thirst, and the stalks eaten
either raw or sodden, are good for the diseases of the liver. 15 Drunk with
wine, it is singular good against reume. 16 And drunk with water, it is a
singular help against the Sciatica. 17 The ashes of it are good for the sores
and swellings in childrens mouths. 18 Seethe it with Sugar and Hydromel, and
use it for the sharpness and roughness of the throat. 19 The ashes of the
flowers are good for all griefs of the mouth and gomes, especially of
children. 20 Roste the root in the embers in a weete cloute, and mix it with
as much roasted apples and a little butter to assuage the pain of a white
flawe, and to ripen all froncles or felons, and to take away the roughness of
the tongue. 21 Steep Buglosse in water and wine of a Pomegranate, and hold it
in thy mouth to delight thee when thou have a Fever. 22 Stamp the flowers of
Borage or Buglosse when they are full ripe, and put thereto thrice so much
Sugar by little and little, and sun it in a Gally pot twenty or thirty days,
and it will last a year. It causes mirth, and comfort the heart and
spirits. 23 Their water drunk with wine, comfort the brain, heart, and
memory, and wit, ingendreth good blood, voydeth melancholy, madness, and
frenzy. 24 Buglosse eases the pain that comes of repletion of the veins
in every part, heart trembling and panting, especially for women which are much
subject thereto, make a drink with two ounces of the clear juice, and two
drams of Sugar, and drink it every night blood warm to bedward ten days
together. 25 Seethe the leaves and roots in water, and quench steel therein,
to make it hard and sharp. 26 Gout, drink the juice with warm water, and
apply the substance. 27 Senowes shronke, stamp it and apply it. Stomach cold,
and brain moist, mix six drams of Aqua vitae, four drams of Buglosse water,
Cinamom, and Saffron, of each one penny weight, and steep them together 24.
hours, and drink it fasting. 28 Madness, take Aqua vitae two egg shells
full, wine thrice as much, powder of Seen two drams, and take it iii. mornings.
29 Vomiting to stop, drink Buglosse water. 30 Heart stiche, eat potage made
with Buglosse, butter and water, morning and evening warm. 3 Heart feeble, use
Buglosse, or the powder thereof in thy brothes. 32 To refresh the body, stewe
an old hen with good store of Buglosse, and drink thereof morning, noone,
and evening. 33 Coldness by long sickness, seethe one handful of Buglosse in
a quart of wine, and streine it and drink it morning and evening. 34 Iaundies,
drink Buglosse water. 35 Feebleness of the heart, shortness of breath, and
sighing, drink the juice with honey. 36 For passions of the heart, eat it or
drink it raw or sodden to put out the noisome humors. Pissing blood from the
reins, drink the juice often. 37 Liver and milt griefs, use Buglosse in thy
pottage, and look that thy belly be soluble. 38 Belly bound, stamp Ote-meale
great, and seethe them with Buglosse, and use the broth. 39 Use Buglosse for
griefs of the heart, and impostumes. 40 Pissing blood, drink the juice.

Bullfoote.
FOr the grief of the lungs and spitting of blood, mix it with Hogs lard
chopped, and a new laid egg, and boil it or bake cakes of it, and eat it
ix. mornings. It makes a man fat. For the Kings evil, stamp it well with the
root and all, with flower of Lynseede and Barowes grease, and apply it morning
and evening, and after it is healed, wash it with white wine x. or xv. days. 2
To heal wounds speedely, anoint the tops of the leaves with honey, and apply
them, and as soon as they be dry, apply fresh. 3 Legs sores, stamp it and
apply it. 4 To pluck out thorns or pricks apply it with Swines grease. 5
Fever tertian and quarten to avoid, drink the juice thereof x. days. 6
Drink the juice for the cough and for wounds. 7 Breast griefs, drink the
juice of Hysope, Horehound, and Bullfoote. 8 The leaves punned with honey, do
cure S. Anthonies fire, and all other inflammations. 9 The perfume of the dried
leaves received through a Tunnell upon the quick coals, helps shortness of
wind, the dry cough, and breaks impostumes of the breast without danger,
and so does the root laid on hot coals. 10 Seethe it in meede, and drink
it to cast out a dead child. 11 Drink three spoonefull of the distilled water
for the inflammation of the Liver, the gnawing of the stomach, and the venom of
ye burning fever, and the same also applied outwardly with linen clothes. 12
The herb distilled with flowers of Eldren, and Solatrum, of each like much.
The virtues thereof cannot be sufficiently esteemed, the same is good
especially against inflammations, carbuncles, the holy fire, the piles, hot
apostumes and burnings, and so is the juice of the leaves. 14 The same is good
also against all hot aches of the head, and heat of burning Fevers, and
against all whelkes and pusshes coming of heat, and against all hot griefs
of the secret parts: for the pyles and emerodes, and such like. The juice
heals burnings, skaldings, and hot inflammations. 15 The fume received
through a tronke, helps and cleanses the lungs quickly, and heals rotten
and old coughs.

Cough of the lungs, take of the fume of the powder of it laid on a
chafingdish of coals through a tunnill, at morning, noone, and evening iii. or
iiii. days, if the cough come of hot reume, it will dry it up: or sees ii.
handful of Bullfoote in a quart of clear posset ale, with a stick of licoras
cleansed and bruised, and when the one half is wasted, drink it at morning,
afternoon, and to bedward, by a little at once, but yet a good quantity in
the whole. Seethe Bulfoote, and Penyroyall, with a little salt in water, and
drink it fasting to avoid all evils from the heart.

Achehote 14 Apostume 13 Blood spit 1 Breast griefs 1 Breath short 9 Burnings
13. 14 Carbuncle 13 Cough 6. 9. 14 Dead child 10 Deliverance 10 Emerodes 13.
14 Fat to be 1 Fever hot 11. 14. quarten 5 tertian 5 Head ache hot 14 Holy
fire 13 Impostume 9 Inflammation 13. 14 Kings evil 1 Leanenesse 1 Leg sores 3
Liver hot 11 Lungs griefs 1. 15 Piles 13. 14 Pricks 4 Priuities griefs 14

Burre.
THe juice of great Burre drunk with honey, provoke urine, and swageth the
pain of the bladder. 2 The same drunk with old wine, heals the bytings and
stingings of venomous beasts. 3 The leaves punned with a little salt, is good
against all venomous bitings of mad dogs or serpents. 4 The powder of the seed
drunk with the best wine that may be gotten forty days, is good against the
sciatica. 5 A dram of the root punned with the kernels of a Pine apple, is a
sovereign medicine against the spitting of corrupt matter. It is good for such
as have ache in the joints and bones that have been out of joint or broken. 6
The green leaves punned with whites of eggs, cures burnings and old sores. 7
The leaf laid on the top of the head draws the matrixe upward, and laid to
the soles of the feet, it draws it downward, and so it helps the
suffocation, and the falling or displasing of the matrixe. 8 Sees the root in
Ale, and so let it stand 24. hours close stopped, and then drink a good draught
three or four times to help the yellowe Iaundies speedely. 9 Drink powder of
the seeds with pure white wine to purge the gravel from the reins, but more
speedily with Aqua vitae, 10 The juice of the lesser Burre with red stringy
roots drunk with wine, is good against all venomous bytings, and the gravel
and stone. 11 The fruit stamped and applied to cold swellings, does consume
and scatter them, and is good against the Kings evil, swellings, wenns, and
scrophules in the neck and throat. 12 The ripe seed of great Burres in powder
drunk, is good for them that have the stone. 13 The fresh leaves are good for
old ulcers and sores, and for joints that are lose, and broken members, and
for all heat, and ach being applied. 14 The root taken with Pineapple kernels
in quantity of a dram, is good against the coughing out of matter and blood.
15 The root is good to be laid to the ach that comes by wrenching and
streining. 16 The leaves are good to be laid upon old sores. Drink one dram
with Pineapple kernels, to help the cough, spetting of blood and matter,
filthiness of the stomach, and contraction of of the finewes, and arteries. 17
The leaves or juice do heal old rotten fores and stinking filthy ulcers. The
decoction of the root is good to wash ulcers and wounds withal. 18 The root
stamped with salt and applied, is good against the bytings of mad dogs. 19 The
root used inward or outward, prevails against the bytings of Serpents. 20 The
root sodden in wine and drunk one hour before the fit, delivers from the
horror of the Fever quarten. 21 And the root stamped with Swines grease,
helps the squincy and swelling in the throat. 22 The Ditch burre, or lesser
Burre with red roots, is good to be laid to swellings. 23 The bark of Burre
roots drunk, wastes the swelling of the milt. 24 And the decoction of it
sodden in wine, and the mouth washed therewith, fastneth lose teeth. 25 Drink
the distilled water of Di^ch burre four ounces, with half an ounce of white
crude honey, four or five hours before meat warm thirty days together
against the catharre to cure it, except it come of the pox or hectyke, for the
which also it will do good, if not cure them, 26 Seethe the roots with red
Nettle crops in good stale ale, and clarify it, and drink it before the cold
fit of the Fever quarten, and after the great heat is past, drink possit ale
made with Marygolds and Fenell, and do so four times if need be. 27 Stamp
the roots with Sage leaves and apply it to saint Anthonies fire. 28 Grind the
roots of Burres and Planten with vinegar and salt, and anoint therewith the
freckles, red blaynes, and sausflegme of the face. 29 Seethe the roots in
water, and set thy feet therein up to the ancles as hot as may be suffered to
help the bloody flux. 30 For the gout nd Sciatica, seethe the roots in strong
wine and apply it. 31 Stamp the bark or pill, and streine it with new Ale,
and drink it against all gouts, proved. 32 Foment with the decoction of the
pill of the roots in wine wheresoever the grief be, or stamp the roots and
seethe them in Ale, and streine it and drink it at evening hot, and at
morning cold for the aforesaid. 33 For ache of the reins, drink the root
with Ale and butter at morning cold, and evening hot. 34 Sciatica, seethe the
roots in strong wine, and apply it. 35 Bloody flux, chop the roots as much
as a penny lofe, seethe them in a new pot with good Wine, and sit over the
vapor of it, it stops also the terms, or seethe the roots or seeds, or
both in rain water, or conduit water, and drink it fasting. 36 Belly and guts
pain, drink a sciat of the juice of the leaves. 37 Back ache, stamp the
roots, and seethe them in Ale, and drink it at evening hot, and at morning
cold. 38 Pyles, take up the fume of the roots of Burres and Veruen, with
Frankincense laid on coals. 39 Fever, stamp three roots of Burres, and
seethe them with half a pint of Ale, and drink thereof leuke warm before
the fit. 40 Speech lost, hold the juice of the herb and root under thy
tongue, and be whole. 41 Cough and pose, use powder of the seeds with Wardens
or Pears, or drink it morning and evening. 42 Pursinesse of wind, and to
break phlegm and much corruption, drink powder of the seeds as much as you
can take up with two fingers and a thumb, first and last at morning and evening
with White wine or old Ale: proved. 43 Ringworme, seethe the root in vinegar
and apply it. The stalk near the root, is good in sallads. 44 Impostume to
break, seethe the root in Ale, and drink it nine days to break, and avoid
it downwards. 45 Squincy and griefs of the throat, drink powder of the
seeds with Ale as often as need is. 46 Face blaines, stamp the roots of
Planten and Burres with salt of each like much, with vinegar, and anoint at
night to bedward. 47 Belly or guts fretting, seethe the root of Burre and
Elecampana, in wine, and drink it warm morning and evening. 48 Bloody flux,
stamp the roots, and seethe them in water to the one half, and stand in it,
but not to the ancles, for then it binds too much, and brings danger of
death by costiuenesse.

Bursa pastoris.
BVrsa pastoris, blood to staunch, hold thy hands full of it: nosebleeding,
bind it about thy neck, and hold thereof in thy hand, and also use it in thy
meats, and apply vinegar and water to the secret parts. 2 Spetting blood,
seethe it with Planten, and Knotgrasse in rain water, and streine it and
drink thereof with Sugar, at morn, noone, and even. 3 Blood to stop, apply
the juice with powder of Antimonium, or dip an Elderne pith in the juice, and
cast on powder of Sinnach, and put it in. 4 Chafing in the flanks, wash or bath
with the decoction thereof, or of Planten, or Horsetaile, or Knotgrasse. 5
Fever hot, stamp one handful with as much Smallach, and as much Frankincense
as a wall nut, and as much Bay salt, and apply them to the wrists two hours
before the fit. 6 Nosebleeding, apply the juice with Bol armoniake to the
temples with the white of an egg. 7 Or mix powder of Bursa pastoris with the
juice thereof, powder of Camphire, and Nettleseedes, and make little tents
thereof and put them in, or put in powder of the flower, rynd, and kernels of a
Pomegranate with the juice of Bursa pastoris. 8 Teeth ache, stamp a good
handful, and apply it to the soles of thy feet. 9 For one that is new
bursten, seethe Bursa pastoris, Mugwort, Ribwort, and Polipody ana, one
handful in a pottell of strong Ale to a quart,, then streine it, and drink
three spoonefuls fasting warm daily. 10 Blood to stop, hold thy hands full of
it, and look to the sun, and be not strait girded. 11 Flowers to stop, put
in a pessarie of the juice, and Goats doung. 12 Urine flux, use it in thy
meats. 13 Bloody flux, drink the juice, or bake cakes of wheat flower with
the juice of it and of Yerrow and Planten ana like much in the embers, and eat
them hot, and drink the juice of them with Red wine warm three days:
proved. 14 Teeth ach, grind it with Sage and Mints ana like much, and put it
in a linen bag, and hold it to thy teeth, and shut thy mouth while one may say
three Pater nosters, then open thy mouth and let out the glutt, and do so as
often as need is. 15 Bloody flux, drink it with Red wine, or milk, or drink
the juice with twice so much Red wine when thou go to bed, to heal the
flixe speedily. 16 The decoction thereof drunk, stops the laske, the bloody
flixe, spetting blood, pissing blood, the flowers, and all other issues of
blood, most excellently well howsoever it be taken, but especially with Red
wine or Planten water. 17 Stamp it with vinegar and fresh Swines grease, to
quench all inflammations or heat of the body, as shingles, etc. 18 The juice
alone does heal a new wound, and stops blood. 19 Nothing is better to
stop the flowers, then to make a fomentation or moist bath thereof, and to sit
over it close, and to drink of the same clarified in Red wine. 20 Seethe the
dried herb in Red wine, or rain water wherein hot steel has been often
quenched, and drink it to all kinds of fluxes both white and red, the terms
and all other gnawings of the bowels. 21 Nose bleeding put in the juice with a
tent, and the like into wounds warm. 22 Ears running, put in the juice. 23
Use it in plasters for the sores of the head. 24 Drink the juice for
straitness of breath, the strangurie, to stop reume, and provoke urine. 25
Drink it with wine against venomous bytings. 26 Seethe it in wine and honey to
cure wounds. Use it in pessaries to stop terms. 27 It helps ache of the
ears. 28 It preuenteth the fitts of the Fevers being taken one hour before
the fit. 29 It cures creeping and running sores, fistulaes, spetting of blood
and matter, the holy fire, swellings and hardness, shingles, heat of the
stomach, new wounds, hot apostumes, and reumatike sores and ulcers of the
ears, and all kinds of fluxes.

Burnet.
BVrnet opens the stoppings of the liver, causes urine, and helps the
Iaundes. 2 And with honey and white wine, it vnbindeth sore stitches of the ribs
and teats. 3 Stamp it and seethe it with wine or milk, and streine it, and
drink it hot for the grinding of the belly. 4 For all sores, wash them with
the juice of Burnet and Sugar. 5 To heal the Plurisie and putrefaction of the
matrix, distill it in the end of May, and drink the water four ounces morning
and evening. 6 Burnet drunk, cures the bloody flixe, spetting blood, pissing
blood, the flowers, and all other fluxes of blood, and so does the powder of
the herb and seed drunk with wine or water wherein iron has been often
quenched, and so does the herb alone being but holden in the hand. 8 Wounds,
stamp the green leaves and apply them to keep them from apostumation, and
inflammation, and to hot tumors, botches, swelling and ulcers. 9 It is very
good to heal wounds used both inward and outward, to avoid inflammation and
bleeding. 10 The leaves steeped in wine and drunk, do comfort and rejoice the
heart, and help the trembling thereof, and confirms the stomach. 11 In
pottage, it binds the belly. 12 It is very good in the plague time, and so is
the water thereof. 13 It stops the flowers and all fluxes, and represseth
cholerike vomitings. 14 The root and seed are most binding. 15 The leaf in
Ale, Beer or Wine, is good against the reume and flixe of the body, and
against the hot running gout, used both inward and outward. 16 Burnet opens
the stoppings of the liver, causes urine, and helps the Iaundes, and with
White wine and honey it vnbindeth stitches of the ribs and teats.

Butchers broom.
BVtchers broom, or Knee holme: Kankers in wounds, apply powder of the roots.
2 Yard inflamed, stamp the leaves and boil them with Rose water and a little
wine, and apply them. 3 Seethe it in wine, and drink it to provoke urine, to
break the stone, and drive out the gravel and urine. For the Iaundes and
headache, and to provoke the flowers. 4 The leaves and fruit be of the same
force that the roots be of, but not so strong. It is good for the strangury. 5
The young stalks are eaten as Sperage in sallads.

Flowers stopped 3 Headache 3 Iaundes 3 Kanker 1 Stone 3 Strangury 4 Urine stopped 3
Wounds 1 Yard inflamed 2
Butterburre.
BVtter burre: Plague, drink the powder of it with wine, it helps the
pestilent Fevers, provoke sweat, dries up all venom and evil heat from the
heart. It kills worms, and is of great force against the suffocation of the
mother. 2 It cures all naughty ulcers, and all filthy fretting sores or
consuming pox and inflammations, the powder being cast into them or on them. 3
The same cures the farcion in horses either given inwards or applied
outwardly. 4 The root is good against all venomous bytings and poison being
used either inward or outward. 5 Being sodden in wine and drunk, it helps
the difficulty of breathing, it kills broad worms like gourd seeds, and
drives down urine and terms. 6 The powder of the root does effectually
heal al running sores and moist wounds. 7 Oil of the root of it is good
against all shaking and cold fevers being anointed before the fit, and the
same scoureth away all the filthiness of the skin, and is good for the extreme
coldness and shakinng of the ioints and sinews. 8 Stamp the herb and apply
it to any sores that be extremely hard to heal. 9 For the pestilence, drink
one dram of the powder of the root with wine, and cover thee well to sweat.
10 The same powder is also good against the strangling of the mother, and
kills worms both in men and beasts, and helps them that are shortwinded.

Bytings venomous 4 Breath short 5. 10 Cold griefs 7 Fevers 1. 7 Flowers

Calament. ( See Nep.)
CAlament drunk three days, helps the Iaundes, and the stomach, causes
digestion, and stays vomiting, and being drunk and applied, it helps
venomous bytings, and wounds. 2 Stomach ache, seethe it with Reasins, and dry
Figs in wine, and drink it first and last, or use it in brothes. Wounds to
heal, stamp Nep and drink it with Ale. 3 Worms, drink it with wine. Bruised
blood, drink the juice to cast it out. 4 Wounds ache, stamp it with wine and
eat it. 5 Fever quarten, drink the juice of Nep with wine to sweat it away. 6
Seethe it in water and honey, and drink the broth to provoke the flowers. 7
Ears worms, rub the head with Calament. 8 Lytargie, drink ashes of the skin
of a Hare with Calament. 9 Breasts swollen, stamp it with Wormwood, Sage, and
tosted white bread and vinegar, and apply it as hot as may be suffered. 10
Stomach griefs, stamp Nep, and seethe it in Wine and drink it. 11 Cough and
impostume, eat roasted figs with powder of Nep. 12 Bleeding inward, stamp it
and streine it with Ale or Wine, and drink it three or four times a day, and
the blood shall come outward. 13 Drink it with Wine for shortness of breath.
14 Dead child to expel, drink it and Betony with Ale. 15 Sciatica, stamp it
and apply it. Heart cardiak, drink it and apply it. 16 To preserve from the
lepry in the beginning chewe it fasting, and hold it, and thou shall never be
leprous. 17 Stones swollen, stamp it and apply it. 18 Teeth ache, apply the
leaves. 19 Woman mischieued in child birth, stamp good store of Nep with a
little Veruin, and streine it with White wine or stale Ale, and drink it first
at and last at morn and even as long as need is. 20 Bruses and bruised blood,
stamp Nep leaves with salt and apply them. 21 Yexing, drink Nep with Wine:
cough cold, stamp as much Nep as two wallnuts with two eggs, and make a tansy
and eat it. 22 Pyles, bruise one handful of Nep and apply it. 23 Ears worms,
put in the juice. 24 Matrix cold and moist, use pessaries or subfumigations of
Nep, it helps conception. 25 Worms and superfluous flesh in sores, apply
powder of wild Calament. 26 Pissing bed, drink a little Nep before supper. 27
Wounds bleeding inward, drink the juice fasting by it self, or with Cheruill
and Wine. 28 Calament or Nep boiled and drunk or applied, is good against
venomous bytings. 29 Drunk with Wine aforehand it preserves from poison, and
chaseth away all venomous beasts from whence it is strawed or burned. 30
Drunk with honyed Wine, it warmeth the body, cutteth gross humors, drives
away cold shiuerings, and causes sweat, and so it does being boiled in oil
and all the body anointed with it. 31 Drunk as aforesaid, it helps
brusings, digesteth congealed blood, and is good for burstings, pain of the
bowels, shortness of breath, stopping of the breast, and the Iaundies. 32
Boiled in Wine and drunk, it provoke urine and terms, expels the dead
birth, and so it does in a pessary or in other suppositer. 33 It is good for
lazers and lepers to eat of it, and to drink it in whay of sweet milk after
it. 34 Eaten raw or sodden with meats, or drunk with salt and honey, slays
and expels all kinds of worms out of all parts of the body, and so does
the juice drunk and laid to where they are. 35 Boiled in Wine, it helps
bruses, and black spots being often washed therewith, or the green herb
stamped and applied. 36 It is good to be applied to the Sciatica. It helps the
strangury or stopping of the urine, the stone, conuulsions of the stomach,
wheasings, pains of the guts, stopping of terms, tertians, and the kings
evil, being drunk in wine, or the powder or syrop used. 37 The water is but
weak, except to stop vomits. 38 The oil is a present help against the
Sciatica, and enters quickly. 39 Drink the juice with wine, to kill worms,
resist poison, cause sweat, open the liver and milt, and to heat the kidneys
that have taken cold, or seethe the herb with wine for all the aforesaid, and
to cleanse the breast, provoke vrin, heal ruptures, help the Iaundies, to
restreine cholerik fluxes, to comfort the stomach, for the Fever tertian, the
stomach being first cleansed.

Matrix griefs of all sorts, stamp the leaves and flowers of Calament, and
seethe them in water with powder of Cauell, and streine it, and drink it warm
with sugar morn and even.

Calamus aromaticus.
CAlamus aromaticus does cleanse, dry, and waste all windiness within the body
without hurt. 2 The root sodden in wine and drunk, helps the white morphue,
and causes a good color in the face. 3 It does help to purge, cleanse, and
dry the water between the skin and the flesh, being sodden with the seeds of
Smallach, Parsley and Fenel, and streined, and so it helps cramps also, and
griefs in the sinews. 4 Being drunk in wine, sodden with Sage and fresh
Capars, it helps the coldness of the milt, liver and reins. 5 The powder
thereof drunk, augmenteth seed of generation, and purges the terms. 6
Nothing is better for the dropsy then Ale of Wormwood or of Sage, drunk with
the said powder. 7 It also cleanses the bladder and voydeth the stinking of the
urine. It is a noble herb of great virtue, chiefly the root. 8 Boiled with
Parsley seed, it is good for the strangury, pain in the reins and bladder,
and the dropsy. 9 The same taken any ways, is very agreeable to the inner
parts of the stomach, liver, milt and matrix, and for all ruptures. 10 Breath
stink, chew it and hold it in thy mouth. 11 Liver and milt stopped, stamp it and
steep it in sufficient vinegar, and seethe it in the same vinegar to the one
half, and to one pound of Calamus put six ounces of honey, and boil it to a
syrop, and take an ounce and a half every morning and be whole.

Calamus aromaticus causes urine and terms taken in warily, or fomented out
warely, and is good in plasters for the liver and stomach. It is good for
strangurie and griefs of the kidneys. It washes all windiness from all
parts without hurt. Seethe it in Wine and drink it against the white morphue.
It helps sores of the bladder, and expels stinking urine, and with
convenient things, it helps the dropsy.

Backache 8 Bellyache 8 Bladder griefs 7. 8 Breath stink 10 Bursten 9 Cholik
1 Cramp 3 Color bad 2 Dropsy 3. 6. 8 Flowers stopped 5 Kidneys cold 4. griefs
8. 10. Liver cold 4. griefs 9. 10. Lust to cause 5 Matrix griefs 9 Milt cold
4. griefs 9. 10. Morphue 2 Seed to increase 5 Sinews griefs 3 Stomak griefs
9 Strangurie 8 Urine stink 7 Windiness 1
Caltrop.
CAltrop or star thistle: drink powder of the seed with wine, to expel the
urine, for the gravel and the strangurie.

Camomill.
CAmomill: stinking sweat, seethe Camomill and Wormwood with some Alom in water
and wash therewith. 2 Stone, drink the juice with wine. 3 Fevers, seethe
Camomill, Isop, and fiueleafe ana, one handful in a quart of Ale, and make it
an Alebrew and use it. 4 Ache, stamp it and apply it by it self or with
Pepper. 5 Milt pain, drink one dram of powder of the flowers with three
ounces of White wine, and a little of a childs urine morning and evening. 6
Itch and ill humors, seethe Ladies mantell, Camomill flowers, and Iacea ana
one handful in good Wine, and drink four ounces every morning, and also wash
therewith twice, and be whole. 7 Bruses, boil Camomil, Wormwood, and wheat
branne ana one handful in wine and after in honey, and apply it. 8 Stomak
impost. drink vi. ounces of the distilled water every morning at the break of
day. 9 Strangury and stone in ye reins, drink one ounce of the water when need
is and eat a little sugar after it. 10 To make ye oil of it, put iii. ounces
of the flowers after one days gathering in one pint and a half of sallet
oil in a glass, and set it in the sun xl. days, it opens the pores,
resolves vapors, stops flowing of humors, corrects evil qualities,
comfort the sinews, and mitigateth ach or pain. 11 Aches and swellings,
seethe the flowers of Camomill and Roses in white wine, and apply it
plasterwise. 12 Kernels in the throat, mix powder of it with honey, and take a
spooneful of it morn and even, and let it go down by a little at once. 13
Fevers cold, seethe it and wormwood in a quart of Ale to ye one half, then
streine it and drink it first and last. 14 Head ulcers or biles, seethe it in
vinegar or water and wash therewith. Fever and Iaundes, drink the juice with
warm water. 15 Headache, stamp it with red Fenel, Sage and Cummin, and apply
it. 16 Chollik, stone, and stopping of the vrin, stamp Camomil and wild
Mallows ana one handful, and seethe them in water till it be thick, put them
into two pockets, and sprinkle them with white wine, and apply them one after
another from the nauil to the yard as hot as may be suffered. 17 Seethe Camomil,
Rosemary, and Time ana, one handful in a pint of Malmsey, and take up the
fume thereof into the ears that are dull of hearing, or apply a ball of bruised
Camomil. 18 Seethe two handfuls of Camomil in strong Ale, and apply it hot as
may be suffered, or take up the fume thereof into the mouth for the headache,
and when it is cold heat it again and hang a cloth over thy head. Mouth
byles, chew Camomill. 19 Sinews shronk, and for swelling in the neck, grind
it with as much water cresses, of each one handful small, and fry them with wheat
meal and honey, and apply it hot as may be suffered: proved. 20 Stitch, stamp
the flowers with a little vinegar, and apply them hot in a bag, or seethe three
handfuls with as much wormwood, some Mallows, and one handful of Rosemary in
a gallon of water to the one half, and put them into two or three bladders and
apply them hot one after another. 21 Worms, seethe Camomil, Tansy, and
Peniroyal ana, like much, in one pint of Malmsey to ye one half, then strein
it, and drink thereof. 22 For the cholik at all times, fill a stillatorie with
Camomill, and one handful of Mints, all shreaded small, put thereto a quart of
White wine and distill it, and drink the water. 23 Head pusshes and wheales
seethe it in vinegar and wash therewith. 24 Headache of a burning fever, use
Camomill. 25 Mouth kanker, burn it and use the powder. 26 Milt griefs, drink
one dram of the powder forty days. 27 Urine stopped, seethe it in wine or
water, and drink thereof often, it helps also the stopping of the liver and
milt. 28 Flowers stopped, seethe it in water and bath therein. 29 The oil of it,
stamp the flowers with oil olive, and let it rest xii. days, then seethe it
and streine it, and do so the second time, and let it stand xvi. days, then
seethe it, and streine it and use it. 30 Cholik, seethe it with Rue, and drink
it. 31 Headache, seethe it in water and wash therewith luke warm and apply the
herb till the ache cease. 32 Sleep to cause, apply Camomill to thy temples.
33 Headache of stopping, seethe the flowers in lee and wash thy head therewith,
and apply the flowers, and steep a piece of bread in wine, and eat it with
powder of Cinnamom. 34 Madness, seethe Camomill flowers and Veruin ana one
handful in a quart of water or lee, and wash thy head therewith. 35 Sweat to
cause, use Camomil and the flowers thereof in baths. 36 Liver cold with stitch
and palenes, purge thy body, and set thy feet in warm water wherein Camomil
has been sodden, and warm, them, and beware thou take no cold. 37 Loins ach
of cold cause, Seethe the flowers in wine with as much water, and stamp them
well, and seethe them again in the same liquor till it be wasted, and apply it
as hot as may be suffered a foot broad, and then use hot ointments or oils.
38 Fevers of dry cause, or heaviness, seethe Camomill and Dill ana, two
handfuls in water, and sit over it up to the knees, and cover thee well that
the water may strike up through thee, then rub well thy legs downwards and
walk, and use meats that warm moderately, and beware of cold. 39 Fever
quotidian with great thirst, set thy feet in the like water aforesaid and dry
them and rub them with salt, and as much oil of Violets. 40 Camomill drunk
with wine, breaks the stone, helps the Iaundes, the ach and grief of the
liver, sores of the mouth, headache, and megrem, and expels vrin. 41 A good
plaster for the stomak: stamp Camomil, Mints, sage, and good store of wormwood
with sour bread, and boil them in vinegar, and apply it warm. 42 The
decoction of the flowers, herb and root drunk, provoke terms, expels the
dead fruit, drives out urine, and breaks the stone, and so does the bath of
the decoction thereof. 43 The flowers and herb boiled in wine and drunk,
expels the wind, and cures the cholik and pain in the belly, and so it
purges and beautifieth those that have an evil color after the Iaundes, and
all griefs of the liver. 44 Drink one dram of the herb and flowers with
wine, against all venomous bytings. 15 Seethe it in water and apply it to the
region of the bladder for the pain thereof, and to drive forth the urine and
grauel. 46 Chew it in the mouth for the ulcers thereof, or wash the mouth with
the decoction thereof. 47 Mix it with oil, and take it in a glister against
all Fevers coming of obstruction or stopping of the skin. 48 The oil thereof
swageth all ache, it cures bruised and wearied parts, it softneth all
hardness and swellings, and opens all that is stopped. 49 Seethe it in
water, and wash pusshes of the head therewith to heal them. 50 Strangury and
stone in the kidneys, drink Camomill water with sugar fasting, till the pain
be gone. 51 Stamp it and streine it with white wine, and drink it to expel a
dead child presently, and to cleanse the bladder. 52 Wash one handful and bruise
it, and seethe it in a pint of Ale to the one half, scom it and streine it,
and drink it one hour before the fit of an ague with sugar, and cover thee
well to sweat three days together fasting. 53 The smell of it comfort ye
brain. 54 Seethe the herb and flowers in wine and drink it to help the
stoppings of the liver and milt to purge choler to expel terms to help the
torments of the small guts, to heal ye grief of the kidneis and bladder, to
mitigate the inward griefs of the matrix, for straitnes of wind, sighing,
wheasing, the griefs of the lungs, the flux lienteria, to warm the cold
stomak to drive away many inward griefs. 55 Seethe the flowers with vinegar
and honey, and drink it daily morn and even for the falling sickness. 56 There
is no medicine more usual amongst men then Camomil for all griefs. 57 Smell
to Camomill and wash thy head therewith, or with the lee thereof, for the
weakness of the head and brain. 58 Wash filthy ulcers with the decoction
thereof. 59 The oil of the flowers thereof, softneth all hard swellings and
humors, and mitigateth aches. 60 No man can tell all the virtues thereof. 61
Anoint the headache with the oil, and all other aches, bruses, shrinkings,
hardness, and stoppings, etc.

Take the flowers of Camomill, or any other flowers, or fresh green herbs,
chop them small, and boil them artly in oil, cool it and press, and put
therein fresh flowers, and sun it, and use it.

Take powder of any simple wood, as Sanders, Aloes, Tamariske, or Guiacum, soke
it in oil of sweet Almonds ten days, then heat it, and press out the oil,
the like may be done with any flower or herb.

Capars.
CApars: the bark of the root is good against the hardness and stopping of
the milt to be taken with Oximel or mixed with oils, or ointments fit for that
purpose and applied. 2 The root used in drink is good for the Sciatica, the
palsy, and bruised blood, it provoke terms and urine mightily, that it
waxes bloody if it be much used, it cleanses old ulcers and rotten sores
that be hard to heal. 3 And laid to with vinegar, it voydeth foul whitespots
and morphue, the fruit and leaves have the like virtue as the roots, but not
so strong. 4 The seed boiled with vinegar and kept warm in the mouth, swageth
toothache. 5 The juice of the leaves, flowers, and young fruit dropped into the
ears, kills worms in them. 6 The Capers preserved in salt or pickle, as
they be brought into this country, being washed, and boiled, and eaten with
vinegar, are meat and medicine: for it causes appetite, opens the stopping
of the liver and milt, consumes cold flegmes in the stomach, but they nourish
little or nothing at all. 7 Eat Capers, and drink the water of a smithes
cole-trough to heal the swelling of the milte, though it have continued seven
years. 8 Raw Capers eaten, trouble the stomach, wherefore they must be sodden
and mixed with oil and vinegar and so eaten. 9 The continual use of them is
good for them that have the palsy, the gout, and that are flegmatike and
splenetike, for excess of terms, the sciatica and stopping of the urine. 10
Drink two drams of the fruit forty days with wine to waste the milte, and
drive down the urine and bloody excrements, for the sciatica, weakness of
the sinowes, ruptures, crampes, to provoke flowers, to purge the head, and
loosen the belly. 11 Capers sodden in vinegar, helps the tooth ache, and so
does the dried bark of the root, which decoction serves also to cleanse all
manner of filth of the skin, all filthy sores and white skurfe and hard
swellings. 12 The fruit or leaves applied with Barley meal, is good for the
hardness of the milt, wennes and kernels. 13 They would be eaten with Oximell
before other meats. 14 Flowers to cause, stamp the bark of the tree, and
steep it all night in white wine, and streine it, and drink it fasting two or
three mornings. 15 Distill them when they are green, and wash hair with the
water in the sun, and it will be green. 16 Drink Capars to dissolve the
ache of the bones. 17 Kings evil, use the decoction of the bark of Capars,
and Sperage, and anoint with oil of serpents.

Ache 16 Appetite 6 Belly bound 10 Bones ache 16 Bruised 2 Bursten 10 Crampe 10

Cardamom.
CArdamom, or Grains of Paradise, are good to be drunk against the falling
sickness, the sciatica, the cough, resolutions of the sinowes, ruptures, pain
of the belly, to kill worms, and provoke urine. 2 Drink one dram in wine,
with as much bark of Laurus to break the stone. 3 The common grains be near
hand as good. 4 Grains are good for a cold stomach, and are much like Pepper
in operation. 5 It is a good spice for women. 6 Chollike, seethe white time and
Parslie in Ale, and streyne it and drink it with powder of Graynes. 7 Brain
weak of reume or pose, put powder of Cardamom to oil of Musk into an Egg
shell, till it seethe, and anoint therewith: it is chief of all seeds. Put
powder of it into the nose to comfort the feeble brain. Griefs of the heart,
lungs, and stomach, and to preserve from all evil humors, take Cardamom, iii.
ounces, Galingall, vi. ounces, Sugar, iiii. ounces, Saffron, i. peniworth, and
take half a spoonefull of their powder morning and evening, till you be whole.

Belly ache 1 Brain sick 1 Bursten 1 Chollike 6 Cough 1 Falling evil 1 Reume
7. 1 Sciatica 1 Sinowes grief 1 Stomach cold 4. 1 Stone 2 Urine stopped 1
Women's griefs 5 Worms 1
Camepitis.
CAmepitis, ground Pine, herb Iue, or field Cypers: liver, milt, kidneis,
and bladder stopped, seethe it and Germander in oil, and apply it and use the
powder of the herbs as an Electuarie with honey. 2 Drink the distilled water
of Camepitis, and anoint the place with it to help the gout. 3 The leaves
drunk with wine seven days, heals the Iaundies. 4 And drunk with Mede or
Mellicrate forty days, it heals the sciatica. 5 Liver and flowers stopped,
drink it. Wounds and corrupt ulcers, stamp it green with honey, and apply
it. 6 Pappes hard, stamp it green, and apply it, and so it heals also all
venomous bitings. 7 Dead child, and inward bruises, seethe it in vinegar and
drink it. 8 Sweat to cause, anoint with the juice.

Bitings venom. 9. 6 Bladder stopped 1 Breasts hard 6 Bruised 7 Dead child 7
Flowers stopped 5 Gout 2 Iaundies 3 Kidneis stopped 1 Liver stopped 1 Milt stopped 1
Sciatica 4 Sweat to cause 8 Ulcers 5 Wounds 5
Charloke.
CHarloke Rapistrum, is not used in medicin, but some use the seed thereof for
Musterseede, and it may serve in steed thereof, but it is not all out so good.

Carrots.
CArrots: mother, drink one spoonefull of the juice of ye roots of wild
Carrots, with a little drink, and apply the dross to the privy place. 2
Sodden tenderly in meat, they are pleasant, and wholesome, they nourish well,
and warm all the inner parts being eaten moderatly. 3 The green leaves
bruised with honey applied, does cleanse unclean fretting sores. 4 The feeds
of wild Carrots drunk or applied to the matrix, brings down flowers, it
provoke urine being drunk, and is good against all venomous bitings and
stingings. 5 He that takes it aforehand, shall not be bitten of serpents: it
is good for conception. 6 The root drives out urine, and provoke venery. 7
And laid to the convenient place, it brings forth the child that sticks
in the birth. 8 The Garden Carrots has the same virtues, but not so strong,
but yet more fit for meat, and provoke venery. 9 The roots especially of
the wild Carrot, provoke urine, taken in any sort, and increases love. 10 The
powder thereof drunk with honied water, opens the stoppings of the liver,
milt, and kidneys and is good for the gravel and the Iaundies. 11 The seed of
ye wild provoke terms, helps the suffocation of ye mother: being drunk
in wine, or used in pessaries, it provoke urine, casts out gravel, and is
good for the strangury and dropsy, and for the pain of the sides, belly, and
reins, against all venom, and venomous bitings. 12 The seeds of garden
Carrots have like virtues, but not so strong. 13 The seeds especially of the
wild sodden in wine, draws down the terms and urine, and water of the
dropsy. 14 The root used in meats, is good against the dropping of the
urine, it may be kept in vinegar and honey as other roots. 15 The seed,
herb, or root sodden and applied, brings down the dead birth, the
seconds, and the flowers. 16 And stamped with honey and applied, it is good
against the pockes, kankers and fretting sores, which eat the flesh and
skin. 17 The seed sodden in wine helps the chollike, and wind in the
stomach and the hyckit.

Carway.
CArway: To clear the sight, hold thy eyes over the vapor of the seeds
powdered and sprinkled upon hot Barley bread. 2 Drink the decoction of the
seeds to provoke urine. 3 Carway breaks wind, helps the cough, and is
good against the frenzy, and venomous bitings, with Alome it helps scabs and
tetters, and restores hair. 4 The seed is good for the stomach and the
mouth, it helps digestion, provoke urine, and dissolueth all windiness of
the inward parts, and is of the virtue of Anniseedes. 5 The roots boiled, are
good to be eaten as Carrets. 6 The young stalks are wonderful pleasant in a
Sallad vnsodden. 7 The herb serves to make sweet and well smelling pottage,
it makes a sweet breath. 8 The roots are better then Persnips. 9 Both seeds
and the herb are good against hot swellings. 10 Seethe it in wine, and
drink it to purge the reins.

Back greefes 10 Bitings venom. 3 Breath ill 7 Cough 3 Digestion 4 Eyes dull 1
Frenzy 3 Hair fallen 3 Skabbes 3 Swellings 9 Tetters 3 Urine stopped 2
Windiness 3
Cassiafistula.
CAssiafistula: to purge a woman with child, stamp half an ounce, and seethe
it in white wine, and streine it, and let her drink it and lie upon her bed,
if the child be full of venom all about, it shall be clarified and live, and
the woman whole: proved. 2 The inner pulp is a very sweet and pleasant
medicine, and may be taken of all people that are weak, and women with child,
without danger. It loses the belly and purges choler chiefly, and
sometimes phlegm gathered about the guts, one ounce being taken: it is very
good for hot Fevers, the Plurisie, the Iaundies, or any other inflammation of
the liver, especially mixed with waters, drinks or herbs that be of cooling
nature, it is good for the reins or kidneis, it expels the gravel and
stone, and preserves against the stone, mixed with the decoction of licoras, or
the roots of Persley or Cythes, or a decoction of all together and drunk. 3
Throat swollen, Garlike with Cassia to dissolve and break the Apostume. 4 Gout,
apply it. 5 It may be eaten alone, or tempered with Endive water, or Goats
wheye, or Barley water. 6 It is good in washing and clensing glisters to soften
hard Apostumes being laid to. 7 With Hierapicra, use it for pain in the guts,
with syrup of Licoras for the reins. 8 That which is shining black is best,
it cleanses the blood, and quenches the blood and choler, and is good in
Agues before bloodletting. 9 But to some it is a poison, especially such as
have slipperie and weak guts, to such it must be given with Myrabolanes,
Rubarbe, Mastike, and Spikenard. 10 But to them that are much bound, with oil
of Almonds, or with Mussilage of Fleawort, it is excellent for ye stopping of
the urine being taken with medicines therefore, as Persley, Alisander seed,
Fenell seed, and such like, because it works very slowly, some increase the
strength thereof with Hysope, or the wheye of Gotes milk. 11 Many give it with
Hierapicra, or with syrup of Roses solutiue, or the syrup of Cycorie with
Rubarbe, or such like: the dose is commonly one ounce, two hours before dinner.

Apostume 3. 6 Back ache 7. 2 Belly ache 7 Blood cleansing 8 Conception 1
Correction 9. 10 Dose 11 Fever 8 Gout 4 Iaundies 2 Liver stopped 2 Plurisie 2
Purgation 1. 2. 5 Squincie 3 Stone 2 Throat swollen 3 Urine stopped 10
Cats tail.
CAts tail, or red Mace, the down thereof mixed with Swines grease well washed,
heals burnings and skaldings. 2 And the same down heals broken and hollow
kibes being laid on.

Burnings 1 Kibes 2
Cedria.
CEdria, the liquour of Cedar swageth toothache being put therein. Eyes dull,
spots and skarres apply the liquour. 2 Ears worms, drop it in with vinegar. 3
Ears noise and dull, put it in with the decoction of Hysope in wine. 4 Being
put into dead bodies, it preserves them from corruption, but it consumes and
corrupts the flesh of living bodies. 5 It kills lice, and all such vermin,
and preserves against worms and mothes and such like being anointed
therewith. 6 The fruit is good to be eaten against the strangurie, and to
provoke urine and ye terms.

Ears dull 3. noise 3. worms 2 Eyes dull 1 Spots 1 Lice 6. 5 Mothes 5
