Celondine.
Mix the juice with honey, and seethe it in a vessel of Copper or Brass, and
drop it into the eyes to clear the sight, and to avoid the spots, skars,
blemishes, bloodshooting and web. 2 Mix it with wine, and wash fretting and
consuming sores therewith to heal them. 3 Seethe ye root in white wine with
Anniseedes, and drink it for ye stopping of the liver and the Iaundies. 4
Chewe the root to help the tooth ache. 5 Stamp it and apply it 14. days to
all Ringwormes, Tetters, Impetigo, and Serpigo, and black spots, wheresoever
they be morning and evening to heal them. 6 Sees it in white wine and receive
the vapor thereof into the mouth to heal the kanker, and to assuage the pain
that comes by watching. 7 Stamp it with old grease, brimstone, and salt,
and anoint all balde places therewith, and to help the skabbes and griefs of
the head. 8 Seethe a good handful of the roots in a pint and half of Rose
vinegar, and put thereto one ounce and a half of Treacle, and drink thereof
ii. or iii. ounces, and cover thee well to sweat against ye plague. 9 Apply
the herb or juice to heal fistulaes, creeping sores, pockes and kankers. 10
The root with the herb stamped and applied to the navel, helps the
torments of the guts. 11 The powder of it purges and heals wounds. 12
Seethe the herb in wine, and apply to the belly against the chollike. 13 Eyes
bloodshot, stamp Celondine with Wormwood, with the white of an Egg, and Rose
water, and apply it when you go to bed. 14 Breast kanker, apply the juice with
ye dung of a white Goose. Flowers stopped, wear Celondine under thy feet. 15
Anoint any chaps wheresoever with ye juice thereof and vinegar when you go to
bed. 16 Drink the juice of it to drive forth ye water of ye dropsy by urine.
17 For the headache, boil Celondine with butter, and streine it and keep it
in a close box, and anoint therewith: it is a precious ointment, and also wash
the head with the decoction thereof afterward. 18 Iaundies: seethe the root
in stale, and drink it three days. 19 Kanker, wash it well with wine or
vinegar, and then apply the juice of the herb and roots thereof. 20 Anoint
all skabs with the juice to heal them. 21 Stingings, stamp ye root and
herb, and apply it. 22 The juice dries up wounds, and with swines grease it
heals them up. 23 Iaundies, seethe the root and herb of Celondine chopped
small one pottell, in water in a close vessel, and make thereof to bathe
therein. Take powder of Columbine seeds two drams, Saffron one penie weight,
vinegar water one ounce, Celondine water two ounces, and drink it first and
last, stamp the green root as much as a Walnut, and streine it with a
dishfull of milk or wine, and drink it iiii. hours before meat, and walk
after it. 24 Legs black and swollen, stamp it with Horehound, and herb
Benit, and seethe it in water to the one half, and wash therewith iii. or
iiii. times eueryday. 25 Sores old and stinking, mix the juice of it and
Planten with Honey, and the yolke of an Egg ana with Barley flower, and apply
it raw. 26 Skabs to heal, anoint with the juice and Brimstone. 27 For all
diseases of the liver, lungs, Iaundies, and all other griefs, seethe the juice
of it with possitale, and clarify it and drink it with Sugar. 28 To make one
to break wind, make powder of the root, Ants eggs, and a little ginger, and
give it in meat or drink, and he shall fart till he drink water. 29
Ringwormes, anoint with the juice of Celondine, or mix musterde with black
soap, and the juice of Celondine, and apply it. 30 Eyes dull, and worms in
them, 31 Eyes web and pearl, streine the juice of it with Aloes, and drop
thereof into the eye. 32 Gout burning, stamp Celondine and fry it with guilts
grease, and put thereto as much powder of brimstone, as will hill the sore, and
anoint therewith. 33 Leaprie, stamp Celondine with vinegar, and apply it. 34
Skab general, anoint with the juice of Celondine, Rue, Centorie, and
Wormwood. 35 Face freckles, anoint with the juice of Celondine and wine, daily
till it be well. 36 Iaundies, stamp Celondine with ye roots thereof one
pound, of Licoras raced, a quarter of a pound, seethe them in a gallon of water
to the one half, and drink thereof. 37 Itch, take white vinegar one pint,
Rosemary and Celondine ana one handful, boil them and streine them, and put
in a quantity of white Coprose, while it is hot, and wash often therewith. 38
For all sores, especially green sores, put in the juice of Celondine and
Houseleeke ana into the wound, and apply the bruised herbs. 39 Head pushes,
sores, or biles, beat old grease, Brimstone, Celondine, and salt, and anoint
therewith. 40 Eyes sight to restore, mix the juice with the gall of a Cock
and honey, and anoint. 41 Squincie, swelling in the mouth, and to purge the
head, stamp the root, and sees it in wine and gargarise therewith. 42 Eyes
dull, put in the juice of Celondine (See in Alisander.) 43 Fellon, apply the
juice of Celondine and Planten, and it will go away. 44 Iaundies, sees the
roots of Celondine, Red-docks, and Nettles in white wine, and put honey to it,
and drink it morning and evening. 45 Bitten with a mad dog, drink Celondine
with wine. 46 Teeth to fall out without pain, rub them with the juice of
Celondine, and apply the substance. 47 Canker in the pap, anoint with the juice
of Celondine and Gotes doung. 48 Morphewe, anoint with the juice and powder of
Brimstone. 49 Drink it with thine own urine if thou have drunk poison. 50
Lay it under a sick man's head, with the heart of a Moldwarpe, if he be in
danger of death, he will immediately cry out or sing, if not, he will weep. 51
Tetter, Ringworme, or such like, and black spots, stamp it, and apply it
morning and evening fourteen days. 52 Bitings or stingings venomous, stamp
it with as much Planten and some stale urine, and apply it and drink the
juice of Planten. 53 Eyes pin, or web, drop in the juice of Celondine. 54
Ringworme, stamp it between two stones, and apply it often. 55 Stamp it
with old suet, and apply it to skabbes and ulcers, and wounds to heal them
speedily. 56 Yard canker, boil the juice of Celondine and Planten, and a
little salt, and apply it between the yard and the skin thereof. 57 Skabs
to dry up and heal, anoint often with the juice of Celondine. 58 Canker,
seethe the powder of Celondine and Roses in vinegar, till it be thick as
mustard, and anoint. 59 Black Iaundies, kneade Rye meal with the juices of
Celondine, Smalage, and Wormwood ana one handful, and bake it on the hearth,
and receive up the vapor of it at the mouth, hanging a kerchiefe over thy
head, and do so four or five times, and be whole. 60 For all diseases of the
liver, lunges, Iaundies, and all other inward griefs, seethe the juice of
Celondine with possit ale, and clarify it, and drink it with Sugar.

Centorie.
CEntorie: for worms that eat ye hairs of the head and face, mix the gall
of an ox or sheep with Centorie, and boil them in wine or vinegar, and
anoint therewith. 2 Eyes red and dull, put in the juice of it and of hounds
tongue. 3 Ears dull, put in the juice with the gall of an eele with tents. 4
Appetite to cause, seethe Centorie and Planten, and Pepper in wine, and drink
it luke warm three nights to bedward. 5 Teeth worms, apply the juice. Breast
pain, seethe it in water and drink it. 6 Coughes dry, seethe it in stale ale
and stamp it and seethe it again in the same ale, and streine it and put
thereto a third part of honey, and boil it till it be as thick as honey, and
take thereof iii. spoonefull fasting to cleanse the stomach from gleete and be
whole. 7 Reins grief, drink the juice with vinegar: biting or stinging, the
juice with water. 8 To provoke appetite, and to cleanse the stomach and
breast, and to purge the back and reins, and heal them, seethe it in water
and drink it. 9 Worms, sees it with Wormwood in milk, and drink it
fasting. 10 Brain weak, mix Centorie, Rue, and Fenell seed, with strong
vinegar, and drink it in the mornings, and shave thy head, and apply thereto a
black Cock cloven through the midst four and twenty hours, and then bleed
in the master vein of the head and in the arm likewise. 11 Breast griefs,
seethe it in white wine, and stamp it and seethe it again therein and streine
it, and drink two or three spoonefull with Sugar candy as often as need is. 12
Eyes watring, apply Centorie to the nape of the neck. Ague cake, use to drink
Centorie water. 13 Phlegm to break and void, seethe it in white wine or ale
with Licoras, and streine it and drink it with Sugar morning and evening, and
for horsenesse with Sugar candy. 14 Stinging of a Snake or Adder, steep it in
new Ale and streyne it and drink it, and also stamp thereof with gray salt,
and apply it to the wound. 15 Fever quarten, stamp it and streine it with
ale, and drink it before the fit. 16 Fever quotidian, drink as much powder as
one small Walnut with wine, and drink a little more wine after it to cleanse
thy mouth. 17 Fever of the gall, drink one dram of the powder three mornings
fasting with white wine, it helps also digestion, the cough, and
costiuenesse. 18 To cleanse the head, cheast, and stomach, seethe iii.
handful in a gallon of water, to the one half, cleanse it, and put thereto
one pint of honey clarified to the one half, and drink two spoonefull at once
first and last. 19 Bitings venomous, drink it with thine own urine. 20
Appetite to cause, use Centory any way. 21 Dropsy, distill it with Sage and
water Cresses, of each like much, and drink the water first and last. 22 Eyes
dull, or web, eat the seeds. 23 Palsy, seethe it in wine and oil, and apply
it for ache of the back, and all evils within the body, drink it with cold
water. 24 Spitting matter, seethe it in oil of Masticke, and anoint the chest
therewith where it is sore. Teethe worms, put in the juice. 25 Eyes smarting,
put in the juice with woman's milk. Ears worms put in the juice of Centory
and Leekes. 27 Drink the juice against all poison. 28 Drink the juice four
mornings to have a clear voice, and to cleanse the breast meruailously. 29 For
all griefs in the stomach, and to cause appetite, stamp two handful, and
seethe it in three quartes of Ale to the one half, then put thereto one pint
of honey, and take thereof every morning three spoonefull. 30 Stamp Gentian one
part, Centory two parts, and distill them, and drink the water morning and
evening to preserve the body from all diseases, to void all impostumes, to
cause a good coullour, to resist the plague, to help the ptysicke, to cleanse
the stomach and milte from watrish humors, to break the stones in the reins,
and to provoke the flowers, and to purge the belly, void choler, and cleanse
the blood, to heal all inward wounds, to clear the sight, and cure venomous
bitings, but to cure the wounds, put powder of Centory to it, and use it nine
days. 31 Worms, seethe it in water to the third part, and drink it. 32 Eyes
griefs, anoint with the juice and honey. 33 Wound swelling, stamp it and apply
it. 34 Fevers cold, anoint the pulses and plants with the juice. 35 Blood
casting, drink the juice of it and Cheruile with Pease broth. 36 Breath
stinking, belching, and loss of appetite, and to cleanse the chest and
stomach, seethe it in wine or water, and drink it. 37 Back ache, drink it
and Yarrow with vinegar. 38 Thirst continual, stamp it with the root of
Louage, and drink them with wine or water iii. nights to bedward. 39 Eyes to
be clear, put in the juice of Centory the greater with honey. 40 Drink the
juice or powder with wine to help all venomous bitings, but with vinegar for
inward poison. 41 Anoint the sores of the bitings with the juice of it. 42
Ears dull, put in the clear juice of it. 43 To open a wound, stamp it well,
and apply it. 44 The water of it helps the griefs of the liver and milt,
causes appetite, and is good for the worms, and salsflegme. 45 Centory must
be gotten between our Lady days. 46 Breast phlegm, and the stomach, steep the
tops of green Centory in ale or beer all night, and drink it fasting, but in
winter take the root with white wine. 47 Breast to cleanse, seethe Centory and
Hysope in white wine, and drink it iii. days. 48 Sees it in water or wine to
purge downward chollerike, flegmatike, and gross humors, and for the
sciatica, purge therewith till the blood come. 49 It is very good against the
stopping of the liver, the Iaundies, and hardness of the milt. 50 The
decoction drunk, kills and expels worms, and is good for the crampe, and
all diseases of the sinowes. 51 The juice applied in a pessarie, provoke
terms, and expels the dead birth. 52 Stamp the herb green, and apply it
to heal fresh and new wounds, and old ulcers that are hard to cure. 53 The
powder thereof in plasters and ointments, powders and such like, fills up
hollow fistulaes, and sores with flesh, and does molifie all hardness. 54
Drink the syrup thereof with a little vinegar and salt to cleanse the body. 55
The leaves and flowers sodden and drunk, is good against all raw humors of
gross flegmes watrie or windy, it does cleanse blooddy matter within the body
of man or woman. 56 The powder in a pessarie draws forth the dead birth. It
is wholesome against the plague in the Winter time. 57 The decoction of it is
good in glisters for the sciatica. 58 The juice put in with wool, draws
down the terms. 59 The juice drunk heals the griefs of the sinowes. 60
Centory is good against the stopping of the milt and liver, the chollike, the
ache of the mother, spitting blood, and to kill worms. 61 And applied to the
region of the milt, it does soften it. 62 The juice may be streyned out and
dried against the Sun for all griefs aforesaid in this wise: gather it when
it is ready to seed, steep it five days in water and seethe it, till the
better half be wasted, then streyne it, and seethe it again to the
thickenesse of honey, and so keep it: the like may be done with any herb or
flower. For the Balm of it (See in Betony.)

Cetrache.
CEtrache: milt stopped, and fever quarten, take the leaves forty days with
vinegar, or boil it in wine, and apply it to the hardness. It also is very
good for the strangurie, stone in the bladder, heat of the urine, yexing,
stopping of the liver, and the Iaundies: but it is not good for women that
would have many children.

Fever quarten Iaundies Liver stopped Milt hard Stone Strangurie Urine hot
Cherytree.
CHerytree: Ringworme, and Tetter, dissolve the gum in vinegar, and anoint
therewith. 2 Strangurie, drink powder of the kernels with Gotes milk. 3 Eyes
mystie, dropping and red, put in water of the flowers distilled in May, morning
and evening cold. 4 Stamp the middle rind, and streine it with white wine,
and drink it iii. or iiii. times to void the stone, grauel, and urine
presently. 5 Stone, drink the gum dissolved in white wine. 6 Headache of
choler, bleed in the vein of the liver, and eat sower Cheries. 7 Stomach
hot, use confections of Cheries. 8 Iaundies, seethe a handful of the leaves
in a pint of milk, and drink thereof a good draught morning and evening. 9
For the heat of the liver and stomach, and the hot fever, and to cause
appetite, eat conserve of Cheries in the mornings six hours before any other
meat. 10 For heat in the night by the fever, hold the conserve in thy mouth.
11 Fevers of hot blood, drink the syrup of Violets, and water wherein black
Cheries have been sodden. 12 Falling evil, drink the water of the leaves or
flowers. 13 The gum dissolved in old wine and drunk by sups, eases the
sharp arteries of the breast, and voydeth belching and lothing. 14 Sweet
Cheries eaten fasting with their kernels, loses the belly so strongly, that
the feet being sore shall be healed thereby. 15 Cheries sodden in vinegar
with Pears and drunk with Masticke, do greatly bind the bellye. 16 The
gum does mightily break the stone, and loose the gravel. 17 Make Conserve
of Cheries as of Barberies, but not with so much Sugar. 18 Cheries eaten before
meat, loosen the belly very gently, but they nourish but little, and are
hurtful unto moist and unhealthy stomakes, especially the small Cheries, which
do often breed agues, and other maladies. 19 The red sour Cheries do
likewise loosen the belly, and are more wholesome and convenient for the stomach,
for they do partly comfort, and partly slake thirst. 20 The black sour
Cheries do strengthen the stomach more then the rest, and being dried, they
stop the laske. 21 The gum of the mazer or wild Cherytree, of the Spanish
Cherie, and our common sower Cherytree is good to be drunk in wine for the
gravel and the stone, and excoriation of the throat, lungs, and breast, the
cough and hoarsenesse. 22 The water distilled of the fresh and new gathered
Cheries, is good to be powered into the mouths of them that have the falling
sickness, as often as the course of the fit does trouble them. 23 Cheries
breed good blood, cause appetite, cut phlegm and gross humors, expel urine,
and soften the belly, being eaten when they are fresh: and being condited with
sugar, they are good for them that be sick of inflammations and extreme
heates. 24 And being dried in an oven, they are good against all flures. 25 The
distilled water of the wild black Cheries, is good for them that have lost
their speech. 26 The gum dissolved in wine, is good for the old cough. 27
Tart Cheries be more wholesome then sweet, and eaten before meat, they mollify
the belly, and prepare digestion, and are most excellent in hot burning
choler, and are good also after meat. 28 The gum sodden in Wine and drunk,
helps old coughes, causes good coullour, sharpeneth the sight, helps
digestion, and cleanses out gravel from the reins. 29 The stones break the
stone, if they be eaten dry or made milk. Preserved Cheries and Plummes, are
without danger: but beware of surfeiting by Cheries raw.

Cheruill.
CHeruill eaten with other meats is good for the stomach, it gives taste to
meat, and causes appetite. 2 Strangurie, boil it in wine and drink it, and
also apply the herb to the region of the bladder. 3 It is good for them that
be dull, old and without courage, to rejoice and to comfort them, and increase
their strength. 4 It dissolueth bruised blood, especially with the powder of
the burned eyes of crabs, and the coals of the Linden tree. 5 It is good for
the plurisie and pricking in the side. 6 Being used in sallads, it is good for
the stomach and head. 7 The leaves bruised and applied, are a good remedy
against bruises, it is good for the stone in the kidneys. 8 Liver and milt
stopped, eat Cheruil and use powder of the seeds of it. 9 Sides ach, drink
Cheruil with wine. 10 Swellings sudden in the lims, Seethe Cheruil, and
Hartstong chopped small with dregs of ale, wheat bran and sheeps sewet, till
they be thick, and apply it. 11 For a woman that has her throws before her
time, seethe a good handful in a quart of Claret wine, and drink thereof at
all times needful. 12 Mouth ranker, apply the juice of Cheruill and Woodbine
often to it. 13 The seed expels the urine and stone. 14 The herb is very
good against Carbuncles, and venomous bytings. 15 Drink it with wine to provoke
urine, and to take away the ache in the reins and bladder. It also expels
wind and helps the griefs of the liver, and all kinds of madness, and
staieth vomiting. 16 And stamped with vinegar it destroys the wildefire, and
heals the canker and all other wounds. 17 Headache, drink the juice of
Cheruill daily fasting. 18 For wounds that penetrate, drink the juice of
Cheruil, or the decoction, or water thereof, or of Cheruill. To know whether a
man that is wounded shall live or die.
19 To know whether a wounded man shall live or die, let him drink it, if he
cast it not up he shall live and be cured, let him drink daily Pimpernell,
Sanicle, and Bugle. 20 Wounds bleeding and sore within, drink Cheruil, and Nep
in wine. (See Centorie.) 21 For all griefs of the mouth, seethe it in water
and wash therewith often. (See Alehoofe, Briony.) 22 Lean to be, take one
egshell full of the juice every morning fasting. 23 Mouth stinking, eat
Cheruill. 24 Canker, stamp it with honey and apply it.

Appetite to cause 1 Bitings venomous 14 Blood bruised 4. 7 Carbuncles 14
Dullness 3 Headache 17 Kanker 16. 24 Lean to be 22 Liver stopped 8. 15 Madness
general 15 Milt stopped 8 Mouth griefs 21. 23 Mouth Canker 12 Plurisie 5 Reins
ache 15 Sides ache 9 Sides pricking 5 Stone 7. 13 Strangurie 2 Swelling sudden
10 Vomiting to stop 15 Urine to expel 13. 15 Wildfire 16 Wind to expel 15
Wounds bleeding 20 Wounds general 16. 18
Chestnuts.
CHestnuts are best kept and preserved amongst Wallnuts, eat them fasting with
honey for the cough. 2 Flux to stop, boil the middle red bark in water to the
third part and drink thereof. 3 Chestnuts of all wild fruits are the best
and meetest to be eaten, for they nourish reasonably well, but they be hard of
digestion, and do stop the belly: with the meal of Chestnuts and honey, is
made a good electuarie against the cough and spetting of blood. 4 The powder
thereof with barley meal and vinegar applied, does cure unnatural blastings
and swellings of the breasts. 5 The polished red bark boiled and drunk does
stop the laske, the bloody flixe and all other flixes and issues of blood. 6
Chestnuts make fat, stop flixes, and harden the milt. 7 Stamp them with honey
and salt and apply it to the biting of a mad dog to heal it. 8 They cause
lust, and offend the head and milt. 9 Prick through the husks with a knife and
roasted and eaten with honey fasting, they are good for the cough, but their
chief force is in binding and stopping flixes. 10 Acorns are much like in
operation.

Bitings venomous 7 Blasting 4 Bloody flixe 5. 6 Breasts swollen 4 Cough 1. 3.
9 Fat to be 6 Fluxes 2. 5. 6 Laskes 5. 6 Lust to cause 8 Mad dog 7 Spetting
blood 3 Swellings 4
Chickweed.
CHickweed, great Chickweed stamped and applied to the eyes, or the juice
thereof is good against all their inflammations and hot ulcers, and likewise
for all ulcers and inflammations of the privy parts. 2 Ears ache, drop in
the juice. 3 Boil small Chickweed in water and salt, and wash the hands often
therewith for their heat and skyruy itch. 4 Joints ach and swollen, seethe it
with Camomil and wheat bran in grounds of Ale or Beer and apply it. 5 Stamp
Chickweed and apply it to wounds to keep them from impostumation and to draw
the corruption out of them. 6 Seethe it with vinegar and gargle therewith often
warm, to draw phlegm from the head, and to help the tooth ache. 7 Seethe it
in wine and drink it to cleanse the reins of the back. 8 Apply it with barley
meal to the inflammations of the eyes. 9 Apply it to all inflammations or
gatherings of blood and choler. 10 It is good for wounds, it withstandeth
swellings, it draws out pricks and splents. 11 The juice helps tooth ache
put into the nostrell of the contrary side to the ache. 12 The juice with fine
honey, clears the eyes, and takes away the white or red spots thereof. 13 It
is good for the stone in the kidneys, the dropsy, griefs of the liver and
kidneys, and the swelling of the fundament. 14 The juice put into ye nose,
purges rotten filth from the head, and drunk with mulse, it scowreth the
belly. 15 It has all the virtues of Parietary, and of Purslen, and is good
against consumptions either used by it self or drunk with wine. 16 The same
is good to be given to young children that be troubled with sickness and great
inward heat, and to prevent the cramps. 17 The juice it self or the water or
herb is good against hot wounds or ulcers, and therewith may be made cooling
ointments as is said in housleeke, as good as Populeon. 18 Seethe it bruised in
running water to the one half, and wash therewith three or four days as hot
as may be suffered for the heat and worms in the hands. 18 Uvula fallen, roast
one handful in the embers, and apply it to the bone of the neck as hot as
may be suffered, and lay a plaster of sower leaven to the molde of the head
ix. days. 20 Eye perle, apply it with the gleyr of an egg, a little dry
Saffron, and a spoonefull of woman's milk, with flax upon the eye. 21 Stone
and Strangurie, stamp one handful with black soap and fresh butter of each
as much as a nutmeg, and fry them, and apply them to the navel. 22 Teeth ache,
seethe the leaves and roots in water and gargle therewith. 23 Bruise and apply
it with grounds of Ale or Beer, and wheat bran thrice a day of a reasonable
thickness. 24 Stone and chollick, take Chickweed one handful, bright soap,
and sweet butter ana as much as three nuts, fry them till they be brown, and
apply it to the navel as hot as may be suffered. 25 Headache, anoint with the
juice of Chickweed, ground Iuy and Housleek two nights, to avoid it. 26
Iaundies, stamp it and streine it with stale ale or white wine, and drink it
first and last five days. 27 Child iaw fallen, moldfall, or roof fallen, roast
one handful in the embers, and apply it to the bone of the neck, and apply
sower leaven of white bread to the mold of the head ix. hours to raise it. 28
Seethe the leaves and roots in water, and hold it in thy mouth to void the
toothach. 29 Eyes blood and white spots, put in the juice of Chickweed and
blackbery tops. 30 Eyes dull and blemishes, put in the juice of Chickweed. 31
Seethe Chickweed and apply it to the pecten and yard, if the pain increase,
the stone is in the bladder, if not, it is in the reins. 32 Flowers stopped,
roast it in the embers and apply it to the matrixe. Cramp, eat the juice with
fresh beef or mutton or in a sallad.

Back griefs 7. 13 Bruises 23 Childrens griefs 16. 27 Chollick 24

Cinnamom.
CInnamom comfort the stomach and principal parts of the body. 2 An
excellent water of Cinnamom, beat one pound of good Cinnamom somewhat gross,
and steep it in a pottell of good rose water with as much Sack or Canary
wine, or else in a gallon of wine without rose water in a close vessel xxiiii.
hours, then still it in a limbek, and keep a pint of the first water by it
self, for the latter will be weaker: some put one pound of good Sugar candy to
it with the Cinnamom to steep to make it pleasant, and that is the best way. It
has innumerable virtues especially to restore and preserve: it strengthens
the brain, stomach, liver, milt and sinews, one spoonefull taken now and
then. 3 Cinnamom helps the stopping of the liver, flixes of all sorts, the
dropsy, all pain of the guts, lungs and breast. It causes a sweet breath,
and is good in sops and blaunch powder. 4 Ears griefs, use it with oil:
flowers and urine stopped, use it with Myrrh. 5 Stomach cold, make powder of
Cinnamom, Galangal, Mints, and Sugar, and use it upon tostes with Ale or Wine.
6 Teeth to be white, and breath to be sweet. Mix powder of Cinnamom and
Coral with vinegar of squilles, and rub them therewith. 7 Yard apostumed, blow
in powder of Cinnamom that has lost his virtue, and of the pil of a
Pomegranate between the skin and the yard. 8 Flux, mix powder of vii. or
viii. Acorns, with two drams of Cinnamom, and a quantity of fine chalk, and
seethe them in Sack, and drink it and none other drink xxiiii. hours. 9
Chaps, put in powder of Cinnamom.

In paste, one pound of the powder of it with oil of sweet Almonds till it be
like an ointment, and warm it, and let it stand in a earthen vessel well glased
and close covered xiiii. days, then heat it and press out the oil, it
preserves the stomach from corruption being used both inward and outward. (See
Almonds, Yarow, Knotgrasse, Horsetaile.)

Belly griefs 3 Breast griefs 3 Breath ill 3 Chaps 9 Chollick 3 Dropsy 3
Ears griefs 4 Fluxes general 3. 8 Flowers stopped 4 Liver grief 2. 3 Lungs
griefs 3 Milt grief 2 Sinews griefs 2 Sickness general 2 Stomach griefs
1. 5 Teeth clensing 6 Urine stopped 4 Yard apost. 7
Cimbelaris. (See Penywort.)

Cicory.
CIcory. Liver pain, use the broth, decoction, or powder of Cicory or Endive
with water and honey. 2 Breasts to be round, little, and hard, anoint them with
the juice. 3 Headache, anoint with the juice, oil of roses and vinegar, and
apply it. 4 Eyes dull, put in the distilled water. 5 Iaundies, seethe the roots
and flowers in wine with as much water, and drink thereof morn and even. 6
Liver griefs cut three or four roots, and seethe them in a quart of water
till the third part or more be wasted, then cool it and drink thereof in the
mornings, but not too much at once. 7 The juice opens the stoppings of the
liver, milt, kidneys, and bladder caused of heat. 8 The juice put into the
eyes, sharpeneth the sight, and put into the ear or nostrell on the contrary
side, it helps the tooth ache. 9 Fever Tertian, drink the juice. 10 Liver and
milt griefs, drink the juice in the mornings with sugar. 11 Cicory and Endive,
do comfort a weak and feeble stomach, and do cool and refresh a hot
stomach. 12 Drink the juice of Cicory for the heat of the liver, the Iaundies,
hot fevers, and tertians. 13 Stamp the green leaves of Endive and Cicory, and
apply them to hot inflammations, impostumes or gatherings of evil humors of
the stomach, the trembling of the heart, the hot gout, and inflammation of the
eyes. 14 And with parched barley meal to all chollerick inflammations, S.
Anthonies fire, and such like. 15 Apply the juice of the leaves in Cicory and
Endive, with oil of roses and vinegar to the forehead for the head ache. 16
And with ceruse and vinegar to all tumors, impostumes and inflammations that
require cooling. 17 Seethe the herbs and eat them for the heat and stopping
of the liver and milt, and to comfort the stomach. 18 Use Cycory and Endive
any way to cool the heat of the liver, to open and strengthen it, and to
preserve health, especially in the broth of a Chicken, or drink a good draught
fasting with sugar, or the syrop, or the green herbs used as Sage in Ale. 19
Seethe a handful of Cicory in water, and drink it to draw down choler. 20
Seethe the herb and root of Cicory in Wine or water, and drink it hot
against the obstruction of the liver and mile, especially in the beginning of
the dropsy. 21 Apply Cicory leaves to all impostumes, swellings, inflammations
and pusshes of the priuities, the hot gout, the scabs of childrens heads, and
to all aches coming of heat. 22 Seethe Cicory in Wine, and eat it with meat
to help digestion. 23 Stamp the root and flowers, and apply them to the gout
to ease it forthwith, and to the holy fire to allay the great heat of it. 24
Mix the juice of Cicory, Endive, and Hartestong with sugar, and seethe it with
a little water and vinegar, and use often to drink it for the stopping of the
liver and milt, after that take the purging pills of Rubarbe, and after that
some Triasandali. 25 Drink the boiled juice of Cicory to losen the belly, and
to help the stomach, liver, and kidneys. 26 Apply the distilled water to the
pestilent pusshes with linen clothes. 27 Bruise the herb and root, and make
thereof round cakes which afterward mix and dissolve in rose water, and
anoint any scabbed place therewith to heal it and make the skin fair. 28
Gather the flowers betime in the mornings, and distill them in Balneo Mariae,
and use the water for the pin, web, mystines, and ulcers, and diverse other
griefs of the eyes. 29 Cast the flowers of Cycory among a heap of Ants or
pismires, and they will soon become as red as blood. (See Endive.)

Aches hot 21 Apostume hot 13. 16. 21 Back griefs 7. 25 Bladder griefs 7
Breast griefs 2 Children scabbed 21. 27 Choler 19 Digestion 22 Dropsy 20
Eyes griefs 48. 13. 28 Experiment 29 Fever hot 12. tertian 9. 12 Gout hot
13. 21. 23 Heart griefs 13 Head ache 3. 15 Holy fire 23 Hot griefs 13
Iaundies 5. 12 Impostume 13. 16. 21 Inflammations 13. 14. 16. 21 Liver griefs
1. 6. 2. 10. 12. 17. 18. 20. 24. 25. Milt griefs 10. 12. 18. 20. 24. 25.

Cycers.
CIcers white, apply a plaster of the meal to the apostume of the cods. 2
Scabs in the head or else where, wash with the decoction of Ciches peason.

Cods apostume 1 Head scabs 2 Scabs 2
Cyperus.
CYperus, or English Galangal, make powder of ye root with Amber and Pepper,
and drink it for the grauel, stone and stopping of urine, and to swage the
pain. 2 Matrix pain of wind, drink one dram of the root with good white
wine. 3 Sores moist, put in powder of the roots. 4 The roots boiled and drunk,
provoke urine and terms, expels the stone, and is good for the dropsy,
poison, venomous bytings and stingings. 5 Mother, cold, and stopped, seethe it in
water and bathe therein warm. 6 Use powder thereof to old running sores of the
mouth and secret parts that waste the flesh, laid on with wine. 7 It is very
good to be put into hot ointments and plasters. 8 The seeds drunk with water,
stop the flixe and all superfluous running forth of flowers, but too much
thereof taken causes headache. 9 The roots laid among clothes, gives them a
sweet smell. 10 Powder of the root mixed with as much powder of Bays, and
drunk with the urine of a chaste boy and also applied on the belly, helps the
dropsy marueilously. (See Spignell, Galangall.)

Ache 1 Bitings venomous 4 Flowers stopped 4. 8 Fluxes 8 Gravel 1 Matrix griefs
2. 8 Mouth sores 6 Poison 4 Priuities sores 6 Sores moist 3. 6 Stingings 4
Venom 4 Urine stopped 14
Cipers tree.
CIpers tree: the fruit taken into the body stops the laske and the bloody
flixe, spetting blood and all issues of blood, and so does the decoction
thereof made in water. 2 The oil wherein the fruit or leaves have been sodden,
does strengthen the stomach, stops vomiting, and stops the belly and all
other fluxes of the same, and cures the excoriation and going off of the skin
from the secret parts. 3 Cipres nuts cure them that are bursten and have their
gut fallen into their cods being applied, and so does the leaves. 4 The fruit
thereof takes away the polip in the nose. 5 The same bruised with fat dry figs
does cure the swelling of the cods, and with leaven put thereto, it dissolueth
botches and byles being applied. The leaves boiled in sweet wine or honyed
water, does help the strangurie and issue of the bladder. 6 The same stamped
small cures green wounds, and stops their bleeding being applied. 7 And
with parched barley meal it is good to be laid to the wildfire, carbuncles and
other ulcers and hot fretting sores. 8 The leaves and fruit laid to with
vinegar makes hair black.

Byles 5 Bladder griefs 5 Blood to stop 6 Bloody flixe 12 Botches 5 Bursten 3
Carbuncles 7 Cods swollen 3. 5 Hair to be black 8 Fluxes 1. 2 Nose polip 5
Priuities griefs 2 Sores 7 Stomach weak 2 Strangury 6 Ulcers 7 Vomiting 2
Wildfire 7 Wounds 5
Citrons.
CItrons. To give Wine a sweet odor stick it or an Orange full of Cloves,
and hang it into the vessel, so that it touch not the Wine, and stop it up
close that the odor go not out. (see Orenges, Wine, Bear, or Ale.)

Clary.
CLary: fry the leaves with newlayd eggs and butter, with powder of Cinnamom,
and eat them morn and even, first and last vii. days to stop the running of
the reins. Distill the flowers with Cloves, wine, and a little water, and use
the water for dull eyes. 2 Wash a canker or fester with the juice, and put in
powder of the same herb and use it. 3 Fevers phlegmatic, make an electuarie of
the juice of Clary, Smallach, and Fenell and use it. 4 Reins running, make a
tansy of Clary and eat it. 5 Reins wasting, prick the leaves, and fry them
with two or three yolks of eggs and powder of saffron, and fry them with fresh
butter and eat it fasting. 6 Feet bruised and sore, anoint with the juice of
Clary. 7 Seethe Clary and Nep of each a handful in possit ale and drink it to
bedward with Grayns, long Pepper, and Ginger. 8 Whites to stop, fry it with
butter and eat it fasting with Cinnamom, it is a restoratiue. 9 In what sort
so ever it be taken, it provoke the flowers, expels the seconds, and
provoke lust. 10 Boiled in Beer in stead of Hops, it causes drunkenness,
and headache, and it has all the virtues of wild Clary. 11 The seeds mixed with
honey clarify the dim eyes. 12 The seeds stamped with water and applied,
draws forth pricks, splents, and thorns, and scattreth all swellings, and so
does the green herb stamped and applied. 13 The seed especially of Occulus
Christi drunk with wine provoke lust. 14 Put two or three seeds into the
eyes to cleanse them and draw out mothes. 15 Chop the leaves small, and boil
them in sallet oil and anoint the back therewith for the grief thereof. 16
Clary with honey scowreth away the pin hawe and web in the eye. 17 Clary is
good for the back, and is a restoratiue in a a waste. A bundle of the leaves
boiled in broth or fried with yolks of eggs, and being often used brings great
ease. 18 Clary put into new must a certain time, or else sodden therewith, is
good for them that have cold stomachs, and for barren women, and such as are
troubled with the whites, and it cutteth phlegm. 19 The powder of Clary put
into the nose, brings down much water from the brain, and causes sneesing.
20 It is good in women's baths that want their flowers being sodden with
Penyroyall and other herbs of like virtue. 21 Seethe it with Planten in red
wine, and drink it to stop the whites. 22 Seethe it in wine and drink it
against cold griefs, and to stop the whites, it has the nature of Dittany.
23 With honey it cleanses the bloody spots in the eyes.

Consumption of nature, make a tansy of xii. or xvi. leaves of Clary, four new
laid eggs, and sweet butter, and use it to restore nature.

Backache 15. 17 Barennesse 18 Conception 18 Consumption 18 Eyes griefs 1. 11.
12. 14. 16. 23. Feet griefs 6 Fester 2 Fever 3 Flowee stopped 9. 20 Head purge
19 Kanker 2 Lust to cause 9. 13 Pricks 12 Reins running 14. 58. 21. 22
Restoratiue 9. 18 Seconds 9 Sneesing to cause 19 Sores 2 Stomach cold 18 Whites
to stop 14. 5. 8. 18. 21. 22.
Clauer.
CLauer or Trifoyl, boil it with the flowers, or by it self in honied water or
wine, and drink it to swage the hot burning and fretting of the bowels, or
seethe it in water, and take it with a glister for the same purposes. 2 The
same drunk in time convenient stops whites. 3 The flowers or leaves sodden
in oil, and applied, does ripen hot apostumes and swellings and other tumors
and breaks them, and sometime does dissolve them clean. 4 Wash thy head
with the decoction thereof and apply the herb unto the forehead for the
swimming, giddines and turning thereof. 5 The seeds and leaves sodden in wine
and drunk, helps the diseases of the sides, the falling sickness, the dropsy,
the strangury both in men and women, and purges the humors menstruall. 6
Drink three drams thereof with wine, to help all venomous bitings, and it will
suffer no venom to come within the body, and so it helps both tertians and
quarten Fevers. 7 It prevails much against poison or venom, if xxv. grayns of
the leaves or seeds be drunk. It heals wounds and cankers. 8 That with the
red flowers or Honey suckles may be used for Fenegreke. 9 Make lee therewith and
wash the headache therewith. 10 Vrin to cause, drink the seeds of it. 11
Seethe it well and apply it to any inward impostume to break it. 12 Eyes
griefs, put in the juice of that which has white spots on it. 13 Stamp it
finely raw with honey, and anoint to restore the hair, and to keep it from
falling: proved. 14 Drink it with wine for the chollicke and stone. 15 Head
giddy daseling and swimming, seethe it in water and wash therewith and apply
the herb to the forehead. 16 Fever tertian, stamp three slips, and drink the
juice with water. 17 Eyes perle or web, put in the juice, it clears the
sight, (See Honysuckle, Trifoyl.) 18 Treacle, or garden Clauer, ye leaves,
flowers, or seeds drunk in water, is good for the pain in the sides, the
plurisie, strangury, falling sickness, the dropsy, suffocation of the mother.
It provoke urine and terms, and cleanses the matrixe. 19 The leaves taken
with Oximel, is good against venomous bitings, and so is the decoction thereof
with the root being also washed therewith. 20 The leaves and roots are mixed with
Treacles and Mithridates, and preservatives made against poison and the plague.
21 Drink three crops with wine before the fit of the fever Tertian, and four
before the fit of the fever Quarten. 22 Boil the leaves in wine, and drink
it for the white flux of the matrix.

Apostume 3. 11 Bellyache 1 Bitings venomous 6. 19 Chollick 14 Dropsy 5. 18
Eyes griefs 12. 17 Falling evil 5. 18 Fever quarten 6. 21. tertian 6. 16. 21.
Flowers stopped 5. 18 Giddiness 4. 9. 15 Headache 9. griefs 4. 9. 15 Hair
falling 13 Impostume 3. 11 Kankers 7 Mother griefs 18. suffocation 18. Plague
20 Plurisie 18 Poison 20 Sides griefs 5. 18 Stone 14 Strangury 5. 18 Swellings
3 Venom 6. 19 Urine stopped 10. 18 Whites 2 Wounds 7
Cloves.
Cloves comfort the heart and stomach and liver, they help digestion and
stop the belly, they quicken the eye sight, scour away the clouds and hawes.
2 They are generally good for all cold diseases. 3 The oil of Cloves is good
for a cold stomach and brain, and all cold griefs. 4 Cloves comfort the
sinews and dissolve superflous humors: and being sodden whole in milk, or
the powder eaten in milk, they comfort the debilitie of nature, and stir up
Venus. 5 They are used both in meat and medicine to give a sweet savor, and
likewise to distilled waters and powders. 6 To dry up rheum, mix powder of
Cloves, Mace, Nutmegs, and Rosemary with sweet Sallet oil till it be some
what thick, and apply it to the crown of the head. Vomiting, drink four
grayns of Cloves with four or five spoonefuls of red wine. 7 Stone, put powder
of Cloves into Goats blood, and dry it in the sun, and drink the powder
thereof with the juice of Mugwort. 8 Mother suffocat. take up the fu^e of
Cloves, grayns, Frankincense, and other sweet smelling things into the body. 9
Stomach griefs general, seethe Cloves half an ounce, sugar aquartre: of a
pound, and Treacle a peniworth, a little in a quart of Malmsey, and drink
thereof daily warm, and use good no^ishing meats. 10 Cardiak passion use
Cloves. Stomach ^old and windy, cardiak passion and swooning, use Cloves. One
dram drunk with milk fasting, causes Venus. 11 Brain weak, use Cloves and
Ma^e in brothes and also in the nose. 12 Gums gnawen, seethe powder of Cloves
in rose water, and dry it, and do so often, and then use the powder of it. 13
Mouth stink, wash it with vinegar and water, then chew Mastick a good while,
then seethe Cloves Aniseeds and Mints in wine, and wash therewith. 14 To
comfort the stomach after vomiting, take powder of two Cloves with one
spooneful of the juice of Mints morn and even. 15 For agewes and all other
sicknesses, take powder of Cloves and Pepper of each like much, as much as will
lie on a groat or six pence at once fasting, and drink not two hours after
it. 16 Stomach weak, steep hot bread in good wine, and cast powder of Cloves
and Nutmegs on it, and apply it.

Belly loose 1 Brain cold 3. weak 11. Cold griefs 2. 3 Cardiack pas. 10
Digestion 1 Eyes dull 1 Fevers general 15 Fluxes 1 Gums griefs 12 Heart
cardi. 10. to comfort 1 Liver weak 1 Lust to cause 4. 10 Mother suffocat. 8
Mouth stink 13 Reume 6 Sinews cold 4 Stomach cold 3. griefs general 9.
weak 14. 16. Stone 7 Sickness general 4. 9. 15 Swooning 10 Vomiting 6
Coleworts.
COleworts: put them into scalding water, and let them be but half sodden, and
power out almost all ye water from them, then put thereto a little salt, oil
and Cummin, and heat them together a little more, and when the broth is somewhat
cold, fup thereof and also eat the Wort, to provoke vrin, and do so daily
till you be well. 2 Bruise the tender leaves and stalks, and apply them to all
swellings, ulcers and cankers morn and even to heal them. But the cankers
must be first washed with warm water. It helps also bruises and cankers of
the paps, but if this medicine be too sharp, put barley meal to it and apply
it. 3 Beat Coleworts raw with Rue, and the herb of Coriander shreaded
together, or a little salt and barley meal with Oximel mixed together, and with
the whole anoint the gout and ache of the joints to help them in short time. 4
Stamp the same herbs with wine and strein out the juice, and drop it warm
into the ears to help their deafness in short time. 5 Flowers stopped, seethe
Coleworts in pleasant wine and drink it. 6 Mix the juice with the purest honey,
and drop thereof into the corners of the eyes to help diverse griefs of them. 7
Drink the juice xl. days with white wine to cure both the Iaundies and the
diseases of ye milt. 8 Mix iii. parts of the juice with ii. parts of Allom
infused in vinegar, and anoint therewith the foul scurfe and leapry to heal
it. 9 Mix the juice with meal of Fenegreke and vinegar, and apply it to
gouts, aches of the ioints, and filthy ulcers to cleanse and heal them. 10
Draw up the juice into the nose to purge the brain. 11 Drink the juice with wine
to help the biting of an adder or snake. 12 Drink the juice with red wine to the
cough. 13 Hold juice with oil in thy mouth to heal the blisters thereof. Eat
the leaves raw to cause sleep without dreaming. 14 Roast the green stalks and
roots in the embers and temper them with barowes grease, and apply it to heal
ye continual pain and stitches in the sides. 15 Eat Coleworts raw with
vinegar often to help the griefs of the milt. 16 If it be eaten alone, it
ingendreth troubled blood and melancholy, and yields small nourishment, but
the tenderer that it is sodden with fat flesh or hens flesh ye holsomer it is.
17 The first broth of ye herb softneth the belly, and provoke vrin, but the
eating of the substance binds the belly. 18 To dry a moist belly, boil the
herb a while, and power out the broth, and power in quickly other seething
water, and boil it till it be very tender, then eat ye substance thereof
seasoned with Pepper and salt to bind the belly, but eat the substance and
broths together and then it works temperately, so that the broth of the first
seething loosneth the belly, and the substance of the second seething does
bind it. 19 Dog wound, bruise the leaves and apply them. 20 To cause children to
go soon on foot, let them eat Coleworts tenderly sodden. 21 If thou would
drink much at supper, eat the raw leaves with vinegar beforehand, and after
supper eat again iiii. or v. leaves raw, and they will make thee so fresh and
hungry, as though thou had neither eaten nor drunk at supper or banquet, and
so thou may drink as much wine as thou will and not be drunken. 22 If any
drop some drops of wine upon them as they are boiling fast, they will boil no
more but change their color as it were a thing dead in it self. 23 Colewort
especially the Cabbage cole boiled, is very good with beef with vinegar and
Pepper, but the much use thereof breeds melancholy, and causes evil dreams,
hurt the stomach, and dull the sight. 24 But eaten last they preserve ye stomach
from surfeiting, and the head from drunkenness. 25 The seeds kill worms. 26
Drink the broth of the second seething tempered with Allom to bind ye belly. 27
Stamp Coleworts, and apply it to a new and red leapry to heal it. 28 The
leaves sodden with honey heal ulcers and cankers. 29 The juice loses the
belly, the latter seething binds it, but especially the first seething with
Salt peter, or by it self purges. 30 Drink the juice with wine against the
bitings of serpents. 31 Gout, apply the juice with meal of Fenegrek. 32 Ears
deaf, put in the juice with vinegar, it helps also their noise. 33 Flowers
stopped, put it in as a pessary. 34 Hoarsenes and cough, boil it as a syrop with
honey, and lick often thereof. 35 The broth of any kind of Colewort with Sugar,
or alone, does gently loosen the belly, and cause the flowers to pass, and
the same broth is good to wash all wounds often, to cleanse and heal them. 36
The young leaves eaten raw with vinegar or perboyled, do open the belly very
gently, provoke urine, and are good for the milte, and taken after meals in
the same manner, do cure drunkenness and headache coming thereof. 37 The same
alone or with parched barley meal, are very good to be laid to blewe marks of
bruises or stripes, and other hot inflammations and swellings. 38 The leaves
sodden and applied with honey, are very good for consuming sores and filthy. 39
The seeds taken with Mede, kill all manner of worms. 40 The ashes of the
burned stalks mixed with old Swines grease, is good for the old ache and pain
of the side. 41 Seethe the tender part of the herb till it boil in water,
then stamp it and strein it, and drink it with a little salt and Cummin seed
three or four hours after meat two ounces at once to purge choler
marueilously, or else take the raw juice with Niter and Ireos for the same
purpose. 42 Coleworts eaten in meats are good for a weak stomach, they help
digestion and suffer not the body to be hard. They provoke vrin, and draw down
choler and phlegm. 43 Seethe the herb or seed in wine, and drink it hot
against the stinging of serpents. 44 Seethe Colewort with an old Cock, and
drink the broth to help the chollick, the torments of the belly, the stoue of
the kidneys, and for the griefs of the liver and mile. 45 Eat two or three
leaves raw with salt after meat, to avoid drunkenness and surfeiting. 46
Coleworts are good to be used in meats or brothes of them that have the gout,
especially with some Rue and Coliander seed, and so it will purge the more
effectually. 47 Stamp the leaves with Honey, to heal all inflammations, aches,
creeping sores, ulcers and skabs. 48 The leaves applied to the head, keep the
hair from falling, and so does the urine of him that has eaten much of it
daily, not only the griefs aforesaid, but also fistulaes, cankers,
gangreues, wheales, pushes, and other griefs of the skin, and therefore Cato
wishes children to be washed therewith against many griefs. 49 The ashes of
the stalks thereof, or of Cabbage mixed with Swines grease, helps all
flowing griefs of the skin. 50 The lee made of the same ashes, is good for
the holy fire, ringwormes, tetters, shingles, and all such like. 51 Coleworts
eaten, are good for them that cannot see well, and for the trembling of the
members, the tender buds are best. 52 The juice drunk with wine, heals the
bitings of serpents and vipers. 53 Put the juice with Daruell meal into the
matrixe, to draw down the flowers. 54 The leaves laid too by themselves, or
bruised with Barley meal, are good for the inflammations and soft swellings,
burnings, impostumes, and cholerike sores or quats like wheales and leapryes,
and other griefs of the skin. 55 And with salt they burst Carbuncles. 56 The
leaves chewed and the juice sucked down, restores the voice that is lost. 57
Apply Coleworts with the white of an egg, to burnings and skaldings. 58 The
ashes of the root breaks the stone. 59 The juice with the wine of raisins, is
good for the milt and the yellowe Iaundies, and to provoke urine and the
terms. 60 Lay a Colewort leaf on the crown of the head, to draw up the
vuula. 61 Snuf the juice into the nostrels to purge the head, and to void
pain and reume. 62 The ashes of the stalks made into a plaster, lets the
growing up of hairs. 63 Wash the head with lee made of the ashes of Coleworts
and of red Nettles, and white wine, to take away the pain without doubt. 64
The seeds are used in Treacles. 65 Glaunders and sores in the mouth, wash them
or anoint them with honey and the ashes of Coleworts stalks. 66 Ach and
bruises, sees red Coleworts and Auens in stale ale or water, and apply it. 67
Pricks, apply the juice of red Coleworts sodden with wax. 68 Leg marmoll,
wash with the juice of red Coleworts, wild Tansy and Planten. 69 Sinowes
broken, hacke red Colewort roots small, and sees it in water to pap, and
weete a cloth therein, and apply it. 70 Dropsy, seethe water Cresses, red
Coleworts and Sowthistle in water, and drink it morn and even. 71 Blood to
stop of vein or sinowe, stamp red Nettles and Colewort leaves with Swines
dung, and apply it. 72 Eyes watering, apply the leaves of red Coleworts,
tempered with the white of an egg when thou go to bed: proved. 73 Surfeit,
lay three small leaves of red Coleworts in vinegar, and eat them with salt. 74
Hoarsenesse, take the decoction of Coleworts with Penidies and syrope of maiden
hair. 75 Cough perilous, anoint a Colewort leaf with butter, and apply it to
thy stomach. 76 Headache by drinking hot wines, drink the juice of
Coleworts, and apply the substance to thy head. 77 Seethe the herb and roots
of your red Coleworts in water, to the third part, and foment the sinowes
therewith that are shrunk, and there is no better medicine for green wounds,
then to be bathed therewith. 78 Throat apostume or squincie, stamp red
Coleworts and Eldren leaves of each one handful with butter and honey, of each
one spoonefull, and apply it. 79 Iaundies desperate, make lee with the ashes of
Coleworts, and weete a cloth therein, and bind it about thy head warm when
thou go to bed eight nights together, and also wash thy body therewith. 80
Loins apostumed, mix Coleworts and Fenigreke together, and apply it. 81
Emerods, take up the fume of Coleworts sodden, in a close chair. 82 Side
griefs, apply sodden Coleworts with honey. 83 Tongue palsy, chewe well the
seeds of red Coleworts, and hold them under the root of thy tongue, it
purges marueilously. 84 For the host, clarify the juice of red Coleworts,
and put thereto Saffron, Sugar, and Honey, and make it an Electuarie and use it.
85 Belly bound, put the pith of the stalks into thy fundament. 86 Burning,
anoint with the melted fat of Bacon, and apply a Colewort leaf. 87 For great
pain in the eyes, mix ashes of the leaves with the yolke of a roasted egg,
woman's milk, and a little honey, and bind it too. 88 Eyes dull, eat great
Coleworts often. 89 Mouth flap fallen, apply the ashes of the root. 90 Flux,
eat the stalks roasted in the embers. 91 Ache in the back, belly, and sides,
apply the ashes of the branches with stale grease. 92 Milt griefs, eat them
with vinegar raw. 93 Matrix windy, seethe a linen cloth in lee of the ashes,
and apply it. 94 The root dries up milk. 95. Fever continual, seethe the
leaves with oil of Roses, and apply it to the stomach to mitigate the heat.
96 Colewort ought not to be sown with Rue, because they accord not together.
97 Emerods, sit over the decoction of red Coleworts, and wash therewith also.
98 To purge choler and phlegm, put a bundle into seething water, while one may
go v. or vi. paces, then stamp them and streine out the juice, and keep it
in an earthen vessel in the open air, then put a little salt and bruised
Cumminseede to it, and drink it in the morning, and walk upon it iii. or
iiii. hours, but you must wash your hands, arms, legs, and feet ouernight
with hot water, and go supperlesse to bed. 99 Ears deaf, drop in the juice
with warm water. 100 To dry up milk, bathe the breasts with the decoction
of the leaves. 101 Strayning to go to the stool, seethe them in water, and
then fry them in oil and sit over it, it helps also the Emerods being
sodden in water and butter, and the fume received up. 102 Hair not to fall,
seethe the stalks and roots of red Coleworts in water of a spring to the one
half, and wash therewith often.

Colophony.
COlophony, a searecloth for the spleen or stitch, or wind in the body, and
to staunch blood, melt it in an earthen pot, and strike it on leather, and
apply it: but for bleeding, apply it to ye reins and betwixt the shoulders up
to the neck. 2 The suffumigation thereof binds the belly, and helps the
falling of the fundament and matrix, and furthereth conception. 3 Tenasmus,
anoint the pains with honey, and cast powder of Colophony and Cresses, of each
like much on it. 4 Shortness of breath of cold cause, take up the fume
thereof, the matter being digested and dissolved.

Bleeding 1 Breath short 3 Cough Conception 2 Fluxes 2 Fundament fallen 2 Milt
1 Matrix fallen 2 Stitch 1 Windiness 1
Cockle.
COckle: eyes pearl, chewe Cockle in thy mouth, and put in the juice thereof
morning and evening. 2 Freckles, mix Cockle meal with as much of the gall of
a Cock, and apply it one night to take them away. 3 Stamp the meal with the
roots of Daffadil and honey, and apply it to any prick or thing that sticks
in the flesh. 4 Impost to open, apply ye meal sodden with the doung of a
Wooddoue in wine. 5 To heal sore tetters, apply ye meal with brimstone and
vinegar. 6 Teethache apply powder of it in a cloute. 7 To open the matrix and
cause conception, seethe Cockle, Myrrh, white Frankincense, and Saffron in
wine or water, and anoint therewith. 8 Conception to cause, take up the fume of
Cockle and Frankincense. 9 Gout, bathe it well with water, and seethe oil in
water and honey, and mix it with Cockle, and apply it. 10 Sores and Tetters to
heal, mix Cockle and brimstone with vinegar, and anoint. 11 Headache of
reume or murre, blow in powder of Cockle that grows among corn. 12 Belly
bound, anoint with the oil of Cockle. 13 Urine stopped, apply the meal thereof
with hot water to the share. (See Darnel. See Nigella.)

Apostume 4 Ache 9 Belly bound 12 Botch 4 Conception 7. 8 Eye pearl 1 Face
freckles 2 Flowers stopped 7 Gout 9 Headache 11 Matrix stopped 7 Pricks 3 Skabs
5. 10 Sores 10 Teeth-ache 6 Tetters 5. 10 Urine stopped 13
Coriander.
COriander: drink 7. Grains to have speedy deliverance of child. 2 Loins
ache, sees Garlike and Coriander of each two ounces in a quart of wine till
the third part be wasted, then streine it and drink it morn and even. 3 If
thou fear ye coming of an ague, swallowe down three grains of Coriander
fasting. Iaundies eat Coriander. 4 Head swimming and dasling, bake it in bread
and apply it. 5 Belly swollen, boil powder of Coliander seed with butter to an
ointment, and use it. 6 Face salsflegme, mix Coriander with ye juice of
Hemlock, and red Docks with fresh grease and a little quicksiluer, and anoint. 7
Flowers to stopped drink powder of Coliander, Sanders, and Saffron with red wine
in the mornings. 8 The juice drunk, suffers no fumes to ascend to the head,
and for the falling evil. 9 Flowers to stop, drink as many seeds as thou
would stop them days. 10 Fever tertian, take iii. grains of Coriander with
a rear Egg after iii. or iiii. fits. 11 Scrophules, Glandules, or kernels,
kneade Bean flower with the juice of it, and bake it and apply it hot. 12
Carbuncle, or other grievous byle, apply powder of the seed with honey to
destroy it quite. 13 Falling evil, drink ye juice. 14 Breath stinking, seethe
the seeds in Sack, and drink three spoonefull at even hot, and at morn
cold, and forbear excess of meats, late sitting up, early rising. 15 Mix
powder of the seed with vinegar, and cast it on meat to keep it long from
corruption, or cover it with meal flower of branne, it may be so kept all
summer. 16 Uvula fallen, seethe powder of the seeds with Rue in water of
Myntes, and hold thereof in thy mouth cold. 17 Worms, drink the juice.
Fever quarten use the seeds. 18 Breath stinking, use the seeds morning and
evening. 19 Conception, steep the seeds in vinegar, and dry them, and mix
the powder with powder of Akorne cups, and use it morn and even in pottage and
drink. 20 Worms to drive out, drink ye seeds with Malmesey. 21 Coliander
resolves windiness and wennes. 22 The seeds in receiptes may well be kept
two years. 23 The seeds in meats help digestion, and are good for the pain
in the stomach and windiness, and so is the wine of the decoction thereof. 24
The powder of the seeds cast upon meats, causes them to digest the better,
and with sweet wine it moves lust, but too much use of it breeds the
frenzy and raging, and the much eating of the herb and seed together, is
venomous to dogs, and kills them. 25 Coriander comfects repress ye vapors
ascending to the head, and therefore are good for the falling sickness. 26 The
seed may not be eaten raw but steeped in vinegar, or covered over with Sugar.
27 Prepared with vinegar, and bruised and taken with the juice of Planten, it
staieth great bleeding at the nose. 28 Look how many grains of the seeds a
woman does take, and so many days her course shall run. 29 The herb must
not be taken inward, because it hurts the head and the blood. 30 The juice
with vinegar does cool and heal the holy fire. 31 The seeds a little
bruised, and given in reasins, do kill worms in children. 32 Mix the juice
with the juice of Lettuse and of Planten, the white of an egg and oil of
Roses, and apply it to hot apostumes, burnings, swellings, blisters, and
shingles to heal them. 33 Coliander steeped one night in wine or vinegar and
dried, is good for the stomach, and against all evil air. 34 The herb with
the meal of Beans or Fitches, and Rose oil applied, takes away all
inflammations and swellings. 35 Apply it with bread or Barley meal to the
wild fire, spreading sores, night plowkes, and with honey and reasyns to
inflammations of the stones and carbuncles: with Bean meal it drives away
kernels, hard swellings and wennes. 36 The seeds increase natural seed. 37
The juice with white lead or lytarge, vinegar oil of Roses heals
inflammations of the uttermost skin. 38 It makes flesh wherewith it is
sodden, to have the taste of spice. 39 Drink the parched seeds with wine to
kill and expel worms, to stop the bloody Flixe, and all other extraordinary
issues of blood. 40 The fresh and green herb sodden with white bread crumbs,
or Barley meal, consumes all hot tumors, swellings, inflammations etc. 41
The Comfects eaten after meals, strengthens the stomach. 42 With bean
meal it dissolueth the kings evil, hard lumpes, wennes and kernels.

Ache 2 Apostume 12. 32 Backeache 2 Belly swollen 5 Bleeding 27. 39 Blisters 32

Coloquintida.
COloquintida, the pith or white pulp thereof taken about one scruple, purges
mightily gross phlegm, choler, slime and stinking corruption and scrapings of
the guts, and sometime causes blood to issue, and so it does if it be soked
or boiled in honied water, or any other liquor and so drunk. 2 It is good
against al cold dangerous diseases, as ye apoplexia, the falling sickness,
giddiness of ye head, pain in fetching of breath, the chollike, looseness of
the synowes, and places out of joint: and for the same purposes it may be taken
in glisters and suppositories. 3 The oil wherein it has bin boiled, takes
away the pain in the ears, and the noise. 4 The pulp or pith may be taken
with gum Dragagant and Mastike, and after made into balls or trochiskes with
honey for the use of medicine. 5 Steep one apple of Coloquintida in pertis and
water twelve hours, then streine it and drink half a pint of it in the
morning to purge melancholy and choler adust, but it is a very gross
purgation: but the trochiskes are better to purge with. 6 Sees a dram of
Coloquintida in powder with mirts and Oate water to a thickness, and make
thereof pills, and use them. Sees it in vinegar, and hold it in the mouth to
kill worms in the teeth. The oil thereof is good for the Sciatica. 7 It
kills worms in the ears, and also in the belly, being used in drinks or
plasters. It is perilous to women with child, and to weak folks. 8 Knit a
piece in a cloute and steep it all night in a draught of white wine, and
streine it and drink it in the morning to purge a strong body from much filth
and the Iliake passion: But there must be four or five branches of Issop
steeped therewith. 9 It will do the like, being sodden in sweet water. 10 Mix
it with an Ox gall, aloes, honey, meal of Lupines, and oil of wormwood, of
each a dram and a half, and apply it to the belly to loose and purge it,
to kill worms, and to expel them. 11 Steep the spongie part thereof with the
kernels four or five hours in a draught of wine, and drink it to bedward to
purge phlegm, choler, and gross humors, and to help the dropsy. 12 The
balls broken and powered in by glister, purges and takes away the palsy, the
Sciatica, and the chollicke. 13 Sees it in honied water, or sweet wine, and
cool it in the open air, and drink it to purge gross humors, and things
like shauings. 14 A suppositer thereof plucketh down the excrements of the
belly: a glister thereof heals all the diseases of the guts, kidneys and
loins, and the palsy the seeds being cast out. Mix it with a Bulls gall
and honey, and apply it to a belly that is costiue. 15 Steep a penie weight
pulled in pieces all night in ale, and streyne it and drink it to purge the
belly, or drink powder of three or four of the kernels. 16 Seethe it in
vinegar, and hold thereof in the mouth to help the toothache. Seethe it in
oil and dry a cloute or cotton therein, and put it into the natural place to
provoke the Flowers. 17 To kill fleas, steep an apple of it in water twelve
hours, and sees wormwood therein, and sprinckle the house therewith.
Purgation, take powder of three seeds with as much Diagridium as a pease with
a rear egg.

Columbine.
COlumbine, for the iaundies and the liver, take powder of the seeds and of
saffron, of each a penny weight, wine, water and vinegar, of each one eggeshel
full, drink it first and last. 2 Take one scruple of powder of the seed, with
two eggshels full of wine first and last to drive out the iaundies by urine. 3
Eyes running, anoint with ye juice. 4 For the water canker in ye mouth, drink
the seeds. 5 Emerodes, stamp red dock leaves, unset leekes, and Columbine
roasted in the embers, and apply them. 6 Squincie, drink the seeds often with
good ale, or stamp the seeds and herbs with honey, and take it with milk or
drink. 7 Frenzy, at the first drink the juice of Columbine, and use pottage
of sage, valerian or rue, and be whole for ever. 8 Ioints broken, drink the
seeds with feuerfew in stale ale. 9 Deliverance to cause, drink Columbine. 10
Swelling, drink the juice with five leaves of the same herb and stale ale.
11 Headache, stamp Columbine, and fry it with May butter, and anoint therewith.
12 Palsy, sees Primrose, Columbine, peony, lauender and saffron in ale, and
drink it before and after meat. 13 Breath-stinking, eat the seeds often. 14
Columbine is good against the iaundies, and swooning, it opens the liver, and
is good for the inflammations and sores of the jaws, and windpipe. 15
Scratches and gallings, stamp the flowers with wheat meal and apply it. 16
Iaundies, and stopping of the liver, and many diseases that may come thereof,
drink a dram of the seed with a half penny weight of saffron with wine, and
cover thee well to sweat. 17 The water of the flowers is good for the same
purpose and for swooning. 18 Stamp Columbine, and apply it to dry up scabs and
fistulaes. 19 Seethe it in milk, sweet wine, or oximel, and drink it or gargle
with it to help the Struma or painful swelling in the throat, called ye kings
evil. 20 The juice with wheat meal applied warm, dries up moist humors in
byles and sores. 21 It is good for young children to drink it against the
redgum or fellon.

Comferie.
COmferie, the roots stamped and drunk, are good for spitting of blood, and al
inward wounds and ruptures. 2 Bruise it and apply it to heal fresh wounds
wonderfully. 3 The root boiled and drunk, cleanses ye breast, and cures the
griefs of the lungs, and so it does mixed with sugar, syrrops or honey, and
often licked. 4 for all tumors and hot inflammations, especially of the
fundament, stamp it with ye leaves of groundswel and apply it. 5 Ruptures and
broken bones, stamp the^ and apply them. 6 To stop the bloody flux and terms,
seethe the root in water and drink it. 7 Chew thereof to void thirst. 8 Roste
the roots in the embers, and eat them fasting 3. days against ruptures and
bursting. It helps together broken bones, it stops all fluxes of blood,
and vomiting blood, the juice being drunk with red wine and a little mastick. 9
Hoarsenesse, eat powder of it, and of Elecampana with honey fasting. 10 Bones
broken, stamp it with dasies, egrimonie, and vinegar, and apply it til it be
whole. 11 Roste the roots of elecampana and Comferie, of each like much, or
seethe them in water to the one half, then put thereto a third part of
clarified honey, and make it in an electuarie, and use it morn and even for
the chincough. 12 Flux to stop, apply the juice of Co^fery and both plantins
with the burnt clay of an old oven or furnace to the belly. 13 Burstings and
broken bones, eat the roasted roots with honey. 14 Matrix rent by travail of
childbirth, put in powder of Comfery and Cynamom. 15 Matrix griefs, drink
Comfery with Ale or water three days. 16 Bloodyfluxe wash the root in cold
water, and scrape it with a knife of bone or iuorie, or of a hearts horn, and
eat thereof two ounces or more: but eat no vinegar that day, for that takes
away the virtue of the root. 17 Bursten, put the juice into thy bread, and eat
the root either raw or roasted. 18 Teethach, seethe it in vinegar, and hold
thy mouth over it. 19 Bruised, drink two spoonfuls of the juice of Comfery, and
scabious morn and even, or stamp Comfery, housleek, orpin and flower, and apply
it. 20 Flowers to stop, sees Co^fery in running water, and drink it. 21
Spitting blood, drink Osmund and Comfery with stale ale 9. days and be whole.
22 If a man that is wounded drink Comfery and keep it, he shall live, if not, he
shall die. 23 Vein broken in the breast, frye the roots with eggs and meal, and
eat them. 24 Or sees the^ and slice them, and dry them, and use the powder of
them with wine and water.

Blood casting 8 Bloody flux 8. 16 Bones broken 5. 8. 10. 13 Breast cleansing 3
Bruised 19 Bursten 1. 5. 8. 13. 17 Chin-cough 11 Flowers to stop 20 Fluxes 12

Coral.
COral: drink Coral and pepper with water, and thou shall have the cra^p no
more. 2 Falling evil, hang it about thy neck. 3 Heart burning, let a man hold
red Coral in his mouth, and a woman white Coral in hers. 4 Heart cardiack,
apply Coral red or white with oil of roses. 5 Teeth ach, mix powder of
mastick, gals and Coral with honey, and rub therewith where need is. 6 Teeth to
fall out, put in powder of red Coral. 7 Give a child twelve grains in powder
when he is newborn, with the nurses milk, and it shall never have the
falling sickness. 8 Coral strengthens the stomach, stops spitting of
blood, preserves the heart from pestilence, stops terms, is good for the
falling evil, and withstandeth lightnings being borne on one, and stops
bleeding at the nose. 9 Matrix flux, purge the cause, then take powder of
sanguis Draconis, bol armoniack, white amber, and red Coral, and drink a dram
with two ounces of plantine water. 10 Or take old conserve of roses two ounces,
plantine seeds, two drams, sanguis draconis, and bol armoniack, ana a dram and
a half, white and red Coral ana one dram, make a confection with syrrop of
mirtles, and drink it morn and even as much as a mean chestnut two hours
before and after meat, and wear Coral about thy neck and hand. 11 Teeth to
be white, rub them with powder of white Coral, white marble, cuttle bone,
sal-gem, masticke, bay salt, and the pills of a Cytron, ana like much every
morning, and after wash them in white wine, sodden with oil and camomil. 12
Hang it about thy neck down to the pit of the stomach to cause digestion. 13 It
consumes superfluous flesh in wounds without pain. 14 The powder strengthens
ye gums. 15 Drink the powder with water to appease the griefs of the stomach
and belly for ever, and to dry up the phlegm. 16 Coral drunk stops the
terms, it comfort the heart and stomach, dissolueth the fever, in Lozenges
it is restoratiue. 17 Heart griefs, use the powder with sugar roset. 18 Impost.
drink the powder with the juice of a ha^dful of scabious roots, and as much
aqua vitae. 19 It comfort the eyes, and dries up the tears, it cleanses
ulcers. 20 Gums bleeding, apply the powder by it self, or with honey.

Belly griefs 15 Crampe 1 Digestion 12 Eyes griefs 19 Falling evil 2. 7. 8

Cornefloure.
COrnefloure, or blew battle, stamp it and apply it to the pain, rednes,
inflammation, and running of the eyes, or to any hot apostume about the eyes,
and so is the distilled water or juice good for the same purposes. 2 Sees the
flower and seed in wine, and drink it against all venomous bitings and
stingings. 3 Drink half a dram of powder of the seeds to purge chollar
downward. 4 The herb is good for the diseases of Swine.

Apostume 1 Bytings venomous 2 Eyes griefs 1 Inflammations 1 Purgations 3
Swine sick 4
Cornerose.
COrnerose, or wild poppy, is in nature much like to poppy. 2 Boil five or
six heads in wine, and drink it to cause sleep, or take the seed with honey. 3
Stamp the leaves and green heads, and apply them to all evil hot swellings,
ulcers, and wild fire. 4 The seeds put into honied cakes loosen the belly
gently. 5 The powder of the flowers is good for the plurisie, and so is the
syrop of the same flowers. 6 The leaves gathered green, used in meats, purges
downwards. 7 To make read butter for the diseases aforesaid, put thereto the
red leaves: and likewise into cheese, to cause sleep. 8 The juice of the
leaves will make butter or cheese green and profitable for the diseases
aforesaid. 9 Mix the juice with myrthe, saffron, and oil of bitter almonds,
and put it warm into the ear to restore hearing, if it be curable. 10 Seethe
the seeds in Mede, and drink two ounces and a half to loosen the belly
gently. 11 Sees five or six heads in wine, till the better half be wasted,
and drink thereof, and apply it to the forehead to cause sleep. 12 Stamp the
seeds with honey, and eat it to loosen the belly gently. 13 The distilled
water drunk, helps all inward heats and inflammations of the mouth, throat
and liver. 14 The same applied with hemp hards, helps the shingles, the holy
fires, the inflaming fire, and the bleeding at the nose. 15 The same water
helps all inflammations, and exulcerations of the eyes, mouth, throat and
secret parts. 16 Applied to the forehead with hemp hards, it is good for ye
frenzy. 17 The juice of the flowers with brimstone and saltpeter, is good
against scabbes, and foul spots. 18 Plurisie, drink powder of the red
flowers dried in the sun, and use it in meats, and anoint with oil of
Lysarts warm. (See Poppie.)

A syrrop for the stomach, and to digest a surfeit, put a quart of claret wine
into a basin, steep it full of the leaves of red poppy, that grows in wheat,
on a chafingdish of coals, and lay two flat white sticks over the basin, and
take a piece of white cotton a span long and an inch broad at the one end, and
small at the other end: put the broad end into the liquor, and the small end
into a glass, then whelme a basin over the sticks, and so boil it till the
liquor be boiled up, or distilled into the glass: and to every pint of the
liquor put one pound of sugar, and boil it to a syrrop, and keep it in a
close glass, it reuiueth one that is in a deadly swoone.

Cotton weed.
COtton weed is good to be drunk with tart wine against the bloody flixe, the
common flixe, and the terms. 2 It is good to be put into the fundament for the
Flux tenasmus: apply it to old rotton sores. 3 Cartifilago has the same
virtues.

Flowers to stop 1 Fluxes 1 Sores 2
Couslip.
COuslip, Oxlips and Primroses, are now used amongst herbs, but not much in
Physic. 2 They are good for the head and sinews. 3 Drink the juice nine days
together to help the falling sickness. Blood to stop, stamp the leaves and
apply the^. 4 Eyes bleared or red, anoint with the juice or water. 5 The
flowers co^dited with sugar, are good for the Apoplexia, often swooning, all
inward griefs, the palsy, and to comfort the heart: the herb also applied
outwardly. 6 Bitings venomous and stingings, apply the flowers or leaves. 7
Headache of heat, use the water, the same takes away all spots and wrinckles
of the face and skin: falling evil, drink the juice with powder of a kites
liver 9. days. 8 Canker in the hand or joint, stamp the Primrose roots with
clarified honey, and apply it morn and even til it be whole. 9 Speech lost by
sickness, hold the juice of Couslips or sage in thy mouth. 10 Teeth ach put the
juice of Primrose into the contrary nostril. 11 Aches hot, bruise Couslips and
apply them. 12 Crampe and stretching of the sinews, seethe it in water, and
bathe therewith, or with camomill flowers sodden in water: or wash with the
decoction of Primrose. 13 Speech lost, stamp Primrose and sage, and anoint
under thy tongue. 14 Head impostume, put the juice of primrose into the nose to
break it. 15 Palsy and benumbed limbs, distill the flowers with oil olive in
a glass in the sun, and to two spoonful of it put one spoonful of aqua vitae,
and anoint therewith. 16 Headache and to cleanse the brain, put the juice of
Primrose, with Cowes milk into the nose with a feather. 17 Head megrem, stamp
the roots of Primrose with rosemary leaves, and boil them in good ale dregs
and honey, and apply thereof 3. or four days as hot as may be suffered: or
mix the juice of Betony and Primrose roots, and Cowes milk, and put it into
the nose bloodwarme with a fether: or put in Primrose leaves with milk. 18
Voice lost, mix the juice of Primrose with wine or water, and hold it in thy
mouth. 19 Dog bitten with a mad dog, give him the juice of Primrose, with milk
within 24. hours after he is bitten.

Make Conserve of the flowers with sugar to help against feeblenes, swooning,
and to restore strength. Take Couslip flowers, stamp them, and set into the sun
in a close glass five or six weeks: this oil helps the gout of the feet
and other members: it cures also fresh wounds, if the same be infused in oil
olive. It will then serve for many griefs, gather the flowers dry.

2 impost. 14. 16. 17
