Cowparsnip.
COwparsnip or Wild carrat growing in meadows: swellings cold, stamp it and
apply it. 2 Some seethe it in drink with leuin, and use it in sted of ale or
bear. 3 The seed drunk, scoureth out phlegm, and heals griefs of the liver,
the iaundies, shortness of wind, the falling evil, and strangling of the
mother. 4 The perfume thereof wakeneth them that are fallen into a dead sleep.
5 Frenzy, litargy and headache, seethe it in oil, and anoint therewith. 6
Creeping sores and tetters, apply it with rue. 7 Liver griefs and iaundies use
the roots of it. Shave the root, and put it into fistulaes or false wounds, to
take away their hardness. 8 Ears mattering, put in the juice of ye grene
filmes. 9 The juice may be dried in the Sun, and kept as other juices be.

Drink 2 Eyes sore 8 Falling evil 3 Fistula 7 Phlegm 3 Frenzy 5 Hardness 7
Headache 5 Iaundies 3. 7 Litargie 4. 5 Liver griefs 3. 7 Mother suffoc. 3
Purgat. 3 Sicknesses 3 Sores 6 Swellings 1 Tetters 6 Wounds 7
Crabs.
CRabs or Wildings: face swollen, distill them in a limbecke in the end of
June, and wash therewith often. 2 Flux chollerike, use sirrup of Crabs. (See
Apples.)

Face swollen 1 Fluxes 2
Cranesbill.
CRanesbill or Acus moscata, apply it to all wounds and ulcers. 2 Drink one
dram with wine to expel all windiness of the mother. 3 Bruises and black
spots, bathe them with the water thereof, and apply it four or five days.

Bruises 3 Mother windy 2 Ulcers 1 Windiness 2 Wounds 1
Cresses.
CResses: stamp them with pitch and apply it to break and heal apostumes. 2
Hair not to fall, anoint with the juice. 3 Flux to stop, stamp the seeds and
boil them with honey, and apply it to the womb, it never fails, being
applied hot in a cloth. Vain broken, drink a little powder of the seeds. 4
Teethache, put the juice into the ear on the same side. Bloody flux, eat a
penny weight of the seeds three days fasting, and drink wine or water after
it, and it shall either staunch or turn to another, or else it is death or not
curable. 5 Gout, seethe them with leeks and red mints, and wash therewith morn
and even. 6 Head worms, stamp them with goose grease, and use it. 7 Gout
old, stamp them with sewet, and apply it, or stamp the leaves with bran and
vinegar, and apply it. 8 Carbuncles and venomous bitings, stamp it with bran
and apply it, or stamp the herb and seed together, and apply it. 9 To stop
the bloody flux and all other fluxes, mix three drammes of the seeds with as
much honey, and make it sharp with vinegar, and drink it once or twice:
proved. 10 Brain to purge, blow in powder of Garden Cresse into the nose. 11
Flux diaria, drink powder of the seeds with wine or vinegar, or drink the
said powder with powder of planten seeds and red wine. 12 For all skabs,
skalles and sores of the head, mix powder of the seeds with fresh goose
grease, and anoint, or with the juice and goose grease. 13 Blood to stop,
drink a little of the seeds with the juice of planten. 14 Speech lost, anoint
or rub the tongue with the juice of Cresses and powder of Castorie. 15
Trembling, with water of the decoction of Cresses and Lauender. 16 Vomit to
cause, seethe the seeds of Dill and Cresses in water, and put a little oil to
it, and drink it luke warm. 17 Tongue palsy, chew the seeds, and hold them
under thy tongue. 18 To know whether a wounded man shall die or not, let him
drink red wine, and then eat a penny weight of the seed, and do so three
days, if he stanch not, he may not live. 19 Palsy and maleflanke, seethe the
seeds in wine, and apply it to the side and palsy members. 20 Vrin stopped,
seethe it with wine and oil olive, and apply it to the share. 21 Fundament
fallen of cold cause, put it in again, and straw on the powder, or anoint the
raines with honey, and cast on the powder with Cummin, or powder of Colophony.
22 Burn the stalk to kill venomous beasts with the fume thereof. 23 To break
the stone, make powder of Cresse seeds, Parsley seeds, Annyseeds and black
Flints, and use it morn and even. 24 Bitings of mad dogs, seethe the seeds
with Penyroyall in water, and drink it to cast out the venim. 25 Fluxes
general, drink powder of the seeds with ale morn and even. 26 The seeds
especially are used in medicine, and may be kept five years. 27 The green
herb is also of great effect, being somewhat dried before it be ministered. 28
The seeds bruised and drunk in wine, expels the dead yongling, and drunk
with vinegar, it helps the griefs of the milt. 29 Eat it with the best honey
to help the cough, and open the breast. 30 Chew it and hold it in the mouth
for the palsy in the tongue. 31 Cresses may not be eaten alone, for then they
diminish the strength, and breed evil humors. 32 The seeds taken whole, stay
the distilling of the head without harm. 33 Put the seeds into the nose in
powder to purge the brain, and help the headache. 34 Seethe them in wine and
apply them hot to the palsy members in a bag. 35 Litargie, blow the powder
into the nose. 36 Sciatica and chollike, seethe the seeds in wine, and apply
them in a bag hot, or seethe the green herb in wine and oil, and apply it
hot to the belly for the chollike and strangury. 37 The herb drunk with
Mints in wine, does drive out both long and flat worms in beasts. 38 Hair
falling, anoint with the juice. 39 Teethache, drop the juice into the ear. 40
Eat the herb often in sallets to have a sharp and ready wit. 41 Eaten with
Lettuse it is of virtue like Rocket, and is good amongst cold herbs. 42 The
seed looseneth the belly, kills and expels worms, diminishes the milt,
and expels the flowers, seconds, and dead child. 43 It is good against
venomous beasts, and the perfume thereof causes them to avoid. 44 Take it with
broth of a chicken, or any other moist broth, to ripen phlegm and avoid it,
and so to cleanse the breast. 45 Milt hard, apply it with honey, and so it
scowreth away foul spreading sores, dissolueth cold swellings and keeps
hair from falling. 46 Apply it with vinegar and honey to the sciatica, old
headache, and old and cold diseases. 47 Stamp it with goosegreace to heal the
worms of the head. 48 The seed is of virtue like senuie seed, it expels
worms, and is ill for women with child, it provoke terms and venerie, it
scowreth away leapry and scurfe, and sores called Fauae like to honey combs, it
ripeneth and bursteth carbuncles, it drives forth the griefs of the lungs,
being sodden with suppings. The same drunk withstandeth poison and venim. 49
Applied with parched barley meal and vinegar, it is good for the sciatica and
disperseth swellings. 50 And with brine it drives forth angry sores and cats
hair, the leaves and branches are good for the same purposes while they are
green, but not so strong, for then they may be eaten with bread. The dried
herb may serve for the seed. 51 The juice cleanses filthy sores. 52 The
seeds cause abortion, with vinegar it takes away the scab. 53 With honey it
takes away ache in any place. 54 It is good in medicines for shortness of
wind. 55 Sodden with vinegar it dissolueth scrophules, and ripeneth cold
apostumes. 56 Take a dram of the powder of the seeds with red wine six or
seven mornings two hours before meat to stop the laske. 57 Seethe the seeds in
white wine, and drink it to stop the gonorrhea or wasting of nature, and to
drive forth the urine. 58 Stamp the root with swines grease, and apply it
warm four hours to the pain of the joints, and the sciatica: but for women
but two hours, and go presently to sweat in a bath, and then anoint with oil
of Cresses and warm wine sodden. 59 Seethe Cresses in wine, and drink it
against pain of the joints, the dropsy, timpanie, gowt, swelling, palsy,
pocks, apostumations, rumes, bloody fluxes, bruises, moistness of the brain
and eyes etc. (See Rocket Senuie.)

Crowfoot.
CRowfoot leaves or roots being stamped and applied, causes blisters and
ulcers, and therefore are good to be laid to corrupt nails and to warts to
make them fall off. 2 The leaves also may be used to foul skurfe or tetters,
wheales, gauls, skabs etc. being stamped, but it may not lie long, but be
taken away immediately. 3 The powder of the root provoke sneesing. They are
all poison to be taken inward. 4 Stamp Crowfoot green, and apply it to hard
ulcers and swellings, and to eat out dead flesh, warts, wennes, and all such
like, prints of wounds, little marks like pricks. 5 The powder of the root put
to the tooth that aketh takes away the pain, but it breaks the tooth. 6 The
juice tempered with boares sewet restores hair. 7 The juice takes away skabs
and crusty scurfe: and tempered with swines grease, it helps the swelling of
the throat. 8 Bind it with a red third about the neck in the wane of the Moon
in the first part of or both for the falling sickness and lunacy. 9 The same
root steeped in wine is good to be drunk in the plague, and to cause sweat, but
not good in a hot fever. 10 Stomach hot, stamp Crowfoot with crummes of
bread, and apply it. 11 Toothache, gather the root in May, dry it in an Oven,
and keep it all the year, and when need is, apply it being bruised with wax
and pitch, etc. three hours on the top of the tooth two or three times.

Falling sickness 8 Flesh dead 4 Hair to restore 6 Lunacie 8 Nails corrupt
1 Plague. 9 Skabs 2. 7 Sneesing to cause 3 Stomach hot 10 Teethache 2 Tetters
11 Throat swollen 7 Ulcers hard 4 Warts 4 Wennes 4
Cubebs.
CVbebs strengthen a weak and windy stomach, they skower the breast, help
the milt, expel wind, and help the cold griefs of the matrix. 2 Head and
brain to strengthen and cleanse, chew them with Masticke. 3 For trembling of
the heart, melancholy, and the falling evil, there is no better medicine then
Cubebs with Balm water. 4 They provoke urine, break the stone, and open
obstructions. Heart faint, take four drammes of Cubebs with the juice of the
roots and leaves of Parsnip.

Brain grief 2 Breast grief 1 Falling evil 3 Heart trembling 3. faint 4 Head
griefs 2 Matrix griefs 1 Melancholy 3 Milt griefs 1 Obstructions 4 Stomach
weak 1. windy 1 Stone 4 Urine stopped 4
Cucumber.
CVcumber wild: head sores, biles, etc. mix ashes of the roots with water,
and wash therewith. Headache, boil the root with water and oil, and apply it.
2 Ears griefs, put in the juice of the leaves, it kills worms therein also.
3 Face wrinkles and all griefs of the skin in any place, mix powder of the
root with water, and wash therewith, and wash it again with other cold water,
and do so thrice or three days. 4 Teethache, use the decoction of it with wine
or water, and hold it in the mouth, or put it into the ear on the same side. 5
Gla^dules, kernels, scrophules, and old hard swellings, stamp the root with
barley meal, and apply it. 6 Dropsy of cold cause, use wine of the decoction
of the root to purge out the swelling. 7 Fever quarten, drink the root before
the fit. 8 Burning, sprinckle on ashes of a dry Cucumber. 9 Ringwormes, tetters
and skabs, seethe the roots to the third part, stamp and strain them, and put
thereto litarge of silver and brimstone in powder, of each like much, and a
little wax, and rub the place therewith. 10 Milt griefs, take powder of it as
much as you can take up with three fingers, with wine before breakfast. 11 Face
wrinckles and deformities, wash it with cold water, and anoint it with fine
powder of the root and honye three days. (See Elaterium in Dodoneus.) 12 Ears
pain, put in ye juice.

Burnings 8 Dropsy 6 Ears griefs 2. 12 Pace deformed 3. 11 Fever quart. 7
Glandules 5 Hardness 5 Headache 1. skabd 2 Kernels 5 Milt griefs 10 Ringwormes
9 Skabs 9 Skin deformed 3. 9 Skrophules 5 Swellings 5. 6 Teethache 4 Tetters 9
Wrinckles 11
Cucumber.
CVcumber of the garden, the whole substance thereof eaten in Summer is good
for them that use much exercise, but not for the flegmatike. 2 The water or
juice of them helps the fever and cease thirst. 3 They which are hard and
heavy are not so good as they that be ripe. 4 Bladder blistred, drink the
seeds in milk. 5 Cough, drink the seeds with wine and as much bruised cummin
as may be taken up with three fingers. 6 Frenzy, bruise the seeds, and drink
them with woman's milk. 7 Spitting blood and matter, drink the seeds with a
little cummin. 8 Belly bound, use to eat cucumbers. Mad, smell to cucumbers
to restore the wits. 9 Urine stopped, seethe the seeds in wine, and drink it. 10
The same helps biting of dogs, the seeds and leaves being also applied. 11
Pushes hot, stamp the seeds with honey, and apply them. 12 Drink the seeds
with milk or sweet wine, to loosen the belly gently, and for the blistering,
rawnesse and stopping of the bladder. 13 Dog biting, stamp the green
leaves, and apply them. 14 Swooning, smell to a cucumber. 15 The juice with the
seeds mixed with meal, and dried in the Sun, is made into a soap to make the
face and skin white and neat, but it must be anointed with wine. 16
Cucumbers, melons, and pepons are good for hot griefs. 17 Their seeds are good
for the strangury and griefs of the reins and bladder. (See Mellons, Gourds
etc. 18 Burning, sprinckle on the ashes of a dry Cucumber.

Belly bound 8. 12 Bladder griefs 4. 12. 17 Burnings 18 Cough 5 Dog biting 10.
13 Face deformed 15 Fevers 2 Frenzy 6 Hot griefs 16 Lungs griefs 7 Mad 8
Pushes 11 Skabbe 11 Skin defor. 11. 15 Spitting blood 7. and matter 7
Strangury 17 Swooning 14 Thirst 2 Urine stopped 9. 12 Wits lost 8
Cumminseedes.
CVmminseedes: if one that has eaten Cummin do breathe on a painted face, ye
color will vanish away straight. 2 Ache or gout, seethe two handful of the
powder in a pottell of white wine to the one half, and drink thereof a good
draught first and last 15. days. 3 Ears deaf, stamp half a pound grossly,
and put it into a bag, and sprinkle it with Rose water and Malmesey and bind it
fast to the ear hot, and lie on it all night, and do so thrice and keep thy
chamber iii. days. 4 Hickit, drink Cummin. 5 Bruses and black spots, boil
powder of Cummin and salt ana one ounce in 4. ounce of honey a little, and anoint
therewith. 6 For all aches and swellings, stamp it with the leaves of
Colworts, and drink it with wine continually. 7 Vomiting much, sees it with
Mints in wine and drink it or eat it. 8 Eyes blooddy, boil it in white wine
and put thereto the juice of Rue, and put it in or apply it. 9 Blooddy flux
and bleeding at the nose, steep it in vinegar iii. days, then dry it and use
ye powder of it. 10 Belly or stomach ache, bake cakes of meal of wheat, rye,
or otes, slice them and anoint the inside with honey, and cast on it powder of
Cummin, and apply it hot to the navel twice or thrice. 11 Yard ranckled,
seethe Beans, Cummin, and Holly, and apply them. 12 Stomach to comfort after
purging, sees crumbs of bread with Cummin in ale and sup thereof. 13 For all
griefs of ye stomach, make powder of the seeds of Cummin, flax and
smallage, of each like much, and drink one sponefull 9. mornings fasting. 14.
Sides griefs, see the powder of Cummin in white wine in a linen bag to ye one
half, and dip a green felt in the wine, and apply it often hot. 15 Flank
sickness, drink Cummin and Rue with wine or stale ale, when thou fear ye
coming of it. 16 Belly loose with flux and vomiting, seethe it in wine, and
drink it or eat it. 17 Sweat to cause, mix the fine powder with oil, and
anoint thy hands and feet when thou art warm in thy bed, and cover thee well.
18 Head ache or migreme, cast powder of it on a piece of sliced beef, and
apply it two fingers broad from ear to ear one night and be whole 19 Belly
worms, seethe it with more gall and oil, and apply it to the navel Milk to
cause, seethe one ounce with 4. ounces of ho^^ in 3. quat^es of water to ye
third part, and drink thereof often. 20 Stitche, seethe it in white wine and
apply it often in a bag. 21 Appetite to cause, seethe powder of Cummin, Ginger,
and Licoras ana one peniworth in honey till it be thick, and mix a little geane
Triacle with it, and eat thereof first and last. 22 Cummin expels wind and
all other evils from the stomach, and provoke urine. 23 Headache, stamp it
with Betony and Veruaine, and apply it. 24 Ears dull, stamp it and sees it
in vinegar in a bag, and apply it as hot as may be suffered to the ear. 25
Liver chafed, stamp it with Sengreene, and sees them in vinegar and apply it
hot to thy side, as often as need is. 26 Cods swollen, sees it and bean
meal with honey and apply it. 27 Ache in any place apply the powder with honey.
28 Headache straw the powder on a new laid Eg hard roasted, and cut in the
mids, and apply it to the nape of ye neck. 29 Breath stinking, sees two
handful of the powder in a quart of white wine to a pint, and drink it hot
nine days fasting. 30 Swelling, fry ye powder with bean meal and honey, and
apply it. 31 Headache, boil gray bread and powder of Cummin in vinegar til
they be thick, and apply thereof. 32 Breath stinking, seethe the powder in
vinegar, and take v. spoonefull at once 9. mornings. 33 Eyes ache and dull, and
congealed blood, stamp it with Rue and the yolke of an Eg, and apply it, or
mix the powder with crumbs of bread, and the white of an Eg, and apply it. 34
Ears deaf, stamp it with onyons and oil, and rub the ear and apply it
hot. 35 Flux and vomiting, eat Cummin or boil it in vinegar and drink it.
36 Emerods to flow, eat Cummin. 37 Pain after child birth, sees onyons in
water and stamp them with Cummin and oil and apply it, or sees Eggs mightily in
water, and mix their yolks with suet, ye juice of Mugwort and Cummin, and
apply it. 38 For swelling above or under ye eyes, and bloodinesse, mix the
powder with virgins wax and apply thin plasters thereof warm as often as
need is. 39 Eyes bruised or hurt, mix ye powder with May butter, and apply it
till the swelling be past, and then apply Saffron with woman's milk. 40 Ears
apost. to break it, mix the powder with wheat flower, honey, and sheep
tallow and apply it. 41 Ears deaf and noise, seethe the powder in ye juice of
Leekes, and put it in warm. 42 For the host, seethe Sage, Rue, Cummin, and
Pepper with Honey, and take thereof morn and even daily. 43 Appetite to cause,
seethe Peniroyall and Cummin ana like much with some Pepper in Ale, and drink
it at even hot, and at morn cold. 44 Iaundies, seethe a hen with yellowe
feet in white wine with Sage, Cummin, and saffron, and eat the flesh and
drink the broth. 45 Reins ache of wind, apply a plaster of Rue, Cummin,
Calament, and wheat bran with white wine. 46 Back pain, strain thine own
urine through a cloth, and put thereto a fourth part of vinegar with powder of
Cummin, and the juice of Parsley, and boil them together and streine them, and
anoint therewith against the fire. 47 Yard ranckling, boil beans clean
hulled with Cummin, and apply it, and forbear garlike and pepper. 48 Cods
swollen, seethe barley meal with honey, and put powder of Cummin to it and apply
it. 49 Heart cardiake, mix the juice of Betony with Treacle, powder of Cloves,
and Cummin and Annise, and use it 9. days. 50 Yard standing or satyriasis,
seethe Cummin with wine or water and drink it and also apply it. 51 Ear
apostumed, frye wheat meal and powder of Cummin with honey and Capons grease
or Hens grease and apply it. 52 Vomit to stop, apply Mastike, Cummin, and
Bays, with the juice of Rue plaster wise to the stomach. 53 Headache, stamp
red Fenell, Camomile, Sage, and Cummin, and apply it. 54 Belly windy, sees the
seeds of Cummin, Fenell, and Anise in wine, and drink it. 55 Strokes black
and not broken, fry ye juice of wormewod, honey, virgins wax, barowes grease,
and powder of Cummin, of each like much, and apply it. 56 Ache of cold, sees
Cummin in thine own urine, and apply it often warm. 57 Stomach weak, boil
red mints and Cummin with vinegar and crumbs of bread and apply it. 58
Conception to cause, take up the fume of the seeds of Cummin, Parsley, Fenell,
and Alisander, of each like much into the matrix. 59 Face bruised or hurt, mix
powder of Cummin and Anise with wax and apply it. 60 Headache, heat powder of
Cummin in a pan and sprinkle it well with the best red wine that can be had,
and apply it in a linen bag as hot as may be suffered. 61 Stitch, fill a dish
with hot ashes, and cast Cummin on it, and lay a wet cloth over it, and apply
it, and sees red Thyme and Cummin with Malmesey, and drink it. 62 A plaster
for the stomach, stamp Cummin, Wormwood, Mints and Frankincense ana one
handful, with dried crumbs of four bread and vinegar, and apply it in a bag
sprinkled with vinegar. 63 Sweat to cause, frye powder of Cummin with oil and
barowes grease, and anoint therewith the plants of the hands and feet. 64 Head
megreme, anoint a Rye toste with aqua vitae, and cast powder of Cummin on it
and apply it. 65 Breath evil, sees two ounces of powder of Cummin in a
pottell of white wine to the one half, and drink a little of it warm to
bedward xv. nights. 66 Head megreme, apply the fine powder of Cummin with the
gall of an Ox to the nape of the neck. 67 Eyes blooddy, apply the powder with
Wormwood and the white of an Eg with flax hurdes. 68 Teeth yellowe and
stinking, seethe two handful in wine, and drink it xx. days. 70 Belly ache,
seethe Cummin and Rosemary in wine, and drink it. 71 Belly swollen, seethe it
in stale ale and drink it warm. 72 Breath short, sees it with Pulyol and
Calamint in wine and drink it, and cover thee well to sweat. 73 Drink Cummin
with milk to be delivered of a dead child. 74 Ears deaf, boil Cummin and
the juice of Leekes in a hollow Onion and streyne it and drop it in. 75 Eyes
ache and swelling, apply powder of Cummin: it helps any ache or swelling. 76
Eyes bruised, roste the powder of Cummin with the white of an Eg, and cleave it
in two parts and apply it. 77 Feet swollen and gout, spread powder of Cummin
with oil on a Wort leaf, and apply to the soles of ye feet: proved. 78
Gout, mix fine powder of Cummin with honey, and apply it. 79 Apostume, seethe
Wormwood and Cummin in wine and apply it, or seethe Onions and Cummin in wine
and apply it to ye place: proved. 80 Mouth griefs, sees powder of Cummin in
wine to the one half, and drink it morn and even. 81 Paps griefs and
swelling, mix honey and powder of Cummin with the juice of Onions and Smallach
and crumbs of hot bread, and apply it. Pap apostumed, seethe Cummin in oil with
bean meal and apply it. 82 Milt swollen, seethe a bag of Cummin in white wine,
and apply it hot. 83 Stitch, drink Stitchwort, and apply Cummin sodden in
thine own urine to thy back. 84 Ache of the stomach and small guts, put ii.
parts of Bays, and one part of Cummin to honey a little, and apply it to the
stomach. 85 Swelling of the stomach and belly, sees it in ale and drink it
hot. 86 Swellings of all sorts, sees Otemeale with sweet milk, Cummin, and
saffron, and apply it. 87 Ache and other griefs of the matrix, stamp Paritary
with honey and Cummin and apply it. 88 Cods swollen, boil crumbs of brown bread
and bean meal of each like much with new Worte, and when it is almost
boiled, put thereto some Cumminseede and a dish of fresh butter, and apply it.
89 Brain to comfort and restore, steep it iii. days in vinegar, and dry it
and chewe thereof, and hold it long in thy mouth, and then swallow it down,
and do so often. 90 Vomiting of cold and moist cause, make iiii. bags of a
spanne square, quilt into every one, one ounce of Cummin, seethe them in a
quart of vinegar, and bind them to the wristes and insteps warm often: and
eat some gray peason sodden with Cummin, and drink some good strong drink,
and at every breakefast eat one penny weight of beaten Saffron to comfort the
brain and stomach, and stop vomiting, and these take away all gripings. 91
Urine stopped, heat a new brick glowing hot, sprinkle thereon good wine
wherein Cummin has been sodden, and sit over the fume of it that it may go
in. 92 Hardness and griping of the body, seethe the seeds of Cummin and
Fenell in sallet oil, and anoint therewith. 93 Chollike passion, seethe crumbs
of clean wheaten bread, and powder of Cummin with white vinegar, and apply it
as hot as may be suffered. 94 Cummin may be kept five years and used in
meats, and drinks, and sawces, to comfort and help digestion. 95 Seethe the
seeds of Cummin and Fenell, with dry Figs well bruised together in wine,
and drink it against the wind and torment in the guts, and for the cough
coming of cold. 96 Cheeks swollen, stamp the seeds with Figs, and seethe
with wine and apply it. 97 Head cold reume, apply powder of Cummin and Bays
warm to the head in a bag to help it without fail. 98 Bruises, melt wax
with fine powder of Cummin, and apply it warm. 99 Seethe it and Fenigreke in
wine, to void the swelling and griping of the guts. 100 Strangury and other
passions of the bladder, seethe it in in wine and apply it to the navel. 101
Seethe the seeds in water, and wash therewith to be clearer and fayrer. 102
Nose bleeding, seethe the bruised seeds in vinegar, and apply to the nose
warm, and to the matrix to cease the reds. 103 Cummin may be used in meats as
Pepper, being sodden with Pease, it expels wind, phlegm, and gross humors,
and takes away the lothing of the stomach. 104 Sees it in wine, and drink
it to help the Iaundies and the vertigo. 105 Cummin skattereth and breaks
all windines of the stomach, belly, guts and matrix, and is singular good
against the gripings and torments of the belly, either drunk or in glisters,
or laid to with Barley meal. 106 The same eaten or drunk, is good for the
cough and cold, and stopping of the breast, and drunk with wine it is good
for them that are hurt of any venomous beast. 107 It slaketh and dissolueth the
swelling of the cods being applied. 108 Mix it with Darnell meal and the pulp
of reasins, and apply it to a woman's belly to stop the inordinate course of the
flowers. 109 Nose bleeding, smell to the powder with vinegar. Eyes red, apply
the powder with juice of Rue with cotton. 110 Mix Cummin and Honey of each
three ounces, Turpentine two ounces, and Bay salt one ounce on the fire, and
apply it to any swelling that comes of a stroke or fall. 111 Eat it after
Garlike to take away the smell thereof. 112 Cummin used too much, causes a
pall color. 113 The fume of it drives away gnats. 114 Fry it with Barley
meal and honey, of each like much, with a little sheep suet, and apply it to
the swollen cods.

Currants.
CVrrants differ not much in virtue from frail reasins (See Seen) 2 Eat them
with meat to void belching and stop the flux. To void phlegm and engender
good blood, eat every morning 7. drams.

Belching 2 Blood to increase Phlegm 2 Fluxes 2
Daffadill.
DAffadill: swellings great in all parts, stamp the roots, and drink them
with water, saffron, and sugar, and be whole. 2 Stamp the blades and seethe
them in a pint of ale or wine with a spoonefull of Grains bruised, and drink
it before the fit to help the ague. 3 Apply the root with oil to the pain
of the heart or liver. 4 It does draw and dissolve. 5 Apostume to ripen,
stamp the root with Honey and meal of Orobus, and apply it. 6 Boil two
drammes of the fresh root new gathered in wine or water with a little Anise or
Fenell seed, and a little Ginger, and drink it to drive forth by seege tough
and clammie phlegm, and to help all diseases that come thereof. 7 The root
eaten or drunk, provoke to vomit. 8 It is good for burnings. 9 The root
broken with a little honey heals cut synowes, joints that are out, and old
aches of the joints being applied. 10 With vinegar and Nettleseede it takes
away the spots, and morphue of the face. 11 With Fitches it scowreth away
matter from wounds. 12 With Darnel meal and Honey, it breaks apostumes, and
draws out pricks and splents. 13 It makes flesh to grow in wounds. 14
Breasts swollen, and all inflammations, bruise the root and apply it.

Ache 9 Apostume 12. 5 Belching Breasts swollen 14 Burnings 8 Cuts 9 Face
deformed 10 Fever 2 Phlegm 6 Flesh to grow 13 Heart grief 3 Inflammation 14
Joints out 9 Liver grief 3 Morphue 10 Pricks 12 Purgation 6 Sinowes cut 9
Skin foul 10 Swellings 1 Vomit to cause 7 Wounds 11. 13
Damsons.
DAmsons are most wholesome of all Plums, which eaten before meat cool the
stomach and loosen the belly, (See Plumtree.) 2 Mouth heat, seethe Damsons,
Violets, and a little Sorell in water, til the Damsons begin to break, then
streine it and seethe the liquour again with a few Barberies and streine it
and drink. 3 To dry them, gather them in Somer, and slice them, and lay them
on a boorde in the Sun, and sprinckle them often with vinegar, and let them
dry so, then put them in a box of wood, and sprinckle them with a little
vinegar, and use to eat of them daily against the heat of the stomach. 4
Sees the leaves or rind of the root in wine or water, and wash the mouth
therewith to help the toothache, and looseness of the gummes and all the
mouth without pain. 5 The gum breaks and expels the stone. When they be
ripe, gather them and slit them, and sprinkle them often with vinegar, and dry
them in ye sun xv. days, then keep them in a wodden vessel one year: for
so long they will last, then are they good in sharp fevers for costiuenesse
coming of dry choler, if they be new, eat them, if they be old, boil them in
water and drink it for the fever tertian, stopping of the liver, the Iaundies,
sharp fevers, costiuenes, want of appetite, and many other griefs. 6 Set i.
li. in a pot in an oven with a batch of bread, then streine it, and put as much
honey to it, and so make it in conserve. It is good against choler and heat of
the stomach and liver and other hot griefs. 7 Seethe the leaves, bark or root
in water or wine, and wash the mouth therewith to fasten the teeth, and keep
the mouth from all pain. (See Plum, Prune.)

Belly bound 1. 5 Fevers sharp 5. 6. tertian 5. 6. Hot griefs 6 Iaundies 5
Liver stopped 5. 6 Mouth griefs 2. 4 Sickness hot 5 Stomach hot 2. 3. 6
Stone 5 Teeth-ach 4. 7. loose 4. 7.
Danewort.
DAnewort, or Wallwort. Gout pain, seethe it in wine and apply it, or stamp
the leaves and roots, and strein them with wine and seethe it with May butter
and anoint often. 2 Dropsy, seethe it in wine or water and drink a good
draught morn and even xx. days and be whole. 3 Gout, stamp iii. li. with i.
li. of May butter, and let it stand ix. days, then boil it half an hour and
streine it and anoint. 4 Ach and bruses, stamp good store with some Balm and
Smallach, and i. li. of May butter, and let it lie in balls ix. days, then
stamp it again and fry it and strein it, and keep it in a vessel of earth or
glass and use it. Gout cold in any place, and ach of the bones, stamp iii.
handfuls with one handful of Horehound, and strein out the juice, and boil it
with a pint of swines grease half an hour, then strein it and use it, (see
Eldren. 5 Legs swollen, mix the juice with barley meal and vinegar and wax of
each like much, and boil it, and apply it. 6 Ears worms, put in the juice. 7
Costiuenesse, drink the juice with honey. 8 Danewort is good for the dropsy,
tetters, and scabs, and draws evil humors out of the body. 9 Teethach, rub
them with it. 10 Bruses and swellings, seethe the roots in water and stamp them
with bores grease and apply them. 11 Dropsy, stamp it and seethe it, and lie
therein, and hyl thee well to sweat. 12 Swellings in the thighs or feet,
seethe the middle rind in water and apply it hot with bores grease
plasterwise. 13 Dropsy, drink the juice of the root with wine iiii. days to
help it, though it have continued a year, or use the syrop of the juice of it.
14 Gout, seethe the juice with as much wine to the thicknes of an ointment, or
honey and anoint there with. 15 Stone, chop a bushel small, put it in a bag,
seethe it in water, and bath therein ix. days and apply the bag where the
stone is. 16 Fever quotid. steep ii. ounces of the whitest pith in half a pint
of the best aqua vitae iii. days, then strein it and drink thereof, if it
chafe too much, put some wine or other drink to it. 17 Head vanity, anoint the
temples with the juice, salt, honey, wax, and incense boiled together. 18
Backache, seethe it to pap and stamp it, and fry it with sheeps tallow, and put
wheat bran to it and apply it. 19 Cods sw^llen, boylerye meal with the juice,
honey and vinegar till it be thick and apply it. 20 Dropsy, seethe great store
in water and make a bath of it, and lie therein all night, and cover thee well
with the herbs and water, and also drink the juice thereof. 21 Sleep to cause,
(see in Lettis, Eldren, etc. 22 Teeth-ach, rub them with ye root. 23 Stomach
swollen and belly bound, drink the juice with honey ix. days. 24 Dropsy, seethe
it in wine or water, and drink it to have present help. 25 Cods swollen, apply
the juice with bean flower, and common oil. 26 Matrix swollen, impostumed and
hardness: Foment, with the decoction of the root. 27 Fever quotid. stamp the
root and seethe it in ale or white wine, and drink it before the fit, and sleep
not. 28 Scrophules, stamp it and apply it. 29 The leaves and new buds, have the
same virtues that ye leaves and crops of Eldren have being taken after the same
manner. 30 Priuities swollen, seethe the leaves and apply them. 31 Take up the
fume of the decoction thereof for the swelling pain of the belly and matrix
being set in a close stool. 32 The juice of the fruit makes hair black. 33
The fume of it burned, drives away serpents and other venomous beasts. 34
Seethe the leaves in wine, and apply them to the torment of the gout, or seethe
the juice of the herb and root with wine and butter, and anoint therewith
iiii. or v. times every day. 35 Mother windy and other griefs of it, sit in
the decoction of it. 36 Apply the tender leaves to swage inflammations and
burnings and biting of dogs. 37 They draw together gaping wounds that become
like fistulaes. 38 Gout, apply the leaves with bulls tallow, or goats sewet. 39
Both Danewort and Eldren are very hurtful to the stomach, yet the tender leaves
sodden and eaten like a sallet, purge phlegm and choler. 40 The juice of the
Beries stamped with fresh grease and barley meal, do cleanse rotten sores, and
cools the burning of a gout and pain in the joints. 41 The tender crops at
ye spring time are used in meats to soften the belly without danger. 42 The
same sodden with wine and mixed with honey and drunk, is good for the cold and
dry cough and to cleanse the breast. 43 The root is more effectual then the
leaves. 44 Dropsy, seethe the root in wine, and drink it morn and even: it is
excellent good. 45 Squincy, gargarise with the water, or with the decoction of the
leaves and some Piretrum put to it. 46 Seethe or steep ye leaves in water and
sprinckle it about the house to kill fleas and gnats.

Dandelion.
DAndelion, is in virtue much like to Cicory, and may be always used in stead
of it. 2 The juice often applied, lays down the staring of the hair of the
eybrowes, and causes new hairs to grow. 3 Head hot griefs, temper it with
rose vinegar and use it, and so does Sowthistle and Cicory. 4 Eyes dim, put in
the water of it. 5 Fever tertian, drink the juice three or four times before
the fit, especially with powder of crystal and wine. 6 Sees it well in
water, and use it for the knitting of wounds and for burstings and for
ruptures, etc. 7 Bitings venomous, stamp it and apply it. 8 Fever quotidian,
use the roots of it. 9 Fevers, drink the water of it and of Sorell, Sowthistle
and Endive all mixed together.

Bitings venomous 7 Bursten 6 Eyes dull 4 Fevers 9. quotid. 8. quarten, tertian
5. Head griefs hot 3 Hair to grow 2. standing up 2. Wounds 6
Darnell.
DArnell. Kings evil, seethe it in wine with the dung of an ass and Linseeds,
and drink it. 2 Reume in the head, apply a bag of Darnell and salt, and
Anniseeds. 3 Scrophules and wheals, seethe it with Linseed, Pigeons doung and
quick brimstone in wine and apply it. 4 The meal applied with salt and Radish
roots stays wild scurfe and fretting sores. 5 The same with brimstone and
vinegar applied, cures spreading scabs and leapry, and scurfe. 6 With Pigeons
doung, oil, and Linseed boiled and applied, it helps wennes and hard tumors,
and draws forth all pricks splents and thorns, and does ripen and open
impostumes and tumors. 7 Sodden with Mede or Oximel, it swageth the pain of
the gout and sciatica. 8 Headache, apply it to the forehead with birds grease. 9
Put into Ale or Beer, it causes drunkenness, and troubles the brain. 10
Apply the meal to rotten burning and deadly sores to cure them. 11 Conception
to cause, use perfumes of the same, with parched barley meal and Myrrh or
Saffron. 12 The meal sodden in wine with Linseed and Doves doung, dissolueth
hard lumps and wennes, and breaks such places as are hard to ripen. 13 The
root sodden in wine and drunk after it has stood certain days, kills
worms. 14 The seeds ground with salt, vinegar, and quick brimstone, heals
ringwormes and tetters.

Apostumes 6. 12 Byle 9. 12 Conception 11 Gout 7 Head rheum 2 Hardness 6. 12
Headache 8 Kings evil 1. 3 Leapry 5 Ringwormes 14 Rheum 2 Sciatica 7
Scrophules 3 Scabs 5 Scurfe 4. 5 Sores 4. 10 Swellings 6. 12 Wenne 6. 12
Wheales 3 Worms 13
Dasy.
DAsy. The decoction of small Dasies with their leaves, or boiled alone in
water and drunk, helps agues, and all inward inflammations of the liver, etc.
2 The herb in meats and pottage loosneth the belly gently. 3 Maudlinwort, or
the herby part of the wild Dasy, is good against all burning ulcers,
impostumes, and inflammations of the eyes and their runnning being applied. 4
The same applied, keeps wounds from inflammacions and impostumation. 5 Apply
it to avoid all great swellings and wenns. 6 Apply it and drink it to heal
wounds. 7 Use the juice for the palsy, the gout and the sciatica. 8 Dasies red
or white, single or double be all of like virtues, they are used in potions for
fractures of the head and deep wounds in the breast. 9 Put the juice of the
herb and root into the nose to purge the brain. 10 Use Dasies in pottage. Use
the green herb with sharp things to supple the bound belly, or the decoction
thereof with fat flesh. 11 The herb heals swellings of the throat and pain
of the neck. 12 Stamp it and apply it to break and heal botches. 13 Eyes web,
put in the juice. 14 Stamp the herb and the root, but do away the red spotted,
and seethe them and clarify them and put thereto honey and yolks of eggs as much
as the herb, and put wheat flower to it, and seethe it til it be thick, and use
plasters thereof to all cuts and sores. 15 If a wounded man drink the juice,
and cast it up, he shall die, if not, he shall live. 16 Wounds, drink the juice,
and apply thereof with sweet milk and wheat flower. 17 Heart griefs, use it
with other medicines. 18 Seethe the herb with Parsley roots in water, especially
with Radish water, and drink thereof morn and even, to cause vrin. 19 Bones
broken, stamp Dasies, Cumfery, and Egrimony with vinegar and apply it till it be
whole. 20 A handful of the less Dasy with milk, stops all issues of blood
inward and outward in ix. days. 21 Breaking out, stamp the leaves, and fry
them with fresh butter, and streine it, and anoint therewith. 22 Hands broken
out with heat and worms, and blanes, stamp wild Tansy and Dasy flowers in
cold running water, and wash therewith. 23 Ribs broken, drink the juice of it
and also mix thereof with sweet milk and wheat flower, and apply it. 24
Head megrem, put the juice of the herb and root into thy nose lying on thy
back. 25 Breast swollen and hard, mix the juice of Dasies and Morell with
barley, dregs of vinegar, and a hard sodden egg, and apply it. 26 Yard sore and
full of of holes, stamp good store of Dasies and apply them often. 27 Pyles,
stamp the leaves and roots with honey, and apply it. 28 Bitings venomous,
stamp the roots and apply them. 29 Bruses boil Mawdlin in water and apply it.
30 Streining to go to the stool, and to stop the blood of the emerods, seethe
Mawdlin in tart wine, and foment therewith.

Dates.
DAtes be hard of digestion, they stop the liver and the milt, they breed wind
in the belly and head ach, and breed gross blood, especially being eaten
green, but when they are through ripe, they are not so hurtful. And being well
digested in a good stomach, they nourish indifferently. 2 Dry Dates do stop ye
belly, and stay vomiting and wambling of the stomach, especially of women with
child being laid as an emplaster to ye stomach or belly, and mixed with other
medicines and eaten. 3 Also they restore and strengthen the feeblenes of the
liver and milt with convenient medicines either inwardly or outwardly. 4 The
leaves and branches of the Date tree do heal green wounds, and close up
ulcers and cool hot inflammations. If Dates be plentifully eaten, they cause
drunkenness. 5 Dry Dates are good to be eaten against spetting of blood, griefs
of the stomach, the bloody flixe, and the roughnes of the throat. 6 The stones
burned in an vnbaked pot and quenched in wine, or the ashes burnt will serve
for Spodium. 7 Dates are evil for the head, eyes, teeth, and gums. 8 But they
are good in a co^sumption or lask, especially sodden in milk or in Muscadel. 9
The powder of the stones with Sanguis draconis in rasp wine, or red wine, is
passing good in ye same cases. 10 The electuary called Diaphenicon, half an
ounce taken, purges phlegm and choler. 11 Tie one stone bored through to ye
necks of beasts, and they shall not be hurt with their fetters, or if they be,
they shall be cured. 12 Burn the stones and apply the powder to the ulcers and
fistulaes of the fundament, or upon the hole of the fundament and be whole. 13
Stone in the kidneys, make powder of Date stones and white Allom, and use it
with roasted figs at night only. 14 To stop the whites, take powder of Date
stones, half an ounce, Dragons blood one dram. Mix it with red wine and take
one dram of it by the break of day, and as much when thou go to bed. 15 To
cause deliverance of a dead child, drink water of Rue, with powder of two Date
stones. 16 For a consumption, take Dates ii. li. wash them and slise them, and
seethe them in a quart of honey clarified, till they be dissolved, then put in
by little and little, fine powder of long Pepper, Cloves, Mace, and Nutmeg of each
half an ounce, and stir it til it wax thick, and use it first and last. If you
take thereof upon a full stomach you shall not surfeit (See Almonds.) 17 Date
stones takes away the tooth ache. The powder of them drunk with wine eases
women in travail. (See Consumption restoratiue.)

Belly loose 2. 8. 9 Bloody flux 5 Blood spetting 5 Consumption 3. 8. 9. 16
Dead child 15 Deliverance 15. 17 Fundament fistula 12. sores 12. Horse griefs
11 Inflammation 4 Liver bad 3 Milt bad 3 Purgation 10 Sores 4 Stomach bad 2. 5
Stone 13 Throat rough 5 Vomiting 2 Whites 14 Woman in travel 17 Wounds 4
Deadnettle.
DEadnettle (See Archangel) 2 Matrix white flux, drink three ounces of the
water.

Matrix fluxes 2
Dew.
Dew: to cause the hair to grow long, wash the head with the Dew in meadows
all the mornings of March thrice a day.

Hair to grow. 1
Daucus.
DAucus: Breath streite and unsavory, seethe it with figs and drink it. 2 The
seeds are good against the hycket. 3 Dry cough, seethe the root with wine and
figs, and streine it, and drink it. (See Saxifrage, Wild Carrats.)

Breath ill 1 Cough dry 3 Hycket 2
Diagridium.
DIagridium, six grayns taken purges down vehemently chollericke humors,
and is good for the Iaundies, pluxisie, frenzy, hot fevers, and all griefs
coming of heat. 2 Apply it with honey and oil to dissolve all cold
swellings, 3 And with vinegar to heal all spreading scabs, and hardness of
the skin. 4 Head ach old, apply it with oil of Roses and vinegar, put it into
the matrix, to provoke the terms, and expel the seconds and dead birth. 5
Take it with the pulpe of prunes, or with conserve of roses, or with masticke,
and the juice of quinces. 6 The best is shining and black. 7 There is good
that is whitish, but much is sophisticated with the juice of spurge Colophonie
etc. 8 Cast the powder of it on a bruised mallowe root, and put it into the
Matrix to bring down the flowers. 9 Costiuenesse, seethe a good quantity in
water, and seethe therein a capon and eat it and sup the broth. 10 Hecktike,
drink a little of the powder with the decoction of Lycoras.

Belly bound 9 Consumption 10 Fevers hot 1 Flowers stopped 4. 8 Frenzy 1
Headache 4 Hectike 10 Hot griefs 1 Iaundies 1 Plurisie 1 Purgation 1. 5. 9
Scabbes 3 Skin deformed 3 Swellings 1. 2
Dill.
DIll: drink the broth of the leaves and seeds when it is ripe, to breed
milk, to cease gnawing and windiness, it stops the belly and vomiting,
provoke urine, swageth the Hycket, it dulleth the sight, and being often
drunk, it stops the seed. 2 Seethe it in water and sit over it for the
greefes of the mother. 3 Hard bunches and knobbes about the fundament, apply
the ashes of the seeds plasterwise: it does the like in all other places. 4
Green Dill, swageth ache, provoke sleep, and ripeneth raw humors. 5 The
oil is good for weariness in Winter, for it softeneth and moysteneth, it is
good for flegmatike agues, and all cold diseases and swellings. 6 The
decoction thereof with sugar, is good for the Strangurie, and Dissurie. 7 The
decoction of the tops and crops with the seed boiled in water and drunk,
causes plenty of milk, expels wind, swageth gripings, stops vomitings
and laskes, and provoke urine. 8 A suffumigation thereof helps the
suffocation of the mother. 9 Chafe well the seed, and smell to it to void the
Hicket. 10 Ashes of the herb do close up and heal moist sores, especially in
the shares and privy parts. 11 Boil Dill in oil to resolve, digest, and
swage pain, provoke lust, and ripen all raw and unripe tumors. 12 Dill often
used, diminishes the sight and the seed. 13 Seethe it in oil to release
shrinking and astonishing of the sinews, and many other passions. 14 Mix
powder of Dill with acorne cups, and drink half an ounce with half a pint
of Ale or Wine, to cure the bloody Flux. 15 Sleep to cause, anoint the head
with the oil. 16 Ears pain, drop in the oil. Sleep to cause, wear a
garland of green Dill to thy head. 17 Seethe the herb and seed in wine, and
drink it to help straitness of pissing, and to increase milk. 18 Boil a
handful of Dill in Wine, and apply it to the payned Matrix. 19 Seethe Dill
with poppie seed, and drink it to stay vomiting, griping, and windiness. 20
Strangurie, seethe Dill in wine, and drink it. 21 Seethe Dill with sugar in
wine and oil, and drink it to drive down the Flowers and seconds, and to
help the mother, but drink but two drammes at once. 22 Mix powder of the
seeds with as much powder of nettle seed, and mix it with water and honey,
and apply it to the piles to heal them in short time. 23 Belly ach, drink
the juice or decoction thereof. 24 Pissing bed, drink the seed with water
or wine. 25 Stomach cold, seethe nutmegges and maces with Dill seed and
feuel seed in wine and drink it. 26 Belly grynding, drink the juice of
penyroyal and plantine, boiled with powder of Dill. 27 Seethe the seeds in
water and dip old silk therein, and wipe the emerodes therewith, and make a
suppositor of the same: it helps also the tenasmus. 28 Ashes of the seeds
helps the scalding and all other griefs of the yard and privy parts. 29 A
plaster of the powder with Sheep tallow, and black soap, helps the
emerodes. 30 Lothing, seethe the leaves in water, and drink four ounces and
an half, and smell to the herb and seed to avoid the hicket. Vuula fallen,
burn the roots, and apply the powder. 31 Lungs griefs, drink powder of the
seeds morn and even, and so it helps pissing in bed. 32 Lust to void,
eat the seeds often. 33 Hicket, apply powder of the seeds with the juice of
mints to the stomach.

Knobbes 3 Loathing 30 Lungs griefs 31 Lust to cause 11 to void 32

Dittanie.
DIttanie drunk with water or wine, causes speedy deliverance, and easy,
though the child be dead, or out of due course, and expels the seconds,
penyroyall does the like. 2 Deliverance, and to save both the woman and the
child: stamp Dittanie, veruine, and hyssope ana one handful, and streyne it
with ale, and drink a good draught in thy travel. 3 Goats to give milk, tie
it about their bellies. 4 Ptisicke, and spitting of blood, drink Dittanie often
with woman's milk. 5 Deliverance, stamp Dittanie, and streine it, and drink
it. 6 Pricks, stamp it and apply it. 7 Teethach, sees it in white wine, and
hold it in thy mouth. 8 Plague, poison, and venim, use the water of it. 9
Flowers stopped, sees it with sauin in wine, and drink it. 10 Pricks and thorns,
stamp it with Polipody, and swines grease, and apply it. 11 Strangurie, drink
the juice with white wine. 12 It helps all venime, and poison, and drives
out pellets, and all other pricks, the place being also anointed therewith.
13 Dead child, and seconds, put in the juice and powder especially of the
root. 14 Sleep to cause, mix it and dogge-fenel with oil of roses and
anoint. 15 It is used of some in stead of pepper. 16 Sciatica, stamp the root
with soft grease of a goose, or capon, and apply it. 17 Milt swollen, stamp it
and apply it. 18 Sciatica, apply it with clecampana four hours, and then
open the blisters.

cause 3 Milte stopped 17 Plague 8 Poison 8. 12 Ptisicke 4 Pricks 6. 10. 12
Sciatica 16. 18 Seconds 1. 13 Sleep to cause 14 Strangurie 11 Teethach 7
Venime 8. 12
Dockes.
DOcks and Sorell: the leaves of all Dockes sodden, and eaten, loosen the
belly gently, and so does the broth of them. 2 Head apostume and swellings,
stamp the green leaves and a little saffron, and oil of roses, and apply it.
3 Bloody flixe, or laske, seethe the seeds in water or wine, and drink it,
it helps also the wambling pain of the stomach, and venomous bytings. 4
Eat the seeds before hand, and no biting or stinging shall pain thee. 5
Seethe the root in wine, and drink it to heal the Iaundies, provoke urine
and terms, and to break and expel the stone and gravel. 6 The root boiled
in vinegar, or bruised raw, does heal all skurfes, as itche, and maunge, and
griefs of the skin, being applied. 7 The decoction or broth of the root
helps all maunge, festering, and consuming skabbes being washed therewith. 8
Teethach, seethe the roots in wine, and hold it in thy mouth, and put thereof
into the ear for the pain thereof. 9 Boil the roots and apply them to
hard kernels and swellings behind the ears to consume them, stamp them with
vinegar, and apply them to the hardness of the milt. 10 Flowers to stop,
stamp the roots and apply them to the Matrix. 11 Kings evil, or swelling in
the throat, hang the root about thy neck. 12 Headache, stamp sorell with
oil of roses, and apply it. 13 Whatsoever meat is sodden with any kind of
Docke, will become tender, though it be never so old. 14 Conception to cause,
tie the seeds to the left arm. 15 The roots either new or dry put into
wine, will turn it from white to read. 16 The great garden Docke drunk in
wine, purges phlegm, choler and water downward. 17 Carry the feeds of
sorell gathered by a chaste boy about thee, and thou shall have no pollution
of seed neither by night nor by day. 18 Swine pockes, hang sorell roots
about thy neck, or plantine roots. 19 Drink one dram of the root of the
garden Docke, or Monks rubarb to purge withal. 20 Chollicke, seethe the
leaves of Dockes, and mallows in water, and stamp them and apply them. 21
Milt-swollen, seethe the root in strong vinegar, and stamp it and apply it:
the leaves so used, does the like. 22 Urine stopped, stamp the roots, and
seethe them with wine, and apply it above the yard. 23 Face salsflegme, mix
the juice of read Dockes and wormwood with aloes, and anoint. 24 Gout,
seethe the leaves of great Docke in May with wine or Ale, and drink it. 25
Scabbes and Itche, boil the juice of read Dockes, with giltes grease, till
the juice be consumed: then put thereto a little Turpentine, and Quicke-siluer
mortified, and use it. 26 Leaprie, stamp the roots of sharp read Dockes,
and round Dockes, their pith taken out, and boil them with vinegar and salt
butter till the vinegar be consumed, and use it both for the Impetigo and
Serpigo: or boil the juice of sharp leaued Dockes with Swines grease, till
the juice be consumed. Then streyne it, and put thereto Turpentine, and
quicksilver mortified, and anoint therewith the Morphew, white or black
spots and Leaprie. 27 Leaprie, boil the juice of sharp Dockes, Fumiterre,
and Scabious ana like much with swines grease, till the juice be consumed,
then streine it and anoint therewith morn and even. 28 Stitch, stamp read
fenell, and read Dockes, and frye them with May butter, and apply it. 29
Make ointment of the roots of Celondine, and read Dockes, with wormwood, of
each like much, tempered with May butter, and use it, proved. 30 Worms in
the hands, Boil the juice of wormwood and read Dockes with May butter, and
stir it: and when it is thick like a salve, keep it to thy use. 31
Emerodes, Roste the leaves of read Dockes, Columbine and Leekes in the embers,
and stamp them, and apply them, and be whole in three days. 33 Impostume to
break, stamp the roots of read Dockes with Licoras and anniseedes of each
like much, and seethe them in water till the third part be wasted: then
streyne it, and drink it daily. 33 Kings evil, seethe read Docke roots in
white wine, and drink it daily. 34 Hands scabbed, stamp sharp leaued
Dockes, and Fumiterre, of each like much, and make it an ointment with May
Butter, Swines grease, and some roche allume, and anoint therewith. 35 Itche,
boil the roots of sharp leaued Dockes or Sorell, and wash therewith. 36
Iaundies, wash the roots of the reddest Dockes, and put them into a vessel
of good ale, and when it is stale, drink thereof daily. 37 Burning, anoint
with the juice of Sorell and Plantine. Flux to stop, use powder of read
Docke seeds. 38 Gout, grind the over bark of read Docke roots with
vinegar, and boil them to the one half, and strain it and anoint. 39 Brain
to purge, put in the juice of Rue and read Dockes into thy nose. 40 Breast and
breath stopped, make pannecakes with Dockes and eggs, or meat, and use them. 41
Iaundies, lay the roots all night in ale, and drink thereof. 42 Apostumes to
ripen, Roste the roots or leaves of Dockes, and Lilies in the embers, and
apply them with Swines grease. 43 Coddes swollen, stamp the roots with
Swines grease, and apply them. 44 Morphewe, anoint with the juice. 45 To know
whether the Gout be hot or cold, roste the tender stalk of a red Docke in
a leaf of the same Docke, and apply it to the holes eight and forty hours,
and if it fall not away, it is the Gout, Festerhote. 46 Scabbes, stamp read
Docke roots with fresh butter, and boil them and strain it into cold water,
and gather the oil and anoint therewith.

17 Chollicke 20 Cods swelling 43 Conception to cause 14 Emerods 31 Face
salsflegme 23 Flowers stopped 5 to stop 10
Gout 24. 38. 45 Gravel 5 Hands skabbed 34 worms 30
Headache 12 apostume 2 swollen 2
Iaundies 36. 41 Impostume 32 Itch 25. 29. 35 Kernels 9 Kings evil 9. 11. 18.
33 Laske 3 Leapry 26. 27 Maunge 6. 7 Milt hard 9 swollen 21

Dodder.
DOdder, boiled in water or wine, and drunk, opens the Liver, milt, kidneys,
and bladder, and gaul, and veins, and purges choleric humors byseege and
urine. 2 It is good for old fevers, and the Iaundies, especially that which
grows on hoppes and brambles. 3 The other sorts have the properties of the
things that they grow upon. 4 Seethe one handful in wine, and drink it
against all obstructions: the Iaundies, the dropsy, etc. 5 The distilled water
is very good against the French pockes, to provoke sweat, and to withstand
the Fever tertian, and expel melancholy. 6 The same used in bathes is good
against melancholy, the iaundies, that is old, and the ague in children: it
must be taken with anniseed. 7 With wormwood it purges yellow choler. 8
Seethe it with mirrhe and oil, and use it for the ache of the back, breast and
other limbs.

Aches 8 Backach 8 Bladder stopped 1 Brestach 8 Choler 1. 7 Dropsy 4 Fevers 2

French pocks 5 Iaundies 3. 6. 2 Kidneis stopped 1 Liver stopped 1 Melancholy 5. 6
Obstructions 4 Sweat to cause 5
Dogge-fenell.
DOgge-fenell, or mathes, the juice drunk, it helps the canker, pyles and
emerods, the falling evil. 2 Sleep to avoid, smell to it. 3 Headache, and to
cause sleep, anoint with oil of roses, Dogge-fenell, and castorie. 4
Teeth-wormes, put in the juice of the root or herb. 5 Dooge-fenell roots
expel broken bones. 6 Plague hot, drink as much powder of the root as will
lie on a crown with vinegar, but in the cold plague with wine. 7 Hair to
grow again, seethe raddish leaves with as much Dogge-fenell roots well in
water, and wash therewith. 8 Put powder of the roots into wounds, that being
healed break forth again, by reason of a putrified bone. 9 Fundament
falling, and for the sig, drink the juice and apply the substance. 10 It is
called Cotulafetida, or stinking camomil, mathes, or Dogfenel, and is good
against the looseness and falling down of the matrix, being sodden in water,
and the feet washed therewith. 11 And being smelled unto, it helps the
suffocation thereof, and it has the nature and all the virtues of Castorie. 12
Drink the juice of a handful of it with a pint of Malmesey against the Ague,
the plague, and to comfort nature every morning. 13 Smell to it to avoid
sleep in the Lytargie. Falling evil, give him the juice to drink in the
fit, to cure him presently. 14 Squincy, drink the juice. Seethe it in wine,
and drink it for the stopping of the liver and milt, the strangury and the
flux. 15 Milt hard, use it in plasters. 16 Seethe it in water and wine with
barley and licoras, and drink it to help the cold humors in the spiritual
members. 17 Drink the juice thereof nine days with ale and honey to cast out
an impostume.

Dragagant.
DRagagant is good for the cough, roughness of the throat, hoarsenes being
likt in with honey. 2 Steep a dram in wine, and drink it with some powder of a
Hearts horn burnt and washed, for the pain of the kidneies and bladder. 3 It
is used in colliries for the eyes. The clearest is best, it helps ulcers and
blearednesse of the eyes, ulcers of the intralles. Drink the powder of it
against the crampe, and breaking of veins inward. 4 Dissolve it in Rose water,
for chaps and excoriations with some starch. 5 To make the face white, and to
avoid ranknes, steep it a night in Rose water, and in the morning put a little
borace or camphire to it, and strike the face therewith. It tempereth the
sharpness of hot medicines. 6 With Fenell water it helps the griefs of the
reins and bladder. 7 One dram with clean honey cleanses the lungs, clears
the voice, and helps the cough. 8 Lips chapt, dissolve Penides in water with
gum Dragagant, and anoint. 9 Dissolve it in Rose water, and strain it and
mix therewith powder of Amidum, and anoint therewith the sores and clifts of
the mouth and lips. 10 Seethe it in wine with Stecados, and drink it to
warm and cleanse the breast, and stomach, and bowels, for the chollike, the
stopping of the milt and urine, the strangury and dissury. 11 Chaps, steep it
in hot water, and anoint with the mussilage. 12 Lepry, anoint with the
mussilage and honey.

Dragons.
DRagons stamped with oil and put into the eyes, takes away their ache. 2 The
root stamped with the root of a white Onion and honey heals all wounds that the
kanker has been risen in. 3 He that rubbeth his hands with the root in May,
take adders, and they shall not venim him. 4 Eyes dull, anoint with the juice.
5 Lust to avoid, drink the juice with wine. 6 Biting of a Dog or Adder,
drink Dragons, Rue and Betony. 7 Chollike, seethe it in wine or water, and
drink it. 8 Mouth griefs, apply the juice. 9 Drink the juice against all
venomous bitings, poison and venim. 10 The seed drunk, helps the sight. 11
Dragons bound to the priuity of a woman in labor, causes present deliverance,
but take it away speedily lest the matrix follow. 12 The root boiled or roasted,
and mixed with honey, and licked, is good for the straitness of breath,
dangerous coughs, and catharres, conuulsions, and cramps, they consume gross
and tough humors, and scowre and cleanse the inner parts: they have like power,
being sodden three or four times, till they have lost their sharpness, and
then eaten in meat. 13 The same dried and mixed with honey, scowreth malignant
and fretting sores that are hard to cure, especially mixed with the root of
Briony: and it takes away all white spots and skurfe being rubbed therewith.
14 The juice of the root puts away all webs and spots of the eyes, and is
good in eye medicines. 15 The same dropped into the ears with oil, takes away
their pain. 16 The fruit cures malignant ulcers, and the polip in the nose,
kankers, and malignant ulcers that consume. 17 The fresh leaves heal green
wounds. 18 The leaves laid among cheese, keeps it from perishing or rotting.
19 Some hold that he that carries the leaves or roots about him, cannot be
hurt of vipers and serpents. 20 New cheese wrapped in the dry leaves, will not
molde nor putrify. 21 With the roots and leaves are made oiles, ointments and
plasters excellent good to heal ulcers, biles, fistulaes, pocks, kankers,
fretting and consuming sores, and all such like. 22 The leaves with honey take
away the spots of the face. 23 The leaves applied to venomous bitings, draws
out the poison, and heals the wound. 24 The root purges all the inner parts.
25 The water drunk with Venice treacle or mithridate, is good against the
pestilence. 26 The savor of the herb is hurtful to women newly conceived. 27
The wine wherein it is sodden, heals kibed heels. 28 The herb bruised with
Planten, heals a new wound. 29 Apply the juice with lint to the
nolimetangere in the nose. 30 Kanker in the body, drink nine penny weight of
powder of the root with white wine three mornings warm. 31 Nose stink, put in
the juice. 32 Ears ache, put in the seed with oil. 33 Head purging, put in
the juice with wool into the nostrels. 34 Stingings, drink it, and apply it.

Ducks meat.
DVcks meat or water Lentiles: drink the distilled water two or three times a
day, against all inflammations and heats, especially of the plague. 2 The same
applied to the region of the liver, helps the inflammation thereof, and the
inflammations and swellings of the cods, impostumes and gatherings of humors
that run from place to place, to the wild fire and great burnings, to the
gouty members both alone and also mixed with meal of parched barley, or wheat
flower. 3 It gleweth or makes fast the bowels of young children, and the
falling of the fundament. 4 Yard and cods swollen, apply the juice.

Apostumes 2 Cods swollen 2. 3 Bursten 3 Gout 2 Fundament fallen 3 Hot griefs
2 Inflammat. 1. 2 Liver hot 2 Plague 1 Swellings 2 Wild fire 2 Yard swollen 4
Dwarf gentian or Soap wort gentian.
DWarf gentian or Soap wort gentian: the decoction of the leaves or root
drunk, cleanses the breast, and is good for the falling sickness, and all
poison, venim, and corrupt air: and so is the powder of it. 2 Seethe it in
wine, and wash wounds, and corrupt ulcers therewith, or straw on the powder to
heal them speedily. 3 Chop it small, and give it to swine and other cattle to
eat against the murren and other like diseases, and in a contagious time. 4
Apply it to the belly, to kill worms. 5 It may be used for the great gentian.
(See Gentian.)

Breast clensing 1 Falling evil 1 Poison 1 Swine sick 3 Venim 1 Ulcers 2
Worms 4 Wounds 2
Earthnut.
EArthnut: the upper part draws up by vomit cholar and phlegm, and the nether
part purges downward: the whole purges both ways.

Purgation 1 Vomit 1
Earthbinde.
EArthbinde: Headache of rume, put in the juice of white Earthbinde into the
nose.

Headache 1 Rume 1
Eyebright.
EYebright: distill the leaves, stalks, and flowers, and drop the water into
the eyes, to clear them, and avoid all their pain, and drink three ounces an
hour before night, and wash the eyes therewith to preserve the sight. 2 Eat
powder thereof daily with a rear egg or potcht egg to restore the sight. 3
Or drink half a dram of the powder forty mornings to restore the sight with
the water of the same herb. 4 To break the pearl or web, mix the juice with
gilts grease and goose grease, of each like much, boil them well together, and
keep thereof in a close vessel, and put thereof into the eye when thou go
to bed. 5 Eyes sore, fry it with fresh goose grease, and anoint therewith. 6
Eyes dim, put in the seeds of Eyebright to clear them. 7 Eyes dull, seethe it
well in water, and drop thereof into the eye. 8 Web, stamp good store of it
with grease of a bore, capon, or goose, and boil them together, and when it is
cold, put it in boxes, and put a little of it now and then into the eyes, or
fry it with grease of a goose or heron, and anoint the eyes. 9 Eyes dull,
drop in the juice with wine, to make them clear. 10 Mix three parts of the
powder with a fourth part of Maces, and take every morning a spoonefull by it
self, or with sugar or wine, to clear the sight and memory. Eat powder of
Eyebright with a rear potched egg certain days together, to restore decayed
sight: or drink half a dram of the powder with the water thereof forty
nights together to the same effect.

Eyes ache 1 Dull 1. 2. 3. 6. 7. 9. 10 Memory 10 Pearl 4 Sore 5 Web 4. 8
Egrimonie.
TO strengthen and cleanse the liver, drink the decoction of it at morn and
even. 2 Bitings venomous, seethe it in wine, and drink it. 3 Pissing blood,
seethe it in water, and drink it. 4 Bloody flux, and laskes, drink the feeds
in wine. 5 Old wounds, stamp the leaves with swines grease, and apply it to
warm. 6 Drink an eggeshell full of the juice to cast up all poison, and to
heal all venomous bitings. 7 Stamp the herbs and roots of Betony, Egrimony,
and Mugwoort, with old grease and vinegar, and apply it three or four times
to avoid the pain of the back. 8 Use Egrimonie to all hollow wounds and
ulcers. 9 Drink it or the powder of it to heal the fistula in the eyes, and
all other places. 10 Apply it with vinegar to warts, to take them clean away.
11 Seethe it in red wine, to cleanse all wounds being washed therewith. 12
Stamp the leaves, and apply them to sores that be evil healed, or joined, to
open them again. 13 Seethe it with Alome, and wash therewith the ranckled and
swollen yard and coddes warm. 14 Seethe it with wine, and drink it against
the obstruction and stopping of the liver, and the chollike. 15 The distilled
water helps the cough, and the iaundies, and kills worms. 16 The leaves
stamped with swines grease, heals cuts, ulcers and wounds. 17 The herb
either green or dry, sodden with Wheat branne in old dead wine, and applied
to the joints that be loose, does much help them: and so it does being
sodden with Butter, Vinegar, and Wheat branne. 18 The sirrop is good to open
the liver. 19 Egrimonie comfort the liver, stomach, and bowels, and is good
against the ache of them, the griefs of the milt, and for long fevers. 20 And
drunk with wine, it is good against the evil habit, and the dropsy, and the
ulcers of the intralles or bowels. 21 Pluck it up with the root thereof, and
stamp it, and bind it to thy heel, to cause speedy deliverance of a dead
child, but take it away speedily, least that the matrix follow. 22 For the
fistula, hang it about thy neck, and also put it in. 23 Gummes griefs, apply
the juice of Egrimonie. 24 Knees ache, or gout, seethe it in water, to the
third part, and drink a cup full thereof fasting, and apply the herb
warm. 25 Boil Egrimonie with honey, and apply it to the head ach, and megrem.
26 Apply Egrimonie to a broken head, to draw out the boanes, and heal it
speedily. 27 Put the juice of it into a Kanker that is old, with a pipe of
brass, and bind a plaster thereof about it, to heal it. 28 Wartes, stamp
Egrimonie and apply it. 29 Pissing bed in youth, drink two drammes of
Egrimonie in wine or broth. 30 Fistula in the head, dry the root in the
smoke, and hang it about thy neck. 31 Nose bleeding, hold it and the root
of it in thine hand. 32 Nails falling off, and aching, and to make them grow,
apply the powder. 33 Milt pain, eat Egrimonie often. 34 Back ache general,
stamp the roots of it and Mugwoort with Swines grease and Vinegar, and apply
it to thy back. 35 For a woman that can not hold her urine, Stamp it with
Salt, and seethe it in old wine, and drink it when it is sodden to the third
part. 36 Bitings venomous, drink two drammes of the powder, with two measures
of Wine called ciats, to cast out the venime. 37 Squincie, seethe Egrimonie in
Wine, and apply it. 38 Back ache, (See Betonie.) 39 Apostume general, seethe
it with Houseleeke and Fiueleafe in Red Wine, and apply it. 40 Mad dogs
biting, wash the wound with the blood of the same dog, and apply the juice
of Planten and Egrimonie with new Honey, and the Whites of Eggs. 41 Warts,
stamp Egrimonie with salt, vinegar, and brimstone, and apply it. 42 Backache,
stamp Egrimonie, Mouseeare, and Smalach, and their roots with bores grease and
vinegar, and apply it: or stamp Egrimonie and Louage of each like much with
barrowes grease and red vinegar, and fry them well together, and apply it. 43
Drink Egrimonie with wine, to help all venomous bitings and carbuncles, or
drink an egshell full of the juice to expel it upward easily, and all other
poison. 44 Egrimonie is a special good thing against hollow wounds and
ulcers, and fistulaes, the powder thereof being put into them. 45 Glandules,
scrophules, and kernels, drink the juice with whey nine days in the wane of
the Moon. 46 Belly ache, eat Egrimonie, or drink the powder of it with
water. 47 Stamp it with vinegar to help the wounds made with iron. 48 Use it
in meats to help the ache of the milt. 49 Liver stopped coming of phlegm,
seethe the powder of Egrimonie in white wine, and drink it. 50 Eyes hurt or
blasted, apply the juice of Egrimonie with the white of an egg. 51 Pricks,
stamp Egrimonie, and apply it. 52 Biles to avoid, stamp Planten and Egrimonie
with goose grease, and anoint therewith. 53 Bones broken, stamp Daisies,
Egrimonie, and Comfery with vinegar, and apply it till it be whole. 54 Back
ache, stamp the leaves and roots of Egrimonie and Mugwoort with old grease
and oil Olive, and apply it in a bag. 55 Bottes in horses, let him eat
Egrimonie early in the morning five or six mornings together, and let him
eat nothing else until it be noone. 56 Yard or coddes swollen, seethe
Egrimonie or the water thereof, till it almost boil, with a quantity of Alome,
and bathe it therewith with a linned cloth, well and warm, and apply thereof
with a cloth wetten therein. 57 Itch, seethe it with Sage in rain water, and
wash therewith. 58 Leg sores, apply the juice with linen clothes. (See
Comferey.) 59 Yard kanker, stamp it with Houndstong, and Pimpernell, and the
pappe of sodden Linseed, and apply it. 60 Headache, seethe it in water, and
drink it at even hot, and at morn cold. 61 Ptisicke, and spitting of blood,
drink the juice with wine, and Honey, and Fenell roots nine days. 62 For all
griefs of the stomach, Stamp it with Mouseare, and barrowes grease, and
vinegar, and fry them together and apply it to the back as hot as may be
suffered. 63 Sores to heal, stamp it well with May butter, and make it into
bals, and lay them to mould well, then seethe them well and streine it, and
anoint therewith. 64 Hair to grow, stamp it with Goats milk, and anoint
therewith. 65 Eyes dull, use the water with twice so much water of white honey
suckles or Clauer. Drink it with vinegar fasting daily in the plague time,
both to help the disease, and to prevent it.

Elaterium.
ELaterium. The juice of wild Cucu^bers dried: take x. grains to purge phlegm,
choler, and watrish humors, and to help the dropsy and shortness of breath.
2. Delay it with sweet milk and power it into the nose to take away the ill
color of the eyes after the Iaundies, and to swage headache and purge the
brain. 3 Put it into the matrix with honied wine to expel the terms and dead
child. 4 Apply it with oil or honey, or the gall of an ox or bull to heal the
squincy and swelling in ye throat. 5 The juice of the bark and root does purge
as aforesaid. 6 The root soked in vinegar and made soft and applied, helps
ach and swelling of the gout, and sodden in vinegar, it swageth the toothach. 7
With parched barley meal, it dissolueth cold tumors. 8 With Turpentine, it
does open and break impostumes. 9 The powder of it with honey cleanses and
voydeth foul scurfe, spreading tetters, maundge, pusshes, wheales, red spots,
and all other blemishes of the skin in any place. 10 Drop the juice of the
leaves into the ears to void their pain. 11 Elaterium must be taken with Mede
or sweet milk, a little salt and Anniseeds, or with Gum, Dragagant, salt, and
Anniseeds, from vi. grayns to xii. one good grayn is enough for a child. 12 To
purge the belly, put twice so much salt to it and as much stibium as will
color it, and give a pill as much as a pease, and after drink one ounce and
v. drams of worm water. 13 But to provoke vomit, take the water that Elaterium
is steeped in, and dip a feather therein, and put it to the root of the tongue,
but if the receiver be hard to vomit, dissolve it with oil or ointment of the
Flower deluce, and forbid them to sleep: if he cannot cease vomiting, or
purging, give him wine and oil, or cold water, or barley meal vinegar and
water, Apples, etc. (See Cucumbers.)

Ache 6 Apostume 8 Dead child 3 Ears ache 10 Flowers stopped 3 Gouts 6 Headache
^ Iaundies 2 Maundge ^ Purgation 15. 11. 12 Pusshes 9 Scabs 9 Skin deformed 9
Squincy 4. 6. 7 Swellings 4. 6. 7 Tetter 9 Throat swollen 4 Vomit to cause 13
Elecampana.
ELecampana is good for all griefs of the breast, lungs and heart. 2 Breast
and lungs griefs, boil it and lycoras in powder ana like much, with good
store of honey, and put one ounce of ginger to it after it is sodden thick and
use it. 3 Scabs general, seethe it tender, and put thereto sheeps tallow, and
tie them in a cloth and anoint therewith by the fire. 4 Ears worms, put in
the juice of Elecampana, Rue and Wormwood. 5 Cough dry, use powder of
Elecampana and Comfery with honey. 6 Scabs general, slise the root and seethe
it to pap and stamp it, and strein it with swines grease, and put thereto some
mortified quick silver and anoint. 7 Itch, seethe it in running water, and wash
therewith thrice. 8 Scabs, seethe the root to pap, and mix it with oil olive
and anoint. 9 Mother suffoc. seethe powder of Elecamp. and pepper with wine or
ale and drink it: proved. 10 Frensy with pain of the stone, seethe ye leaves in
wine and apply them. 11 Pricks, stamp the root with reed roots hedghogs grease,
and honey and apply it. 12 Elecampana fastneth loose teeth, provoke vrin,
causes deliverance of a dead child, and is good for the cough. 13 Hoarcenes,
eat powder of Elecamp. and Comfery with honey fasting. 14 Face falseflegme,
seethe iiii. ounces of Elecamp, in white wine, and stamp it and strein it, and
put thereto powder of Sulphur half an ounce, of Mercury an ounce, and mix them
with as much swines grease and stir it well, and keep it in bores, being first
boiled and cooled and use it. 15 Scabs and pilling of the skin and nails,
seethe the root in water to pap, and grind it with oil or grease, and anoint
and be whole. 16 Canker, to destroy it, anoint with the juice of Elecamp. and
Radish with wheat flower, and the white of an eg. 17 Dropsy, drink Elecamp.
with wine iiii. days to drive it downwards. 18 Belly and guts freting, seethe
the roots of it and Burres in wine and drink it morn and even. 19 Conserve of
Elecamp. is made with the pap of the root, and ii. or iii. times so much sugar,
it comfort the stomach and nourishing members, it loses tough phlegm,
marueilously, and consumes it by seege. 20 Fistula to heal, stamp the root of
Elecampana and Lignum vitae, and seethe them in white wine and use it with a
syrindge. 21 Itch, put powder of Elecampana, brimstone, and bay ^alt ana like
much into a bag, and dip it in falls oil; and rub any itch therewith warm,
or do the like with Elecamp. bay salt and oil of Iris, which also helps the
cold cramp. 22 Chincough, seethe the root with as much Ginger in water to the
one half, and take the pap thereof with a third part of honey boiled and
scommed and make it an electuary and use it v. or vi. days morn and even, a
good quantity at once. 23 Stomach to cleanse, seethe Elecampana and Radish ana
half an handful in a quart of water, and a pint of honey, and a farthing worth
of bruised Licoras, and drink thereof first and last. 24 Child bursten, distill
the root in a limbeek, and drink iii. ounces of the water. 25 Bruses within the
flesh, apply the leaves and roots. 26 Loins pain, drink two drams of the root
in wine. 27 Ruptures in the body, distill the root from July to September, the
leaves in the end of May, and drink an egshel full of the water morn and
even. 28 Dead child to expel, drink ii. or iii. ounces of ye water of the
root. 29 Coughs cold, make an electuary of the powder or pap and Licoras and
use it. 30 Scab and itch, stamp the root with swines grease and anoint. 31
Blood to stop, stamp the leaves and apply them. 32 Fluxes to stop, stamp it
with as much of the kernels of nuts, and seethe them into an electuarie and use
it. 33 Fistula to heal, stamp the leaves with salt and apply them. 34 Use
Elecampana to comfort ye heart-root, and spiritual members, and for the
sinews to cleanse them, the breast and lungs, and for all evil humors in the
stomach, stopping of the liver and milt, and for all cold griefs and windines.
35 Bursten, use the juice of Rue and Elecampa. 36 Coughs and stopping of the
breast, mix powder of Elecampana and Licoras with twice so much sugar and use
it. 37 Consumption, boil powder of Elecampana and Tormentil with honey and use
it. 38 Health to preserve, eat it in pottage one or twice a week. 39 The
decoction thereof drunk, provoke vrin and terms, and is good for inward
burstings and drawing together of any part. 40 The root taken with honey in an
electuary, cleanses the breast, voydeth tough phlegm, and is good for the cough
and shortness of breath. 41 Bitings and stingings venomous, drink the powder of
it. 42 The confects of it are good for the stomach and to help digestion. 43
Sciatica, boil the leaves in wine and apply them. 44 It is good against poison
and comfort the heart. 45 The wine thereof does cleanse the lungs and breast.
46 The powder with honey easily to spet and break wind. 47 Seethe it with Rue
and use it against the windy chollick and ruptures that come of the wind. 48
Use it in baths to wash and cleanse the body from filth, itch, and scabs, and to
keep the body warm, and to make them red that were pale. 49 Teeth loose, chew
the root. 50 The oil thereof helps the torments, wind of the guts, and is
good for the sinews. 51 Spetting blood, drink the root. 52 The powder of the
root mixed with sugar and honey, is a blessed medicine against shortness of
breath, sighing, and coughing, it cleanses the breast, and heals the
impostumes of the lungs, matrix and other parts, or intralls. 53 Bitings
venomous, and inflammations, and swellings of the secrets both of men and
women, stamp the green leaves and apply them. The roots, and all other roots
must be gotten at the fall of the leaf.
