39 Windiness 34. 46. 47
Eldren, or Bourtree.
Choler or phlegm to purge, boil the leaves and tender crops of common Eldren
in some broth or pottage and eat thereof. The green middle Bark of the
branches, does not much vary from the leaves and crops, but that it is
stronger in operation, purging with pain and violence. 2 The seed especially,
the little flat seeds dried one dram drunk at morn with wine, are good for the
dropsy, and are good for them that are fat and would be leaner being used a
certain space. 3 Swellings and hot tumors, stamp the green leaves and apply
them. 4 Gout pains, stamp the green leaves and apply them with Deares sewet
or bulls tallow. 5 Sleep to cause, warm the leaves between two tiles, and
bind them to the nape of the neck. 6 Drop in the juice into the ears to kill
the worms therein, and to cleanse out the matter and filth. 7 Dropsy, seethe
the roots and drink the broth at morn, noone, and even to cure it perfectly.
8 Headache, heat the leaves between two tiles and apply it. 9 To preserve life
long, gather the flowers on Midsommer day, and drink a spoonefull thereof with
a draught of Burrage water morn and even xxx. days. 10 Burnings or scaldings,
boil the inner rynd with sheep tallowe, and sheep doung and anoint
therewith, and it shall not be seen. 11 The leaves sodden in Wine and taken
before meat, helps the dropsy, and is good against venomous bitings. 12 The
same sodden in water and the vapor thereof taken up into the matrixe, does
soften, open, and amend the hurtes that are commonly about it, and so does
the fruit being drunk in wine. 13 The same laid to, makes hair to be
black. 14 The tender and fresh leaves applied with barley meal, swage
inflammations, and are good for burnings and bitings of dogs. 15 The same does
glue together all hollow and gaping sores like fistulaes. 16 The powder of the
leaves and tender crops gathered at the spring of the year and taken with
Pease broth, does soften the belly. 17 And so does a lotion of the sodden
Berries. 18 The water is good to wash the head or any other place, against such
griefs as come with the heat of the sun, and so does the Mushromes or
Jews ear, being steeped in water of Eldren flowers or of Roses. 19 The leaves
or water applied, help the bitings of serpents and vipers, and heals up
running sores or fistulaes. 20 Ears running, put in the juice of Eldren and of
Violets. 21 Nose bleeding (see Bursa pastoris.) 22 Swelling in the throat,
apply the green Bark with salt. 23 Milt stopped, seethe the root in white wine
to the third part and drink it. 24 Liver and milt stopped, seethe the leaves with
Smallach and drink the broth. 25 Emerods, stamp the leaves and apply them. 26
Knees swollen, seethe the leaves in water and bathe therewith. 27 Knees ach
great, and legs likewise, stamp the leaves with Fiueleafe, and Penyroyall with
barrowes grease and apply them. 28 Feet swollen, bath them in the decoction
thereof or of the leaves. 29 Burning or scalding, take the inner Bark, a
quarter of a pound of sheeps sewet, and sheeps tretles ana half a pound, frye
them and streine it and use it. 30 Leapry of phlegm, seethe the leaves in
strong wine and bath therewith. 31 Morphue, drink three spoonefuls of the water
fasting, and walk till you sweat, and steep ix. Oak apples slised in a pint
of white vinegar three days and wash therewith. 32 Burning and scalding, boil
the inner Bark of Eldren with new grease, put thereto Mastick, Frankincense
and wax, and boil again until it be melted, and anoint often therewith. 33
Dropsy, use syrop made of the tendrels of Danewort and Eldren, or seethe half
a pound of the inner Bark next the wood in a pottell of the clarified juice of
water Cresses till the third part be wasted, then put thereto a quart of good
Hidromell, and one pound of honey, and seethe them together, and clarify them,
and put it into a clean vessel when it is cold, and stop it close: it is the
best medicine that may be had. Use the middle Bark of Eldren to cure the
dropsy, but if it have continued a year it is hardly curable. Or use the
seeds of Eldren or wine of the decoction of Eldren roots, or of Isop and
Eldren. 34 Eyes dull, drink the roots of Eldren, and make lee of the ashes of
them, and wash the head therewith for the swimming thereof, and of the eyes. 35
Feet swollen apply the middle Bark of Eldren with bores grease bring first
boiled in water. 36 Gout, stamp the Bark of the roots with white wine, and
apply it. 37 Voice to be clear, seethe Eldren flowers and drink the broth.
Make powder of the Beries dried in the Sun where no rain comes, and drink
the same with good Wine to clear the voice. (See Throat in Colewort.) 38 Vomit
to cause, take two drammes of the green Bark of roots of Eldren. 39 To cause
sweat, lay some of the leaves and flowers under the nether sheet. 40 Fever
quotidian, take powder of the inner bark of Eldren roots, with an egshell
full of aqua vitae three mornings fasting to purge the phlegm whereof the Fever
comes: or seethe the said Bark in a quart of Ale or Beer one handful, and
drink it. 41 Belly bound, dry the flowers two or three days in the sun,
keep them in a bladder, and when need is dry them as Saffron, and take
thereof with Ale or pottage to have three or four stools by and by. 42 Reins
impostume, wash old guilts grease twice or thrice in water, and stamp it with
green Bark of Eldren and Wallwort, and anoint the reins therewith, and apply
a plaster of wheat flower and butter. 43 Belly bound, mix powder of a
millstone with the juice of the middle Bark of the Eldren, and apply it to thy
stomach to cause vomit, and to thy navel to purge downwards. 44 Itch, boil
the middle Bark with oil Olive, and keep it, and when need is put thereto
powder of Masticke and Oliban and use it. 45 Sleep to cause, mix the juice of
Lettuse and Eldren with oil of Violets, set them in a pot into a vessel of
seething water till it be thick, and anoint thy forehead and temples therewith.
46 Apostume to draw outward, stamp the leaves of Eldren and Briers, with white
Mustard seed, and apply it. 47 Legs swollen of travel, or humors with heat,
wash them with the decoction of the leaves or Bark of Eldren and salt. 48
Bloody flixe, lay Eldren flowers three hours in vinegar, then stamp them and
streine them, and drink it with wine or Ale. To keep them all the year,
steep them seven hours in vinegar, then dry them in the sun, and when need
is, make powder thereof, and drink it with red wine or vinegar. 49 Burnings
and scaldings, stamp Smallach and the green Bark of Eldren ana like much, and
fry them with the doung and sewet of sheep, and strein it and anoint therewith
till it be whole: proved. 50 Teethach, stamp the middle Bark with salt and
pepper ana like much, and apply it. 51 Chollike and Iliacke, apply powder of a
millstone with the middle bark of Elderne. 52 Chollicke and stone, drink
powder of the flowers with water of Woodramsons morn and even. 53 Dropsy,
scrape the root clean, and slice it and steep it in white wine, and drink
the wine. A good ointment: Receive Elderne berries, one gallon, black soap one
pound, set them in the ground three weeks in an earthen pot, then melt it and
streine it: if you will make it hard, put thereto tallowe and pitch and use it.
54 Stone, drink water distilled of the berries. 55 Ears impostume and
deafness, put in the juice of the buddes, leaves, bark, or young branches
blood warm: proved. 56 Legs swollen, dropsy, gout, ache, and fevers:
Stamp the leaves of Eldren and Bloodworte with Bay salt and Roch-alome, and
frye them with Bores grease, and apply it plaster wise. 57 Seethe the green
leaves in water to pap, and lay them on a piece of red clothe, and anoint the
Emerods with oil Olive, and then apply it as hot as may be suffered, and as
it cools, apply new and do so all night, if need be to cure it in one
night. 58 Flies to avoid, seethe the leaves with Lauender-cotton and Cummin in
water, and sprinckle the house or chamber therewith. 59 The juice of Elderne
sprinkled, kills Fleaes. 60 For the windy dropsy, mix two ounces of water
of the root of Danewoorte with four ounces of Elderne, and drink it thirty
mornings together early in the morning. 61 Dropsy and oppilation of the liver,
distill the flowers in Balneo Mariae, and drink three ounces morning and
evening. 62 Bruise, stamp the leaves with the white of an Egg, and apply it.
63 Toothe-ache, stamp the leaves of it, or the young shootes and tops
thereof with nine leaves of Sage, and fifteen corns of Pepper and apply it
between the cheek and the teethe that do ache. (See Alehoofe.) 64 Ears
deaf, put in the clear juice. 65 Warts to avoid, put three drops of the
blood of a Warte into an Eldren leaf, and bury it in the earth, and the
Wartes will vanish away: or put three small stones into a leaf and lay it in
the way, and he that takes it up shall have the Wartes. 66 Chollicke, drink
the green bark with stale Ale. 67 Gout, anoint it often with the juice of
the berries when they are ripe. 68 Swelling, bruise the leaves with ground
mustard, and apply it. 69 Wartes, wash them with the juice of the berries when
the berries be black, and do so every night, and so bind them to in the
nights.

Ellebore white.
ELlebore white, the root causes to vomit up mightily all superfluous,
slimie, venomous, and noughtie humors, and is good against the falling
sickness, frenzy, old pain of the head, madness, sadness, the gout, the
sciatica, all sorts of dropsies, poison, and all cold diseases that be hard
to cure, and such as will not yield to any medicine. 2 The root with oil or
ointments, is good against all roughness of the skin, wild scu^ffe, knobs,
foul spots and leapry. 3 The same cut in slices and put into fistulaes, takes
away their hardness. 4 The powder causes sneesing, and purges the brain. 5
The same put in as a pessarie, draws down the terms or dead birth. 6 The
same boiled in vinegar and holden in the mouth, swageth toothache. 7 And put
into dry medicines, it does clear and sharpen the sight. 8 The root punned
with meal and honey, kills mise and rats, and such like, and drives them
away: and likewise waspes and flies, if it be boiled in milk and they eat
thereof, for then they swell and break. It is not good to be given unprepared,
nor to young, old, or sick folk: they that be weak, that spit blood, or be
grieved in their stomach, nor to women with child, nor in winter, but in
summer only, and before supper. 9 Put it into the greater end of a radish root
one night, then press it hard out, and take one dram of it in milk or
frumentie to help the falling sickness, vertigo, melancholy, madness, white
leapry, winds in the guts, dropsy, tympany, goutes, quartens, cough, and many
such like griefs. 10 It is given fasting by it self, or with sesame seeds,
or with broth, or with sodden barley, or with mede, or with pottage, or with a
lentill broth, or any such like supping. 11 Some give it with a great deal of
broth or supping. 12 Some give a little meat immediately before it, especially
to them that are weak, and so it may be taken without ieopardy. 13 Vomit to
cause, put a suppositor of it into the fundament. 14 Steep the root 24.
hours in wine, or Oximel, and dry it, and drink half a dram of the powder
of it with wine to help madness, melancholy, and such griefs as be written of
in black Ellebore. 15 But to take it without danger, steep it ii. days in
wine, or sees it in the broth of flesh, and take a siat thereof to purge both
upward and downward. 16 Put it into the nose with Margerom to cleanse the
brain and head. 17 The root sodden with lee, or mixed with any ointment
kills lice and nits, and takes away the scurfe of the head. 18 The black
wild Ellebore does the like things and effects. 19 Ellebor white, heals the
scab and morphue, and tetters, purges choler and phlegm, and being applied,
it cures ye Emerods. 20 The powder put into grewel, kills worms. 21 Mix i.
dram with syrup, of ii. parts of honey, and i. part of vinegar, to purge phlegm
and melancholy to help madness and reume, and to work both upward and
downward. 22 It is corrected with long pepper, hysope, daucus, and aniseede.
23 It works better and with less danger, if it be boiled with the broth of a
Capon or any other meat, and then the broth drunk. 24 Head skalde, apply
white Ellebore with as much swines grease. 25 Vomit to cause, take one scruple
with pease broth, or one penie weight with some broth. 26 Steep two drams in
two ounces of aqua vitae, in a close vessel 14. days, then streine it and
drink two drams of it with one ounce of wine to comfort and purge the body. 27
Head worms and falling of the hair, stamp it with swines grease, and apply
it all over the head. 28 Head to purge, blow powder of Ellebore, Pepper, and
Castory into thy nose. 29 Mix the juice with course meal as it comes from
the millstone and butter, and apply it to the stomach to purge upward, and on
the navel to purge downward. 30 Leapry, or any other deformity of the
skin, seethe it with Louage and Fenell in wine, and wash therewith. 31 Steep
white Ellebore in milk, and put white Arsnike to it, and sprinckle it to kill
Flease. 32 Ears pain, seethe it half in vinegar and put it in. 33 Face
freckles and other spots, seethe one ounce in half a pint of strong white
vinegar to the one half, then mix therewith honey three spoonefull, Mercury
sublimate one penny weight, and seethe it till it become thick, and anoint
therewith the morphue, freckles, staynings, and all deformities of the skin.

Ellebore black.
ELlebore black: the root steeped in wine, and made into powder, and drunk,
helps them that be mad, melancholy and witless, the falling sickness,
swimming in the head, giddiness, gout, dropsy, fevers quarten, leapry,
crampes, torments of the intralles. 2 Put it into the matrix to draw down the
terms, and into malignant ulcers and fistulaes, and old wounds to cleanse
them. 3 Stamp it with vinegar, and apply it to heal skabs, spots, leapry,
tetters, and ringwormes, and it does merueilously heal gangrenes, and is used
in eating medicines. 4 It purges phlegm and choler downward, either by it
self or with Scamonie, or with one dram or one scruple and a half of salt. 5
It is also good with Lentiles, or broths which are taken for purgations. 6 It
is good for the palsy and the gout. 7 It is good to be put iii. days into
fistulaes to skoure them. 8 And put iii. days into the ears that are deaf,
it helps them much. 9 With Frankincense it heals skabs. 10 Laid to by it
self or with vinegar, it heals kernels, skurfe, and leapries. 11 Teeth-ache,
seethe it in vinegar and wash therewith. 12 Dropsy, apply a plaster thereof
made with Barley meal and vinegar. 13 The pith ought to be taken out of black
Ellebore, as well as out of ye white. 14 Black Ellebore has all the virtues of
the white Ellebore, and more. 15 Drink iii. penie weight to cast out worms,
to cleanse phlegm and melancholy and the dropsy. 16 In a pessary it cleanses
the matrix, and draws down the dead birth. 17 Ears deaf, put in the juice.
Use it in plasters to kill worms. 18 The juice helps horses of the bots, and
swine that be infected, and put into their ears, it helps pain of their
heads. 19 It is so bitter, that no beasts nor fowls dare eat thereof, but
only quails. 20 Taken inwardly, it purges gross, thick, and chollerike
humors, and helps madness, melancholy, the gout, and sciatica, being taken
in pottage, or sodden with boiled meat, and the broth drunk or taken with
long pepper, hysope, daucus, and anyseedes. 21 Cattle sick or hurt, cut the
beast in some place, and put in powder of black Ellebore to draw out the
poisoned humor, and to help presently. 22 Face spots, mix powder of the root
of black Ellebore, one dram of Irios, two drams with honey, and anoint at
night, and in the morning wash it with water. 23 Fever quarten old, use the
decoction of black Ellebore. 24 Ears ache, seethe one dram of the roots well
in one pound of vinegar, and receive up the fume, and when it is almost cold,
put two drops into the ear, or seethe Ellebore, Castorie, and Piretrum, with
strong wine and drop it in, and provoke sneesing. 25 The powder of it kills
Rats. 26 Bearefoote purges by seege mightily both melancholy, and other
superfluous humors. 27 Taken inward, it purges the nether parts of the body
from gross and thick phlegm, and chollerike humors. 28 The root of common
Bearefoote steeped in wine and drunk, does loosen the belly like black
Ellebore, and is good for all such things as it is good for, one dram thereof
taken with wine. 29 The same boiled in water with Rue and Egrimony, heals the
Iaundies, and purges yellowe superfluities by seege. 30 The same thrust into
ye ears of oxen, sheep, and other cattle, helps them against the diseases
of the lungs, and draws all the corruption into the ears. 31 If in the
plague time the root be put into any part of the body, it draws thither all
the corruption and infection as it does in beasts in the time of any murren,
infection, or rot. 32 Worms in the head, apply it all over the head with
Swines grease. (See Ellebore white.)

Wounds 2
Eglentine.
EGlentine: morphue, mix it with vinegar and wash therewith. (See Bryer.)

Elm.
Elm: head skurfe, seethe the middle bark in water and wash therewith. 2
Burning or skalding, do off the uppermost bark of young Elm, and slice the
green bark, and steep it in running water two or three hours till it become
a ielly, and anoint with it often to have speedy remedy, or cast on ye ashes
of the rind, it heals them without skarres. 3 Ears dull, do with it as
with Ash. 4 The leaves falling before their time, do foreshewe a death of
cattle. 5 To mittigate all kinds of griefs, gather the water in the cods of
the leaves, keep it in a glass close, sun it twelve days and anoint
therewith. 6 Skurfe or skales in the head, or brows, or bearde, anoint with
the juice of the leaves. 8 Fistula and canker, stamp the bark with wormwood
and water, and apply it. 8 Burnings, seethe the rind half a day in water, and
gather the thick cream on the water, and anoint therewith. 9 The leaves heal
green wounds being laid to, and so does the inner bark laid to. 10 The
brothe of the leaves, bark, or root, is good to bathe arms or legs in,
that are broken or bruised, for it heals broken bones speedely. 11 Leapry and
skurfe, stamp the leaves with vinegar and apply them. 12 Drink one ounce of
the bark with wine or water to expel cold phlegm and loosen the belly. 13
The liquour in the leaves to cleanse the skin, and beautify it, and skowreth
away all spots, freckles, pimples, and spreading tetters being laid to, and
also heals fresh and green wounds being powered in. 14 The green leaves
stamped with vinegar and anointed, heals the leapry effectually, and bind
wounds together. The first green leaves sodden are good pothearbes.

Ache 5 Belly bound Bones broken Bruises Burnings 1. 2. 8 Cattle death 4 Ears
dull 3 Fistula 7 Freckles 13 Head skurfe 1. 6 Kanker 7 Leapry 11. 13. 14
Pimples 13 Purgation 12 Skalding 2 Skin deformed 13 Skurfe 6 Skabs 13 Tetters
13 Wounds 9. 11. 13. 14
Endive.
Endive, the leaves sodden are used in medicine, but not the root nor the
dried leaves. 2 Endive comfort the heart and liver both in heat and cold.
Kings evil, drink the syrup of Endive with water of the decoction of hearts
tongue, it is a singular remedy. 3 Burning pushes, anoint with the juice of
the leaves. Apostume hot, apply the bruised herb. 4 Liver hot, apply the
herb, or for want thereof, the bruised seeds. 5 Belly lose, seethe it in
vinegar and use it. 6 Cardiake passion, stamp it with vinegar, and apply it to
the left pap. Apply it with vinegar, Rose Water, and Ceruse, to the holy fire,
hot apostume and headache coming of heat. 7 Drink ye herb with wine for
griefs of the liver and bladder. 8 Drink it ii. or iii. days for spitting
blood, and excess of sperme. 9 Drink the distilled water ii. ounces, morn
and even for straitness and stopping of ye breast, and so it is also good for
women with child to strengthen them and their senses. 10 Drink iiii. or v.
ounces morn and even to help ye plague and the kings evil, to quench thirst,
and qualify the heat of the liver, the pain of the side, and pricking about
the heart. 11 The water drunk, helps the stitch at the heart, the iaundies,
the inflamed liver. 12 Liver to cleanse, take wood of saunders, with water of
cheruile and endive, of each an ounce and a half at thrice three mornings. 13
Liver chafte, use it in brothes, and steep it in water, and drink it. 14
Back gout, drink the juice with white wine daily. 15 Cough, shortness of
breath, and pain of the stomach, apply it plasterwise to the stomach. 16
Dropsy of hot cause, eat it and drink the decoction thereof. 17 Drink the
juice with hot water for the stopping of the liver and milt, the iaundies, the
fever tertian, and great heat of the stomach and liver.

Epithime.
EPithime, wash hair with the decoction thereof, to make it yelow. 2 Urine
distilling, seethe it in good wine and oil olive, and apply it hot between
the nauill and the priuities. (See Dodder)

Hair to be yelow 1 Urine distilling 2
Euphorbium.
EVphorbium, Teethach of humors, lance betwixt them, and rub ye place with a
little of the powder on thy fingers end weted and dipped therein. 2 Pricking in
the sinews, mix old oil an ounce, with wax three drammes, and Euphorbium
one dram, and anoint therewith. 3 Headache, anoint with old oil and three or
four grains of Euphorbium. 4 Falling evil, put oil of Euphorbium into the
nose. 5 Wearines, weakness, and nummednesse, take wax an ounce, Euphorbium a
dram beaten in a mortar with five or six drops of oil, and temper them over
the fire with as much oil as will make it a searecloth, and apply it to the
reins of the back. 6 Hair falling, mix Euphorbium with oil and use it. 7
Mother suffocat. smell to it to cause neesing. 8 Gout, take wax a pound, oil
olive ten pound, good wine two pound, boil it til the wine be consumed: then
put thereto fine powder of Euphorbium four ounces, and anoint therewith. 9
Glandules, schrophules, and kernels, mix the juice of wild lilie with
Euphorbium, and take seven pills thereof thirty mornings, to expel them quite,
that none remain. 10 Hair falling, anoint with Euphorbium and oil. 11 Ears
dull, put in powder of Euphorbium with the juice of housleek. 12 Lust to cause,
stamp it with bays and arom well with oil, and anoint the virge therewith. 13
Feet, or any other member sleep, mix Euphorbium with as much Agryppa, and
boil them in wine, till the wine be consumed, and anoint therewith. 14
Iaundies, take two grains with a rear egg. Fever quotidian, mix half a dram
with an egg shel full of aqua vitae, and take it three mornings together to
purge the slime whereof it comes. 15 Lyturgie, hold the powder to thy nose in
a cloute to cause neesing. 16 Fistula to heal, make a tent of Euphorbium,
masticke, and French soap ana like much, and put it in. 17 Euphorbium purges
tough, cold and slimy flegmes, and choler from the sinews and far parts,
and is good for old headache, palsy, crampe, weakness, that follows the
French pocks, the pain of the sinews, and extreme parts that are of long
continuance, and the iaundies, and is good also against the plague, and such
like contagious sicknesses. 18 Make a plaster thereof with twelve times so
much oil and a little wax, which is singular good against all pains and
aches of the joints, takings, lamenesse, palsies, crampes, shrinking of the
sinews, and all aches and disorder of the same. 19 Mix it with Boares grease,
oil debay, or Wolfes grease, or such like, to cure the skurfe of the head, and
baulde places, to cause the hair to grow again, being anointed with it: not
only the head, but other bare places. 20 Mix it with oil, and stroke it on
the temples for the Lytargie, sleepiness, and raging, to waken them and
quicken their spirits again. 21 And apply it to the neck, or nape of the
neck, to restore speech lost by the Apoplexia. 22 Mix it with vinegar, and
stroke it on the place to take away all foul and evil favored spots of
the body, especially the white skurfe and skale of the skin. 23 Mix it with
oil, and use it against falling of the hair and baldenesse. 24 It may be
mixed with as much masticke and gum Dragagant, and put into the midst of an
vnbaked loaf, and so baked, and the crumme taken, and made into small pills,
which are singular good against the weakness that follows the French pockes,
and all pain of the outward parts. 25 It may be mixed with as much masticke,
and made into pills with the juice of orenges, and so it is excellent against
the plague. 26 Seethe it with oil of eldren, bean flower, and earth worms,
and use it against pricking in the sinews.

Aches 17. 18. 24 Apoplexia 21 Benumbed 5. 13 Crampe 17 Choler 17 Ears dull
11 Fistula 16 Falling evil 4 Phlegm 17 French pockes. 24 Glandules 9 Gout 8

Palsy 17 Plague 17. 25 Purgation 17. 24 Sinews griefs 17. 18. 2. 25 Skin
clensing 22 Sleepie members 13 Speech lost 21 Taken 18 Teethach 1 Weariness 5
Eringium.
ERingium, the leaves are good to be eaten in sallads. 2 The roots boiled in
wine, and drunk, are good for the chollicke, and gryping of the belly, and
expels wind, provoke terms, and is good against the stone, and gravel,
and pain in making water: it provoke urine, expels the stone, and cures
the griefs of the kidneys being drunk fifteen days together, and is good
for the griefs of the liver, and all venomous bytings or poison, especially
drunk with the seed of wild carrots: it helps also the crampe and the
falling sickness. 3 Bytings venomous, especially of Frogs, stamp the green
herb, and apply it. 4 The root preserved or comfited, is good for old
folks, and others that are wasted and withered, to restore them again, and so
is the root of the thistle Centum capita: but not so good. 5 The root drunk,
expels the urine and terms, it is drunk with wild carrot seeds against
many griefs. 6 Apply it to wartes and swellings, to cause them to fall: it may
be kept in vinegar, urine, or sugar, or honey, as Sperage and Sampere are
kept, and condited. 7 Sees the root in wine, and drink it against against the
griefs of the liver, mylte and lungs, the torments of the belly and
inflammations. 8 Drink a dram with some bruised seeds of wild carrots to
resist poison that has been drunk. 9 The continual use of the root helps
the stone. 10 Drink the roots with Hydromel for the cricke in the back, and
the falling sickness. 11 Apply the root to kernels under the ears. 12
Pricks and splents, bruise the root, and apply it. 13 Bones bare without
flesh, stamp the root, salt, and swines grease, and apply it. 14 The young
leaves may be boiled, and with salt and oil preserved for sallads. 15 The
herb with the root, must be gathered when the Sun is in Cancer. 16 They
be black without, and white within; very aromatike like spice. 17 The herb or
root made in powder, infusion, or decoction, and drunk, cleanses the reins,
bladder, and Matrix, and provoke terms. 18 It greatly prevails against the
chollicke, and torments of the belly, being drunk with Hydromel. 19 Drink a
dram at once against the falling sickness. 20 The root must be tender
sodden and preserved in sucket, for meat or medicine in Winter, and to restore
nature. 21 Drink a dram of the root with wine against the stinging of any
venomous beast or worm, or the Fever. 22 Drink it sixteen days morn and
even, to cure all griefs of the reins, the stone, and stopping of the urine.

Back griefs 1. 17. 22 Belly ache 2. 7 Bitings venomous 2. 3. 21 Bones bare
13 Chollicke 2. 18 Consumption 4. 19 Crampe 2 Falling evil 2. 10. 19 Fevers 21
Flesh to grow 13 Flowers stopped 25. 17 Frogge biting 3 Gravel 2 Inflammation 7
Kernels 11 Kidneis griefs 2. 17 Liver griefs 27 Lungs griefs 7 Matrix to
cleanse 17 Milt griefs 7 Poison drunk 2. 8 Pricks 12 Sickness general 5
Restoratiue 4 Sores 13 Stinging 21 Stone 20. 22 Swelling 6 Urine stopped 25 Warts
6 Windiness 2
Erisimon.
ERisimon, lick in the seed often with honey, to cleanse the breast and
lungs, shortness of breath, and the old cough, the seeds being first
steeped in fair water, and then dried by the fire, or lapped in paste and
baked, for else it will be too hot. 2 Use the same seed so prepared, against
the iaundies, gryping in the belly, the sciatica, and all venomous bytings. 3
Mix the seed with honey and water, and use it for hidden cankers, hard
swellings, impostumes behind the ears, old and hard impostumes of the
breasts, and genitors applied, for it wastes cold swellings.

Bellyach 2 Bytings venomous 2 Breast griefs 1 Breath short 1 Coddes swollen 3
Cough old 1 Hard swelling 3 Impostumes 3 Iaundies 2 Kanker 3 Lungs griefs 1
Sciatica 2 Swelling 3
Esula.
ESula, the juice, seed or root, purges chollericke and sharp humors, like
the Tythimalles, and are in all things of the nature of the Tythimalles. 2 The
seed and leaves do the same things that the juice does. 3 Belly worms,
kill them with other things, and then take two drammes of Esula to expel them.
4 Steep the bark of Esula, or Tythimall in vinegar four and twenty hours,
and dry it, and make it into powder, and put thereto anniseedes, or fennel
seeds, dragagant, and masticke, and minister it with some cold liquor, as of
endive, or cicory, or orenges, and so it will not inflame the throat. (See
Tythimall)

Purgation 1. 2. 4 Worms 3
Fearne.
FEarne: worms to kill, drink an ounce of powder of the roots dissolved in
wine. 2 Burnings, burn it and apply it with the white of an egg. Wounds,
festers, and cankers, stamp them with their roots, and wash the griefs with
the juice, and apply the dross. 3 Nosebleeding, the roots staunch blood, and
heal the wound. 4 Mother suffocat. sees louage, hissop, wormwood, and Fearn
leaves, and apply them to the nauil and shares. 5 Burnings, stamp the roots
with cowes milk, and apply it. 6 Chop a basket full of Fearn and sees it in a
bag in the third part of a tun of water, and bathe therein to restore the
strength of the sinews. 7 Milt pain, seethe the root in water and drink it.
8 The root of male Fearne, called Osmund rosal half an ounce taken with honied
water, kills, and expels worms. Milt stopped, sees it in water and drink
it. 9 The leaves of both Fearns put into bedstraw, drives away punises, and
all other such worms. 10 Fearne is very dangerous for women with child. 11
Worms broad, drink four ounces of the root of male Fearne with twelve grains
of Diagridium, or twelve grains of black ellebore, but take garlic before
it. 12 Wounds made with reed, drink the root and also apply it. Worms both
round and broad, drink three drams of the root of female Fearne. 13 Sores to
skin, apply powder of the root, the same heals the galling of the necks
of oxen. 14 Belly bound, sees the young green leaves with other worts, and
use them. 15 Burnings, apply the juice of the roots with rose water, or cold
water to heal it when all other things fail: it does the like with water of
cowes dung. 16 If a horse be sick, and it is not known whereof, put a portion
of the root under his tongue, and he shall by and by cast out his excrements
both ways, and so rise and do well. 17 Powder of the root is good for all moist
ulcers both of man and beast. 18 The root of the female makes women barren.
19 The powder of brakes does heal dangerous sores both of men, kine, swine,
etc.

Barren to be 18 Belly bound 14 Burnings 2. 5. 15 Cattle galled 13 Festers 2
Gnats 9 Horse sick 16 Kanker 2 Milt pain 7. 8 Mother suffocat. 4 Nosebleeding
3 Purgation 10. 14 Sinews griefs 6 Skin off 13 Sores 13. 17. 19 Worms 1.
8. 10. 12 Wounds 2. 12
Fenegreke.
FEnegreke, Apostumes, and the plurisie to dissolve them, boil it with
linseed, oil of violets and butter, and apply it. 2 Gut to cleanse, seethe
half an ounce of the meal in a pint of water, and to the cleerest of it, put
one ounce of honey and drink thereof morn and even. 3 Guts fretting, drink
half an ounce of the meal, with two drammes of honey, with warm water first
and last, to purge out all superfluous slime, and avoid the pain. 4 Loins
apostumed, apply Fenegreke and colworts together. Impostume inward to break,
seethe the meal with water that mallows have been sodden in, and apply it. 5
For the host, liver, and lungs, and milt, stamp bays, Fenegreke, and pepper,
and boil them in ale, and take a spoonful of it every day. 6 Reins apostums,
stamp mallows and holy oak, with Fenegreke, and bearfoot, and swines grease,
and apply it. 7 Apost. general, seethe it with holy oak and linseed, and stamp
them with butter or swines grease, and apply it, being first boiled with barlie
meal. 8 Speech lost, sees it and honey in the juice of Hoorhound and water
cresses to an electuarie, and use it. Plurisie, apply the root of holy oak
with Fenigreeke, branne of hempeseede and butter. 9 Voice to be clear, sees
it with hyssope, and peniroyall, and white wine, and drink it. 10 Gonorrhoea,
sees the seeds in water till the third part be wasted, and drink four ounces
morn and even three or four days to cure it. 11 Bruise, seethe it with wheat
bran, honey, and larde in white wine, and apply it to aches, bruises, or goutes,
etc. 12 Byles and botches, seethe it in linseed with cowes milk and water, and
apply it. 13 Belly bound, sees it in water and drink it to losen the belly
without peril. 14 The decoction, or broth of the seeds drunk with a little
vinegar, expels all evil humors that stick in the bowels. 15 The same
decoction first made with dates, and after with honey, til it come to the
thicknes of syrrop, does cleanse and cure the griefs of the breast, so that the
patient have no fever nor headache, for then it is evil. 16 The meal sodde^
with meed helps cold hard apostumes, and swellings. Milt hard and swollen,
apply it with vinegar and saltpeter. 17 Sit in the decoction thereof, or bathe
in the decoction of it for the impostumes, ulcers, and stopping of the matrix.
18 Mix the straining or juice with goose grease, and put it into the matrix,
to soften al hardness and pain of the neck thereof. 19 Wash the skurfe skale
and nittes of the head, with the decoction thereof. 20 Apply it with brimston
and honey to pushes, pimples, spots, wheales, maunge, skurfe and itch of the
face or else where to heal it. 21 Rawnes, vlceration, and feeblenes of any
part, apply green Fenegreke, with a little vinegar. 22 The seeds prepared as
lupines, may be eaten, and is of like virtue, and loseneth the belly gently.
23 The young crops are good in sallades with vinegar and oil: but being too
much used, it brings headache, and ouerturneth the stomach. 24 Sodden in
honied water, and drunk, it softeneth all inward impostumes, and helps the
pain of the intralles. 25 Use the decoction of the meal for the griefs of
the lunges and the old cough. 26 Seethe the seeds in water, and strain it,
and use it to heal spreading sores of the head, and the skurfe, and skall, and
to make the hair to grow. 27 Put the same with Goose grease into the Matrix
or fundament, to enlarge them in the passage place. 28 Use the decoction
thereof for the tenasmus and stinking bloody flixe. 29 Use the meal in
glisters for the torments and exulceration of the bowels. 30 It is good against
all tumors and swellings. 31 The meal sodden with wine and Saltpeter does
quickly take away the skalles and skurfe of the head or beard. 32 The oil
thereof cleanses spots and skarres of bruses or wounds, and the hot apostumes
of the priuities.

Apostumes 1. 7. 16 Back apost. 4. 6 Belly ache 3. 24. 29. bound 22 Biles 12
Botches 12 Bloody flux 28 Breasts griefs 15. 5 Bruises 11. 32 Cough old 25
Face deform. 20 Fundament hard 27 Gomor pas. 10 Guts to cleanse 2 Impost. 4. 24
Itch 20 Head griefs 19. 26. 31 Liver griefs 5 Loins apost. 4 Lungs griefs 5.
25 Matrix griefs 17. 18. 27 Maunge 20 Milt griefs 5. 16 Plurisie 18 Priuities
griefs 32 Purgat. 2. 3. 14 Reins running 10 Skin off 21 to cleanse 20 Speech
lost 8 Sores 26 Swellings 16. 30 Tenasmus 28 Voice lost 9 Wheales 20 Wounds 32
Whites 10
Feuerfue.
FEuerfue: take two drammes of the powder of it with honey, to purge by siege
melancholy and phlegm, and to help giddiness and swimming or turning in the
head, for shortness of breath, pensiveness and sadness. 2 Seethe the herb
without the flowers in water, and drink it for the stone. 3 Seethe it in wine,
and apply it to the nauill, heart, or side for the suffocation, hardness, and
stopping of the mother. 4 Sit in the decoction of it for the hardness, and
swelling, and inflammation of the mother. 5 Stamp the green leaves with the
flowers, and apply it to the wild fire, and other inflammations of cholar. 6
Stamp it with Salt, and apply it to the wrists of children at every xxiiii.
hours end especially to avoid the ague. 7 Drink the juice or powder to loose
the belly, to drive down phlegm and choler, to kill worms, cleanse the
matrixe, and help cold fevers. 8 Give it with salt to cattle to help their
swelling and difficulty of breathing. 9 Stamp the green herb and apply it
to the greefes of the belly. 10 It has also the virtues of wormemood and of
centorie: and Tansie has the same virtues. 11 Drink the herb and flower for
shortness of wind and the stone: but Tansie is better for men, and Feuerfue
better for women. 12 Feuerfue comfort the stomach, and is good for the
Fever quotidian, the crampe, and coldness of the stomach, it cures venomous
bitings being applied. And with vinegar it helps the Morphue. 13 Stamp it
and apply it to wounds wherein are broken bones, and to knit and heal them. 14
The root stops the bloody flux. 15 Stamp it and apply it above a botch to
remove it from place to place. 16 Stomach gleet stamp it with Auense, and
drink it with stale Ale morn and Even. 17 Fever quotidian, stamp it with as
much Smallach, and streine them with water, and drink thereof when the fit
comes thrice and be whole, or drink the juice of it and Smallach of each ii.
handfuls with small Ale warm before the fit, and cover thee well to sweat. 18
Gout, stamp it with as much Saint Mary Garlike and apply it. 19 Vomiting,
take it iii. days with a rere Egg and be whole. 20 Ears ache and dindling,
put in the juice and stope it in. 21 Fluxes general, sees it in water, and
sit over the fume of it. 22 Heart greefs, sees it in wine with salt and drink
it. 23 Mother suffoc. Drink the juice of Motherwort and Feuerfue with gross
Pepper in old Ale and be whole. 24 Gout, anoint with the juice and a Neats
Gaul mingled together warm. 25 Impost. Drink the juice.

Bellyach 79 bound 7 Bytings venim 12 Bloody flux 14 Botch 15 Breath short 1.
11 Bones broken 13 Cattle sick 8 Crampe 12 Ears ache 20 Fever quotid. 6. 7.
12. 17 Phlegm 1 Fluxes general 21 Gout 18. 24 Heart griefs 22 Head giddie 1

7 Wounds 13
Fennel.
Fennel, head pushes and ulcers, seethe the seeds with wine in a glass, and
anoint therewith. 2 Eyes watering, seethe the roots with Betonye, and wash
therewith. 3 Eyes itch, (See Aloes.) 4 Eyes greefs, seethe the root in water,
and put in a drop. 5 Eyes blemish, bruise Camphere and streine it with the
juice and use it. 6 Vomit to cause, stamp the root of Fennel and Mugwort
with wormwood leaves and drink it with warm water and honey, to provoke it
presently. 7 Eyes watery, sees it with water in an earthen pot, and put it into
the eyes. 8 For the host, griefs of breast, heart, stomach and sides, and to
cause appetite, sees ii. parts of the juice with iii. parts of honey to the
thickenes of honey, and put Pepper to it, and eat iii. spoonefuls every day. 9
Stomach swollen, sees the roots of Fenell and Smallach in wine of each like
much, and temper them with water, and drink it fasting. 10 Stamp Louage,
Persly, Fenell of each like much, and temper them with water, and drink it for
the griefs of the bladder to void the urine well. 11 Cods swollen, sees the
roots of Persly and Fenell in water, and dip clowts therein and apply it often.
12 Headache, seethe red Fennel, Feuerfue and Sage of each like much in strong
Lee to the one half, and wash therewith as hot as may be suffered: or stamp
red Fenell, Camomile, Sage and Cummin, and apply it. 13 Heart burning, chewe
crops of Fennel, and suck down the juice, and spit out the rest. 14 Belly
windy, seethe powder of the seeds of Fennel, Annise and Cummin in wine, and
drink it. 15 Stytch, stamp red Fennel and red Docks, and frye them with May
Butter, and apply it. 16 Brain feeble, mix Centorie, Rue, and red Fennel
seeds withstrong vinegar, and drink it in the mornings. 17 Cough and Kings
evil, stamp Isope and Fennill roots, and strain them with ale, and drink it
at even hot, and at morn cold. 18 Head white skall, shave it, and apply
Coprose with the juice of Fennill. 19 Vomit to stop, stamp Fennill, and drink
it with wine. 20 Milk to increase, sees the roots of Fennill and Parsnip in
the broth of a chicken, and eat them with a little fresh butter. 21 Eyes dim
and dazzling, seethe the juice of Fennill roots with as much honey, to the
thicknes of honey, and keep it in a brass vessel, and when need is, mix
thereof with woman's milk that suckleth a boy, and apply it. Proved. 22 To
open the pipes, stuff eight figs with Fennill seeds, and seethe them with a
little Isope and two branches of Organy in a pottle of water to the one half,
then strain it, and put thereto Sugar candy, and drink thereof warm. 23
Headache, seethe Rue and Red Fennill, and wash the head therewith. 24 Liver and
milt griefs, use the decoction or powder thereof, or of the rind of the root.
25 For the ptisike, dryskab, burning or skalding, press out the oil between
two hot tiles or plates, and use it. Lean to be, seethe it in water, and
strain it, and drink it first and last. 26 Ptisike dry and cold, drink the
juice of the roots with white wine. 27 Stomach cold, urine stopped, and for the
stone, seethe it with Parsley and Smalach, of each like much, and drink it. 28
Dropsy, seethe the seeds in water, and use much of it in thy wine, or use
powder of the seeds of Fennill, Anise, and Peony in thy drink, or seethe
Fennill roots in thy wine. 29 Eyes griefs, apply the juice of Rue and Fennill
with cotton. 30 Eyes bruised and read, mix powder of Cummin with the juice of
Fennill roots and white wine, and seethe them with a gentle fire, and strain
it two or three times, and put one drop of it into the eyes. 31 Flowers
stopped, seethe Sauin with the roots of Smalach, Parsley and Fennill in wine,
and strain it, and drink it. 32 For all headache, seethe Rue and Fennill in
water, and wash thy head therewith. Liver stopped of cold cause, cleanse it with
the seeds of smalach, Fennil, and Dill. 33 Megrem, stamp long Planten,
Fennill, and Betony with woman's milk, and apply it, and as the grief remoueth
follow it therewith till it come to the ridge bone. 34 Marmall, apply a plaster
of Fennill and Salt. 35 Reins griefs, use Fennill roots. 36 Stomach cold,
seethe Nutmegs and Maces with Fennill seeds and Dill seeds in wine, and drink
it. 37 Stomach weak, seethe Maces in the juice of Fennill, and drink the
decoction with wine. Proved. 38 Strangury, seethe the leaves of Fennill,
Smalach, and Parsley with Wheat branne, and apply it: or seethe the roots of
Fennill, Parsley, Smalach, and Water cresses in white wine, and drink the
broth, and apply the roots with the leaves of Water cresses plaster wise. 39
Trembling, use the seeds of Fennill and Parsley mixed together. 40 Vomit to
stop, seethe two parts of the juice of Fennill with one part of Honey, till it
be thick, and use it morn and even. 41 Headache, bathe sometimes in a bath
made with Fennill. Liver impost. hot, drink the juice of Fennill. 42 Loins
ache, seethe the roots in water, and drink it morn and even. 43 Vrin to
cause, stamp Smalach, Parsley and Fennill, of each like much, and seethe them,
and put Butter to them, and apply it to the lomes and secret parts hot. 44
Strangury, use the roots. Headache, seethe it in water, and wash therewith. 45
Eyes bloody, anoint with the juice of Read Fennill roots and Honey. 46 Vomit to
cause, seethe two parts of the juice with one part of Honey, till it be thick,
and drink thereof morn and even. 47 Stomach swollen, stamp the roots of
Fennill and Smalach, of each like much, and strain them with wine, and drink
it at even warm, and at morn cold. Milk to increase, drink the juice of
Fennill and Veruin. 48 Lungs and milt to restore, seethe two parts of the juice
with three parts of Honey to an electuary, and use thereof morn and even. 49
Liver wasting, seethe Water cresse, Red Fennill, and Sorrel, with a chicken,
in an earthen pot, and use it nine days. 50 Liver and milt stopped, and for the
dropsy, make a sirrup with the juice of Fennill and Dawke, and use it. 51
Slender to be, eat two or three cloves of Garlike, with as much Bread and
Butter, morn and even three hours before and after meat, and drink water
wherein Fennill has been sodden, morn and even fourteen days. 52 Dropsy,
drink three halfepeny weight of powder of the Adamant, with the juice of
Fennill, to expel the water. 53 Cough extreme, seethe the roots with bruised
Aniseed and Licoras in White wine, and drink a good draught to bedward, and in
the morning eat a Fig and a Date roasted, somewhat hot, two or three hours
before meat, and do so three or four times. 54 Milk to cause, seethe the
seeds in Barley water and drink it, or seethe Ryce in milk with croms of
white bread, Sugar and Fennel seed, and use it. Or drink powder of Fennel
seed and Crystal of each like much with wine. 55 Eyes dull and giddie, let a
child eat sweet Fennel seeds every morning, and then lick the diseased
eyes. 56 Horsenesse and straitness of the breast, sees Mullyn, Fennill, and
Lycoras in water or wine till it be tender, then streine it and sugar it, and
drink thereof. 57 Chollike, make powder of Fennel seeds ii. ounces, Mynts as
much as can be taken up with three fingers, and drink thereof i. dram with
vi. ounces of warm wine. 58 Lean to be, Drink Fennel, and eat the seeds
daily. 59 Cough perilous, Stamp the roots and streine them with wine or ale,
and drink it nine days morn and even. 60 Stomach swollen, dry cough, and
headache, stamp the root of Fennel and Smallach, and streine them with white
wine and drink it fasting. 61 Stomach swollen and gleete about the Heart,
Liver, Lungs, and Mylt, boil two ounces of the juice with three ounces of
Honey till it wax thick, and use it as an electuarie first and last, the body
being first well purged. 62 Vomiting and weakness of the stomach, to cleanse
the Lungs, to comfort the Mylt, to destroy Rume, and for all griefs of the
brain, seethe two parts of the juice, with one part of Honey, till it be
thick, and drink thereof morn and even with sodden water. 63 Ears worms,
put in the juice. 64 Ach of strokes, apply it with swines grease. 65 Eyes dull,
make an ointment of the juice of Rue and Fennel with honey, and anoint
therewith, or eat them, and let thy breath go into thine eyes. 66 For the
fever, poison, and to cleanse the stomach and sharpen the sight, eat Fennel
seeds, but it must be used as medicine, and not as meat. 67 Biting of an
Addar, stamp Rue and read Fennel with Butter and fire it, and streine it and
drink it, and be whole. 68 To keep a horse from all diseases, give him good
store of Fennel baked in his bread, and let him eat it three days, every day
aloafe. 69 Eyes ache, mix the juice of red Fennel with Alome in a brazen
vessel, and set it in the sun xii. days, then keep it in a box, and use
it when need is. 70 Eyes sore, anoint with the juice of Rue, and Fennel, and
honey of each like much. 71 Milk to cause, seethe it in wine and drink it. 72
Lean to be, seethe it in water and drink it first and last. 73 Chollike,
drink powder of the seeds of Fennel, Parslie and Alysander. 74 For swelling
in the stomach and to cause Appetite, stamp the root of Fennel and of Ash
of each like much, and streine it with wine and drink it. 75 Headache, seethe
Rue and Fennel with water, and wash thy head therewith, and apply the herbs.
76 The seeds comfort the stomach, opens the stoping of the Reins and
Bladder, the juice helps webs in the eyes. 77 Drink it with wine or water to
expel all poison and venom out of the body. 78 Drop it into the ears to
kill worms in them. 79 Drink it with wine to help the dropsy and all
swellings, and to stop vomiting. 80 Drink it with wine and water to increase
milk, with oil it helps a swollen yard. 81 Headache, drink Fennel and Rue
with Pepper in wine: Eyes dull, drop in the juice of the roots morn and even.
82 Urine to cause and to expel the stone, drink the juice of Fennel,
Smallach, Parsley and Pimpernell of each like much with water. 83 Biting of an
Adder, seethe Rue, Betony and Fennel, in Butter, and drink it. 84 Stomach ach
of cold or wind, eat powder of Filipendula and Fennel seeds together. 85
The seeds, herbs, roots and rynde, are used in medicine: gather the seeds in
September, they may be kept three years. 86 Boil the herb or seeds in
fair water, and drink a glasse-full every day to avoid unnatural heat, and
to cleanse the sight. 87 The whole roots may be plucked up in May and kept three
years. 88 Stamp Fennel, and mix it with old Barrowes grease, and anoint
the face therewith lightly, to avoid the red spots like Leprie. 89 Eat Fenel
to increase milk. 90 To provoke Vrin and terms eat the seeds, likewise for
the stopping of the Liver and Milt, and the shedding of Urine. 91 Mix the
juice with warm Milk, and give it sucking children to help the hardness of
fetching breath. 92 Seethe the rynde of the root and drink it morn and even
for the pain of the stone when it comes of hot cause. 93 Eat Fennel to
comfort the stomach and help digestion, or eat or drink powder of the seeds.
94 Seethe the roots till they be soft, and apply them to women's Paps that
begin to opostumate to heal them without harm. 95 Put the juice into a Tin
Poringer, and sun it xv. days, and drop thereof into the eyes to clear
their dimnesse, but if Aloes epatike be put thereto it is much the better: or
boil the juice between two dishes, and gather the dew of the upper dish, and
keep it in a vial, and use it, it mendeth the eyes greatly. 96 Ears worms,
put in the juice warm. 97 Crampe and dropsy, seethe the roots in wine, and
drink it. 98 Burning and swelling, anoint with the juice and Vinegar. 99
Breath to be sweet, use Fennill. 100 Eyes dull, eat the seeds often fasting.
101 Use the root clean washed, in Potage and Ptisants. 102 Seethe the tufts in
wine, potage, or ale, to help the bladder, reins, and stone, and to increase
milk and natural seed. 103 Fennill is good to wash the feet withal to
bedward, and for Barbours baths, with Balm and Bays. 104 The sirrup is good
for a flegmatike stomach. 105 Stamp Fennill, Parsley, Water cresses, of each
like much, put there to White wine, and crummes of Barley bread, let it stand
all night in a stone Mortar, then strain it, and clarify it, and drink it to
cleanse the reins from gravel, and stone, and cholar, for the strangury, and
to cause much urine. 106 Fennill is good for fat men, to open the veins and
guts. The seed has greater virtue then the root. 107 Mix the juice of the
roots with clarified Honey, and anoint the eyes therewith for their redness.
108 To increase milk, and provoke terms, seethe the leaves in water or wine,
and drink it often. 109 Seethe the seeds of Fennill, Anise, and Cummin in
wine, and drink a good draught first and last four or five days to avoid
wind in the belly marueilously. 110 The decoction of the crops, eases the
pain of the kidneyes, expels the stone, vrin, and terms, and so does the
root, which is also good for the dropsy. 111 Drink the leaves or seeds with
wine, against all venomous bitings or stingings. 112 Drink the seeds with
water, for the pain and wambling of the stomach, and desiring to vomit. 113
The herb, seeds and root are very good to open and comfort the liver, lungs,
and kidneyes. 114 Mad dog biting, stamp the root with Honey, and apply it. 115
Stamp the leaves with vinegar, and apply them to the wild fire and all hot
swellings. 116 Stamp them together with wax, to avoid the blackenesse of
strokes and bruises. 117 Seethe Fennill in wine, and bathe the ache of the
yard therewith, or stamp it with oil, and anoint therewith. 118 Dry the
juice of Fenell in the sun, and use it in collyries for the eyes to quicken
the sight. 119 Apply the broth of the tops to the back for the ache of the
kidneis, and to drive forth water. 120 Drink Fenell in an ague with cold
water, to slake lothsomenesse and the heat of the stomach. 121 Some cut the
stalk and take out of it a juice like a gum, which is very good for yt eyes.
122 Fenell provoke men to generation of children. 123 Serpents chewe it to
clear their eyes. 124 The use of Fenell in wine, is good for the dropsy, the
griefs of the liver and lungs. 125 The broth of the roots in water or wine,
is good for the griefs of the kidneis and bladder. 126 The herb or decoction
thereof applied to ye pecten, drives forth urine, ye seed stirs man to
procreation. 127 The seed or broth of the herb is good for a plurisie. 128
Seethe the seed in wine, and drink it against venomous bitings and stingings,
to expel all poison and venom, terms, stone, urine, and viscus humors. 129
The seeds and flowers that grow in the midst of it, are the best parts. 130
The same sodden in water and drunk, takes away the heat and lothing of the
stomach, and helps the hot and dry cough. 131 The seed chewed by it
self, or condited with sugar, cutteth tough phlegm, and makes it easy to be
spit out, and sharpeneth the sight, and so does the distilled water dropped
into the eyes morn and even. 132 Eyes worms, drop in the water or juice. 133
Stamp the roots with honey and apply it to bitings or stingings of mad dogs,
or serpents, the same being first washed with urine or vinegar. The juice may
be drawn out of the root, herb, flower, and unripe seed, and dried in the
sun, and kept to be used with other medicines when occasion serves. Oil of
Fenell, press it out between two hot stones or irons, it will keep long,
and is good for the ptisike, dry scab, burning and scalding. Heart faint,
drink the juice often.

Figs.
FIgs new gathered, nourish more then other fruits, but they breed wind and
loosen ye belly gently, abate heat, quench thirst, but taken of too much, they
hurt the stomach, and make it weak, and without appetite. 2 Dry Figs nourish
better then green and new, yet they breed no good blood, for they that eat
them much, become lousy and full of vermin. 3 Figs eaten before meat loosen
the belly, are good for the kidneis, and drive forth gravel with the urine. 4
They provoke sweat, and thereby expel stinking humors, and therefore are good
for young children for the small pockes, measels, and wheales, to bring them
forth speedely without peril. 5 They are good for the throat and lungs, the
cough, shortness of breath to void phlegm etc. whether they be taken raw, or
roasted, or sodden with hysope and drunk. 6 Bruised inward, seethe them in
water, and drink it to mitigate the pain. Stamp them with salt, rue, and
nuts, and use it to withstand all poison, venom, and corrupt air. 7 For
hoarsenesse, sharpness of the throat, all swellings, and impostumes of the
mouth, throat almons, jaws, and swellings of the tongue, gargarise, with the
decoction of Figs, or hold it in the mouth. 8 For ache of the teeth and jaws,
hold Figs in thy mouth. 9 Apply them with wheaten meal to soften and ripen
impostumes and angry swellings behind the ears, especially with Linseede and
Fenegreeke put thereto, but the roots of Lilies put thereto, ripeth and
breaks impostumes and botches: with Barley meal, they scatter and consume
swellings. 10 Sodden in wormwood wine with Barley meal, and applied to the
belly they are good for the dropsy. 11 Stamp them finely with Mustarseede, to
help the ringing noise and sound of the ears, and mend the hearing, being
applied outwardly. 12 Dried Figs soften, consume and make subtle, and may be
very well used both inwardly and outwardly to ripen and soften impostumes, and
dissolve them. 13 Kings evil, swelling, kernels in the throat, and all other
tumors, stamp the leaves finely, and apply them. 14 The milkie juice helps
all deformities of the skin, Leapries, spreading sores, Tetters, small
Pockes, Mesels, Pushes, Freckles, Lentiles, and such like scurfe and spots of
the body and face being laid to with parched Barlie meal, and with fat or
grease, it takes away Wartes, it cures the tootheache, being applied with
Bombase or Cotton, or a little pellet made thereof, and put into the hollow
toothe. It opens the veins of the Emerodes, and loses the bellye being
applied to the fundament, and so do the leaves if they be put into the
fundament. 15 It is good to be applied with meal of Fenigreke and Vinegar
upon the hot gout, especially of the feet. The same juice is good to be put
into all venomous bitings of Serpents and mad dogs. 16 The same turns
milk, and causes it to curde. 17 The ashes of a Fig Tree mixed with oil and
wax cures burnings. 18 And lee made with ashes of the Fig, heals
scuruinesse and festered foul fretting sores being washed therewith. Dod. 19
Head scurfe, stamp the leaves and branches, and streine them with water and a
little vinegar, and anoint therewith. 20 Roste iii. Figs, and seethe them in a
cup of Beer with some bruised Licoras, and Aniseedes, and keep it warm by ye
fire, and drink thereof warm to bedward and eat the Figs, and so it helps
the cough in three nights. 21 A little of the wood of the tree put into a pot,
makes the meat to be soon sodden. 22 Stamp a handful of Figs, till the
kernels be broken, and temper them with a little fresh grease, and apply it to a
sore breast as hot as the woman may suffer to avoid the swelling and pain.
23 Rub warts with Figtree leaves and bury them, and the warts will go away. 24
Seethe Figs in wine with hysope and streine it, and drink it to help the
griefs of the throat, lungs, and old rotten coughs. 25 Figs be good against
melancholy and the falling sickness. Stamp them with shoomakers wax to
heal ulcers. 26 Figs will ripen hard apostumes and the plague sore. 27 They
are good against reumes and flowings of the belly. 28 They are very good for
the throat, winde-pipe, kidneis and bladder, for them that be ill colored with
long sickness, shortness of breath, the dropsy, and the falling sickness.
29 Stamp them with snailes, swines grease, and bean flower, and apply it to a
swollen throat to ripen it, and help the squincie. 30 Figs in meat, cleanse
the blood. 31 The same made warm and drunk with hysope, purge the breast, and
are good for the cough, the belly, and old diseases of the lungs. 32 Figs
eaten with Niter and Saffron soften the belly. 33 Sodden with Rue, they are
good in glisters against the gnawing of ye belly. 34 Sodden and applied, they
drive away hardness, and so soften the swelling behind the ears and other
swellings. With the shell of a Pomegranate they purge away agnayles, and such
angry swellings. 35 With Coprose they heal running issues of the leg, which
are almost incurable. 36 Sodden with wine, worm wood roman, and barley meal
and applied to the belly, they are good for the dropsy. 37 Burnt Figs applied
with a plaster of wax, are good for kibed heels and itchings. 38 The milkie
juice broken with an Almond and drunk, opens the mother. The same laid to
with the yolke of an Eg, draws down the terms. 29 It scowreth away lepries,
freckles, skurffe, and deformities of the face, and skabs, and running sores of
the head laid to with barley meal. 40 Figs stamped with leuin and salt, soften
plague sores and other ulcers and apostumes and breaks them. 41 A Fig tied to
a Bull, will make him tame though he be never so wild. 42 Figs are best eaten
fasting with nuts or almonds, and so they cleanse ye breast and lungs. 43 And
eaten fasting with powder of ginger, pepper, time, or peniroyal long before
meat, they are good against oppilations of the liver and milt, congealed
matter in the body, distillations or reume falling into ye breast and stomach,
they cleanse the reins and make ye body soluble. 44 Steep ii. or iii. Figs al
night in aqua vitae and eat them in ye morning against shortness of wind and
the cough. 45 Sees Figs in water and a little vinegar, and stamp them and
apply them to the swines evil, kernels, and swellings in the throat. 46
Apostume, stamp iii. Figs with oil, and apply it. 47 Yard swollen, apply a
plaster of iiii. Figs, wheat meal, and oil Olive. 48 Poison to withstand,
eat every day xx. leaves of Rue with iii. Figs, and a little salt to be safe
that day. 49 Seethe half a pound of Figs with one handful of hysope, and one
sponeful of honey in a pottel of white wine to the one half, and drink ii. or
iii. sponefull first and last to help the reume and the cough. 50 Chollike,
grind Figs with mustardseede and fenigreeke, and apply it cold: proved. 51
Mithridates medice against ye plague, mix xx. leaves of rue with ii. Figs and
ii. walnuts, and a little salt, and eat it and be sure from venom that day. 52
Cough, roste iii. Figs, and put them in a cup of Beer with a little powder of
Licoras and Aniseedes, and eat them and drink the drink warm to bedward
iiii. nights. 53 Shoulder ache, grind Figs and reasins of the sun in a
querne with mustardseede, of each like much with strong vinegar, and apply it
with a lambs skin. 54 Stamp the fresh branches and seethe them with vinegar,
and stamp them well, and apply them to the mentagra or lychen, which is a
foul breaking out of the face, with a scab beginning at the chin. 55 Liver
stopped, eat dry Figs with Pepper amongst thy meats, or else the seeds of
Cuscuta preserved with fine sugar. For the ptysike, old catharre, the cough,
and other griefs of the lunges, boil one handful of hysope with iiii. Figs,
and some reasins in water, and a little honey, and drink thereof a glass full
fasting. 56 Tongue palsy, mix one dram of the pulp with vi. grains of
Euphorbium, and hold as much as a bean under thy tongue, and spit often.
Breast stopped with cold, sees Figs with bruised mustard seed in wine, and
drink it luke warm. 57 Bitings venomous, stamp them with rue and nuts, and
apply it to all venom. 58 Bones broken, sees Figs and poppy seeds in water
and apply it. 59 Cods swollen, sees Figs in wine and apply them. 60 Side
impost. stamp them with oil or grease and apply them. 61 Make tents of the
rindes of old Figs, and put them into fistulaes, and lay a Fig plasterwise
above on it. 62 Phlegm or reume in the stomach, stamp radish roots with dry
Figs, and a little honey, and boil it into an electuarie and use it. 63 Cough of
outward cause, take a dishfull of beaten Barley, iiii. ounces of reasins, and
xii. Figs washed in warm water, seethe them in a new pot with iiii. quartes
of water, one hour, then streine it and seethe it again with vi. ounces of
sugar, but let it boil but once, and cool it and drink it morning and
evening, to soften and cleanse the breast: if it wax too thick, put more
water to it. 64 Cough and impostume, eat roasted Figs with powder of Nep.
Loins apostumed, stamp barley meal iiii. ounces, Figs ii. ounces, the juice
of mallows vi. ounces, and apply it with a sponge or cloth. 65 To open the
pipes, and clear the voice, roast powder of hysope in Figs, and eat every day
one. 66 Hoarsenesse, stamp Figs, and seethe them in wine or ale, and drink
it. 67 Straitness of the breast and stomach, sees fat Figs well stamped in
wine, with some bruised mustardseedes, and drink it warm to bedward, or sees
fat Figs with hysope and lycoras, with barley in water, and drink it. 68
Apost. apply a plaster of Dwale and Figs or reasins. 69 Reins impostumed, use
Oximel with the decoction of reasins and maiden hair. 70 Apostume to break,
stamp honey and fat Figs with swines grease, and apply it as the best medicine.
71 Emerods to provoke, rub Fig leaves first in thy hands, and then upon the
veins of the fundament, and then bind them to it. 72 Hoarsenesse, roast sugar
in Figs on the coals, and eat them hot. 73 Breast to purge, seethe Figs and
honey in white wine, and drink it. 74 Cough, fill a dry Fig with the seeds
of Tansy, and seethe them in white wine with one ounce of lycoras with a soft
fire to the one half, and drink thereof every night. 75 Impost. stamp Figs
with fresh grease, and apply them hot to the side or grief, and drink ye
juice of Feuerfue. 76 Stomach cold griefs, seethe hysope, Figs, and honey
together and use it. 77 Chollike, stamp Figs with mustardseede and vinegar,
and apply it cold. 78 Cough, seethe x. good Figs in a quart of white wine with
lycoras, any seeds, and sugar candy, of each like much to the one half, and
drink iii. or iiii. spoonefull morning and evening. 79 Apost. to ripen, stamp
fat Figs with swines grease, and frye them together, and apply it. 80 Squincie,
gargarise with the decoction of dried Figs, and a dogs dung to open the
apostume, or put mustard seed into Figs, and eat them at night to dissolve
the gross humors, and to open the lights, and help the breathing. 81 For
stopping of the liver, shortness of breath, and spitting of blood, seethe dry
Figs in white or claret wine with mustard, and drink it every night, first
eating the figs, and then drinking the wine. 82 Plurisy, stamp dry Figs with
suet, or oil and gum, and apply it. 83 Laske to stop, drink ashes of
Figtree branches with water. 84 Swelling about the yard, mix Figs with wheat
flower and oil, and apply it. 85 The ashes of an old Figtree causes sweat.
86 To cause deliverance of a dead child, take the white juice of Figs, or
powder of Dittanie with water in an ague, but with wine without an ague. 87
Gout, stamp a little bread, dry Figs, honey and vinegar together, and bind it
to. 88 For painful pushes on the legs, stamp dry Figs with flowers of Iuie,
and apply it. 89 Warts apply the milk of Figs.

Filipendula.
FIlipendula: strangury, drink it with good white wine. Ptisicke, seethe it in
white wine and use it. 2 Shortness and straitnes of breath of cold cause, use
powder of it and Gentian in brothes and drinks. 3 Chollicke passion, seethe it
with Fiue-leafe and Time and apply it. 4 Iaundies, drink powder of it with
other medicines. 5 The knots that hang by the roots used in powder, are good
for fistulaes and hollow sores both inward and outward. 6 Emerods, anoint with
eeles grease and cast on powder of the roots. 7 Poison to avoid, stamp the
herb and root in the end of May and distill it, and drink six ounces at a
time: it helps also the plague. 8 It breaks wind about the liver and milt,
and destroys the stone. 9 The root boiled in wine and drunk, helps the
dropsy, strangury, pain of the bladder, stopping of the urine and the stone.
10 Drink the powder thereof with Fennel seed against all cold and windy
griefs. 11 Use powder of the root often with meats against the falling
sickness. 12 The leaves and seeds sodden with wine and honey and drunk,
brings down the seconds, helps the dropping and stopping of urine, the
strangury, and griefs of the bladder and Iaundies, and so does the root
sodden in wine. 13 The powder of the root licked in with honey, helps the
cough, yexing, and shortness of wind. 14 The powder drunk with wine is good
for the falling sickness and the Iaundies. 15 Use it in brothes for ache of
the back and kidneys, windynesse of the stomach, the stone, strangury and
stopping of the urine.

Bachache 15 Bellyache 8. 12 Bladder grief 9. 12 Breath short 2. 13 Chollick 3
Cold griefs 10 Cough 13 Dropsy 9 Emerods 6 Falling evil 11. 14 Fistula 5
Flowers stopped 12 Hicket 13 Iaundies 4. 12. 14 Poison 7 Ptisick 1 Sores 5

Fillbeards (See Nuts, Hasill.)

Fitches.
FItches are not used in medicine, but given to horses. 2 But parched and taken
with honey, as much as a great nut at once fasting they are good for a
consumption. 3 Apply the meal with wine to venomous bitings the place being
first well cleansed. 4 Apply it with wine and honey to the swelling of the paps,
and to spreading sores: it cleanses spots, as Lupines does, and may supply the
want of Lupines, with vinegar it helps the tenasmus, and is good for the
stopping of the urine. 5 They feed oxen and kine fat speedily. 6 Boil them in
wine wherein saffron has been boiled, and stamp them and apply them to any
bruise. 7 Eyes rupture in the tunicles, mix the meal with Frankincense and the
white of an egg and apply it.

Bitings venomous 3 Breasts swollen 4 Bruses 6 Bursten 7 Cattle feeding 5
Consumption 2 Eyes hurt 7 Sores 4 Tenasmus 4
Fiueleafe.
FIueleafe. The roots boiled in water, till the third part be wasted, helps
the raging ache of the teeth, and the sores of the mouth being well washed
therewith and then drunk, and so it stops all bleeding, bloody flux and
other fluxes, and the sciatica. 2 Seethe the root in vinegar to soften fretting
sores and dissolve wennes, and cold swellings. It cures evil favored nails,
the inflammations of the fundament or mother, and al naughty scurfe being
applied. 3 Drink the juice of the young roots for the griefs of liver, lungs,
and all poison. 4 Fever tertain and quarten, drink the leaves with honied
water, or wine with pepper. 5 And drink it in the same manner xxx. days for the
falling sickness. 6 Stamp the leaves and apply them finely to burstings and
falling of humors into the cods. 7 Stamp ye leaves with salt and honey to heal
up wounds, fistulaes, and spreading sores. 8 Drink the juice of the leaves to
cure the iaundies, and comfort the liver. 9 Seethe it with vinegar to heal the
running sores, wens, windy swellings, impostumes, hot inflammations, agneils in
the fingers or toes, hard lumps that put forth blood in the fundament or
mother, and also scabs and scurfe. 10 Drink v. ounces of the juice to heal the
iaundies quickly. 11 Drink Fiueleafe to resist poison and venim. 12 Drink ye
juice xxxiii. days to heal the falling sickness perfectly. 13 The root, water
and juice, serves for all things that Tormentil serves for. 14 Hands
trembling, wet them often in the distilled water of it. 15 Drink ye syrop of it
xii. times to help the squincy and all fluxes and terms. 16 It helps fevers,
resists poison, expels devils. 17 The leaf taken with wine twice, helps
the ephemera, iii. the tertian, iiii. times ye quarten. 18 Carry Fiueleafe and
nettles in thy hands against fear and fancy. 19 Throat sore, seethe i. handful
with as much Columbine in a pint of new milk, and drink thereof hot often. 20 For
head ach, ach of the lims, and sorenes of the mouth, tongue and throat, seethe
it in wine, and drink it iii. days morn and even and be whole. 21 For ach and
gnawing, drink the juice with ale. 22 Nose bleeding, drink the juice with ale,
and apply the juice to thy forehead. 23 To kill a canker, seethe it in white
wine with swines grease and apply it. 24 Mouth, throat, and tongue sores, rub
with honey and the powder of it. 25 Poison and venomous bitings, drink the
juice with wine. Hoarsenesse, seethe crops of Mints, Sage, Fiueleafe, Ginger
and lycoras well bruised with stale ale, and streine it and drink it as hot as
may be suffered, and as often as need is. 26 Mouth or tongue scalded, seethe
it in water, and hold thy mouth over the vapor of it, and also wash thy mouth
therewith thrice a day. 27 Stone, seethe it and the root of it in wine and drink
it fasting to break and expel it. 28 Biting of an adder: stamp it and drink
it with wine. 29 Belly ache, hardness, and swelling and bound, drink two
spoonefull of the juice. 30 Chollick, seethe it in ale or wine and drink it.
31 Eyes web, apply it with swines grease and salt. 32 Iaundies, use it and
Mints in syrops. 33 Ilyak, seethe it in wine or ale and drink it. 34 Kings
evil, drink the juice or broth with salt and honey three cyats and use it. 35
Reins ache, drink one handful with warm water. 36 Strangury, drink the
water or juice. 37 Gums rotten, bruise it and rub them therewith. 38 Mouth and
throat sore, bruise it and seethe it in water, and draw in the vapor of it and
also gargarise therewith often, and so it is good for the squincy. 39 Vomit to
stop, bake the leaves with whites of eggs and eat them. 40 Woman's belly hard,
stamp it and drink it with hot milk. 41 Flux, use powder of it with the juice
of Planten. 42 Flowers to stop, sees it with rain water and bath therewith. 43
Legs ache, drink it. 44 Bitings and all venom, drink the juice. 45 Chollicke,
drink powder of the root, and long Pepper with good ale. 46 Flix Diaria,
drink the juice with sweet milk. 47 Bloody flux, drink two spoonefuls of the
juice. 48 Tongue greatly swollen, hold the juice in thy mouth. 49 Biting or
stinging, drink the juice with wine. 50 Mouth canker, boil it and
Honysuckles, Roch allom, and honey in vinegar and running water, and wash thy
mouth therewith. Bleeding, drink ye juice with red wine. 51 Stomach cold, drink
it with ale or wine. 52 Teethach, gargarise with the decoction of it. 53 Nose
bleeding, drink the juice and anoint the nostrels with it. 54 Flux, use ye root.
55 Emerods, sees it in goats milk, and use it iii. days when they bleed. 56
Fistula, put in the juice with a spout. 57 Nails to grow, stamp it with any grease
and apply it. 58 Mouth stink, seethe ye leaves in wine and wash therewith. 59
Iaundies, drink iiii. ounces of ye water or decoction of it. 60 To heal inward
^^ptures, and to dissolve congealed blood distill it with the root thereof in
the midst of May in a limbek and drink four ounces morn and even daily. 61
Flux and excoriation of the belly, drink the juice. 62 For great griefs
within the body, boil it with Penyroyall and Poppy leaves of each like much in
wine, and foment therewith. 63 Seethe it in vinegar and gargle therewith for
all griefs of the teeth, gums, mouth and throat. 64 Pissing blood, seethe it
with Reed mace in wine and drink it.

Aches 20. 21. 43 Adder biting 28. 49 Apostume 9 Agneils 9 Backache 35
Bellyache 21. 29. 61. 62. 33. bound 29. hard 29. 40. swollen 29. 40.
Bitings venomous 25. 28. 44. 49. Bleeding 1. 22. 50 Bloody flux 1. 47. 50
Bruised 60 Bursten 6. 60 Cods swollen 6 Chollick 30. 33. 45 Demoniak 16 Dropsy
(see Belly) Eyes web 31 Emerods 55 Falling evil 5. 12 Fancy 18 Fear 18 Fevers
