Flags.
FLags or yelow Flower de luce, or common Flags have the nature of the roots of
Tormentill and Bistort, and being boiled in the water and drunk, it stops
the bloody flux, and all other fluxes of the belly and all bleeding and the
flowers howsoever it be taken, yea, if it be used but outwardly in plasters or
bathes. 2 Teeth ache, put the juice of the yelow Flag into the ear on the same
side. 3 Freckles, seethe the root of stinking segs in in Cowes milk, and use
it, (See Acorus, Flower de luce, Gladen.)

Bloody flux 1 Flowers to stop 1 Fluxes 1 Freckles 3 Teeth-ache 2 Whites 1
Reins running 1
Flax.
Flax. Seethe the seed in water and apply it as a pultisse or plaster to
appease al pain, to soften cold swellings, apostumes of the ears, neck, and
all other places. 2 Stamp the seeds with figs and apply it to ripen and break
all apostumes and to draw forth thorns and pricks being mixed with the root
of wild Cucumber. 3 Apply the same with Cresses and honey to rough and evil
favored nails to make them come off, and to heal them. 4 Stamp it raw and
apply it to all spots in the face. 5 Seethe it in wine and wash ulcers and old
sores therewith to keep them from corruption, festring, and ranckling. 6
Seethe them in water, and drop thereof into the eyes to clear the sight. 7
Take them in glisters for the pain of the belly and matrixe, and to cure
wounds of them. 8 Mix them with honey, and take it as an electuary or lotion,
to cleanse the breast, to help the cough, and eat them with raisins for the
consumption or ptisicke, 9 Fevers and hectic. 10 Apply the meal of it with
Mallowe roots and swines grease warm, to ripen and break apostumes. 11 Eat
it with Pepper and honey to move Venery. Use the decoction thereof to cleanse,
mollify, and ripen the apostumes of the matrix. 12 The oil serves for
Printers ink, Painters colors, for vernishing of boards, for the Armorer in
making clean harness and weapons, and lamps. 13 The oil washed in five or
six waters with a stick till it wax white, and then with a spoone taken
forth (for it will swim aloft) will heal burnings, scaldings, and
inflammations, it mollifieth hard sores, and is good for bone setters to
strengthen the sinews, ioints and bones, for conuulsions, emerods, etc. If it
be drunk after poison, it will cast it up by vomit and cleanse the stomach.
With powder of a Bores tooth, applied with a fether, it heals ye squincy
presently. 14 The dross of the seeds after the oil is streined forthsteeped a
while in rain water, amendeth all the spots and deformities of the skin being
washed therewith. 15 Linseed has the nature of Fenegrek. 16 If it be taken in
cakes with Pepper plentifully, it causes lust. 17 Let women sit in the
decoction thereof for the inflammation and heat of the matrix. 18 Drink six
ounces of the oil against the plague. Drink two or three ounces of it with
barley water for the plurisie, but let the oil be fresh and not old if it be
taken inward. 19 The seeds lickt in with honey as much as a nutmeg at once,
helps the cough, and causes lust. 20 Anoint with the oil against
obstructions, chollicke, and hardness, or use the decoction of the seed
either in glisters or outwardly. 21 The seed or oil helps burnings,
softneth all hardness or apostumes, mendeth the defaults of the face,
especially the seed sodden in wine and the face washed therewith. 22 The seeds
sodden with as much Cresse seeds and honey, is good to be applied to skuruie
nails. 22 Breasts ranckled, apply the meal with the white of an egg, and
then apply the juice of Smallach with Rye meal, and let her drink the juice
of Veruin, Fenel seed and Amber. 25 Seed to restore in ye back, drink powder
of it with goats milk three or four times fasting. 26 Seethe the seeds with
Fenigreke in oil of Violets and butter, to dissolve all apostumes and the
plurisie. 27 Flowers to stop, seethe it in Goats milk and drink it. 28 Legs
swollen, seethe it in water tender, and stamp a great handful of Hemlocks, and
seethe them together and apply them till it be nesh and soft. 29 Noli me
tangere, dip a cloth in the oil and apply it. 30 Stinging, pluck out the
sting and apply a plaster of Linseed and vinegar. 31 Swellings, apply Linseed,
Holy oak, and Mallows boiled together: it heals sores also. 32 Side pain,
seethe the bruised seeds in water, and dip a cloth in it and apply it to have
present help. 33 Yard burnt, apply ashes of the seeds in a linen cloth. 34
Vrin stopped, seethe the seeds long in honey and use it. 35 Freckles, seethe it
in vinegar and use it, and after wash with woman's milk. 36 Quincy, mix the
juice of wormwood with milk, honey, and meal of Linseede and apply it. 37
Yard apostumed, apply powder of the seeds with gylts grease. 38 Belly bound,
seethe the seeds in water till they be tender, then do away the water, and
fry the seeds with fresh grease, and eat it hot. 39 Gout hot, stamp
Linseede, Iuy leaves with oil Olive, and apply it hot at every eight hours
end. 40 Pap apostumed, seethe the seed till it be broken, then power out the
water, and seethe the seeds in milk to pap, and apply it often till it be
broken. 41 Apostume to ripen, seethe the seeds in water to pap i.li. then put
thereto Holy oak leaves, and swines grease, and boil them and malax it and
apply it. 42 Gout at the bone, seethe it in water till it be thick, then stamp
it and mix it with sheeps sewet and the juice of Henbane, and herb Benet, and
seethe them well together and apply it. It helps also all running gouts. 43
Swelling of a bruise or hurt, stamp the seeds and seethe them in milk and
apply it. 44 Gout, take yolks of eggs, Linseed, saffron, and woman's milk of
each like much, work them well together and apply it: proved. 45 Hair to grow,
mix ashes of the seeds with honey and anoint often. 46 Quincy hot or cold,
apply a plaster of Linseed and Goats milk. 47 Hands ranckled and scabd, wash
with the decoction of the seeds. 48 Weariness and to cause sweat, apply water
of the decoction of the seeds to the stomach. 49 Sores ache, apply a plaster
of the seeds. 50 felon rankling, seethe the meal of linseede and barley in
ale, and apply it. 51 Soreness, and chafing of the yard, and for women's
breasts, boil the juice of morell with linseed, and barrowes grease, and
apply it. 52 Paps sore, seethe the seeds or meal, and apply it. 53 Stomach
greefes general, stamp the seeds of smallach, cummin, and linseede, of each
like much, and drink it with hot water. 54 Belly, or womb griefs general,
seethe a bag of linseede in water two hours, and apply it as hot as may be
suffered. 55 Crampe, bathe in the decoction of linseede. 56 Put the seeds into
a raddish root, and set it into fat earth, and the herb will come forth
like Dragons, and taste like vinegar and salt, and is used for sawse without
vinegar and salt. 57 Flax to be soft as silk, dress it and kembe it, and
cover it over with fresh calves doung, and let it so soke five or six hours,
then wash it, and it will be soft as silk. 58 Canker in the yard or else
where, cast on powder of linseede, and apply a plaster of mallows and
wormwood, sodden and stamped with Swines grease. 59 Codswolne, seethe Flax
and salt in vinegar, and apply it. 60 Yard scalde, or ape galde, burn an old
Flaxen cloth clean washed, and anoint it with oil of eggs, and cast on the
powder. 61 Hair falling, burn the seeds, and mix them with oil olive, and
anoint therewith. 62 Yard swollen, seethe the seeds with mallows and apply
it. 63 Nauel of children, swollen by much crying, cough, fall, or bruise, mix
powder of fair old linen cloth, burned, and of bitter lupines, and apply it
with tow to the navel. 64 Short winded, eat powder of the seeds with honey.
(See for Oil.)

Nails scallen, and falling off, mix the seeds, with as much seeds of wild
mints, and honey, and apply it.

Fleawort.
FLeawort, Psillium: Eyes heat, steep it in water, and apply it. 2 Hair not
to grow, use the cotton that is found in Fleawort. 3 Eyes tears, heat and
itche, steep it all night in water, and wash the eyeliddes therewith. 4 Flux,
roste the seeds in an eggeshel, and drink the powder thereof with wine. 5 A
bathe of the decoction of Fleawort, takes away all pain of the gout, of what
sort soever it be. 6 Fevers continual, steep the whole seeds all night in
water, and streine it, and drink it with sugar to quench intolerable heat. 7
Bind as much Fleawort as a filbert in a cloute, and lay it in warm water
three hours, and stroke thy tongue therewith to avoid the heat and
bitterness of the iaundies. 8 Thirst and dryness of the tongue, tie the seeds
in a cloth and steep it in cold water, and rub thy tongue therewith, and drink
the water wherein it has been steeped. 9 Seethe or steep the seeds in water,
and drink it to purge down a dust or choleric humors, to swage pain and
inflammation of the intrals, hot fevers, all inward heates, drought and
thirst. 10 Bruise the seeds, and purge them at the fire, and use them for the
bloody flux, and vehement laske, especially when they come of violent
medicines: mix the seed with oil of roses and vinegar, or water, and stroke
it on hot griefs, apostumes, and swellings behind the ears, or else where, and
headache. 11 Apply the seed with vinegar to the going out of the nauel, and
burstings of young children. 12 Apply water, wherein the seed has been steeped,
to S. Anthonies fire, and all hot swellings, and drop it into the ears that
run, or have worms in them. 13 Straw the green herb in the house to
withstand breeding of fleas.

Apostumes hot 10 Bloody flux 10 Bursten 11 Ears running 12 Eyes hot 1. 3

Flower de luce.
FLower de luce, Six drams of ye root taken with water and honey, purges
gross phlegm and choler, provoke sleep, staieth tears, and ceasseth (...)
stamp them and drink them with water, and cover thee well to sweat. 41
Flowers stopped, make a pessary of the root, and anoint it over with oil de
bay, or common oil, and cast thereon powder of walwoort, and put it in all
night till it provoke it to bleed. 42 Pricks or bones to draw out, stamp
the root and apply it. 43 Bruises, drink the root. 44 It heals ache of
the sinews. 45 Drink it with ale or wine to cleanse the breast from evil
humors, and to help the cough. 46 It helps crampes, and venomous bytings,
it expels a dead child. 47 Drink the juice of it and morell, of each one
egg shell full clarified, and sweetened with sugar to heal all dropsies that
be curable both hot and cold, but some take the juice of Iris one day, and
the juice of morell another day: for Iris loses, and morell provoke urine:
proved. 38 Take an egg shell full of the juice of the root raw, to purge
phlegm, and watrish humors from all parts of the body. 49 And with the juice
of time it is good for ache, and swelling in the head, stomach, and legs,
and bowels, and wind in them: you may put to it a little sugar, or honey, and
cloves, or a little aqua vitae. 50 Mix the juice of the flowers with gum
water, and it will be perfect and durable, blewe or green. 51 Cough to heal
speedily, use cawdles with the powder of. 52 Cattle hidebound, give them the
juice of the leaves. 53 Dropsy ascites, mix half an egg shell full of the
juice with four ounces of mellicrate and half a dram of powder of the best
rubarb, and drink it hot in the morning once a week: it is wonderful. 54
Ache in the loins or haunches, stamp the roots with brimstone, and bears
grease, and apply it. 55 Aches general, stamp the root with the oil of it
and honey, and apply it. 56 Hair falling, mix the powder with as much soote
of a chimney, and temper them with old oil, and anoint. 57 Fistula to heal,
stamp one ounce of the root with verderam, and oil of tartar, of each a
dram, and apply it to the sore. 58 Stingings of serpents, apply powder of the
upper parts with wine. 59 Apostumes under the ear, boil the root and stamp
it with salt, and ayply it to dissolve it. 60 Belly torments, drink a dram of
the powder with sour wine. 61 Belly bound, drink the juice with the yolke of
an egg as hot as may be suffered. 62 Milt griefs, drink it with wine. 63
Flowers stopped in a new laid woman, and to bring down the seconds, stamp the
roots, and boil them long in vinegar, and receive up the fume thereof through
a narrow mouthed glass, or other vessel. 64 Skin to cleanse, wash with the
powder in water. 65 Costiuenesse, drink the powder with any liquor.

Frankincense.
FRankincense, cough old, eat iii. grains by it self, or with a rere Egg. 2
Teethach, apply it with the juice of red nettles and the white of an Egg. 3
Eyes bloody, mix it with Mastike the juice of Smallach and the white of an
Egg and apply it. 4 For a woman that has been in labor and given over, and
for the Emerods, set it in a close chair on hot coals and sit over it, but an
earthe^ vessel is better then a close chair. 5 Ears dull, boil it with oil
olive and skum it clean, and anoint the forehead therewith from the one ear
to the other. 6 Vomit to stop, mix powder of Masticke and white Frankincense
with Rose leaves and the juice of Mints and apply it to the stomach. 7 Flux
white, mix i. d. weight of Nutmegs, and ii. d. weight of white Frankincence
with the juice of Quinces, and drink it. 8 Sores old, cast on powder of
Frankincense and Orpiment. 9 Teeth-wormes, receive up the fume of the seeds of
Leekes and Henbane, with powder of Frankincense. 10 Flux, roste an Onion
tender and bruise it, and lap it in a cloth, and apply it to the fundament, and
sit down upon it as hot as may be suffered a long time, and roste
Frankincense in an other Onyon, and put off the covering and apply it hot to
the Navel. 11 Itch, anoint with powder of Frankincense and oil de Baye. 12
Wounds and hurts to heal, melt virgins wax, a quarter of a pound, with
sheep sewet ii. ounces, and take it from the fire, and mix therewith
Frankincense i. ounce, and use it, see in lib. Animalium fol. 9. 13 Eyes
watering, mix it with Mastick, Bolarmon. gum Dragagant, and the white of an
Egg, and apply it to the forehead and temples. 14 Vomit to stop, mix it and
as much Masticke with Barlie meal and the white of an Egg, and spread it on
Towe and apply it to the mouth of the stomach. 15 Wounds bleeding, mix it
with the hairs of a horse belly, and the white of an Egg, and apply it. 16
Headache great and heavy, mix it with Aloes and Mastike ana, with vinegar and
white of an Egg, and apply it to the forehead and temples with stuphes. 17 But
if it come of vapors, mix it with Barley meal and the white of an Egg, and
apply it to the temple on the same side that aketh with a Paper. 18 Or mix it
with Pigeons dung, Wheat flower and the white of an Egg and apply it. 19
Pissing bed, in a cold cause, drink iii. drams of the powder of it. 20 Teeth
ach, mix it with worm wood, hot bread and vinegar, and apply it. Or roste it
in a red Apple and apply it. 21 Or with Wheat flower, the white of an Egg, and
Morell and red Nettles, or take it and Masticke ana, iii. drams, Peritrum vi.
drams, mix them with honey or Treacle, and apply it to the tooth. 22 Head skal,
mix it with Pitch and rosen of each like much with fresh grease, and shave thy
head and anoint it, and when the hairs rise like bristles, pluck them up and
apply new plasters, the powder and grease must be melted together. 23 Stomach
griefs, mix it with wormwood, Mints, Cummin and dried bread crumbs ana i.
handful, and stamp them with vinegar and apply them hot in a bag sprinkled
with vinegar. 24 Stone, stamp it with Gromelseed, Parsley seed, red Mints,
Violets and Saxifrage, and let it steep in good stale ale all night, and drink
it first and last. 25 Emerods pain, sit over the fume of the powder of it laid
on a tile almost red hot, and laid in hot water to the midst. 26 Drink fine
powder of white Frankincense with wine in cold weather, and with water in hot
weather wherein reasins have been sodden, to comfort ye brain, memory and
stomach. 27 Face swollen with tooth ach, apply it with the juice of red Nettles
and the white of an Egg. 28 Vomiting, boil it with the juice of Mints and a
little vinegar, and apply it to the pyt of the stomach. 29 Nose bleeding, stamp
it with earth-wormes and the white of an Egg, and apply it. 30 Fundament
fallen, receive up the fume of it and Pitch, and Masticke. 31 Leg swollen hard
and sore, hold it over the fume of it and vermilion, and lay a cloth over it.
32 Whiteflaw, apply it with the pulp of Resins. 33 Rume and distilling of the
head, use the fume of it, or apply a plaster of it. 34 Ach of all sorts, apply
it with the white of an Egg. 35 Use it to clear the sight, to heal new
wounds and stop al fluxes of blood. 36 With milk it heals all evil ulcers of
the Fundament, and dissolueth gross Phlegm, it strengthens ye memory. 37 And
with Ducks grease it heals wounds. 38 Emerods, sit over the fume of it in a
close chair. 39 Tooth ach, lay it and the seeds of Henbane and Leekes on hot
coals of each like much, and receive up the fume of it through a funnil. 40
Chollik, roste it in an Onion and apply it, and be whole. 41 Head ach, apply it
with Honey and the white of an Egg and white wine to the temples and neck, or
beat it with the white of an egg and oil of Roses, and apply it to the temples.
42 Pyles, mix it with oil of Roses and anoint. see Olibanum. Flowers to stop,
receive up the fume of it.

Sores 2. 17 Stomach stopped 2. 5 Weak 19. 20 Vrin stopped 5 Wheales 5 Worms 8

Furs.
FVrres or Thorne-broome, Seethe Leaves in wine or water and drink it, to stop
the Flowers and the Laske. 2 Drink the seed in wine against all venomous
bitings and stingings.

Bitings Venomous. 2
Galbanum.
GAlbanum is good for the old cough, shortness and streitnesse of breath,
Burstings, Brusings, cramps and shrinking of senowes. 2 Drink it in wine with
Myrre against all venom and poison by drinks or shots, to provoke Terms and
expel the dead births, and so it does in a Pessary or Perfume. 3 Let a woman
in painful travail, drink as much as a Bean, with a glass of white wine.
4 Burn it in Perfume to expel serpents and venomous beasts: if a man be
anointed therewith, none of them shall hurt him. If it be mixed with oil, and
the seed or root of Angelica or of Spondilium, and they touched therewith, it
causes them to die. 5 The perfume of it helps the strangling of the Mother,
and the falling evil. 6 Apply it to the nauill, to set the Matrixe in the
natural place. 7 It does soften and draw forth Prickles, Thorns, and cold
humors. 8 Apply it to all cold swellings. 9 Use it in all ointments and
emplasters that shall warm, digest, dissolve, ripen, break and draw
Apostumes and Pricks. 10 Apply it to the hardness of the Milt, and pain of
the side. 11 Facefreckles or spots or elsewhere, apply it with Vinegar and
Niter. 12 Toothach, put it into it. Ear running or mattering, put it in with
oil of Roses, or of Nardus. 13 Sleep to cause, apply it to the head. 14
Lethargy, smell to the fume of it: make it soft, and apply it to to a plague
sore or botch to take it clean away. 15 Soften it and put in a cloth of silk
and so into the mouth of the Matrixe, and let the woman's head be clean, and a
thin caul, and a clean kerchiefe on it, without any odours: if in the
morning, after she has lien with it in this manner all night, her head smell
of it in the crown, she is apt to conceive. 16 Mix it with powder of
Piretrum and the milk of Spurge or Wartwort and apply it to any rotten or
aching tooth, to break it, or pluck it out. 17 Dissolve it in Vinegar, and use
it to all hardness and knots of the joints, and to heal Fellons. 18 A Pessary
thereof brings down the Terms strongly. 19 Milt hard, apply it with
Assafetida and Wax, or dissolve it with as much Armoniake and Vinegar, and put
thereto Wax and powder of Wormwood and of Cost, and use it. 20 Plague sore,
apply it with black Soap. 21 Belly worms, take pills of it and Sugar candy
beaten together. 22 Apply it under the Navel to provoke Urine presently in the
strangurie. 23 Take Pills of it for the old Cough, and shortness of breath,
bruses and ruptures, or drink a little with Mire in Wine. 24 To cleanse it,
put it in a bag, and hang it in a deep pot, and set it into a vessel of
hot water, and the best will be in the bottom, and the dross in the bag:
or dissolve it in Vinegar and streine it. 25 Heels kibed, mix powder of it
and Dragagant with Ox Tallowe and a little oil of Violets, melt them together
and apply it. 26 Temper it at the fire and cleanse it, and apply it to a Byle
two days without remoouing, and do so as often as need is to break it and
heal it fair. 27 Breath stopped, take two drams of it with a rere Egg, or with
Barley water. 28 Worms, make Pills of it, and annoint them with Honey and use
them. 29 Urine stopped, apply it to the end of the Yard, but for a woman, to the
Navel. 30 It cleanses wounds, and keeps them open. 31 To cleanse it, put
it into very hot water, and by little and little the filth w^l separate from
the clean, and so it may be used in Plasters, etc. or resolve it all night in
Vinegar, or in Vinegar and water: and in the morning boil it and streyne it.
The like may be done with other Gummes that will not be powdered. 32 Dissolve
it it vinegar, and apply it to a swollen Pappe to break it, dissolve it and
anoint in vinegar of each like much and apply it to Apostumes.

Apostume 8. 9. 14. 32 Botch 14. 26. 32 Breasts swollen 32 Breath short 1. 23.
27 Stopped 27 Bruised 1. 23 Bursten 23 Conception 15 Cough 1. 23 Crampe 1 Dead

displaced 6 Suffocate 5 Plague sore 14. 20 Poison 2 Pryckes 7 Senowes shrunk 1

Gallingale.
GAllingale (See Cyperus.) Put the root or juice into the nose to comfort the
Brain. 2 Heart worms, chewe it and swallow it down. 3 Stomach cold, use
powder of it with Cinamome and Sugar upon tostes with ale or wine. 4 Put the
juice into the eyes to clear them. 5 Stomach pain of cold cause, stamp
English Gallingale, and boil it in oil, and apply it to the mouth of the
stomach, and apply it above the yard to provoke vrin, or sees it in water and
drink it to void vrin. 6 Gallingale stops the flowing of the urine coming
of coldness of the reins and bladder. 7 English Gallingale helps Chaps. 8
Hycket, sees one dram of the powder with a pint of good white wine, and
drink ii. ounces morn and even two hours before meat. 9 Appetite to cause,
make powder of Galingale, Pepper and Parsley seed of each two drams, and with
new honey, make it an electuary, and take one spooneful morn and even ii.
hours before and after meat. 10 Stomach windy and ill, use it in sauses with
ginger, Mints, and vinegar: it is the best root or spice for the stomach. 11
For the griefs of the breast and breast bones, take out the core of a ripe
apple, fill it with powder of Galingale and lycoras and honey all well mixed
together, and roast it, and pill it, and eat it as often as need is. 12 For
griefs of the heart, lungs, and stomach, and to preserve from all evil
humors, take Cardamom three ounces, Galingale vi. ounces, saffron i.d. worth,
sugar four ounces, make them into a fine powder, and take thereof half a
spoonefull morn and even till you be well. 13 Stomach hot, eat Gallingale
with green Parsley. 14 It takes away the coldness of the breast, heart, guts,
reins, and matrix. It causes a sweet breath, expels wind, helps
digestion, provoke lust, dissolueth the hard milt. 15 It comfort the
brain and memory being put into the nose. 16 Hold a piece in the mouth to
cause belching. 17 It is good for the chollick. 18 Drink it with the water or
juice of Planten to stop the bloody flux, and strenthen nature, to comfort the
brain and the trembling of the heart.

Appetite 9 Back griefs 14 Belly ache 14. 17 Bloody flux 18 Brain weak 1.
15. 18 Breast griefs 11. 14 Breath stink 16 Chaps 7 Chollick 17 Digestion 14
Eyes dull 4 Flux 18 Heart griefs 2. 12. 14. 18 Hicket 8 Lungs griefs 12 Lust
to cause 14 Matrix griefs 14 Memory 16 Sickness general 12 Stomach cold 35.
griefs 12. hot 13. windy 10. Vrin dropping 6. stopped 5. Windiness 10. 14
Gall, or noble Myrtle, etc.
GAll, or noble Myrtle, or dwarf Myrtle: brewe the leaves, buds, and flowers
in Beer in stead of Hops to make it have a pleasant smell and taste: but it is
good to use therewith some hops or Rosemary, Calament, or Groundpine or such
like opening seeds or herbs, as the seeds of Carway, Fenel, or Anise. 2 Drink
it to kill heart worms.

Beer 1 Worms 2
Gallion.
GAllion stamped and applied to burnings, draws forth the heat, and heals
them. 2 Apply it to the nose or to wounds to stop their bleeding. 3 Mix it
with oil of Roses, and set it in the sun, and apply thereof to wearied
members to comfort them. 4 The roots provoke Venus. 5 The herb is very good to
be put into rennits to make pleasant cheese. 6 It is good for the holy fire,
shingles, and burnings. 7 Seethe it, and wash the feet therewith against
weariness, and also wash dry scabs therewith.

Blood stopped 2 Burnings 1. 6 Cheese 5 Holy fire 6 Lust to cause 4 Shingles 6
Scabs 7 Weariness 3. 7
Garlike.
GArlike, breaks all evil winds in the body, and provoke vrin, but it
hurts the eyes and causes thirst. Chollick windy, roast iii. cloves of
Garlike in a wet paper in the embers, and pill them, and put them into the
fundament somewhat warm. 2 It heals venim within a man. 3 It heals al cold
sores as it were Treacle. It healteth scabs, morphue or bladders being chafed
well with the juice. 4 Worms to kill, apply it with rye bread, salt, and good
ale dregs to the navel or breast to make them come out. 5 Head scalde, stamp
it with honey and apply it. 6 Urine stopped, stamp it with Hocks and vinegar, and
seethe them in ale till the third part be wasted and drink it often. Pyles,
drink powder of it. 7 Biting of a man, stamp it with Rue, meal and honey and
apply it. 8 Chollick, stamp three cloves with a good handful of Time, and
streine them with ale, and make a possit with it, and drink the ale of it. 9
Horse bots, cut horse hair small, and give it him with warm milk in a horn,
and put in either ear a spoonful of milk, and a cloue of Garlike, and knit
the ear with a list two hours. 10 Teeth-ach, stamp it with honey and apply it
to the cheek. 11 Worms, drink sweet milk four days, and the fifth day stamp
Garlike with vinegar, and eat it to kill them all. 12 Gout, stamp pilled Garlike
with Housleek, and anoint therewith strongly. 13 Head ach of cold, eat
Garlike, and mix the ashes of it with vinegar and apply it. 14 Pissing blood,
seethe the heads with their roots and all in wine and water, and drink it three
days and be whole. 15 If a spider be in thy cup, or crept into thy mouth,
drink Garlik. It helps also poison and venomous bitings. 16 Voice to be
clear, seethe Garlike in milk, or pun it by it self, and eat it with soft
cheese. 17 Teeth-ach, pill a Garlike head, and bind it to the wrist on the same
side that the grief is on, bruised as broad as a wallnut all night, and let the
water go out of the blister, but if it run too sore, lay to the rough side of a
wallnut leaf. 18 Hoarsnes and old cough, eat sodden Garlike. 19 Stomach with
cold humors, eat raw Garlike with salt and bread fasting. 20 For small worms
in the belly, eat Garlike fasting. 21 Loins ach of cold cause, seethe Garlike
and Coliander of each ii. ounces in wine one quart, till the third part be
wasted, then strein it and drink it morn and even. 22 Bladder stopped with the
stone or slime, and for the stitch and pain thereof, stamp ii. Garlike heads
and their roots well cleansed with a good handful of Mallows, and their roots,
and seethe them in a new pot half an hour with a quart of wine, and strein
it, and put thereto ii. drams of sugar, and drink thereof cold a good draught
morn and even as often as need is, and hold a toste of bread to thy mouth, if
thou doubt to cast it up again. 23 Teeth-ach, stamp it with saffron and
pepper, and apply it between thy teeth. 24 Squincy, stamp Garlike and rub it
therewith, and stamp more and apply it plasterwise. 25 Fundament fallen, bake
Garlike, and put it in, and when it is gone in, apply of the said Garlike with
tallow, and when it is in put in a stoppel. 26 Gout cold, stamp pilled Garlike
and seethe it with man's vrin and scum it, and apply it six hours thrice and
be whole. 27 Canker and fester to destroy them mix Orpiment with Housleeke and
Garlike and apply it. 28 Biting of ^ mad dog, stamp Garlike cloves with Mints,
Morell, and salt, and apply it. 29 Plague to resist and to kill worms, eat a
top of Rue, a Garlike head, and a corn of salt xxx. mornings: proved. 30
Matrix to open, put in a cloue of pilled Garlike. It helps the suffoc. of the
mother. 31 A plaisteer of the cloves and leaves, stops the humor causing
reume. 32 Teethache, stamp two cloves, and bind them to the wrist on the same
side that the grief is on. 33 Chollick and Ilyak, eat Garlike with a little
bread. 34 Fundament falling, receive up the fume of the warm and clear juice
of Garlike. 35 Stone, seethe vii. heads in water a good while and drink it
iii. days. 36 Flowers to cause, put a cloue of pilly Garlike into the matrix.
37 Mother suffoc. dissolve Treacle, Cloves, and Garlike in strong wine and
drink it. 38 Fever certian and quotidian, bind Garlike to the outward parts
before the fit come. 39 Eat Garlike and drink after it the blood of a cock
with warm wine, and no venomous beast shall hurt thee. 40 French Garlike fried
with oil, kills ill scabs and breaking out, and breaks apostumes. 41 Eat
Garlike and breath upon a painted face and the color will quickly vanish away.
42 Gout hot or cold, stamp Garlike with as much Housleek and apply it. 43
Chollick, stone, and strangury, stamp vi. cloves, and strein them with a
draught of Renish wine and drink it iii. days. 44 Stone, and to expel vrin,
burn ye cloves in a pot, and drink the powder, or use it in pottage. 45 Serpent
crept into the body, eat Garlike. 46 Teeth-ach in ye nether jaws, pil Garlike
and bruise it and apply it to the soles of the feet to help it speedily. 47 Vrin
stopped, stamp Garlike and Mallows and streine them in white wine, and drink a
good draught ix. times. 48 Sow Garlike when the Moon is under the earth, and
pluck it when she is above the earth and it will not smell, it will be the
sweeter if it be bruised when it is set, or olive stones set about it. 49 To
take birds that eat the seeds when they are sown, seethe Garlike that it may
not grow again and cast it to them, and they that eat it may be taken up with
your hand. 50 Cough, stamp Garlike with hogs grease, and anoint the back and
feet therewith by the fire. 51 Cocks that eat Garlike are stout to fight, and
horses that eat it with bread and wine at the hour of battle, are lively and
fierce. Therefore traueilers and warriers do bite thereof often to cause
agilitie and courage. 52 Moules to catch, put Garlike, Onions, or Leeks into
the mouths of their holes, and they will come out quickly as amazed. 53
Coughs, stamp three or four cloves with bores grease and anoint thy feet when
thou go to bed and keep them hot with a tosted trencher and warm clothes,
it helps all coughs in young and old. 54 Emerods bleeding, drink the juice of
Yarowe, and cast on burnt Garlike and they will dye. 55 Teethache, put a cloue
of Garlike into the ear on ye same side that aketh. 56 Cough, cleanse two or
three heads of Garlike and stamp it with hogs grease, and warm thy feet hot,
and rub them well therewith, and lap them hot, and cover thee well, rub
therewith also the smals of thy legs. 57 Side chollick, seethe four heads with
a pint of white wine, and drink thereof, and go to bed and cover thee well. 58
Ears noise, put in the juice of Garlike and saffron with goose grease. 59
Apostume or swelling in the groyne or share to break it, mix two Garlike
heads with vnslakt lime and yolks of three eggs and apply it. 60 To defend from
the plague, eat Garlike and drink wine after it. 61 Ringworms, mix the ashes
of Garlike with honey, and anoint therewith. 62 Flowers and seconds to bring
down, seethe it in water and receive up the fume of it. 63 Pissing blood,
seethe heads in water to the third part and drink it. 64 Scabs, stamp it
finely, and apply it especially with swines blood. 65 Pissing bed, seethe it
with sage in wine, till the third part be wasted, and strein it and drink it
morn and even. 66 Bitings venomous, drink Garlike with wine, and apply it with
fig leaves and Cummin, or anoint the biting of a dog with the juice, or apply
Garlike or Onions with Rue and salt, and wash the sore first with the juice of
Garlike or Onyons. 67 Flux to stop, pill two heads and stamp them, and seethe
them in almost a pint of milk with some shaven chalk, and drink it once or
twice. 68 Bleeding to stop, drink the juice of Yarowe with powder of burned
Garlike. 69 Garlike consumes, dissolueth, and expels poison. 70 Stamp it,
and apply it to any venomous bitings of beasts or worms. 71 Worms in the body,
take Garlike with the juice of Parsley and Mints with a little vinegar and
pepper, and make it a sause, and eat it with bread or meat. 72 Chollick and
pain of the reins, seethe it in wine and oil and apply it plasterwise to the
belly, and round about the root of the yard. 73 Eat Garlike to withstand all
corrupt and stinking air. 74 Teeth-ach, hold a cloue of it in thy mouth when
the ache comes of cold cause. 76 Garlike makes inflation, dries and harmeth
the stomach, and causes thirst. 77 Apply it to the skin xii. hours to raise
blisters, and therefore the eating of it by them that are chollerick is
hurtful, for that it inflameth them, dries up the whole body, especially in
hot seasons, and ingendreth leapry in in them, causes frensy, hurts the
sight, and moves headache, and it does more harm raw then sodden or roasted,
but the moderate eating of it in Winter by them that are phlegmatic, is right
profitable. 78 Roast it and stamp it with figs and barowes grease to break an
apostume as is aforesaid, and to draw forth the matter. 79 Anoint the head with
the juice to kill both lyce, and nitts. 80 Drink Garlike with the decoction of
Agarik, to kill both lyce and nitts. 81 Mix the ashes with honey and anoint
thin places of the head to help the sheading of hair. 82 Mix the ashes with
honey and May butter and anoint the scab or leapry and all filthiness of the
skin, and after go into a bath or hot house. 83 Ulcers old, sprinckle on
the ashes. 84 Seethe Garlike and eat it against hoarsenesse, the old cough,
to purge the breast and dry up the moisture in the stomach. 85 Seethe it with
the leaves and all in wine, and drink it to procure urine, terms, and
seconds, and anoint the belly therewith also, or take up the fume of it in a
close chair. 86 The savor of it drives away all venomous worms. 87 If any be
stung of an adder, or has drunk poison, let him eat Garlike and he shall have
no harm thereby. 88 Seethe it with vinegar and drink it with honey, to kill, and
expel al kinds of worms in the body. 89 Sees it with oil olive, and anoint
swellings and other griefs of the bladder. 90 Seethe it with milk, and drink
it to heal the blistering of the lungs. 91 Seethe it with Centory in wine and
drink it to help the dropsy gathered of cold cause. 92 Bruise it with Coliander
seed, and so take it with wine to assuage the pain of the loins, and to open
the straitnes in making of water. 93 Seethe it with leaves and temper it with
oil olive, or oil of Poppy, and anoint the temples therewith for the headache.
94 Seethe Garlike and after roast it dry and make it into powder with Pellitory
and Mastick, and wash the mouth therewith to help the toothach. 95 If a woman
cannot smell the savor of Garlike being set by her bedside in the night, she is
undoubtedly with child. 96 Garlik is good to be eaten of laboring men that eat
often meats that are cold and hard of digestion. 97 Rue eaten after Garlike
takes away the smell thereof, and so does a raw bean, or a Beet root roasted in
the embers. 98 Garlike used in meat, resists all poison and infirmities
coming by drinking of corrupt and evil water, and kills worms and venomous
things in ye body. And being drunk with wine and also applied outwardly, it
helps the bitings and stingings of vipers, serpents and mad dogs. 99 Garlik
eaten, clereth ye voice, helps ye cough, is good for ye dropsy, provoke
urine and softneth the belly. 100 The juice anointed, takes away scabs and
leapry from the skin, and all filthy spots from the face being rubd therewith,
but especially the ashes of it with honey. It is a singular remedy used any
ways for diseases of cattle. 101 Wild Garlike is more strong to al effects
then ye garden Garlike. 102 Stamp it and apply it to the emerods. 103 Sees it
and the smell of it will be gone, but ye virtue remains to be eaten against
coughs, pain of the lungs, and to cause sleep. 104 It is the common peoples
treacle. It makes sanguine men to have red faces. 105 Stamp it with Mastick, and
hold it in ye mouth to assuage toothach. 106 Stamp it and gargarise with it for
the squincy. 107 Drink it with new ale to kill worms. 108 Eat it against the
falling evil. 109 Mix it with pitch, brimstone, and rosin, and use tents
thereof to heal fistulaes hot. 110 Stamp vi. cloves and streine it with a
draught of Renish wine and drink it for the stone, chollick, and strangury. 111
Stamp a whole head p^^ied and apply hot to the soles of the feet for the
toothach that comes of cold cause. 112 Garlik dispatcheth all windines,
opens all stoppings, kills and expels broad worms, provoke vrin,
clears the voice, cures old coughs, and is good for the dropsy either raw
or sodden. 113 Burn the cloves in a pot to drive out vrin and the stone. 114
Stamp it with swines grease and anoint the feet and backbone there with for the
cough coming of cold cause. 115 Teethach, stamp it with vinegar and apply it,
or boil it in water with a little incense, and wash the mouth therewith, and put
it into the hollow teeth, or mix it with goose grease, and put it into the
ear. 116 Headache, bruise it and apply it to the temples. 117 Bruses, black
spots, or other deformities of the skin, anoint with the ashes of it and honey.
118 For the white scurfe, leapry, running ulcers of the head, manginesse, wild
fire, spreading scabs like tetters, etc. stamp it with oil and salt and apply
it. 119 Swelling hard, apply it with grease. 120 Fistulaes, apply it with
sulphur and rosin. 121 Seethe it twice or thrice in water to put away the
sharpness of it, and so it is much better then raw. It expels wind, and
breeds no thirst, clears the voice, helps the cold cough, provoke urine
and the terms, causes lust, helps the windy chollicke and stone, and the
sciatica coming of phlegm. 122 Adders bitings, apply it with oil de Bay. 123
Burn it to heal great wounds. 124 Seethe it in milk to help the old cough,
spetting blood and matter, and for the reume and distillations.

Gelofers.
GElofers: make conserve of al kinds of cloue Gelofers with sugar, and use it
to comfort ye heart for hot fevers and the plague. 2 The root of garden
Gelofers is good against ye plague. 3 Sta^pe Gelofers and apply them to heal
wounds of ye head, and to draw forth broken bones. 4 The decoction of them is
good to wash the head withal. 5 Sees ye flowers in white wine, and drink it
against ye terror of ye tertain fever, and the horror of ye quarten fever warm
before the fit, and to kill worms. 6 The oil of Gelofers heals the biting of
a mad dog, the wounds of ye sinowes and cold goutes. 7 The root is good for ye
falling sickness. 8 They with ye purple flower are preserved as roses with
sugar, and are very good against ye plague or any kind of poison, yt falling
sickness, ye palsy, and the crampe, and giddiness. 9 Drink iiii. ounces of
ye juice of ye whole plant after the first assalt of ye plague to cure it. 10
Put the herb and flowers in vinegar certain days to make it pleasant and
very good to revive one out of swooning, ye nostrels and temples being washed
therewith, and so it also delivers from ye plague, being daily used in like
manner. 11 Winter Gelofers in medicine, are much of like nature. The conserve of
the flowers, is good against ye weakness of the heart, and hot burning
fevers. 12 Anoint ye temples with the vinegar thereof for ye headache. 13
Drink a glassefull of the juice of winter Gelofer against all griefs. 14 To
draw a woman's pap that would rot, stamp double Gelofers, and heat them with
fair water, and pluck out ye stoppell of the glass, and set it on the pap
head. 15 Wall-gelofers, dry them and boil them in water, and drink it to
provoke urine and terms, to cure hard apost. of ye mother being bathed
therein. 16 Sees ye flowers in oil and wax, and use it to chaps, or rifts of
ye fundament, and falling down of the long gut, and to close up old ulcers. 17
Mix it with honey to cure the ulcers and swellings of the mouth. 18 Drink ii.
drams of ye seed to expel ye terms, seconds, and dead birth, or put it into
the matrix as a pessary. 19 Eyes dull and spots, drop in ye juice. 20 Milt
hard, stamp ye root with vinegar, and apply it, and likewise to ye liver for ye
hardness thereof. 21 The flowers may be kept dry to purge ye matrix and terms.
22 Seethe the roots soft in vinegar, and apply it to hot apostumes, and the
gout. 23 Sees ye root soft with vinegar and oil of roses to help ye hardness
of ye liver and milt. 24 The oil of ye flowers is precious for griefs of the
reins, bladder, and ioints and sinowes. 25 Temper ye juice with honey to heal
sores of the mouth and head. 26 And with wax it heals chaps. 27 Sees the
dry flowers in water, and sit therein for the inflammation of ye mother, and to
bring down ye terms. 28 In a cerot they heal the rifts of ye fundament, 29
With honey ye sores of the mouth. 30 Drink the wine of the decoction thereof,
or the distilled water v. spoonefull morn and even, for the griefs of the
liver and kidneys. 31 Drink the seed or juice to drive down the flowers,
seconds, and dead birth mightily. 32 Sees the fresh flowers in wine, and
drink it for the inflammation of the matrix. 33 Drink the distilled water
daily for a certain time, to strengthen all the inner parts to comfort the
blood, to cheer the mind, and take away pain. 34 The juice of all kinds of
Gelofers put into the eyes, takes away all spots and mystinesse thereof. 35 It
is the best of all Gelofers. 36 They with the purple flower are much of like
nature.

Gentian.
GEntian: (see Dwarf Gentian) drink one dram of the root in powder with
wine, and a little pepper and rue for all inward poison, and all venomous
bitings. 2 And with water for the griefs of the liver and stomach, and use it
for all cold diseases of the intralles. 3 The juice of the root dissolueth
bruised blood, and helps the grief of the side and burstings. 4 The same
juice cures festered and fretting sores and wounds being dropped into them. 5
Apply the same with linte to the eyes to swage the pain and heat. 6 It
skowreth all filth from the skin, being anointed therewith. 7 Put the root
into the matrix as a pessary to pull down the dead birth and terms. 8 Stamp
Gentian with twice so much Centorie, and soke them in wine v. days, then
distill it, and drink the water morn and even, to preserve the body from the
plague, to heal the ptisike, to cleanse the stuffed stomach, to break and
expel the stone from the reins to avoid watery humors from the milt, to
provoke terms to purge choler and corrupt blood, to heal inward wounds and
venomous bitings, to clear the sight, to preserve the body from all diseases,
to avoid all impostumes, and to cause a good color: but in healing wounds
apply ye powder of Centory outwardly. 9 The root is much used in medicines
against poison. It is perilous for women with child to drink. 10 There is
nothing better for ye iliaca passio, and the dropsy, being drunk in wine and
water, and for all the diseases of the lungs, and for all diseases of horses,
kine, oxen etc. 11 Horse pussy, or broken winded, give him powder of it in his
water to drink. 12 Ptisike, drink powder of the root of Gentian, and
Filipendula of each one dram with honey and water often. 13 Mad, drink the
seeds of Rue and Gentian with vinegar, and apply a black cock to the head,
cut through the midst xxiiii. hours, and ye third day bleed in the head. 14
Or use Gentian, and Rue, and also wash thy head with the same herbs, or
drink Gentian often with honey and vinegar. 15 Breath short, and strait, use
powder of it in meats, brothes, and drinks: spiders biting, apply the juice.
16 Stomach to cleanse, use Gentian and Tormentill, of each like much in thy
potage and be whole. 17 Fever quarten and quotidian, drink powder of Gentian
and maces, of each like much, with a little pepper with glarified Ale and Sugar
before the fit. 18 Fever quarten, sees the root in wine, and drink it before
the fit: it is taken to be mate-fellon. 19 Drink Gentian in water and honey to
help the swelling of the stomach and body, to help venomous bitings, and
cause deliverance of a dead child.

Germander.
GErmander: milt hard, urine stopped, and for the dropsy, in ye beginning sees
it in wine, and drink it thrice every day. 2 Stamp it when it flowreth, and
drink the decoction, and also apply the herb to bruises to help them
speedely. 3 Stamp it and apply it to fistulaes of ye eyes, or make oil of ye
herb, and drop it into them to heal them presently, especially if ye body be
of cold co^plection. 4 Sees the herb in wine, and drink it to avoid ye
kings evil. 5 Sees it in wine with fenel seeds and Seen, to help greatly ye
stoppings of ye liver and milt, and parsley seeds put thereto, it helps ye
strangury and stone. 6 Palsy, boil it in wine, and apply it to help it. 7
Wounds to heal, bruise it with oil, and apply it. 8 Boil ye green herb in
conduit water, and drink it to help ye crampe, ye palsy, the cough, hardness
of the milt, stopping of urine, and the water between the skin and flesh. 9
Sees it in wine, and drink it against poison, and apply ye herb to ye
bitings of venomous beasts, worms and serpents. 10 Sees it in wine and
vinegar, and drink it for ye hardness of the milt, the old cough, and old
ulcers mixed with honey and so drunk 11 Eat ye powder of the herb with honey to kill
worms. 12 Reume, heat ye powder in a linen bag and apply it. 12 Mouth
blisters, wash with ye decoction of it thrice a day. 14 Scab small, make an
ointment of it with swines grease, and anoint therewith often. 15 Eyes dull,
haw and pearl, apply the juice of ye leaves with oil straked on ye eyes. 16
Stamp ye leaves and lay them in oil, and apply them to burstings, wounds, and
consuming sores. 17 Sees Germander and the flowers of it with a little betony in
wine or water, and strain it, and sugar it, or honey it after the manner of a
decoction: it does mightily heal ye cough, ye beginning of ye dropsy, stopping
and hardness of ye milt, ye strangury and stopping of the urine and terms, it
serves for all griefs ye Betony serves, especially for women that are cold,
and troubled with the whites. 18 Germander dried and sodden, is good for women to
sit in, or to be applied to their natural place in bags to stop ye whites and
the gnawing of the matrix. 19 Sees it with salt and vinegar, and stamp it with
leuin, and apply it to ye stomach for ye coldness of the stomach, and the
belching, lothing, and vomiting. 20 Eat ye leaves by themself, or with
reasins, the stones taken out fasting to withstand ye plague. 21 They help the
tertian fever, and open the liver and milt, one handful being boiled with Seen
i. ounce, and aniseedes ii. drams in a quart of white wine. If ii. drams of
parsley seed be put to it, it helps also the strangurie and stone, and when
the one half is wasted, streine it and drink it fasting ii. days, ii. hours
before meat. 22 Drink it with vinegar to abate the swelling of the liver and
against poison. 23 Drink it with good wine, and also make pills thereof with
honey, and swallow them to purge sores and ulcers. 24 It opens the stoppings
of the joints, and dries gross humors. 25 Stamp the leaves with oil to
heal wounds. 26 Drink the seeds to draw out yellow choler, and to comfort
the eyes. 27 Steep it in aqua vitae, and drink it to purge melancholy
madness. 28 Seethe it in red wine, and drink it often to stop a laske, and
eat parched almonds, and be whole. 29 Worms in the eye lids, stamp it with
old wine and apply it. Flowers stopped, stamp half a handful and streine it
with ale, and drink it with one peniworth of saffron in the mornings. 30 Head
fistula, put in powder of Germander, and wash the head with the decoction of
it. 31 Ruptures inward, stamp it with a wooden pestell, and steep it in good
white or red wine that is astringent, and drink thereof often. 32 Gather
Germander when it flowreth, dry it in the shade, and mix one spoonefull of ye
powder of it with the yolks of two eggs, and seethe it, and eat it morn and
even eight days, and keep a good diet to cure the falling evil.

Bitings venom, 9 Bruises 2 Bursten 31 Cough 8. 10. 17 Crampe 8 Dropsy 1. 8.
17 Eyes fistula 3 griefs 15. 26 worms 29 Falling evil 31 Fever tertian 21
Fistula 3. 30 Flowers stopped 17. 29 Fluxes 28 Joints stopped 24 Kings evil 4

Ginger.
GInger: eyes dull, grind white Ginger on a whetstone into a fair basin, and
put thereto as much salt, and grind them well together, and temper them with
white wine, and let it stand xxiiii. hours, and put the clearest in a glass,
and use to anoint therewith when thou go to bed. 2 Teeth-ache, boil Ginger
in honey and vinegar, and put it into thy hollow tooth, or boil ground Iuie
and Ginger in wine, and hold thy mouth over it, and rub thy teethe with the
Ginger, or burn Ginger, black pepper, and salt of each like much in a linen
cloute, and lay a little of the powder on a linen cloth, and apply it to the
tooth. 3 Cough, eat roasted apples with Ginger and sugar candy. 4 Flowers to
stop, lay Ginger, Baye leaves, and Sauine on hot coals, and receive up the
fume thereof through a tunnell in a close chair. 5 Eyes dull and red, grind
white Ginger on a whetstone into a brazen mortar, and put thereto as much salt,
and grind them well together, and let it stand hours, then put ye scom into a
vial, and with a feather anoint xxiiii. well the eyes when thou go to bed,
and be whole. 6 Chincough, sees Elecampana with as much Ginger in fair water
to ye one half, and stamp it and streine it, and put thereto a third part of
honey boiled and scommed, and make an electuary of it, and take thereof a good
quantity morn and even. 7 Eyes pearl, rub Ginger dipped in white wine on a
whetstone of Norway over a sawser, and with that wine wash ye eyes with a fether
to void ye pearl, and preserve the eye. 8 Breast to be clear and voice good,
mix powder of Ginger, lycoras, and sugar with ye yolke of an Eg, and a little
salt, and warm it in ye shel, and eat it fasting. 9 Ache, take new wax a
qz. of a li. oil olive v. sponeful, Ginger pared and grated iii. rases. Melt
ye wax, put in ye oil, and heat it a little, and then put in the Ginger, and
dip a cloth in it, and apply it hot, and role it and keep it warm. Hickit,
eat every morning a race of green Ginger, and drink ii. draughts of malmsey
iii. hours before meat. 10 Chollike and stitch, drink powder of Bays and
Ginger, and use it also in meats. 11 Face salsflegme, anoint with powder of
Ginger and pepper, and ye juice of pimpernell. 12 Appetite to cause, seethe
powder of Ginger, Cummin, and Licoras of each one peniworth in honey, till it be
thick, and mix a little geine Treacle with it, and eat thereof first and
last. 13 Sees it with Figs in wine, and drink it to help the cold and the
cough, or eat ye powder in Figs. 14 Use the powder in meat to withstand
swooning, for rawnesses in the stomach, and to loosen the belly, and cause
digestion. 15 Take ii. drams, and as much sugar with warm water to purge viscus
humors. 16 Green Ginger provoke lust, digesteth meat, warmeth the stomach,
and dries up the moisture that comes by eating of fruit. It is good for the
phlegm of the lungs, the old cough, shortness of breath, and all cold
griefs: it opens obstructions, helps digestion and appetite, and expels
gross humors and wind. 17 Ringwormes, anoint them with black soap, and
almost as much Ginger iiii. or v. days, it helps tetters also in like sort.
Mix i. penny weight with thrice so much sugar, and put thereof into the eyes to
consume ye white phlegm that grows over the eye in short time. 18 Take Ginger
ii. ounces, sugar viii. ounces, Cinamom half an ounce, use it as blaunch
powder with roasted wardens, apples, quinces, hensawes, and such like. 19
Stomach griefs, and to help digestion, use green Ginger before meats. 20
Eyes pearl, mix fine powder of Ginger and pepper with the gall of an Eele and
fine honey, and use it to kill it. 21 To drive down the Emerods, drink powder
of Ginger, long pepper and grains, of each like much to bedward warm: proved.
22 Face salsflegme, grind powder of Ginger and brimstone with honey, and the
juice of red nettles and anoint therewith. 23 Flowers stopped, boil a pottell of
the best wine with a good raze of Ginger, and a few maces and grains in
powder with butter and drink thereof often. 24 Teeth-ache, sees powder of
pepper and Ginger in ale, and put it into a cloute dipped in aqua vitae, and
apply it.

griefs 16. 13 Cough 3. 13. 16 Breath short 16 Digestion 16. 17. 19 Eyes dull

Gooseberies.
GOoseberies unripe, stop the belly and all issues of blood, especially the
juice of them pressed out and dried. 2 The juice of green Gooseberies is very
good for all hot inflammations, shingles, and wild fire, and so be the leaves,
but not so good as the juice. 3 The berries eaten with meats, provoke appetite,
and cool the heat of the stomach and liver, and are good against hot agues.
4 The young leaves eaten raw, provoke urine, and are good for the grauel and
stone. 5 They are good in sawses before they be ripe, with flesh and fish for
them that be chollericke, hot and sick.

Appetite 3 Bloody flux 1 Fluxes 1 Fevers hot 3 Gravel 4 Hot griefs 5
Inflammations 2 Liver hot 3 Shingles 2 Stomach hot 3 Stone 4 Urine stopped 4
Wild fire 2
Read Gooseberries.
Read Gooseberies, or ribes do refresh and cool the hot stomach, and
liver, and are good against all inflammations, and heat of the blood and hot
agues. 2 Chew them and hold them in the mouth for all hot humors and
inflammations, and to cool thirst in agues. 3 It stops the chollericke
laske, and the bloody flixe, especially the rob or dried juice thereof. 4 The
rob made of the juice of common ribes with sugar, is very good for all the
diseases aforesaid, it stops vomitings, and is good for hot agues, being
drunk with a little cold water, or holden in the mouth against thirst. 5 They
may be kept either in their own juice, or in vergis, or dried in the sun. 6
They have in all points the virtues of barbaries. 7 They take away all inward
heates.

Bloody flux 3. 4 Fevers hot 4 Fluxes 3. 4 Heat inward 1 Liver hot 1. 4
Mouth heat 2 Stomach hot 1. 4 Thirst 1. 2. 4 Vomiting 4
Goosefoot.
GOosefoot is in nature much like to morell or nightshade, and in outward
causes may be used for it. 2 It kills swine if they eat it, and is very
dangerous as Solanum is. See Morell, Nightshade, Petymorell.

Gooseheirife.
GOoseheirif or Cleuer, drink the juice of the leaves and seeds against
venomous bitings. 2 Ears ache, drop in the juice. Wounds bleeding, stamp it
and apply it. 3 Kings evil, and all kernels and wennes in any place: stamp it
with swines grease, and apply it, and so it helps swollen paps of curded milk.
4 Iaundies, sees it in wine and drink it. 5 Sores or scabs in any place,
bruise it and lay it in spring water four and twenty hours, and then wash
therewith. 6 Cough and phlegm in the stomach, sees a handful in a quart of
ale with a little pared licoras, and some currants to the one half, then
streine it, and drink it first and last, at morn and even. 7 Dropsy, mix
the juice of it and walwort ana six handful, and drink it ten days, and
bathe thee every day with the same herbs, till the water come out at the
soles of thy feet, then bathe no more, but continue the use of the said drink
ten days out. 8 Worms in the flesh, drink the juice of it and of tansie.

Bitings venomous 1 Bleeding 2 Breasts swollen 3 Coughs 6 Dropsy 7 Ears ache 2
Iaundies 4 Kernels 3 Kings evil 3 Scabbes 5 Sores 5 Wennes 3 Worms 7 Wounds 3
Goosetansie.
GOosetansie, face pimples, wash it with water of it and of roses. 2 Fluxes,
kneade wheat cakes with the juice of it, and yolks of eggs, and bake them and
eat them. 3 Liver to restore, seethe it with new woort, and streine it and
drink it with white wine or ale: proved, or sees it with liuerwort and
ribwort in strong wort, and streine it, and put in sugar, and sometimes drink
thereof, and sometimes set a barme on it, and drink thereof first and last
thirty days, (see Dasie for hands.) 4 Liver hot, and face deformed, distill
it with a quarte of strawberries, and three pintes of new milk, and drink
thereof morn and even, and wash thy face therewith. 5 Seethe it in water or
wine, and drink it to stop the bloody flux, and al other fluxes of blood,
and the whites and terms. Boil it in water and salt, and drink it to
dissolve bruised and congealed blood. 6 The decoction of it cures ulcers, and
sores of the mouth, and the hot humors that fall into the eyes, and stripes
that perish the sight, being washed therewith. 7 It has many other virtues, as
against the stone, inward wounds, and corrupt fretting ulcers of the gummes,
and secret parts: it strengthens the bowels, it closes up green wounds, it
fastneth loose teeth, and helps the toothach. 8 The distilled water is good
for the freckels, spots, pimples, and sun burning of the face, the ach,
fluxes, redness, and spots of the eyes, and to cleanse the skin, and make it
white. 9 Steep it in white wine, and wash therewith to make the skin white.

Bloody flux 5 Bruises 5. 6 Eyes griefs 6. 7. 8 Face deformed 1. 4. 8
Flowers to stop 5 Fluxes 2. 5 Freckles 8 Liver hot 4 wasting 3
Mouth sores 7 Priuities sores 7 Skin to cleanse 8 Stone 7 Teethach 7 loose 7
Ulcers 6 Whites 5 Wounds 7
Goulds.
GOulds, or wild Marigolds growing in corn. 2 Boil it in wine to cure the
Iaundies, and to restore good color, and drink it after long and often
bathing. 3 The seed drunk in wine by it self, or stamped with the flowers,
does also cure the iaundies. 4 Stamp the flowers with oil and wax to
dissolve cold swellings of the head. 5 The leaves and tender branches may well
be used in pottage and sallades.

Color bad 2 Head swellings 4 Iaundies 2. 3 Swellings 4
Gourds.
GOurds: Deliverance to cause, tie the root to her reins, but take it away
speedily, least the matrix follow. 2 Anoint any cattle with the juice in
summer, and hot weather, and no flies will touch them. 3 Face read, make an
oil of two ounces of the seeds, and four ounces of peach kernels, and anoint
therewith morn and even. 4 Stamp the leaves and rub horses with them, and no
flies will touch them, or rub them with lees of wine at morn and noone. 5
Dissolve a dram of the leaves in good wine, and drink it as often as need is
for ye prefocation of the mother. 6 Sores moist to heal, put the powder of the
rind. 7 Headache, frenzy, and want of sleep, dip a cloth in the juice of
Gourds, and purslan with vinegar, and apply it. 8 Pissing blood, drink powder
of the seeds of Gourds, cummin, and mallows, of each four penie weight, with
two ounces of milk, and use to eat good store of milk. 9 Liver chafed,
scrape off the uttermost of a Gourde, and steep the same scrapings in vinegar
and apply it. 10 Apply the juice to a bare place, to withstand the growing of
hair. 11 Ashes of dry Gourds does quickly heal rotten ulcers of the yard.
12 Gourdes are not eaten raw, but sodden, roasted, or fried. 13 The seeds
clean picked from their uppermost skins, and sodden in barley water, and
streined and drunk, helps the griefs of the liver, kidneyes and bladder,
the impostumes of the breast, and provoke urine. But if the patient cannot
drink of this water, then make it into a syrrop with sugar, and so it is good
also for all agues. 14 Mix the meat of gourds, or rather the juice with milk
and vinegar, and apply it to the liver for the heat thereof, with a cloth dipped
therein. 15 Gourds ought to be hanged up and dried, and when winter comes,
the seeds must be taken out, and rubbed with salt, that so the clammie humor
may be avoided, and then they are to be laid up in a dry place, and so they
may be kept three years. 16 Apply the meat of the gourds to the forehead of
young children to avoid the great heat and inflammation of the head and
brain. 17 Anoint burning goutes, and the inflammation of the eyes, with the
juice of Gourdes, and drop thereof into the ears for the burning heat in
them, either by it self, or with oil of roses hot, the same is good to
anoint the ridge bone, to assuage the burning heat of agues, and for the holy
fire, being anointed. 18 The ashes of the rindes cast on the ulcers of the
privy parts, now grown to a rottenness, does cleanse and heal them, and
so it does burnings and scaldings. 19 The decoction of the meat with a little
honey and niter drunk, looseneth the belly gently. 20 Distill the meat and
seeds of ripe Gourds, and drink four ounces of the water twenty or forty
days to help the stone in the kidneis: and drink it ten days to cleanse the
reins and bladder. 21 Apply the meat of them shreaded small to hard
swellings. 22 The water drunk, provoke urine, and qualifieth the heat of
the ague: boil the meat and seeds, and slice them and boil it with onions,
butter, and salt, and so it is good for them that be lean. 23 If a gourde be
made hollow, and filled all night with good wine, and drunk in the morning,
it purges the belly or body. 24 The juice or distilled water of the meat of
unripe Gourdes drunk, quenches heat of burning fevers, the same being also
applied to the heart and liver. It helps also ache of the ears, and of the
eyes, and al other parts, and the hot gout. 25 Bruise the meat and apply it
to swellings and apostumes. 26 Drink the juice of the whole herb boiled with a
little honey and saltpeter, to loosen the belly gently. 27 Gourdes, drive away
Venus, and engender thin blood. 28 The juice of the tender branches drunk
with sweet wine and a little vinegar, cures the bloody flux. 29 The seeds of
Gourds is almost of like virtue with the seeds of Cucumbers.

Grains.
Grains, see Cardamom: flowers to cause, drink one nutmeg, as much Grains,
and as much saffron in powder, with half a pint of drink, warm. 2 Emerodes
to drive down, and for the shaking fever, drink powder of grains, long
pepper and ginger. 3 Impostume in the breast, bake water cresses, sage, and
auence a handful, grains one ounce, clarified honey one pint in paste, and
when it is well baked, it is sovereign for aching. 4 Mother suffocat. take up
the fume of Grains, cloves, frankincense, and other sweet things laid on a
fire of charcoale into the matrix: proved.

Breast impostume 3 Emerodes 2 Flowers stopped 1 Impostume 3 Mother suffocat. 4
Grass.
Grass, Seethe it to help the griefs of the milte. See Hay.

Gratiola.
GRatiola, or gratia Dei, boil it and drink it, or eat it in any kind of
meat to open the belly freely, and to purge gross phlegm and choler. 2
Wounds to heal speedily, straw on the powder of it, or use it in oils or
ointments. 3 Two scruples will purge a meetly strong body. 4 Wounds to heal,
bruise the herb and apply it.

Purgation 1. 3 Wounds 2. 4
Gromel.
GRomel, Vrin stopped, stamp it with parsley, and strain it, and drink it with
white wine. 2 It is good for the stone and all griefs of the bladder. 3 Urine
stopped, stamp it with parsley and rue, and drink it with white wine, and be
whole. 4 Eat tostes of bread, or sops in wine with powder of the seeds of
Gromel, and parsley to void the stone after it is broken. 5 Urine stopped,
seethe mallows, and a good quantity of Gromell in vinegar a good while, and
drink thereof warm. 6 Stamp the seeds and drink them in white wine to break
the stone, especially in the bladder, and to drive forth urine. 7 Bruise the
seeds and steep them all night in white wine, with some fenell, parsley, and
seen, and in the morning sees it, and streine it and sugar it, and drink it
to purge phlegm and choler, to open and cleanse the reins and bladder, and to
expel wind plentifully: it must be boiled in a stone vessel. 8 Stamp the
herb and apply it hot for the same purpose.

Back grief 7 Bladder griefs 2. 7 Purgation 7 Stone 2. 4. 6. 7. 8 Urine
stopped 1. 3. etc.
Groundswell.
GRoundswell: Brestssore, stamp a great handful, and drink it with white
wine, or stale ale morn and even 15. days, and keep thee from men and
queasie meats. 2 Fever, stamp four handful with vinegar and bay salt ana
three spoonfuls, and seethe it til it be almost dry, and apply it to thy
wrists as hot as may be suffered. 3 Breast to cleanse, stamp white horehound
four ounces, Grounswel three ounces, walwort ii. ounces, and sees them with
fresh barows grease, and apply it to thy breast, and in one night thou shall
avoid much phlegm and corruption. 4 Wound to heal, stamp it with some
wormwood, and old swines grease, and apply it, and so it heals pushes and
whelks. 5 Boil the leaves and stalks in water or sweet wine, and drink it to
heal the ach of the stomach, coming of choler. 6 Stamp the leaves and
flowers alone, or with a little wine, and apply it to the burning heat, and
inflammation of the stones and fundament. 7 Mix it with fine powder of
Frankincense, and apply it to heal all wounds, especially of the sinews. 8
Eyes bleared and dropping, apply the down of the flowers with saffron and
water. 9 Apply it with a little salt to waste and consume the kings evil, or
struma in the throat or neck. 10 The small Groundswel is good in sallads with
oil and vinegar. 11 Stamp Groundswel and seethe it in water and drink it with
pottage to purge hot choler. 12 The heads with the flowers tempred with a
little wine and Manna heals the wounds of sinews. 13 Saint James wort is of
the same nature. 14 The whole stalk sodden in water and drunk with Malmesey,
heals the choleric ach of the stomach.

Breast to cleanse 3 Breasts sore 1 Eyes griefs 8 Fevers 2 Fundament inflam. 6
Head scald, (See before) 1 Inflammations 6 Kernels 9 Kings evil 9 Priuities
sores 6 Purgation 3. 5. 11. 12. 14 Pushes 4 Sallades 10 Sinews cut 7. 12 Sores
4 Stomach ache 5 Stones heat 6 Wennes 9 Whelkes 4 Wounds 4. 7
Guiacum.
GViacum or Lignum Sanctum: It dries up makes fine and subtle, it melts or
resolves, skowreth away and provoke sweat, and withstandeth putrefaction. 2
Use the broth thereof for the French pockes, for the Gout that is not deeply
rooted, the griefs of the Liver and Milt. 3 Dropsy, seethe it in wine and use
it. 4 Use the broth for the Iaundies and many other griefs that be hard to be
cured. 5 It is very good to be sodden in Renish wine. 6 And the powder of it
sodden in Beer wort, is drinkeable enough: but whether it be sodden in water
or wine, or Beer wort or Ale wort, such herbs must be sodden with it as do
respect the disease that it is taken for. 7 For the Gout, Dropsy, Sciatica and
Timpany, it is comparable with the best medicines, and likewise for the Ranker.
8 The sap is not so good as the heart. It helps the extreme pains of the
Joints, senowes and veins, muskles, veins, senowes, head and feet, and
bones, and no disease is so sharp and cruel to nature, but this precious wood
will heal it both speedily and gently, and swage the pain: The french Pocks,
the Gout, the Dropsy, the Strangury, Pissing blood, the stopping of the urine,
Oppilations, Headache, Vertigo or giddiness: Fevers, Shyngles, horrible
Apostumations and swellings of the belly: but strait diet is not to be allowed.
9 For the Rume and gross humors, fill a diet pot with Cunduit water al saving
a quart, which must be white wine, Lycoras scraped and cut small, one pound,
Lignum vite half a pound, the bark of it one ounce, boil them one hour and
an half, then streine it and keep it in a close vessel, and drink thereof
first and last, the best is from saint John's Island: for hot griefs, use the
more water, and less wood: for cold griefs, more wood and less water. It
cures the Pocks and almost all other griefs: it must be sodden in a close
vessel set in seething water x. hours. 10 Diet, use meats competently to
suffice nature, as Mutton, Veale and Hens sodden in a double vessel, and
seasoned with salt and brought to a pleasant taste: but use no excess drink,
as much as is needful for the disease, always warm: but if thou be saint,
use therewith some Renish or small white wine, as much as of the drink mixed
together: but drink no Beer till thou be whole. Take the drink by five a
clock, and cover thee well. Drink eight ounces at once, and sweat two
hours, or more or less as strength may bear, and dry up the sweat with
warm clothes, after put on thy clothes warm, and sit by a good fire or walk
in thy Chamber till eight a clock, then go to Dynner: first sup a little of
the broth with a little bread, then eat competently of the flesh, and after
walk, or use some recreation of mind and body, and suppe at four of the
clock, and go to bed at seven, and drink eight ounces, and sweat. 11 For all
griefs of the joints, knots, tumors, etc. Receive Lignum vite well prepared
one pound and an half, Lycoras and Polipody ana one ounce, Seen, Aniseede and
Fenell seed ana half an ounce, water twelve pound: steep the wood in the
water twelve hours, then seethe it with the rest in an earthen vessel and scum
it as long as long as the scumme will rise, and save the scumme to anoint
withal, and take the water every morning or every other morning, and cover
thee well to sweat two hours, and continue it three or four weeks. 12 For
the salt humor, sees half a pound of the wood and the bark thereof with
Lycoras and Aniseedes, and half a pound of clear Honey with cold herbs, as
Liuer-wort, Harts-tong, and two ounces of french Barley, and half a pound of
Reasins of the sun, the stones taken out, seethe them well and use it.

Ach general 8 Apostumes 8 Belly swollen 8 Cold griefs 9 Diet 10 Dropsy 7. 8
Fevers 8 French Pocks 2. 8 Giddiness 8 Gout 27 Hot griefs 9 Humors gross 9
Joints ach 11. 8 Kanker 7 Knots 11 Liver griefs 2 Mylt griefs 2 Pissing blood
8 Rume 9. 12 Sciatica 7 Senowes ach 8 Shyngles 8 Salt humor 12 Sickness
general 8 Stone 8 Strangury 8 Swellings 11 Tympany 7 Urine stopped 8
Haresfoote.
HAres foot, Seethe it in wine and drink it to stop the laske and bloody
flux: but in an Ague, use it with water. 2 Apply it to the inflammations and
heat of the Share.

Bloody flux 1 Fluxes 1 Inflammations 2
Hearts ease.
Hearts ease or Pances, seethe the flowers and drink it, to cure and stay the
beginning of the falling sickness in children that foam at the mouth. 2 Sees
the flowers and plant together, and drink it to cleanse the Lungs and the
breast for fevers and inward inflammations. 3 Use the herb inward and outward,
or the powder thereof for all wounds and ruptures, especially with red wine. 4
Drink the water of it for the torments of the belly of children, and for
inflammations, and to cleanse the Lungs and Chest: or sees it in wine and
drink it. 5 The herb is good for the Squincie of Swine. 6 It is good for all
wounded men, women and children, and for all them which have broken bones. 7
Outwardly it cleanses the skin from all Itch, Skab, shingles, ring-wormes,
ulcers, etc. 8 It heals green wounds without danger of any Apostumation. 9
Used in Plasters or the juice preserved with oil, for herbs being streined,
and the juice clarified on the fire, and cooled and kept in a clean glass and
a little oil Olive powered on it, it may safely be preserved till time of use
for Syrops and Salues. 10 Use it with other medicines for the green sickness.

Belly ach 4 Bones broken 6 Breast to cleanse 2. 4 Bursten 3 Falling evil 1
Green sickness 10 Fevers 2 Hogs squincy 5 Inflammations 4 Itch 7 Lungs to
cleanse 4 Ryngwormes 7 Skabs 7 Skin deformd 7 Shingles 7 Sores 7 Wounds 3. 6. 7
Hartshorne Planten.
HArtshorne Planten, Stamp three pound, and mix it with common oil and let
it stand nine days, then put to it one pint of water, and boil it till the
water be consumed, so that the oil be green, then streine it and use it for
the Gout and all aches. 2 It has the virtues of planten, and is singular good
against pissing of blood, the gravel and stone: it helps the Flixe, and is
good in sallads: it does cleanse and comfort the stomach, and heals burnings.

Aches 1 Fluxes 2 Gowt 1 Gravel 2 Pissing blood 2 Sallads 2 stone 2
Hartstong.
HArtstong, Seethe the leaves in wine, and drink against biting of Serpents:
it stops the Laske and bloody Flixe: it is good for the Milt that is too
loose, or too much opened. 2 Power it into the mouth of the cattle that are
bitten with Serpents. 3 The water comfort the heart, and voydeth the Hycket.
4 The same is good against Dygs of the mouth being gargarised. 5 Apply it with
Hempe-hurds to the heat of the Liver and stomach. 6 Use it to malignant
ulcers, sores and wounds. 7 It stops all fluxes both in man and beast: it
must be gotten early or late, when neither the sun nor Moon do shine on
it: it is of nature much like to Cetrache. 8 Kings evil, seethe it in wine and
drink it. 9 Stone and Strangury, bind it fast together, and seethe it in a
mess of sweet Milk, and make a possit thereof, and drink the ale warm, or
sees it in three parts of water till two parts be wasted, then streine it and
drink one part thereof with two parts of good white wine to expel the stone
and gravel. 10 Iaundies and griefs of the Liver and Milt, seethe it in water
or wine and drink it, or eat the herb. Heart griefs, drink powder of it,
and of a Hearts horn, Maces, Nutmegs, Cloves and Saffron, and Sugar, and use
them in broths. 11 Milt griefs, make powder of it, and of the Lungs of a Fox,
Maces and Sugar candy, and drink thereof with wine or ale proved. 12 Or make
powder of it and quickebeam of each like much dried in an Oven, and put thereto
as much powder of large Maces, some red Saunders, and a little Saffron, and as
much Sugar Candy as will make it sweet, and eat thereof, the oftener the
better. 13 Liver griefs, sees it with Fumiterre and Liuerwort, of each one
handful in clarified Wheye, and drink thereof first and last, especially in
May, with a little Rubarbe or Chamepiteos. 14 To dry up and diminish the Milt,
drink it with wine thirty days. 15 Milt stopped, drink powder of the root
with wine at the wane of the Moon. 16 Iaundies, drink one dram and an half
of the powder of it with white wine twenty mornings. 17 Seethe it in oil of
Roses, and apply it to Apostumes to break them. 18 Coughs, drink it with wine
or Ale.

Apostumes 17 Bitings venem. 1. 2 Bloody flixe 1 Cattle venem. 2 Coughs 18
Fluxes 1. 7 Heart griefs 3. 10 hot 5
Hycket 3 Iaundies 10. 16 Kings evil 8 Liver griefs 10. 13 hot 5
Milt griefs 1. 10. 11. 12. 14. 15. Mouth griefs 4 Stone 9 Strangury 9
Hasell.
HAsell Nuts and Filbeards nourish very little, and are hard of digestion, they
engender wind in the stomach, and cause headache if they be eaten too much. 2
Cough old, drink them with honied water. 3 Roste them and eat them with a
little Pepper to ripen the Rume and Catharre. 4 Burn them and apply them with
Hogs grease or Bores grease, to heal the skurfe and skales of the head, and to
restore hair. 5 The skales or husks are good for the Squincy, even as the
husks of Wall-Nuts. 6 Sees the inward rynde of green Hasell branches in
small ale to the one half, and drink thereof a good draught first and last
eight or ten days to have sure remedy for the Strangury. 7 Burn the seeds
that hang on the tree, and blow the powder of it into the Nose to stop
bleeding of it. 8 The utter rynde of Nuts makes ye hair black being stamped
with vinegar. 9 Sees Nut leaves in water, and wash ye head or beard therewith
where hair falls away. 10 Hasell Nuts cause ye Cough, therefore they are
best to be eaten with Reasins: they may be eaten after fish, in stead of Cheese.
11 Take two ounces of the powder of the Shales with tart wine, to stop the
Flux and the Whites. 12 Stamp Nut kernels with Honey and Hysope water, to
help the Cough. 13 Stamp them with Dittanie and black soap, to draw pricks
out of the flesh. 14 The shales burned and applied to the hinder part of a
childs head, cause the gray eyes to become black. 15 Flowers to stop, Drink
one dram of the powder of the skins that cover the Kernels. 16 The Kernels
ground with the grease of a Hog or Bore, restores hair, being anointed
therewith: or dry Nuts with their Shells on a Harth, and make them into powder,
and mix it with old Lard of a swine unsalted, and anoint therewith, to have
present help. 17 Flux to stop, dry the flowers in an Oven, and drink the
powder with wine. 18 Flux to stop, stamp the kernels with as much Elecampana,
and sees them to an Electuarie, and use it. 19 Venom of all sorts, Apply a
Plaster of Nuts, Rue, and Figs. 20 To knit broken bones in five or six days,
drink powder of the Catstaile of the tree, and of red Docke seeds. 21 Head
pose, Eat the kernels roasted, with powder of Pepper. 22 Lay Hasell of three
years shoot in the fire, and gather the sap, and drop it on a new ground Axe,
and touch the Web in the eye therewith to break it, and then anoint the eye
with healing salues. 23 Hair to be black, Mix the shales or utter rindes,
with the juice of Sloes and ynke with Vinegar and apply it. 2 Hair falling,
Seethe the leaves in water, and wash head and beard therewith. 25 Ears worms,
Drop in the juice of the Husks. 26 Cough and horcenesse, Roste Nuts and eat
them with Honey. 27 Reins and Bladder pain, stamp Filbeards and drink them
with water or wine. 28 Urine distilling, Use roasted Filbeards. 29 Fever
quotitian, Sees the middle bark in water, and drink it with nine grains of
the less Spurge, or Peony. 30 The rynde and leaves of a Nut tree drunk in
Vinegar takes away the rigor of the fever quarten. 31 Apostume flegmatike or
melancholy, to break it, Stamp Nuts with Rue and Honey, and apply it. 32
Burnings, anoint with oil of Nuts and Wax. 33 Ears oul, Use the juice or sap
with other medicines, especially with the grease of an Eele, or with Honey. 34
Nose bleeding, Burn Hasell sticks, and blow in the ashes or powder thereof. 35
Pricks, stamp the kernels with fresh Butter and apply them. 36 Hair to grow
where none is, Burn ye Nuts and husks with Beech-mast and the leaves of
Elecampana, and mix the ashes with Honey, and sees it, and anoint therewith.
37 Nose bleeding, Burn the taklings and blow in ye ashes. 38 Stamp the
kernels with May Butter and Pigeons dung, and apply it to Apostumes to break
them, and avoid the pain in the back. 39 Fill a pan full of the flowers,
sees them xxiiii. hours, and put wine to them that they burn not nor dry
not, and streine it, and drink thereof in February five days to become Lean.
40 Mix the ashes of the Nut and husks with old swines grease and anoint, to
cause the hair to grow. 41 Mix ye ashes of ye shells with powder of Senuie and
Goose grease, and anoint a leprous face therewith to heal it. 42 Mix powder
of the takling, two drams with an Egg roasted with oil, till it be hard, and
take it four or five mornings fasting, to help the bloody flux: if that
serve not, take iiii. drams with an Egg. 43 Apply the Moss of the tree, the
older kept the better, to stop blood.

Apostume to break 31. 38 Back grief 27. 38 Blood to stop 7. 43. (See Nose
bleeding. Bladder grief 27 Bloody flux 42 Bones to knit 20 Burnings 32

black 14
Face leprous 41 Fever quotid. 29 quarten 30
