distilling 28 Whites 11
Hauergrasse.
HAuergrasse which is like Otes, Sees the herb and root in water, till the
third part be wasted, then streine it and boil it again with honey til it wax
thick, and so it takes away the smell of the stinking sores of the Nose being
put in with a Tent, especially with some Aloes put to it. 2 Sees it in wine
with dried Roses, and wash the mouth therewith to amend ye corrupt smell of it.

Breath ill 1. 2 Mouth stink 2 Nose stink 1
Hawthorne.
HAwthorne, Stamp the Bark with red wine, and frye it with Bores grease and
apply it hot to draw out a prick. 2 The white Thorn is never stricken with
lightning. 3 Use the leaves with white wine to expel the stone. 4 The Hawes
stop the Laske and the Flowers, and are good against the gravel and stone,
especially with white wine.

Gravel 4 Prick 1 Stone 2. 4
Heath hather
HEath hather or Linge, Eyes ach red and dull, drop in the juice of the
leaves. 2 Bitings Venomous, apply the flowers and leaves. 3 Stone in the
Bladdar, sees it in fair water, and drink five ounces warm morn and even
three hours before meat thirty days, and at the last, enter into a bath of
the decoction thereof, and sit upon the Heath in the bath. 4 The bark of it
may be used for the bark of Tamariske. 5 The water of the flowers is good for
the Chollicke and Headache, and the pain and redness of the Eyes. 6 Stingings
of venomous things, and the swelling of the same, stamp the flowers with the
tender springs, and apply them. 7 It is good in Foments and sweating bathes,
namely the flowers of it, for the Gout, Palsy, and griefs of the joints.

Ache 7 Biting venom. 2. 6 Chollike 5 Eyes griefs 1. 5 Gout 7 Headache 5
Palsy 7 Stone 3 Swellings 6
Heye.
HEye: leapry, hold a piece of iron over the reeke of Heye, and anoint with
the liquour that is on the iron, all itche, skab, and marmoles.

Itche Marmoles Skab
Hemlocke.
HEmlocke: apply it to the stones of young children, or breasts of young maidens,
to cause them to continue small, but then they will be weak and sickly all
their life time. 2 Apply it to hot apostumes, inflammations, and wild fire,
to swage the pain and heat, as Henbane and Opium does. 3 Leg swollen, heat it
between two tiles and apply. 4 Birds to catch, steep such seeds as they live
by in the juice, or in wine lees, and sprinckle it where they haunt, and by
eating thereof they will become giddy, and then they may be taken. 5 Quench
hot iron iii. or iiii. times in the juice till it be cold, and it will become
soft. 6 Apply it to women's breasts after they be delivered to waste away the
milk. 7 The juice may be gathered and dried in the sun, and kept to use. It
must be taken out of the tops and leaves before they seed, the same is good in
eye medicines, S. Antonies fire, all hot griefs, and the things aforesaid,
and for running sores that spread abroad. 8 Lust to void, apply the leaves to
the stones. 9 They are not to be used inward, but the herb, juice, or water
applied somewhat warm, it helps all inflammations and swellings that cannot
otherwise be helped: it takes away heat and ache of the head, or any other
part, the shingles, holy fire, ringwormes, tetters, it cease all ache,
procures sleep, and helps all hot griefs. 10 The juice is strong poison,
but if any have drunk it, let him drink plenty of hot and sweet wine. 11
Headache, sees them soft, and apply them hot all night morn and even iiii.
or v. times. 12 Sees it in wine, and drink it to help the falling sickness.
13 Stamp the leaves, and dry them, and make it into a plaster to heal all
ruptures and chappings within ix or x. days. 14 Legs swollen with a fall or
bruise, heat it between ii. tiles and apply it. 15 Gout, sees old piss, and
clarify it, and sees it therein and apply it, or sees it in wine and apply
it. 16 Breasts not to be great, grind the seeds with vinegar, and anoint them
often. 17 Lust to abate, stamp it, and apply it to the pecten: matrix
swelling, and coming out, stamp it and apply it. 18 Gout hot, apply the
juice with swines grease, it helps great swellings. Falling evil, apply it to
the soles of the feet, to draw down the humors. 19 Swellings, wash with
water of it.

Aches 2 Birds to catch 4 Breast to be small 1. 6. 16 Bruise 14 Bursten 13
Chaps 13 Chaste to be 1 Gout 15. 18 Falling evil 12. 18 Headache 9. 11 Holy
fire 9 Hot griefs 2. 7 Inflammations 2. 9 Iron to be soft 5 Leg swollen 3. 14
Lust to void 8. 17 Matrix falling 17 swelling 17 Ringwormes 9 S. Antonies fire
7 Sleep to cause 9 Sores 7 Swellings 3. 9. 19 Tetters 9
Hemp.
Hemp: the seed expels windiness. 2 If a man take a little too much of it,
it dries up natural seed, and the milk of women. 3 Iaundies, and stopping
of the liver, stamp ye seed, and drink it with wine. 4 Ear pain, and
vermin therein, put in the juice of the green leaves. 5 Gout and shrinking
of sinowes, sees the root in water, and apply it. 6 Hens to lay apace, give
them the seeds. 7 Gnats to void, lay the moist branches by thee. 8 Belly
bound, stamp the seeds, and sees them in running water and streine it and
drink a good draught when thou go to bed. 9 Oil to make, stamp the seed,
and sprinckle it with a little wine, and heat it in a new earthen pan well
glased, and when thou can not suffer thy hand any longer in it, press out
the oil through a square bag, and drink one ounce of it, to make thee merry,
fierce, and hardy to fight, and comely to see to: and in like sort thou may
draw oil out of all seeds. 10 Cough dry, seed the seeds in milk, and use
it. Give a horse as much seed to eat as thou may take up with both thy
hands to cause him presently to piss and void the chollike and stone, but he
must not drink of ii. hours after. 11 Fever quarten, take the juice of Hemp
before the fit, (see Fenigreeke.) Sinowes shrunk, seethe the roots in wine,
and apply them. 12 Ears noise, purge with pills Hiera picra, and put in oil
of Hempe-seede warm with a little vinegar, but if it come of great heat, then
with woman's milk, and leap on the foot on the same side often, and provoke
sneesing. 13 Breast suppuration and mattering, seethe Hemp-seede in water, and
use the milk thereof. 14 Stamp ye seed and streine it with water, and put to
it two rear roasted Eggs, and take it fasting to stop the bloody flux. 15 Ears
worms, put in the clear juice of the leaves and seeds. 16 Appetite to cause,
steep ye seeds in ale one night, then rub them between your hands till ye
husks be off, and wash them clean, and stamp them, and make it like an
Almond caudell and use it often. 17 Canker or fester, burn Hemp-seede and Rye
meal, and mix the powder with ye juice of Smallage and honey, and dip tents of
linen therein and put it in. 18 Sees ye seeds in Goats milk to ye third
part, and drink it iii. days to avoid al inward poiso^.

Appetite to cause 16 Blooddy flux 14 Belly bound 8 Breast griefs 13 Cough
dry 10 Ear pain and vermin 4. 12 15 noise 12 Fester 17 Fever quarten 11
Gnats to void 7 Gout 5 Hens to lay 6 Horse sick 10 Iaundies 3 Kanker 17
Liver stopped 3 Milk to abate 2 Mirth to cause 9 Oil to make 9 Sinowes shrunk
5. 11 Seed to abate 2 Strong to be 9 Urine stopped 10 Windiness 1
Henbane.
HEnbane: Emerods, stamp the leaves of it and Purslen with oil of Roses,
crumbs of bread, and the yolke of a hard egg, and apply it to have speedy
help. 2 Teeth worms, take up the fume of the seeds tempered with wax and
laid on coals. 3 Anoint thy temples with the juice, and thou shall see
meruailes in thy sleep. 4 Teeth-ach, sees the root in vinegar and Rose
water, and hold thereof in thy mouth, or sees them in white wine, and hold the
wine in thy mouth hot a good while. 5 Worms in hands or feet, set a red hot
tyle in a vessel of water, and lay Henbane seed on it, and hold the hands or
feet over the vapor of it. 6 Cods apostumed, apply meal of Beans and Barley
with Henbane leaves, and oil of Roses. 7 Stamp the seeds with lyme, and
apply it to sores that rot at the bone. 8 Teeth-ache, heat the root well, and
apply it to the root of the tooth, or burn the juice with Leekeseede, and
receive up the fume of it. 9 Poisoned, drink one dram of Symphonia, with a
woman's urine. 10 Teeth-ache, take up the fume of the seeds with Leekeseedes
and Frankincense. 11 Apostume to break in one day and a night, apply Henbane
leaves. 12 Frenzy, apply a plaster of the leaves or seeds luke warm to the
forehead, and if he sleep, he shall mend, or else die. Or seethe it in
sweet wine, and bathe the forehead therewith, and the temples, ears, and
nostrels. 13 Teethe ache, stamp it and apply it. 14 Tooth to fall out, touch
it with the powder of the root. 15 Oil of Henbane, fry the seeds with oil
and press it out, it helps all swellings and burnings. 16 Teeth-ache, make a
candle of the seeds with wax and Pimpernell, and hold thy mouth over it as
it burns, or seethe the root in Oximell, and apply it, or sees the seeds
of it and leaves, and take up the fume. 17 Worms called Digs, lay a hot
tylestone over a vessel of water, and lay thereon Henbane seed, and hold thy
feet over it, and they will come out. 18 Sleep to cause, Sees Henbane in
water or wine, and wash thy temples, pulses, hands and feet therewith. 19 Yard
apostumed, apply a plaster of Henbane and Gilts grease. 20 Teeth-ache, heat
the root of black Henbane well, and apply it to the tooth and the root
thereof, and it will fall out. 21 Lust to void, anoint thy yard with the
juice. 22 Cods ache and swelling, stamp the leaves and seeds, and apply them.
23 Breasts pain and kernels, stamp the seeds with wine, and apply it. 24
Gout pain, anoint with the oil of Henbane, or boil the juice with hogs
grease, and put wax to it, and anoint therewith, or seethe the herb in wine,
and apply it. 25 Scabs, pockes, and Leapry, take up the fume of the seed to
the grieved part. 26 Henbane is good for the gout coming of melancholy. 27
The seeds mixed with ye seeds of Hemlocke, and a candle made thereof, and
burnt on a stone, with the smoke thereof, slays worms in the teeth. 28 The
juice is good for all wounds. 29 It is good for the cough, hot apostumes and
the gout. 30 The seeds should be gathered in August. 31 To avoid ye ache of
the gout by and by, stamp the seeds with oil olive, and let it stand so
xxiiii. hours, then fry it and streine it, and apply it. 32 The juice is
drawn forth of the leaves and stalks, and dried in the sun, it is good for
collyries for the eyes, for the heat, reume and pain, and the like in the
ears and matrix. 33 The same laid to with meal of wheat or parched barley,
is most profitable against all hot swellings of the eyes, feet, and other
parts of the body. 34 The seed is good for the cough, falling down of reume
and humors into the eyes, or upon the breast, against pain, the inordinate
flux of the terms, and all other issues of blood viii. or x. grains being
taken with Hydromell. 35 The same stamped with wine and applied, swageth the
pain of the gout, heals all pain and swellings of the genitors or stones,
swageth the swellings of the paps after deliverance. It may also be put into
all anodyne medicines, to swage pain. 36 The leaves alone, or stamped with
parched Barley meal, or mixed with other ointments, plasters, and medicines
swage all pain. 37 If one wash his feet with ye decoction of Henbane, or take
it in glister, it causes sleep, and so does the seeds laid to with oil,
or any other liquour to the forehead, or if one do but smell often to the
herb and flowers thereof. 38 The leaves, stalks, flowers, seed, root, and
juice, do cool all inflammations, cause sleep, and swage pain, but it may
not be used too much. 39 Seethe Henbane in water, and wash thy forehead and
feet therewith hot, to cause sleep in the hot evil, and apply a plaster of
the seeds with woman's milk and vinegar hot to thy temples. 40 And so it also
destroys the Emerods. 41 Gout and sciatica, stamp the root and apply it.
42 Teeth ache, bruise Henbane, and hold it in thy mouth a good while. 43 The
juice mixed with other medicines for the purpose, takes away hair. 44 Frenzy,
draw the humors downward with suppositories or glisters, and dip a spondge in
the juice or decoction of Henbane, and apply it to the head, or smell to
Henbane, to provoke sleep, or seethe it in sweet wine, and wash the temples,
ears, and nostrels therewith to provoke sleep, or apply the flowers, seeds,
or herb, to void madness and cease pain. 45 Apply the juice with a cloute to
the eyes, to void their inflammation, running and pain. 46 Ears ache, put in
ye juice or oil. 47 Ache or swelling, apply the green leaves. 48 Apply
Henbane with parched Barley meal to any ache or gout. 49 Sleep to cause,
wash thy feet with the decoction thereof, or anoint thy forehead and temples
thereof with the oil of it and vinegar. 50 The juice may be mixed with wheat
flower and made into little cakes and dried and kept to use for one year. 51
The smoke of Henbane taken in at the mouth, is good for the cough.

Ache 31. 34. 35. 36. 38. 47. 48 Apost. 11. 29. 19. 22. 35. 6 Blood to stop 34

Herb Iue, drink it to kill worms, (See Camepitis.)

Herb Robert.
Herb Robert: it stauncheth blood of green wounds bruised and applied. It is
excellent good against sores and ulcers of the paps of women, and priuities of
men, either the juice or the substance applied. 2 The juice cures ruptures and
sores of the mouth, and the stink of them. It heals wounds. 3 The powder of
it slays the canker in any place, and so does the herb stamped with salt
and honey.

Blood to stop 1 Breasts sores 1 Breath stink 2 Bursten 2 Kanker general 3
Mouth sores 2 Priuities sores 1 Wounds 1. 2
Hermodactil.
HErmodactil: gout cold, stamp the root of it, and of wallwort, with hogs
grease and apply it, or stamp Hermodactil with vinegar, and apply it. Take
Hermodact. iiii. drams, Cummin, and Ginger ana one dram, and take thereof ii.
drams in powder. It is wonderful good for all goutes and griefs of the
joints. 2 The powder of it takes away superfluous flesh of knots in the face,
and with Agrippa it does heal up the same. 3 It purges phlegm from the far
parts, and is very good against the gout, sciatica, and pain of the joints.
It must be taken with a little Ginger, long Pepper, Anise, or Cummin, and a
little Masticke, and so it does not ouerturne the stomach. 4 They are of the
nature of Affodill. And with Barley meal and honey, they draw forth all
pricks. 5 The roots bruised and applied, draws forth all great aches.

Aches 1. 5 Face knots 2 Goutes 1 Pricks 4 Purgation 1. 3 Sciatica 3
Heps.
HEps dried, and the down taken out, stops the belly strongly, but the
leaves bind weakly. 2 The down within it is very perilous for the throat and
wind pipes. 3 Tartes made of Heps, are very good against fluxes and vomiting.
Flowers to stop, pill them and dry them, and drink the powder of them. Stamp
vii. or viii. of the beries, and streine them with old wine without an ague,
but with water in an ague, and drink thereof iii. days if need be, to help
the griping, fretting, and streining of the belly. (See Rose.)

Flowers to stop. 3 Fluxes 3. 1 Vomitings 3
Hypocistis.
HYpocistis stops all laskes and fluxes of the belly, and is of stronger
operation then the flowers or leaves, and therefore cures al fluxes and the
terms. 2 Ladanum drunk with old wine, stops the laske, and provoke
urine. 3 It is very good against the hardness of the matrix laid to in a
pessary. 4 The perfume, taken up, draws down the seconds being laid on hot
coals. 5 Head skurfe, and hair falling, apply it with Myrrh, and oil of
Myrrh. 6 Ear pain, drop it in with honey or oil of Roses. 7 Sores skars or
wounds, apply it with wine. 8 Hardness and ach, use it in ointments. 9 Use it
in ointment to ye breast for the cough, and in other medicines: for ye cough:
flux, and to cause urine, drine it with wine. 10 Matrix cold, use it in
pessaries. 11 Ears deaf, use it melted in oil of bitter Almonds. 12 Teethe
loose, mix it with Masticke and use it. 13 Hair falling, melt it with Bares
grease, or oil of Myrrh, and anoint therewith. 14 Use it in suffumigations to
bring down the seconds, and terms, and urine. 15 Drink it with old red wine
to stop the bloody flux: use it both inward and outward to preserve health. 16
Put a tent of it into the nose to break the pose. 17 The best is heavy and
black. Falling evil, anoint the spine of ye Back with it. 18 Headache, use
it with convenient medicines. 19 Apply it with wine to skars of sores or
wounds. 20 Reume in the brain, use a Pomander with cubebs, maces, and greek
pitch. 21 With vinegar it takes away hair.

Ache 8 Bloody flux 15 Cough 9 Ears deaf 11 pain 6 Falling evil 17 Flowers

to fall 21 Health to preserve 15 Matrix cold 10. hard 3. Pose 16 Reume 20. 16

Holly.
HOlly: ears deaf, put in the sap of Holly laid on the fire and provoke
sneesing, or use it among other like medicines. 2 Pricks, apply birdlime with
the yolk of an eg. 3 Some say, that five of the Beries taken inwardly are good
for the chollick, and provoke to the stool. 4 The broth of the Bark of the
root is good for ioints that be out and have waxed hard thereafter. It
dissolueth and drives away swellings and sodereth together broken bones. 5
Chollicke, stamp the Berries and streine them with ale and drink it warm. 6
Stone and stopping of vrin, seethe a handful of Berries in a pint of ale to
the one half, then streine it and drink it with a little butter v. or vi.
spoonful at once. 7 Flux red, drink powder of the leaves, and use it in thy
meats. 8 Stitch, dry the leaves in an oven, and take off the pricks and drink
the powder of the leaves with ale.

Belly bound 3 Books broken 4 Bloody flux 7 Chollick 3. 5 Ears deaf 1 Ioints
out 4 Pricks 2 Stitch 8 Stone 6 Swellings 4 Urine stopped 6
Holyoke.
HOlyoke and Mallows: crampe, take Holyoke, oil of violets, and swines
grease, of each like much, fry them and streine it, and anoint therewith. 2
Teeth ache, stamp it and apply it. 3 Belly hard stamp it with soap and apply
it to the nauel. 4 For all aches and bruses of wounds and strokes, seethe the
roots tender, and grind them, and fry them with wheat flower and oil olive,
and apply it as hot as may be suffered. 5 Swelling of tooth ache, stamp it and
apply it. 6 Leapry, seethe it in vinegar, and stamp it and streine it, and
anoint therewith. 7 Griefs of the matrix after deliverance, stamp the roots,
fry them with new swines grease and apply it. 8 Wounds general, seethe the
roots, and put in the juice of them, or stamp the roots with otemeale, and
seethe them and apply them. 9 Apost. behind the ear, seethe the root to pap,
and fry it with bores grease bruised, Linseed, Fenigreke and barley meal, and
apply it to all impostumes. 10 Belly and matrix pain, apply the leaves. 11
Dead child to expel, stamp the leaves with a little salt, and goose grease,
and apply it to the matrix. 12 For pain of the back, loins, belly and
matrix, seethe the leaves in water, and wash them often therewith. 13 Yard
canker and swelling, seethe it and apply it with gylts grease, or stamp powder
of Linseede with it and Wormwood, and seethe them and apply them, and so it
ripeneth apostumes also. 14 To break a botch bile or keyll, seethe the roots
in water, and stamp them and streine them, and put theereto swines grease, and
apply it to draw and heal. 15 Plurisie, dip wool in the decoction of Holyoke
and butter and apply it. 16 Gout, fry Holyoke with sheep tallow, and apply it
three days. 17 Seethe it with Linseede to dissolve all gatherings of humors
in the body. 18 Apostumes, seethe the roots to pap, and put thereto as much
Fenigrek and Linseed as the pap, seethe it till it rope, and stamp them well,
then strein it and put thereto barowes grease and barley meal, and fry it and
use it. 19 Holyokes or garden Mallows white or red, are moist as the other
kinds are, and may be used both inward and outward. 20 Seethe the herb, root,
or seed in milk, or in wine, and drink it to cease the hot and dry cough, the
blistering of the lungs and ptisik. 21 Seethe it in wine or water mixed with
honey and Allom, and gargarise therewith to heal the blisters of the mouth and
throat, and other stinking sores. 22 Belly bound, seethe it, and eat it, to
help the ague that comes of costiuenesse, or seethe it, and make therewith a
glister to open the belly and soften it. 23 Distill water of the flowers of the
greater Mallowe, to heal the breaking out of the mouth, and all inward and
outward heates, the holy fire, blisters of the throat, and all other swellings
being gargarised or otherwise applied with linen clothes. 24 Wash the head
with the decoction of Mallows to cleanse it from all scurfe, the roots do the
like. 25 Stamp Mallows and Garlike together, and streine it with white wine,
and drink thereof nine times to cause thee to make water freely. 26 Seethe
Mallows in water, and stamp them well, and fry them with swines grease till
it be somewhat thick like an ointment, and apply thereof morn and even to
swollen legs three or four times together and be whole. 27 Seethe the seeds
of Holyoke or other Mallows with figs and raisins in water, and use it for the
coughs and chincough. 28 Mallows are good for wounds, brusings, and
rancklings. 29 The garden Mallows is better inward then outward, and the wild
better outward then inward. 30 Mallows taken in meat, nourish better then
Lettuse, and soften the belly, but art hurtful to the stomach by loosing,
mollifying, and relenting the same. 31 Eat the raw leaves with a little salt,
to help the pain and vlceration of the kidneys and bladder, and for the same
purpose, and for the gravel and stone boil them in water or wine, and drink
it. 32 Drink the decoction or broth of the roots presently after the taking
of any kind of poison to vomit it up again. 33 Bath in the broth of Mallows
to mollify the hardness and tumors of the matrix. And use it in glisters for
all painful griefs of the guts, bladder, mother, and fundament, and going
off of the skin. 34 Drink the seeds in wine to cause abundance of milk and
for the gravel and pain of the bladder. 35 Apply Mallows to the stinging of
Bees and Wasps, and to draw out thorns and splinters. 36 Stamp them raw or
sodden by them selves or with swines grease, and apply them to supple,
mollify, ripen, and dissolve all kinds of tumors hot or cold. 37 Roast
Mallowe roots in the embers and stamp them and apply them to the
exulcerations and soreness of women's breasts. 38 Mallows boiled and
moderately eaten with oil, and vinegar are indifferent good of concoction, and
do avoid superfluous matter, through the belly. 39 Use Mallowe roots or
seeds in Wine or milk daily for the hot cough and exulceration of the lungs
and Ptisick, and use the herb, seeds or roots daily in meats and brothes,
or conserues of the flowers. 40 Seethe the herb and root with the seeds of
Fenel and Dill, and drink it to have plenty of milk, for gnawing of the belly,
guts, and bladder, and to losen the belly. 41 Drink the distilled water
continually to cool all hot fevers, and to help the griefs of the lungs and
sides, the plurisy and spetting of blood and matter, the bloody flixe and hot
impost. of the kidneis and bladder. 42 Seethe the flower in water or wine and
mix it with honey and Allom as sometime the disease requires to cleanse ye
exulcerations of the mouth and throat and all inflammations both inward and
outward, the holy fire, the squincy, and other kinds of swellings. 43 Use the
water or juice against the stinging of wasps and bees. 44 The oil of the
flower defends from being stinged. 45 The leaves and roots sodden in wine
helps the scurfe of the head. 46 Apply the water warm to heal wounds. 47
The leaves, roots, and seeds with swines grease soften all hard apost. and the
swellings of the liver, milt and matrix. 48 Seethe the herb, root, and seed
with barley meal in water, and mix it with oil of Roses, or of olives, and
apply it to soften all hot apostumes, the holy fire, shingles, and
inflammations, and to draw out pricks and stings. 49 Seethe a bag full of the
leaves and roots in water and bath therein and apply the bag to the grieved
place for the obstructions of the liver, milt, kidneis, and bladder, and to
help the stone. 50 Drink half a cup full of the juice every day to preserve
thee from the falling sickness and all other sicknesses. 51 Eat the tender
leaves with salt to heal the impostume of the eye, and to prevent the danger
of the fistula there, and also apply thereto the herb stamped with honey. 52
Scotch the root of a Mallow and rub the teeth therewith to cleanse them and make
them white but of all things for that purpose powder of Mastick rubbed on once
a month is the best, and so preserves the gums. 53 Chew the leaves raw and
apply them with a little salt and honey to the corner of the eye to help the
apostume there, but when it begins to heal put in no salt. 54 Stamp the
leaves with oil, and apply them to the wild fire and burned places, and rub
thy face or hands therewith, and no bees nor wasps shall sting thee. 55 Eat the
leaves with salt and honey to heal the squincy. 56 Sees the root soft and
apply it to women's breasts with black wool warm to heal the ach, burning,
swelling, and hardness of them. 57 Seethe a handful of the leaves with oil
and wine to purge women. 58 Seethe the leaves in wine and apply them to the
mouth of the matrixe after deliverance, to stay the falling down of it, and to
make it soft. 59 Seethe it in oil and vinegar and apply it to burnings and
saint Anthonies fire. 60 Drink the seeds in wine to cleanse the stomach from
rotten and stinking phlegm and melancholy. 61 Drink the juice often to cleanse
the lungs, and to have a clear voice. 62 Seethe Holyoke with swines grease,
goose grease, and Turpentine, and apply it to the belly to assuage the grievous
swelling, burning, and inflation thereof. 63 Seethe the root in wine, and
drink it to provoke urine, to ease the stone, the cleanse the reins for the
sciatica, ruptures, and bloody flux. 64 The seeds be good for the stone and
reins, the roots do stop the bloody flux. 65 When Mallows are drunk to
expel inward poison, drink milk after them to vomit them up. 66 Seethe
Holyoke with the broth of a hen, wheat flower and butter, and apply it to
ripen apostumes of hard maturation. 67 Use Holyoke also in fractures of bones
to knit them. 68 Bath the feet in the decoction of Mallows to provoke sleep
in sharp fevers. 69 Stamp the leaves with new swines grease, and heat it on
a tile, and apply it to the hardness of the liver or milt. 70 Drink the juice
with wine for the strangury and stone. 71 Wash the hands, face, and feet with
the broth of Mallows, or Holyoke, to provoke sleep. 72 Drink the broth of
the seeds for the ptisike and cough. 73 The seed sodden in oil, softneth
hardness, cleanses and ripeneth. Abhorring meat, anoint the stomach with oil
of Roses, or of Violets, and seethe Mallows in the said oils and apply them.
74 Belly bound, seethe Mallows and Polipody, of each like much, and drink the
broth. 75 Swellings, apply a plaster of broom, and Mallows. 76 Chollick,
seethe Mercury and Mallows in oil, and apply them. 77 Flowers stopped, anoint
the over bark of the root with honey and cast on powder of Scamony, and put it
into the matrix. 78 Burning and scalding apply sodden Mallows. 79 Eyes hot
griefs, bruise Mallows and apply them. 80 Aches in any part, seethe Mallows
and apply them. 81 Head scurfe, wash with the decoction of Mallow roots. 82
Hoarsnes, anoint the breast with Bole and fresh butter, and apply a plaster of
Mallows sodden in sallet oil to the breast. 83 Impostume, apply a plaster of
Mallows, barley meal, whites of eggs, and fresh grease to ripen it when it
comes of a hot humor. 84 Paps griefs, stamp Mallow roots and apply them. 85
Plurisie, seethe Mallows, Brankursin in oil of Violets and butter, and apply
them. 86 Sinews shrunk, apply sodden Mallows. 87 Squincy, apply a plaster of
Mallows and Lily roots, with May butter. 88 Stitch, stamp Mallows, and
wormwood with new butter and apply it. 89 Stones apostumed, boil Mallows,
Henbane, and wormwood in water, and foment therewith often. 90 Stone to expel,
seethe Mallows long in water and drink thereof warm. 91 Stone and strangury,
drink the juice of Mallows. 92 Swelling of blood letting, and for swelling of
the yard, boil Linseed, Mallows, and Holyoke together, and apply them. 93
Head dry scalles, seethe the root in water and wash therewith often. 94 Eyes
spots or blemish, hand ye root of Althea or Veruin about thy neck. 95 Breast
impost. seethe the leaves and seeds of Mallows in fresh butter or cream with
some Capons grease, and strein it and anoint thy breast therewith. 96 Cough
straitness and stopping of the breath and heart, sit in a dry bath over the
decoction of Mallows, Valerian, and ote straw, and sweat well, if the liquor
cool, put hot flints into it, but if thou be fat have a siege or two first. 97
Sweat to cause, put Mallows into a close tub, and sit over the fume thereof in
a bath. 98 Belly swollen, seethe a basket full of Mallows in water, and sit
therein warm as thou can suffer, and keep thy belly soluble. 99 Fundament
falling, seethe Mallows in goats milk, and apply them hot often. 100
Strangury, sees Mallows and Garlike well bruised in a quart of wine til the
third part be wasted, and drink thereof thrice a day. 101 Hair to grow and to
void scurfe, seethe Mallows and their roots and wash therewith. 102 Belly
bound, seethe Mallows, and use the broth. 103 Back sore, seethe Mallows in
water and apply them hot in a red cloth. 104 Belly bound, use Mallows and
Mercury in pork broth, and drink whey after it. 105 Apost. to ripen, stamp
Mallows, wormwood, and Mugwort, of each like much, and fry them with swines
grease, wheat flower and honey, and boil it together till it be thick and apply
it. 106 Eyes rupture of the tunicles, mix ye juice of Mallows with barley meal
and the yolk of a raw eg and apply it. 107 Plurisy, sees Mallows in wine and
apply them hot (see Fenigrek and in Linseeds.) 108 Belly bound, seethe Mallows
and put thereto a cup of new ale and eat them. 109 Head broken, seethe field
Mallows, wormwood and Mugwort, of each like much stamped with honey and swines
grease and apply them. 110 Ach of arms or legs, apply sodden Mallows. 111 Face
rawnes and spots, sees ye roots of wild Mallows, and stamp them with vinegar,
wine, sallet oil and honey, and anoint therewith. 112 Head scurfe, sees Mallow
roots in running water and wash therewith. 113 Whites to stop, seethe wormwood
and Mallows in sack, and apply it to the belly hot as may be suffered. 114
Belly bound, seethe Mercury and Mallows ana i. handful with a piece of pork or
with whey, or white wine, and drink the broth. Handsscabd and ranckled, wash with
the decoction of Mallows. 115 Wounds to heal speedily, seethe Mallows well
and stamp them and strein them and mix the juice with old barowes grease and
barley meal and apply it. 116 Plurisy, stamp iiii. ounces of wild Mallow roots
well sodden, and put thereto butter i. ounce, honey i. ounce and a half, pigeons
doung ii. drams, mix them and apply it hot to break the corruption. 117 Eyes
ulcers, chew the leaves of Mallows and apply them with a little salt. 118
Morphue, bath in the decoction of Mallows, wormwood, and the chaff of barley or
otes, and use ointme^ts after it. 119 Belly bound, stamp a root and seethe it,
and mix it with old hogs grease and a little bran, and apply it to the stomach.
120 Stomach swollen, use Marsh Mallows sodden in water. 121 Matrix hard, foment
with the decoction of Mallows. 122 Paps swollen, stamp Mallows and apply them
hot with oil. 123 Matrix pain after childbirth, sees ye roots of Marsh
Mallows and walwort, and stamp them and apply them with oil. 124 Gout to
heal in iii. days, stamp wild Mallows roots with stale grease and apply it.
125 Belly bound, use Mallows and Mercury with sweet hogs grease. 126 Impost.
hot in ye beginning, stamp Mallows and apply them, or stamp them with swines
grease, and lay it on a hot tile, and apply it to ye impost. to ripen and break
it. It destroieth al hardness of the liver and milt. 127 Bruised blood to cast
out, drink ye juice of white Malowes with wine. 128 Belly bound, sees Mallows
and red nettles in water, and sit over the fume thereof. 129 Legs swollen, sees
Malowes and stamp them, and fry them with barowes grease til they be as an
ointment, and apply it morn and even iii. or iiii. days. 130 That no flies nor
bees shall touch thee, stamp Mallows with oil olive and anoint, but if thou be
stinged already stamp Mallows and apply them. 131 Mix i. li. of ye powder of
Mallow roots dried in ye shadow with iii. li. of honey sodden and scummed, stir it
on the fire to an electuary, and use it for shortness of wind. 132 Oppilations
or stopping, seethe wild Marsh Mallows, and strein it, and drink thereof with
sugar candy. 133 Backache, stamp i. li. of Mallows with fresh sheeps doung and
loffe grease of each ii. li. and apply thereof with unwashed wool. 134 Matrix
windy, seethe Mallows and Parietary, and bath in the water, and apply the
herbs in a bag. 135 Wounds made with iron, seethe them in water and stamp them
with swines grease and barley meal and apply it. 136 Belly bound, seethe them
in ale and eat them. 137 For sickness and anguish in the sides, seethe the
tender crops in water, and stamp them and put thereto the fatnes of wheat, so
that it be tough as glue and apply it hot as may be suffered. 138 Yard swollen,
seethe Linseeds with Mallows and apply it. 139 A ripening plaster, seethe
Mallows and wormwood to pap, then let ye water run from them, then grind them
finely with i. li. of old swines grease: it is most precious of all other for
sore breasts that do rot. It does ripen and cleanse by the pores, and mitigateth
pains in the breasts and all other apost. as of the neck, throat, armeholes or
else where. It must be applied warm on a double cloth morn and even. 140 Teeth
black or yelow, cleanse them well and use to rub them with a Mallow root. 141
Botch, seethe them with Rue, and wormwood in running water, and when they be
soft, fry them with fresh butter or fresh grease and apply it.

Horehound.
HOrehound white, boil it in water, and drink it to open the liver, and
milte, and all stoppings, it cleanses the breast and lunges, and is good for
the old cough, pain in the side, old spitting of blood, the ptisicke, and
vlceration of the lungs. 2 The same taken with the root of Iris, causes to
spit gross humors, and tough phlegm from the the breast, and so does the
juice boiled with the juice of Fennel, til the third part be wasted, and taken
a spoonful at once, and so it helps the old cough. 3 Boil it in wine, and
drink it to open the matrix, to expel the terms, seconds, and dead birth,
and to help deliverance in time of travel, and against the bitings of
venomous beasts and serpents. 4 Drop the juice with honey and wine into the
eyes to clear the sight, and into the ears to swage their pain, and open the
hearing, and draw it into the nose to take away the yellowness of the eyes,
remaining after the Iaundies. 5 Stamp the leaves with honey, and apply them to
old ulcers, corrupt vlcered nails, or agnayles, and painful swellings about
the nails, and joints to cure them. 6 Mix it with hens grease to resolve
the swelling or Struma in the neck. 7 The dried leaves with vinegar do cure
virulent and spreading ulcers. 8 Drink three spoonful of the juice with as
much scummed honey, for the falling sickness. 9 Seethe the leaves in white
wine, or water, with scummed honey, and drink it against shortness of breath,
the cough and the plurisie. And with Iris for the stopping of the liver, milte,
kidneys, matrix and bladder, and to bring down the terms and seconds. 10 The
juice clears the eyes, and kills worms in the ears. 11 All kinds of
Horehound are good for women to bathe in, that are troubled with the whites,
and pain in their back, sides and legs. 12 The distilled water is good
against all scabbes, pushes and wheales. 13 The lee of the ashes of black
Horehound helps the scabbes and sores of childrens heads. The powder of
Horehound heals the piles. 14 Seethe Horehound in wine and oil, and apply
it to the bladder to provoke urine, and to the milt for the hardness thereof.
15 Use powder of Horehound and wormwood, with sweet milk or wine to kill
worms, and lay a plaster thereof to the belly. 16 The dried leaves sodden in
water with the seeds thereof, or the juice of the green herb with honey, is
good against sighing, shortness of breath, the cough and ptisicke. 17 With
powder of Iris it cleanses the lunges from gross and tough phlegm. 18 It is
good for women to sit in the broth thereof after their deliverance, to draw
down the flowers and secondes if need be. 19 It is good for them that have
had a hard and long travel, and for them that are bitten of Serpents: but it
hurts the bladder and kidneys. 20 The leaves are good with honey to scowre
filthy and stinking sores, they stay fretting and eating sores, and agnayles,
and swage the pain of the side. 21 The juice of the leaves dried in the sun,
is good for the same purposes. 22 The same laid to with honey and wine,
clears the sight, and put into the nose, scowreth the Iaundies, and put into
the ear by it self, or with oil of roses, it takes away the pain thereof.
23 Seethe it in fair water with honey and sugar, and streine it, and drink it
to cleanse the stomach from stinking fleagme. Drink the water thereof against
the falling down of the rhewme from the head and lunges. 24 The syrrop thereof
helps the Kings evil. 25 Stamp it with honey, and apply it to the eyes to
cleanse the sight. 26 Teethach, chewe the root fasting, or else drink it. 27
Flixe to stop, seethe it in wine and oil, and stamp it well, and apply it to
the shares. 28 Chollick, stamp it and seethe it with oil olive, and apply it,
or drink the decoction of it with the root of a lilie. 29 Emerodes swelling,
seethe it in water, wine, and sale, and set it in a close stool, and sit over
it, and apply the herb. 30 Iaundies, drink the juice with thine own urine. 31
Scabs, sees it in running water, and wash therewith as hot as may be suffered,
and then use other ointments. 32 Breast griefs, drink the juice of Horehound,
bulfoot, and hissop with sugar. 33 Cough perilous, seethe the juice with honey
and lycoras, and use it. 34 Cough, and short winded, take Horehound, hissop,
woodbine, chickweed and beconie, stamp them, and sees their juice with ale or
wine, and honey, and drink thereof daily. 35 Hoarsenesse, take Horehound and
comfery, stamp them, and streine out the juice, and seethe it with honey, and
drink thereof warm, or eat it five or six days. 36 Breast stopped, seethe
the juice with honey and fresh butter, of each like much, and drink it as
hot as may be suffered to beddewarde. 37 Burnings, bruise and apply it. 38
Cough, use the syrrope of Horehound. 39 To help digestion and stay vomiting,
seethe Horehound and Puliol-montan. in water with powder of pepper, and drink
it luke warm. 40 Side pain, stitch, or impostume: chop good store of white
Horehound, and seethe it in milk in a bag and apply it. 41 Ears deaf, put in
the juice of betonie, and Horehound. 42 Cough perilous, drink ye juice with
honey. 43 Worms, drink the juice of Horehound and mints. 44 Scabs, wash with
the juice, and use ointment of docks and wormwood. 45 Cough old, sees 3.
pound of dried Horehound in ten pound of spring water, til the third part be
wasted, then strein it, and put thereto good honey a pound and a half, and
powder of pepper half an ounce, beile it till it become thick, keep it in a
vessel of glass, and take a spoonful morn and even. 46 For pain in the
bladder, and difficulty of pissing, seethe Horehound in wine and water, and
strein it, and drink it. 47 Head Vertigo, or swimming, seethe it with rue and
penie royal, with a little salt in water, till the third part be wasted: then
streine it and put honey to it, and sees it till it become thick, and take a
spoonful or two seven mornings. 48 Chollicke, sees it in wine, and drink it.
49 Weariness by travel or labor, anoint with the juice and oil of roses. 50
Scab, seethe it in water, and wash therewith and be whole. 51 Eyes blind, drop
in the juice with honey. 52 Stomach ach, drink the juice with water in a
fever, but in wine without a fever. 53 Ears worms, put in the juice of it and
wormwood. 54 Lungs griefs, drink it with butter, or some fat thing. 55 For the
liver, milte and lungs, boil the juice with as much honey, til the third part
be wasted, and take every day 3. spoonful. 56 Ptisick, and spitting blood,
sees it in water and use it for all griefs of the lungs. 57 Breast stopped with
cold, seethe it with honey and butter, and drink it at night as hot as may be
suffered, and cover thee well to sweat. Breast stopped with choler, lay a bed of
fresh butter in a new earthen pot, and another bed of it, and so til the pot be
full: then paste it up close, and set it in an oven til the herb be boiled, then
streine it and keep the butter and heat as much as the yelke of an egg, and
drink it hot, it helps the moist cough, clears the voice, and helps the
ptisick. 58 Breast griefs, and for the cough, sees it with fresh butter, add
hissope in ale or bear, and drink it early in the morning daily. 59 Stomach
to cleanse, take the juice of Horehound a quart, honey and new butter, of each a
pint, boil them together, and drink thereof hot as may be suffered. 60 The
water is good for the lungs, breast, cough, and chollicke.

stopped 1. 55 See Breast, Cough, Stomach Matrix to cleanse 3 stopped 9 Milt stopped 1.
29. 55. 14 Nails ulcers 5 Neck kernels 6 Plurisie 9 Ptisicke 1. 16. 56. 57
Purgation 23. 59 Pushes 12 Rheum 23 Seconds 39. 18 Sides pain 1. 11. 20. 40
Scabbes 12. 13. 31. 44. 50 Sores 20 Spitting blood 1. 56 See Lungs Stitch 40
Stomach ache 52 to cleanse 23. 59
Swellings 5 Teethach 26 Venime 3. 19 Ulcers 5. 7. 20 Urine stopped 14. 46
Vomiting 39 Voice ill 57 Weariness 49 Whelks 12 Whitflawe 5 Whites 11 Women's
griefs 11. 18 Worms 15. 43
Houndstong.
HOundstong heals wounds, and with barley meal it heals wild fire. The
root heals wounds and wild fire. 2 The wine or water wherein it has bin
boiled, cures old sores, wounds, and hot inflammations, and is excellent
against the ulcers and griefs of the mouth. 3 Boil the juice thereof with honey
of roses, then mix it with turpentine, and stir it hard till it be
incorporat, and then use it to wounds. Roste the root in the embers, and apply
it to the fundament to heal the inward emerodes. 4 Seethe the seed, root, or
plant in water, and drink it for the fever quarten: wash the teats with the
juice thereof co make them small and soft, 5 Dogbiting, stamp the herb with
swines grease and apply it. 6 Wounds new and bleeding, apply it. 7 Mix it
with honey to preserve hairs from falling: with vinegar it quenches burnings.
8 Sees it in red wine, and drink it to stop the bloody flux, and the running
of seed, and to heal ulcers, scabbes, pocks, and such like, and also apply
it. 9 Seethe the root in wine, and drink it morn and even, to soften the
belly. 10 Wrap it in leaven, and roste it in the embers leisurely, then take
it out of the leaven, and put it into the fundament, to take away the heat and
pain of the emerodes presently, and to cure the same quickly. 11 The water,
juice, or powder thereof is very good for the same purpose. 12 The water
heals wounds, especially of the privy parts. 13 The herb bruised with
swines grease, and fried, heals the bytings of mad dogs, and burnings,
and restores hair in bald places, and is good against old breaking out of
wheals, pushes, fistulaes, and swellings. 14 Seethe the juice with as much honey
of roses, till the juice be consumed, then mix it with turpentine, and use it
for all the griefs aforesaid. 15 Apply the root with oil to heal Wennes,
and with barley meal it heals Saint Anthonies fire, and provoke sweat,
being anointed with it. 16 It heals sores of the mouth, that be almost
incurable, and all other sores, and is good for the bloody flux: therefore it
ought to be used for all sores and wounds, the French pockes, and such like.
17 It helps also the issue of seed and catharres: wherefore the herb made
into pills is good for the rhewme. 18 The root drunk, is good against the
Fever tertian and quarten: it helps the cough, ripeneth and breaks
apostumes, and draws out thorns and pricks being applied. 19 Ears dull,
put in the clear juice. 20 Take the root out of the earth, make a hole in it
as long and deep as you can, fill it up with salt, and cover it well that
nothing come into it, and set it again as it was, and cover it with earth
three days, then take it out, and take out the liquor and keep it in a glass,
and put thereof into the ear fourteen days if need be, to restore hearing.
21 Emerodes, distill it in a limbecke, and drink three ounces of the water
morn and even, and also wash therewith if they appear outward. 22 Fundament
falling, sees it with ale in a new pot, to the one half, and drink it
morn and even. 23 Dogge-biting, stamp it with salt, and apply it. 24
Swellings of all sorts, roste the roots and apply them with swines grease. 25
Head shaking, use to eat it. 26 Eyes read, put in the juice of it and of
centorie. 27 Pissing blood, stamp the roots of Houndstong, and Oxetong, with
galts grease, and apply it to the reins. 28 Apply Houndstong green or dry
to carbuncles, stings, and venime to ripen it.

Apostume 18 Belly hard 9 Bitings venim. 5. 13. 14. 28 Bleeding 6 Bloody flux
8. 15 Breaking out 13. 14 Breasts to be small and soft 4 Burnings 7. 13. 14
Carbuncle 28 Catharre 17 Cough 18 Ears dull 19. 20 Eyes red 26 Emerodes 3. 10.

Herb Christopher.
Herb Christopher, see Osmund, or Waterfearne, it is good for the falling
evil, and the frenzy.

Hoppes.
HOppes, the decoction thereof opens the liver, milte and kidneis, and
purges the blood from all corruption of humors by urine, and is good for
scabbes, scurfe, and such like griefs, coming of corrupt blood, and so does
the young springs and tender croppes that come up in March and April, used in
sallades. 2 The juice purges yellowe choler, and cleanses the blood from all
filthiness. 3 The same juice dropped into the ears cleanses out their filthe,
and takes away the stink thereof. 4 The roots sodden and drunk, opens the
liver and spleen. 5 The syrrop thereof does purge gross raw phlegm from the
guts. 6 Steeped in whey, they purge blood and yellow choler. 7 The syrrop is
good against hot fevers, and the Iaundies. 8 The Hoppe with his juice, and
parched barley meal is good for the burning headache, and for the great heat
of the stomach and liver. 9 Hoppes purge both choler and melancholy, and
drive away impostumes and swellings, and the water of the dropsy. 10 The juice
purges most, but it opens not so much: when it is sodden, it opens more,
and purges less. 11 The flowers sodden in wine, and drunk, are good against
poison, and all manner of evils in the intralles. 12 The decoction of the
flowers is good to be sitten in against the swelling of the matrix, to provoke
urine, and for the stone in the bladder. 13 Sweat to cause, use Hoppes in
bathes.

Belly swollen 9 Bladderstopt 12 Blood to cleanse 1 Choler 2. 6 Dropsy 9 Ears
cleansing 3 Phlegm 5 Headache 8 Impost 9 Kidnes stopped 1 Liver hot 8 stopped 1. 4
Matrixe swollen 12 Melancholy 9 Milt stopped 1. 4 Poison 11 Purgat. 1. 2. 5. 6.
9. 10 Sickness general 11 Stomach hot 8 Stone 12 Swelling 9 Sweat to
cause 13 Urine stopped 1. 12
Horsmint.
HOrsmint: Ears worms, put in the juice of Horsmint and of wormwood, with
powder of Aloes and Vinegar. 2 Kanker dry, Sees it with Honey and Barley flower
and vinegar in an earthen pot with unslaked Lime and black Pepper, and let it
dry to make powder, and lay thereof to the sore.

Ears worms 1 Kanker 2
Horstaile.
HOrstaile or Shauegrasse: Yard griefs and swelling, distill it in a Limbecke,
and apply it. The decoction thereof heals chafing of the skin in the flanks
or elsewhere. 2 Sees it in wine or water, and drink it to stop all fluxes of
blood and all other extraordinary fluxes, terms, and laskes both white and
red, and so does the juice drunk alone, or with wine, and is most convenient
in the same sort for all ulcers, sores and hurts of the kidneys and bladder,
and bowels, and all burstings. 3 And boiled with the root, it is good against
the Cough, difficulty of breathing and inward burstings. 4 The juice put into
the Nose, stops bleeding. 5 And into the Matrixe, it stops the terms. 6
The powder of it cast upon fresh wounds, do join them together and heals
them, and defends them from inflammation, and so does the fresh herb stamped
and applied. 7 The juice drunk with wine stops all manner of fluxes, and
helps all ruptures and bruises of the bowels, guts and bladdar, and so does
the herb or root thereof sodden in wine or water. 8 The juice or water is
good for all Ringwormes, Tetters, red Pshes, Quats, inflammations of the
fundament, the bloody flux and swellings of the stones. 9 It is good against
all stoppings of the Bladder, it cleanses the stomak, sides and Lungs. 10 The
syrope or juice of it heals wounds of the Guts, it stops blood, and
heals wounds and ruptures, and falling of the Bowels into the Cods being
drunk often and also applied warm with vinegar to the Belly. 11 The fume of
it is good to cause childrens Guts to go back into their body, when as
through Flux or cold they hang forth, and so it stops the immoderate
terms of women.

Bladder hurts 7 stopped 9

swollen 8 Cough 3 Flowers to stop 2. 5. 7. 11 Fluxes 2. 7 Fundament fallen 11

Sores inward 2 Stomach stopped 9 Tetters 8 Urine stopped 9 Wounds 6 inward 2. 10
Whites 2 Yard griefs 1
Housleeke.
HOusleeke or Sengreene: drink the decoction or juice against the bloody Flux
and all other fluxes of the belly, and against biting of field Spiders. 2
Headache, apply the juice with parched Barley meal and oil of Roses. 3 Eyes
inflamed, drop in the juice or bruise the herb and apply it. 4 Flowers to stop,
put in the juice with Wool or Cotton. 5 For the hot Gout and inflammations,
bruise the herb alone with parched Barley meal and apply it. 6 The juice made
into an ointment with soote, oil and wax, heals burnings, the heat of the
head and Liver. 8 Apply the bruised herb by it self or with Barley meal
parched, to Saint Antonyes fire, hot burning and fretting sores or ulcers,
skaldings, burnings, and all hot griefs. 8 Eyes sore and hot, apply the
juice with Honey and the white of an Egg with Flax hurdes. 9 Eyes burning and
pricking, drop in the juice four or five nights. 10 Gout hot or cold,
stamp it with as much Garlike and apply it, to ease it much. 11 Drink three
or four spoones full of the distilled water against all burning Fevers, Bloody
Fluxes, and other fluxes. 12 Drink the juice to kill worms, apply the water
or juice to all inflammations, heat of the eyes, inflammations of the Liver,
Kidneys and Joints, the hot Gout, Burnings, and the Frenzy. 13 With the
juice of Solatrum, and the eyes of Poplar tree sodden with swines grease and
streined, it is much better then Poplar. 14 The leaves laid to by themselves
or with parched Barley meal, are good for burning heat of swelled places, and
all inflammations. 15 Stonecrop is of the same nature: it quenches hot
Apostumes, Byles, Fellons, Skaldings, Burnings, the hot Gout, etc. especially
with oil of Roses, Vinegar and parched Barley meal. 16 Liver chaft, stamp
Housleeke with Cummin, and seethe them in Vinegar and apply it to the side as
hot as may be suffered as often as need is. 17 Abhorring meat, grind
Housleeke and Penywurt with oil of Violets, and apply it warm to the
stomach. 18 Ears dull, boil the juice with Cummin in an Onion, and streine
it, and put it in, and provoke Sneesing. 19 Ears griefs, boil it with a
Rams Gaul and the grease of an Eele, and use it. 20 Stamp the leaves of
Housleeke, Sparewort and Peach leaves, and put the juice into the one ear,
till it run out of the other, to restore hearing, if it be curable. 21
Frenzy, shave the head and apply the juice of Housleeke to the molde of the
head and mids of the forehead, or anoint the forehead and temples, and joints
of the Arms with the juice of it. 22 Headache of heat, apply the juice of
Housleeke, Morell, and Lettuse with vinegar, or anoint the forehead and temples
with the juice of it, and woman's milk that suckleth a boy. 23 The same with
the white of an Egg applied to the forehead and temples, is good in a hot
fever to avoid the ach, and to cause steep. 24 Apostumes, stamp Housleeke,
Planten, and Nightshade, and apply them. 25 Liver apostumed, apply the juice
of Housleeke, Nightshade, and such like. 26 Mad, sees Housleeke in water, and
apply it warm to the head. 27 Nose bleeding, stamp Housleeke, Planten, and
Ribwort with Barley meal and apply it to the neck. 28 Pissing much, apply
Housleeke or the juice thereof. 29 Madness with great heat in the head,
stamp Housleeke and Roses of each like much with woman's milk, and apply it to
the forehead and temples. 30 Stingings of Bees, Anoint with the juice of
Housleeke. 31 Ears running, roste the juice in an Onyon or Skallion and
streine it, and put it into the Ear. 32 Legs ach and swelling, sees Otemeale
and the juice of Housleeke in milk with sheep tallowe and apply it. 33 Fever
hot and the Plague, mix the juice with Wheat flower and the white of four
Eggs, and apply it to the sides. 34 Heat and burning of Gunpowder, anoint with
the juice and gleers of Eggs. 35 Eyes dull, put in Euphorbium with the juice of
Housleeke. 36 Lust to void, anoint the Yard with the juice of Housleeke, great
Morell and Vinegar. 37 Liver grief and swelling, apply the juice of Housleeke
and Morell with Barley meal and Vinegar. 38 Apostumes general, sees it with
Egrimony and Five leaf in red wine, and apply it hot. 39 Rubbing and chafing,
apply the juice with Rose water and the white of an Egg, but most of the
juice. 40 Kanker and fester, mix Housleeke with Garlike and Orpiment, and
apply it. 41 Sores general, put in the juice of Housleeke and Celondine, and
apply the herb: proved. 42 Face swollen or scorched, rub it twice or thrice a
day with the juice of Housleeke. 43 Ears dull, put the juice of Housleeke,
oil Olive, the juice of a Leeke, and the milk of a woman that suckleth a boy,
into a Vial three days, and let it stand open, and use it. 44 Ears deaf,
boil the juice with as much Eeles grease, a little, and put it into the Ear
nine nights: proved. 45 Eyes heat and pricking, clarify the juice in an Egg
shell, and keep it in a glass, and use it four nights: proved. 46 Warts,
pill off the skin, and apply it four days or more morn and even. 47 Face
swollen or inflamed, anoint with the juice. 48 For the hardness of the brawnes
of the feet, dip them in hot Piss till they be soft, then lance them about,
and apply the juice of Housleeke, and it will be well on the morrow. 49
Rankling and heat in any place, stamp it with Vinegar and Flax hurds, and
apply it.

Iasmyn.
IAsmyn cures the foul dry scab, and red spots: it dissolueth swellings and
wennes, or hard lumps and gatherings being applied, and so does the oil
thereof, which being put into the nostrels, and often smelled unto, causes the
Nose to bleed, in them that are of an hot complexion. 2 Iasmyn dries Rumes,
and the moystnesse of the brain, and is good against the cold griefs
thereof, and for salt phlegm, and for old men of a cold complexion, and for
aches that come of clammie and tough humors. 3 The same either dry or green
laid upon any Tetter or foul spots will drive them away: It is good for the
pose, but it causes headache in them that are of a hot complexion.

Aches 2 Brain moist 2 Hardness 1 Head griefs 2 Nose to bleed 1 Rume 23
Skabs 13 Spots 13 Swellings 1 Tetters 3 Wennes 1
Juniper.
IVniper: the fruit or berries is good for the Lungs, stomach, Liver and
kidneys, it cures the old Cough, the griping and windiness of the belly, and
provoke Urine, being boiled in Wine or Honied water and drunk: and so it
helps them that be bruised. 2 The juice of the leaves does withstand all
venom, especially of Vipers and Serpents, being drunk and applied on the
wounds. 3 The fruit is good for the same purpose, howsoever it be taken. 4
Juniper or the berries thereof burned, drives away all venomous beasts, and
all infection and corruption of the Air, and therefore it is good to be used
in the Plague time. 5 The ashes of the rynde heals naughty skurfe and
fretting skabs, being mixed with water and applied. 6 The gum is good for the
stomach and bowels that are cumbred with cold phlegm: It expels all kinds
of worms, and stops the flowers. 7 The perfume of Vernix is good for the
Brain, it dries up superfluous humors of the head, and stops the Ruin. 8
This gum tempered with oil of Roses, helps the riftes and chaps of the
hands and feet. 9 Use the berries against all bitings and stingings of
Serpents as the best remedy therefore. 10 Drink the berries against the
diseases of the breast, to expel urine, to help bursten places and the
suffoc. of the Mother. 11 The ripe berries are good against many griefs, and
are much more wholesome then Pepper. No man can fully express their virtues,
being used in meats they are good for a cold stomach, they digest phlegm
therein, they help inflammations and torments, they purge the griefs of the
breast, the Cough, provoke Vrin, expel poison from the heart, the flowers, and
tough humors from ye Hyps. 12 Lee made with wine and the ashes of Juniper
drives forth Vrin, and helps the Dropsy. 13 The precious oil of the
berries is as good as Baulme, and so is the oil of the dry wood. 14 The oil
heals all manner of evil skabs, and all chaps and clifts of the hands and
feet. 15 The ashes of the bark anointed with water, drives forth the Lepry,
and is good against the bitings of Serpents and Vipers. 16 The oil warmeth the
senowes, comfort the head being overcome with cold. 17 The wood makes
ardent hot fyers. 18 It is not good to sit long under the Juniper tree. 19
Poison or plague, make fine powder of the berries, and of Terra Lemnia, of each
two drammes and a scruple, mix it with Honey, and keep it in a clean
vessel, and take thereof as much as an Hasell Nut, with three ounces of Mulsa,
which is Honey one part, and water eight parts, sodden and scummed till the
fourth part be wasted: if there be any poison, this will cast it up, but if
there be none, it will rest in the stomach. 20 Cough in children, steep the
berries in wine and drink it. 21 Plague to withstand, use the fume of the
berries and cloven roots. 22 Matrixe apost. sees the roots or fruit in
water, and bathe therewith. 23 Dead child and poison or venom to expel, and
for stingings, 24 Gather the berries in September when they be ripe, bruise
them and distill them through a Lymbecke, and drink iiii. drams of it. 25
Chincough, drink the berries with wine. 26 Drink the leaves with water and
Honey to cause deliverance, and to expel the seconds. 27 The berries are
excellent against all poison and venomous bitings. 28 Ears deaf, sees ye
berries with Sauin in good wine, and take up ye fume thereof.

Iuiubes.
IViubes eaten, are hard of digestion, and nourish very little: but taken in
Electuaries, Syropes, and other medicines, they mollify the roughness of the
Throat, Breasts and Lungs, and are good against the Cough and exulceration and
inflammation of the kidneis and bladdar, and the reins of the back being
vexed with any sharp or salt humor, and they quench the heat of choleric
blood.

Blood hot Breast grief Back grief. Kidneys grief Lungs griefs Salt humors
Throat rough
Iuye.
IVye: boil the leaves in wine to cure great wounds, and to stay great and
corrupt Ulcers. 2 Boil the same in vinegar and apply it for the stopping and
hardness of the Milt. 3 The flowers applied with oil and wax, heal all
burnings. 4 The flowers sodden in wine, and drunk morn and even, heals the
dangerous laske and bloody flixe. 5 Boil five Iuie berries with oil of Roses
in the rynde of a Pomegranate, and put it into the ear of the contrary side to
that which the tooth ach is on, to heal the tooth ach. 6 The gum of Iuie
kills Lice and Nits. 7 It also takes away hair from any place that it is
laid upon. 8 To provoke Urine, drink powder of Iuie berries with ale or white
wine. 9 For the frenzy and melancholy sadness, put the juice of Iuy into thy
nose, and seethe Mints in vinegar, and lay them to thy head. 10 For daseling
and turning in the head, mix the juice of it with old larde and anoint
therewith. 11 For the megrem and watching, anoint thy brows and nostrels with
the juice of Iuy oil and vinegar. 12 For the polip in the nose, put in the
juice of Iuy. 13 For the strangury, put a handful of Iuy leaves with a pint of
good aqua composita into a close vessel, drink thereof iii. or iiii. spoonfuls
morn and even first and last v. or vi. days to have present help thereof. 14
Take the dried wood of Iuy and the gum of Iuy ana like much, put them into an
earthen pot bored full of holes in the bottom, or in ii. or iii. places and set
another pot close under it in the earth pasted together with clay, and make a
fire round about the uppermost pot, and there will distill an oil into the
nether pot, which heals all cold griefs of the ioints. 15 To help the
bloody flixe, drink one ounce of the flowers in wine and be whole. 16 The
leaves sodden in wine and drunk, or the powder of the Berries, drives down
terms. 17 One ounce of the Berries being bruised and drunk with wine,
expels the stone. 18 The leaves sodden in wine helps all manner of ulcers
being washed therewith. 19 Iuy used in baths, draw down the terms, and so
do the leaves or tops thereof stamped and put in as a pessary. 20 The leaves
stamped with vinegar and a little Rose water, is good for all old ache of the
head. 21 The juice makes hairs black being anointed therewith. 22 The tender
leaves sodden in sharp vinegar and tempered with crumbs of leauened bread and
applied, does help the griefs of the liver. 23 The tender leaves also
stamped with Roses and tempered with oil of Roses, vinegar, and woman's milk
and applied to the forehead, help the pain of the head. 24 The juice with oil
of bitter Almonds put warm into the ears, helps the hearing. 25 The leaves
sodden in wine are good for the spots, scabs of the face, skin and privy parts
being washed therewith. 26 Nothing is better for the canker then the juice of
Iuy tempered with clarified honey and wine sodden together. 27 The juice put
into the mouth of the matrix, draws forth terms and dead child. 28 One dram
being drunk after the flowers be past, causes sterilitie in women. 29 Honey
mixed with the Berries of Iuy will kill lice in childrens heads. 30 The green
leaves sodden in wine do knit, join and heal wounds or cuts. 31 The juice
often drunk in wine, does heal the terror of a quarten or tertian. 32 The
gum of Iuy tempered with wax and put to a pained tooth will draw it out
without pain. 33 Anoint the emerods, or any great aches or cold with this gum.
34 Drink a little of it with white wine against abhorring of meat. 35 This
gum is very hot and will blister. They that will gather it must cut off the
bark of the Iuy, and renew the cut every morning, and wash their hands and
face with vinegar and Rose water before they gather it, but wipe them not and
so the gum will not blister them. 36 This gum must be kept close in a glass
or box of metal. 37 For extreme headache, anoint with the juice of Iuy, and
oil of Violets, or with vinegar, and anoint the nostrels therewith. 38 Hair
not to grow, anoint with the juice of Iuy and ashes of blood suckers mixed
together. 39 Marmoll, wash it with the decoction of Iuy to heal it. 40 For the
stone, gather Iuy Beries that grow on an Ash tree, dry them and do off their
black part, and make them into powder with a quantity of Cinnamom and
lycoras, and use in brothes and drinks daily. 41 Teeth-ache, boil the Berries
and leaves in wine, and hold it often in thy mouth to take away the ache and
stink, or boil Iuy and Ginger in Wine, and hold it in thy mouth, and rub thy
teeth with the Ginger, or boil the leaves or gum of Iuy in vinegar in a hot
cause, or in wine in a cold cause, and use thereof. 42 To drive out the stone
of the bladder and kidneys, drink powder of Iuy Berries two ounces morn and
even, with two ounces of wine and be whole. 43 Head swimming, anoint with the
juice of Iuy and old larde. 44 Nose polip, put in the juice, or use the gum
in ointments. 45 Milt pains, sees Iuy in wine and drink it. Oil of Iuy
Berries, stamp the leaves and Berries, and steep them in oil and wine three
days, then seethe it, and streine it, and use it. 46 Gout pains, garsh the
place, and lay thereon bean meal, and lay thereupon Iuy leaves or Colewort
leaves. 47 Plague, drink as much powder of Iuy Berries as will lie upon a
groat, with a draught of white wine, and cover thee well to sweat, and change
thy clothes. 48 To draw out a tooth without pain, rub it and none other with
powder of the gum of Iuy. Oil of Iuy, receive powder of Balm one ounce,
oil Olive one pint, set it into an onen after the batch is drawn, and when it
is cold streine it, and melt therein half an ounce of gum Hederae, and two
penyworth of Camphire, and put it into a vial, and hang it in hot water, and
it will be a pure balm. 50 To have gum Hederae, cut a great branch of Iuy in
sunder, and bruise the end that is cut with the head of an axe, and set it
rest three or four weeks in Winter when the virtue is in it, and then take
it. 51 Shoulders ache, anoint with honey, and cast on bean flower, and lay on
Iuy leaves. 52 Stone, mix powder of the red bark of Iuy tree, with as much
get, and drink thereof with wine or ale five or six times blood warm. 53
Hairs to be yellowe, wash with lee made with the ashes of the wood without
the bark. 54 Hair not to grow, apply Labdanum, gum Hederae, Emets eggs,
Arsnike and vinegar to the place. 55 Toothach, seethe Iuy roots in wine, and
hold it in thy mouth. 56 Urine and stone to expel, drink Iuy Berries with
warm wine. 57 Fever quarten, take three grayns of the gum. 58 Legs
painful, stamp dry figs with the flowers of Iuy and apply it. 59 Warts, apply
the gum of Iuy with vinegar. 60 Wine of the decoction of the roots holden in
the mouth, helps the toothache. 61 Iuy sodden in wine till it be thick,
breaks botches. 62 Belly hard and sore, drink two spoonefuls of the juice of
Iuy leaves. 63 Eyes pin and web, use water of Iuy growing on an Ash tree
gathered between the S. Mary days (See Alehoofe.) 64 To draw out a tooth,
burn a green Emet or Newt to powder in a new earthen pot, and melt gum
Hederae with the powder and milk of spurge, and put thereof under the stone of
a ring well closed, and touch the sore tooth with the stone, and it will fall
into thy hand. 65 Pissing much, seethe Iuy Berries in white wine, and drink
it, and it shall stay quickly. 66 Canker, seethe the leaves of wild Iuy with
wine, and apply it to kill it. 67 Pappes hanging sagging down, wear thereto a
garland of Iuy, or stamp Iuy and apply it. 68 Tooth to draw out without
pain, burn the gum and green leanes ana like much in a new earthen pot,
and mix the fine powder thereof with milk of spurge, and put some of it into
the tooth, but if it be not hollow touch it therewith and it will fall out. 69
Aches cold, use oil of Iuy. 70 Iaundies, seethe it when it flowreth in white
wine that is not too sour nor too sweet, and drink it seven mornings. 71
Sciatica, anoint with the juice of Iuy drawn out by Alchimi, or fry the herb
in fritters, and eat it ix. days fasting. 72 Liver and milt hard and swollen,
steep Iuy in wine x. days till it rot, then boil it and strein it when the
wine is consumed, and mix it with oil Olive and wax, and use it to anoint
therewith. 73 Stone, drink ix. of the Berries with wine, or the juice of the
leaves with water. 74 Teeth-ache, stamp the Berries and seethe them in wine
with the shauing of a Hartshorne, and apply it without the cheek.

Aches 69 Belly hard 62 Bladder stone 42 Blister to cause 35 Bloody flux 15
Botch to break 61 Burnings 3 Child dead 27 Cold griefs 14 Cuts to heal 30
Deafness 24 Emerods 33 Eyes web 63 Face spots 25 Fever quarten 31. 57 Fever

Knotgrasse.
KNotgrasse helps all diseases of the heart and mouth of the stomach, the
griefs of the back, the stone and chollick, by drinking it or the infusion of
it. 2 Fever quarten, drink the juice with powder of vii. Pepper corns before
the fit to put it quite away. It must be gotten on a Thursday, and the juice
gotten in the wane of the Moon. 3 Spetting blood, drink the juice. 4 Sweat to
cause, and to heal the plague, stamp herb Rape, with the roots of the less
Planten and Knotgrasse ana half a handful, and boil them in vinegar and
streine it, and drink it, and cover thee well to sweat. 5 Teeth-ach, stamp a
handful, and bind it to the plant of the foot of the contrary side, and lie
down and sleep. 6 Eye spots, put in the juice. 7 Pissing blood, drink it with
wine fasting and be whole. 8 Belly long worms, drink the juice with milk. 9
Blood to stop, drink it with stale ale. 10 Worms, drink the water. 11 Bloody
flux, use Knotgrasse any ways. 12 Nose bleeding, drink the juice. 13 Breast
or ribs pain and soreness, stamp it with butter and apply it, or stamp it
with oil of Roses and anoint. 14 Chafing, use the decoction of it. 15 Eyes
perle and web, put in the juice viii. nights when thou go to bed. 16 Ears
deaf old, stamp Ants eggs, and streine them with the juice of Knotgrasse and
put it in. 17 Spetting or vomiting of blood, drink the juice. 18 Teats
swelling, carry it about thee. 19 Stamp it with Comfery, and seethe it with
milk of a red kow, and strein it, and drink it morn and even to void the
pain of the back, and heal any sore of the kidneys. 20 Drink the juice to
help spetting blood, pissing blood, and all other issues of blood, vomiting
and lasks. 21 Drink it with wine against all venomous bitings. 22 Boil the
leaves with wine or water, and drink it to stay all manner of lasks and fluxes
of the belly as well white as red, spetting blood and all such like, and the
terms, as well as the juice. 23 It is also good against tertian fevers, drunk
one hour before the fit. 24 Flowers to stop, put in the juice with a pessary. 25
Nose bleeding, put in the juice with a tent. Ears pain and filth, put in the
juice. 26 Boil it with wine and honey to cure the inflammations and ulcers of
the secret parts. 27 Stamp the green leaves, and apply them to the heat of
the stomach, hot swellings and impostumes, the consuming burning of S.
Anthonies fire, and all green and fresh wounds. Prosper has the same virtues.
28 It would be gathered on Thursday in the increase of the Moon: but the juice
in the wane of the Moon. 29 Seethe it in red wine, and drink it to stop all
fluxes, terms, spetting and vomiting blood. 30 It expels all poison, and the
stone of the kidneys strongly, and restrains all inward heat of the stomach
and other parts, and helps the gnawings of all the intrals, and is good for all the inner parts, and so is the water of it drunk with powder of the seeds.
31 The water or juice is good for all ringwormes, tetters, shingles, holy fire
and inflammations both inward and outward, stinking filth in ye ears, rotten
sores, gangrenes of the gums, and all wounds both new and old, especially of
the secret parts both of men and women, and does preserve the same against
inflammation and all other evil accidents. 32 There is no herb that stops
blood better then Knotgrasse. It stops the whites and is good for the
strangury, all sores of the priuities. It is good to keep back such matter as
would run to sores or wounds. It provoke vrin. 33 Stone to expel, seethe
Prosper in wine and drink it.

Ladies mantel.
LAdies mantel is much like to Sanicle in quality, and serves for all such
griefs as Sanicle is good for, and also takes away all heat of all wounds,
inflamed ulcers, and apostumes. 2 The same stamped and applied to the paps of
wives and mayds, makes them hard and firm. It has also the virtues of
Tormentill. 3 It is very good for burstings in children. (See Sanicle.) 4 Drink
one dram of the powder with iii. ounces of the water to help all ruptures in
short time without cutting, and with the water and sugar xv. or xx. days to
cause conception let by cold causes.

Apostumes 1 Breasts fagging 2 Bursten 3 Conception 4 Inflammations 1 Sores 1
Wounds 1
Lady thistle.
LAdy thistle. The root drunk in wine is good for them that spet blood, that
have feeble stomachs and loose bellies. It provoke urine and expels it
forth. 2 Teeth-ach, seethe it in wine, and hold it in thy mouth. 3 Swellings
cold and soft, stamp it and apply it. 4 The seed is good for the cramp in
children, or the drawing awry of any member, and the biting of any venomous
beast. 5 Teeth loose and foul, seethe the root and wash with it.

Belly loose 1 Spetting blood 1 Stomach weak 1 Swellings cold 3 Teethach 2.
foul 3. loose 3. Urine stopped 1
Larks spur, etc.
LArks spur or Larks claw, drink the seed of it against all poison, and
venomous bitings.

Langdebeefe.
LAngdebeefe: it takes away the red color of the face, the cardiacke and
evil humors in the lungs. 2 The juice drunk with hot water, causes a good
memory and wit. It must be gathered in June and July. 3 Swellings in any part,
seethe it in vinegar or wine, and put thereto honey and salt, and apply it as
hot as may be suffered. 4 Ioints ache, seethe one handful in a pint of white
wine, and one spoonefull of honey till it be soft, then grind it and seethe it
till it be somewhat brown, and then apply it. (See Buglosse.)

Ache 4 Face red 1 Heart griefs 1 Joint ache 4 Lungs griefs 1 Memory 2
Swellings 3 Wit 2
Lunaria, or Moonwort.
LVnaria, or Moonwort: it is of the nature of Adders tongue and Picola, in
healing all wounds both inward and outward.

It stops the whites and red flowers in women. It helps burstings of
children. 2 The powder of it is good for the whites, reds, and bloody flux. 3
For a blast, and to heal cankers, stamp it with as much Pimpernell, and apply
the juice. 4 Wounds bleeding, stamp it and apply it. (See Adders tongue.) Falling
sickness, drink it when luna is in virgo in the wane.

Blast 3 Blood to stop 4 Bursten 1 Bloody flux 1 Falling evil 4 Flowers to
stop 1. 2 Kanker 3 Whites to stop 1. 2 Wounds general 1. 4
Laureall.
LAureall. The leaves purge the slimy phlegm, and watrish superfluities, and are
good for the dropsy, and so does xiiii. or xv. of the Beries taken at once. 2
The leaves chewed or put into the nose, purge the head and brain, and cause
sneesing. 3 The leaves must be steeped 24. hours in good strong vinegar, and
then dried, and their powder drunk with Aniseedes and Masticke, or else boiled
in whey of sweet milk, or broth of a Capon, and so taken. 4 Or sees v. or
vi. scruples with Comfery in wine, and streine it and drink it to purge the
belly. 5 A little of the powder given to children in pottage, takes away the
superfluous humiditie, and kills worms. 6 It causes quick and speedy
deliverance in child birth, and brings down the seconds and terms, being
drunk three or four times three penie weight at once, and also drives forth
urine. 7 The same stamped and bound to the head, takes away the pain thereof.
8 The leaves green or dry drunk, provoke terms, and causes vomit. Belly
bound, temper it with as much honey, and use it, one sponefull causes vomit, or
sees the powder with water and honey, and drink it luke warm. 9 Flux to stop,
drink the powder of it. 10 To cause deliverance of a dead child, drink the
powder. 11 To purge all venom, poison, and impostumes out of the body, 12
Stamp Laureall and Stonecrop, and streine it with old ale, and drink it
twice a day. The same does kill and expel worms. 13 Laureall purges phlegm
and choler, and helps digestion: the juice put into the ear, or a
suppositorie put into the ear, is good against dull hearing. 14 Make an
Electuarie with powder of Laureall, pure honey, and bread crumbs with good store
of Saffron, and use it both to purge and to restore. 15 Laureall draws out
yellowe water. 16 Steep the leaves in vinegar, and the juice of Barberies, or
the juice of Pomegranates, or of Quinces, and cast thereon powder of
Mirabolanes, then dry them and boil two scruples, or one dram in fat broth
with Cinamom and Sugar. The powder may be taken from five grains to ten,
with Tamarinds, Mastike, and Spike. Hermius. It helps the dropping of urine,
and pissing of blood.

Correction 3. 16 Dead child 10 Deliverance 6 Digestion 13 Dose 16 Dropsy 1.
15 Ears dull 13 Flowers stopped 6. 8 Fluxes 9 Headache 7 purging 2 Impostume 11
