Lauender.
LAuender: smell often to it to comfort and clear the sight. 2 Boil it in
water, and weete thy shirt in it, and dry it again and wear it, and no lice
will be in it so long as it smells of it. 3 Steep the flowers in wine and
distill them, and hold the water in thy mouth to recover speech lost by the
apoplexia. 4 It has many other virtues, it helps all cold griefs of the
brain, crampes, and gripings of the body coming of cold, the stopping of the
milt, it heals the belly, and provoke terms. 5 Shread the herb with the
flowers, and distill it in June, and drink ii. ounces of the water to help
giddines of the head, and rub the head all over with it, and let it dry in by
it self. 6 The same also helps the crampe, apoplexia, the astonishing and
trembling of the members and hands, and the palsy members being rubbed
therewith. 7 Drink iii. ounces at once for the heaviness of the moving of the
tongue. 8 Hold thereof in thy mouth for the ulcers thereof, and the
toothache, and the blistrings of the mouth. 9 Sees the flowers in wine, and
drink it to provoke urine well, and drink it iiii. days to provoke the
flowers and seconds, to expel wind, and to help the Iaundies. Or take the
flowers with cinamom, cloves, mace, grains, cubebs, and the leaves of
rosemarie, to help all the aforesaid more strongly, and also the palsy and
toothache. Headache and dissinesse of cold, wash it with the water. 10
Benumbed or taken, wash with the water or decoction of the flowers often. 11
For all cold griefs of the head, and to comfort the brain, quilt ye flowers
into a cap, and wear it daily. 12 Heart griping, sees the flowers in wine,
and drink it, especially seethe the flowers with roses, cloves, maces,
cinamom, cubebs, and cardamom in wine, and drink it for all griefs
aforesaid, and for the apoplexia, and to restore speech, the water will do
the like. 13 Palsy, sees it well in water, and drink half a pint first and
last xiiii. days, the same takes out any stayne in cloth being rubbed
therewith. 14 Sprinckle a toste of wheat bread with Malmesey, and cast thereon
the dry flowers, and apply it hot in a cloth to the navel to help the
chollike. 15 Take as much as a bean of the conserve of the flowers for the
beating of the heart, the Iaundies, giddiness of the head, the palsy members,
and to comfort the brain. 16 Fever quarten, seethe Sage, Lauender, and
Rosemary in wine, and drink it before the fit. 17 Speech lost, seethe
Lauender, Couslip, and Sage in wine, and drink it hot. 18 Trembling, use
water of the decoction of Cresses and Lauender. 19 For all passions of the
sinowes, drink two ounces of the water, and wash the head therewith. 20 Ears
dull, put in the oil of Spike, with as much juice of Betony. 21 Lauender-spike
causes urine. 22 A decoction thereof applied to the matrix, stops
superfluous terms, and takes away the humors of the matrix. 23 Drunk with
cold water, it puts away the weakness and trembling of the heart. 24
Steeped in lee, and the head washed therewith, it causes hair to grow, and
stays it from falling. 25 The oil of Spike well drawn by a glass, is very
sweet, and has many virtues, especially for the palsy members. It ^aseth the
gout, and all other greefes of the joints. It helps swellings of the
stomach, the diseases of the liver and kidneis, and the Kings evil. 26 The
decoction of Spike helps the palsy of the tongue, comfort the sinowes,
and dries up moisture from the tongue. 27 The flowers steeped in wine and set
in the sun a certain space in a narrow mouthed glass, well stopped, and
after distilled by glass in Balneo mariae with a soft fire, (but if the fresh
flowers may be had, it need not be infused) this water is very precious
against all cold griefs both inward and outward. 28 Put thereof with a linen
cloth into the nose for the grief of the head and brain. Drink two ounces at
once for the chollike coming of cold. 29 Anoint the forehead and nape of the
neck for the pain and giddiness of the head. Apply it to members that have
the palsy, shaking and cold. 30 Matrix inflamed, seethe it in water, and sit
over it. 31 Use it to dry up the moisture of the dropsy. 32 Heart weak,
sick, and swooning, sees it in wine, and make it a syrup, and use it. 33
Liver and milt stopped, seethe it in goats milk, and use it long. 34 Dropsy
cold, sees it in the urine of a goat or black sheep and drink it, and
sees it in Goats wheye, and drink it first and last a long time for both
dropsies hot and cold. 35 Spikenard comfort the brain and sinowes,
warmeth every cold part of the body, and is good for the falling sickness,
the chollike, flux, cardiake, dropsies, and hyckit. 36 With honey it increases
hair, it provoke urine, helps the fretting or gnawing of the stomach, it
dries up reumes of the breast and belly, put into the matrix, it does dry up
and cleanse it, and the fume thereof helps conception. 37 For swooning and
the cardiacke passion, sees it in wine or rosewater, and drink it with sugar.
38 Brain weak, put it into the nostrels, or seethe it in oil, and so it is
also good for deafness and running of the ears. 39 For coldness of the
stomach, want of digestion, and stopping of the liver and milt, with any cold
humor, use wine of the decoction thereof. 40 Gummes rotten, use the powder of
it. 41 The oil thereof is good for the palsy, falling sickness, goutes of
the joints and of the feet, both taken at the mouth, and also anointed.
Steep powder thereof in oil xx. days, then boil it and streine it. 42
Sweating too much, cast on the powder of it. 43 Seethe Spikenard in water, and
temper thy wine therewith, and also make a syrup with the said water, and use
it against swooning, and to comfort the heart. 44 Stomach gnawing, drink it
with cold water. 45 It is used in Antidotes and Treacles.

Lauender cotton.
LAuender cotton, or garden Cypers, drunk with wine, is good against all
poison and venom: it is the female kind of Sothernwood. 2 Stamp it and streine
it with milk, and drink it fasting to kill worms. 3 Both it and Wormwood
are good to be set in the house and windows to expel serpents. 4 And drunk
with wine, are both good against deadly poison. 5 The leaves drunk with wine
7. days, helps the yellowe iaundies, the obstruction of the liver and
kidneis, and is good against the sciatica, and all things that Rue is good for,
and S. John's woort. 6 Matrix swollen and falling, stamp it well, and apply it.

Back griefs 5 Iaundies 5 Kidneis stopped 5 Liver stopped 5 Matrix fallen 6
swollen 6 Poison 1. 3. 4 Sciatica 5 Venom. 1. 3. 4 Worms 2
Leekes.
LEekes: the seeds may well be kept iii. years. 2 Stamp Leekes with salt,
and apply them to evil pushes to heal them. 3 Mix powder of Leekes with oil
of Roses and vinegar, and drop it into the ears to take away their pain, and
to help the toothache. 4 The much eating of Leekes does much harm the
stomach and eyes, and fills the body with wind, and therefore it ought to be
twice sodden with water before it be eaten. 5 Leekes provoke the passage of the
terms, causes urine, and procures a superfluous heat. 6 Drink the juice
with woman's milk to help the old cough, the blistring of the lungs, and
spitting blood. 7 Take two drams of the juice with as much powder of Galls and
Olibanum, mix them well together, and drink it against vomiting of blood that
is of a bruise, and put thereof into the nose to stop the bleeding of it. 8
Drunkenness to avoid, eat Leekes raw. 9 Stamp Leekes with honey and apply
it to broken and bruised members to swage the swelling and consume the bruised
blood. 10 Sciatica, drink the juice. 11 Sores and wounds cold, and full of
rotten flesh, put in the juice. 12 Sciatica, or pain in the hips, anoint with
the juice of Leekes and Lilly roots. 13 The often eating of Leekes causes
headache, and thirst, burdeneth the stomach and inflameth the blood. 14 The
juice mixed with salt and laid on fresh wounds, does unclose them. 15 Lust to
cause, eat Leekes: for the old cough and dropsy, drink the juice with wine.
16 Headache, mix two parts of the juice with one part of honey, and drop it
into the nostrels and ears. 17 Seethe unset Leekes in white wine and butter,
and apply it hot on the belly iii. or iiii. times together to help the
chollike. 18 Distill the roots in June, and drink ii. ounces of the water
morn and even, against spitting up of cold blood. The same is good against
barrenness, being often drunk, and put into ye nose, stops the bleeding of
it, and being drunk, it loses the belly, helps the sciatica, purges ye
kidneis and bladder, causes urine, and expels the stone. 18 Wounds, wash
with ye water morn and even. 19 The same helps ye exulceration and fractures
of the matrix after childbirth being bathed or washed therewith morn and even.
20 Unset Leekes eaten with vinegar, are good for the stomach, and soften the
belly. 21 And eaten with honey, are good for the griefs of the breast, increase
natural seed, and are good for all kinds of ulcers and apostumes like as
Onyons are. 22 Headache, sees them in wine, and apply them to the forehead
and temples. 23 Hair not to fall, wash with ye juice. Put Leekes into
moldholes to make them come forth. 24 Drink the juice with honey against the
bitings of serpents and venomous beasts. 25 Stone to break, use the seeds in
medicines. 26 For the old cough, horsenesse, and to cleanse the breast, use the
juice in an Electuarie, or Lohoc. 27 Abath of Leekes sodden in salt sea water,
opens the stoppings of the matrix, and provoke terms, and softneth the
hardness of the matrix by sitting over it. 28 Nose bleeding, put in the blade
or juice with a little vinegar and fine powder of Frankincense, or with like
quantity of Myrtle berries, or Galls, or Mintes. 29 The juice with woman's
milk stops the issue that comes when a woman has had her birth before
her time. 30 Burning, apply the bruised leaves. 31 Ears griefs, use the
leaves with a Goats gall, or like portion of honied wine. 32 Leekes are good
for the Iaundies, and the dropsy. 33 Drink two ounces and a half with honey
to skowre the mother. 34 Leekes quench thirst, drive away drunkenness, and
soften the belly, provoke terms, scower the breast, void sour belchings, and
are good for a moist and slimie matrix, and are good to be used of them that
would have children. 35 Use them in a ptisand, or eat them raw every other
day fasting to clear the voice. 36 The heads twice sodden, and the water
changed, stop the belly. 37 The use of them hurts the teethe and gummes. 38
Fistula in the fundament, sit over the fume of the seeds. 39 Lick in the
seeds with honey for all griefs of the breast. 40 Apply Leekes with salt, to
take off crustes of sores. 41 Leekes are good for the Emerods, and such as have
cold stomachs, but not for them that are hot of nature. 42 Lips chopped,
anoint with ye ashes of Leekes mixed with honey. 43 Leekes are best sodde^, or
washed thrice before they be eaten. 44 Wounds, stamp them well with honey, and
apply it. 45 Cough, drink the juice by it self, or with woman's milk. 46 It
heals fractures, and takes away hardness. 47 To destroy the wild fire,
stamp Leekes heads on a shard over the fire to burn, and while they be moist
in the shard, apply them. 48 For all goutes, seethe Leekes and Otemeale with
sheep tallowe, and apply them hot. 49 Wounds or cuts, put in the juice of
Leeke heads with tents, and apply the dross upon it, and renew it every day
once, and after the third day mix hot milk with white wine, and apply it
with linen clothes, and do so every day til it be whole, and drink Bugle,
Pagle, and Goldin. 50 Stone and all griefs of the bladder, stamp Porrets of
unset Leekes, and sees them in ale or wine from a pottel to a quart, and
drink thereof ix. days morn and even with powder of Filipendula one ounce,
and be whole. 51 Chollike, stamp unset Leekes, and apply them to the navel.
52 Chollike and stone, drink the juice of unset Leekes, and of the beries of
Kneuel with stale Ale. 53 Emerods, stamp unset Leekes, and fry them with
sheep tallowe, and apply them as hot as may be suffered two or three times,
and be whole. 54 Belly and stomach swollen, stamp the heads, and drink them
with cold drink, and roast them in Docks and apply them hot to the breast and
navel. 55 Reins running, use pottage of water, otemeale and unset Leekes, and
anoint the reins with oil of roses: proved. 56 To stop issues of blood,
drink the juice. 57 Ears ache, sees the roots in urine, and put it in. 58
Seconds to cause, drink ye juice of Leekes and persley, with oil of
peniroyall. 59 Swellings inward, drink good store of the roots. 60 Spitting
blood, take ii. drams of leekeseedes and myrrh. 61 Belly-ache, apply the heads
sodden in oil. 62 Yard swollen, stamp them with fresh Bores grease, and apply
it. 63 Woman in travel, stamp the blades, and skald them in hot water, and
apply them to her navel hot, and when the child is out, say quicunque vult
thrice over her, and she shall be safe. 64 Emerods, apply leekes with salt. 65
Canker in any place, seethe a handful of unset Leekes with their roots with
xx. branches of Yarrowe in white wine till it be soft, then strain it and
clarify it, and drink it morn and even blood warm, and use local medicines
withal. 66 Chollike passion, stamp al ye white part of unset Leekes and fry
it with May butter, and apply it. 67 To heal wounds yt are bloody and
bleeding, stamp ye blades with unset Leekes, with honey and wheat flower, and use
it raw. 68 Ears running, drop in the juice of ye heads and roots with a little
vinegar. 69 Ears deaf and noise, put in ye juice with Cummin warm. 70
Teeth-ach, take up ye seeds of Leekes and Henbane sodden in water. 71 Stone
and griefs of ye bladder, stamp unset Leekes with their roots, and sees them
in wine or ale from a gallon to ye one half, and drink it ix. days with powder
of Filipendula. 72 Reins impost. sees the roots of Leekes and lillies with
hysope in milk, and use it. 73 Pissing blood, sees the heads and roots in
water to the third part, and drink it. 74 Yard swollen, apply a plaster of
Leeke blades about it all night. 75 Goutes general, sees Leekes, and stamp
them well, and put thereto otemeale greates, and sheep tallow, and boil them
well together, and apply thereof. 76 Apost. to break, sees ye roots with honey
and oil, and apply it. 77 Wounds, stamp the heads and roots with white wine
and swines grease, and apply it. 78 Emerodes, stamp mullin and Leeke beardes,
and fry them with May butter, and apply them hot in the nights. 79 Blood to
stop, put in the juice of Leekes with oil of roses and vinegar. 80 Emerodes,
stamp unset Leekes with a little honey, and apply it, or stamp unset Leeks,
Columbine, and red dock leaves roasted in the embers, and apply them, and be
whole in three days. proved. 81 Heart pain, stamp mints and unset Leeks, and
seethe them with vinegar, and apply them to the heart and stomach. 82 Nature
to restore, stamp Leeke heads very small, and seethe them in water with
marowbones, and the flesh withal, then break them a little, and boil them a
little more, then take out the marrow and put it into the pot again with
worts that have been boiled, then streine it, and put thereto powder of pepper,
ginger, cinamom and nutmegs, and eat thereof first and last. 83 Worms in
children, stamp unset Leeks, rosemary, and plantine, of each like much, and
seethe them in Malmesey, and apply it to the navel. 84 Pissing blood, boil
the heads and roots in water to the third part, and drink it. 85 Worms to
kill, stamp the blades with vinegar, and apply them to thy stomach, and sit in
thy warm bed. 86 The seeds also kill worms: the juice stops both the
flowers and afterbirth. 87 Deliverance to cause, drink the juice of Leekes
with warm water. 88 Seconds to cause, drink the juice of Borage, Leek blades,
and patsley roots with oil. 89 Glandules, scrophules, and kernels, stamp the
roots and apply them, and make ointment of the juice of the blades, oil and
wax, and anoint therewith. 90 Burnings, see the Leeks, and stamp them and
apply them. 91 Put nine or ten fresh Leeks on a thread and hang it about thy
neck, the blades vpwardes to stop the bleeding at the nose. 92 Nose polip,
mix the juice of vnsette Leekes, with green wax, and powder of Tartar, and
put it into the nose with a tent. 93 Hair falling, anoint the head with the
juice. 94 Coughs vehement, seethe the juice with oil and drink it. 95 To stop
the bleeding of Emerodes, drink the juice before breakfast. 96 Ears noise,
put in the juice with woman's milk. 97 Distill the roots in June in a
Limbecke, and apply the water with bombast to the ruptures of the matrix, and
bleeding of the nose. 98 Yard apostumes, seethe the blades with honey and oil
olive, and apply it. 99 Hoarsenesse coming suddenly of heat, or cold, hold
the juice of Leeks long and often in thy mouth. 100 Swelling by bloodletting,
fry the blades with oil, honey and wine, and apply them lukewarm. 101
Ptisick, and spitting of blood, drink the juice of Leeks boiled with oil. 102
Blood to stop, drink a violeful of the juice. 103 Deliverance to cause, scalde
the blades, and bind them to the navel, and remove it as soon as the child
is borne. 104 Gravel and stone, stamp the heads of unset Leekes and fry them
with life honey, and a little white wine or vinegar, and apply them to the
navel as hot as may be suffered.

Lentils.
LEntils: milk curded in the breast, use the seeds with sea water. 2 Kanker to
kill, apply water Lentils with Barrows grease. 3 Glandules or kernels, drink the
seeds with wine to expel them. (See Milk in Dill.) 4 Belly bound, use the
first decoction of Lentils. 5 Sees Lentils, and cast away the first water, and
sees them again in fresh water, and then they bind and dry, and are good
for the bloody flixe, and dangerous lasks, and excess of terms, especially
with some vinegar put thereto, or Cicory, or Purslan, or red Beets, or Mirtles,
or the rind of a Pomegranate, or seruises, or unripe binding pears, or dried
roses, or medlars, or quinces, or plantine, or whole gals, or the berries of
Sumach, the pil or shel of Lentils does the like and much better. 6 Swallow
down thirty grains of husked or hulled Lentils against the ouerturning of the
stomach. 7 Boil them with parched barley meal, and apply them to the ache of
the gout. 8 Their meal with honey cleanses and heals rotten sores and
ulcers. 9 Boil it with vinegar to dissolve Wens, and hard swellings strumaes.
10 With Mellilot, a quince, and oil of roses, they help the inflammations of
the eyes, and fundament, and with sea water it helps shingles, S. Anthonies
fire, and such like.

Ache 7 Belly bound 4 loose 5
Bloody flux 5 Breasts curded 1 Eyes inflamed 10 Flowers to stop 5 Fluxes 5
Fundament inflam. 10 Glandules 3 Gout 7 Hardness 9 Kanker 2 Kernels 3. 9
Kings evil 9 Sores 8 Shingles 10 S. Anthonies fire 10 Swellings 9 Stomach
turning 6 Ulcers 8 Wennes 9
Lettuce.
LEttuce does moysten and cool, and causes sleep, nourishes and breeds
good blood, it is better sodden then raw, except for the^ that are choleric. 2
Young Lettuce is good for the stomach, and increases milk in the breasts, but
when it is hard, it is both dry and bitter, and hotter, and breeds evil
blood, hurts the sight, and corrupts the sperme. 3 But being young, it
helps the ague, either raw or sodden being eaten. 4 Liver and milte stopped,
seethe it with vinegar and a little saffron, and eat it and drink the broth.
5 Liver and milte stopped, to breed good blood, and to help the fever tertian,
eat it raw or sodden with vinegar and sugar. 6 Dropsy, seethe it and mix it
with oil olive, and eat it with meats. 7 Stamp it with oil olive, and
apply it to apostumes to assuage them mightily. 8 Let milch women eat the
seeds to increase milk and amend the sight. 9 Drink the bruised seeds in wine
to cause sleep, and void venerious dreams, and abate lust. 10 Bruise the
seeds with the milk of a woman that has a woman child, and the white of an
egg, and apply it to the forehead and temples to procure sleep. 11 Drink the
bruised seeds with warm water for the ague. 12 Drink the seeds to stay the
shedding of nature speedily. 13 Drink the juice fasting, and thou shall not be
drunken that day. 13 Pluck up Lettuce with thy left hand before the sun rising,
and lay it under the covering of a sick man's bed, (he not knowing thereof)
to cause him him to sleep: or gather five, three, or one of the leaves next
the stalk, and lay them under his feet, and as many next to the top under
his boulster, he not knowing of it, to cause him to sleep: it is not good for
women with child, or would be with child, to use Lettuce much, because it
causes barrenness, and makes the children raging of mind, and foolish, and
the same is evil for them that be short winded, flegmatike, or spitte blood,
being much used, especially raw, and in Winter. 15 Eat Lettuce after supper
to cause sleep. Use Lettise with vinegar, salt and oil to provoke appetite,
to temper the heat of the blood, to mitigate the heat of the liver and heart,
but the often use of it, does greatly hinder the increase of sperme. 16 Use
Lettuce in Summer with oil, vinegar, salt and sugar, to temper the heat of
the stomach and liver, but it is better sodde^ in broths, or in water, with
some rocket, onions, leeks, or garlike. 17 The seed drunk with ale morn and
even, voydeth lust, evil dreams, and flowing of seed. 18 Apply the green
leaves bruised to burnings, and scaldings before they be blistered, and all
hot swellings, wild fire, and shingles, drink the seed with wine against
the stingings of scorpions. 19 Lettise may be laid up and kept in brine. 20
Apply the seed with oil of roses to the stomach, to destroy the hot
apostume there. 21 Drink the juice or powder of the seed to heal the flixe.
22 Breasts sore, sees Lettuce and apply it hot: lust to abate, use the seeds.
23 Headache, apply the juice of housleeke, Lettuce, and morel with vinegar. 24
Mad, use syrrop of the juice of Lettise and sugar. 25 Sleep to cause, seethe
Lettise in vinegar, and anoint thy forehead and temples therewith. 26 Sweating
too much, stamp linseed with Lettise, and apply them to thy stomach till thou
be well. 27 Cough of heat, and the urine red, make pottage with Lettuce, water
and butter, and eat them: for unkind heat of the stomach, drink Lettuce with
wine, or eat it daily. 28 Gomerpassion, drink the seeds with water. 29 Pissing
against will, drink powder of the seeds. 30 Canker fester, and fire of hell,
stamp Lettise with white vinegar, and apply it somewhat from the sore, and so
nearer and nearer. 31 Headache, mix oil of roses with vinegar, woman's milk,
and the juice of Lettuce, and apply it with linen cloth to the forhead and
temples, or stamp the seeds of Lettuce and smallach, with the white of an egg,
rose water, and woman's milk, and apply it to the forehead, temples and pulses.
32 Ears pain hot, apply bruised Lettuce. 33 Sleep to cause, mix the juice
with rose water and woman's milk, of each like much, and cast thereon powder of a
nutmeg, and apply it to the forehead and temples with a cloth. 34 Urine
burning, use the seeds. 35 Pissing bed, drink the seeds 36 Flux to stop,
make drink of the seeds of Lettuce, and white poppie, and use it. 37 Sleep to
cause, anoint the head and stomach with the juice and oil of roses. 38 Milk
to cause, eat Lettuce with butter.

Sweating too much 26 Swellings hot 18 Urine burning 34 Whites, See Gomor.

Lentiske or Masticke tree.
LEntiske, or Masticke tree: The leaves and bark stop the common laske, and
the bloody Flux, spitting blood, pissing blood, the Flux of the Matrix, and
all other fluxes of blood, and are good for the falling down of the Matrix and
fundament. 2 The Masticke is also good against spitting of blood, the common
Laske, the bloody flux, the flux of the Matrix, and all other issues of
blood from any part, it strengthens the stomach, stays vomiting, and
swageth all pain and griefs thereof, and reuiueth the appetite. 3 Being
chewed, it does dry and comfort the brain, stays the falling down of
rhewme, and humors, and causes a sweet breath. 4 Rub the teeth therewith
to make them white and fast, and to strengthen the gummes and jaws: no man can
reckon the virtues of Masticke, Rosen, Turpentine, and Pitche. 5 Masticke is
good in ointments to cleanse the face, and to make the skin white. 6
Turpentine, and also Rosen do cleanse wounds and sores both new and old,
and do soften all hardness and Apostumes in the body, and do heal all
manner of scabbes and deformities of the skin of man or beast. 7 Mix powder
of Masticke with the white of an egg, and anoint chappes therewith. 8 Swallowe
down three grains of Masticke every night when thou go to bed, to
preserve thee from pain of the stomach. 9 It is good in perfume against
corrupt air. 10 The pills thereof be of singular virtue against rhewme. 11
The oil thereof does much comfort the sinews, and does incarnate flesh. 12
And anointed on the head, helps the catharre or rhewme. 13 Teethach, mix
powder of Masticke, Coral, and galls with honey, and anoint or rub them
therewith. 14 Lungs griefs, drink powder of Mastick and sugar with cold water,
as the best medicine. 15 Nature or seed distilling, use powder of Masticke,
Olibanum, Storax and Cardamomum. 16 Blood to stop, mix powder of Aloes and
Mastick with the hair of a Hare, and the white of an egg, and apply it, or
cast on powder of Masticke, and Sanguis Draconis. 17 Mouth stink, wash it
first, and then chewe Masticke a good while. 18 Teeth ach, chewe Masticke with
wine. 19 Vomit to stop, apply it with the white of an egg to the stomach. 20
Apply it with wine, and the white of an egg to the temples, helps the
windy griefs of the head, and staieth the falling of rhewme. 21 Sees it in
water, and drink it to comfort the stomach, and make good digestion. 22 With
Fenell seed, it helps a windy stomach. 23 With bolarmoniack, the white of
an egg, and vinegar applied plaisterwise to the stomach, it restreineth the
choleric vanity. 24 Seethe it in rain water, and drink it to stop the
flux, boil it in rain water, or rosewater, and drink it to stop the flux
and vomiting, but it must be sodden but a little. 25 Plague, make powder of
mastick two ounces, euphorbium one ounce, spikenard five ounces, if thou be
under ten years old, take one scruple, from ten to twenty dram and a
half, from twenty upward one dram, and apply roasted fiueleafe to the sore,
as in fiueleafe, take it with drink. 26 To keep the teeth vncorrupt, eat
every morning some grains of masticke. 27 Chaps, anoint with masticke,
frankincense, new wax, and oil of roses. 28 For choleric or flegmatike
vomiting, take powder of masticke, and frankincense ana one dram, with the
yelke of a roasted egg every morning. 29 Boil anniseedes in white wine, and
dry them, and make thereof powder with masticke and cinamome of each like
much, and use it in meats for the cruditie of the stomach, and to avoid the
hicket. 39 Eyes blood, mix powder of masticke, and frankincense with the juice
of smallach, and the white of an egg, and apply it. 40 Vomit to stop, mix
powder of mastick and white frankincense, with rose leaves, and the juice of
mints and apply it to the stomach. 41 Make fine powder of white pibble stones,
found by the water one ounce, mastick a dram, and rub thy teeth therewith
exactly every fortnight once to keep them clean. 42 Take oil of roses twelve
ounces, good wine 8. ounces, mastick three ounces, seethe them in a double
vessel, it comfort the stomach, liver, sinews and joints, it softneth hard
apostumes, and swageth aches, and is right precious. 43 Chew mastick gently to
cleanse the head and brain, and to help the toothach, or take up the vapors of
it. 44 It stops vomiting, spitting blood, and casting blood. 45 Burn gum
arabic and mastick, of each like much on a tile, and mix it with flower and
make thy bread thereof, and use it for the bloody flux. 46 Face scabs, and
filthy sores, put three eggs into strong vinegar four or five days till they
be soft, then put thereto powder of masticke, and frankincense of each three
ounces and a half, and spread thereof on a linen cloth, and apply it without
removing till it fall off, and the scabbes with it. 47 Pissing blood, bleed in
the inner saphene vein if need be, and mix powder of Masticke and Olibanum
of each like much with whites of Eggs and oil of Roses, and apply it to the
reins. 48 Heart griefs, use to eat one grain of Masticke with Sugar. 49
Liver griefs, sees Masticke and Madder in water and drink it, it keeps a
man from all sickness of the Liver and stomach. 50 Wounds to heal, melt
Colophony and Masticke with sheep sewet and wax ana, and use it. 51 Liver to
comfort, use Masticke. 52 Vomit to stop, melt Masticke in a vessel, and
apply it on a cloth to the pit of the stomach, and in like sort it heals
wounds. 53 Stomach cold, take a Pyll of Masticke before meals. 54 Masticke
helps against the spitting of blood and all fluxes white and red, the terms
and ulcers of the intrals, it resolves impostumes of the stomach, and is good
for the Cough. 55 Lips chapt, anoint with Masticke, new wax, Frankincence and
oil of Roses made into an ointment to heal them presently.

Licium.
LIcium stops the laske, the bloody sluxe, spitting blood and the Cough. It
stops the terms either taken inward or applied outward. It is good against
corrupt Ulcers and running skabs, and running ears, the inflammation of the
Gums and Almonds under the tongue, and the chaps of the lips and fundament
being applied. It clears the sight, and cures the skuruie festered sores of
the eyelids and corners of the eyes: it makes the hairs Yellowe, it dries
moist skabs, and is good for them that are bitten of a mad dog. It stops
both the red and white flowers.

Bitings venomous Bloody flux Chaps Eyes dull Flowers to stop Fluxes general
Fundament chaps Hair to color Lips chapt Mad dog Mouth sores Skabs Sores
Spitting blood Ulcers Whites
Licoras.
LIcoras: The root is good against the roughness of the throat and breast, it
opens and cleanses Lungs that be stuffed and laden, it ripeneth the cough, and
brings forth phlegm being chewed, and so does the juice of the root taken
in like sort, and for the same cause they make a kind of small cakes or bread
against the Cough with the juice of Lycoras mixed with Ginger and other spices:
but the same serves but for old and cold Coughs and like infirmities of the
Lungs. 2 The root quenches thirst, and does cool and comfort the hot and
dry stomach, and is good for the diseases of the Liver either chewed or
drunk in a decoction. 3 The same is good against the ulcers of the kidneis and
skabs, and sores of the Bladder: It cures the sharpness and smarting of the
vrin, and also the filthy corruption and mattering of the same, being boiled
in water and drunk often. 4 The same with Honey heals sores and ulcers. 5
Licoras and the juice thereof is good and wholesome to swage pain, and for all
griefs of the Lungs, kidneys and bladder. 6 Throat rough, hold the juice under
the tongue. 7 For the heat of the stomach breast and liver, skabs of the
bladder and pain of the kidneis, drink it with malmsie. 8 It heals wounds,
griefs of the mouth, quenches thirst, helps the cough and hoarcenesse, and
softeneth impostumes. 9 The fine powder of it put into ye ears, helps the
running and sores thereof. 10 With wine and Honey it heals wounds both inward
and outward. 11 The yelowest and moystest is best. 13 For all griefs of the
breast, and for the cough, seethe it with smallach seeds in water and drink
it. 14 Take Licoras scraped and bruised, powdered half a pound, seethe it with
a Gallon of new Wurt in an earthen pot with Suger-rosset one dram, powder of
Ginger, two ounces, clarified Honey one pound, seethe it to the one half, and
streine it and use it at even hot, and at morn cold for the Cough. 15 Heart
burning, chewe Licoras and swallow down the juice and spit out the rest. 16
Pipes stopped, sees Anniseeds and Licoras in water to the one half, and streine
it and drink it at even hot, and at morn cold. 17 Breast or ribs impostumed
or plurisie, sees it in water and use it, or the juice of it. Reins and back
to purge and heal, drink the powder with water that Centory has been sodden
in. 18 A dredge powder: take fine powder of Licoras and Anniseeds of each one
pound, sugar candy two pound, Peper and Ginger of each two ounces: mix them and
use it for most inward griefs. 19 Scrophules, swelling, stamp Licoras and
apply it. 20 Reume, hold two pieces of an inch long and as thick as a Barley
corn between thy gums and cheek on either side one all night, fifteen
nights to dry it up. 21 Sickness sudden in the stomach and breast, put a
spoonefull of powder of Lycoras to a spoonefull of Aqua vite three hours, and
drink it fasting or to bedward. 22 Lungs stuffed, mix powder of Lycoras,
Aniseedes and sugar, with sack possit ale, and drink it fasting. (See Beans,
Fennel, Elecampana, Guiacum.) 23 Fevers general, sees a quart of white
vinegar with Saunders and Lycoras, of each one peni worth to the one half, and
drink a spoonefull or two at once.

stopped 1. 16. 22

Lyllie.
Lyllye: The oil of white Lyllies softneth the Matrixe. 2 The sodden root
does ripen hard Apostumes. 3 The root roasted, with Rose water heals the
holy fire, and increases flesh in wounds. 4 The root sodden and mixed with
swines grease or oil Olive, softneth impostumes mightily. 5 Take the roots of
white Lyllies, marsh Mallows and Brankursin of each a quarter of a pound,
bruise them well with four measures of wine, and sees them with half a pint
of oil Olive, unto a thickness, then streine it and put thereto a little Wax,
and use this ointment for the hardness and pain of the Milt. 6 Burnings,
sees the roots tender, and after seethe them with oil of Roses and annoint
therewith. 7 Seethe the root in wine and drink it to bedward to purge the
body downward from noisome humors. 8 Wounds to heal, seethe the leaves in
vinegar and apply them. 9 Senewes loose or cut, apply the roasted roots with
Honey. 10 The flowers is evil for the plague. 11 The ointment of Lillies
softeneth the senowes well, and the hardness of the Matrixe. 12 Apply the
leaves to the stingings of Serpents. 13 The same made hot, are good for burned
places. 14 The juice sodden with Honey and vinegar in a brazen vessel, is a
good medicine for old sores and green wounds. 15 Roste the root and mix it
with oil of Roses to heal burnings, to soften the Matrixe, to bring down the
terms, and to cover wounds with a skin, and with Honey it heals cut
senowes and places out of joint, skurfe, skales, skabs, lepries: It skowreth
away running sores in the head and face, it takes away wrinckles. 16 And
brayed with Henbane leaves, wheat meal and vinegar, it swageth the
inflammation of the stones. 17 The seeds drunk, is a remedy against the
bitings of Serpents. 18 The leaves and seeds are good to be laid to
inflammations and Shingles, or holy fire. 19 The water restores the voice that
is lost, and is good for feebleness or faintness deing drunk three or four
spoones full at once. 20 The water of the root is excellent good against the
inflammation of the Liver, the dropsy, and the pain of women in travel. 21
The oil of Lillies is good against all hot aches, burnings, and Carbuncles:
especially the leaves of the flowers being applied after the anointing. 22 The
flowers are the best part, then the roots, and then the leaves. 23 The roasted
root with Honey and vinegar, heals all deformities of the skin in the head,
face or body. 24 Stamp the root with Henbane and Barley meal, and apply it to
all inflammations and aches, hardness and swellings, or ulcers in the hands,
cods or elsewhere: some seethe the roots in Goats milk for all the same
purposes, and for the swelling of the Paps and Genitors. 25 The fresh leaves
are good for the holy fire, black pushes or whelks and the stingings of
Scorpions. 26 The root sodden in Honied water and drunk, drives out by
seege, all corruption of blood. 27 Sees the root in vinegar, and apply it to
corns of the feet three days without remoouing to take them away. 28 The
same mixed with oil or grease and applied, brings hair again upon burnings
or skaldings. 29 The roasted root with oil of Roses, is good for all foul
breaking out, and the wild fire, for burnings, and to close up ulcers: the
leaves have the same virtues, and are good also to be laid to the bitings of
Serpents. 30 With the flowers is made a good ointment or oil to supple and
soften the senowes, and hardness of the Matrixe. 31 The root sodden in water,
takes away redness in the face being dressed therewith morn and even, so
does the juice of the root mixed with vinegar and used ten days. 32 Lyllies
and Roses planted together, will both smell the pleasanter. 33 Wash a root and
sees it in white wine to the one half, and drink thereof against the
pestilence, and thou shall be full of blisters as if thou skalded, and they
will dry up of themselves and become whole. 34 The roasted root applied hot,
breaks the plague sore or botch. 35 Stamp it with tallow or oil to ripen
and break apostumes. 36 Stamp good store of the root with Docke seeds and
Louage roots, and steep them nine days in oil, then seethe it and streine
it, and put wax to it and anoint the sore and hard milt therewith. 37 The
juice heals the venom of Addars and wounds, 38 Roste the root and mix it
with oil Olive to heal burnings. 39 Drink it with ale, wine or beer against
many diseases, and to comfort the senowes. 40 To draw out any prick, or an
arrowe head, stamp the root and seethe it in wine and apply it three days.
41 For all spots and wrinckles of the face, roste the root and use it with
other ointments or with oil of Roses. 42 Dropsy, knead cakes of Rye meal
with the juice of the roots, and bake them under an earthen bake-pan, and lay
them to the belly hot one after another often. 43 Fellon, drink the juice of
Matfelon and of Lyllie, of each three spoones full at once, and dip clothes
therein, and apply them. 44 Apost. stamp Brankursin and Lyllie roots with oil
and apply them. 45 Pissing against will, sees the roots in water and apply
them to the reins. 46 Squincy, apply the roots with Mallows and May butter.
47 Vrin stopped, sees Lyllies in wine and drink it. 48 To heal a wound that no
print shall be seen of it, Roste the roots and grind them with old swines
grease, and when the wound is healed, anoint therewith often. 49 Face skabby
and skelfering cheeks that will not heal, roste Onyons and Lylly roots of
each like much, cleanse them, stamp them and streine them, and put thereto oil
of Roses and anoint. 50 To cause an easy sweat, lay under thy feet the
leaves and flowers of Eldren, and Lyllie leaves, of each two handfuls, and lie
on thy back upon them to sleep. 51 Iaundies, drink water of Lyllyes. 52
Apostume to break, boil the root and an Onyon, and stamp them and frye them
with swines grease and apply it hot. 53 Matrixe hard, fry the roots in oil,
and apply them. 54 Face and hands to be white, stamp the roots of Louage and
Lillies, and seethe them in water till the third part be wasted, and wash often
therewith. 55 Ears dull and impost. roste a Lyllye root and apply it. 56
Mother suffoc. anoint with oil of Lyllies. 57 Eyes Hawe, put in the juice of
the root. 58 Matrixe hard, seethe the juice with oil and anoint therewith. 59
Matrixe griefs general, use the oil. 60 Skabs, leaprie, and plowks, stamp
the leaves and apply them. 61 Face red, sees the roots in water, and wash
therewith morn and even, or mix the juice of the root with vinegar, of each
like much, and anoint therewith nine nights. 62 Byles, Fellons and Vncomes,
mix Honey with wheat flower, woman's milk, black soap and Lyllie roots and
apply it, and when it is broken, heal it with other salues. 63 To break a
sore breast, sees the roots in milk with leven till it be tender, and apply
it hot morn and even, and when it is broken, stamp a handful of Parsley
with a piece of fat Bakon, and the Yolke of an Egg, and apply it to heal it.
64 Sores old, boil the juice of the leaves, with as much Honey and vinegar as
the juice, and apply it. 65 Strangurie, sees the roots in white wine and
drink it. 66 Face sauce phlegm, sees Lyllyes in water, and wash therewith
three days. 67 Sores, sees thee roots with Otemeale greats in milk till it
be thick as a Plaster, and use it three days.

Lignum aloes.
LIgnum aloes: Head and brain weak and cold, use the fume of it: Milt
griefs, take as much of the powder of it as will lie on a groat with broth or
wine fasting three mornings, etc.

Limons.
LImons: Freckle, wash with the juice and Bay salt, and let it dry in as often
as need is. 2 Sees rain water with as much verges to the one half, and as
it seetheth, fill it up with the juice of Limons, and when it is cold, put to
it the Whites of four new laid eggs beaten together and use it against all
sunburning and filthiness, and staining of the skin. 3 For steines of the
hands, wash with the juice of Limons and a little Bay salt, and so it helps
skabs and skurfe. Plague, drink the juice with wine, and powder of Angelica. 4
Skin to be white, and to void freckles, etc. see before in vergis and rain
water. 5 Teethe to be white, distill Limons, and wash them with the water or
with the juice. The same takes spots out of woollen and sunburning. 6 For
gravel and pissing blood, drink one ounce of the juice of green Limons with
iii. ounces of Malmsey when the grief comes. 7 Put a piece of gold, or the
leaves of gold into the juice of Limons, 12. hours, then drink the juice with
white wine, and powder of Angelica, or the decoction of the root of it against
the plague, though it seem that all hope of remedy be past. Wash thy hands
with the juice of Limons and Baysalt, and let it dry in by it self, and after
wash with cunduit water, to make them white and soft, and to avoid all
deformities of them. 8 Stone, drink the juice of Limons with white or renish
wine and sugar fasting thrice a week, to strengthen the heart, stomach and
wits, to resist poison, to expel melancholy, and cause a sweet breath. (See
Oringes, Citrons.) Face cleansing, lay Limons in butter milk, and wash
therewith.

Face freckles etc. 1. 2. 3. 7 Freckles 1 Hands foul 2. 3. 7 Heart weak 8
Gravel 6 (See Stone.) Melancholy 8 Memory ill 8 Plague 3. 7 Poison 8 Pissing
blood 6 Skin deformed 1. 2. 3. 7 Sunburning 2. etc. Steines 5 Stomach weak 8
Stone 8 Teeth foul 5
Liuerwort.
LIuerwort cleanses the hardness of the liver: and is good for the fever
quarten, and with fresh grease it heals wounds. 2 Stamp as much as an egg,
and apply it one night to the region of the liver (but not to the stomach) for
the griefs of the liver, and for all vncomes and unkind heates, blaines,
blisters, swellings and inflammations one night, and after anoint with new
vnguentum album. 3 Liver chafed, kneade thy bread with the juice of Sorell, and
Liuerwort, and apply the dross to the place. 4 Liver griefs general, seethe
Liuerwort and the juice of Smallach in wine or water and drink it. 5 Liver
corrupt and wasted, bruise it a little and seethe it in strong wort, with some
Rubarbe, and use it till you be well. (See in Lungwort, Goosetansy, Fumiterre,
Hearts tongue. 6 For ruptures and chaps, drink it with wine daily. For the
unkind heat of ye liver, sees it with Fumiterre and Hearts tongue in wheye,
and clarify it and drink it morn and even. 7 Liver stopped and inflamed, the
fever tertian, and inflammation of the blood, use ye decoction of it. 8 Wounds
bleeding, bruise it and apply it to stop the blood, and to keep it from
inflammation and impostumation. 9 Apply it with honey to all skurfes, spreading
skabs, burnings, pockes, wild fire, and burning with iron. 10 Reume to stop,
boil it in water, and hold it in thy mouth often.

Blaines 2 Blisters 2 Blood to stop 8 Burnings 9 Bursten Chaps 6 Fever quarten
1 tertian 7 Inflammation 2 Liver griefs 2. 3. 4. 5 Pockes 9 Reume 10 Skabs 9
Swellings 2. 8 Vncomes 2 Wild fire 9 Wounds 1. 8
Long rape.
LOng rape, Nauewe, or Nauet gentle, is in nature much like Turnips. The seed
is good against poison, and therefore used in Treacles, and preservatives. 2
The roots sodden and preserved in salt, are wholesome to be eaten. 3 They
sharpen the sight, smoothe the breast and throat, and heat the kidneis. They
be best twice sodden.

Breast to smoothe 3 Eyes dull 3 Poison 1 Throat rough 3
Louage.
LOuage: The seeds may well be kept three years. 2 Drink the seeds fasting
to purge both upward and downward. 3 And use them in glisters to ease ye gout
in the feet. 4 Steep them one night in wine, and drink it to expel the
terms, and dead youngling, but because the seeds be very strong, the seeds
of Anise and Fenell may be mixed with them in like weight. 5 Use the herb in
bathes, and rub well the body therewith to open the pores and draw forth
evil humors. 6 Seethe the seeds in wine or water, and drink it to open the
stopping of the milt. 7 Bruise the seeds with Cummin seeds, and drink them
in wine to mende the stomach and avoid wind in the belly. 8 Bruise the
seeds, and seethe them in wine with Galingale and Cinamom, to help the
griefs of the stomach, milt, and bowels, the pain in the belly etc. 9. Sees
the seeds in wine, and drink it to void pain in the belly, swelling in the
stomach, the bitings of Snakes and Adders, and to provoke urine and terms. 10
Drink two or three drams of the distilled water morn and even for the griping
of the sides and stomach, the griefs of the stone, kidneis, and bladder,
hoarsenesse, and the dangerous swelling in the throat called the Squincie, and
wash the face therewith morn and even to make it fair. 11 The decoction of
the root, seed, or herb in wine or barley water, cleanses the lungs,
passages of the urine and terms, and does heal inward wounds. 12 Apostume and
hardness, seethe it and apply it. 13 Dead child, apply it warm to the belly
to expel it. 14 To skowre the reins and milt, to expel wind, and mende the
liver, drink powder of the seeds with some thin broth, or pearcing wine,
and so it expels the seconds. 15 The seeds eaten alone provoke vomit, but
used with Rue, it is good for the dropsy. 16 Let women drink the decoction of
the root for the health of the matrixe, belly, precordials and breast, it
warmeth and makes good concoction. 17 The powder of the root is as good sause
to all meats as Pepper that is brought out of far Countries. It is good for
a cold stomach, it helps digestion. 18 Drink half a dram of the root
in powder with good wine to cease inward pain, to expel urine, terms,
poison, and all things that Angelica serves for: the seed is more hot and
effectual in all things. 19 Iaundies, and Plurisie, gargarise with the water,
and also drink thereof. 20 The root may be condited in Vinegar and Salt, as
the root of Elecampana, and other herbs, and kept in store. 21 Bathe in the
decoction of Louage to expel the stone and urine, and to heat all inward
parts. 22 Stamp the root or seed, and apply it to any venomous bitings, or
stingings of mad dogs, or serpents. 23 Teeming women, use the roots and leaves
in meat and drink, and sweating bathes, that they may be purged rightly after
childebirth. 24 The Squincie is healed by continual drinking of the water of
it through the stalk of it. 25 The water cleanses the face and skin from
all blackenesse, spots, bruises, skarres, skabbes, and such like, being often
washed therewith, and it helps the exulceration of the mouth, throat,
fundament, and priuities, being applied with linen clothes. (See Angelica,
Parsley, and Smallage: for Louage is much of like nature to them.) 26 Use
powder thereof with powder of Cinamom for the windiness and ache of the
stomach and guts. 27 The root is good for all inward diseases, and so is the
seed, and may be used for Pepper. 28 The infusion or decoction of the seeds
with as much Fenell seed, or Aniseede streyned and drunk, works in purging
the body as does Parsley and Fennel. 29 Legs red, stamp the leaves and
stalks, and distill them in a Limbek, and bathe with the water, and apply it
with linen clothes. 30 Emerods, stamp Louage and Rue with honey, and frye them
and apply them. 3 Seethe it with Yarrowe in wine, till the third part be
washed, and drink it to strengthen the stomach. 32 Thirst to void, seethe
the root in wine or water, and drink it three days. (See Lilly, Centory.)
33 Knees swollen, stamp it with Rue and Honey, and apply it. 34 Face to cleanse
and to make it white, mix the root with water and wash therewith, or drink
Borage in wine. 35 Rising in sleep, bear the seeds about thy neck. 36 Liver
and milt griefs, use the water or decoction thereof. Knees-ache sore and
swollen, apply it with rue, and honey thrice. 37 For the host, stamp the roots
and streine them with water, and drink it when thou go to bed. 38 Bladder
griefs, stamp Parsley, Louage, and Fenell, and drink them with water to
avoid urine well.

Linden tree.
LInden tree: for filthy sores of childrens mouths, Seethe the leaves in
water, and wash therewith. 2 Feet swollen, stamp the leaves and apply them. 3
Skabs and white skurfe, stamp the bark with vinegar, and use it. 4 Belly-ache
by the bloody flux, drink the distilled water of it. 5 Burnings with tough
humors on them, seethe the inner bark in vinegar, and use it. 6 The coals of
it are good to make Gunpowder. 7 The distilled water is good for the falling
evil.

Belly-ache Bloody flux Burnings Falling evil 7 Feet swollen 2 Gunpowder 6
Mouth sores 1 Skabs 3 Skurfe 3
Lungwort.
LVngwort of the Oak, or of the ground made into powder and drunk with water,
is good for the inflammations and ulcers of the lungs. 2 Wounds bleeding, cast
in the powder to stop them and heal them. 3 Boil it in wine and drink it to
stop the spitting of blood, pissing blood, the flowers, the flux and
bloody-fluxe. 4 That of the oak joins and heals green wounds, especially
of the lungs. 5 Take Lungwott iiii. drams, Aniseedes, Fenelseedes, and Licoras,
ana ii. drams, ye lungs of a Fox i. dram, Elecampana a dram and an half, Sugar
one ounce, make them into a fine powder, and take a spoonefull every day morn
and even with wheye, for griefs of the lungs. 6 Coussips of Bedlem is much of
like nature. 7 Hoarsenesse, take Lungwort, Liuerwort, and Horehound, of each
one handful, bruise them and boil them in oil, and streine it, and put sugar candy to it, and drink it warm morn and even. 8 Emerods, sees it in wine,
and bathe them therewith, and apply the herb to destroy them.

Bleeding 2 Bloody-fluxe 3 Emerods 8 Flowers to stop 3 Fluxes 3 Hoarsenesse 7
Lungs-griefes 1. 4. 5. 7 Pissing blood 3 Spitting blood 3
Lupines.
LVpines: hair to fall and grow no more, apply the branne. 2 Morphue, mix
powder of Lupines and mint leaves with vinegar, and anoint. 3 Worms, use the
juice of Lupines. Head fistula, sees bitter Lupines in salt water, and put
vinegar to it, and streine it, and put in powder of Germander, and wash
therewith. 4 Worms, apply ye meal with as much ox gall as will thicken it to
the belly, with wool as often as need is. 5 Worms in children, kneade ye
meal with honey, and apply it to the navel. 6 Hands skab, wash with ye broth
of Lupines. Nauel swollen, (see in Flax.) 7 Belly worms and leanenesse of
body, mix ye gall of a Cow with a little meal of Lupines, and apply it with
wool iiii. or v. days. 8 Their meal taken with honey or with water and
vinegar, does kill and expel all kinds of worms, and so does the decoction
thereof drunk, or stamped and applied to the navel fasting. 9 The decoction of
Lupines boiled with Rue, and Pepper, and drunk, opens the liver and milt. 10
A pessarie of Lupines, Myrrh, and honey mixed together, draws down the
terms, seconds, and dead birth. 11 The decoction of Lupines does beautify
the face, and drives away all freckles, spots, and lentiles, and so does the
meal applied with water. 12 The meal, with meal of parched barley and water,
swageth all apostumes and swellings. 13 The same boiled with vinegar, swageth
the pain of the sciatica, dissolueth and consumes the kings evil or swelling
in the throat. It opens and breaks wens, botches, biles, and plaguesores.
14 Soke them long in water, till they have lost their strength or bitterness,
and then they may be eaten, and so they take away the lothsomenesse of the
stomach, and desire to vomit, and cause appetite, but they engender gross
humors. 15 The roots sodden in water provoke urine. 16 The smoke of Lupines
burned, drives away gnats. Seethe Lupines in rain water till they be broken,
and streine it when it is cold, wash the face with it to take away all
foulness and spots. 17 Cankers to kill, apply the herb and seed with
swines grease, vinegar, and brimstone, and so it also heals skales of the
head. 18 Sees it in Parsley water and drink it to cleanse the bladder and
provoke urine. 19 Drink it with vinegar to cleanse the stomach, help
digestion, and void lothing. 20 Eat the powder with vinegar or honey, to drive
all worms out of the body, or seethe it with Rue and Pepper in water, and
drink it, and so it opens the liver and milt. 21 For all kind of skabs,
skalles, gangrenes, pushes, whelkes, pockes, and other deformities of ye face,
skin, and for spreading sores of ye head, wash with water of ye decoction of
Lupines. 22 Rub ye lower part of any tree with meal of Lupines, and there will
no pismires come thereon.

Linaria.
LInaria: wild flax, or tode flax, for the old and cold stopping of the
liver and milt, and the old Iaundies without Fevers, use the decoction of it.
It helps all the stopping of the bladder, when the urine passes by drops,
and the kidneis, and provoke urine well. 2 Seethe the flowers and roots in
water, and drink iiii. ounces morn and even to skowre the reins and bladder.
3 Urine flux, stamp it and apply it, from the navel downward, to the nether
end of the belly.

Bladder stopped 1. 3 Iaundies 1 Kidneis stopped 1. 2 Liver stopped 1 Milt stopped 9.
20 Urine flux 3 Urine stopped 1. 3
Maces.
MAces be in virtue almost like to Nutmegs, and do stop the laske, the bloody
flux, and flowers. It helps the trembling of the heart, and is much better
for all cold griefs then Nutmegs. 2 The oil of Mace laid on the stomach
cures the infirmity thereof, and the wambling, and disposition to vomit. It
causes appetite, and helps digestion. 3 Used in meats, they are good for
the stomach, and a restoratiue, being used in brothes, cullisses, or milk,
and are very good to be drunk against spetting of blood, bloody fluxes,
excessive laske, and the chollick. 4 Seethe it in wine, and drink it for the
coldness of the stomach to help digestion. 5 Mix the fine powder of it with
oil of Roses and wax, and apply it to the stomach for the feebleness
thereof. 6 Chewe them to strengthen the brain. 7 Boil them in the juice of
Fennel, and in the end put thereto a little wine, and strein it, and drink it
for the weakness and coldness of the stomach and liver, the chollicke and all
griefs of the spiritual members, and for the ache of the heart as the best
medicine, and use their powder in meats and drinks. 8 Mouth griefs, seethe
them in white wine and drink it, or eat Maces often, and drink a little wine
to it to void the stink of the mouth. 9 Brain to restore, chew them. 10 Make
powder of a Pomegranate, large Mace, long Pepper, and Sugar, and drink it with
possit ale, or Malmsey, or other broth sodden together for the black iaundies:
proved. 11 Reume, bind powder of Cubebs and Maces in a cloth, and hold them in
thy mouth. (See Cloves) 12 Megrem of phlegm, cause sneesing with Maces and oil
of Violets.

Appetite 2 Black iaundies 10 Bloody flux 1. 3 Brain weak 6. 9 Chollick 3.
7 Consumption 7. 3 Digestion 2. 4 Flowers to stop 1. 3 Fluxes 1. 3 Heart ache
7. trembling 1. Laske 1. 3 Liver weak 7 Megrem 12 Mouth stink 8 Restoratiue 3
Reume 11 Sickness general 7 Spetting blood 3 Stomach cold 4. 5. 7. griefs
2. 3. 5. 7.
Madder.
MAdder. The root is sharp and bitter, and therefore purges the liver and the
milt, provoke much gross, and sometimes bloody vrines, and scowreth meanly,
and helps the yelowe Iaundies, the Sciatica and loose members. 2 Seethe it
with Masticke in water, and drink it to preserve thee from all griefs of the
stomach and liver. 3 It cleanses the liver, milt, kidneys and matrix very
well, expels gross urine, the terms, seconds and birth being put into the
convenient place. It expels the stone, and is good to be drunk against
bruses and pestilence. 4 Drunk with sweet water, it helps the iaundies. 5 The
root sodden cleanses the liver, gall, milt, urine, matrix, bruses and pains of
the joints, especially the sciatica. 6 With vinegar it takes away the white
spots or white morphue. With Mellicrate it is good for the palsy. 7 Seethe it
in wine and drink it for the weakness of the stomach and liver. Water of the
decoction thereof colors hairs red. It keeps all the parts of the body
from putrefaction, and cures the morphue. 8 For the iliak, take it with honey
and hot water. 9 To provoke the flowers, steep it in wine xxiiii. hours, and
drink the wine. Arms sore, seethe Madder and Roch Allom in conduit water from
a pottell to a pint, and wash therewith to have help though it be in the
marowe. 10 For the marmall, anoint it with oil Olive, and by and by lay to a
Planten leaf: and every morning wash the sore with Madder water. For pricks,
boil powder of the roots with oil Olive and apply it or anoint. 11 A red
water for sores old or new, take running water a pottell, ashes of old Ash
wood, tan oose that lether never came in a pottell, Madder and Allom of each
one pound in fine powder, steep them together ten days, then put thereto ten
ounces of green copres, and one ounce of Ginger, and seethe it to a quart,
then strein it and wash with the water, and use the rest plasterwise. 12 Worms
to kill, drink Madder. 13 Seethe it in whey with Paunces, called Herba
trinitatis, and give it to swine for many diseases, as botches, byles, and
soreness in their throats. 14 Matrixe coming out, wash it with the juice or
decoction of Madder. 15 Flowers to cause, seethe it in White wine and drink it
with Triphera magna. 16 Head megrem, mix powder of Madder with Rye flower and
aquavitae and apply it.

Ache 5. 9 Arms sore 9 Bellyache 8 Byles 13 Bruses 3 Coloring red 3
Deliverance 3 Flowers stopped 3. 9. 15 Head megrem 16 Iaundies 1. 4 Iliak passion
8 Joints loose 1. 5 Kidneys griefs 3 Liver griefs 1. 2. 5. 6. Matrixe fallen
14. griefs 3. Milt griefs 1. 5 Marmall 10 Morphue 6. 7 Palsy 6 Plague 3
Pricks 10 Sciatica 1. 5 Seconds 3 Sickness general 7 Sores 9. 10. 11 Stomach
bad 2. 7 Stone 3 Swines griefs 13 Throat sore 13 Urine stopped 1. 3. 5 Worms 12
Maidenhaire.
MAidenhaire, Capillus veneris. Seethe it in wine, and drink it for shortness
and straitness of breath, the hard and uneasy cough, and to cause easy
spetting. 2 It stops the flux and spetting of blood, provoke urine,
provoke terms, breaks the stone, expels the seconds, vnstoppeth the
liver and milt, helps the griefs of the milt, and the yelowe iaundies, all
fluxions and moystnesse of the stomach, and bitings and stingings of venomous
beasts. 3 Bitings of mad dogs and venomous beasts, stamp it green and
apply it. 4 It restores hair, dispatcheth the strume or swellings in
childrens throats. 5 Head scurfe and scales, steep it in lee, or seethe it,
and wash therewith. 6 Headache, wear a garland of it, or a quilted cap of it
about the head. 7 The leaves of Adianthum or Wall Rue mixed with a little Salt
peter, and the vrin of a young child, takes away the shriueled wrincklings yt
appear on women's bellies after their deliverance being washed therewith. 8
Venus hair drives away wens and scrophules. 9 Given in meat to quails it
makes them to fight well. 10 The broth wherewith i. li. of ye green herb has
been sodden purges yelow choler and phlegm from the breast and stomach. 11
Tricomanes, Polytricon or English Maidenhaire has the same virtues that
Capillus veneris has being sodden with wine or Hydromell, and drunk daily, it
helps the obstructions of the liver, the iaundies, griefs of the lungs,
difficulties of breath, it voydeth melancholy by urine, it softneth the
hardness and swelling of the milt, expels poison, that has been drunk,
and the flowers and seconds, and breaks the stone.

Bitings venomous 2. 3 Breath short 1. 11 Cough 1 Flowers stopped 2. 11 Flux 2
Head scurfe 5. head scalls 5. ache 6. Hair to grow 4 Iaundies 2. 11 Kernels 4
Liver grief 2. 11 Lungs grief 11 Melancholy 11 Milt grief 2. 11 Mad dog 3
Obstructions 11 Poison 11 Purgation 10 Quails 9 Scrophules 8 Seconds 2. 11
Spetting blood 2 Stomach raw 2 Stone 2. 11 Throat swollen 4. 8 Urine stopped 2
Wennes 8 Women's griefs 7. 8 Wrinckles 8
Marierom.
MArierom. It is to be gathered when it flowreth, and dried in the shadow, and
may be kept a year. 2 Headache grievous, seethe it in lee, and wash the head
therewith. 3 Stomach cold and lack of digestion, use powder of it in meat or
wine. 4 Black and blew spots, mix powder of the leaves with honey, and anoint
therewith. 5 Marierom comfort the brain, opens obstructions, and cures
the apoplexia. 6 The oil of it heateth the members both inward and outward,
the joints, sinews and matrix being applied warm. It helps all griefs,
comfort the brain, and all members of the body. 7 Marierom heateth all the
inner members, softeneth the milt, and swageth the swelling thereof. 8 For the
dropsy in the beginning, griping in the body, and to provoke urine, seethe the
herb and drink it. 9 Stomach pain, apply the herb and flowers in a bag. 10
Head to cleanse, put the powder of it into the nose. 11 Matrix to cleanse, sit
over the vapor of it sodden in water. 12 Flowers to cause, put in the herb as
a pessary. 13 For the ache, swellings and looseness of joints or members,
apply the herb with wax to strengthen them, and to help other griefs of
them. 14 Reume to stop, and to cause sneesing, blow in powder of it with
vinegar. 15 Use it in sallads to comfort the stomach marueilously. 16 The
juice drawn into the nose, to comfort the brain, cause sneesing, to revive
them that have the lethargy and the falling evil. 18 Speech lost, strike the
water of it on the tongue. 19 To comfort the brain and memory, drink the
water three or four ounces morn and even daily, use the herb as other pot
herbs for all meats. 20 Stamp Marierom with barley flower, and apply it to
the ache, inflammation and swelling of the eyes. 21 Apply the juice to
congealed blood to desperse it, and to the swelling of the milt. 22 The oil of
it softneth hard sinews, and the hardness of the matrix. Isop does the like.
23 Stamp the leaves with vinegar and salt, and apply to the biting of a
scorpion. 24 A plaster of Marierom, oil, and wax, dissolueth cold swellings,
and is good for members out of joint or wrenched. 25 Smelling lost, and to
purge and comfort the brain, put the powder or juice into the nose. 26
Marierom is good for all cold griefs, and for fretting and consuming ulcers.
27 The oil put into the ears with wool is good against deafness. 28
Headache of murre, bruise it and put it into the nose. 29 Head sleepy or
drowsy, provoke sneesing with powder of Marierom gentle. 30 Stomach griefs
and windy, stamp the leaves and flowers and apply them. 31 Reume, apply it to
the head. It dries the mother, and consumes the superfluities thereof. 32
Drink the powder of it with wine to heat and comfort the stomach and help
digestion. 33 Members out of joint, apply powder of it with wax. 34 Headache,
put the juice into the nose. 35 For the white and cold flux of the matrix,
distill it in a limbek in the end of May, and drink three ounces of it. 36
Bruses and black spots, anoint with the powder of it and honey.

Aches 6. 13 Apoplexia 5 Bitings venomous 23 Black spots 4. 21. 36 Brain

Maple.
MAple. Side pain, stamp the root, and drink it with wine. 2 Tongue palsy,
stamp the keys and seethe them in possit ale, and streine it and drink it
with sugar morn and even daily. 3 Liver pain, stamp one ounce and a half of
the root, and drink it with sweet wine.

Liver grief 3 Palsy 2 Side pain 1 Speech lost 2
Marigold.
MArigolde. The flowers steeped in vinegar and salt, may be kept two years. 2
Drink the flowers with wine to comfort the stomach, procure appetite, to
consume humors of the stomach, and to heat the stomach. 3 Seethe the rynd of
the root in Wine, and drink it to digest evil humors, and to help the
griefs of the liver. 4 Mix powder of the rynd of the root with the juice of
Fennel, a little wine, and a little oil, boil them together to a thickness,
and put a little wax to it, and anoint the cold stomach therewith to help it
greatly. 5 Ears worms, drop in the juice. 6 Apply powder of the rynde to
help little pushes. 7 Palsy, take the juice of the herb and root in a
glister. 8 Seethe the flowers of Marigold and Spikenarde in wine and drink it,
and also apply it to swage the swelling of the breasts by stopping of the
terms. 9 Drink the decoction of the flowers to stop pissing of blood in short
time. 10 The distilled water heals all griefs of the eyes both hot and
cold, clears the sight, and auoydeth all griefs of the eyes and head. 11
Bruise a Marigold leaf, and put it into thy nose to cleanse the head and avoid
reume. 12 The Flowers themselves, or with their plant boiled in wine and
drunk, provoke terms. 13 The same with the herb dried and strawed on quick
coals, draws down the seconds and dead child, the fume thereof being
received up into the natural place. 14 Take the conserve of the Flowers
fasting, to cure the trembling of the heart, and to withstand the plague and
evil air. 15 Drink the flowers or juice to draw down the terms taken warm.
16 Wash the mouth therewith for the toothach, it is a present remedy. 17 The
flowers color hair yelow. 18 Seethe the herb in possit ale or white wine and
drink it to provoke sweat in the pestilence. 19 Teeth-ache, put in the powder
of them. 20 Emerods, seethe Marigolds and Mulleine in wine, and foment
therewith. 21 Frenzy, drink the juice of Marigolds, Sage, and Southrenwood.
22 Megrem, anoint the temples with the juice. Preservative from death, drink
iii. grayns of Marigolds. 23 Warts, wash them in the juice of Marigolds, or
wash thy hands, and then rub them with the juice of Marigolds and salt. 24 Wits
lost or mad, take the juice of Marigolde and Wormwood of each one spoonful.
The leaves or juice boiled with milk to an unguent, heals all ulcers,
wounds, with as much white wine, at even hot, and at morn cold: the warm
juice with a little vinegar, helps aches, bruses, swellings, apostumes,
cankers, carbuncles, fellons, and rednes, inflammations, breasts sores, or
cankers. 25 Flowers stopped, drink the juice, or make fritters of them with eggs
and meal and use them. 26 Feet or toes corns, stamp Marigolds and apply them
morn and even. 27 Palsy, drink the juice of a handful of Marigolds with a
good draught of Ale, and a spoonefull of Mustarde. 28 For chafing of the liver
and griefs of the milte, stamp Marigolds with Saffron, and drink them with
White wine first and last. 29 Warts, apply powder of Sauen with the juice of
Marigolds. 30 Sit over the fume of the Flowers to bring down the seconds, or
drink the decoction of them, or use them in a pessary. 31 Agnails, pare them
to the quick, and stamp Marigolds and apply them. 32 Emerods or pyles, stamp
them and apply them. 33 Fever quarten, drink possit ale made with Marigolds
and Fennel four times before the fits if need be. 34 Head and stomach to
cleanse from phlegm, xoll a Marigolde leaf between thy fingers, and put it
into thy nose, and to be in stead of a gargarisme. 35 Cramp in children, seethe
Marigolds in water, and bath them therein, and anoint with oil of Lillies or
of Priuet. 36 Seconds, drink powder of the flowers and put thereof about a wax
candle, and light it, and receive up the fume thereof. 37 Cankers in wounds,
apply the juice of the greater Marigolds. 38 Flowers to stop, drink the juice
of Marigolds. 39 Flesh mole, stamp Bentbrow with young Marigolds that never
flowred, and strein it, and anoint with the juice with a crows fether. 40
Warts, apply the juice of Marigolds and onions. 41 Teeth-ach, wash thy mouth
with the juice of the flowers and leaves.

Air corrupt 14 Agnails 26. 31 Appetite 2 Breasts griefs 8 Corns (see

24 Seconds 36 Stomach clensing 23. 34. cold 2. 4. Sweat to cause 18 Teeth-ach

Marsh mallowe.
MArsh mallowe sodden in wine or Mede, or bruised and applied, is good for
wounds, hard kernels, swellings and wennes, for burnings and swellings behind
the ears, impostumes, burning impostumes of the Paps, bruising of the
fundament, windy swellings, and for stiffness of the senowes: for it drives
away, makes ripe, bursteth and covers with a skin. 2 Sees it in wine or
Mede, and put to it swines grease or Goose grease, or Turpentine, that it may
be clammie, and put thereof into the Mother for the inflammation and stopping,
as a pessarye: the broth that the herb is sodden in, is good for the same, it
draws out also burdens of the Mother and the seconds. 3 Sees the root in
wine and drink it for the difficulty of making water, the rawnesse that
comes by the stone, the bloody flixe, the sciatica, the trembling of any
member, and the bursting. 4 Teethach, sees ye herb in vinegar and hold it in
thy mouth. 5 Stamp the seeds and anoint freckles and foul spots therewith in
the sun. 6 Mix the seeds with oil and anoint thee, and no venomous beast
shall bite thee. 7 It is good against the bloody flux, vomiting blood, and the
common flixe. 8 Drink the same seeds sodden with water and vinegar or in
wine, and drink it against all stinging of Bees, wasps and such like. 9 Apply
the leaves with a little oil to burnings, bitings and stingings, etc. 10 Take
the roots of Marsh mallows or Holyokes, or common Mallows twelve ounces,
Linseeds six ounces, fats or greases of hens, geese, capons or neates feet,
a wine quart, wax six ounces, turpentine one ounce, rosin three ounces:
bruise well the roots and seeds, steep them 48. hours in a pottell of water
skalding hot, or rather in half water and half white wine, then sees it
till the broth be all slimy, then streine it and sees a pint of the slimy
broth with the fats, till the warry substance be sodden away, then melt the
wax, rosin and turpentine, and sees them a little altogether, and scum it and
keep it, for all hard lumps, swellings and bruises in any place, whether it
come of inward or outward cause, it is good also for horse feet that be
swelled or bruised. 11 Sees the root of Marsh mallow in wine, and drink it
to help all the griefs of the lungs or breast, and of the whole body, the
gnawings of the guts, the bloody flixe and other griefs coming of choler, and
whatsoever is before written of the Mallows, this has the double virtues. 12
Slice the root thin and sees it in milk or water, to heal all hardness,
ulcers and vncomes. 13 The leaves or the oil of them helps and heals all
stingings of waspes and Bees. 14 The root sodden in water, and mixed with
swines grease, goose grease or Turpentine, and put in as a Pessary, helps all
inflammations and pyles of the Matrixe. 15 The powder of the seeds mixed with
Deaw gathered in May, takes away the foul spots of the face. 16 The root or
seed sodden in vinegar and holden in the mouth, helps the tooth ach. 17 The
root boiled in wine and drunk, is good for the pain of the gravel and stone,
the bloody flixe, the sciatica, the trembling and shaking of any member, and
cramps and burstings: and boiled in milk, it heals the Cough. 18 The roots
boiled in wine or honied water and stamped small, do heal new wounds,
dissolve and consume all cold tumors and swellings, as wennes and hard kernels,
impost, behind the ears, burning impost, of the Paps, old and windy
impostumes and swellings, rifts and chaps of the fundament, and trembling of
the senowes and senowye parts: the leaves are good for all the aforesaid, but
not so good as the root. 19 The leaves applied with oil, heal burnings,
bitings of men or dogs, and stinging of Bees and waspes. 20 The seed green or
dried, punned and drunk, heals the bloody flux, all issues of blood and the
laske, and with vinegar they take away the foul spots of the face does black
and white being anointed in the hot sun or in a bath or stewe. 21 Bloody
flixe, drink the juice. 22 Ptisicke and infection of the Lungs, sees the
leaves and seeds in milk and drink it every morning. 23 Mouth and throat
sores, sees the leaves with wine and honey, and put thereto Roch Alom, and
wash therewith cold. 24 White flawes and Apost. of the fingers, stamp the
leaves with barrowes grease and crumbs of bread and apply it. 25 For
unquietness of Fevers, to cause sleep and avoid drought, Distill the herb
and root in a Lymbecke in the beginning of May, and rub the feet with the
water. 26 Plurisie, sees Mallows in oil, and stamp them and apply them.

Apostume 1. 18 Belly ach 11 Biting venom. 6. 8. 9. 19 Bloody flux 3. 7. 11.

Medlers.
MEdlers: stone to break, use the powder of ye stones of them. 2 Medlers stop
the belly, especially being green and hard, for after they have been kept a
while, they become soft and tender, and stop not so much, but then they are
more convenient to be eaten, but they nourish little or nothing at all. 3 The
stones made into powder and drunk, break the stone and drive forth gravel:
if one eat too much of such binding fruit, they will stop both the liver and
the milt. 4 Gedlers are to be used for medicine, and not for meats. They are
good after meals for them that be Laxatiue, but being eaten much, they breed
melancholy. 5 The kernels are good against ye stone, one spooneful of their
powder being drunk with white wine, wherein Parsley roots have been sodden.

Grauel 3 Stone 1. 5
Medowort.
MEdowort: Drink the decoction or powder of it to stop the laske and all
issues of blood. 2 Boil the flowers in white wine and drink it to cure the
fever quarten. 3 Sees the root in wine and Honey and drink it to loose the
belly and draw down choler. 4 But sodden in red wine it stops the bloody
flux: Stamp the herb with Mede and apply it to swellings, and to draw forth
pricks, splents. 5 Use not the seed, for it causes headache: Sees it in fresh
butter and streine it, and anoint therewith any burning or skalding.

Belly bound 3 Bloody flux 1. 4 Burnings 5 Fever quarten 2 Fluxes 1 Skalding 5
Melilot.
MElilot boiled by it self with sweet Malmesie, or with the yolke of a roasted
Egg or the meal of Fenigrek or Linseed, or with fine flower or meal, or with
Cyeory, to swage all kind of hot swellings, especially of the eyes, matrixe,
fundament and stones. 2 Apply it with Galls or chalk, or with good wine to
heal skurfe and mattering sores. 3 Stamp it raw or sodden with wine, and
apply it to the pain of the stomach, and to dissolve the impostumes and
swellings thereof. 4 Ears pain, drop in the juice. 5 Headache, apply it to the
forehead with oil of Roses and vinegar. 6 The common Melilot is good for all
the aforesaid, it is most used to swage pain, as the flowers of Camomile is. 7
The same boiled in wine and drunk, provoke urine, breaks the stone,
swageth the pain of the kidneys, bladder and belly, and ripeth phlegm, causing
it to be easily spit forth. 8 Eyes dull, spots and pearls, drop in the
juice. 9 Ears pain, drop in the juice with Malmesie: drink it with wine to
soften the hardness of the stomach and Liver. 10 All sorts of Melilot sodden
in wine and drunk with some Honey, do mollify all inward impostumes. 11 The
same sodden with Malmesie and drunk, helps the tumors of the matrixe. 12 All
the kinds of it are good to mitigate all outward aches, especially the
inflammations of the eyes, being stamped and applied, and are good to provoke
sweat. 13 The distilled water is good for hot griefs of the eyes: Vein cut,
stamp Melilot and Costmary, and apply it but once. 14 Stitch, anoint with oil
of Melilot, then stamp Melilot and apply it but once on a piece of Leather,
and change it but once a week. (See Clauer, Honysuckle, Trifoyle.)

Aches 6. 12 Backach 7 Bellyach 7 Bladder ach 7 Ears pain 4 Eyes grief 1. 8.

grief 1. 11 Sores 2 Skurfe 2 Stomach grief 3. 9 Stones grief 1 Stitch 14
