Mellons.
MEllons: Mouth stink, use the seeds. 2 Pill off the uppermost skin of the
seeds of Mellons, and make the rest into powder, and with Bean meal kneade
cakes with Rose water, and dry them in the sun, and therewith wash the face
and skin orderly to cleanse it from all spots, sun burning, and red pimples
and foulness, and to make it clear and fair. 3 The same seeds eaten or
drunk, cause vrin, and purge the Lungs and Kidneys. 4 The root does heal
such ulcers as do stand full of matter, being applied with Honey. 5 Many eat
the Mellons with vinegar, Peniroyall and Onions mixed together. 6 Distill
Mellous when they are ripe, and drink three or four ounces of the water in
the mornings a month together, to help the stone, to provoke urine, and to
purge the kidneys. 7 Eyes running, lay the uttermost pill to the forehead and
temples. 8 Drink the water with sugar, to cool all inward unnatural heates,
and to cease thirst and swellings in the body wheresoever it be, being also
applied with linen clothes. 9 The fruit of the garden Pepon or Pompion is best
to be eaten fasting, and not to eat any other meats after them till they be
half digested, and so they are good against unnatural heates and wicked
Agewes. 10 The seeds purge the skin being washed with the decoction of them.
11 They must not be eaten raw, but be boiled with good flesh or sweet milk,
and so it is better then the Cucumber, and is good for a hot stomach. 12 The
flesh or substance of it being finely stamped, does swage and heal the
inflammation of the eyes being applied. 13 The seeds may be used as the
seeds of Melons, to cleanse the skin. 14 Drink one ounce of the root with
Honied water to cause vomit: Mellons and Pompions be both of one nature.

Breath stink 1 Eyes grifes 7. 12 Face deform. 2. 13 Heat inward 8. 9 Kidneys
to cleanse 3. 6 Lungs to cleanse 3 Mouth stink 1 Skin to cleanse 2. 13
Stomocke hot 8. 9. 11 Stone 6 Swellings 8 Thirst 8 Ulcers 4 Vomit to cause 14
Urine stopped 3. 6. 10
Meu.
MEu, Meon, or Spignel, boil or soke the roots in water, and drink it to open
mightily the stoppings of the kidneys and bladder, to provoke urine, to help
the strangury, and consume all windiness of the stomach. 2 Take it with Honey
against the gripings of the Belly, the griefs of the Mother, Gout in the
feet, ache in the joints, Reumes, and Catharres in the breast. 3 Flowers to
cause, sit over the decoction thereof. 4 Apply it to the lower part of childrens
backs to provoke urine. 5 The root drunk, causes headache, (See Spikenard,
Cyperus.)

Aches 2 Back ach 1 Belly ach 2 Bladder stopped 1 Catharre 2 Feet Gout 2
Flowers stopped 3 Gouts 2 Joints ach 2 Kidneys stopped 1 Reume 2 Strangury 1 Urine
stopped 1. 4 Windiness 1
Mints.
MInts: Worms, eat powder of Mints with milk. 2 Belly bound, eat Mints. 3
Color bad, use Mints daily. 4 Mints are healthful at any time. 5 Anoint the
holy fire with the juice of Mints, brimstone and vinegar, to cease the pain
forthwith. 6 Guts and kidneys pain, sees Mints in wine and drink it. 7 Sees
Mints in wine and oil, and apply it to impostumes to dissolve them, and to
help the Paps that are hard with curded milk. 8 Mouth, gums and teeth rotten
and stink, sees garden Mints in vinegar and wash therewith, and after rub
them with powder of Mints. 9 When any medicine is given against poison, it
ought to be given with the juice of Mints, or else with wine of the decoction
thereof: which wine or Mints with Honey does help against stopping of the
liver, milt and passage of the water, and the juice with Honey slays worms in
the belly and in the ears being dropped in. 10 Mints put into milk, does not
suffer it to curd, although ^uen be put to it, and in like sort generation. 11
Drink the juice with vinegar against spitting of blood, to stop vomiting, to
kill small worms in the body. 12 All Mints green or dry, are good for the
stomach, and also the distilled water, to help digestion, to avoid the
hicket, lothing and choler, especially used in sawses: it provoke lust, and
comfort all the members, and the smell of it comfort the brain and
memory. 13 Headache, apply the juice or water with a cloth, and to swollen
breasts for their curded milk, and drop it into the ears for their ache. 14
Biting of a mad dog, stamp Mint with salt and apply it. 15 Mix powder of
water Mints with leven and apply it to the stomach to withstand belching and
vomiting. 16 All Mints are good to bath in to provoke sweat. Headache, apply
Mints. 17 Tongue rough, rub it with Mints. 18 It is singular good in sawses,
and for a woman that has had hard labor, being drunk with wine. 19 Eat
powder of Mints after meat to help digestion, and heals all the griefs of
the milt. 20 The juice withstandeth venom, and slaieth worms: let no wounded
body use any Mint, because it hinders the healing of the wound 21 Lethargy and
forgetfulness, stampered Mints with Rue, oil and vinegar, and apply it to the
nostrels. 22 Frenzy, seethe Mints in vinegar and apply them unto the head, and
put the juice of Iuye into the Nose. 23 Apply Mints to thy head to void all
pain that comes of cold cause. 24 Stamp water Mints, and apply them to
the midst of thy browe and nape of thy neck against madness, and to provoke
sleep. 25 Garden Mints in meats and drinks is very good for the stomach, it
warmeth and opens it, and dries up all superfluous humors therein, voydeth
the pain and helps digestion. 26 Drink two or three branches with the juice
of a sour Pomgranate against the Hicket, vomiting, and chollericke passion,
which has a laske withal. 27 Seethe Mints in water, and drink it three days
to cure the gryping and gnawing of the belly, and the chollicke, and to
provoke the terms. 28 Stamp Mints with parched Barley meal and apply it to
tumors and swellings to consume them, and to the headache to cure it. 28 Mix
the juice with Honied water, and drop it into the ears to cure their pain,
and gargarise therewith to avoid the roughness of the tongue and throat. 30
Water Mints are much of like nature to garden Mints, and are very good for the
gravel and stone in the kidneys, and the strangurie or pissing by drops being
boiled in wine and drunk. 31 Apply it to the stinging of Bees and Wasps. 32
Sees three branches in wine and drink it fasting to help replection. 33 The
juice mixed with good Treacle and eaten in the mornings, kills worms in
children. 34 Mints are wholesome to be sodden in windy meats, as peason, etc.
and sodden in possit ale with Fennel seed, it increases vital seed. 35
Blood to stop, stamp Mints and apply them. 36 For swooning and weakness of
the heart by fevers or other sickness, stamp them with vinegar and a little
wine, and rub the lips, tongue, teeth and nose, and temples therewith, and dip
a toste therein and chewe it, and suck thereof and swallow it. 37 Liver, milt,
kidneys and bladder stopped, sees wild Mints in wine and drink it with sugar.
38 Gomor passion or flux of nature, use powder of Mints dried in an Oven. 39
Abhorring meat, eat new sodden eggs with sauce of Mints and vinegar. 40 Belly
bound, drink the juice of Mints with warm water. 41 Headache of reume, stamp
green Mints with Ladanum and vinegar and apply it. 42 Iaundies, use Mints in
syrops: Leprie elephantia, eat Mints. 43 Morphue, mix powder of Lupines and
Mints with vinegar and anoint. 44 Put the juice of Rue and mints together into
the Nose, to amend the brain and void all stink of the mouth or nose. 45
Reins running, seethe Cassia Lignea, Mints, and housleeke in vinegar and
plaster it to the reins. 40 Paps with curded milk, seethe the roots of
Holyoke, and grind them with yolks of eggs, saffron and Mints, and apply it.
47 Shingles or holy fires, mix Rue and Mints with oil and vinegar, and anoint
therewith to help it the same day. 48 Pissing against will, use the juice of
Mints with Treacle. 49 Spitting of matter or quyttor from the Lungs, use powder
of Mints with other medicines. 50 Worms, drink the juice of Roman Mints. 51
Vomiting of red choler, eat Mints. 52 Forgetfulness or Lethargy, sees red
Mints and Rue in strong vinegar, and draw up the vapor thereof into thy Nose.
53 Headache and dasing, of cold cause, apply Mints. 54 Mouth stink, wash with the
decoction of Aniseeds, Cloves and Mints, or wash with Mint water, or rub it
with the powder. 55 Vomit to stop, use sirrope of Mints. 56 Appetite, eat
Sage, Parsley, Mints and Pepper with vinegar, with fish or flesh, or use
Cardamon with the juice of Mints. 57 Hands itch and worms, anoint with the
juice. 58 Heart griefs general, steep Sage and Mints in white wine, and
sees it and drink the wine, and apply the herbs to cause appetite. 59 Eyes
red, stamp Mints and apply them. 60 Stomach weak and to cause good
digestion, boil powder of Mints with twice so much sugar till it be thick,
and keep it in a wide mouthed glass, and use it. 61 Head impost. put the
juice into thy ear three or four nights. 62 Worms, frye wormwood and Mints
ana like much with salt Butter, and put vinegar to it and a little of the Gaul
of a beast, and apply it to the belly. 63 Emerods, sit over the smoke of dried
Mints laid upon coals of Ash wood. 64 Agew cake, frye red Mints and red Nettles
and wormwood of each an handful, with fresh butter and apply them as hot as
may be suffered. 65 Mouth stink, wash with the juice, water or decoction of
Mints with some white vinegar, or put the juice of Rue and black Mints into
the Nose, of each like: proved. 66 Iaundies, drink the broth of Mints sodden
with an old cock with Cinamome and Maces. 67 Shingles, anoint with the juice
of Mints. 68 Vomit to stop, Apply wheat Branne with the juice of Mints and the
white of an egg, or apply the juice with Frankincense and a little vinegar
boiled together to the pit of the stomach. 69 Chollicke, drink the juice of
Mints with eight corns of Pepper and a little Honey. 70 Worms, drink the
juice with Goats milk. 71 Milk to dry up, use Mints. 72 Sciatica, bruise
wild Mints and apply them. 73 Mad, stamp water Mints and apply them to the
mids of the browe, and nape of the neck, first tickling the brow to bring
sleep, but if he be far gone, clean a Tench, and apply the one half warm
before, and the other behind. 74 Consumption, use powder of Mints in thy
broaths, and the water of them in thy drinks. 75 Vomit to stop, stamp them
with burnt bread and vinegar, and heat it on a hot tyle or brick, and apply
it to the stomach. 76 Loins pain, apply the seeds of wild Mints with
wheat flower. 77 Loins and Belly pain, drink two drammes of the powder of
water Mints with iii. ounces of water of Radish. 78 Pappes hard with
concongealed milk, seethe Mints with oil and wine, and apply it. 79 For
watrie skabs in childrens hands, mix the juice with vinegar and Brimstone and
anoint therewith with a feather. 80 Ache and swelling in the stomach or belly,
sees with Rue in sweet milk, and drink it. 81 Vomiting much, seethe it with
Cummin in wine, and drink it or eat it. 82 Hycket, apply powder of Dill seed
with the juice of Mints to the stomach. 83 The juice of Mint Roman or white
Mint, kills worms in the belly, and in the Nostrels. 84 The powder of it
cast on meats, helps digestion. 85 Brown or garden Mints, use the decoction
of them for the stopping of the Liver and milt, kidneys and bladder. 86
Tetters, anoint with the juice of Mints, vinegar and brimstone and be whole. 87
Head wounds, stamp Mints and apply them. 88 Side pain, stamp Mints and sees
them in old wine or ale, and drink it with xx. grains of Pepper in the
night. 89 Hoarsenesse, stamp the crops of Mints, Sage, Fiueleafe and Ginger,
and Lycoras, and sees them in stale ale and streine it and drink it hot
morn and even, as often as need is. 90 Dropsy, take nine crops of Mints,
nine crops of blind Nettles, and nine crops of Sage, stamp them and drink
them with stale ale morn and even, or eat water Cresses with Mints and
Parsley daily. 91 Stomach griefs, stamp Mints, Sage, Cammomile, and good
store of Wormwood and sower bread, and boil them in vinegar and apply it
warm to the stomach. 92 Botches, sores and swellings in the head, stamp Mint
Royal and apply it. Ache and stink in the teeth, sees it in white wine and
vinegar, and wash the mouth therewith and rub them with the powder of it. 93 A
sawse thereof with vinegar causes appetite. 94 Stitch, seethe two or three
handfuls of red Mints, and a handful of Sage crops in running water to the one
half, and apply it as hot as may be suffered in a linen bag, and warm it
again as often as need is. 95 Botch to avoid and vanish away, drink the
juice of Mint roots one spoonefull, with some Treacle. 96 Breast phlegm,
drink the crops of red Mints, red Nettles and Wormwood, with wine or stale
ale first and last.

Agewe cake 64 Appetite 56. 93 Apostume 7. 92. 95 Backach 6. 27. 77. 80 bound
2. 40
Belching 15 Bitings venem. 14 Bladder stopped 37. 85 Blood to stop 35 Brain ill

Myrhis.
MYrhis or mockcheruill. The root drunk with wine provoke the terms,
voideth the seconds and dead birth, and purges women after their deliverance:
it provoke urine, and is good against all venomous bitings. 2 The same boiled
in the broth of flesh, does cleanse the breast from phlegm and all corruption,
and is very good for such as be lean and unlusty, or falling into a
consumption. 3 It is good to be drunk with wine in the plague time, for they
that have drunk it three or four times shall not be infected with the plague.
4 Seethe it in drink to help the Ptysicke. 5 Some steep the sliced root in
white wine all night, and drink it in the morning with sugar, and so it gives
three or four stools or seeges. 6 The juice with powder of burnt Allom
kills the kanker in the mouth or throat.

Belly bound 5 Bitings venom. 1 Breast cleansing 2 Consumption 2. 4 Dead child
1 Phlegm 2 Flowers stopped 1 Kanker 6 Leanness 2 Mouth kanker 6 Plague 3
Ptisicke 4 Purgation 5 Seconds 1 Throat kanker 6 Vrin stopped 1
Milfoyle.
MIlfoile or Yarrowe: The decoction thereof does cure the bloody flixe and all
other laskes, and the excessive flux of the terms, being also applied, or the
suffumigation of the decoction thereof received up into the natural place. 2
Stamp it and apply it to wounds to stop the blood, to keep it from
inflammation and swelling, and to cure them, and to stop bleeding at the Nose.
3 Seethe it in wine by it self, or with wound herbs, to heal wounds and
bitings, and to dissolve bruised blood. 4 It kills worms, and expels
poison out of the body, and helps the ach of the belly. 5 Use it in salues
and plasters to cleanse, dry and heal sores. 6 Stamp the green herb and
apply it to heal up wounds as if they were sowed up. 7 Stamp it and apply it
to stop the terms, it is a secret experience amongst women. 8 Teethache,
put it in with Butter. 9 Drink it with vinegar against the stone, stopping of
the Urine, and to dissolve bruised blood. 10 Drink the juice fasting to
withstand drunkenness. 11 Bloody flixe, drink the juice of it and Planten
with wine or ale. 12 Fluxes, stamp it and drink it every four and twenty
hours. 13 The juice with oil rubbed, causes curled hair, and with honey it
causes hair to grow. 14 Megrem, drink the juice of Yarrow three days in
May, with Marygolds, Balsamin and Auens, of each like much. 15 Wounds general,
put in the juice and apply the herb. 16 Restoratiue, mix the juice with wheat
flower and yolks of eggs, and bake cakes thereof and eat them thrice aday. 17
Reins griefs, drink the juice with vinegar. 18 Belly grinding, drink the
juice of it and Planten ana with warm water. 19 Emerodes, stample it and apply
it warm. 20 Worms in the flesh, stamp it and Parietarie with a little salt,
and apply them twice or thrice. 21 Fundament fig, stamp it and Polypody of the
oak and drink them with ale. 22 Wounds bleeding, mix powder of it and of Bole
armoniak with the white of an egg, and apply it. 23 Ears worms, put in the
juice. 24 Emerodes, drink the juice of Yarrowe, Mouseare and Betony often, of
each like much. 25 Vomit to stop, drink the juice with wine. 26 Reins grief,
drink the juice of it and Centory with vinegar, and anoint the back with
Agrippa. 27 Teeth ach, sup the juice often, but swallow it not down. 28 Nose
bleeding, drink it or smell to it. 29 Emerods flowing and pain, drink it and
apply it. 30 Fever quarten, drink it with wine before the fit. 31 Bloody flux,
stamp it with as much Planten, and drink it with red wine three or four
days. 32 Emerodes bleeding, drink the juice of it and cast on powder of burnt
Garlike, and they will die. 33 Eyes dropping and tears, stamp it with a little
incense, and steep it in white wine seven days, then streine it and put in a
drop or two at night into the eyes. 34 Back pain, put the juice into a glass
close luted, and set it into an Oven to boil, and there will be an oil:
wherewith, anoint the back. 35 Vomiting, stamp it and drink it with wine
warm. 36 Teeth ache, eat the roots fasting. 37 Emerods bleeding, stamp the
roots and drink them with vinegar, or stamp the herb and apply it often
hot. 38 Vomiting, boil it in wine till the third part be wasted, and drink
it: some put Louage and Rue to it. 39 Pissing blood, drink the juice with
vinegar. 40 Deliverance to cause, gather it on S. John Baptists day at sun
setting, and let a woman hold it in her hand to her right shoulder blade, and
take it away as soon as the child is borne. 41 Bleeding to stop, drink the
powder of burnt Garlike. 42 Urine stopped, drink the juice with old ale often. 43
Stamp it with swines grease, to heal wounds and cuts. 44 The same is good for
the breast and side, and for them that cannot piss. 45 Drink the juice with
vinegar to help a wound marueilously that has taken cold. 46 Stamp it with
Butter to heal wounds well. 47 Drink the juice with water to comfort the
stomach and help digestion. 48 To help many griefs of the body, drink the
powder or juice of it with wine or good ale. 49 It helps against heart
burning. 50 Head ach, stamp it and apply it. 51 Bitings of mad dogs, stamp it
with wheat and apply it. 52 Drink it nine days, to stop the whites. 53
Veins or senowes cut, stamp it and apply it, and keep it too three days. 54
Bloody flux, drink the juice.

Mirabolanes.
MIrabolanes citrine, or Yelowe, purge choler, and are good for hot
complections being steeped in vergice of Grapes, or in Rose water, or the juice
of Fennel, they skowre the eyes, and take away their heat. 2 The fine powder
of them stop the watring and overmuch moisture of the eyes. 3 Mixed with
Masticke, they heal sores. 4 They may be taken in gross powder from two drams
to five drams, and in infusion from five drams to twenty drams. 5 They make
not a man weak, but rather strengthen the stomach and all the inner parts. 6
They keep a man long young, and cause a good color, and sweet breath. 7 They
cause mirth, and void sadness. 8 They comfort the liver, and are good for ye
trembling of the heart. 9 They are good for the Emerods, and quench the heat
of choler. 10 Myrabolanes Chebuly preserved in syrope and eaten, preserve
youth excellently well. 11 Mirabolan citrine well conserved, cause one to piss
well, one of them taken every morning.

Breath stink 6 Choler 1. 8 Eyes heat 1 running 2 Heart trembling 10 Liver
griefs 8 Melancholy 7 Mirth to cause 7 Purgation 1. 4 Sores 3 Stomach weak 5
Urine stopped 11 Youth to preserve 6. 10
Myrtle.
MYrtle beries are very good for them that spit vomit, or piss blood, for they
stop all issues of blood, and the terms, the laske and the sores and ulcers of
the bladder: the dried juice of Myrtles serves well for all the aforesaid,
and also for the weak and moist stomach and venomous bitings. 2 The decoction
of the berries makes the hair black, and keeps it from falling, it cures
all the evil sores of the head, and cleanses the same from skurfe and skales
being often washed therewith. 3 Wash outward ulcers and sores with wine wherein
the seeds have been boiled. 4 It is good to be laid to the inflammation of the
eyes that matter and run, with a little fine flower. 5 Take it aforehand to
prevent drunkenness. 6 Sit over the decoction of the seeds and leaves to
stop the flowers, and wash therewith members that be out of joint and
burstings, to strengthen them. 7 Apply the green leaves to moist sores, and to
falling down of humors in any part. 8 The same with oil of Roses or such like
is good against consuming and rotten sores and ulcers, wild fire, spreading
tetters, and such like hot scabs and pushes. 9 The dry leaves applied with
convenient ointments or salues, do heal the exulceration of the nails, and
take away the sweat of all the body. Flux, drink the juice with wine. 10 Wash
filthy sores of the priuities with wine of the decoction of it. 11 It cleanses
the eyes. 12 The syrop of Mirtles is good for the cough and exulceration of the
lungs, and is thus made: take the juice of Mirtles well streined vi. li. boil
it with iii. li. of pure sugar, with a gentle fire, to the thicknes of honey or
a syrop and then use it. 13 Heat the seed in wine and strein it, and drink it
to comfort the weak brain. 14 The broth of Mirtles heals the white morphue.
15 The powder of the leaves is good to be cast upon agnailes, and white flawes,
and the stinking sweat of the flanks and armpits, and the sweating of the
cardiak passion. 16 The raw or burned leaves with a treat made of wax, heals
burning agnailes, and white flawes. 17 The broth of Mirtles or Mirt seeds with
butter, stops the sweating too much. 18 The leaves comfort the heart, and
take away the trembling thereof. 19 The juice is good for the burning of the
bladder and kidneys. 20 An emplaster of Mirtles is good for the pyles and the
falling down of the fundament. 21 Let not the Apothecaries, Physicians, nor
Surgeons use the shrub growing in fennes, called galtes in stead of ye right
Myrtle, but procure those leaves yt come out of Italy. 22 Chafing and galling,
cast on powder of Mirtles. 23 Whelks red or white, anoint with oil of Mirtles.
24 Sweat stinking, use ye water or decoction inward and outward.

Agnailes 15. 16 Bitings venomous 1 Bladder heat 19 Bloody flux 1 Bones broken

Mirrhe.
MIrrhe. Teethach, hold it under thy tongue, and eat Sage every day twice or
thrice. (See Aloes.) 2 Ears apost. and running, seethe it in oil Olive and
put it in warm. 3 The fume thereof dries and refreshes the brain. 4
Swallowe as much as a bean for the old cough, shortness of breath, and pain
of the sides. 5 The fume thereof cleanses and opens the matrixe and draws
down the terms and birth. 6 It increases flesh in ulcers. 7 To cause
deliverance, drink as much as a good nut with good wine. 8 Pissing bed, and
for the griefs of the stomach, seethe it in good wine and drink it. 9
Fundament fallen, cast powder of Mirrhe, Aloes, Galls and Frankincense of each
like much. 10 Head scall, shave it and wash it and cast on powder of Mirrhe,
Aloes, and Frankincense. 11 Impost. drink powder of Mirrhe with wine. 12 Canker
when it is killed, heal up the sore with powder of Mirrhe. 13 Matrix fallen,
drink powder of a Hearts horn, Bay leaves and Mirrhe of each like much with wine
or ale. 14 Noli me tangere in the nose or face, mix Ginger with the juice of
Rue and anoint. 15 Yard pushes, straw on powder of Mirrhe, and stamp the
leaves of greent Mints and apply them. 16 Worms to kill, take Mirrhe and Aloes
cicatrin. in powder. 17 A powder incarnatiue to be thrown into wounds, take
Mirrhe iii. drams, Aloes iiii. drams, Olibanum two drams, but if you suspect
bleeding, use Bolarmon. with oil of roses. 18 Fistula or canker, mix the milky
juice of Tithymall with fresh swines grease, melt them, and put thereto powder
of Mirrhe, and put in tents to the bottom to kill them quite. 19 Worms,
drink powder of Aloes, brimstone and Mirrhe, or for children, anoint the
stomach with aqua vitae, and cast on powder of Mirrhe. 20 To fasten the gums
and loose teeth, mix a little Mirrhe with wine and oil, and wash therewith.
Breath to be sweet, chew Mirrhe. 21 Mirrhe preserves from putrefaction, both
the intrals and all outward sores, wounds and ulcers. Falling evil, to preserve
thee from it, smell to Mirrhe daily, and also drink thereof six grayns with
Betony water, and so it helps the griefs of the lungs, kills worms, and
is good against the yelow water, but for worms apply it also to the belly. 22
It is good for the ulcers of the eyes, and gleweth together broken pieces of
the bones of the head. It takes away spots of the eyes, and is good in
medicines for the old cough and shortness of breath. 23 Ears running, put in
the gall of a goat, woman's milk, honey and Mirrhe tempered together. Gums
rotten, rub them with Mirrhe. 24 The fume thereof taken at the mouth purges
the head. 25 Breasts and ribs pain, wash with water that Mirrhe and gum Arabik
have been sodden in. 26 Spetting blood and matter, take two drams of Leeksseeds
and Mirrhe. 27 Belly torments, drink Mirrhe and Treacle with Malmsey. 28
Flowers stopped, drink powder of Mirrhe, and Southrenwood with wine.

Bellyache 27 Brain weak 3. 24 Breasts sore 25 Breath short 4. 22. stink 20.

Millet.
MIllet. Parch it in a frying pan, and apply it in a bag to the torment of
the belly, or to any other ache or pain, and any superfluous moisture, and to
comfort the brain. 2 For want of corn bread may be made of it, but it binds
the belly and provoke urine and nourishes little. 3 Roast it, and stamp it,
and make broth therewith with milk to stop the flux. 4 Flowers to stop, apply
a hot bag of it to the hips.

Aches general 1 Belly ache 1 Brain to comfort 1 Flowers to stop 4 Fluxes 3
Urine stopped 2
Misselto.
MIsselto. The leaves with the fruit and tar and wax, do consume and soften
hard swellings and botches about the secret parts and other rebellious
impostumes and cold swellings. 2 The same leaves and fruit with Frankincense,
do cure all old ulcers and sores and great corrupt and evil impostumes. 3 And
with Arsnick, they cure felons and naughty sores which rise in the toes and
fingers ends. 4 The seed stamped with wine lees, does waste and cure the
hardness of the milt being applied to the side. 5 The wood of that which grows
in oaks, is good against the falling sickness and the apoplexia being hanged
about the neck. Lay Misselto to ye head to draw forth evil humors. 6 Drink it
for the falling evil. 7 Missel birdlime, has power to soften and ripen
apostumes with rosin and wax. 8 Misselto of the oak, hasill, or pearetree
gathered, so that it touch not the ground, made into powder and drunk with
wine, is good against the falling sickness, and so is beads made thereof and
hanged about the neck, or put in a silver tablet and hanged about the neck. 9
The juice of any kind of Misselto put into the ears does cleanse them, soften
them, and take away their pain. 10 Misselto stamped and applied, drives away
knots, kernels and swellings. 11 Mixed with chalk and dregs of wine, it takes
away the roughness of the nails. 12 With unslaked lime it draws forth
corns. 13 Drink the juice with rauensegs to help the falling-euill, or gather
it in March, and hang it about thy neck. 14 To cause conception, drink it with
wine before or after the terms. 15 Head turning and pain, apply Misselto. 16
Gout, boil it in water and bath therewith.

Agnailes 12 Apoplexia 5 Apostumes 1. 2. 3. 10. 12. Botches 1. 3 Conception 14
Corns 12 Ears griefs 9 Falling evil 5. 6. 8. 13 Fellons 3 Gout 16 Head ach
15. gid. 15. griefs 5. Hardness 1. 10 Kernels 10 Knots 10 Milt hard 4 Nails
rough 11 Priuities griefs 1 Sores 2. 3 Swellings 10. 12 Ulcers 2. 3 White
flawes 3
Monkshood.
MOnkshood. The powder of the seed and root mixed with oil and anointed
kills lice nits and scurfe. They are strong poison to be taken inward.

Lice, nits and scurfe 1
Mockgelouer.
MOckgelouer, or Dwarf gentian, chop it small, etc. (See Dwarf gentian.)

Morell, Nightshade, etc.
MOrell, Nighshade, or Petymorell. The green leaves stamped with parched barley
mease, is marvelous good against S. Anthonies fire, corrupt and running
ulcers, and all hot inflammations, and so is the juice with oil of Roses,
ceruse and litarge. 2 The same by it self is good against headache, the heat of
the stomach, and all hot distemperance of the ears, eyes, liver, milt, and
bladder, being stamped and applied. 3 The same with salt, dissolueth the apost.
and swellings behind the ears called Parotides being applied. 4 The juice mixed
with the white of an egg and applied to the forehead, is good against all
inflammations, rednes, reumes, fluxions, and all other hot diseases of the
eyes. 5 Ears pain, drop in the juice. 6 Flowers to stop, apply it with cotton
as a supposicer. 7 Morell is good against all diseases and accidents which
need cooling or restreining, tetters, hot scurfe and scabs. 8 The juice
drunk, does help the yelow iaundies, the burning of choler, but if one be
evil at ease after it, let him drink Oximell simplex, and put his finger into
his mouth to vomit. 9 Felon, drink the juice of Morell and Planten, and apply
the herbs. 10 Lust to void, anoint the priuities often with the juice of
Morell. 11 Sleep to cause, drink the juice of green Beries well clarified. 12
Hands itch and worms, anoint with juice of the less Morell Beries. 13 Impost.
in the stomach, liver or bowels, drink the juice of Morell with a ptisand of
barley to ripen it and destroy it. 14 Gomer passion, anoint thy yard and
clothes with Camphire and the juice of Morell. 15 Lust to void, anoint the
yard with the juice of great Morel, Housleek and vinegar. 16 Sores ranckling in
the hand, apply the juice of Morell with a possit curd. 17 Frensy, apply the
juice with vinegar to the temples. 18 Eyes ulcers, put in the juice. 19 Iaundies,
drink the juice. 20 Fevers hot, seethe it and apply it to the stomach. 21 For
any thing fallen into the ear, put in the juice. 22 Emerods and swelling of
the fundament, heat Morell on a tilestone and apply it. 23 Fundament falling,
stamp Morell with as much Houndstong, and seethe it in ale, and drink it, and
stamp Garlik, and fill the orifice with it, and it will draw it in and heal it.
24 Wounds aching, burning, and ranckling, mix the juice of Morell and Planten,
and Smallach, with honey, barley meal, or wheat flower, and whites of eggs, and
apply it cold. 25 Pety Morell, the leaves, and branches, and fruit, are best
green, they are good for stopping of the milt and liver, and for the yelow
iaundies, the juice drunk with a little Rubarb. 26 Impost. in any part, seethe the
juice with barley water and drink it. 27 Yard chafed, boil the juice with
Linseed and barowes grease, and apply it hot. It helps also the soreness of
the yard and women's breasts. 28 Ach or gouts in the arms or bones, mix Morel
with oil, and let it stand ix. days, then strein it and anoint therewith by
the fire. 29 Nightshade for biting of a mad dog, seethe it with milk and
strein it and drink it with sugar: proved. 30 Burn Nightshade, and blow the
powder into the mouth for the stink thereof. 31 Guts pain, seethe it in water
with ashes and apply it. 32 Hair not to fall, seethe the roots with
Mustardseed in wine and wash therewith. 33 Ears noise, put in the juice of the
leaves. 34 Eyes scum white or red drop in ye juice.

Morsus diaboli.
MOrsus diaboli. Seethe the herb and root in wine and drink it against all
griefs that Scabious serves for, and also against the plague, and to dissolve
bruised blood. 2 Seethe the root in wine and drink it against the pain of the
mother, and against all poison. 3 Stamp the green herb with the root and apply
it to ripen and heal carbuncles, botches, and plague sores. 4 Mix the
distilly water, or the juice with Vitriall, to dry up and heal all pushes,
whelks, moist scabs, etc. 5 Eat the root by it self, or drink the wine of the
decoction of it, for the pain of the mother, and to save a man from the plague
or pestilent air. 6 Drink the powder to kill worms. 7 Stamp the herb and
apply it to brusings and bitings. 8 Throat squincy or apostume, seethe it in
milk or water and gargarise therewith as hot as may be suffered. 9 Side
stitch, drink the water or decoction thereof. 10 Fevers in children, hang the
root and herb about their necks, and let the nurse drink powder of cristall,
or steep it in wine and drink it.

Apostume 3 Bitings 7 Botches 3 Bruses 1. 7 Carbuncles 3 Childrens fever 10
Mother 2. 5 Plague 1. 5 Plague sore 3 Poison 2 Pushes 4 Side stitch 9 Squincy 8
Scabs 4 Stitch 9 Throat swollen 8 Worms 6
Moss.
Moss. Flowers to stop, sit in the decoction of it. 2 Nose bleeding, put in
Moss. 3 It is good to be put into all salues, ointments and oils that be
astringent. 4 Moss of the Cedar is best, then that of the Poplar, and then
that of the Oak. 5 Moss of the earth sodden in wine and drunk breaks and
expels the stone. 6 Stamp it and seethe it in wine and apply it to any ache
or gout. 7 The same put into a vessel of wine and stopped in a few days
restores the wine again being dead, (see in all several trees.) 8 Matrix
white flux, foment with the decoction of Moss and trees. 9 Ache of knees or
joints, fry Moss of trees with butter and apply it.

Ache 6. 9 Gout 6 Joints ache 9 Knees ache 9 Flowers to stop 1 Matrix flux 8
Nose bleeding 2 Stone 5 Wine dead 7 Whites 8
Motherwort.
MOtherwort: bruise it and apply it to wounds to keep them from impostumation
and inflammation, to stop the blood, and to cure them. 2 It is of wonderful
force against the griefs of the heart, it helps crampes and palsies, it
kills worms in the body, it cleanses the breast from phlegm, it opens
cold obstructions, it provoke urine and terms, the juice or decoction being
drunk. 3 A sponefull of the powder of it drunk, helps ye hard labors of
women, or sees it with red nettles in wine and drink it. 4 It is good for the
falling evil. 5 Matrix suffoc. drink the juice, or drink the juice of it with
Feuerfue, with gross pepper in old ale, and be whole.

Crampes 2 Deliverance 3 Falling evil 4 Flowers stopped 2 Heart griefs 2 Matrix
suffoc. 5 Palsy 2 Urine stopped 2 Worms 2 Wounds 1
Mouseare.
MOuseare: seethe the root and leaves, and drink ye broth to cool all wounds
inward and outward, and also hernies, ruptures, and burstings. 2 Powder of the
leaves cures wounds. 3 The juice of the greater Mouseare put into the ears,
cleanses them from all filth and ache. 4 The same used in meats, clears the
sight, and cures the redness of the eyes. 5 Gather the root in May, and use
it against all ruptures, wounds, and the whites and reds in women, and to heal
a broken head. 6 If it be given any way to horses, they cannot be hurt in
shooeing. 7 Teeth-ache, put in the root. 8 Fundament fig, stamp it with
Yarrowe, Planten, and Morell, of each like much, and drink it with water. 9
Stamp it and streine it with stale ale, and give it a wounded man, if he keep
it, he shall live, or else not. 10 Fistula to heal, gather it kneeling and
saying the Lords prayer, and drink the juice 9. times, and be whole. 11 For
all evils in the stomach, stamp it with Egrimonie, Barowes grease and
vinegar, and frye them together, and apply it to the back as hot as may be
suffered. 12 Skabs dry, seethe it and herb Benit, of each like much in
running water, and wash therewith. 13 Voice to be clear, drink the juice of
Mouseare with wine or ale. 14 Emerods, drink the juice of Mouseare, Betony,
and Yarowe often. 15 Back ache, (see in Egrimonie.) 16 Iaundies, seethe it in
wine or water, and drink it. Squincie, drink Mouseare. 17 The juice heals
all wounds. For the stone and stopping of the urine, stamp Mouseare and
Hilwort, of each half a handful, with ix. quick Bees, and streine all
together with a little white wine or stale ale, and drink it, for it is
excellent. 18 For the wind chollike, stamp it with as much Prosper, and seethe
them in a double vessel with white wine, and streine it and drink it with
sugar.

Mugwort.
MVgwort: stomach pain, stamp it with oil of sweet Almo^ds and apply it. 2
Ioints ache and shaking, anoint with the juice, and oil of Roses. 3 It helps
also the drawing and shrinking of the sinowes. 4 Put it into Beer vessels to
keep it from sowring. 5 Carry it about thee to keep thee from weariness and
venomous bitings. 6 Seethe it in oil, till the third part of the oil be
wasted, and anoint any ache or gout therewith to put it away quickly. 7 Sees
it in water and apply it to a woman's nauel and thighs when she is in labor, or
apply it raw, that she may have speedy deliverance of the child and seconds,
but if it tarry long, the matrix will follow. 8 Hands trembling, steep it in
Rose water, and wash therewith. 9 Backe-ache, stamp it with Egrimony, Betony,
old grease, and vinegar or vergis, and apply it iii. or iiii. times. 10 Sit
over the fume of it, to bring down the flowers, dead birth; and seconds. 11
Mugwort helps ye suffocation and inflammatio^ of the matrix, breaks ye
stone, provoke terms and urine yt is stopped. 12 Apply it to ye nether part of
ye belly to provoke ye terms, or put it into ye matrix, or ye juice thereof
with myrrh, or drink iii. drams of the tops and leaves for the same purpose,
and to cleanse ye matrixe. 13 Stamp it and spurge with oil of sweet Almons,
and apply it to the stomach for ye pain thereof, and to bring health. 14 It is
good in women's baths, it comfort, cleanses, and warmeth the matrix, and
breaks the stone. 15 Stamp it with swines grease, and apply it to the ache
of ye feet coming by wearines. 16 Drink ii ounces of the juice with white
wine for the grief of the bladder and the strangury. 17 Drink the powder
thereof with honied wine or water to avoid the ache of ye intrales or bowels. 18
Mix the juice with swines grease and vinegar, and apply it to ye ache of the
hips iii. days together. 19 The smoke of it makes children joyful, and
drives away the incursions of ye evil. 20 For ache and swelling of the
sinowes, stamp it with oil, and apply it. 21 For great ach of ye feet, eat ye
roots thereof with honey, it is scarce to be credited how great virtue it has.
22 Anoint with the juice and oil of Roses against the fever. 23 The herb
being rubbed, smells like unto Laser. Use it in brothes or sallads for the
chollike. 24 The powder thereof and of Horehound strawed on the Emerods,
heals them. 25 Drink it with wine for the yellowe Iaundies, to comfort the
stomach, and to cause a good color. 26 Bake wheat flower with ye juice of
it, and eat it for ye bloody flux. 27 To expel gravel and stone, drink
every day half a cupfull of the juice. 28 Flowers stopped, sees it in wine, and
drink it, or stamp it and apply it to the navel and thighs. 29 Fever
quarten, drink it with oil iii. days. 30 Mix ye juice of that which has
but one stalk with oil of Roses, and anoint ye backebone and pulses therewith
to heal the fever. 31 Wearines, drink the root at night. 32 Deliverance,
apply a plaster of Mugwort, to the left thigh, and so up to the navel raw,
and also sees thereof in white wine and drink it. 33 Leapry, boil ye juice
with swines grease, and put thereto some brimstone and anoint. 34 Mother
suffocate, sliue great store of it downwards, boil it to pap in running
water, and wash therewith from the navel to the shares and grains as hot as
may be suffered, and as often as need is, but not above the navel, and at
thrice doing it will be well. 36 Women's griefs, drink Mugworte with Ale. (See
in Egrimony, Betony, Cloves, Motherwort, Bursa pastoris etc. 36 Flowers stopped,
sees it in oil, and apply it to the matrix after letting blood, or seethe it
in any wine, and drink it, or stamp it, and apply it green in the night, or
apply it to the navel. 37 For the strangurie in a cold cause, and pain in
the bladder, drink two drammes of the juice. 38 For women's griefs after
deliverance, boil the yolks of Eggs in wine if she hatte no fever, or else in
water, if she have a fever, and stamp it with the juice of Mugwort, and
Cumminseede, and apply it: proved. 39 Memory to be good, lay it in wine, and
distill it, and drink it fasting. Breast and ribs griefs general, bruise and
apply it and be whole in three days. 40 Belly ache, stamp it and apply it: or
drink the powder thereof for that grief, and many others with wine and honey.
41 Backe-ache, see in Egrimonie. 42 Mother suffoc. slip great store of the
leaves downwards, and seethe them tender in running water and wash therewith
from ye navel downewardes, but not vpwardes when you go to bed three nights
and be whole. 43 Feet pain, (See Mallowe.) 44 Gout pain, seethe a handful
in sweet oil olive, till the third part be wasted, and anoint therewith. 45
Chollike, seethe it with Sage and Smallach, of each like much in good wine,
till the third part be wasted, then streine it and drink 4. or v. ounces at
once, as often as need is. 46 Feet pain, mix the leaves and flowers with
swines grease, and apply it. 47 Feet chafed and skalded with travel, stamp
it and frye it with Barowes grease, and apply it. 48 Deliverance, drink it and
Sauery with water hot. Fevers hot, anoint the pulses and plants with the
juice. 49 Flowers stopped, stamp it with as much Rue with oil de Bay, and put
it in as a pessary in a linen bag: proved. 50 Gout, apply the leaves with
black soap and wheat flower. 51 Stone, seethe it with as much Parietary in a
pottell of white wine to the one half, and apply it to the navel as hot as
may be suffered. 52 Mugwort is good against al griefs of women. 53 Stamp it with
tallowe and apply it to the ache and soreness of the feet. 54 Keep it in the
house, and no wicked spirit shall come there. 55 Stamp it with running water,
and use it for ye ache of the belly and many other griefs. 56 Stomach griefs
general, drink ye seeds. 57 Mugwort cleanses ye mother, causes terms and
conceptio^. 58 To cause deliverance of a dead child, stamp it and apply it
cold to ye womb.

Mulberie.
MVlbery: the green and unripe fruit dried, do stop the belly, the
bloody-flixe, and vomiting, being drunk with red wine. 2 The ripe berries
taken fasting, do loosen the belly, but after meat they are soon corrupted
in the stomach, and cause windiness. Of the juice of ripe Mulberies is made a
confection in manner of a syrup, very good for ulcers and hot swellings of ye
tongue, mouth, and almonds of the throat. 3 Burnings, apply the leaves with
oil. 4 Sees the bark of the root in water, and drink it to open the liver
and milt, to loosen the belly, and expel worms both long and flat. 5
Teeth-ache, hold the decoction of ye leaves and roots in thy mouth. Skotch the
root about ye latter end of harvest, and there will come forth a gum or juice
exceeding good for the toothache, and to drive away all swellings and lumps,
and will purge ye belly. It is to be had under ye root on ye morrow after it is
skotcht. 6 The fresh leaves are good in meats. 7 Stamp them with vinegar to
heal burnings and skaldings. The juice looseneth the belly, and taken ii.
ounces and a half it is good for the bitings of ye field spider. 8 The leaves
are a sovereign medicine for the squincie and strangling. 9 The bark is a
treacle against ye poison of Henbane. 10 When ye tree begins to bud, ye
chief cold of winter is past. 11 Put ripe Mulberies into wine, if they swim,
ye wine is pure, if they sink, it is mixed with water. 12 Drink the powder of
Mulberies to stop spitting of blood and the laske. 13 Eyes dull, put in powder
of the leaves. 14 Teeth-ache, seethe ye rind of the root in the juice of a
cluster of grapes to the one half, and wash therewith, and they will never
ache, or seethe the scrapings of the root in wine, and hold it in thy mouth. 15
Apost. to break, drink very ripe Mulberies, and also apply them.

Apostume 15 Belly bound 2. 7 Bitings venom. 7 Bloody-fluxe 1 Burnings 3. 7
Eyes dull 13 Fluxes 1. 12 Liver stopped 4 Lumps 5 Milt stopped 4 Mouth grief 2
Poison 9 Purgation 5 Skalding 7 Spitting blood 12 Squincie 8 Swellings 5
Teeth-ache 5. 14 Throat griefs 2. 8 Vomiting 1 Wine to try 11 Worms 4
Mullin.
MVllin: sees it in wine, and skom it and drink it, and also wash the Emerods
therewith to heal them. 2 It is good for ye flux. 3 Bruise, wash ye sore, and
anoint with the juice, and apply the bruised leaves 24. hours to heal it
speedely. 4 Emerods, stamp ye small leaves, and fry them with sheep suet, and
apply them in a linen bag twice a day, and keep it warm. Apply powder of
Mullin with the juice of Horehound to break their swelling. 5 Horse cough, and
broken winded, give him powder of it to drink in his water: Gentian will do
the like. 6 Warts, stamp the flowers between two stones, and apply them, or
apply the distilled water of them. 7 Eyes red and dropping, wash with the water
of Mullin. 8 Matrix windy, apply the juice of Mullin and Rapes with Barlye
meal. 9 Cankers, burn it and apply the powder. 10 Burnings, bathe it with the
water distilled in a Limbecke, or with barbars lee, or anoint it presently with
honey. 11 Skab and itch, distill the flowers and leaves in a Limbecke, and use
the water with cloutes. 12 Wounds to close up, stamp the flowers, and apply
them. 13 Emerods, sit over the fume of the roots, or stamp Mullin, and seethe
it in good red wine and apply it: or mix the juice with as much Barowes grease
by little and little, and anoint therewith warm: or apply Mallows sodden in
running water hot. 14 Bleeding in any place, stamp it and apply it to the
branches of the teates. 15 Belly loose, drink one knot of the root of it. 16
Emerods, seethe it in wine, and apply it, or apply the rust or skalles of iron,
with the juice of it, or apply the juice mixed with Antimonium and silk. 17
Tenesmus, seethe it and stamp it, and apply it to the fundament, or sit over
the fume of it. 18 Fever tertian, put the juice of it into the nostrels before
the fit. 19 Fever quarten, drink the juice before the fit. 20 Bitings venomous
and stingings, put in the juice, and apply the rest. 21 Fundament falling, frye
it with sheep tallowe, and mix it with oil Olive, and apply it hot. 20
Gout cold, seethe it in wine and apply it. 23 Wounds of sword, or staff,
wash it with white wine warm, and put in the juice, and apply the substance,
and bind it fast to a whole day. 24 Emerods, boil two leaves with fresh
butter in a sawser till they be soft, and apply them hot as may be suffered.
25 Flowers stopped, bind it to the soles of the feet, flowers to stop, bind it
to the arm pits. 26 Fundament fig, an anodine infallible, stamp Mullin with
as much salt, and apply it either to man or beast: proved. 27 Canker in the
mouth or gums, sees the roots in strong vinegar, and wash therewith ii. or
iii. times a day, and anoint it with alome and honey incorporated together. 28
Gout, sees Mullin in wine, and apply it. Piles, sees ye leaves soft in water
and mix them with May butter, and anoint therewith. 22 Leapry and falling of
ye hair, seethe it with Scabious in water, and bathe therewith. 30 Sees the
root in red wine and drink it to stop and heal ye dangerous flux, and the
bloody-fluxe. 31 For ye cold cough and all ruptures, boil it in water and
drink it. 32 Teethach and griefs of the mouth, seethe the root and gargarise
therewith. 33 Dry Figs wrapped in Mullin leaves, may be long kept from
corruption. 34 The leaves are good to wipe and cleanse the Emerods withal. 35
Sees the leaves in wine and wash the mouth therewith for the griefs thereof.
36 Stamp the leaves and juice, and apply it to any bruise or stroke 24. hours
to heal it finely. 37 The leaves and flowers allayeth all ache both inward and
outward. 38 Belly loose, drink the root. 39 The root sodden in red wine, or
in a fever with water and drunk, helps the white flux, and is good against
al ruptures, and fractures, bruises, griefs of the lungs, ye cough, al inward
impostumes, all aches, and inflammations. 40 Eyes inflamed, and likewise the
fundament and privy parts, and for all botches and goutes, sees the leaves
and flowers in water, and apply them. 41 Use the distilled water into the eyes
to stop their running. 42 Apply the same to all redness and pimples of the
face, the shingles, S. Antonies fire, burnings, scabs, and leapry. 43 Stamp
the herb in a leaden mortar with clarified honey, and put thereto wine and
vinegar, and use it to heal ulcers and stinging of waspes, adders, and snakes.
44 Burnings and skaldings apply the juice of the leaves with oil of Linseede.
45 Fistula, put in ye pith of the root. 46 Kings evil, sees the flowers in
vinegar, and gargarise therewith, and apply it. 47 The root, seed, or leaf
sodden in wine and drunk, is good for all the griefs of the lungs, breasts,
sides, and reins, and also casts out of the flesh any thing therein fixed,
as nail, thorn, or prick. 48 A good medicine for horses, kine, or swine,
stamp Mullin, and put thereto Fenegreeke and Madder with warm Ale, and give
it them with a horn or tunnell to cleanse and heal their lungs, and so to
save many that otherwise would die. 49 The leaves of that with the golden
flowers sodden in water, are good for the swellings and inflammations of the
eyes, and for sores and rottenness with honey or wine, but with vinegar they
heal wounds. 50 The black Mullin with his pleasant yellowe flowers, boiled in
water or wine, is good against the diseases of the breast, lungs, spitting of
rotten and corrupt matter. 51 The leaves of the same boiled with Rue, does
appease the pain of the side. 52 And the same boiled in water are good for the
cold swellings, and the ulcers, and inflammations of the eyes. 53 And punned
with honey and wine, they cure mortified ulcers, and with vinegar they cure the
inflammation of wounds. 54 The golden flowers steeped in lee, colors the
hair yellowe, being often washed with it. 55 The seeds of Mullin is good to
be drunk against burstings and falling out of joints, to cease the swelling
and ache.

Mustardseede.
MVstardseede: it may be kept v. years. 2 Chewe it, and hold it under thy
tongue for the palsy thereof. 3 And for the palsy in any place, seethe a bag
of the seeds in wine, and apply it especially in the beginning of the
sickness. 4 Head to purge, provoke sneesing with the powder of it. Stingings,
apply the seeds with vinegar. 5 The seeds do merueilously purge, break the
stone, and comfort the stomach. 6 Stamp them with Elecampana, and apply them to
apost. to ripen, break, and draw them without pain. 7 Gargle the seeds with
water and honey, to help the blistering of the mouth and the squincy. 8
Dropsy, eat the seeds with Figs and Cummin. 9 Mix the seeds with Pellitory
and Ginger, of each like much with roasted honey, and wash the mouth therewith,
holding it therein a good while to purge the brain, and to void headache,
and the falling of the roof of the mouth, and ulcers of the throat. 10 Mix
meal of the seeds with honey, and make little balls of it, and swallowe down
thereof every morning to have a clear voice to sing in short time. 11 Chew ye
seeds to drawn phlegm and purge the head. 12 Honey with Mustard and vinegar
together, is an excellent gargarisme to purge the head, teeth, and throat. 13
Mustard is good against all the griefs of the lungs, stomach, phlegm, and
rawnesse of the guts, and conducent food to the body, provoke urine, helps
the palsy, wastes the quarten, dries up moist reumes applied plasterwise to
the head. 14 Honey and Mustard helps ye cough, and is good for the falling
sickness: but the common use of it is ill for the eyes, it is good against all
cold passions of the belly. 15 Sneesing with Mustardseede may be helped by
holding bread to the nose. 16 Grind Mustard with vinegar, and rub the plants of
the feet therewith to help the Lethargy. 17 Lay 7. whole Eggs in vinegar till
their shells be tender, and put thereto iiii. ounces of stamped Mustardseede,
grind them together, and anoint therewith spots of the face to cleanse and
heal them. 18 Boil Mustard with vinegar and pepper, and hold a spoonefull in
thy mouth, and walk up and down, and when it is cold, spit it out and take
another to purge reume. 19 The seed with vinegar is good against all venomous
bitings. 20 The seeds ground with vinegar is a wholesome sause for hard and
gross meats either fish or flesh: for it helps digestion, warmeth ye
stomach, and provoke appetite. 21 It is good in meats for them that be
short winded, and stopped in the breast: for it ripeth and causes to cast out
raw phlegm from the stomach and breast. 22 The seeds chewed cleanses the
brain and helps the toothache, and so it does mixed with mede and gargled.
22 Gargarise with honey, Mustard, and vinegar against ye swelling of the vuula
and almonds about the throat and root of the tongue, but if they be old and
hard, then take the juice pressed out of the seed, and mix it with mede, and
so it slaketh and consumes such swellings and hardness. 24 Drink the seeds
with honied water against the shakings and fits of agues, and to provoke urine
and the terms. 25 Sneese with the seeds against the falling evil, and
strangling of the mother. 26 Senuie draws from the bottom of griefs and
aches, and is good for the milt. 27 With vinegar it is good against all
venomous bitings. 28 Stamp it with figs, and apply it to the humming and noise
of the head and ears, and for deafness. 29 The juice of Senuie dried in the
sun, and after dissolved in honey, clears the sight, and takes away the
roughness of the eyebrowes. 30 Apply a plaster to the head of them that have
the Lethargy and drowsy evil, to the sciatica, hardness of the milt, the
dropsy of the belly, all cold griefs and diseases, especially when they are
waxen old to bring into them the heat again, and to draw forth the cold
humors. 31 Senuie with honey and new grease, or with a cerote of wax, cures
the naughty skurffe and skabs of the head, which cause the hair to fall off.
It skowreth the face from all freckles and spots, and takes away blewe marks
that come of brusing. 32 Laid to with vinegar, it cures leapries, wild skabs,
running skurfe, and bitings of serpents. 33 The perfume thereof drives away
all venom and venomous beasts. 34 Drink Senuie with wine to purge the brain,
warm the stomach, help digestion, provoke lust, expel urine, increase
natural seed, and void the continual pain of the belly. 35 Sees it in
wine, and drink it against poison and venomous bitings. 36 Grind it with
vinegar, and anoint therewith red pushes, tetters, and creeping sores. 37 Sees
ye meal thereof with water and honey, and use it against al hard swellings and
old knots of ye jaws and windpipe. 38 Mix the meal thereof with honey or fat,
and anoint thy head and beard therewith against ye falling of the hair, and to
cleanse ye face and avoid blew marks of stripes and bruses. The best seed is
red and full grown, not wrinckled. 39 With a fig and vinegar, it blistreth and
draws out old aches, and dissolueth hardness. 40 Memory to be good, and to
void the Lethargy, rub well the plants of the hands and feet with Mustard
and vinegar. 41 For the sciatica and swelling of liver and milt, stamp the
seeds with a third part of bread, dry figs, honey, and vinegar: it is a noble
plaster. 42 For ye Gout of what cause soever it be, grind the seeds with
strong vinegar, and apply it to the place till it be hot as may be well
suffered, then take it of and anoint the place against the fire with grease of
a male hog for a man, and of a female hog for a woman, and chafe it well in,
and do so three or four times if need be, it never fails. 43 Headache,
stamp the seeds and streine them with water, and mix it with honey, and
gargarise therewith. 44 Childrens heads skalde, grind the seeds with honey,
and grind therewith often to heal their skabs. 45 Leapry, burn Haselnut
shelles, and mix the ashes with powder of the seeds, and Goose grease, and
anoint. 46 Lethargy, mix powder of the seeds with the juice of Smallache and
vinegar, and apply it. 47 Palsy, eat powder of the seeds with sugar. 48
Reins griefs, anoint with oil of Senuie. 49 Headache to cleanse it out, mix
powder of pepper with as much Mustard, and roll as much as a pease with thy
tongue about thy mouth fasting. 50 Cough, chewe the seeds in thy mouth, but
do not swallowe it down. 51 Oil of Senuy seed, grind iiii. pound of the
seed, with iiii. pound of oil, and let it stand ten days, then streine it
and keep it for palsies, goutes, stitches, and swellings. 52 Litargie, anoint
well thy head and forehead with Mustardseede and vinegar, and bind it thereto
all night. 53 Matrix windy, foment with ye decoction of the leaves. 54
Agnailes, stamp the seeds with swines grease, and apply it. 55 Apostume to
remove, (see in Eldren.) Breast pain, (see Figs.) 56 Cough, (see Pepper.) 57
Litargy, anoint well thy head and forehead with the seeds and vinegar, and
bind it to all night. 58 If a man stand in doubt of the palsy, let him eat
ii. or iii. seeds with ii. corns of pepper. 59 Headache, stamp the leaves,
and apply it. 60 Reume, shave the head, and apply the seeds, or put the seeds
in dry Figs, and eat them at night against reume, and stopping of the lungs.
61 Spitting blood, fill Figs with the seeds, and seethe them in Claret wine,
and eat the Figs, and drink the wine at night to open the liver, and have
breath at will. 62 Dropsy, drink the seeds or wine of the decoction thereof.
63 Gout, mix the seeds with a little bread, dry Figs, honey and vinegar, and
apply it. 64 Fevers cold, as quotidians, and quartens, eat the seeds before
the fit. 65 Scrophules to cleanse, stamp the seeds with old grease and apply
it. 66 Forgetful, rub ye soles of the feet with the seeds ground with
vinegar. 67 Chollike, grind the seeds with figs and vinegar, and apply it
cold. 68 Bitings venom. apply ye seeds with vinegar. Plague, (see F^gs.) 69
Hair not to fall, seethe the seeds with the roots of Nightshade, and wash
therewith. 70 Matrix windy and swollen, seethe the seeds in water, and foment
the place therewith. 71 Tongue heavy by much moisture, mix the seeds with
honey, and hold as much as a bean in thy mouth, and also suck thereof for the
old cough, and spit out the rest. 72 Stamp the seeds, and boil them with
water, and drink thereof fasting to help ye cough, (See Pepper, Alehoofe,
Colewort. 73 Palsy and weakness of the stomach of cold cause, and for the
megreme, anoint with ye oil. 74 Head to purge, eat the seeds, and put some
into the nose. 75 Fevers general, mix Mustard with as much Treacle as a
bean, and drink it thrice before the fit. 76 Stomach ill, drink Mustard and
red vinegar of each a sauser full, with as much Treacle as a bean. 77 Tongue
palsy, chewe the seeds, and hold them under thy tongue. 78 Seethe the seeds
in wine with figs, and hold thereof in thy mouth till it be almost cold v. or
vi. times a day for the old pose and cough, and to cleanse ye brain and lungs.
79 Sees the seeds in water with Fenel roots, and streine it, and put honey to
it, and drink it for the stopping of the milt. 80 Milt hard, sees the leaves
in wine, and apply it. To ripen and break an apostume, stamp the herb with
hogs grease, and apply it. 81 Strangurie, sees the seeds in oil and wine,
and apply it. 82 Sciatica, and other old sores, mix the seeds with vinegar,
figs, white bread and honey, and apply it. 83 Eat the seeds to sharpen the
memory and wits, to cleanse the belly, to break the stone, to purge the urine
and menstrues, and to comfort ye stomach. 84 Surfeit or fulness, and want of
digestion, eat a spoonefull of the dry seeds, and drink ii. or iii.
spoonefull of water presently after it, and in the morning thou shall be well.
85 Tetter, grind the seeds with honey, and apply it once or twice. Oil of
Senuie, grind ye seeds with like weight of sallet oil, and let it stand 9.
days, then streine it and use it for palsies, stitche, goutes, and swellings.

Sneesing to cause 4 to stop 15 Spitting blood 61 Stinging 5 Stitch 51. 86
Squincy 7. 9 Stomach ill 76 cold 20. 34 weak 5. 73 Stone 5 Strangury 81
Surfeit 8. 4 Swellings 23. 51. 86 Teeth-ache 22 Tetter 36. 85 Tongue palsy 2.
77. heavy 71 Throat sore 12. 23 Venom 33 Voice ill 10 Vrin stopped 13. 34 Vuula
fallen 9. 23
Nauewe.
NAuewe sodden in two waters tender, has indifferent nourishment between good
and ill, but not well boiled, it is hard to digest, and causes windiness, and
stopping of the veins and pores, so that it were good to boil them in two
waters, and the third time in fat broth of Beef or Mutton, it nourishes less
then Rape or Turnip. 2 The seeds are good against poison, and therefore put
into Treacles and preservatives. 3 And being drunk, it is good against poison
and venom. (See Long rape.

Poison 2. 3 Venom 3
Nenupher.
NEnupher, or water Lilly, The root or seed of the white boiled in wine and
drunk, stops the laske and bloody flux, and Tenasmus. 2 Boil it in white
wine to cure the griefs of the milt and bladder. 3 The seed and root in
decoctions drunk, is good against venus and fleshly lusts, or the same used
in meats or powder, does the like, and dries up the seed of generation, and
so does the root bruised and applied to the genitours. 4 The Conserve of the
flowers is also good for all the aforesaid, and for hot burning Fevers, for
the headache, and to procure sweet sleep, and avoid all Venerious dreams.
5 The root stamped and applied, is good for the pain and inflammation of the
bladder, and stomach. 6 The same root stamped with water, takes away all
spots of the skin, being often rubbed therewith, and applied to wounds, it
stauncheth blood, and being mixed with tar, it cures the naughty skurfe of ye
head. 7 The root of yellow water Lilly boiled in thick red wine and drunk,
stops the flowers, especially the whites, and so does the seed. 8 The
water of the flowers of the white, or the Conserve thereof, is good for all
burning fevers in the plague time, and for the ethike and plurisie, the dry
cough and thirst, the inflammation of the liver and milt, and for the daily
white flux. It quenches lust, and so does the oil thereof. 9 The root of
the white sodden in red wine, is excellent good to stop the flowers, and so is
the seed thereof. 10 The water of the white helps the hot griefs of the
head, the inflammation of the liver and milt, and all hot pushes. It helps
the ache of the back and kidneis, and so does the oil thereof, which oil
helps also carbuncles, felons, vncomes, and hot apostumes, and ulcers, in
any part of the body. 11 The water heals all hot griefs of the face, the
morphewe and skurfe, and all other griefs that come of hot cause. 12 To dry
up the Emerods, or any sore, cast on powder of the leaves of Nenuphar or Canes.
13 Bowels griefs, and watery ruptures, distill the flowers in Balneo mariae,
and drink ii. ounces of the water morn and even 10. or 12. days. 14 Eyes
ache, sees the flowers in water and drop it in warm. 15 Flowers to stop, use
powder of the root or seed of yellowe water Lillies, it is the best medicin.
16 Yard standing, or satiriasis, stamp water Lilly, and apply it. 17 Stamp
the flowers with wine, and drink it to stop vomiting. Flowers to stop, use the
seeds or roots. 18 Fever ephemera, use the syrup of the flowers. It helps
also all sharp fevers.

Apostume hot 10 Backe-ache 10 Belly-ache 13 Bladder griefs 2. 5 Bloody flux
1 Bursten 13 Consumption 8 Cough dry 8 Carbuncle 10 Dreams ill 4 Eyes ache 14
Emerods 12 Face deformed 11 Fellon 10 Fevers hot 4. 8. 18 Flowers to stop 7.

void 3. 4. 8 Milt grief 2 hot 10 stopped 8 Morphewe 11 Plague 8 Plurisie 8

Nettle.
NEttle: The seed of Roman Nettles mixed with Honey and licked often, cleanses
the breast from all tough slimie phlegm and rotten humors, and is good for
shortness of breath, the vehement cough of children, the inflammation of the
Lungs, the old purisie or Longsought. 2 The same drunk with sweet wine,
causes lust, and helps the windiness of the stomach. 3 And one scruple
drunk with Mede after supper, causes an easy vomit. 4 The leaves boiled
with Mussles and drunk, do soften the belly and provoke Urine. 5 The
decoction of the leaves of all kind of Nettles drunk with Myrrh provoke
the terms, and so does Nettle seeds drunk with sweet Wine. 6 The juice of
the leaves gargled, helps much against the falling and inflammation of the
Vuula. 7 Biting of a mad dog, stamp the leaves with salt and apply them, and
so it helps malignant Ulcers, Kankers and such like stinking sores, and all
hard swellings, apostumes, botches behind the ears. Milt hard, mix the
leaves with oil and wax, and apply it. 8 Nose bleeding, stamp it and apply
it to the Nose and forehead: but put into the Nose, it causes it to bleed. 9
Flowers to cause, stamp it with Myrre, and put it in as a Pessarie. 10 Use the
buds of red Nettles in brothes at the spring of the year to cleanse the
breast, break wind, and expel urine. 11 Sees the leaves in wine and drink
it to soften the belly, to expel wind and help the torments thereof, to
purge the loins, to provoke urine and lust: or sees the seeds in new wine,
or mix the seeds with Honey and lick it in: it helps also all inward
wounds. 12 Sees the root of the great keen Nettle in wine with Honey, and use
it against the old and cold cough, wheasing, hoarsenesse, and to cleanse the
Lungs, chest and breast, and help the Plurisie and other griefs of the
breast, and of the Vuula coming of Viscus Humors. 13 Gargarise therewith for
the griefs of the mouth, but the seeds with Honey is best. 14 Stamp the
leaves with salt and apply it to the bitings of mad dogs, and to wounds, rotten
sores, Gangrenes, evil ulcers, creeping sores and tetters, apostumes,
hardness, cold swellings of the joints, milt, behind the ears. 15 Let him
that is nettled, anoint the place with oil of Roses or of Olives. 16 The
green leaves applied, sets the Matrixe in the place, if it be fallen. 17
The seeds drunk with Malmesie provoke lust, and opens the Matrixe. 18 The
powder of the seeds with wine or broth, increases natural seed. 19 The
seeds of red Nettles gathered between Saint Mary days, may serve poor men
in stead of Pepper, and is as good as Pepper. 20 The juice with clarified Honey
cleanses the Lungs, stomach and sides, and drunk with Ptisan, it cleanses
the belly and Matrixe. The juice drunk with Myrre warm, provoke the terms.
21 The leaves sodden with fish or flesh, cleanses the reins, back and bladder,
and provoke vrin. 22 And they are good against obstructions of the Liver in
cold causes, and kill worms. 23 The syrope thereof is most excellent to be
drunk of women in their painful travel, and causes speedy deliverance. 24
Stamp it and eat it with Honey for the shortness of breath and Plurisie, and
to cleanse the breast, and so does the decoction thereof with Barley. 25 And
the juice gargled, cures the apostume of the Vuula. 26 Eaten with Onyons and
yolks of eggs, it moves Venus, looseneth the Belly, provoke urine, and
helps the ache of the kidneys. 27 And drunk with Hemp seed, it helps the
ache of the milt and side. 28 Anoint the arteries with the juice to mitigate
the feuerous heat of the Heart. 29 Chewe the root and hold it in thy mouth to
stop any bleeding. 30 Drink one spoonefull of the powder of the red Nettle
with a draught of red wine every day to break the stone, though it be never so
great. 31 Sees red Nettles and Mallows in water, and drink thereof, and also
sit over the fume of it. 32 Cast a sick man's water on a red Nettle, if it die
by the next morning, he shall die, if not, he shall live: or steep it in his
vrin four and twenty hours for the same purpose. 33 Swelling of toothache,
mix the juice of the seeds with the white of an Egg, Frankincence, and
Wheat flower, and apply it. 34 Nose bleeding, rub the temples with the juice
thereof. 35 Stomach weak, drink the seeds every morning with Malmesie. 36
Make Lee of the ashes of the roots of Nettles, Colewurts and Brionye, and wash
the pain of the head therewith. 37 Drink a spoonefull or more of the powder
of the seeds with good wine, to assuage the pain and windiness of the
Matrixe. 38 Lick in a scruple of the said powder, with syrope of Violets, to
spit out Viscus matter and tough humors. 39 Stamp the tops of red Nettles,
and seethe them in white wine in an earthen vessel to the one half, and
drink a good draught morn and even ten days, and apply the herb to the
Fundament against the going out thereof, to heal it perfectly. 40 Palsy,
anoint the place with sallet oil, and cast on powder of Pepper, and lay too
Nettles, and when the warmenesse is come into the member, take them away, and
anoint with the oil for the Palsy. 41 Whelkes or ploukes, anoint with the
roots of Nettles and Dockes. Melancholy, rub the body with Nettles. 42 Fear
and fancy, carry Nettles and Five leaf in thy hand. 43 Spitting matter,
lick in powder of the seed with syrope of Violets, or other Pectorall
medicines, by a little at once. 44 Children syriasis coming of inflammation of
the brain, Stamp Nettles with Populeon, and apply it to the temples and
wrists at every half hours end, till it be whole. 45 Anoint the forehead
with the juice of Greek Nettles, to stop bleeding at the Nose, or chewe Nettle
roots till they may be swallowed down. 46 Gout, stamp keen Nettles and Sage
of each an handful with Barrowes grease, and apply it. 47 Sciatica, bruise the
seeds and apply them, or if the pain be not very vehement, apply Nettles
vnstamped: but if it be vehement, stamp them and apply them, or stamp red
Nettles two hands full with wheat branne and Deares sewet, and apply it as
hot as may be suffered. 48 For the Vuula, use the juice of Nettles and
vinegar. 49 Wounds, stamp Nettles with salt and apply it. 50 Head ach of
blood, put powder of the seeds of red Nettles into thy Nose. 51 Sweat to
cause, sees Nettles in oil of Nuts, and anoint therewith at nights. 52 Hair
to void, shave it and stamp Nettle head with vinegar, and anoint when thou
sweatest in thy bed two days, and it will grow no more. 53 Headache, make Lee
with white wine and Colewurts, and Nettles burned, and wash therewith. 54
Sleep to cause (See Beam. 55 Cough, seethe the seeds in oil and anoint thy
hands and feet. 56 Stomach phlegm, seethe good store of Nettles in running
water and butter till they be tender, and eat them. 57 Women's breasts to be
soft, drink Nettles and salt with ale. 58 Fundament falling out, seethe red
Nettle crops with white wine to the one half, and drink thereof first and
last, and apply the herb hot as may be suffered, and be whole. 59
Consumption, seethe a pint of the juice of young Nettles, and skum it till it
wax red, then put thereto a quart of Malmesie and brewe them together a good
space, then put in yolks of eggs well beaten, and Sugar, and brewe them well
together, and take thereof a reasonable draught morn and even blood warm. 60
Flesh to grow fair and well, stamp red Nettles with two or three corns of
salt and some May butter, and apply it. 61 Gout in the bones, stamp Nettles
and apply them. 62 Stone to break and avoid, chop the roots of red Nettles,
Parsley and Parietarie, in all two pound, steep them in a quart of white wine
four and twenty hours, then distill them and drink the water. 63 Hair
eaten with worms, seethe Sage and Nettles in wine, and wash thy head
therewith, and cast on powder of Nep. 64 Blood to stop, stamp red Nettles and
red Colewurts, and apply them. 65 Kanker, stamp red Nettles with salt, and
apply it. 66 The tops of Nettles gathered when they begin to seed given to
Hens with a little Branne and Hemp seed, cause them to lay Eggs all
winter. 67 Fish to catch, anoint thy hand with the juice of Greek Nettles, and
hold it in the water, and the fishes will come to it. 68 Back ach and bloody
Urine, take Polypody, water Cresses, and red Nettle croppes, of each one
handful, seethe them in Ale and streine it and drink it morn and even with
Sugar. Nose bleeding, drink the juice of red Nettles, with some Chaulke if
need be, or make powder of Nettle seed, Bursa pastoris, and Camphere, and
make little baules thereof with the juice of Bursa Pastoris; and put them in,
or drink the juice of red Nettles. 69 Bruised and voyding blood; drink the
juice of the young buds of red Nettles either by it self or with vinegar, or
with cold water, and there is none so corrupt blood but it will purify it,
nor no laske so great but it will stop it. 70 Face false phlegm, grynd powder
of Ginger and brimstone, with honey and red Nettles and anoint therewith. 71
Falling evil, drink the water of the less Nettle. 72 Agew cake, take
Wormwood, red Nettles, red Mints ana one handful, fry them with fresh butter,
and apply it as hot as may be suffered, and use other helps withal. 73 Stone,
seethe mother Time, and red Nettle crops of each one handful in a quart of
white wine to the one half, then streine it, and put in half a spoonefull of
sea Holly in powder, and drink thereof daily. 74 Women's griefs, let her drink
the juice of red Nettles with ale, and cast her on her belly, and cast her
hair into her mouth, and cause her to vomit. 75 Wounds bleeding, stamp red
Nettle crops with honey, and apply it, or bruise a good handful of Nettles, and
bind them hard to, to stop it presently. 76 Sleep to cause (See Colewort.) 77
Blood to stop, chew the root well, and hold it in thy mouth, but swallow it not
and thou shall loose no blood, or blow in the powder of a Nettle into thy nose.
78 Fundament chaps and emerods, lay brimstone on hot coals, and thereon blind
Nettles, and sit over the fume thereof thrice. 79 Matrix suffoc. stamp Nettles
and put them into the matrix, and drink Parsnep seed with wine. 80 Matrix
pain and windy, drink the seeds with wine. 81 Breasts swollen, seethe Nettels
in vinegar and apply them in all increase of the same, and for all swellings
and hardness with oil of Roses. 82 Gout ache, seethe Nettles that grow in a
hot ground and dry, in lee of vine ashes, and wash it therewith and apply the
Nettles. 83 Fever tertian apply the like Nettles stamped with salt to the pulses
of the arms before the fit. 84 Fever hot, annoint the pulses with the juice.
85 Stone to break, drink one spoonefull of powder of the root with white wine
somewhat warm daily, 86 Fundament fallen, stamp the tops of red Nettles in a
stone vessel vt supra. 87 Breast to open and to drive out gravel from the
back; drink powder of the seeds. 88 F^^er quarten, stamp Nettles with
copwebs and salt in a wooden dish, and apply it to the left arm, to take away
the heat of the fever. 89 Gout, seethe Nettles in oil and wine, and apply
them hot two or three times. 90 For voyding of blood at the fundament, and to
stop all fluxes, drink the juice of the young springs in the mornings by it
self, or with some strong vinegar and cold water. 91 Pricks, stamp the
roots with salt and apply them. 92 Matrixe falling out, stamp the leaves and
apply them. 93 Hands scabd by the French pocks, seethe a handful of leaves
with Cinnamom, and Cloves, of each two drams, and bath the hands with the fume
thereof sodden in water. (See in Cloves.) 94 Emerods, cresty swellings of the
fundament, and rednes of the face, apply the juice or water of blind Nettles.
95 Apost. to ripen, stamp green Nettle seed and salt and apply it. 96 Hair
not to grow, anoint the place with the warm blood of a Hare, and upon that
anoint with wild Nettle seed and oil Olive. 97 Kings evil, drink Nettles with
wine. 98 Dead flesh in sores, put in powder of Nettles to cleanse and cure it.
99 Cough of cold cause, stamp the seeds and wixe them with honey, and use it as
an electuary, it dissolueth all cold humors. 100 Swelling, drink iii. vials
of the juice three days. 101 Breast to cleanse, sees Nettles in barley water and
drink it. It cleanses the stomach also, voydeth vomiting, helps the chollick,
expels wind and cold out of the lungs, swelling of the belly, and the
cause thereof. 102 The Nettle also is good for the griefs of the joints. 103
Nose bleeding, burn red Nettles and their roots, and blow in the powder. 104
The juice of red Nettles stops all fluxes of blood at the Nose, bloody
flux, of what cause soever they be, Emerods and all such like, etc. 105 Ach,
anoint with the juice of red Nettles. 106 Conception to know, give her the
juice of red Nettles, if she cast it up, she is corrupted by man, if she keep
it, she is a maid. 107 Face mesels, mix bores grease with the juice of Cresses
and of Nettles of each like much, and put quickesiluer to it and anoint morn
and even. 108 Nostrels stink, burn green Nettles and mix their powder with
as much burnt Pepper, and blow it in to bedward. 109 Palsy, if the skin be
thick by lack of flesh, rub it well with crops of red Nettles, that the
ointment may the better go in, which is this, Roste three or four red Onyons
tender, stamp them with four times so much of the gaul of an Ox or Bull all
of one color, and anoint well the place till it be drunk in, and wrappe thee
well in a clean sheet, and do so nine nights, it will make the flesh grow,
though it be much away: and it serves for all aches. 110 Face salsflegme,
anoint with Barrowes grease, Mercury and red Nettles. 111 Palsy, distill red
Nettles with Juniper and red wine, and drink three spoones full morn and even
daily. 112 Blood to stop of vein or senowe, stamp red Nettles and Colewurt
leaves with Hogs doung and apply it. 113 Deliverance to cause, seethe red
Nettles and Motherwurt in wine and drink it. 114 Lust to void, drink red
Nettle seeds and the flowers of Poplar or Willowe. 115 Iaundies, seethe the
roots of red Nettles, red Dockes and Celondine in white wine, and put Honey to
it, and drink thereof morn and even 116 Drink the juice of Nettles with
wine, to dissolve bruised blood. 117 Flowers to stop, bruise Nettle roots, and
apply them one night. 118 Kankers and ulcers, stamp the seeds and apply them.
119 Breast phlegm, drink the crops of red Nettles, red Mints and Wormwood
with red wine or stale ale first and last. 120 If a woman piss on green
Nettles, and they die, she is no maid. 121 Cast a sick man's Urine on a red
Nettle while it is warm, at night, if it be dead in the morning, he shall die,
or else not.
