Nigella.
NIgella or Gyth: Drink the seeds in wine to help shortness of breath, to
dissolve all windiness in the body, to provoke urine and terms, to increase
milk. 2 Drink it with wine or water, or apply it to the Navel to kill
worms, or anoint with the oil of the seed. 3 Drink one dram with water
against all poisons and venomous bitings 4 The fume thereof tosted or burned,
drives away all venomous beasts, and kills flies, bees and waspes. 5 Head
ach, apply it to the forehead with oil of Arios, and put it often into the
Nose against the Web and bloodshoting in the eyes in their beginning. 6 Put the
powder of it into a thin bag and smell to it often to cure all Murres or
Catarres and Poses, to dry the brain, and to restore the smelling being lost.
7 Boil it with vinegar and hold it in the mouth to swage the tooth ach. 8 Chew
it dry to cure the ulcers of the mouth. 9 For Lentiles, Freckles and other
spots in the face, to cleanse the skurfe and itch, and to soften old, cold
and hard swellings, stamp it with vinegar and apply it. 10 Steep it in old
wine or stale urine, to cause Corns and Agnailes to fall off, being first
scarrified round about. 11 Too much of it taken, brings death. 12 Apply the
seeds with Rose vinegar to the forehead against the Frenzy. 13 It serves
also for the same things that Coliander is good for. 14 Drop the juice into
the eyes, to heal the Epiphora, or dropping. 15 Stamp it with an Ox gaul and
apply it to the belly to kill worms. 16 Wild cockle that grows in corn, is
of the same kind, and the juice may be pressed forth as Opium, and kept for
medicin to cause sleep. 17 Nigella Romans provoke sneesing. 18 Ptisick, put
powder thereof in a linen cloth and smell to it often. 19 Brain feeble, mix
powder of the seeds with oil of Camomile or other oil, and drop thereof into
thy Nose in the mornings. 20 Put the flower thereof into the Matrixe, to draw
out all contents therein, as flowers, birth, seconds, etc. 21 To dry up milk
in ye breasts, seethe the seeds in wine and drink it. 22 Face pimples and
spots, grind the seeds with flower and Honey, and anoint to bedward, and in
the morning wash with Parsley water. 23 For fretting, roughness and skalie
spots, bruise the seeds and boil them to pap in vinegar, and then mix it
with oil of Nuts, and anoint therewith to bedward: the meal of Orobus will
do the same, mix the juice of the roots of Peonye. 24 Cockle drunk with
Radish and a little salt, heals the Kanker and other perilous wounds,
comfort the stomach and Liver, kills worms in the stomach, provoke
urine, and is good for the eyes. 25 The suffumigation of it makes women
fruitful without peril, and swageth the great pain of the Liver. A plaster
of the meal thereof with the juice of wormwood laid to the nauil, kills
worms. 26 The seed steeped all night in wine, and the wine drunk in the
morning, heals the strangury, dissurie, and Iliak passion: Nigella with
flower and Honey anointed, takes away spots and pimples, being after washed
with Parsley water.

Agnailes 10 Bees to kill 4 Bitings venom. 3 Brain weak 19 moist 6 Breath
short 1 Chollicke 26 Concept. 25 Consumptio^ 17 Corns 10 Danger 11 Deliverance
20 Dissurie 26 Eyes blood-shot 5 web 5 dropping 14 sore 24 Face deform. 9. 22.
23 Flies to kill 4 Flowers stopped 1. 20 Headache 5 Iliak pas. 26 Itch 9 Liver
griefs 24. 25 Matrixe to cleanse 20 Milk to cause 1 to dry up 21 Mouth sores
8 Murre 6 Poison 3 Pose 6 Ptisicke 16 Reume 6 Seconds 20 Skin deform. 2. 3. 22.

Nutmegs.
NVtmegs does heat and strengthen the stomach that is cold and weak,
especially the mouth of the stomach: it makes asweete breath, withstandeth
vomiting, and takes away the Hicket howsoever it be taken. 2 It is good
against the pain and windiness of the belly, and stoppings of the Liver and
milt, and being parched or dried at the fire, it stops the laske, especially
being taken with red wine. 3 It is good for the mother, kidneys and bladder: it
helps the griefs that stop the urine in them that piss by drops, especially
when the disease comes of cold cause: it is good for other secret griefs,
both in men and women. 4 It breaks and expels gravel, especially being
first steeped or soked in oil of sweet Almonds. 5 It is used in cordials and
wholesome receipts against coldness of the Liver, cardiaks, stopping of the
milt, the dropsy, vomiting, headache, swellings, bloody fluxes: it comfort
the muskles and veins of cold and old people, it makes the breath sweet,
and puts away trembling of the heart. 6 The powder thereof mixed with oil of
Mints, and the forehead and temples anointed therewith, is good against the
coldness of the head or dullness of memory. 7 It is wholesome in Plasters for
the stomach, quilted in leather and silk. 8 It is good in stewed brothes for
them that are long sick. 9 The oil comfort the stomach that is cold. 10
But it is not good for sanguine men to use Nutmegs much, because it will adust
the blood, and makes the face seem as a visor of Coral. 11 The best Nutmegs
are red, fat, and heavy: the worst are black, light, and dry. 12 It takes
away fumes of the stomach, stops the belly, digesteth meat, expels
wind, and comfort the stomach and liver, and is good for freckles in the
face, and ringwormes: it minisheth the greatness of the milt, it softeneth
impostumes of the Liver, and is good for the cold diseases of the Matrixe. 13
Bruise fresh Nutmegs and heat them in a pan and press them, and there will
come out a salt oylish thing like wax, called of some, oil of Nutmegs: which
is precious for all cold griefs of the joints and senowes, and of diverse other
parts, and is good for cold husbands that would have children. 14 Nutmegs
comfort the brain, sight, liver, milt, and mouth of the stomach. 15 And taken
last at night in a cawdell of Almonds or of Hempseede procures sleep. 16 It
is the best spice for students of all other, taken in drink. 17 Nutmegs
condyted, as they may be had at the Apothecaries, are excellent. 18 Head ache,
drink powder of Nutmegs with Betony water. 19 If any man be wounded and bleed
inward, take the heauiest Nutmegs that can be gotten, wash them, wipe them,
and pare them, and let him eat them, and he shall deliver the blood outward,
and also by his ordure, and make him as clean as ever he was, so that the
wound be kept well, and the same used till he has recovered the state of
health. 20 Stomach feeble and cold, eat half a Nutmeg in the morning. 21
Boil them in wine and drink it for coldness of the stomach, and to help
digestion: or boil Nutmegs and Masticke in wine, and drink it for the griefs
of the stomach and bowels, and to break wind and to restore strength after
sickness. 22 Smell to a Nutmeg, to comfort the brain and spiritual members.
22 Stomach cold, sees Nutmegs, Maces, Fennel seed and Dill seed in wine and
drink it. 24 It is much of the nature of Cloves. 25 Mouth stink, use powder
of Nutmegs and Cloves, and forbear meats of evil digestion, and raw fruits.

Belly ach 2 (See stone.) Bloody Flux 5 Brain weak 14. 21. 22 Breath ill 1.
5. 25 Consumption 8. 21 Digestion 21 Dropsy 5 Bladder grief 3 Eyes dull 14
Face deform. 12 Flux 2 Freckles 12 Grauel 4 Heart trembling 5 griefs 5 Headache
5. 18. cold 6 Hicket 1 Joint griefs 13 Impost. 12 Kidneys griefs 3 Liver
stopped 2. 5. 12 Lust to cause 13 Matrixe griefs 3. 12 cold griefs 12
Memory 6 Milt stopped 2. 5. 12 Ringworme 12 Senowes griefs 13 Sleep to cause
15 Stomach cold 1. 7. 9. 20 weak 1. 7. 9. 20
Swellings 5 Vomiting 1. 5 Urine stopped 3 Windiness 2 Wounded 19
Nux indica.
NVx indica: it increases seed, and moves Venus. 2 The oil pressed out of
it, is good for ye Emerods, especially mixed with oil of Peaches. 3 The same is
good for the ache of the knees and the Sciatica being anointed therewith, and it
kills worms.

Ach 3 Emerods 2 Knees ach 3 Lust to cause 1 Sciatica 3 Worms 3
Nuxmethel.
NVxmethel: Four grains with wine makes a man drunken, two drams kills a
man presently, both it and the Nux vomica are fitter to catch fish, then to be
taken into the body of a man: and whether fish or birds be taken therewith, let
their stomachs be taken out presently.

Birds and fish to take 1 Drunkenness to cause 1
Nux vomica.
NVx vomica either alone or with salt, causes a strong vomit. 2 It may be
taken with twice so much seeds of Dill or Fennel, and so drunk with water
warm, it causes vomit of choler and phlegm, and of some works downwards.
3 Pieces thereof eaten by crows or ravens, they cannot fly away but that you
may take them.

Crows to kill 3 Ravens to kill 3 Vomit to cause 1. 2
Oak.
Oak of Jerusalem or of Paradise boiled in wine and drunk, is good against the
stopping of the breast, shortness of the breath, and difficulty thereof, and
cutteth tough humors in the lungs and breast, and provoke urine and terms. 2
Dry it and use it in meats, as Isope, Thyme, and such like, and it yields a
good savor and taste. 3 Lay it into presses and wardrobes to defend clothes
from mothes, and to give them a sweet smell. 4 Drink it in wine to cleanse
the Lungs, and to help the cough, soreness of the chest, and shortness of
breath.

Breast stopped 1. 4 Breath short 1. 4 Cough cold 4 Flowers stopped 1 Lungs griefs
4 Mothes 3 Urine stopped 1
Olive.
Olive: The leaves applied, are good against serpige or wild fire, and
creeping sores, consuming Pocks, and such like hot humors and chollericke
swellings. 2 The same applied with Honey do cleanse ulcers and swage all other
tumors and swellings. 3 They are good against all ulcers, inflammations and
impostumes of the mouth and gummes of children, especially being washed with the
decoction thereof. The juice of them stops the terms and all other fluxes
of blood, taken inwardly or applied outwardly. 4 It is good also for redness,
inflammations and ulcers of the eyes, to be put into collyries and medicines
for the same, and to cleanse the ears from corruption. 5 The green and unripe
Olives do strengthen the stomach and cause appetite, especially being condited
in brine, yet they be hard of digestion, and nourish very little. 6 The ripe
Olives ouerturne the stomach, and cause wambling therein, they breed headache,
and hurt the eyes. 7 The oil of unripe Olives called Omphacinum, does stay and
drive away the beginnings of tumors and inflammations, and does cool the heat
of burning ulcers and exulcerations: it is good also against the rotten sores
and filthy moisture of the gummes, it fasteneth loose teeth being applied upon
the gummes with cotton or fine wool. 8 The oil of ripe Olives does mollify,
swage pain, and dissolve tumors: it is good against the stiffness of members
and cramps, especially when it is mixed with good herbs or flowers, for it
does easily draw out unto it the qualities of them, with which it is sunned or
other ways prepared or sodden. 9 The leaves of the wild Olive tree broken and
applied, do stay chollerike apostumes and inflammations, creeping and running
sores, apostumes of the corners of the eyes, carbuncles and whiteflawes. 10 And
applied with Honey, they take away crusts about sores and wounds. 11 They skowre
all filthy wounds, and drive away all inflammations, and sores called Pauos,
and join together the skin that is plucked off from the head. 12 They are
good for sores of the mouth, especially of young children, being chewed in the
mouth: and the broth has the same virtues. 13 The juice applied, stops the
terms, and is good for the disease of the eye, called Vua, and for wheales,
sores, and falling down of humors, and is therefore put into collyries and eye
medicines: it is very good for the gnawing or biting of the eye lids. 14 If you
will have the juice serve you all the year through, stamp them and put wine
or water to them, and dry the moisture in the sun, and make it into little
cakes. 15 But the juice that is made of the wine, is stronger to be laid up,
then that which is made with water: it helps the ears both if they be sore,
and the skin off, or any matter run out. 16 The leaves applied with Barley
meal, are good for the flixe. 17 The leaves are burned with the flowers, that
the ashes may serve in stead of spodium: and thus they be dressed, Put them into
an vnbaked pot that was never in the fire before, and stop the mouth of it
perfectly with clay, and let the pot stand so long, till all other pots be
baked enough, then quench them while they are yet hot with wine, and kneade
them together, and burn them together after the same manner once again, then
wash them and make them into little cakes: it is well known that this medicine
is as good as spodium in the diseases of the eyes. 18 The leaves of the set
Olive have the same virtues, but gentler. 19 The sweat or water that comes
forth of the tree when it is laid in the fire, heals foul skuruie skabs
being applied. 20 The seed of the Olive tree applied, helps skurfe and
fretting, and wasting sores. 21 That which is within the kernels, with fat and
meal, drives away skabbed or foul rough nails. 22 The Olives that have been
condited in salt, broken and applied to burnings, will suffer no bladder to
arise: they skowre foul wounds. 23 The bryne of Olives fasteneth loose teeth
and gummes being washed therewith. 24 The yellowe and fresh Olive is better for
the stomach, but it is hard for the belly. 25 The black, that is ripe, is
disposed to corruption, and is evil for the stomach, eyes, and head. 26 If it
be dried, it stops fretting or wasting sores, and scatters carbunckles: it
is good to wash the gummes that have filthy moisture, with the oil of wild
Olives, it fasteneth loose teeth being applied with wool or fine cloth, till
they be white, and it will help them. 28 No man can describe all the virtues
of the oil Olive. 29 Olives eaten before meat, loosen the belly, and
strengthen the stomach, cleanse the liver, etc. 30 Being eaten with vinegar,
they loosen the belly. 31 Oil Olive taken with as much Renish wine or white
wine, or powered in by Glister, helps much the Chollicke, Iliake, and pain of
the stone. 32 It may be eaten with white bread in sops in stead of Butter, and
so it looseneth the belly more then Butter. 33 Drink four spoones full with
as much Sack or white wine warm, to provoke an easy vomit, and to cleanse
the stomach. 34 Breath short or difficulty, dippe a sponge in hot oil and
apply it. 35 Chollike, sees raw yarne in ashes and oil and apply it to the
Navel and Reins. 36 Burning, boil Honey and oil togther, and anoint
therewith: or boil the inner bark of Eldren with oil or new grease with
some Masticke and Frankincence, and wax, and anoint. 37 Ears deaf, boil
Cummin in oil Olive and streine it, and drop it in. 38 Earmes worms, boil
quick Lime in it and streine it, and put it in. 39 Eyes web, put in a very
small drop of oil by it self. Face deformed, mix soote with oil and salt,
and anoint. 40 Face red pushes, mix ashes of burned Mice with oil, and
anoint. 41 Frenzy, sees Raphanus in oil, and anoint the head therewith. 42
(See Hearts horn, Planten.) Head skald, shave it and anoint it with oil Olive.
43 Cods swollen, anoint with the oil and whites of Eggs: it helps all
swellings and heat, being beaten together. 44 Hair to grow, mix powder of
Bees dried in a sieve with oil Olive, and anoint. 45 Blood to stop, apply the
oil with Lint. (See Iuy, Baulme.) 46 To ripen a sore, roste it in an onyon and
apply it. 47 Yard ulcers and pushes, Foment with wine of the decoction of the
leaves. 48 Ranker in the Yard or else where, stamp the leaves with Honey and
apply them. 49 Vomit to cause, drink warm water with a little oil, or dip a
fether in oil, and put it into the throat. (See Fig.) 50 Burning or skalding,
beat the oil with water till it wax white, and anoint. 51 Sees half a
handful of white salt in a pint of oil and dip therein, ii. or iii. handfuls
of blackewell, and bind it hot to the navel and bottom of the belly for the
Chollike. 52 Marmoll, anoint with the oil, and apply a Platten leaf and wash
the sore every morning with madder water. (See Madder.) 53 Eyes dull, put in a
very small drop of the oil. Gout, and all aches, stamp iii. pound of Hearts
horn herb, with iii. pound of oil, and let it stand ix. days, then put to
it a pint of water, and boil it till the water be consumed and that it be
green, then streine it and use it. 54 Small pockes, drink one spoonefull of
oil with iii. spoonefull of Malmesey, and as much Treacle as a bean blood
warm. 55 A salve to destroy dead flesh, seethe a quart of oil with a pound of
red lead, till it be almost stiff, then put half a pound of red lead more,
and boil it till it be a salve. 56 Thirst to quench, drink a little warm
water and oil, and cast it up again often. 57 Blood to restore, drink half
a pint of Muscadell with one peniworth of oil in the morning, and walk one
hour after it. 58 Burnings, beat the oil with water, and anoint, and lay on
a Wort leaf. 59 Head skalde, put Brimstone and May butter to it, and use it.
Ears pain and dull, roste the oil in a great Onion on the embers, and as it
drinks in, fill it with more: then pill it and streine it, and put thereof
into the whole ear, and lie on the sore ear, and do so ix. nights if need
be. 60 For the griefs of the stomach, and many other parts, take two
spoonefull of the oil with as much aqua vitae, 7. mornings together 61 Thirst
great, swallowe down oil with the yolke of an Egg. 62 Chafing or galling,
grind oil of Roses with the yolke of an Egg in a leadden mortar with a
leadden pestell, till it be thick, and anoint therewith. 63 Mix one ounce of
powder of Litarge with seven ounces of oil and a little white wine, and stir
it well in a porenger, till it come to a liquid ointment, and anoint the
burning Canker therewith. 64 Bloody flux, drink seven Olive leaves, and seven
corns of Pepper with cold water. 65 To cause deliverance whether the child
be quick or dead, drink the milk of another woman mixed with oil Olive. 66
Ache and swelling, mix three parts of oil with a fourth part of Salt, and
anoint therewith every other day. 67 Hoarsenesse of unkind humors, eat a
little oil with a rear Egg and Pepper, when you go to bed. 68 Emerods, plane
a new Oken boorde, heat it and anoint it with Sallet oil, heat it again,
and sit thereon, and make a pannell of cloth with a hole against the fundament,
and sit on it a great while often and be whole. 69 Chincough, and other like,
with pain in the breast, roste Sallet oil in a great Apple in the embers, and
press it flat, and apply it to the breast as often as need is. 70 Burning and
skalding, beat it with the white of an Eg, or with cream, till it be thick,
and anoint. 71 Ears dull, boil it with Frankincense, and skumme it clean,
and anoint the forehead and temples therewith from ear to ear. 72 Worms to
kill, drink a little of the oil. 73 Short winded, anoint the tongue and
ears, and about the ears with the oil and provoke vomit. 74 Itche and
skabbe, mix it with Turpentine, and anoint. 75 Ears griefs, let one that is
fasting blow in the oil into his ear out of his mouth, and turn down the
head that the ordure may run out. 76 Biting of a mad dog, rub it with a new
cloth dipped in the oil till it bleed. 77 Ears dull, quarter a red Onion
downeright, and boil it in the oil while one may say three Pater nosters, and
streine out the juice, and use it: or seethe the dried gall of an Ox with the
oil and honey, of each like much, with powder of litarge, and apply it. 78
Gout, take oil Olive one pint, May butter, Swines grease and honey, of each
like much, frye them with a gentle fire and put thereto incense two ounces, and
anoint therewith against the fire any ache, swelling, or boneshawe, or seethe
the leaves of Iuie, and Lorell with oil Olive, and anoint with the oil, or
temper Brimstone with oil Olive, and as much Vermilion, and anoint to cease it
quickly, or stamp Henbane seed with oil Olive, and let it stand 24. hours,
then frye it and streine it and apply it, it helps by and bye. 80 Make oil
of Roses with the greenest oil Olive. 81 Wax to increase, boil oil Olive
four pound with the juice of Dyers yellowe till it be yellowe, then put in
wax, and let them incorporate, and cast it into a vessel, and use it. 82 To
take an escare of a bone out of the shinne, or elsewhere, heat oil Olive till
it boil, and power it in hot, then stop it in with a linen cloth, and apply
a pladget of linen cloth, dipped in the oil, and above that a plaster of
Basilicum, and so it will rise from the bone, and do so at every dressing. 83
Ears deaf, dip a linen cloute in oil Olive, and drop it into the ear, and
put in the cloute after it, and lie up therewith all night.

Ache 8. 66. 78. 53 Appetite 5 Apostume 3. 7. 9. 46. 79 Belly bound 29. 30. 32
Bitings venomous 76 Blood to stop 45 to increase 5. 7 Bloody-fluxe 3. 64 Bones

3 Voice lost 67 Vomit to cause 33. 49 Wheales 13 Wilde-fire 1 Wax to increase

Onions.
ONions eaten often raw, cause a rough throat, wind in the stomach, and
headache. 2 And mixed with honey, they take away the grief of the stomach, yet
the eating of them does harm the members, by drying up the moisture of the
body. 3 Temper them with vinegar, and apply them to ye piles to open them. 4
The eating of them does soften the belly and cause thirst. 5 The juice with
honey mendeth the sight, the pain and web, dropped into the eye. 6 Roast them
under the embers, and eat them morn and even to cleanse the breast, void
swelling, and purge the stomach. 7 Bruise an Onion with salt and honey, and
apply it to warts to make them fall off by the roots. 8 Bruise them with
vinegar, and wash the skabbed skin therewith to make it whole and fair. 9
Onions eaten raw, cause lothesomnes to the stomach, but they take away the
stink of the mouth. 10 The juice drawn up into ye nose, purges the head. 11
The juice with ye juice of Rue and honey, helps the biting of a mad dog being
anointed on. 12 The often eating of Onions harmeth the chollerike, but not the
flegmatike. 13 The juice with Capons grease anointed on, helps raw heels
and sleepie-gasses. 14 Ears running and matterie, drop in the juice. 15 Seethe
Onions, and cast away the first water, then seethe them in salt broth with
other good spices, and so they are good for the stomach, and cause better
nourishment. 16 Stamp an Onion with honey, and lay it to any wound to heal
it. 17 Roasted Onions eaten with oil, helps the cough. 18 Ears pain and
noise, drop in the juice with woman's milk. 19 Dropsy, drink the juice with
the juice of Fenell. 20 Sleepiness and lethargy, drink the juice with the
juice of Rue and honey. 21 Apply the juice with reasins and figs to apostumes to
break and draw them. 22 The eating of Onions causes fearful dreams,
especially in them that have been lately sick. 23 Young tender Onions eaten
of laboring people in the mornings, does greatly maintain their health, and
withstand the infection of the air, especially with salt and bread, for so
they less harm the head, but to others they are hurtful, and cause madness,
daseling of the eyes, and the Lethargy. 24 Onions used continually in meats,
soften the belly. 25 Women slice Onions, and steep them al night in spring
water, and give their children the water to kill and expel worms. 26 The
continual use, especially of the seeds thereof, ingendreth natural seed and
lust. 27 The juice with honey clears the eyes, and dropped into the ear,
helps the noise and ache, and put into the nose, it purges the brain, and
being anointed, it restores hair. 28 The juice with vinegar anointed hot,
takes away the spots of the face, especially under the eyes. 29 An Onion
stamped with a fig, softneth and breaks apostumes and ulcers, especially in
the fundament. 30 An Onion put in as a suppositorie, purges the Emerods, and
draws down the flowers. 31 A great Onion roasted in the embers with some
Treacle, and then pilled and applied, softneth and opens all pestilent and
venomous ulcers, and all other gatherings of evil humors and hardness. 32 Fry
Onions with an Ox gall and sheep tallowe, and apply it to any bruise to have
present help. 33 Roste a spoonefull of Treacle in a great red Onion, and
streine it with aqua vitae and vinegar, of each one spoonefull, and drink it
against the plague as the best remedy and most present. 34 Stamp iiii. or v.
great roasted Onions with viii. ounces of aqua vitae, and iii. spoonefull of
Neate-foote oil, and boil it till it be thick, then streine it and anoint
therewith morn and even by the fire a quarter of an hour together, chafing it
well in to help the sciatica. 35 Roast oil Olive in an Onion, on the ember,
and always as it drinks into the Onion, put in more, then take of the
uttermost pill and streine it and put thereof into the whole ear ix. nights
when thou go to bed, and lie on the sore ear, to void the pain and
deafness. 36 Against water in the ear, apply the juice of Onions with Goose
grease. 37 Put Onions and Leekes into Moldholes to make them come out. 38
Onions eaten in meat open the belly gently, and cause urine abundantly. 39
Being laid to the fundament with oil or vinegar, they open ye Emerods, and so
does the juice or ye whole Onion mixed with roasted apples and applied thereto with
cotton. 40 Onions sodden and applied with reasins and figs, do ripen and
break wens, and such like cold swellings. 41 Their juice dropped into the eyes,
clears the sight, and at the beginning remoueth the spots, clouds, and hawes
of the eye. 42 The same is good for the noise, filthiness, and deafenes of the
ears, and put in as a Pessary, it brings down ye flowers and seconds. 43
With Rue and salt it is good against the bitings of dogs. 44 It cures the
naughty skab and itche, the white spots of all the body, and also the skurfe
and skales of the head, and restores hair in pilled places being laid
thereto in the sun. 45 The same with Capons grease is good against blisters,
and galling of the feet with shoes. 46 The long Onion is more vehement then
the round, and the red more then the white, the greye more then the green,
and the raw more then the sodden or preserved in salt. 47 They warm and
cleanse the stomach, and bring good color to the face: they are good for the
new green sickness, and provoke urine. 48 Onions stamped with salt and
applied, help burnings. 49 And eaten abundantly with meat, cause one to
sleep soundly. 50 Drink iii. ounces of the distilled water fasting with a
little sugar to provoke urine abundantly. 51 Sees Onions with oil, white Lilie
roots, butter and wheat flower to ripen apostumes of hard maturation. 52
Onions in plasters are good for the looseness and ache of the joints, and for
the gout. 53 By themselves, or with honey, they draw out pricks and spelds,
with honey they are good for the ache of the stomach. 54 The juice with the
yolke of an egg, vinegar, and honey, takes away red or wanne pimples or spots
in the face and body. 55 Being roasted and mixed with parched barley meal, and
the heads of small fishes, they restore black skarres to their color. 56
Being sodden and eaten, they take away the pain of the sides. 57 The juice is
good to be anointed on the squincie, and helps bloodshotten eyes when they
begin. 58 Put a piece of a bruised Onion into the nose against the dissinesse
of the head and brain. 59 Head to cleanse, put ye juice into the nostrels. 60
Ears pain, (See Houseleeke.) Nose bleeding, put in an Onion. 61 Fluxes to
stop, take Triphera magna with a great Onion. 62 Pain after childebirth, (See
Cummin.) 63 Ears dull, roast a red Onion with the juice of Wormwood, and of
the heads and roots of Leekes, and do off the uppermost pill, and streine it
and drop thereof into the ear. 64 Teeth-ache, roast an Onion, and apply the one
half to the one wrist, and the other to the other. 65 Lethargy, put the juice
of an Onion into ye nostrels. 66 Apostumes, roast salt in an Onion and apply it.
67 Eyes pearl, put in the juice with honey. Plague to heal, roast Treacle in an
Onion in the embers wrapped in a wet linen, and press out ye juice, and drink
one spoonefull of it. 68 Chollike and stone, slice an Onion, and steep it all
night in white wine, and drink it in the morning, and walk one hour after
it. 69 To ripen a sore, roast oil Olive in an Onion, and apply it. 70
Bloody-fluxe roast saffron in an Onion, and apply it to the navel as hot as
may be suffered, and wear Knotgrasse in thy shoes. 71 Roast fresh grease in an
Onion, and stamp it and apply it hot to the navel to loosen the belly. 72
Ears worms, roast the grease of an Eele in an Onion, and streme it and put it
into the sore ear. 73 Ague cake, roast Onions with butter, and streine it and
anoint the side. 74 To skowre the stomach, and cause appetite, boil iii.
great Onions, and grind them with thrice so much sour bread of wheat, and put
thereto v. peniworth of saffron, and one ounce of ginger, and temper them with
vinegar, and make it so thick that a spoone may stand in it, and eat a little
of it daily morn and even. 75 Ears pain, or watery, or worms, drop in the
juice with honey, and a little powder of Bays if you will. 76 Burning and
skalding to heal in iiii. days, cut an Onion ouerwhart, and wring out the
juice upon the place twice a day. 77 Belly worms, pill Onions, and slice them
small, and power spring water over them, and let it stand all night, and drink
it in the morning to expel all worms. 78 Apostume, apply roasted Onions with
wheat meal. 79 Burning or skalding, anoint with the juice and apply the
substance. 80 Ears deaf, roast ye juice of Leeke blades, and powder of Cummin,
in an holow Onion, and put it in. 81 Flowers to cause, eat Onions, or drink
their juice. 82 For ye fever and gleete in the stomach, roast iii. Onions
tender in the embers, and pill them and press them flat, and apply them to the
stomach hot as may be suffered twelve hours, and then renew it, and do so
4. or v. times. 83 Gout of cold cause and sciatica, stamp Onions with oil
de Bay, and put thereto some powder of Pepper or of Euphorbium, and apply it to
the sciatica: or roste powder of Pepper in a great Onion, and work them well
together, and keep it in a box, and anoint well therewith against the fire
wheresoever the gout be. 84 Apostume, seethe Onions and Cummin in wine and
oil, and apply it: proved. 85 Face deformed, (See Lillies.) 86 Breast
mattering, eat roasted Onions with butter. 87 Cold humors in the stomach, eat
raw Onions with course bread fasting. 88 Urine to cause, put the top of an
Onion into the yard. 89 Hair to grow, grind red Onions small, and anoint
therewith. 90 Ears watery, apply the juice with a little Goose grease. 91
Chollike in the stomach and belly of wind, seethe running water, and seethe
therein in four several parts or waters, and press them between two
trenchers, and butter them, and cast on gross pepper, and eat them morn and
even. 92 Piles, roste sugarcandy in great Onions in the embers, as it were a
Warden, and open it and apply it. 93 Knees ache and swelling, and the feet
likewise, anoint with the juice of Onions and Hens grease. 94 Iaundies, roste
as much Treacle as a Chestnut, with some powder of Saffron in a great Onion,
and streine it and drink the juice of it iii. days and be whole. Impostume,
(See Lilly.) 95 Ears deaf, put in iii. or iiii. drops of the juice of a red
Onion iii. iiii. nights. 96 Benumbed, take out the cores of iii. or iiii. Saint
Omers Onions, and put in good aqua vitae, and roste them and streine them, and
keep the oil, and anoint therewith. 97 Emerods, roste red Onions and apply
them hot as may be suffered. 98 Plague, roast Treacle in an Onion and streine
it, and drink one spooneful, and thou shall soon mend if God will: or drink
the juice of a white Onion, Honey, vinegar, and the juice of Rue and Yarowe, of
each like much in Ale, more then half a glassefull warm, and cover thee well
to sweat: do it within the vi. hour after thou art infected or payned. 99 To
keep flies from flesh, lay an Onion upon it. 100 Horse foundred, stamp an
Onion, and steep it in strong vinegar, and make him to swallowe the Onion, and
put the vinegar into his nostrels, (See Almonds.) 101 Ears griefs general,
put in the juice with honey. 102 Bitings venomous, stamp an Onion with fresh
Rue, Salt, and Honey, of each like much and apply it, it is marvelous. 103
Emerods, apply the juice with the gall of an Ox. 104 Urine stopped in Agues,
roste an Onion, and apply it to the bladder. 105 Biting of a mad dog, apply an
Onion with Salt and Walnuts. 106 Hair to grow, stamp Onions and anoint
therewith. 107 Warts, bruise them with honey, and apply them, especially the red
ones. 108 Speech lost, drink the juice with any liquour to restore it. 109
For swelling and pain in the left side, and shortness of breath, apply a
plaster of roasted Onions. 110 Headache, roast Frankincense and Cummin in a red
Onion, and apply it hot in a cloth to the nape of the neck: proved. 111
Stone, roast vi. or x. Onions, and pill them and bruise them, and put them in a
quart of good Malmesey, stir them ii. or iii. hours, then streine it and
seethe it to the one half, and drink thereof iii. or iiii. days mornings or
more. 112 To take away ye heat of fire, stamp Onions with salt and apply it:
proved. 113 Itch and skab, mince Onions, and seethe them in vinegar or water,
and wash therewith. 114 Stone to break, bake a Rye cake, and slice it through
the mids, and lay thereon Onions roasted and sliced, and apply the one part to
the bottom of the belly, and the other to the reins.

Orchis.
ORchis, or Standard grass, the full and sappy roots, especially of
Harebollox, or Gotes orchis eaten or boiled in Gotes milk and drunk,
provoke venus, and do nourish and strengthen them that have a consumption,
or fever hectike, but the withered or shriueled roots repress lust. 2 If men
eat of the full roots, they shall beget sons, but if women eat of the
withered, they shall bring forth daughters. 3 The same roots boiled in wine
and drunk, stop the flux. 4 The same root green consumes all tumors, and
cleanses rotten sores and fistulaes, being applied, and the powder thereof
cast into fretting and devouring ulcers and sores stays the same from further
fretting and festering. 5 The same boiled in wine with a little honey, cures the
rotten sores and ulcers of the mouth. 6 The greatest are best. 7 Satirion is
much of like nature, and so is Palma christi. 8 The round and full roots of
all kinds of Satirion or Orchis, are good in meat and Electuaries to provoke
Venus, but especially with Goats milk, or mixed with white Pepper and Honey. 9
The same bruised and anointed, are good against inflammations and swellings. 10
They purge sores that run, and do heal them, like as Aron does, and
Dragons, especially Orchis Odorata.

Conception 2 Consumption 1 Fever hectike 1 Fistula 4 Flux 3 Generating 2
Inflammation 9 Lust to cause 1. 8 to void 1 Mouth sores 5 Sores 4. 10
Swellings 4. 9
Opopanax.
OPopanax is very good against cold shiuerings of fevers, pain of the side,
ache and gnawing in the guts, the strangurie, inward bruises, being drunk with
meede. 2 With wine or meede, it helps the skurfe and griefs of the bladder.
3 Take two drams or less to purge phlegm and cold tough humors from the
brain, sinowes, and joints, and for all cold griefs of the head, sinowes,
joints, crampes, palsies, etc. and to cleanse the breast, shortness of breath,
old and dangerous coughes, hardness, and other griefs of the milt and the
dropsy, being steeped in wine and drunk. 4 It does scatter, soften, and
dissolve all hard cold swelling tumors being steeped in vinegar and applied. 5
Sciatica, apply it with ye pulp of reasins, and the like to ye gout of the
legs or feet. 6 For windiness and hardness of ye matrix, and to expel the
flowers, dead birth, and seconds, mix it with honey, and use it as a pessarie.
7 To break carbuncles, plague sores, and other tumors, soke it in vinegar and
apply it. Teeth-ache, boil it in vinegar, and put it in, or apply it. 8 Biting
venomous, mix it with pitch, and apply it to bitings of mad and wild beasts.
9 Lethargy, smell to the perfume of it. 10 Fevers cold, drink it with
vinegar one hour before the fit, and anoint the spine of the back with the
juice of Smallach, and oil of Dill. 11 It helps dullness of sight, the
goutes and sciatica. 12 And sodden in must after 12. weeks space it is good
for the dropsy, and swollen milt. 13 And drunk with honied water warm, it
heals the strangurie, expels the terms and dead birth, causes obortion,
and is good for other griefs of the matrix. 14 Milt hard, apply it with the
juice of Smallach. 15 Eyes dull, put it into the eyes alone, or use it in
collyries. 16 Drink as much as a Filbeard to provoke urine, and menstrues, and
for the coldness of the matrixe.

Organy.
ORgany: drink the decoction of the flowers for griefs of the liver: put the
leaves and flowers into a linen bag, and seethe it in wine, and apply it hot
to the head, and cover thee well to sweat, and so it drives forth many
griefs of the head and breast, and the straitness of breath. 2 Seethe it in
wine, and drink it to help the stomach, and ease ye bowels of grievous pain
in making water, and the dropping of urine. 3 Vrin to cause, apply it to the
belly. 4 Tenasmus, sprinckle the powder of it on the fundament. 5 Seethe it in
wine and oil Olive, and strike it on a linen cloth, and apply it to the
matrix for the hardness thereof, and to purge it and to draw down the
terms. 6 To heal the red leapry, take the juice of Organy and Horehound, a
little wine, and oil of Henbane, but yet more then the juices, and put to them
a little oil of Tartar, and anoint therewith in a hot house: but if any pain
remain afterward, anoint with fresh Goats grease melted in a frying pan, and
lie down in clean sheets until it be dried in: and after that bruise
Organy, and mix it with wheat branne, and heat it in a frying pan, and apply
it very hot upon the blisters and leapry, and bind it to till it need
heating again, and do so often and be whole out of doubt. In the mean while
use those good blood, and be of easy digestion, and drink daily syrup of
Fumiterie, but in winter syrup of Egrimonie. 7 Ears pain, drop in the juice
with woman's milk warm. 8 Fundament fallen, stamp it with Roses, Calamus
Aromaticus, and Wormwood, and apply it. 9 Seethe it in wine with Figs, Honey,
and Rue, and use it to help the spitting of matter, continual cough,
shortness of breath, to cleanse ye lungs, and to kill worms drunk morn and
even, or use the conserve thereof to the same effects. 10 Seethe it with figs,
and gargle therewith for the Squincie, and with vinegar for the toothache. 11
Stamp it with figs, and saltpeter, and apply it to the dropsy. 12 Take up
the vapor of it sodden into the ear for the noise thereof: it may be used for
Time, and Time for it. 13 For difficulty of breathing of cold cause, drink
iii. ounces of the water morn and even. 14 Matrix hard, boil it with wine,
and mix it with oil Olive, and apply it. 15 Uvula fallen, and pallat swollen,
gargarise with the water distilled in a Limbeke in June. 16 Chollike, drink
one scruple of the powder of it with good wine. 17 Ears apost. seethe it in
oil Olive, and put it in. 18 Bloody flux, drink it with wine. 19 Itch, wash
with lee made thereof. 20 Teeth-ache, take up the fume of it burned. 21 Flowers
to cause, boil it in red wine and make a syrup thereof, and drink it often,
or apply a plaster thereof to the womb, and over the plaster hold thy mouth
and nose, and also take the suffumigation thereof for the same purpose. 22 To
make any place of the body white, stamp Organy, and rub it therewith.

Opium.
Opium, which is the juice of black Poppy, cools, thicketh, and dries. 2
Take as much as a fitch to swage pain, cause sleep, and help the flixe, but
too much of it is hurtful, for it takes away ye memory, and kills. 3
Headache, power it on the head with Rose oil. 4 Ears ache, put it in with
oil of Almonds, oil of Myrrh and saffron. 5 Eyes burning and inflamed, apply
it with the yolke of a hard roasted Eg. 6 Apply it with vinegar to infla^mations,
shingles, and holy fire, and to heal wounds. 7 Apply it to the gout with
woman's milk. 8 Put it into the fundament to cause sleep. Frenzy, smell to it
to cause sleep. 9 Take Opium and Leuin of each ii. drams well beaten with honey
and vinegar, and anoint the temples and pulses therewith for ye frenzy, or
make a plaster of Opium, Henbane seed with sugar, and the juice of Lettuse,
and apply it to the forehead, or use a suppositorie of Opium and oil of
violets, or apply saffron, Mandrage, and Opium to the head, or take Opium i.
dram, black Poppy ii. drams, mix them with Populeon and woman's milk that
suckleth a wench, and apply it to the temples, all these for the frenzy. Wash
thy face with the decoction of Poppy, and thou shall either sleep, or die out of
hand. Headache dassing, turning, or giddie, take Opium and saffron, ana ii.
drams, oil of Roses. iiii. drams, make thereof a plaster with vinegar, and
apply it to the head. 10 Opium with vinegar dissolueth the gout, or mix half a
dram of Opium in powder with ye yolks of iii. eggs, and oil of Roses, and
apply plasters thereof. 11 To sleep while ye surgian do his office, drink
half a dram of Opiu^ with i. pound or more of wine. 12 As much as a wheat
corn does make a man to sleep without waking, till vinegar be put into his
nose, and his head and face washed all over with vinegar. 13 Frenzy, honey and
vinegar, leven and Opium, of each like much mixed together, and the pulses
anointed therewith. 14 Use it in suppositories to stop the flux.

Ache 1. 2 Ears ache 4 Eyes hot 5 Fluxes 1. 2 Frenzy 8. 9. 13 Gout 7. 10
Headache 3. 9 giddy 9 turning 9 Holy fire 6 Inflammation 6 Shingles 6 Sleep
to cause 2. 8. 11. 12
Orenges.
ORenges, See Citrons, Limons. The juice and inner substance especially where
the juice is very good against all contagious and corruptions of the air, the
plague, and other hot fevers it preserves, and also cures the same, it
comfort the heart, and especially the mouth of the stomach, and helps the
weakness thereof, the trembling of the heart, pensive heaviness, and
wambling of the stomach, vomiting and lothing in agues, and such like
diseases. 2 The juice quenches thirst, and reuiueth appetite, and so does the
syrup thereof. 3 The pills condited or preserved with honey or sugar, do warm
the stomach, and mendeth a stinking breath, and helps digestion. 4 The
seeds withstand all venom and poison, and kills and expels worms. 5 Hang
an Orange pricked full of Cloves into a wine vessel, so that it touch not the
wine, to give it a fine color and taste. 6 Flux to stop, srinke powder of the
pille with posset-ale.

Appetite 2 Air corrupt 1 Breath stink 3 Fever 1 Flux 6 Heart to comfort 1
trembling 1 Pensiveness Plague 1 Poison 4 Stomach ill 1 Thirst 2 Venom 4
Vomiting 1 Wine to keep 5 Worms 4
Orpin.
ORpin, or Liuelong, has the nature and virtues of Houseseeke. 2 Cuts to
heal, stamp it and apply it. 3 Mix the juice with strong white vinegar, and
anoint ye morphue every hour therewith, and likewise all filthy and stinking
ulcers. 4 The juice heals filthy leprous sores. It heals wounds new and
old, and likewise fistulaes and ruptures. 5 The water thereof is good against
all ruptures and conuulsions, and also for all wounds inward and outward. 6 For
gnawing of the stomach, lungs, liver, guts, matrix, and the bloody flux being
drunk daily. 7 The root sodden in wine with honey and drunk, is good for all
the aforesaid. 8 The herb sodereth and heals all wounds, especially
harneyes and ruptures, and stops the bleeding of wounds, and cease the
ache, being stamped and applied. 9 Bruise, stamp it with wheat flower, and
apply it. 10 Finger bruised and flesh raised, stamp it with salt, and apply it
in a fair cloth, and remove it not till it be whole. 11 Squincie, gargarise
with the juice of it.

Aches 8 Belly-ache 6. 7 Bleeding 8 Bloody-fluxe 6. 7 Bruise 9. 10 Bursten 4. 5.
8 Crampe 5 Cut 2. 8 Finger bruised 10 Fistula 4 Flux (see blood.) Leapry 4
Liuer-ache 6. 7 Matrix ache 6 Morphewe 3 Skabs 3. 4 Sores 4 Squincy 11 Stomach
ache 6. 7 Ulcers 3 Wounds 4. 8
Otes.
OTes may be used in plasters and Cataplasmes in stead of Barley. 2 Otemeale
tempered with vinegar, voydeth lentels and spots from the face. 3 The same
taken with meat stops the belly. 4 Otebread nourishes but little, and is
not very agreeable to mankind. 5 The juice of Otes in suppings or brothes, is
good for the cough. 6 The grewell made with Otes, stops the belly. 7 The
meal of parched Otes drunk with honied water, is good for the cough. 8 Otes
sodden in vinegar take away moles, blanes, and spots. 9 Hold any lame member
over the fume of Otes, and then set the same member into the sodden Otes, after
it has been a good while over the vapor, and do so as often as need is till
it be well. 10 Chollike, parch Otes in a pan, and apply them to thy nauill,
as hot as may be suffered. 11 Reins running, stamp good store of Otemeale,
and sees it in a pint of milk, and streine it and drink it with sugar. 12
Morphue, (See Barley, Mallows.) 13 Belly grinding, eat Ote cakes well sowred.
14 Costiuenesse, stamp Otemeale Greyts and sees them with Buglosse and use
the broth, (See Gouts in Leekes.) 15 Legs or feet ache, or swelling, chop red
water cresses small, and put thereto thick dregs of Otemeale as much, and
fresh sheep tallowe, and boil it till it be thick, and apply it. 16 Belly
grinding, apply Cummin, Bays, and Otemeale to the place hot in a broad cloth.
17 Artetica passio, seethe crumbs of bread and Otemeale with wine and apply it.
18 Ach of the Gout, seethe Otemeale and smallach and apply it. 19 Cods swollen,
boil Cowes dung with Otemeale, with milk and dregs of oil, and apply it. 20
Apostume, boil Otemeale with sheep sewet in fair water and apply it. 21
Breath short, make Grewell of Otemeale, water, Puluill and Cummin, and use it:
it opens well and cleanses out phlegm. 22 Bruise, boil Otemeale with sheep
sewet in water and apply it. 23 Wounds, bruses, and such like, stamp Otemeale
with sheep tallow, and boil it in water and apply it: if Holyoke roots be
put thereto, it is the better. 24 Swellings, apply the gross meal with the
white of an Egg and vinegar. 25 Head ach of melancholy, bathe some times in a
bath made with Ote straw, but sit not in it too long nor too hot, and take no
cold after it. 26 Otes are also good in bathes for the headache. 27 Throat
squincy or apostumed, use Otemeale grewell well sifted, and put ten or twelve
Almonds thereto well beaten, and sugar, and eat it with bread, (See Mallows.)
28 Stomach ill after meat, eat thin pap of Otemeale made with wine. 29
Legs cold with age or sickness, sees half a strike of Otes with two quarts
of water, and one quart of wine, and stir it well that it burn not, and put
it into two soft bags, and lap thy legs therein at morn, noone, and even, as
long as need is. 30 Legs ache and swollen, sees Otemeale in milk, and put
thereto the juice of Housleeke and sheep tallow and apply it. 31 Knees, legs
or joints lame, seethe a black sheep head, and the wool thereof all chopped a
pieces, and cast out the bones, and sees Otemeale therein till it be thick,
and apply it. 32 Legs swollen, seethe Otes in water till they be tender, and
hold thy leg over the vapor, and let out the water of the blisters, and
anoint it with Butter: the like is good for any lame member, the same being
also holden in the Otes hot as may be suffered four or five times, if need
be. 33 To break a Bile, Fellon or Vncome, stamp a handful of Otemeale and
sees it in a pint of sweet milk and sheep sewet shreaded small, and when
it is thick, apply it to break it gently, then apply Turpentine upon Lether
prick full of holes, to cleanse and heal it: it is good also for any bruise
or sore. 34 Chollike, parch Otes and apply them hot to the Nauel. 35 Reins
running, seethe bruised Otemeale in milk, with a good piece of sugar, and eat
it, (See face in Lilly.

Palma Christi.
PAlma Christi: The seeds taken inwardly opens the belly, causes vomit,
draws out slimy phlegm from far, and sometimes chollerike and watrish
humors. 2 The broth of meat wherein the seeds have been sodden and drunk, is
good for the bellyach, gout, and sciatica. 3 The same in powder taken in whey
or new milk, drives forth superfluities and chollerike humors, and is good
for the dropsy and Iaundies. 4 The oil drawn forth of it called Oleum
Cicinum, or in shops Oleum de Cherua, heateth and dries, and is very good to
anoint and rub all rough hardness, skurfe and itch. 5 The green leaves stamped
with parched Barley meal, does assuage all inflammations and swellings and
soreness of the eyes. 6 And with vinegar they cure grievous infla^mations and
swellings called S. Ant. fire. 7 The same seeds are good to be taken with
Anniseedes or Fennel seeds and some spices, as Cinamome and Ginger, etc. and
so it will not torment the stomach, but work more gently and effectually. 8
The leaves laid too by themselves or with vinegar, swage swollen breast by two
much milk. 9 Powder of thirty corns pilled and drunk, purges both upward
and downward. 10 The juice cleanses the face from pimples and spots, and
makes the skin smooth from warts being stamped with oil of Tartar, and the
place anointed therewith (See Spurge.) 11 Apply the juice to any wound, to draw
out Iron or Arrowe head, if any such be in it. 12 The powder thereof melted
with Frankincence and put into a clout and holden on the ring finger, and a
ring of gold put on the same finger, and the hand washed in every corner of the
pond, will make the fish come to hand.

Belly bound 1 ach 2 Breasts swollen 8 Chollike 2 Dropsy 8 Eyes sore 4 Face
deform. 10 Fishing 12 Gout 2 Iaundies 3 Inflammation 6 Itch 4 Pricks 11
Purgation 3. 7. 9 S. Ant. fire 6 Sciatica 2 Skin rough 4. 10 Vomit to cause 1
Warts 10 Wounds 11
Pears.
Pears of all sorts taken before meat, do nourish but little, but yet more
then Apples, especially those that be great and sweet. 2 The sower, rough and
chokie Pears and others that are not watrie, eaten raw or baked before
meals, do stop the common laske, and strengthen the mouth of the stomach. 3
They are good to be laid to the beginning of hot tumors and green wounds,
and so are the leaves, for they close and heal new wounds. 4 To keep Pears
long, put them into a vessel that they touch not one another with fine white
salt and cover them close: put a Pare into wine, clean pared: if it swim, the
wine is pure: but if it sink, there is water mixed with it. 5 To keep Pares
dry, sees them in fair water and Rose water with Honey, with a gentle fire,
and let them dreine through a cloth or colander, and then dry them in an Oven
after the batch is drawn forth: if once doing so serve not, do so the second
time, and then barrel them up. 6 Pares are good in Plasters that are made to
stop the course of humors that run to any place. The broth of dried Pares
stops the belly. 7 They are evil to be eaten fasting. 8 The juice of the
leaves is good for venomous bitings. 9 A syrope made of the juice of Pares, is
good against choler, and the chollorike flux. 10 Pares breed the chollike:
it is good to drink Hypocras after them. 11 Pares without wine are poison, but
sodden Pares are a treacle or preservative. 12 Sodden or roasted, they relieve
and lighten the stomach. 13 After Pares drink, but after Apples go to the
stool. 14 All kind of Pares do bind as Quinces do, and therefore are
preserved in electuaries and syrops, to stop vomiting and fluxes. 15 The leaves
are good in baths to sit in, against the falling down of the Matrixe and other
griefs of women. 16 Plasters of the leaves are good to stop vomites and lasks.
17 Pares are worse then Apples, for being eaten raw, they make the blood
watrish, and breed wind and chollike, unless good Sack or Canarie wine be
drunk after them. 18 But baked, roasted or stewed, they are not unwholesome. 19
Pares and other fruits are to be eaten with salt, being first cleansed both
outwarly and inwardly. 20 Pares, Apples and Quinces, may be sodden to Pap and
streined, and to six pound of the Pap, put four pound of Honey, and seethe
them to perfection, and use it. 21 A plaster of young Pares that have been
transplanted, is good for the senowes that are pricked. 22 Vomit to stop, eat
sower bitter Pares. 23 Cough, seethe Pares in wine, Ale or Beer, and take up
the vapor of them at the mouth. 24 Belly loose, use roasted Pares. 25 Bloody
flux, sees dry Pares in water, and drink thereof, it helps also the
laske. 26 Stomach and belly weak, dress Pares in meat and use them. 27
Flux, seethe them in vinegar and drink it with Masticke, or seethe them in
water, and drink it. Liver griefs, stamp the kernels and drink them with
Honey. 28 Burnings, stamp the leaves and apply them. 29 Fundament fallen, bathe
it with the decoction of the leaves.

Apostume 3 Belly loose 2. 6. 24 Bitings venom. 8 Bloody flux 25 Burnings 28
Cough 23 Defensive 6 Fundament fallen 29 Fluxes 9. 14. 16. 27 Liver griefs 27
Matrixe fallen 15 Preservative 11 Senowes pricked 21 Stomach ill 2. 12. 26
Swellings 3 Vomiting 14. 16. 22 Wounds 3
Parietarie.
PArietary: it is singular good against chollericke inflammations, S. Anthonies
fire, spreading and running sores, burnings, and all hot ulcers, being stamped
and applied. 2 An ointment made with the juice and Ceruse, is good against all
hot ulcers, spreading sores, hot, burning, skuruie, and spreading skabs and
such like impediments. 3 The same juice with Deares sewet, is good for the
gout of the feet. 4 The juice with oil of Roses dropped into the ears,
swageth their pain. 5 The decoction or broth drunk, helps the old cough,
gravel, and stone: the difficulty of urine being also applied warm
outwardly. 6 The leaves stamped, heal all burnings, inflammations, hard lumps,
wheales of ye fundament called Pauos. 7 The juice with Gotes sewet, or with
wax and oil of Pryuet, it is good for ye gout. 8 Gargle with the juice and
apply it also to the inflammation of hot kernels under the Jaws. 9 Seethe it
in wine or water with Honey or sugar, to help the old and dry cough,
shortness of breath, obstructions of the liver, milt and kidneys, to cleanse
the Matrixe and inward passages, to drive down the terms and urine, to cease
the torments of the Matrixe, the water or powder does the like. 10 The herb
with Honey, helps the inflammations of the mouth. 11 The juice put into the
ears, takes away their pricking ach. 12 It helps also the shingles, holy
fire, hot apost. swellings, inflammations, burnings, especially being tempered
with Ceruse: and so it helps also creeping sores, Pockes and wheales. 13 The
herb with water cresses fried with wine in a frying pan, and applied to the
bladder, drives forth urine mightily, and applied to the belly, it takes
away the torments thereof. 14 And fried with Bean meal, Mallows and Wheat
bran, oil and wine and so applied, it helps the bruised synowes and muskles.
15 Seethe it with wine and apply it with branne to any ache, and to the ache of
the stomach and belly coming of cold: and in this case, the best wine is
white wine that is somewhat sharp. 16 Strangurie and dissury, boil it in salt
water and oil, and apply it. 17 Boil it and eat it against the cold, and
windiness of the stomach: Fritters made thereof are good for the same
purpose. 17 No herb is better to wash glasses, being used with some salt. 18
Stamp it and apply it to the Cods and under the Navel four times a day, to
avoid their pain, and the chollike. 19 Drop the juice with the gleere of an
Egg into the eye to heal the web, being beaten together and skummed. 20
Chollike, drink it with wine or apply it or foment with it. 21 Fundament
swollen, sees it and apply it. 22 Fundament fallen, seethe it in water and
bathe therewith and apply it. 23 Stone in the reins or bladder, Stamp it and
apply it. 24 For the host, boil the juice of Parietarie and Planten, with
swines grease, and streine it and anoint the breast therewith by the fire, and
be whole. 25 Iliake passion and chollike, boil it in oil Olive, and apply it
very hot, and so it looseneth the belly. 26 Worms in the flesh, stamp it and
Yarow with a little salt, and apply them twice or thrice, and drink the same
herb with wine or ale. 27 Eyes spots, beat the juice with the gleire of an
Egg, and skumme it, and put a drop of the clearest of it often into the eye,
especially when thou go to bed. 28 Chollike, use to drink the decoction of
it in wine, or use it in bathes, plasters or glisters. 29 Cods swollen, sees
it with wheat bran in sweet wine and apply it. 30 Ears ach, put in the juice
with powder of Niter. 31 Knees ach and swollen, wash them with the decoction
thereof. 32 Reins ach, seethe it in wine and drink it and apply the herb. 33
Strangury, sees it in water and apply it to the bladder. 34 Reins running,
stamp it and streine it with Malmsie or white wine, or ale, and drink it
often. 35 To piss well stamp it and frye it, and apply it hot to the shares.
For ach and pain in the stomach and belly, sees it in thy potage and eat
thereof. 36 Stone, bath in the decoction thereof, and also drink it in possit
ale. 37 Bruised inward, sees it in white wine or old stale, and a part of
branne of wheat and Bores grease, and apply it hot, as often as need is. 38
Reins running, sees it with Thyme and Parslie, of each one handful in a
quart of strong ale to the one half, and drink half a pint morn and even
warm ten days. 39 Distill it in a Limbecke, and drink three ounces of the
water morn and even eight or ten days, to purge the Matrixe, reins and
bladder, and to open the liver and milt, (See in Mallows.) 40 For cresty
growings of the fundament, and piles, stamp it with Yarrow and a little salt
and apply it. 41 Matrixe to purge, drink the juice of it. 42 Eyes bloody, put
in the juice with Rose water. 43 Strangurie, sees it well in salt water and
apply it to the reins, shares and greines. 44 Gravel and stone, use it in
pottage and possit ale, with Parslie roots and Saxifrage.

Parsnips.
PArsnips: the roots sodden tender and eaten, cause urine, and are good
against melancholy. 2 The garden Parsnip eaten with meat, ingendreth good
blood, and the wild Parsnip eaten of women, moves terms. 3 The root hanged
about the neck, helps the swelling of the throat, and no venomous thing
shall hurt him that carries it about him. 4 The seed drunk with wine and
also applied to the Matrixe, provoke terms, and helps the straitness of
making water, the pain of the side called the plurisy. 5 The root applied
plasterwise, helps venomous bitings or stingings. 6 The root sodden and
eaten, provoke vrin and venery. 7 The leaves stamped with honey and applied,
does cleanse and heal ulcers that eat greatly into the flesh. 8 The herb with
the root shreaded and distilled about the end of March, and the water drunk
three ounces morn and even, and the palsy members also anointed therewith or
bathed, helps their shaking. 9 The roots eaten in meats, yield better
nourishment then Carrots. 10 The water drunk every night six ounces,
provoke venery and sperme in man, and helps the straitness in making of
water: milk to cause, use the root or seeds. 11 The root provoke urine,
swageth pain of the side, expels wind of the belly, and is good for them
that be bruised. 12 The roots eaten, are good for the lungs, breast and reins.
13 The seed of the wild Parsnip is good against all poison, it heals all
venomous bitings and stingings being drunk in wine, and is so excellent good
for this purpose, that when stags or rather wild Hearts have eaten of it, no
venomous beasts may hurt them. 15 The seed of wild Parsnips drunk, provoke
terms and urine, help the dropsy, resist poison and all venomous bitings,
and help conception. 15 This herb applied into the Matrixe by a skillful
Midwife stamped, draws forth the dead child. 16 And stamped with Honey, it
cures spreading ulcers. 17 Those of the garden are more apt to meat then the
wild. 18 Teeth ache and worms, rub them with the root. 19 Matrixe suffocat.
drink the seeds in wine. 20 Milk to increase, sees the roots with Fennel
roots in chicken broth, and eat it with a little fresh butter. 21 Loins
pain, drink the seeds. 22 Swellings of women's bellies as if they were with
child, drink one ounce of the seeds morn and even. 23 Parsnips engender
thick blood and natural seed being much used, and therefore are good for them
that have been long sick, and they may be eaten raw or sodden against
melancholy humors, either green or dry. 24 To provoke lust and help
digestion, boil the roots first in water and slice them, and sees them again
in fresh water, and put thereto clarified Honey, and boil them to the
thickenesse of Honey, and in the end, put thereto Almonds if you have them, and
then put thereto Ginger, Galingale, and a little Pepper and Nutmegs, and other
sweet sauouring spices, and use it, or sees them soft, and cut them small,
and seethe them again in Honey, some streine them and seethe them in water and
Honey together, and stir them well, that they cleave not to the vessel, and
in the midst of the seething, put Almonds in powder, and then Ginger, Nutmegs
and Cinomom ana i. ounce, it moves lust and helps digestion.

Parsley.
Parsley pearceth and provoke urine. 2 Both the seeds and roots prevail
against the stone. 3 Bruise the dried root and drink it with pure wine, to
cause a good memory, to purge the blood, and to provoke terms. 3 Eat the
seeds for the swelling of the stomach, the dropsy, to consume evil humors,
to cleanse the liver and void the pain of the loins and bladder. 4 Use sallads
of Parsley, sorell and vinegar, to help the burning fever. 5 Eat the herb raw
or sodden for the stopping of the bladder, to provoke vrin and terms, to
cleanse the kidneys, to expel wind, gripings of the belly, and swelling of
the stomach. 6 The seeds in working are best, then the roots, and then the
leaves. 7 Holy fire, apply Parsley with bread. 8 For stopping of vrin and griefs
of the kidneys, apply Parsley. 9 Kidneys griefs, bruise the seeds and sees them
in water and drink it, and apply the seeds with the white of an egg to the
reins. 10 The seeds with white wine help the Iaundies. 11 Neither women with
child or in childebed, nor Nurses, may eat Parsley with their meat, for
hindering conception, drying up the milk of the breasts, and causing the
yonglings to have ye falling sickness: yet does Parsley being thrown into
fish ponds, strengthen and revive the sick fish. 12 Breath corrupt and
stinking, chew Parsley. 13 Stamp it and streine it with white wine, and drink
a good draught five or six times to drive out the urine and stone. 14 Stamp
it with the white of an egg, and apply it to the bruise of the eyes cold. 15
Shingles, stamp it with erums of bread, and apply it. 16 Use it in meats to
strengthen the stomach, cause appetite and digestion, and provoke vrin. 17 The
decoction of the root or seed, opens the stopping of the liver, kidneys and
all inner parts: drives forth vrin, grauel and stone, and is a remedy against
all poison and venomous bitings, blasting and windiness. 18 Use the seeds in
electuary, for the cough and other medicines for that purpose. 19 Stamp the
leaves with bread or barley flower, and apply it to red inflamed eyes, and Paps
swollen with curded milk. 20 Parsley is ill for them that have the falling
sickness, and is utterly to be shunned of them that have it: it hurts the
stones, it is good for the Hicket. 21 The seed taken before hand, withstandeth
drunkenness, it stirs up women to conception. 22 Sit in the decoction of
Parsley, to draw forth the stone, to provoke urine, and heal the kidneis. 23
Use Parsley against the inflation of the stomach and belly, the chollike and
pain of the sides, kidneys and bladder. 24 It drives down the dead yongling
and the seconds, either drunk or put into the Matrixe. 25 Stamp Parsley and
apply it to skabs, morphue and pushes, to cleanse them marueilously. Parsley is
good for the dropsy and all obstructions, and to expel the vrin, stone,
flowers and seconds, and dead yonglings put into the Matrixe, and for fevers
that come by fits. 26 Stamp Parsley with as much Fennel, and streine it and
drink it for the griefs of the bladder, to expel the stone and urine, and to
heal the stomach. 27 For the stone chollike and Nephretica, drink the juice
of Parsley with Aniseedes. 28 Flowers stopped, seethe Sauin with the roots of
Parsley, Smallach and Fennel with wine, and drink it. 29 Senowes ach, stamp
Parsley and apply it, and when it is hot, apply fresh Parsley as often as need
is. 30 Strangury, sees the leaves of Parsley, Fennel, and smallach, and mix
them with wheat bran, and apply it. 31 Trembling, use Parsley seed and fennel
seeds together. 32 Wounds to cleanse, sees the roots of Parsley and smallach
in wine, and wash therewith. 33 To refresh the body, make thick pottage with
green Parsley and flesh, and use it, or use Parsley with a good Hen-broth. 34
Side pain, sees a quart of white wine with a sixth part of Honey, one handful
of Parsley, and two ounces of Parsley seed in a new earthen pot, till the sixth
part be wasted, and when it waxes cold, drink thereof morn and even, 35
Vrin to cause, sees the roots of Parsley and the herb Dasye in water, and
drink thereof morn and even, especially with some water of Radish. 36
Strangury, use the roots of Parsley and Fennel, (See Groundswell.) 37 Stone to
void, make powder of the seeds of small ach and Parsley of each like much, with
as much sugar; and take thereof on sops of bread dipped in wine after meals, and
also first and last at morn and even. Fever quotidian, sees a quarter of a
Hen or chicken with water and Parsley, and iiii. leaves of Letuce, and use it.
38 Eyes black and bruised, apply it with the white of an egg. 39 Stomach
hot, eat green Parsley. 40 Breast pain, stamp Parsley, Isope and Sage, and
apply them hot. 41 Belly hard and urine stopped, drink powder of the seeds of
Parsley, Smallach and Spurge, with wine or water morn and even. 42 Vrin to
cause, sees a good piece of stone Pitch in a quart of white wine with the
seeds of Parsley, Annise and sugar, to the one half, and drink it warm morn
and even. Fevers, (See Centory, Fennel.) 42 Chollike, bruise white Thyme and
Parsley, and streine it with ale, and drink it warm with powder of grains, or
of green broom seed, when need is, (See Nettle.) 43 Bladder griefs, stamp
Parsley, Smallach, and Fennel, of each like much, and drink them with water,
(See Fennel, Cummin.) 44 Biting or stinging of an Addar, drink the juice of
Parsley with vinegar. 45 To cleanse the Matrixe and expel a dead child and the
seconds, put in the juice with a clout into the Matrixe, and also drink thereof
with any drink. 46 To cause deliverance, drink the juice of the roots. 47
Gouts and aches, mix Parsley with oil of Roses and woman's milk, and anoint
therewith. 48 Fever tertian, drink the juice before the fit, (See Basil.) 49
Parsley ingendreth blood greatly, and is good for the Ptisike and the fever
tertian, the grief of the sides, and the dropsy: it comfort the heart and
stomach, and is good in pottages. 50 Dropsy, eat Parsley with water Cresses
and Mints daily. 51 Pissing blood, drink Ambrose, Parsley and Saxifrage, with
Cowes milk daily. 52 Bladder griefs, drink Smallach, Parsley and Fennel with
water, to expel vrin and the stone. 53 Stone to break, make powder of black
Flints, Parsley seed, Fenel seed, and Towncres seed, and use it morn and even.
54 Stone and stopping of the vrin, stamp it and streine it with white wine,
and drink a good draught five or vi. times, or sees it in white wine with
Thime, and into a good draught, shave a spooneful of white soap, and drink it.
55 Ach in any part, sees Parsley and Wormwood of each a handful in a quart of
ale, with some sweet butter, and wash well the place therewith, and apply the
herb as hot as may be suffered. 56 Bladder ach, (See Fennel.) Breasts sore,
(See Lilly.) 57 Emerods, stamp a handful of Parsley with the roots and all,
with sallet oil, and let it stand one day, then streine it and anoint
therewith against the fire, and keep thee warm, and be whole. 58 Vrin stopped,
stamp it with Grounsell, and drink it with white wine. 59 Grauel and stone,
use it in pottage and possit ale with Parietarie and Saxifrage. 60 Stomach
hot, eat green Parslie with Galingale. 61 To slake the after-throwes after
deliverance, sees the juice of a good handful of Parslie in a Cawdell or
Alebrewe made fit for her, and let her drink it: if she have too much of her
disease, let a spoonefull of bruised Pepper be put into her Caudell: proved.
62 To keep a wound from ranckling, anoint it with the juice of Parslie:
proved. 63 Chollike, drink powder of the seeds of Parslye, Alisander and
Fennel. 64 Chollike and stone, boil Parietary and Parslie ana one handful,
Bay berries bruised half a handful, in white wine and drink thereof:
proved. 65 Urine to cause, stamp Rue, Gromell and Parslie, and drink them
with white wine and be whole. 66 Palsy, brew sack with sugar, and put thereto
the juice of a good handful of Parslie, and drink a good draught warm.

Parietary.
PArietarie: (See 461) 1 Stitch, put two handfuls clean piked from the stalks
in a pretty quantity of Malmsie, and set it in a Chafing dish of coals
thoroughly soked in the Malmesie, and apply it hot as may be suffered: proved.
2 Chollike and stone, (See Parslie.) Sees one handful chopped small in a pint
of white wine in a double vessel to the one half, and streine it and drink
thereof when need is. 3 Gouts general, and all ach and swellings, sees it in
wine or water, and apply it. 4 Stone, seethe Parietary and Mugwort, of each like
much in a pottell of white wine to the one half, and drink the wine, and
apply the substance to the Navel, as hot as may be suffered (See 461.)

Aches 3 Chollike 2 Gouts 3 Stitch 1 Stone 2. 4 Swellings 3
Peaches.
PEaches before they be ripe, they stop the laske, but being ripe, they loosen
the belly and engender ill humors: wherefore they ought not to be eaten after
meat, but before. 2 The leaves open the stoppings of the Liver, and loosen the
belly gently, and are good with other convenient herbs against the tertian
fevers. 3 Worms, apply them to the Navel: dry them and straw them on new
wounds to cure them. 4 The kernels open the liver and lungs, and is of virtue
much like to bitter Almonds. 5 Steep them in water of Penyroyall, and use it
to recover speech in the Apoplexia. 6 Stamp them very small, and boil them in
vinegar till they be dissolved like Pap, and anoint therewith to restore hair.
7 Eat every day five or six of them with salt before dinner and supper to
preserve thee from the pain of the side, and from drunkenness, and to
preserve the brain, provoke appetite, to comfort the stomach and breast, and
to kill and expel all manner of worms. 8 Peaches either of themselves or
condited, are good to be used in hot fevers, but the much use of them cools
the body too much, and breeds rotten fevers. 9 The conserve of the flowers or
blossoms, is good for the stomach. 10 The gum dissolved and boiled in wine
and drunk, is good for spitting of blood, to cleanse and heal the
obstructions of the liver, lungs, and passages of the breast, and to break the
stone: but if some Saffron be put to it, it helps the horcenesse and
roughness of the throat. 11 The juice of the leaves drunk and applied to the
Navel, kills worms. 12 The kernels eaten, take away torments. 13 The same
stamped with Rose vinegar and applied, helps the head ach. 14 The gum boiled
in vinegar and applied, helps Ringwormes, Tetters, Pocks, Whelks, etc. 15
Peaches eaten, are good against the stinking breath of hot cause being eaten
fasting. 16 Ears dull, put in the oil of the kernels. Ears worms, put in
the juice of the leaves. 17 For spitting blood and many griefs of the lungs,
use the gum. 18 Fluxes, use the gum. 19 Belly worms, apply the leaves
stamped with vinegar, or anoint the Navel with the oil. 20 Scrophules,
Glandules or kernels, stamp the leaves with salt and apply them. 21 Iaundies,
mix powder of the kernels with vinegar and drink it first and last. 22 Eat
the kernels twelve at once, for the griefs, stoppings and hardness of the
belly. 23 Strangury, make powder of Peach kernels and Akornes of each like much,
and drink it with wine, if that serve not, thou have the stone. 24 Worms,
stamp the leaves with Mints, Wormwood and vinegar, and apply it to the Navel.
25 The leaves falling before their time, betoken Murren of cattle. 26
Chollike, and to withstand drunkenness, eat five or six kernels before
dinner and supper with salt and bread, they kill worms, cause appetite, and
comfort the stomach and breast. 27 Chollike and pain of the side, eat four
kernels daily. 28 Urine stopped, make fine powder of the kernels of Peaches and
medlers, of each like much, with as much sugar as them both, and drink thereof
with good white wine. 29 Stomach pain, stamp the green leaves with old
grease well purified, and apply it. 30 Blood to stop, cast thereon powder of
Peaches. 31 Worms, put in a Suppositor of Peach kernels and Wormwood, or
seethe the leaves of both in water, and wash therewith. 32 Ears noise, (See
Almonds.) 33 Stitch or wind in the body, dry the leaves in the forepart of
the year in the shadow, and drink the powder of them with a little Ale when
need is.
