Wounds 3
Pease.
PEase: their broth is good against the Iaundies and dropsy, it may be used in
all inward greefes without peril. 2 The same sodden in water and lee, helps
spreading sores of the head, the spots of the face, and griefs of the skin.
3 The same decoction mixed with honey and barley meal, cures spreading sores
that be hard to cure. 4 The same sodden in water with Orobus and applied,
helps all swellings and ache, and so do beans. 5 In the new of the Moon,
take for every wart a Pease, and touch the warts therewith, and bind them in a
cloute, and cast it behind thee. 6 Cicers and Fitches be of stronger force
then Peason. 7 Heart burning, eat vi. or vii. Peason or more. 8 Vomiting of
cold moist humors, eat the broth of gray Peason. 9 Pease broth is good to take
purgations withal to cleanse a raw stomach, whether they be gray or white
unsalted. 10 The potage of great Peason are good for the strangury: and to take
Seen withal morn and even for the ague, 11 And Rubarbe for the Iaundies. 12
Nose bleeding, put in fine powder of Peason. 13 Spots or steynes in clothes,
white or other color, seethe Peason in water, and steep the cloth in the
water, and wash it with river water and dry it.

Aches 4 Bleeding 12 Clothes steyned 13 Dropsy 1 Face deformed 2 Fever 10
Heart burning 7 Headsores 2 Iaundies 1. 11 Nosebleeding 12 Purging 9 Skin
griefs 2 Sores 3 Strangury 10 Swellings 4 Vomiting 8 Warts 5
Pease Earthnut.
PEase Earthnut: boil the roots, and eat them as Persnips or Turnips to stop
the flux boiled in wine and drunk, and so it stops the terms and all
issues of blood. 2 Cast the powder of them on sores and wounds to stop the
blood. 3 Stamp the root, and steep it in an earthen vessel, and stir it,
and with a feather gather that which swimmeth aloft, and dry it, and drink
fifteen grains of it to purge both ways without peril. 4 Shepherds
sometimes eat the nuts to provoke vomit.

Bleeding 2 Bloody-fluxe 1 Flowers to stop 1 Fluxes general 1 Purgation 3
Vomit 3. 4
Peniwort.
PEniwort, or wall Peniwort, is good against all inflammations and hot tumors,
S. Antonies fire, and kibed heels being applied. 2 Apply it to the stomach to
refresh it. 3 Eat the leaves and roots to break the stone, provoke urine,
and help the dropsy. 4 Water-peniwort has the virtues of Houseleeke. 5 The
juice of Wall-peniwort with wine applied or put in, loses the stopping of the
priuities. It is good for wens. 6 The leaves and roots taken in meats or
honied wine, is good for the stone, to provoke urine, and help the dropsy,
but especially with Oximel. 7 Stamp it and apply it to red tumors.

Dropsy 3. 6 Inflammation 1 Kibes 1 Priuities stopped 5 S. Antonies fire 1
Stomach hot 2 Stone 3. 6 Swellings 1. 7 Urine stopped 3. 6 Wennes 5
Pellitorie, or Magistrantia.
PEllitorie, or Magistrantia of Spain, drink it with wine against all poison,
corrupt air and infection of the plague. 2 Stamp the roots it self, or with
the leaves, and apply it to carbuncles, plague sores, botches, apost. and
swellings. 3 Drink the root with wine against the rigorous fits of old
fevers, and the dropsy, to provoke sweat, to comfort the stomach, and to
cause appetite and digestion, to dissolve windiness of the belly and flanks,
to heal brusings and burstings, and to dissolve congealed blood in the body. 4
Stamp the roots and leaves, and apply it to bitings of mad dogs, and venomous
beasts, and stingings. 5 The wild master-wort called herb Gerard, stamped and
applied, is good for the gout, and cures the Emerods being bathed with ye
decoction thereof. 6 Chewe the root of Pellitory a good while, and hold it in
thymouth to cleanse the head and brain, and to help the aching and loose teeth.
7 Mix powder of ye root with milk of Wartwort, or Spourge, and Galbanum, and
apply a little of it to any aching or rotten teeth, and break them, and to
pluck them out. 8 It expels wind mightily from the stomach, guts and
mother, and is good for the gnawing stomach, the chollike, and to provoke the
terms and urine. 9 Teeth-ache, seethe the root in tarte wine, and bathe them
therewith. 10 Barrenness of cold cause, and for the strangling of the mother,
and for the cold diseases, as the palsy, the falling sickness, and
nummednesse, drink the root with wine. 11 Fever quarten, drink half a
spoonefull of the powder of it before the fit. 12 It causes a sweet breath,
strengthens all the senses or wits, it is good against the plague, and all
infectious diseases, poison, venomous bitings, shortness of breath,
obstructions, the dropsy, and the griefs of the milt. 13 The herb, juice,
powder or water, is good against all cold griefs of the fevers, and of the
stomach, and all venom and poison, being taken moderately as the cause
requires. 14 Seethe it in wine, and drink it morn and even to help the
cold lungs, shortness of breath, the moist and cold cough, to expel urine,
and the stones of the kidneis, the flowers, seconds, and dead birth, to
mitigate the sciatica, and cold griefs, and cold aches, to provoke sweat,
to drive out the dropsy, to engender natural seed, and it may be used for
Lacerpitium. It is much of like nature to Angelica and Louage. 15 The roots or
juice applied, takes away swellings, hardness, and gatherings of humors. 16
Their juice consumes rotten flesh, and gangrenes. 17 Drink powder of the
root with wine or ale against the palsy, the crampe, the falling sickness,
(See Angelica, Louage, Piretrum, Ptarum.) 18 Take one ounce of powder of the
root with white wine hot fasting, to void the chollike and pain of the
side. 19 Seethe it with figs in vinegar or wine, and gargarise therewith to
cleanse the brain. 20 Tongue palsy, chew it and hold it in the mouth. 21
Palsy and gout, stamp it and seethe it in wine, and apply it: but if it be
green, stamp it and soke it fifteen days in wine, then boil it well, and
put thereto oil and wax, and it is the best ointment for the griefs
aforesaid. 22 Head to cleanse, chew it iii. mornings fasting. 23 Dropsy,
seethe it in wine with Hysope and use it. 24 Frecles, sees it in vinegar and
apply it. 25 Drink water of the decoction of the root for the palsy of ye
tongue. 26 Teeth-ach of worms, apply the powder with honey. 27 Cough, chewe it.
28 Canker, use the powder of it. 29 Headache, chewe it iii. mornings. 30 To
draw out teeth, stamp it and steep it 40. days. in vinegar, then braye it
and keep it to thy use, and when need is, cover the other teeth with wax,
and cover the aching teeth with the medicin, and within one hour pluck it out
with thy finger, and hold it in thy mouth. 31 Bastard Pellitorie, or Bartrum,
or Piretrum. 32 The root taken with honey, is good against the falling evil,
the apoplexia, the long, old and cold diseases of the head and brain. 33 Sees
it in vinegar, and hold it in thy mouth for ye toothache. 34 Sweat to cause,
boil it in oil, and anoint therewith: it is excellent for members that are
cold, benumbed, foundred, or stricken with the palsy. 35 The seed or root
sodden in wine and drunk, drives down by urine and seege, cold and tough
humors: it is generally good for all diseases that come of cold causes. 36 Put
it into the nose to cause much sneesing. 37 Stamp the leaves and flowers, and
apply it to bruises to disperse the congeled blood. 38 Steep the roots in
vinegar, and make them into pills, and hold them in the mouth to purge ye
brain, and to cease ye toothache. 39 Seethe the root or juice in oil, and
anoint the body well with it to put away the fever, cold, tertian quarten, and
it is good for the cold and swollen stomach. Ptermaca chewed and holden in the
mouth, cleanses the brain as strongly as Bartrum, and is good for the
toothache, and is good in sallads, as Taragon or Rocket. 40 The flowers cause
much sneesing. 41 Stamp it and apply it to draw away swellings, and old hard
lumps, and to bruises. It is of the nature of Bartrum or Piretrum. 42 Ache of
the head and teethe, chewe Piretrum iii. or iiii. times a day iii. days. 43
For the palsy, choler, griefs of the stomach, woman's griefs, headache,
ache of the sides, back and reins, the lunacie, and all other sickenesses,
drink iii. spoonefull of the fine powder of it with Mulse, or temper it with
honey or Mulse, and drink ii. cyathes. 44 Scabs and breaking out, seethe it in
water till the water be clammy and yellowe, and wash therewith.

Peniroyall.
PEniroyall: gather it when it bears flowers, and so it may be kept ii.
years. 2 Sees it in water, and wash the itche therewith to cure it speedely.
3 Sees it in wine, and drink it to expel the terms and seconds. 4 Stamp it
with honey and salt, and apply it to the palsy and broken members. 5 Breath
strait, bruise it and eat it with honey. 6 Seethe it with twice so much wine,
and drink it against griping of the bowels. 7 Sleepiness, hold the fresh
leaves under thy tongue. 8 Liver and lungs, drink powder of it two nights with
wine to bedward. 9 Stomach raw and casting, take powder of the seed or
herb. 10 If any man by bleeding be bereft of mind, apply it to his nostrels
with vinegar to restore him. 11 Teeth-ache, rub them with the powder of it. 12
Stamp it and temper it with Saffron, and anoint evil ulcers of the body,
nails, or fingers, to heal them. 13 Milt swollen, bruise it and apply it. 14
Drink it warm with wine to help the dropping of the bladder, and also boil
it with wine and oil, and apply it to the belly for the same purpose. 15
Stamp it and seethe it in wine and apply it twice or thrice to the nostrels to
help the reume, and distilling of the head. 16 Seethe it in wine with dry
figs, and drink it for the dry cough coming of clammy and watrish humors. 17
Seethe it in wine, and drink it to provoke the terms, and to bring forth the
seconds and dead fruit, to provoke urine and break the stone, especially of
ye kidneis. 18 Take it with honey to cleanse the lungs and breast of all gross
and thick humors. 19 Take it with honey and Aloes to purge melancholy, and for
the crampe and drawing together of the sinowes. 20 Take it with water and
vinegar to assuage the disposition to vomit, and for the pain of the
stomach. 21 Take it in wine against the bitings of venomous beasts. 22 And
with vinegar to help the falling sickness. 23 If any be constrained to drink
stinking or salt water, let them put Peniroyall or the powder thereof into it,
and it shall not hurt them. 24 Head pain and giddy, apply a garland of it
round about the head. 25 Stamp it with vinegar and smell to it against
swooning and faintness to quicken the senses. 26 Rub the gummes with the
powder or ashes of it to strengthen them. 27 Stamp it and rub the sciatica and
pain of the gout therewith till it wax red. 28 Mix it with vinegar and
honey, and apply it to the crampe and the grief of the milt. 29 Sit in the
decoction of it for the windiness, hardness, and stopping of the matrix, or
sit over the fume of the same decoction in a Stew or Bath. 30 The same is good
also against itche, maundge or skabbe to wash with all. 31 The perfume of the
fresh flowers drives away flies. 32 A branch lapt amongst wool and smelled
unto, or laid amongst clothes of the bed, cures the fever tertian. 33 Make an
Electuarie of it with Sugar Rosat, and use it in the plague time fasting, as
much as a Chestnut at once. 34 Seethe it in white wine, and drink it morning
and evening to drive down the dead birth, flowers, and seconds, and to stop
the whites. 35 Sees it in vinegar and honey to stop the terms, and for lothing
and vomiting. 36 Seethe it in wine with Honey and Aloes to purge choler and
phlegm about the lungs, to cease inward gripings, to comfort the matrix, and
against venomous bitings. 37 And gargarise therewith against the Squincy and
ulcers of the mouth. 38 Use the water or juice of it to make the eyes clear.
39 And wash the itche therewith to kill it. 40 Apply it to the headache or
gout, till it wax red to cease the pain. 41 Stamp it with vinegar, and
apply it to the nose and mouth of them that swoone, or be sleepie, or have the
lethargy, to bring their senses again. 42 Apply it with Barley meal to all
inflammations. 43 Stamp it with vinegar and Salt, and rub the Crampe
therewith. 44 Apply it to venomous bitings. 45 Wash aches with the broth of it
to avoid them. 46 Seethe it with honey and Aloes, and drink it to cleanse the
liver and purge the blood most excellently. 47 Put the juice with vinegar into
the nose against the frenzy and lunacie. 48 To sharpen the sight, drink it
fasting. 49 Drink the juice with warm wine to provoke the flowers and
seconds, and to help the ulcers of the mouth. 50 To stop vomiting, drink it
with wine or warm water. 51 Head whirling, drink powder of it with the water
thereof. 52 Hoarsenesse, chap a handful small, and seethe it in a pint of
vinegar, till the third part be wasted, then streine it and take a spoonefull
of it morning and evening. 53 Sweat to cause, sit over the decoction of it
that it may strike up into thee. 54 The bath of Peniroyall refreshes the body.
55 Head turning and dasling, seethe it and apply it to the temples, and power
Baulme into the ears ii. or iii. times. 56 Speech lost suddenly, stamp it
and drink it with vinegar, and also apply it to the nostrels. 57 Backe-aches
general, stamp it with vinegar and green oil Olive, and apply it, (see
Fiueleafe, Eldren.) 58 Breast phlegm, seethe it in water with a little salt,
and drink it. 59 Appetite lost, seethe it with as much Cummin and some Pepper
in Ale, and drink it at even hot, and at morn cold. 60 For evils at the
heart, sees it with Tussilago and a little salt in water, and drink it
fasting daily. 61 Liver grief, anoint the side with the juice of it. Back
ache, stamp it with vinegar and oil Olive, and apply it. 62 Ache in the body,
stamp it and apply it to the navel. 63 Belly ache, drink the juice of it and
of Smallache. 64 Worms to kill, seethe it with Tansy and Camomile, of each
like much in a pint of Malmesey to the one half, and streine it and drink it.
65 Pockes, drink the juice of it and of young Tansy. 66 Milt griefs and
swelling, sees it with salt, and apply it. Flowers to cause, seethe it in wine
and drink it. 67 Headache, heat the powder of it without any liquour in a
skillet, and apply it. 68 For cold stoppings in the head, the cough and reume,
seethe it with figs in vinegar, and take a good spoonefull of it, and gargarise
therewith iii. or iiii. times. 69 Seethe it in wine and drink it for the
griefs of the stomach and guts, and the wind thereof. 70 Mix the powder
thereof with honey, and make it into an Electuarie thereof, and use it for the
cough phlegm of the breast, or boil the herb with honey in wine or water, and
drink it. 71 For black choler, boil the juice with wine, and drink it and
be whole. 72 Ache, stamp it green, and apply it. 73 Itch, boil it in
vinegar, and wash therewith warm. 74 Cough and to provoke urine, boil it in
wine and drink it luke warm. 75 Belly griefs, stamp it with Cummin and
water, and apply it to the navel, and be whole. 76 Liver griefs, stamp it
and streine it with water and vinegar, and drink it and be whole. 77 Legs
ache, stamp it with as much Eldren leaves, and apply it. 78 Fever tertian, lap
the branches in a good lock of wool, and smell to it before the fit come. 79
Headache, bind it about thy head, and be whole. 80 Dead child to avoid,
stamp it and streine it with old wine and drink it. 81 Crampe, drink the
juice with vinegar fasting to avoid it. 82 Speech lost, stamp it and drink
it with white vinegar hot. 83 Burn it when it flowreth where fleaes be to
destroy them. 84 That no headache shall come by heat of the sun put it into
each ear. 85 Cattle infected or sick, put it into their nostrels bruised.
86 Hickit, drink it. 87 Flowers and seconds to cause, distill it with white
wine, and drink thereof iiii. ounces fasting, and also if need be, put
thereto a little of the juice of Leckes. 88 For the superfluous moisture of the
vuula and gums, sees it in vinegar and dry figs, and gargarise therewith
often. 89 (See Fiueleafe, Planten, Docke.) 90 Ache, bathe the place with the
broth of it. 91 Headache and lightness of the brain, sees it in vinegar and
drink it, and smell to it, and apply thereof to the head all night, or drink
the juice of it with water, and eat nothing till noone.

Peony.
PEony, the root endures ten years, it comfort and cherishes the body,
provoke urine, and purges the liver and kidneis. 2 The root boiled in wine
and drunk, purges the blood, and is good for women in child bed to purge
their seconds and terms without harm, as much as an Almond is to be taken at
once. 3 The root boiled in wine, does help the gripings of the belly, the
shedding of the gall, and the pain of the kidneis and bladder, coming by
stopping of the urine. 4 The smoke of the little branches of the root
received into the nose, puts away the Kings evil. 5 The root takes away
black spots of the body. 6 The root hanged about the neck, helps the
falling sickness, especially the root of the male Peony. 7 The root of the
female boiled in wine and drunk, does purge women after child birth, and so
does the seeds of it: and in other matters, the roots of both be of like
property. 8 The fresh root worn about the neck withstandeth the vapors
ascending into the head, and strengthens the brain: this does the male
which bears leaves like the leaves of a Walnut tree, and a white root of a
finger bigness a span long. The root is to be gathered in ye wane of the
Moon, and when she is under the earth, and the seeds do especially provoke
terms, and send out the dead yongling, and the seeds drunk in wine, do
help a hard delivery of a woman in travel. 9 The seeds bruised with
Setwell, Galingall, and Sugar, of each like much by weight, and taken every
morning and evening, does expel poison, and loosen the belly gently. 10 Ten or
twelve of the seeds drunk in old wine, do stay the superfluous course of
the terms. 11 And fifteen of the black seeds drunk either in water or
honey, or in wine, do help the nightmare, the strangling of the secrets, and
pains of the matrix. 12 Powder of the seeds given in meat and drink to
children, drives forth ye stone that begins to breed in them. 13 Sees
the root in wine and drink it with powder of the root to help the falling
sickness. 14 Drink powder of the root with white wine to ease the pain of
the reins and bladder. 15 The powder of the root as much as a Bean drunk
with wine, cleanses the matrix after childebirth, and expels the flowers,
the stone of the kidneis and bladder, and is good for the Iaundies, and the
ache of the belly. 16 The water distilled of the roots and flowers,
strengthens the heart, and helps the falling sickness in children, being
taken two or three spoonefull at once. 17 The root and seeds hanged about the
neck of children, is good against the falling sickness, and the haunting of
the Fairies and Goblins. 18 The juice or powder drunk, is good against the
stopping of the gall, liver, and kidneis. 19 And sodden with old red wine and
drunk, it stops the bloody-fluxe. 20 The red grains do stop the red
menstrues. 21 And the black grains sodden in red wine, do strengthen the
matrix that abounds with flux of blood. 22 The root sodden in wine and
drunk, purges the belly, voydeth the chollike, cleanses the guts, and
defends against frensies and passions of the brain, the strangury, and
bitings of Serpents, but there must be taken at once but four drammes. 23
Drink the powder with white Wine and Saffron for the yellowe Iaundies, it is a
sovereign medicine. 24 Drink fifteen or sixteen of the black seeds in
wine or mede against the strangling of the mother, the nightmare, and
melancholy dreams. 25 Drink the powder with Sage, Rosemary, and Margerome in
Hydromell, or meats for the falling sickness. 26 The red seeds eaten, help
the gnawing of the mouth of the stomach. 27 Dropsy, put the seeds of Peony,
Anise, and Fenell into thy drink. 28 Falling evil, drink wine of the
decoction of Peony, or eat every morning and evening five grains of Peony
pilled. 29 Flowers stopped, seethe it in wine and drink it. 30 Mother
suffocated, drink fifteen grains of Peony. Use to drink powder of the
seeds with wine to restore the wits, and comfort the senses. 31 Wear the
seeds about thee, that no evil spirits do hinder thee. Drink powder of
ten or twelve seeds with Wine to avoid the nightmare. 32 Use powder of the
root with Sugar for the falling evil, or drink the juice three several
times. 33 Flowers stopped, drink the powder or decoction of the root. 34
Deliverance to cause, stamp the black seeds with oil, and anoint the loins
and privy parts therewith. 35 Mother suffocated, drink fifteen seeds with
wine. 36 Seethe the roots with Castory in Wine to help the Palsy and the
Stone. 37 Cast the powder of it on Cotton, and put it into the fundament, and
also drink thereof with wine against costiuenesse. 38 Falling sickness, eat
it or drink it with wine, and hang the root about the neck fifteen days.
39 Milt griefs, seethe it in wine and drink it. 40 Drink the powder with
water, honey, and powder of Coriander, to help the griefs of the stomach,
milt, and gravel in the reins. 41 Let women seethe it in white wine, and
drink it against many diseases, to help the stone, the pain of the matrix.
42 Seconds, drink powder of fifteen of the black seeds at once. 43 To cause
a woman to have throws in labor, let her take four or six of the seeds of
Peony. 44 The root gathered on the Sunday in the hour of in, the moon
increasing, and borne on them that have the falling sickness, cures them, or
hang the root of male Peony about a boys neck for the same purpose: or use
the first seeds that are round and black, especially taken with Oximell, or
with syrup of Stecados, and a little Nutmeg. 45 Nose bleeding, put the root
under thy tongue. (See Orobus, Nigella.) 46 For griefs, swelling, and
windiness of the matrix, drink one dram of the powder of the roots in
broth, especially of the flowers of Camomile. 47 For the falling evil, fear
mad, and witless, drink Peony with Wine, Ale, or water: Or use powder of it
with all thy drinks and brothes.

evil 6. 13. 16 17. 25. 28. 32. 38. 44. 47 Face deformed 5 Fayries 17 Flowers
stopped 2. 7. 8. 15. 29. 33 to stop 10. 20. 21 Gall to cleanse 4. 18 Goblins 17
Gravel 40 Heart griefs 16 Head griefs 22 Iaundies 4. 15. 23 Kidneis stopped 3
to cleanse 1 14. 18 Kings evil 4 Liver griefs 1. 18 Matrix griefs 11. 21. 41.

Pepper.
PEpper is good in sauses to give a good taste to meats, to provoke appetite
and help digestion. With the tender leaves of Bay, or with Cummin, it
provoke urine, and expels windiness, and pain of the belly. 2 It is good
against poison and venomous bitings, and therefore used in Treacles and
preservatives. 3 The same drunk before the fit, or laid to, or anointed
outwardly with oil, is good against the shakings of Fevers. 4 The same licked
in with honey, is good for the cough coming of cold cause, and all cold
griefs of the breast or lungs. 5 Chewe it with reasins to purge the brain. 6
Apply it with honey to the Squincy to waste the swelling and tumor. 7 Apply it
with pitch to dissolve the Kings evil, kernels, wens, hard cold swelling, and
to draw forth pricks, shards, and splents. 8 Long Pepper is good in
collyries, and eye medicines for the griefs of the eyes. 9 With Niter, or
natural salt Peter, it skowreth away morphues, and such like foulness of the
skin. 10 Boil i. ounce of fine powder of Pepper with a pint of Aqua
composita, and a beasts gall to the one half, and apply plasters thereof hot
to the sciatica, ache, gout, or other pain iiii. or v. times if need be at
every twelve hours end. 11 Stamp it with good wine, and hold it hot in thy
mouth till it be cold, and then spit it out, and it will kill worms in the
teethe. 12 Gross Pepper helps digestion, and never hurts the liver. 13
Dropsy, drink Pepper and Fenell seed continually with wine to cure the
swelling of it. 14 Flux to stop, grate hard cheese and mix it with a portion
of Pepper and drink it with red wine sodden together with a few crummes of
white bread. 15 Anoint the gout with black Pepper, or apply it. 16 Matrix
suffoc. eat nine grains of Pepper, it is the best medicin. 17 Mouth griefs,
hold powder of Pepper with white wine in thy mouth. 18 Sciatica, stamp Onions
with oil de Bay, and put powder of Pepper, and of Euphorbium, and apply it to
the place. 19 Sweat to cause, drink twenty grains of Pepper with one handful
of Rue in white wine. 20 Eyes pearl and web, put in powder of burned Pepper.
21 Eyes hawe, put in powder of burnt Pepper with the marow of a Goose wing. 22
For the host, seethe Sage, Rue, Cummin, with honey and Pepper, and take thereof
daily. 23 Cough, seethe Senuy and white Pepper in good wine and drink it. 24
Canker and fester, mix powder of Pepper, and of man's doung burned, and use it
as often as need is. (See Pomegranate.) 25 Bloody-fluxe, make caudels of Vine
leaves, Pepper, and hard Eggs, and use them. 26 Eyes pearl, mix fine powder
of Pepper and Ginger with the gall of an Eele and clarified Honey, and it will
kill it. (See Ginger, Grains, Elecampana, Fenell.) 27 Teeth-ache, and swelling
of the gummes, seethe powder of Pepper and Ginger of each like much in Ale,
and apply it in a little bag dipped in aqua vitae. 28 Wind chollike and
phlegm, boil powder of the three kinds of Pepper with Rose water and Sugar in
a porenger till it be thick, and eat thereof to bedward, or when the fit
comes. 29 Gout, plaster it to the grief of the joints or synowes. 30
Scrophules in Infants, mix the powder with hard pitche, and apply it to
disperse them. 31 Teeth-ache, seethe three spoonefull of the powder in a pint
of good white Wine to the one half, and gargarise therewith often hot one
spoonefull at once. 32 Stomach cold, take a rear Egg with gross Pepper
fasting. (See Baye.) 33 Mix as much as will fill up the shell of an Egg with
the yolke, and burn it and mix the powder of it with Wheat meal, and make
little fritters and bake them and eat them first and last to help the bloody
flux. 34 Stomach griefs, drink Pepper with wine hot, and eat Butter after
supper. 35 Palsy, mix powder of Pepper three ounces, and of Senuie seed two
ounces, with Swines grease a little salted and anoint. (See Centorie.) 36 Put
the powder into the nose to cause sneesing. 37 Seethe it with Figs in Wine,
and drink it to cleanse the spiritual members from tough humors, and for the
pose coming of cold, and for the same eat Figs with powder of Pepper. 38
The powder with meats comfort the stomach, and helps digestion, and so
does long Pepper eaten with roasted Apples. 39 Powder of Pepper fretteth away
dead flesh. 40 Long Pepper comfort more then black. 41 Pepper is not good
for Sanguine or Chollerike folks. 42 Headache, drink Pepper, Rue, and Fenell
with Wine fasting. 43 Vuula fallen, fill an Akorne shell full of powder of
Pepper, and burn Alome, and apply it. 44 Mix powder of Pepper with the marowe
of a Goosewing, and put it in a cloute and burn it, and put thereof upon the
hawe in the Eye to avoid it. 45 White Pepper helps the stomach, the cough,
the wind, the chollike, withstandeth the causes of cold Fevers, and eases
the shaking thereof. 46 Diatrion Piperion may be taken at any time of the day
for a cold and windy stomach: for lack thereof, take a few grains of
black Pepper grossly beaten, with a draught of Ale fasting, or a little of the
powder of any of them with meat: for nothing is better against wind and
phlegm then Pepper. 47 Roste powder of Pepper in a great Onion, and work them
well together, and keep it in a box, and anoint the gout therewith against
the fire. 48 Matrixe suffocated, eat nine corns of Pepper, and after smell to
stinking things at the nose. 49 Bloody flux, make caudels of Vine leaves, hard
eggs, and Pepper, and use them. 50 Emerods, burn old shoes, and mix the
powder thereof with powder of Pepper, Honey, and oil Olive, or oil of Cream
sodden, and apply it iii. days hot. 51 Face seeming leaprous, mix quick
silver mortified with Bores grease and black Pepper, and anoint therewith, and
keep the face from wind iiii. or v. days. 52 Seethe honey, and clarify it,
and put thereto powder of Pepper, and sees it till it be black, and lay
thereof upon half a Sage leaf, and apply it to the teethe that ache. 53 Drink
40. corns of Pepper with warm water to void the quarten and intermissiue
fevers. 54 Diatrion is very good against hoarsenesse and stopping of the lungs
and cold reumes. 55 Use the powder in ointments against shaking fevers that
come by fits. 56 It is good against venomous bitings, and expels the birth
being drunk or often eaten. 57 It is used in Lohocks and Syrupes for the cough
and pain of the breast. 58 And with Honey it helps the Squincie. 59 It is
good to be used inward and outward for the apostume of ye milt, and being much
used it expels urine. 60 Reume, gargle with Mustard, Vinegar and Pepper
sodden together. 61 Fevers, drink half a pint of thine own urine with one
peniworth of Pepper bruised one hour before the fit, and cover thee well to
sweat. 62 Chollike, drink powder of long Pepper and Fiueleafe roots with
good ale. 63 Ringwormes, apply fine powder of Pepper with black soap.

Perwincle.
PErwinkle sodden in wine and drunk, stops the laske, the bloody flux,
terms, spitting blood and all other issues of blood. 2 Mix it with milk and
oil of Roses, and put it into the Matrixe as a suppositer to take away all
pains thereof. 3 Chew it to help the toothach, and all venomous bitings or
stingings being applied. 4 Bruise it and put it into the Nose to stop the
bleeding. 5 Sees it in wine and drink it against all torments and fluxes of
the body. 6 Stamp it and apply it to all venomous bitings. 7 Put the juice
into the ears to cease their ach. 8 Put the herb into troubled wine that has
lost the color, fifteen days to restore the color again and the
cleerenesse. 9 The herb buried in the ground dies not. 10 Nose bleeding, hold
it in thy mouth between thy teeth, or lay a lease under thy tongue. 11 Pissing
blood, drink the juice of it and of Planten. 12 Nose bleeding, hold it
between thy teeth and bind the pulses of thy arms and legs, and thou shall
not bleed while it is there.

Belly ach 5 Bitings venom. 3. 6 Bloody flux 1 Eats ach 7 Flowers to stop 1
Matrixe pain 2 Nose bleeding 4. 10. 12 Pissing blood 11 Spitting blood 1 Teeth
ach 1 Wine dead 8
Pimpernel.
PImpernell boiled in wine and drunk, is singular good against all venomous
bitings, obstructions of the Liver, and pain of the kidneys. 2 The juice put
into the Nose, cleanses the head, and helps the toothach being put into the
Nose on the contrary side to the grief. 3 Apply Pimpernell to corrupt and
festered sores and to fretting sores, and to cleanse and heal them, and to
pricks and splents to draw them out, and to the inflammation of the eyes. 4
The juice mixed with Honey and straken often, or put into the eyes, takes away
the dimnesse of sight. 5 Sees it in wine and drink it against all venomous
bitings, and also wash the wound therewith. 6 Drink a draught of it, and cover
thee well to sweat, to expel the plague or any poison, to drive out the
dropsy, to open the liver, to purge the kidneys, and expel the stone. 7 Apply
the juice or water to venomous wounds, stingings or bitings, to mitigate the
ache, and to draw out the venom and stings. 8 It heals painful sores that
creep in the flesh, and the diseases that come of reume. 9 The juice mixed with
pure Honey, takes away the mistiness and redness, and spots of the eyes, and
cleanses the sight. 10 Eyes web, mix the juice with Goose grease, and put a
drop into the eyes. 11 Heart cardiake, drink Pimpernell. 12 Heart stitch,
drink the water or decoction of it. 13 Speech lost, hold the juice of it and
Sage under thy tongue. 14 Plague, drink powder of Pimpernell, Betony, Five
leaf, Sage and scabious, with ale or beer warm fasting a week. 15 Breast
sores, (See Garlike, See Docke, Celondine.) 16 Eyes web and pearl, put in the
juice with the marow of a Goose wing. 17 Apost. or Byle to break, stamp it with
Holyoke and Brocks grease and apply it. 18 Biting of an Addar, drink the juice
of that with the red flower. 19 Nose bleeding, stamp it and put it into the
Nose. 20 Fever continual, drink it with warm water, it helps also the
fever tertian. 21 Fistulaes and hollow ulcers, put in the juice, and apply the
herb. 22 If the Fistula be inward, drink it: if outward, put in the juice.
23 Mix powder thereof with the distilled water and some sugar made into an
electuary, and take thereof two ounces dadly, for the Ptisicke of the Lungs. 24
Drink Pimpernell with Sorell in the Plague time to defend thee, (See Aloes,
Dog Fennel, Lunarie.) 25 Skull hurt, apply the juice often with cloutes.
Fever, bind it to the Pulses, (See Egrimonie, Houndstong) Face sause phlegm,
anoint with the juice mixed with Pepper and Ginger. 26 Pimpernell destroys
venom, and heals apostumes and sores of the eyes. 27 For the griefs of the
bladder, and to expel urine and the stone, drink the juice of Pimpernell,
Fennel, Parsley and Smallach with water. 28 Wounds to heal, drink the juice
of Sanicle, Pimpernell and Bugle with ale morn and even. 29 Pyles to heal,
drink the juice of Pimpernell often, and be whole. 30 For wasting of nature,
drink the juice with sugar, (See Bugle.)

Pine tree.
PIne tree: The scales of the Pine apple with the bark of the Pine tree, do
stop the laske, the bloody flux, and provoke Urine, and so does the broth of
the same drunk. 2 The same is good also against all skorchings and burnings
with fire, being stamped with Litarge of silver and Frankincense, if there be
some Coprose put to it, then it will cleanse and heal consuming or fretting
sores. 3 The leaves heal green wounds, and boiled in vinegar, they swage the
tooth ach. The kernels in the Nuts are good for the lungs, they cleanse the
breast, and cause easy spitting, they nourish well and breed good blood, and
are good for the cough, and for them that begin to dry and consume away
howsoever they be taken. This fruit also does unstop the liver, mitigateth the
sharpness of the urine, and is good for the gravel and stone. 4 The virtues
of the Rosin and Pitch, shall be declared hereafter. 5 The bark both of the
Pine tree and Pitch tree in powder sprinkled upon chafing or gauling, and bare
places, and burnings, with Litarge and fine powder of Frankincence, does cure
them. 6 The same received in a Treat or Cerot of Mirtles, bring sores in tender
bodies to a skin, and stops such as run far abroad, being laid too with
Coprose. 7 The suffumigation thereof brings down the birth and seconds. 8
Being drunk, it stops the belly, and provoke urine. 9 Being taken in
water or Mede one dram, they are good for the diseases of the liver. 10 The
kernels by themselves or with Honey, are good for the cough and griefs of the
breast. 11 The kernels drunk with Malmesie, and the seed of a Cucumber provoke
urine, and takes away the sharpness thereof. 12 And taken with the juice of
Pursten, they swage the gnawing of the mouth of the stomach. They take away
the weakness of the body, and hold down the corruption of humors. 13 But the
whole Nuts newely taken from the trees, bruised and sodden in Malmesie, are
good for the old cough and for a consumption, three Cyaths of the broth that
they are sodden in, being drunk every day. 14 The kernels may be eaten with
Reasins. 15 The Nuts being cleansed and eaten or drunk with the decoction of
Reasins or the seeds of Cucumbers, provoke vrin, and helps the sharpness
of the kidneys and bladder, and the gnawing of the stomach. 16 And with the
juice of Pursten they restore strength. 17 The middle bark of the tree drunk,
stops the flux, and provoke vrin. 18 One dram of the leaves drunk with
Honied water, is good for the griefs of the liver. 19 The oil of the Nuts
cures ye Palsy. 20 The powder of the bark or leaves, helps the chafings
and gaulings, and all ulcers on the outward part of ye body. 21 The leaves
stamped, are good for inflammations, and sodden with vinegar, they are good for
the tooth ach. Stamp the sound or fresh kernels and sees them with wine and
clarified Honey to the form of Honey, and use to take thereof for the Ptisick.
22 Dippe a Pine apple without kernels in Skamony, and burn it, and sit over it
in a close stool, to help both the flux and the Tenasmus. 23 Belly wringing,
sees the rind of the tree in wine and drink it. 24 Bloody flux, lap a Pine
apple in Pitch, and lay it on hot coals, and take up the fume thereof.

Belly ach 23 Blood to increase 3 Bloody flux 1. 24 Breast griefs 3. 10
Burnings 2. 5 Chafings 5. 20 Consumption 13. 16. 21 Cough 3. 10. 13 Deliverance
7 Fluxes 1. 8. 17. 22 Gaulings 5. 20 Inflammation 21 Liver stopped 3. 9. 18 Lungs
griefs 3 Palsy 19 Ptisike 21 Seconds 7. 11 Skin off 6. 20 Sores 26 Stomach
ach 12. 15 Stone 3 Teeth ach 3. 21 Vrin sharp and stopped 3. 8. 11. 15 Wounds 3
Pitch tree.
PItch tree: The fruit, leaves, kernels, nuts and bark, are almost of the
same nature that the like are of the Pine tree. 2 The Rosins both of the Pine
tree and Pitch tree, do cleanse and heal new wounds, and is therefore used
in ointments and plasters for wounds: it softeneth hard swellings, and is good
for bruises being applied in oiles or ointments agreeable. 3 Hairs to avoid,
shave them off, and apply a plaster of the driest Pitch on Lether, that they
grow no more. 4 Stone or dry Pitch, has the virtues of Tar or liquid Pitch,
but not so strong: but is better and apter to glue wounds together. 5 Senowes
shrunk, melt Pitch and wax with Weathers grease, and apply it. 6 Sciatica,
anoint it with oil of Turpentine and Aqua vite, and apply Ceareclothes of
Pitch. 7 Fundament fallen, take up the fume of Pitch. 8 Crampe, apply ship
Pitch with sal Armoniak, it helps the Gout in like sort. 9 Neck and throat,
Pustules and scrophules, melt it with Hogs grease, and put thereto some quick
brimstone and wheat branne, and apply it. 10 Swellings or Apostumes, stamp
Cresses with Pitch, and apply it. 11 Put powder of Pitch into a sore, to
engender flesh. 12 Lethargy, mix ashes of thine own hair with vinegar and a
little Pitch, and apply it to the Nostrels. 13 Sees a good piece of stone
Pitch in a quart of white wine with Aniseedes, Parsley seeds and sugar to the
one half, and drink thereof morn and even, to expel the vrin, (See
Walnuts.) 14 Head skald, sees Pitch and wax, and lay them on a cloth, and
apply it as hot as may be suffered nine days, and do so till it be whole. 15
Knees and senowes griefs, mix Pitch and wax with grease and apply it, it
helps also shrunk synowes. 16 Belly windy, boil Pitch with Honey and Butter,
and anoint. 17 Scrophules, mix powder of Pepper with stone Pitch, and apply
it. 18 For a new Sciatica, mix powder of Pitch with Tar, oil Olive and
unwrought wax, and streine it and keep it in rolls or in a box, and apply
thereof upon Lether or Linen.

7 Head skald 14 Hairs to void 3 Kernels 9 Kings evil 9 Knees ach 15 Lethargy
12 Neck scrophuls 9 Synowes griefs 5. 15 Sciatica 6. 18 Scrophules 9. 17
Sleepiness 12 Swellings 2. 10 Throat scrophules 9 Wounds 24. 11
Plane tree.
PLane tree: the fruit thereof drunk with wine, helps venomous bitings. 2
Burnings, stamp the fruit and apply it. 3 Teeth ach, sees the bark in
vinegar, and use it. 4 Stamp the tender leaves, and apply them to
inflammations, swellings, and running eyes. 5 Vomit to stop, sees the leaves
in vinegar, and drink it. 6 The horinesse that cleaves to the leaves, is ill
for the eyes. 7 Stamp the leaves with grease, to heal burnings.

Burning 2. 7 Bitings venomous 1 Eyes running 4 Inflammation 4 Swellings 4
Teeth ach 3
Planten.
PLanten: Ach, apply the leaves stamped with a little salt, (See in their proper
places, Gout etc.) Apostume, apply the juice or herb stamped.

Back ach or griefs, (See Kidneys, Gomer passion, Stone.) Belly ach, use the
herb, seed or powder inwardly. Sees the less kind of it and apply it. Belly
worms, drink a spoonefull of the juice, (See Worms.) Biles, apply the juice.
To avoid Biles, stamp it with Egrimony and Goose grease, and anoint. (See
Apost.) Bitings venomous, drink it with wine: or drink the juice, and apply
the substance, and hang the root about thy neck: or apply the juice or water:
or drink small Planten with wine. Blaines, blisters, plouks, pushes or
wheales, apply the leaves. Bladder griefs, sees the root by it self or
with the seeds in white wine, and drink it to open the passages of the liver
and kidneys being stopped, and for the Iaundies and exulcerations of the bladder
and kidneys, griefs of the head, stones, the Emerods and the Gomer passion.
Bladder griefs general, cut the leaves near the ground and root, and sees
them in water, and drink half a pint morn and even four or five days. The
roots and leaves with good sweet wine, are good against the sores and blisters
of the kidneys and bladder. Blood to stop, drink a little Cresse seed with
the juice when a vein is broken inwardly: or drink it also, and apply it with
bol armoniak and sanguis draconis, the white of an egg and barley meal: or
stamp water Planten, and apply it: or drink the juice of Planten. Bloody
flux, drink the decoction of the leaves to swage it and all other fluxes of
the belly: or drink the juice: or sees the leaves with Holyoke root in
water, and drink it against the grievous bloody flux: or stamp it with
Yarowe and streine it with red wine, and drink a good draught first and last
four or five days, to stop the bloody flux: or drink the seeds with red
wine: or sees the roots therein and drink it: or eat the herb with salt
and vinegar: or use it in Glisters. Breast griefs, as Ptisike and cough, fry
the juice with Parietarie, Isope and swines grease of a barrowe hog, and
streine it and anoint the breast therewith to have wind at will. Breast and
heart cleansing from rotten humors, take a spoonefull of the juice with Honey.
Breath short, sees Planten and eat it. Burnings, Inflammations, and the holy
fire, apply the juice or water with Housleeke, or anoint with the juice of
Planten.

Catharre and falling down of Reume, the Cough, Ptisik, and Consumption of the
Lungs, and to comfort the stomach, eat the leaves with meat or otherwise,
(See Breast, Breath.) Carbuncles, apply the juice. Consumption, (See Breast
griefs, Catharre.) Cough (See Catharre, Breast griefs.)

Dropsy, fill a pot almost full of the juice, and do ashes on the top with a
cloth, sees it to the one half, and drink thereof fasting daily, for the
Dropsy, Timpany, and Iaundies.

Ears dull, put in the juice with a tent, it takes away the pain also of the
ears. Eyes apostume, fester or botch, apply the juice. Eyes inflamed and
pain, drop in the juice. Emerods, apply the herb, or use the herb inwardly
or outwardly.

Face blaines, stamp the roots of Planten and Burres with salt ana, and
vinegar, and anoint therewith at night. Face pimples and ringwormes, stamp the
roots with salt and vinegar, and wash therewith. Falling evil, drink the
leaves, roots or buds of water Planten. Use Planten any ways, or the water
thereof. Feet surbated, sore and swollen with travel, anoint with Planten
juice, or stamp it with vinegar, and apply it. Fellon, drink the juice of
Planten and Morell, and apply the herbs, apply the juice of Planten and
Celondine. Fevers, stamp three roots and streine them with water, and drink
it. Fevers cold, drink the juice before the fit thrice. The roots taken with
wine and water three at once, cure the tertian, and four the quarten. The
leaves and roots sodden in fair water, or Borage water, and drunk with
sugar, do cure the tertian and quarten Fevers. Fever quarten, drink the juice
with Honied water, two hours before the fit, and it will have a wonderful
effect. Drink the juice of Ribwurt two hours before the fit. Fester, apply
the juice, (See Sores, Kankers.) Fistula, use the juice and herb inward and
outward, or the water: the herb stamped and applied, does heal them
speedily, put in the juice. Flowers to stop, use the decoction of it, drink
the juice with Lapis Hematites. Fluxes, (See in bloody flux.) Use the
decoction thereof or juice, herb or seed. Foul evil, use it inward or
outward. French Pocks, use it as before.

Gums griefs and kanker, use the juice with vinegar, Honey and Alome: use the
juice, water, or decoction thereof. Gomer passion, use it inward and outward.
Gout and all aches, and swellings of the synowes, stamp the leaves with a
little salt and apply them. Gout in the feet, drink it with vinegar, bruise
it and apply it to any Gout.

Hardness of all sorts, stamp it with swines grease, and apply it. Heart
griefs, drink a spoonefull of the juice with Honey, to expel it. Headache, use
Planten, apply the juice or water with linen. Head megrem, stamp ribwort, red
Fennel and Betony with woman's milk and apply it: and as the grief remoueth,
follow it therewith. Stamp Planten, and bind it to the neck to avoid
headache. Boil it with Fenigrek in milk, and apply it in a cloth. Head skald,
wash daily with the juice. Holy fire, apply it with the juice of Housleeke.
Hot griefs, use it inward and outward.

Iaundies, take the juice of Planten, Wormwood and Smallach with sugar: or the
juice of Planten and Wormwood ana with sugar, (See Dropsy.) Drink the juice
of Planten and Letuce with vinegar, and also apply it to the right side, (See
bladder.) Inflammations, (See burnings, hot griefs, holy fire.)

Kankers, use Planten inward and outward: or the juice or water. Apply the
juice with vinegar, Honey and Alome. Stamp Planten and apply it, and also
drink the juice thereof. Kernels, apply Planten with old grease. Kidneys
exulcerat, (See bladder.) Seethe the roots and leaves with good sweet wine
and drink: use the roots by themselves with the seeds in like sort. Knees
swollen, stamp Planten and apply it.

Liver griefs, drink the water, (See bladder.) Leprie, stamp the leaves and
apply them.

Mad dogs biting, apply the juice or water, or leaves, and drink thereof.
Megreme (See head ach.) Morphue white, drink the juice or infusion thereof.
Mother moist and suffocat, put in the juice with wool. Mouth griefs, use the
juice, (See Kankers.) Use the juice or decoction of the roots: for the Vuula,
chew Planten.

Nolimetangere, mix salgem with the juice, and make it somewhat thick and
apply it, and bruise the leaves, and wring out the juice a little, and apply
them and whole leaves upon them. Nose bleeding, stamp Planten, Ribwort and
Housleeke with Barley meal and apply it about the neck and arme-pits on the
same side that bleedeth, or drink the juice with vinegar, or the juice alone.

Pimples (See face.) Pissing blood, drink the juice or decoction. Plague,
poison, and all venom, use Planten. Poison, (See Plague.) Pocks, or swine
Pocks, hang the root about thy neck. Ptisike, (See breast.) eat the leaves
with meat or otherwise, or use the herb, seed or powder inward. Priuities
griefs, use Planten. Purgation, sees Planten in any liquor, and drink it.
Take a spoonefull of the juice with Honey. Pushes, stamp the leaves and apply
them.

Rankling, drink it and also apply it with bol armoniak, barley meal, and
whites of Eggs. Reins running, use Planten. Ringwormes, apply the juice or
water, (See face pimples.) Reume, eat the leaves, or use them any ways.

Saint Anthonies fire, apply it with Cimolea and white lead. Senowes griefs,
stamp the leaves with a little salt, and apply it. Short winded, use Planten.
Sickness general, use it any way, (See Purgation.) Sees it in any liquor,
and drink it.) Serpents biting, drink Planten with wine, drink the juice and
apply the substance. Skurfe, use it inward and outward. Side ach, seethe the
lesser kind of Planten, and apply it hot, or bruise the leaves, and apply
them. Sores general, use Planten stamped and applied. Speech to cause, hold
the juice under thy tongue. Spitting blood, use the decoction of the leaves.
Put as much mouse dung as will lie on a groat, to half a glass full of the
juice, and drink it first and last with sugar, as long as need is: drink the
juice, or drink the seed with wine. Squincie and griefs of the throat, use
the juice inward and outward. Stinging, (See Serpents.) Stomach weak, eat it
or drink it any way. Stomach cleansing, (See Purgation.) Stones griefs, use
Planten. Swellings, use Planten: stamp the leaves with salt, and apply them:
or with old grease. Swine Pocks, (See Pocks.)

Teeth ach, use the juice or decoction of the leaves. Sees the root and rub
often therewith, and chew it. Tetters, apply the juice or water. Thirst, drink
water of the decoction of Planten. Throat griefs, (See Squincy.) Throat wenne,
stamp the leaves with salt, and apply it, (See swellings.)

Vein broken, (See bleeding, pissing blood, spitting blood.) drink Planten
with the juice of Cresses. Venom, (See plague.) Ulcers, (See sores, wounds,
kankers.) Vomiting, drink Planten. Urine to cause, seethe Planten, and drink
the broth.

Wennes, (See throat.) Wheales, (See Pushes.) Worms, seethe good store of
Planten seeds in Malmesie or ale, to the one half, and drink it fasting
daily. Wounds general, use Planten of all sorts, (See bleeding, rankling,)
apply the juice of Planten and Smallach with wheat flower.

Yard sores and chafings, seethe the juice of Planten with a little Honey, and
anoint.

Plum tree.
PLum tree (See Damson, Sloe, Acatia.) for the leprie Impetigo, and Serpigo
dissolve the gum in vinegar and anoint therewith. 2 Ringworme, boil the sap in
vinegar, and streine it and anoint therewith. 3 Swelling of blood letting,
stamp the leaves of a white Plum tree with water, and apply them. 4 Ringwormes
and tetters, apply the gum dissolved in vinegar.

Leprie 1 Ring worm 2. 4 Swelling of blood letting 3 Tetter 4
Polipody.
POlipody: The root opens the belly, and purges Melancholy gross and
flegmatike humors, and is good for the chollike and griping in the belly, the
hardness and stopping of the milt and quarten fevers, especially with
Epithymum. 2 It must be boiled in broth of Mutton or Capon, or the decoction
of Mallows or Beetes, and a little Annise, and then drunk: or the powder may
be drunk with Mede. 3 Nose Polip, put in the powder to take it away. 4 That
which grows at the foot of the Oak is best. 5 The root of that of the Oak
or Willow sodden with a Hen with some Anniseedes and Ginger, and the broth
drunk warm, purges choler and melancholy: some use Beetes, and some
Mallows therewith. 6 A dram or more of the powder drunk with Honied water three
or four hours before other things, does the like. 7 The same root is good for
swine again ye murren. 8 Chaps, stamp the root with Honey, and use it. 9 Milt
swollen, sees the root in wine, and use it. 10 Deliverance to cause whether
the child be quick or dead, stamp it and apply it to her feet that is in
travel. 11 Joint out, stamp it and apply it. 12 Sees it with a Hen, or with
fish, or with Beets, or Mallows, to make a purgation to purge gross humors
from the joints: it is good for all griefs that come of melancholy, as the
quarten, if it be taken with Mede, Dodder of time and salt Indian. 13 All manner
of ways it is good for the Chollike and hardness of the milt. 14 If it be
taken with Mede or barley water, or the broth of Reasins, or of Cocks or
Hens, or sodden with whey, it will not move the stomach to vomiting: it is
good to take it with well sauouring spices or seeds, as Aniseed, Carawayseed,
Fennel seed, Ginger and such like, that comfort the natural power of the
stomach: it will bide long seething, it may be taken from two drams to six
drams: an ounce and a half of our English Polipody, will scarce purge. 15 Some
take powder of the dry root, at the least one dram for a purgation. 16 The
root sodden in wine and sweetened with Sugar or Honey, and drunk certain
days, is good against the quarten, the Cough, shortness of wind, melancholy
and heavy dreams, etc. 17 Belly bound, sees it with as much Mallows, and
drink the broth: or sees it in water, and make pottage therewith: or steep
it in wine, and drink it. 18 Sees i. handful in red wine from a gallon to a
quart, with ii. spoones full of clarified Honey, and drink one spoonefull morn
and even. 19 Stuf an old fat Hen or Cock with it and Honey, and Butter, or
fresh grease, and sees it well and drink ye broth hot, and drink white wine
and no other drink after it, till thou be soluble. 20 Fundament fig, stamp
it with Yarow and drink it with ale. 21 Pricks, apply it with swines grease. 22 (See
Nettles.) Kings evil, take as much powder of it as will lie on a groate, with
Honey or wine one and twenty days, beginning at the quarter decreasing, and
keep good order of diet, and be whole. 23 Ptisike and evil color in the
face, distill it in September, and drink three or four drams in the morning.
24 Chollike, sees it with an old cock, and drink the broth. 25 To preserve
health, and for the quotidian and Iliak passion, stamp half a dram or a dram
with Prunes and violets, or Aniseeds in Fenel water, and streine it and drink
it morn and even: or sees it with Fenell seed in water, and make therewith a
chicken broth with sweet spices, and eat it: or stamp it and boil it in
wine, and after put more wine to it, and so make it a drink with sweet
spices, and use it.

Breath short 16 Chaps 8 Chollike 1. 6. 13. 24 Cough 16 Color ill 23 Dead
child 10 Deliverance 10 Dreams ill 16 Fever quart. 1 quotid 25 Fundament fig
20 Hogs murren 7 Health to keep 25 Iliak pas. 25 Joints out 11. 12 griefs 12
Kings evil 22 Milt griefs 1. 9. 13 Nose polip 3 Pricks 21 Ptisike 23 Purgat 1.
etc.
Pomgranate.
POmegranate: The juice is very good for a hot and weak stomach, as the
juice of Oringes or Cytrons, and for all hot agewes and inflammations of the
liver and blood, especially the sower Pomegranates, and next unto them, such as
be of a winish taste: for the sweet are not very meet to be used in agewes. 2
The blossoms both of the tame and wild Pomgranat trees, as also the rynde or
shell in powder eaten, or boiled in wine and drunk, are good for the bloody
flux, and the inordinate course of the mother, not only as is aforesaid, but
also to sit or bathe in the decoction thereof. 3 The same bark or blossoms,
stop the blood of green wounds, being applied in any sort. 4 The same bark
kills worms, and is a good remedy against the corruption in the stomach or
bowels, being washed with the broth or decoction thereof. 5 Use the bark and
flowers in plasters, against bruising and ruptures. 6 The seeds dried in the
sun have like virtues as the flowers: it stops the laske and all issues of
blood, being taken in the same manner. 7 The same mixed with Honey helps all the
sores of the mouth, priuities and fundament. They that eat three flowers of
the tame Pomegranate, shall be preserved one year from dropping and bleared
eyes. 8 The juice and kernels are good in hot griefs and burning fevers to
quench thirst and heat of the stomach: and so is the syrope of the juice of
it. The kernels of the sower Pomgranats dried in the sun, help all manner of
fluxes, both of the belly and Matrixe. 9 And drunk with raw water, they help
the spitting of blood: and so do the flowers or rindes thereof. 10 The rind
sodden in wine and drunk, kills worms: and the powder of the rind or
flowers drunk or taken fasting, is good for the cold cough and the reume. 11
The juice of the kernels mixed with Honey and sodden, is good for painful sores
of the mouth, yard and fundament, and for the looseness of the skin about the
nails, and for swellings and knots in any part of the body, for ach of the
ears and griefs of the nostrels, especially the kernels of the sower
Pomgranats. 12 The rind of Pomgranats powdered and mixed with Honey and anointed,
sistit fluxum vrinae aureae. 13 The powder of the flowers in plasters, drives
back the hernyes and swelling of the Cods, especially if some gauls be put
thereto. 14 Emplasters made of Pomgranats, be good against hot fevers. 15 The
wine of Pomgranats is good to comfort the stomach after meat. 16 The flowers
of wild Pomgranates stop fluxes, being used in drinks and Glisters. 17 The
kernels of the sower Pomgranat dried in the sun, and either sprinkled on
meat or sodden therewith, stop the belly and stomach that is loose. 18 The
sower Pomgranat is good for the heart burning and the swooning that comes by
choler, the inflammation of the liver, and to cause appetite. 19 The syrope is
good for women with with child, and the heat of the stomach and liver. 20
The juice of the sweet Pomgranat is good for the stomach, but in hot fevers
the sower is better. 21 They are very comfortable and restoratiue in long
sickenesses, consumptions and fluxes. 22 The powder of the rind drunk with
red wine and Cinamome, helps any laske or flux. 23 The kernels steeped in
water and drunk, are good against spitting of blood. 24 The whole Pomgranat
stopt^ lose with clay into an earthen pot, and dried in an Oven, helps the
bloody flux and torments of the belly, one dram and a half drunk with wine.
25 Powder of the kernels of sower Pomgranats, one ounce, with one dram of
Frankincense thereof drunk with Rose water, stops the whites in women. 26
Eyes itch, heat and running, take up the fume of the decoction of the flowers.
27 Teeth ach, wash with the decoction of the flowers, and put powder of the
same into the tooth. 28 Belching and yexing, and to restore appetite, stamp a
Pomgranat whole with the rind, and boil it with a quart of Honey till it be
thick, and take a little of it fasting with cold water. 29 Worms, sees the
rind with the root of an Ash in wine, and drink it fasting, it helps also
the Tenasmus: or drink Acatia with water of the decoction of Pomegranates. 30
The decoction of the flowers fasten teeth, (See Maces.) 31 Heart faint of hot
cause, make pottage of the kernels and barley meal, and use to eat thereof. 32
Thirst to void, sup the juice of it, (See Almonds for the bloody flux.) Yard,
(See Cinamome.) 33 Eyes pin and web, put in the juice of a sour Pomegranate
two or three times to heal it. The same cures sauseflegme, redness and such
like in the face, and also the morphue. 34 Flux red or yelow, use ye syrope of
Pomgranats with Mint water. 35 Wild fire, mix powder of the utter rind with
vinegar, and anoint therewith.

Appetite 18. 28 Belching 28 Belly ach 24 Bloody flux 26. 24. 32 Blood to stop

Pompons.
POmpons, (See Mellons.) make little balls or trochiskes of the juice of the
inner part, and Bean flower, dry them in the shadow, and wash therewith in a
Bane, to avoid all filth and spots from the skin when you begin to sweat,
being broken and mixed with water.

Skin to cleanse (See all.)
Poplar
POplar white: 1 Boil the bark in wine to provoke urine, and help the
strangurie and the Sciatica. 2 Ears pain and ulcers, drop in the juice of the
leaves. 3 The leaves and young buds of black Poplar, stamped and applied,
swageth the pain of the gout in the hands or feet. 4 The ointment that is
made of the buds, is good against all inflammations, all bruisings and
swellings, being applied. 5 The juice of the bark sodden in red wine, helps
the bloody flux and the Sciatica. 6 The leaves of black Poplar applied with
vinegar, are good for the gout. 7 The rosen that comes out of Poplar, is
often mixed with softning and suppling in Plasters. 8 The seed is good for the
falling sickness. 9 An ounce of the bark of white Poplar, is good against
the sciatica, being drunk, and likewise for the strangury. 10 The round pills
which come forth at ye budding time, broken and applied with Honey, heal the
dullness of the sight. 11 The katlins or taklets of Poplar, come forth about ye
end of March and April, and then the buds thereof must be gathered to make
vnguentum Populeon. 12 Poplar is good in baths against most diseases of the
body. 13 Lust to void, drink or eat ye flowers of the tree. Gout, take one
ounce of the rind, (See Feuerfue.) 14 The Populeon has these virtues. 15
Liver chaft, anoint therewith. 16 For such as can not hold their water, anoint
the reins therewith. 17 Anoint the stomach or belly therewith to stop either
vomit or laske. 18 Fever pestilentiall, anoint the spine of the back, and the
plants of the hands and feet therewith, and oil of Roses, and also the region
of the liver. 19 Burning and skalding, mix it with yolks of eggs and apply
it, or mix it with whites of eggs, and oil of Roses, and use it. 20
Headache, anoint the temples with it. 21 Frenzy, shave the head and anoint it
with it, and apply a whelpe or cockrell slit through the midst of the back.
22 Reins running, anoint them therewith. 23 Strangury, anoint with it, and
wear a plate of lead pricked full of holes to the reins. 24 Yard pain and
chafed, mix it with oil of Roses or of Violets, and of Poppy, and the white
of an Egg and use it. 25 Fistula, search it, and put in a tent that will fill
it, anointed with Populeon, and the sore also, but dip the tent point in this
powder: take green Coprose two ounces, burn it in a crusible, and put thereto
Mercury sublimate one ounce, and grind them very fine, and so dress it two
days together with this powder once in 24. hours, and then other two days
with Populeon only, and when it is clean, heal it up with incarnatiues etc.
26 Itch and skabbe, mortify Quicksiluer with fasting spittle, and mix it with
twice so much Populeon, and anoint the plants of the hands, and feet therewith
morn and even.

Bathing 12 Bloody-fluxe 5 Bruses 4 Burnings 19 Ears griefs 2 Eyes griefs 10

Poppie.
POppie: white Poppie seeds gathered when they be ripe, may be kept five
years, they provoke sleep, and swage pain. 2 Bruise the seeds with woman's
milk and the white of an Eg, and apply it hot to the temples and forehead to
provoke sleep. 3 The seed or herb bruised with oil of Roses, and applied,
draws out the great heat of ulcers coming of a bruise, and applied to the
hot liver, it does help it much. 4 Anoint the back with powder of the
seeds, and oil Olive, to assuage the ache of the joints, and to strengthen
them. 5 The juice with oil of Roses helps the hot gout of the feet, and
the ache thereof. 6 Powder of the seeds with oil of Violets anointed on the
back bone, does help the burning of the Fever, and heat of the liver. 7 Any
kind of Poppie, or the juice or water thereof applied to the forehead and
temples, provoke sleep, and helps the frenzy. 8 Put the juice of the
herb with a tent into the nose to provoke sleep: and into the natural place
to stop the terms: apply it to any pain to mitigate the same. 9 Seethe heads
and leaves in water, and bathe the head therewith to provoke sleep. 10 The
broth is good to be drunk against too much want of sleep. 11 The heads broken
with parched Barley meal, are good to be applied to inflammations both
chollerike and others. 12 The green heads must be brayed and fashioned into
little cakes, and dried to serve in time of need. 13 The whole heads are
sodden alone in water to the one half, and then streyned and sodden with honey
to the thickness of an Electuarie, which is good for ye cough, the cathar that
falls into the pipes, and for the running of ye belly, but it will be much
better if Hypoquistida or Acatia be put to it. 14 Drink the seeds of black
Poppie broken in wine against the flux, and all issues of women. Apply it to
the temples to provoke sleep. 15 The seed of Garden Poppie is good to be mixed
with bread to season it, but ye white is better then the black. 16 The use of
Poppie is very good of the much spitting and coughing of raw matter from the
breast, by distilling of reume from the head. 17 The white taken with honey
increases seed. 18 The seed of black Poppie taken by it self or with wine,
helps the cough and falling down of reume, the flowing of women's sickness
and terms, and pains of the small guts: the same does the juice thereof. 19
Powder of white Poppie seed given to children in milk or possite drink, or
an alebrew, or rather with a Caudell of Almonds and hemp seed, causes them
to sleep. 20 Stamp white Poppie and Henbane seed with the white of an Egg,
and apply it to the forehead to provoke sleep in the frenzy. 21 Stamp the
leaves of white Poppie and red Nettles with a little Bean flower, and bind it
to the forehead to provoke sleep. 22 Wash thy face with hot water of the
decoction of Poppie, and thou shall either sleep, or dye out of hand. 23 The
juice of Poppie with oil of Roses provoke sleep. 24 Stamp the heads of
green Poppie with oil of Roses and Rose water, and apply it to the forehead
and temples for headache, and to provoke sleep. 25 The seeds in an
Electuarie are good for the cough and hoarsenesse. 26 The decoction of the
leaves and heads in water drunk, causes sleep, and so it does if the head
and hands be washed therewith. 27 The seed of black Poppie drunk in Wine,
stops the flux and terms. 28 And being mixed with water and applied to the
temples causes sleep. 29 A plaster made of the green heads before they be
ripe, and parched Barley meal is good for the holy fire, and hot tumors.
(See Opium and Corne-rose.) 30 Sleep to cause, stamp the seeds with woman's
milk, and apply it to the forehead and temples, or anoint with the juice and
woman's milk, or apply the juice of Poppie, Houseleeke, and Nightshade, with
the seeds of Poppie, and the white of an Egg in a sharp Fever. 31 Or seethe
the tops of black Poppie in milk and drink it, or stamp them with water,
and apply it blood warm to the forehead, temples, and pulses. 32 Sees crowns
of Poppie heads in milk and drink it. Fevers caused of hot meats, use Opij
Zaccarum with milk of Poppie seed. 33 Costiuenesse and headache, stamp the
seeds and streine it with water, and drink thereof, especially at night, and
apply it to thy forehead. 34 Fever of hot blood, drink water wherein the
leaves of Fleawort have been sodden with a little milk of Poppy seed. 35
Sleep to cause, stamp the seeds of Lettuse and white Poppy, with woman's
milk, and apply it to the pulses. 36 Scrophules, seed wild Poppy, quick
Brimstone, and Doves doung, and Linseede with pure wine, being first stamped,
and apply it to all Scrophules. 37 The branches of wild Poppy and unripe
Figs, draw broken bones out of ulcers. 38 Sleep to cause, apply a plaster
of the seeds with woman's milk, and the white of an Egg to the temples. 39
For a hot impostume and chafing of the liver, stamp the seeds or herb of
white Poppy, with oil of Roses, and apply it. 40 For dryness in a fever
hectike, stamp the seeds with oil of Violets, and anoint the small of the
back therewith. 41 Sleep to cause, stamp the seeds of Poppy and Henbane,
with the white of an Egg, and apply it to the forehead. 42 For great grief in
the body, boil the leaves with Fiueleafe, and Peniroyall, of each like much
in wine, and foment therewith. 43 Headache, apply the seeds with gum
Arabike and woman's milk to the temples. 44 Bones broken, seethe Figs and Poppy
sodden in water and apply it. 45 Flux to stop, make drink of the seeds of
Lettuse and white Poppy and use it. 46 Sleep to cause, drink a spoonefull of
syrup of Poppy, or anoint the temples with oil of Poppy. Sleep to cause,
take one spoonefull of white Poppy seed with a little possiteale made with
Violets, Strawberie leaves, and Fiueleafe, and drink it warm when need is.
Bruise 4. ounces of white Poppy seed, but not ye ripest, steep them in a
pottel of rain water 24. hours, seethe it till the better half be wasted,
streine it, and to every pint put one pound of Sugar, seethe it and skomme it,
and keep it in a close glass, and take one spoonefull when need is to
provoke sleep.

Priuet.
PRiuet: the leaves do cure swellings, ulcers, and apost. of the mouth, and
sores, pustules, and blisters of the throat being washed or gargled with the
decoction or juice. 2 Straw powder of the leaves on hot ulcers and festring
and consuming sores, or bruise the fruit and apply it to the same effect. 3
Burning and skalding, use the broth of the leaves. 4 Headache, apply the
flowers. 5 The oil heateth and softneth sinowes being mixed with things that be
of hot nature. 6 Mouth sores, chewe the leaves. 7 Burnings, carbuncles,
inflammations, stamp the leaves and apply them. 8 The water of the leaves and
tendrels or flowers distilled in May or June, helps the exulceration of the
mouth, hot inflammations, carbuncles, ulcers of the privy parts and burnings
with fire. 9 The flowers applied with vinegar, helps the headache. 10 Feet
galled, wash with the juice of the fruit. 11 Canker, apply the water.

Burnings 3. 7. 8 Carbuncles 7. 8 Chafing 10 Feet galled 10 Festers 2
Headache 4. 9 Inflammation 7. 8 Kanker 11 Mouth sores 1. 6. 8 Priuities sores
8 Sinowes griefs 5 Skalding 3 Skin off 10 Sores 2 Swellings 1 Throat sores
1. 6. 8 Ulcers 1. 2
Purslaine.
PVrslaine eaten green, helps a hot stomach, and the swelling of the mouth
of the stomach. 2 Teeth-ache, sees it and hold it in thy mouth. 3 Apostume
and hot ulcers, stamp it and apply it. 4 Head ulcers, seethe it in wine and
wash therewith. 5 Fever hot, eat it raw with vinegar. 6 Stomach hot,
bruise it with Barley meal, and apply it. 7 Flowers to stop, eat it to stay
them without harm. 8 Headache, and heat of the eyes, apply it with Barley
flower. Fever burning, drink the juice, which also kills worms, and helps
spitting of blood. 9 Belly bound, seethe it in water with Prunes, and drink
the broth. 10 Warts, anoint with the juice to pluck them up by the roots. 11
Holy fire, bruise it and apply it. 12 Thirst, hold it under the tongue. 13 The
eating of it raw, breeds clammy humors in the stomach. 14 Eat it to stop
fluxes, to quench burning choler, to extinguish lust, to help the reins and
bladder, to kill round worms, to comfort the matrix, and to stay the
abundance of terms. 15 Drink the juice in hot Fevers. 16 It may be preserved
with salt, and then it is good with roasted meats. 17 The root hanged with a
thread about thy neck, helps the falling of the vuula. 18 Teeth-ache, and
anedged, chewe it. 19 It quenches the fretting and exulcerations of the
kidneis and bladder, and outrageous lust. 20 It is good in eye medicines, 21 And
in glisters for the flux, and ye gnawing and fretting of the matrix. 22 Head
ache of heat, anoint with the juice and oil. 23 Head plouks and blaines, rub
it with the juice and wine. 24 Wounds rotten and nummed, apply it with parched
Barley meal. 25 Drink it and apply it against all poison and venom, and to
withstand unwholesome water. 26 Chewe it with honey and apply it to sores to heal
them. 27 Apply it to childrens nauels that go far out. 28 Chewe it raw for
the sores of the mouth, swellings of ye gums, and the tooth ache, and to fasten
loose teeth. 29 Apply it to the ache of the neck with as much of a gall and
Linseede. 30 The seed sodden with honey, is good against shortness of breath. 31
Purslaine is good in sallads, and strengthens the stomach. 32 With oil and
parched Barley, it swageth ache of wounds, it softneth ye hardness of the
sinowes, it drives away unclean dreams of venery, and minisheth seed, it
hurts ye eyesight. 33 The juice, water, seed, or any part of it is good for
all inward heates of ye stomach, liver, and kidneis. 34 The water stops the
bloody flux and other fluxes, and is good for the frenzy, the inflammation,
ache, or running of the eyes and ears, and all infla^mations of the belly, the
terms, and Emerods, spitting of blood, the cough and shortness of breath. 35
The seed, herb, or water used, stops ye running of the reins, abateth
lust, and cools the blood. 36 The herb or seed stamped with flowers of
parched Barley, and applied to the forehead and temples, appeaseth headache
coming of heat, helps the frenzy, the inflammation of the eyes, and their
rednes: it helps the holy fire, the shingles, ringwormes, and tetters. 37
Mix ye juice with oil of Roses or of Violets, and apply it to ye temples with
stuphes of Hemp to provoke sleep. 38 The distilled water drunk, works ye
same effect. 39 Mix the juice with oil of wax, and apply it to the swelling
of the yard. 40 It stops all issues of blood, the juice being drunk and the
herb boiled and eaten. 41 The juice powered on ye head with oil and vinegar of
Roses, swageth ye hot headache coming by heat of the sun. 42 The juice
thrown up into the matrix helps the burning inflammations, exulcerations,
gnawings and frettings in the same. 43 And put in by glister, it helps ye
flux of ye guts and exulceration of the bowels. 44 Purslaine cools all
things that are too hot, and defends wounds from inflammation. 45 The seeds
expel worms and stop the laske. 46 Wild Pursten may be used to all purposes
in stead of it: it grows in gardens, alleys and rocks, etc. 47 Purslaine
preserved in salt or brine, heateth and purges the stomach: dip a cloth in
the juice of Purslaine, and Gourde, or Cucumber, and apply it to the head
against ye frenzy with vinegar round about the head. 48 Impost. eat
Purslaine. 49 Strangurie of hot cause, drink ye juice. 50 Fevers hot, use
Purslaine. 51 Burnings, apply it with Barley meal. 52 Purslaine will not
suffer choler to engender in the stomach. 53 Eyes web, drop in the juice of
wild Purslaine. 54 Worms, drink good store of the seeds. 55 Matrix swollen,
drink Purslaine and apply it, or bathe it with the decoction of it.

Quince.
QVince: The Quince stops the laske or common flux, the bloody-fluxe, and
all other fluxes of blood, spitting blood, especially when it is raw: for when
it is either boiled or roasted, it stops not so much, but it is then fitter
to be eaten, and more pleasant to the taste. 2 Women with child that eat
Quinces often in meat or otherwise, shall bring forth wise children of good
understanding. 3 The Codenac, or Marmalad made with honey as it was wont to be,
with sugar as they use to make it now a days, is very good to strengthen the
stomach, and to keep the meat therein till it be perfectly digested. 4 Being
taken before meat, it stops the laske, and after meat it loses the
belly, and closes up the mouth of the stomach so fast, that no vapors can
ascend up into the brain, and cures headache, that comes of such vapors. 5
The decoction or broth of Quinces has ye like virtue, and stops the belly,
and al fluxes of blood, and the violent issues of the terms. 6 With ye same it
is good to bathe the loose fundament and falling down of ye matrix, to make
them to return into their natural places. 7 They are also good in plasters to
stop the flux and vomiting, and for all hot swellings and inflammations of the
breast and other places. 8 The down that grows upon Quinces sodden in wine
and applied, heals carbuncles. 9 The oil of Quinces staieth vomitings,
gripings in ye belly or stomach with ye casting up of blood, if ye stomach be
anointed therewith. 10 The flowers of the Quince tree do stop fluxes, spitting
blood and the flowers, and have the same virtues that Quinces themselves have.
11 If the stomach be very hot and moist, or the belly laxatiue, Quinces are
best to be eaten before meat, being roasted or eaten cold, and the tarter that
they be, ye better they are. 12 And Pomegranates be of the same virtue. 13 But
the custom of taking of Quinces in meats hurts ye sinowes, but by way of
medicin they be excellent. 14 And the cores taken out and preserved in honey or
kept in their mussilage, they may long continue to ye use of rosting or baking:
for they be perilous to the stomach being eaten raw, but preserved, they do
mightily prevail against drunkenness. 15 If he that has drunk well eat a
Quince roasted or otherwise ordered, the drink shall not annoye his brain
much. 16 Quinces well roasted or baked, are of good nourishment, and are good
for the stomach, and take away belching, vomiting, and lothing, especially
taken after meat. 17 The syrupes and Electuaries made of Quinces with spices,
are very profitable for many griefs. 18 The juice of a raw Quince is very
good for them whose wind is stopped, and cannot hold their meat. 19 Quinces
preserved whole in honey, are very good to be used of them that have the bloody
flux. 20 Raw Quinces applied in plasters are good to stop the flux and
vomiting, the heat of the stomach, and inflammation of the breast and liver.
21 The decoction of the leaves is good against the falling down of the matrix
and fundament. 22 The seed steeped in Rose Water, is good against thick and
gross humors, in burnings with fire. 23 Gawles and Medlers be of the same
virtue. 24 No man can sufficiently declare the virtues of Quinces. 25 Quinces
are good for the stomach, they make a man piss well, but when they are
roasted, they are counted to be gentler. 26 The juice of raw Quinces is good
for them that are short winded. 27 The broth of them is good to bathe the
mother in that falls down. The Quinces that are condited with honey provoke
urine. 28 They that are sodden in honey, are more pleasant for the stomach. 29
They are good raw in plasters to stop the belly, for the inflammation of the
stomach and paps, for vomiting, hardness of the milt, and swelling about the
fundament. 30 You may make wine of them, by stamping and streyning them, but it
will not last, except you put to every xv. quartes one quart of honey, for
without honey it will turn to vergis. 31 The wine so made is good for all the
things aforesaid. 32 The oil of Quinces is made of the smallest, roundest, and
best smelling Quinces. 33 The flowers both green and dry, are good in
emplasters for all things that need binding, and for inflammations, and
vomiting of blood. 34 And they are also good against the flixe, and to stop the
terms. 35 Headache, eat roasted Quinces after meals when the ache comes of
vapors. 36 Vomit to stop, steep the kernels in water and drink it, or bind
the leaves unto thy wristes. They may be gathered in August, and kept all the
year. 37 Flux, seethe Quinces after they be pared and cored with Oak apples
and Cinamom, and sugar it and take thereof iii. nights. 38 To make Marmalad of
Quinces, take Quinces xvi. pound, core them, seethe them, and stamp them in a
stone mortar, then clarify ten pound of honey with the gleyre of an Eg, or
white well beaten, and sees all till it be stiff, then lay it on a marble
stone, and cut it of what fashion you will. 39 A plaster of Quinces is
restrictiue and good for the bloody flixe. 40 Tongue sharp and dry, put the
seeds of Quinces, and Psilium, or one of them into a cloth, and steep it in
water, and wash therewith. 41 Stamp Barley meal with half as much Quince
kernels with vinegar, and apply it to burnings or inflammations of the gout.
42 Mix the pap of sodden Quinces eight ounces, with powder of Sugar four
ounces, vinegar six spoonefull or more, Ginger half an ounce, white Pepper
one dram, seethe it to the height of a Conserve, and take thereof before and
after meat to comfort the stomach.

8 Conserve 42 Digestion 3 Drunkenness 14. 15 Flowers to stop 5. 10. 34 Fluxes
