conc. 2
Radish.
RAdish eaten at supper does well digest meat, heateth the stomach, causes
a stinking breath, if any sleep by and by after the eating of it. 2 The root
is hurtful to women with child. 3 Canker in old ulcers, anoint with the
juice of the root, or use the powder of it. 4 Boil the juice with honey, and
mix it with a little vinegar, and streine it and drink it, to help the
quarten Fever and the stopping of the milt. 5 Stamp the root and apply it to
the water between the skin and flesh, and to the hardness of the milt. 6
Kings evil, drink the juice of the root with the lyanor of Reasins. 7 And
with honey to void the cough, stopping the breast, and shortness of breath. 8
Bruise the roots, and steep them two or three days in vinegar, then put
thereto a third part of honey, and streine it and drink of this Oximell to
help the fever quotidian and quarten, except the same come of salt phlegm. 9
For cold and undigested humors in the stomach, steep the rindes of the
roots in vinegar and honey mixed together, and eat daily a good quantity
thereof, and drink after it a draught of warm water, and put thy finger or a
feather dipped in sallet oil into thy throat to procure vomit at any time, but
the best time is in the morning. 10 For hardness of the liver and milt, seethe
the herb alone in oil and wine, and apply it plaster wise hot, and likewise
for the strangury to the bottom of the belly and root of the priuitie. 11
Distill water of Radish in September, and drink iii. or iiii. ounces of the
water morn and even for the stone, to provoke urine, to cleanse the reins and
bladder, and testicles, and for the Kings evil, to kill worms and help
digestion, and to cleanse the stomach from humors that let digestion, to open
all obstructions of the intralles and veins, and to cause a clear voice. 12
Gargle therewith in the throat, and hold thereof in thy mouth to help the
swelling in the throat, and ulcers in the gummes. 13 Drink thereof also iiii.
ounces morning and evening three or four weeks together, and forbear much
other drinking to help the water between the skin and the flesh. 14 Stamp
earth worms, and put thereto the juice of Radish roots, and quench therein
any knife, sword, or other tool to make it cut Iron as it were Lead. 15 Boil
iiii. pound of the outward rindes of Radish with viii. pound of honey to the one
half, then put thereto powder of Cinamom, Cloves, Mace, Nutmegs, and black
Pepper, of each half an ounce, and keep it in a close vessel, and take
thereof half an ounce every morning fasting to be free from the chollike and
iliake. 16 Mix the juice of the roots with white wine and Turpentine burned
or dried in the sun, and drink it to drive out ye stone. 17 The young stemes
and tender crops and buds, may be boiled and eaten with oil and vinegar, and
they nourish better then the roots, though their nourishment be but little. 18
The bark of the root taken before meat with Oximell stirs vomiting,
purges tough humors, and quickens the wit and understanding. 19 The
decoction or broth of Radish drunk, provoke urine, breaks the stone, and
drives it out, ripeth gross phlegm, cleanses the breast and stomach, and
helps the old cough. 20 Radish is good for the Dropsy, the griefs of the
liver, and stopping of the reins. 21 And eaten with Mustard, it is good
against ye Lethargy, drowsiness, and forgetfulness. 22 It is good also for
them that are sick with eating of Todestooles or Mushroomes or Henbane, or
other venom, and for the chollike and griping pain in the belly: it
provoke terms, and causes abundance of milk. The root stamped very small
with vinegar and applied, cures the hardness of the milt. 23 The same with
honey helps fretting, festering, and consuming sores, and is good against
skuruinesse and skales of the head, and restores hair. 24 The same with
Darnel meal takes away blewe spots of bruises and all blemishes, and frecles
of the face. 25 The seed causes vomit vehemently, and provoke urine, and
being drunk with honey and vinegar, it kills and expels worms. 26 The
same taken with vinegar wastes the milt, and slaketh the hardness thereof. 27
The same sodden in honied vinegar and often gargarised hot, is good against
the Squincy. 28 The wild or water Radish has the same virtues, but stronger,
and is singular good to provoke urine. 29 Radish laid to with vinegar, does
mightily skowre away gangrenes, or extreme hot sores. 30 Radish sodden with
water and tempered with honey, is good against the old cough, and cleanses the
breast and lungs being used certain days. 31 The bark of the root stamped
and taken with honey and vinegar, provoke vomit, and so does the seed taken
with warm water. 32 Radish stamped finely with honey, takes away all black
spots of bruises, the spots and pimples of the face, restores hair, and is
good against all venomous bitings and stingings. 33 And the same applied to the
navel of a woman, takes away ye torments of her belly. 34 The great wild
Raysart is much of like nature to Radish. 35 The young plants of Radish with
vinegar at the beginning of meals, is good sause to loosen the belly. 36 But
it is best to seethe Radish, and put vinegar, sugar, and good sweet oil to
it, and not to eat it raw. 37 Radish sodden in wine and drunk morn and
even, breaks and expels the stone, opens the gall, diminishes the
spleen, and moves venus. 38 Drop the juice warm into the ear to help any
pain therein. 39 The ashes of burned Radish does cleanse and dry ulcers. 40
Stamp two ounces of the root, or three drams of the seeds, and put thereto
honied water or barley water or whey, and streine it and drink it to provoke
vomit, and cleanse ye stomach: it may be given to any of any age or kind.
Radish is unwholesome for them that have pain of the gout or ache of the
joints. 41 Stamp the leaves with old swines grease, and apply it to botches
and apostumes, and to help them. 42 Dropsy, make Oximell with Radish, and use
it. 43 Ears dull, seethe the seeds of Radish, Stauesacre, and Wormwood, and
streine it and put it into the ear with a tent. 44 Phlegm to void, put the
root with Oximell into warm water, and drink a good deal, and put thy
finger into thy mouth to provoke vomit. 45 Apply the juice of the roots to
the gout. 46 Eat the roots for the Iaundies, having first drunk Oximell
squillitike. 47 The juice drunk is a good preservative against death drunk
with wine. 48 For phlegm or reume, stamp the roots with Figs and a little
Honey, and boil it into an Electuarie, and use it to cleanse the stomach of
phlegm. 49 Seethe one handful of the roots with four ounces of Saxifrage in
wine to the third part, then put in a little Honey and drink it warm at even
for the stone. 50 Stamp the roots, and apply them to the belly to kill worms
and expel them. Hickit, chewe the root to provoke vomit. 51 Urine to cause,
seethe as much horse Radish as two eggs sliced thin in a pint of water, with
as much honey as the root, and when it is well sodden drink thereof. 52 Or
slice as much as both the fistes, and stamp it and put thereto thrice as much
course branne, seethe it in a pottell of water till the water be consumed, and
lie upon it, thy belly downwards, as hot as thou can suffer. 53 Stone and
stopping of the urine, slice ii. pound of the root of wild or horse Radish,
stamp them and sees them in a linen bag in a pot of water, and put to it
six buckets of other water, and sit therein up to the middle, and apply the
bag unto the place, and drink the distilled water of the same herb at morn,
noone, and even, especially with powder of the kidneis of a Hare two drams. Or
cut the said root checkerwise as dice four ounces, power thereon a quart of
the best wine that can be got, and let it stand 24. hours, and drink thereof
four ounces morning and evening. If you cannot have horse Radish, take common
Radish. 54 Ptisike, dry the root of Radish, and make it into fine powder, and
use it in meats, brothes, sawses, and drinks. 55 Worms, drink the juice
fasting. 56 Canker, apply the juice of Radish, and Elecampana, with wheat
flower, and the white of an Egg. 57 Canker worms, apply the leaves stamped
with black nesh soap. 58 Stone to break, steep the sliced roots in white
wine one night, then streine it and drink it. Oil of Radish causes hair to
grow. 59 Head pushes, and sores, stamp Radish with Hogs grease, and anoint
therewith. 60 Falling evil, stamp it and apply it to the brain. 61
Teeth-ache, fill it with a piece of the root, or rub the teeth and gummes
therewith. 62 Nose-bleeding, put in the rind of Woodbine and the scraping of
Radish. 63 Fever tertian, stamp the root with wheat branne, and apply it
between the navel and the share. 64 Scrophules, use to take Radish any way in
meat or drink. 65 The oil of the seeds with the juice of Broom kills
lice. 66 Anoint thy hand with the juice of the root, and no serpent will hurt
thee when thou handlest her. 67 Face bruised or hurt, anoint with honey and the
juice of the rind of the root. 68 Hair to grow again, (See in Dog-Fenell.)
69 Skin spots, distill Radish in a Limbek, and wash therewith. 70 Fretting
sores, mix well the oil of Radish with salt, and apply it. 71 Bruises and
spots, anoint with the juice or with honey wherein the seeds be dissolved. 72
Eyes dull, gather the roots in an evening, slice them and lay the cut side
downwards in a chafindish, and let it stand all night in the air, and gather
the water, and drop it into the eyes. 73 Radish is good against all choking of
mushroomes and poison, or venom. 74 To help digestion, eat Radish after
meat. 75 Reins ache, cut the roots in small gobbits, and steep them all
night in Malmesey, and drink it first and last nine days. Pare the roots,
and put them in dishes with vnpured honey, and let them stand all night, and in
the morning eat nine gobbits or slices fasting, the next day eight, the next
day seven, and so to one, to break the stone. Biting of a mad dog, pare the
root and seethe it in wine, and stamp it, and apply it, for it will hold
the hole open, and draw out the venom, if you stamp the leaves therewith,
and apply it, it will do better. 76 Stomach to cleanse, seethe Elecampana,
and Radish of each half a handful in a quart of water with a pint of Honey,
and a farthingwoorth of bruised Licoras, and drink thereof first and last. 77
Phlegm to void, seethe Radish in Ale, and eat it.

Rape.
RApe and Turnep: The Turnep taken in meat nourishes meetely well being
moderatly taken and well digested, but taken too much, it ingendreth much
windiness and superfluity of humors, especially eaten raw: for then it
hurts the stomach, and causes windy griping and torment in the small guts. 2
The same boiled in milk and applied, swageth the pain of the gout. 3 Oil of
Roses put into a Turnep, and roasted in the Embers, heals kibed heels. 4 The
broth of Rapes is good for the same purpose being washed and bathed therein
sokingly, and so is the Nauew or Turnep it self being either baked or roasted
and applied. 5 The scrops and young springs of Turnips eaten, provoke urine, and
are good for the stone. 6 The seeds of Turnips or Rapes, withstand all poison,
and are therefore put into Treacles and medicines against poison, and to swage
ache: and so is the oil of the seed. and taken raw, it expels worms. 8
The root prepared and used as is aforesaid, stirs up Venus, and so does the
seeds being drunk. 9 The seeds are also put into medicines that are made to
beautify the face, and all the body. 10 Rapes have also a marvelous property
to cleanse the sight. Rapes sodden and applied hot, help the ach of the Gout,
and heals kibes: especially some oil of Roses and wax being roasted therein.
11 Wild Rapes are put into medicines to cleanse the skin, as with Lupines,
Bean meal, etc. 12 There is great plenty of it made in Marsh land, near to
Linne, very profitable in our common wealth. 13 The oil drunk, is a present
remedy against poison and deadly drinks. 14 The Rape laid up in brine, nourish
less, but causes appetite to meat. 15 It is good that Rapes be twice sodden
before they be eaten, then they nourish sufficiently, provoke vrin, engender
seed, and swage the roughness of the breast and throat. 16 If they be eaten
with salt and vinegar, they cause appetite. 17 Rapes are good for white flawes
and such like diseases of the nails. 18 Poisoned, drink presently the seeds
or roots of Turnips. Vrin to cause, drink the seeds of Turnips. 19 Sees
Raphanus or Rape in oil and anoint thy head therewith for the Frenzy, and
thou shall either sleep or die. 20 Head ach of murre, sees Rapes in a pot,
and hold thy nose over it. 21 Horsenesse lately come, roste a Rape root till
it be black, and pare it, and eat it as hot as may be suffered, and drink a
draught of hot water after it, and wet a cloth in cold water, and wring it,
and bind it about thy neck, and a warm cloth on it morn and even. 22
Lamenesse, eat young Hogs feet sodden with Rapes and Buglosse. 23 Cough and
other griefs of the chest, sees Rape in a pot, and hold thy mouth and face
over it, till thy face sweat, and keep thee warm after it. 24 Matrixe, windy,
foment with the decoction of Rapes. 25 Gout and pain of the joints, use water
of the decoction of Rapes. 26 Matrixe windy, mix the juice of Mullin and Rapes
with Barley meal, and apply it. 27 Eyes dull and misty, use Comfits of Rape
seeds. 28 Matrixe swollen, and windy, seethe Rape seed in water, and foment
the place therewith. 29 Skorching with fire, stamp Rapes with their root, and
distill them in a Limbecke, and wash therewith often.

Appetite 14. 16 Breast rough 15 Burning 29 Cough 23 Eyes dull 10. 27 Face
deform. 9. 11 Frenzy 19 Gout 2. 10. 25 Head ach 20 Horsenesse 21 Joints pain
25 Kibes 3. 4. 10 Lame 2 Lust to cause 8 Matrixe swollen 28 windy 24. 26. 28

19 Seed to increase 15 Stone 5 Throat rough 15. 21 Venom 6 (See poison) Vrin
stopped 5. 15. 18 White-flawes 17
Raspis.
RAspis are of the same virtue that common Brier or Bramble is of: and
moreover, the flower stamped with Honey and applied, is good for the inflammation
of the eyes and the shingles. 2 It is good to be given with water to them that
have weak stomaks. 3 It were good to keep some of the juice of Raspis berries
in some wooden vessel, and to make it as it were Raspis wine, which is good
for many purposes, both for a weak stomach and the flixe, and diverse diseases
of the Gums, Teeth, Vuula, Pallat, and other places thereabouts. 4 The leaves
and tender springs, fruit and root, are not much unlike in virtue, to the
like parts of Briers. (See Briers.)

Eyes griefs 1 Flux 3 Mouth griefs 3 Shingles 1 Stomach weak 2. 3 Vuula
fallen 3
Red rattle.
REd rattle sodden in wine and drunk, stops the terms and all other issues
of blood.

Reed.
REeede called Poole Reed or Canes. 2 Pricks, stamp the root small and
apply it with vinegar, it swageth the pain of the joints that are out. 3 The
green tender leaves finely stamped and applied, do heal cholorike
inflammations or wild fire, and hot swellings and impostumes. If the down
thereof happen to get into the ears, it causes such deafness as can hardly
be cured. 4 The root applied with vinegar, swageth pain of the Reins or
Loins. 5 The ashes of the bark with vinegar heals the falling of the hair.
6 Tongue hurt, seethe it with Honey, and use it, (See pricks in Elecampana.) 7
Stamp the roots with Honey and apply it to pricks. 8 And with earth worms to
the ach of the joints and shrinking of the synnowes.

Ach 2. 4 Apost. 3 Back ach 4 Hair falling 5 Inflammation 3 Joints ach 28
Joint out 2 Loins ach 4 Pricks 2. 7 Synowes shrunk 8 Tongue hurt 6 Wild fire
3
Reasins.
REasins and Vine: Vine leaves, branches and tendrels stamped and the juice
drunk, is good for them that vomit or spit blood, and the bloody flux, and
women with child given to vomiting, and so do the branches and clasping
tendrels by themselves, and likewise boiled in water and drunk. 2 The same
clasping tendrels stamped with parched barley meal, are good for the headache,
coming of heat, and for hot ulcers of the stomach being applied. 3 The ashes
of the dry boughs or cuttings, applied with vinegar, do cure the excressence
and swellings of the Fundament, being first clarified and pared. 4 The same
dissolved in oil of Roses and vinegar, is good for the bitings of serpents,
members out of joint, inflammations or heat of the milt. 5 Green grapes
engender wind in the stomach, belly, and do loosen the belly. 6 The dried
Raisins are good against the Cough and all diseases of the lungs, kidneys and
bladder, and the stopping and weakness of the Liver, to open and strengthen
it. 7 The broth of Raisin kernels, is good for the bloody flux and the laske,
being altogether powered in by Glister. 8 A bath of the decoction of the said
kernels, stops the flowers being bathed therewith. 9 The fame kernels made
into fine powder and applied with falt, do swage and consume hard swellings,
and the swellings of the breasts. 10 White grapes are better then black, and
wholsomer after three or four days gathering, then when they are new
gathered: if they be sweet, they partly nourish and warm the body. 11 They
be wholesome to be eaten before meat. 12 Raisins of the son be very
wholesome, and do comfort digestion: but the stones and rindes would be
refused, and then they be good for the milt and liver: so be Assigants: but
the small Raisins be hurtful to the milt. 13 Reisins be of the nature of
Figs. The sweet are best for the stomach, and yield good nourishment. 14 The
juice or water of the leaves or tendrels of the Vine, are good for spitting of
blood, the griefs of the stomach, and the longing of women with child. 15
The liquor that droppeth out of the wood yearly, is good for the stone being
drunk. 16 The gum dropped into their eyes, is good against their mistiness
and webs, it heals pushes, skabs, leprie, skurfe and such like, being rubbed
on with saltpeter. 17 And the said gum laid too continually with oil,
continually wastes away hair. 18 The pulp of Raisins eaten, is good for the
roughness of the throat, the Cough, and griefs of the kidneys and bladder. 19
And eaten with their stones, they are good for the bloody flux. 20 And taken
in meat with Barley meal and an egg fried, they be good for the same
purpose. 21 If they be laid too with Rue, and without their stones they heal
red and angry night plowks and sores that have matter in them like Honey,
carbuncles, rottenness about the joints, and gangrenes. 22 The same laid too
with the juice of Panik, are good for the Gout, and laid to loose Nails, they
make them come off. 23 Raisins eaten before meals, strengthen the stomach,
provoke appetite, and comfort weak bodies. 24 And without kernels they open
the liver and breast: but eaten with their kernels, they bind: without their
kernels, they concoct raw humors, and withstand putrefaction, and are good for
the griefs of the chest, throat, kidneyes and bladder, and soften the belly
being taken fasting. 25 And so chewed with fine Rubarbe, they take away crudyty
and rawnesse of the stomach. 26 Ringwormes and Tetters, rub them with the
gum, but first rub them with saltpeter. 27 Plant vines near to a Bay tree.
28 Asponge dipped in warm wine, and applied to the left Pap, is good against the
Frenzy. 29 Teeth ach of hot cause, gargarise with water of the decoction of
Raisins: it helps also the stopping of the throat. 30 Liver cold, eat
Raisins. 31 Small Raisins eaten with meat, voydeth belching, and stops the
flux. 32 Teeth ach of heat, gargarise with the decoction of Raisins. 33 Liver
hard, apply a plaster of Dwale and Raisins. 34 Worms in children, eat them
fasting. 35 Eat two drams of great Raisins fasting the stones taken out, to
preserve youth, help digestion, diminish phlegm, comfort the liver and
stomach, and increase blood, and make it thick, and after meat they
strengthen and moysten the belly. 36 Ach, stamp Raisins of the sun, the
stones taken out, and apply it to any ach or grief, (See Figs, Goose heyrif.)
37 Fellon in any place, bruise spanish Raisins and apply them. 38 Raisins eaten
or boiled in wine, are good for the cold cough, and for a cold stomach, and
the Raisins so sodden, are good for cold Apostumes. 39 Stamp well the kernels
of grapes, and bind them in a cloth, and steep them in rain water or spring
water, four and twenty hours, and drink a good draught of it morn and even,
against the looseness of ye belly. 40 Emerods, take up the fume of vine.
Bloody flux, (See Pepper.) 41 Vomiting to stop, for dryness of the stomach,
and obstruction of the liver, use syrope of unripe grapes called Syrupus
agrestis. 42 Burn sower Grapes on a tyle, and put the fine powder thereof into
the eyes that are red and running, (See Mulbery.) 43 Blood to stop, apply the
ashes of a vine with a man's urine, (See Nettle.) 44 Fever tertain, take the
juice of sower Grapes two mornings, or steep vine leaves in wine, and drink
it three or four times, for the fever tertian, or quarten. 45 The gum drunk
with white wine, expels the stone in the reins. 46 Rub Lepries, Ringwormes
and Tetters therewith, and salt peter, to cure them. 47 Stamp green Grapes
with some vinegar, and make little loaves, and dry them in the sun, and
steep them in wine, and it will be vinegar. 48 The water that falls from
vines after they be cut, kills wartes being often washed therewith. 49
Chollike and stone, steep the new ashes of the branches all night in white or
renish wine, and drink it in the mornings. 50 Mix the ashes of the wood with
vinegar, and apply it to the Emerods. 51 For infection of the skin, boil the
roots with Fitches and Fenigreke, and wash therewith. 52 Deliverance to cause,
drink four ounces of the juice or decoction of the leaves sodden in white
wine. 53 Warts or hard knobs, burn the wood, and gather the water or sap
thereof at the end, and rub them therewith. 54 Iliaca passio, drink the juice
of the leaves or buds. (Wine and Vinegar quaere.)

Restharrow.
REstharrow, Cammok, or Petywhin: The bark of the root with Honey provoke
vrin, and breaks ye stone. 2 The broth or decoction thereof sodden in wine
and drunk, has the same virtue. 3 The same boiled in Honey and vinegar drunk,
is good for the falling evil. 4 And boiled in water and vinegar, and holden in
the mouth while it is warm, helps the tooth ach. 5 The tender springs and
crops before they bring forth leaves, preserved in brine or salt, and sometimes
eaten in sallads, are good for the gravel and stone. 6 The bark of the root
drunk with wine, provoke urine, breaks the stone, and helps the Emerods
and fig in the fundament. 7 Seethe the leaves in water, and bathe the legs
therewith up to the knees, to stop the flux.

Emerods 6 Falling evil 3 Fig in the Fundament 6 Flux 7 Fundament griefs 6
Gravel 5 Stone 1. 2. 5. 6 Teeth ach 4 Vrin stopped 1. 2. 6
Rice.
RIce nourish meanly, but it stops the belly. 2 Used with milk, it causes
a good color, and increases natural seed: it must be steeped a night in
water before it be sodden. 3 The flower or meal thereof in drink or glister,
stops ye bloody flixe. 4 Rice may be eaten as a restoratiue, with Almon
milk, and so it comfort nature. 5 Rice potage made with good milk, and
seasoned with sugar and Cinamome, is of easy digestion and restoratiue. 6 If
the milk have hot stones quenched therein first, it is good to stop any
flux, especially thus: Take a good handful of oken bark, boil it in a gallon
of running water to the one half or more, then streine it and cool it, then
beat half a pound of Jorden Almonds husk and all, and streine them with that
water, and so with Rice make potage, and use it for ye flixe. If blanched
Almonds be stamped with Rose water and streined into Rice broth, potage or
milk: it is also very good for ye flixe. 7 Liver cold, use Rice potage. 8
Belly loose, use Rice with Almond milk. Fever flegmatike, purge the body, and
then use Rice potage. 9 Face blaines, pimples and spots, sees Rice in running
water, and wash therewith. 10 Bloody flux, make it into fine flower, and mix
it with yolks of eggs, and frye them with sweet butter, and eat them morn and
even.

Belly loose 1. 8 Bloody flux 3. 8 Consumption 2. 4. 5 Color bad 2 Digestion
5 Fevers flegmatike 8 Fluxes 6 Liver cold 7 Seed to cause 2
Rye.
RYe meal put into a little bag and laid upon the head, cures the old pain
of the head, and dries the brain. 2 The leuin thereof draws forth thorns
and pricks, it ripeth all swellings and apostumes better then leuin of wheat
meal. 3 Rye bread with butter is of the like virtue, but not so strong as ye
leuin. 4 Rye bread is heavy and hard to digest, good and strong for laboring
men. 5 The young blades distilled are good for the stone, and for any great
heat in any part of the body. 6 Teeth yelow, mix Rye meal, salt and Honey, of
each like much, and rub them therewith two or three times a day, and then wash
them with water. 7 Spitting blood, eat a hot Rye cake. 8 Mouth kanker and
stink, bake a cake of sower Rye dough, with good store of salt and Pepper, and
make it into powder, with powder of a Hearts horn, and a Pill of clean leekes,
and apply it all night. 9 Wounds to heal, sees swines grease with Honey and
Rye meal, and a little juice of wild Nep, called Bryony, and use it to
cleanse and heal it fast. Kanker, sees Sloe thorn bark in water, till it be
thick and black, and put Honey to it, and temper it with Rye flower, and apply
it. Black Iaundies, (See Celondine.) 10 Strangury, anoint thy yard with
Populeon, and apply Rye meal on the yard. 11 The meal is good with other
medicines for bruises. 12 Dropsy, bake cakes of Rye meal, and the juice of
Lilly roots, and bake them under a bake-pan of earth, and apply them hot to
the belly one after another: or take sage and Rye meal of each like much, mix
them finely with a little salt, and bake them finely together, and cut it into
gobbits, and put it into a pot of ale, and drink the ale, and eat the cake,
especially first and last. 13 Gout of hot cause, apply Rye meal with vinegar.
Fistula, use Rye meal with other medicines. 14 Gout, apply Rye meal with oil
of Roses. 15 Sciatica, apply Rye flower with vinegar: if it be the hot gout,
the pain will mitigate, or else it is the cold gout. 16 Skabs, mix the juice
of smallach with Rye meal, sewet, wax and brimstone, and anoint, and the
third day bath thee. 17 Wounds ache, mix the juice of smallach with Honey,
swines grease and Rye meal, and apply it. 18 Belly grinding, bake a cake of
Rye flower well sowred, and heat the inside of it being cut through the midst,
and anoint it with Honey, and cast thereon powder of Cummin, and apply it as
hot as may be suffered, and as often as need is. 19 Cods swollen, boil Rye
flower with the juice of wall wurt, Honey and vinegar till it be thick, and
apply it. 20 Gout in the bones, make tostes of Rye bread, steep them in
vinegar, and after in Honey, and apply it iii. days, and lay on it a wurt
leaf. 21 Kanker and fester, burn a dogs head to powder, and mix it with Rye
meal, the juice of Louage and Honey, and apply it with tents of linen till it
be whole. 22 Fester, burn Hemp seed and Rye to powder, and mix it with Honey
and the juice of smallach, and apply it: or kneade a cake of Rye flower with
Honey, and bake it hard, and apply it till it wax nesh, and then apply new as
often as need is.

Ribwurt.
RIbwurt, (See Planten.) Fever quarten, drink the juice two hours before the
fit. 2 Dropsy, use it sodden. 3 Matrixe flux, drink it, or use it in
Pessaries. 4 Fever tertian, drink the juice two hours before the fit. 5 Fever
quarten, drink the juice with warm water and Honey. 6 Swellings general,
stamp it when it is new gathered, with clear grease, and apply it. 7 Burnings
and wild fire, stamp it and apply it. 8 Flux great, sees it in vinegar, and
drink it. 9 Fester cold, make a cake of Rye flower, whites of eggs, and juice
of Ribwurt, and apply thereof often. Bursten (See in Bursa pastoris.) 10 Kanker,
mix it with Honey and Rye meal, and apply it warm, and likewise to ye marmol.
11 Palsy universal, drink the juice. 12 Wounds of all sorts, new or old, use
the juice or powder of it. 13 Speech lost, use to drink it.

Burnings 7 Bursten 9 Dropsy 2 Fester cold 9 Fever quarten 1. 5 tertian 4
Flux great 8 Kanker 10 Matrixe Flux 3 Palsy 11 Speech lost 13 Swellings 6
Wild fire 7 Wounds general 12
Rocket.
ROcket is a good sallat herb to be eaten with Letuse, Purslen and other like
cold herbs, and so they will not hurt the stomach with their coldness: but
eaten alone, it heateth too much, and causes headache. 2 The use thereof
moves venus, especially the seed: also it provoke vrin, and causes
digestion. 3 The seed is good against venomous bitings, and applied with Honey,
it takes away lentils, freckles, and other deformities of the face. 4 And with
the gaul of an ox, it takes away blewe marks and skarres. 5 He that takes
the seeds before he be beaten or whipped, shall be so hardened, that he shall
easily endure the pain. 6 The root boiled in water and applied, draws
forth shords, splinters, and broken bones. 7 The seed drives all kind of
little worms out of the body. 8 With vinegar, it takes away faint spots and
freckles. 9 With Honey it heals all the deformities of the face. 10 The seed
may be used for mustard seed. Pricks, stamp the seeds, and apply it. 11 For
grief coming of Ruptures, fractures or vnplacing of joints, boil the roots
it water and stamp them, and apply them. 12 Black spots or bruises, grind
the seeds with an ox gaul, of each like much, and apply it or anoint. 13
Rocket provoke vrin, and causes lust. 14 With oil and Honey, it cleanses
the skin. 15 The juice drunk, helps the cough.

Ach 11 Bitings venomous 3 Bones broken 6. 11 Bruise 4. 5. 12 Cough 15
Digestion 2 Face deform. 4. 8. 14 Freckles 4. 8. 14 Joints out 11 Lust to cause
2. 13 Pricks 6. 10 Skin deformd 14 Urine stopped 2. 13
Ros solis.
ROs solis: Bruise it with salt, and apply it on the bare skin, to make
blisters and holes, even as Cantarides does. 2 The distilled water of it, is
singular good against consumptions, straitness of breath, vlcerations of the
Lungs. 3 If it be put into a glass wherein is poison, it will make it fly
out, or make the glass fly in pieces, and being heated in a cup of wine with
poison, it will make it fly out. Carry it about thee, to be free from the
danger of thine enemies, and to have them kind and friendly to thee, and to
withstand witchcraft. 4 Apply it to a woman's belly, to cause speedy
deliverance, though the child be dead and rotten. 5 And being carried and also
eaten of every day, it preserves from the falling evil. 6 Drink the juice
thereof against the Apoplexia and drawing of ye mouth awry, to have speedy
help. 7 Hang it about the neck of them that be demoniak. 8 Hold it to the
mouth, to staunch bleeding at the nose. 9 Drink the juice with wine to avoid
weariness by travel, and to heal wounds, drink it in wine or ale ten days,
and also wash the wounds therewith, and apply it with a cloth dipped therein. 10
Apply it to the aching teeth to help them. 11 To make Rosa solis, Take aqua
vite one pint, the flowers of Roses solis, one gallon, a piece of Angel gold,
Rosemary flowers, or the herb it self, and a quantity of fine sugar: distill
them in a stillatory, and take thereof one spoonefull at once by it self.

Apoplexia 6 Blister to make 1 Breath streit 2 Consumption 2 Dead child 4
Deliverance 4 Demoniak 7 Distilling 11 Enemies 3 Falling evil 5 Lungs griefs 2
Mad 7 Mouth awrye 6 Nose bleeding 8 Poison 3 Teeth ach 10 Weariness 9
Witchcraft 3 Wounds 9
Rose.
ROse: Red Roses must be clipped off, when they be not full ripe, and dried in
the son: Rosed Honey eaten, does comfort the blood and the stomach. 2 The
juice sodden with wine, takes away the pain of the head, and helps the eyes
and the gums, being washed therewith, and the toothach. 3 Bruise the leaves, and
apply them to draw out the heat. 4 Rub the gummes and teeth with powder of
the seeds, to help the tooth ach. 5 Sees the heads wherein the seeds he,
and drink the broth, to loosen the belly, and for spitting blood. 6 Mix Roses
with sugar and Honey, and eat it to dry up the evil humors of the stomach. 7
Seethe the leaves in wine, and drink it for the griefs of the Matrixe and
privy parts. 8 The fresh new leaves with Honey, do aptly purge the body. 9 A
special laxatiue: Take the juice of Roses two ounces, mix it with whey of
Cowes milk and a little spikenard: or take syrope of Roses made of fresh
Roses, to purge the belly. 10 The Rose leaves wrought together with sugar and
Honey, does both comfort and purge the belly. 11 Steep Rose leaves one night in
vinegar, and anoint hot members and places therewith, and also apply it to a
hot stomach, to qualify the burning heat of it. 12 Drink the juice of
Roses with sweet conduit water, to loosen the body, to purge the blood,
especially from choler, and to put away the kings evil. 13 Roses do comfort
the heart, and rejoice the blood. 14 The Rosed Honey does both comfort and
expel melancholy and flegmatike matter, and taken with water wherein Fennel
seeds have been sodden, and a little salt put thereto, does purge the better.
15 Clip the Rose leaves from the whites, and boil them in oil of Olives, and
sun it in a glass fifty days: and this is the best oil. 16 Apply thereof
to the liver, to help the heat thereof, and the temples for the ach and
beating pain of the head, and to cool it. 17 Use Rose leaves in meat, for
the heat of the stomach and liver. 18 Mix powder of Roses with vinegar and
the white of an egg, and apply it to ye temples, to take away the pain of the
eyes, to restrain ye humors and the shedding of blood into the veins of the
eyes. 19 Sugar Roset is good for ye bloody flux, the cholerike vomitings, the
faintness of the body, and the cardiak passion. 20 Gather the deaw that
fallethon Rose leaves, and drop it on the nether lid of the eye, to amend the
blearednesse. 21 Boil dry Rose leaves in wine and drink it to amend the
pain of the head, eyes, ears, and gums: and take the same in a glister, to
amend the corruption of the bowels and matrixe. 22 Water of red Roses drunk,
does strengthen and cool the brain, heart, stomach and all inward parts, it
strengthens the spirits and natural heat, and preserves from rottenness.
23 To cleanse, dry and strengthen the sight of eyes, Take red Rose water one
ounce, white wine a little, tutia one dram, aloes epatica and sugar candy, of
each twenty grains: mix them together, and drop it into the eyes. 24 Drop Rose
water with a little sugar into the eyes, for the exulceration of them, coming
of heat. 25 Drink three ounces of the water fasting, to comfort the head. 26
Mix it with wine, and drink six ounces, to take away the giddiness of the
head, and to strengthen the liver. 27 Smell to Rose water in time of the
frenzy, to provoke sleep. 28 The juice or infusion of the reddest Roses, or
the decoction of them looseneth the belly gently without danger, and purges
choler, and opens the stopping of the liver, and strengthens it, and is
good for hot fevers and the Iaundies, the shaking, beating and trembling of
the heart, discharging all evil corrupt humors in and about the veins of the
heart, and is good to be laid to the inflammation of the eyes and all other
hot infirmities, especially S. Anthonies fire, or wild fire. 29 Stamp Roses
small, and apply them to hot inflammations and swellings of the Paps and
outrageous heat of the midrife and stomach, and also the shingles, S.
Anthonies fire and Tetter. 30 Boil dried Roses in wine, and drink it for the
pain of the eyes, ears, and head, hawes, gummes, bladder, right gut and
mother, either powered in by Glister, or anointed. 31 The yelow in the midst of
the Rose, stops the superfluous course of the flowers, and all other issues
of blood, but especially the whites. 32 The fruit eaten, stops the laske
and all other issues of blood. 33 The wild Rose punned with Bores grease, is
very excellent good for the Alopetias or red skall, or falling of the hair. 34
The rough spongious ball of the wild Rose bush, is of great virtue against the
stone and strangury, bringing forth gravel and provoking urine. 35 Anoint the
head with oil of Roses and vinegar, for the frenzy. 36 Drink the hard seeds
that are in the heads of Roses made into powder, with wine, to break the
stone. 37 The red fruit of Roses with all his substance, stamped, streined, and
dried, and made into powder, is excellent good for the running of the reins,
and for the flowers both white and red, and so do the red heads taken before
they be ripe or wax soft, being kept dry and sodden in wine and drunk,
which also heals the bloody flux and spitting of blood excellently well
being well streined. 38 Take i. ounce of the juice of Roses, with two or three
ounces of whey, and a little spikenard, to purge the body: or steep the Rose
leaves in whey, and press it out with Honey, to purge without any grief. 39
The syrope of the juice of Roses, and of Roses themselves, does also purge
gently. 40 The water wherein Roses have been steeped, cleanses, skowreth and
purges. 41 Roses condited with Honey, scowre, purge, and strengthen: but
condited with sugar, they skowre less: but strengthen more. 42 Vinegar of
Roses staunch all inflammations and hot burnings, and cutteth and skowreth,
and strengthens. 43 Roses, especially fresh, can abide no seething, for then
their purging virtue is taken away by the fire. 44 The juice by seething
measurably, is made more fine, and skowreth more mightily. 45 The juice of
Roses is given from one ounce to two ounces. 46 Seethe dried Roses in wine, and
wash the head therewith for the headache, and likewise the eyes and ears for
their pain. 47 Use the oil in lynaments to cool hot burning ulcers and
inflammations, and to any stripe or bruise. 48 Vnguentum Rosarum extinguisheth
the heat of the back and reins, and procures sleep. 49 Few cordials can
want the help of Roses, or Rose water. 50 The little yelowe tufts within the
Roses in powder, stauncheth blood, kill worms, and the kanker in the mouth,
and Polyp in the Nose. 51 The dried leaves of red Roses sodden in wine and
applied, is good for the head ach, and for the ach of the ears, eyes, gummes,
fundament and matrixe, being used warm, they help all inflammations of the
intrals, the griefs of the stomach, and the holy fire: and so does the
vinegar and oil of Roses. 52 The oil is excellent good in the plague time
against the burning Pushes. 53 The water, oil, or vinegar, are good against
all hot and cholerike griefs and for headache, etc. 54 The Rose is chief of
all flowers. 55 Roses shreaded small and sodden in clarified Honey, does
comfort, cleanse and dissolve, and digest flegmatike and thick humors, and
with cold water it stops, and with hot water saxeth. 56 Sugar and Roses
incorporated together, does comfort, bind, helps the bloody flixe, swooning,
cholerike vomiting, and the Cardiake passion. 57 Oil of Roses helps the
heat of the Liver, headache, hot fierce agewes, and causes sleep. 58 Rose
water takes away webs and foul specks of the face, and makes the skin
subtle and thin. 59 The decoction of dried Roses in rain water, stops
all fluxes that come of cold causes. 60 Their powder stops bleeding at the
Nose, and is good for the gummes and loose teeth. 61 Their powder with Saffron
and the white of an egg, heals the sore ach of the eyes, and stops the
humor of blood that runs into the veins of the eyes and the swelling and
falling down of the matrixe. 62 The conserve of Roses does cool and comfort
the principal parts of the body, as the head, heart, stomach, liver, milt and
reins, and is thus made: Take the buds of red Roses before they be ready to
spread, cut away the white part, stamp them small in a stone mortar, with a
wooden pestell, and put thereto thrice so much sugar by little and little, and
keep it in a close gally pot, and set it in the son for a season, and so do
al other conserues. 63 The water of the said leaves drunk by it self, or with
sugar, or with wine, is good for all the aforesaid purposes. 64 The best way of
distilling of Roses or any other thing, is in a stillatory of glass set over a
pot of boiling water, which is called Balneum Mariae: for those that be
distilled in metal, have some smatch of the metal, and are not so wholesome.
65 The juice of Roses is kept in a glass, with oil powered on it, and when it
shall be occupied, the oil is to be taken away with bombase or cotton dipped in
it, it loosneth the belly, comfort and strengthens the stomach, and
cools the liver. 66 Steep Rose cakes in wine warm, and apply them to
mitigate any ach. 67 Roses dried in the sun a little, may be kept three
years. For madness and heat of the head, stamp Housleeke and Roses with
woman's milk, and apply it to the forehead and temples. 68 Hicket and heat,
eat sugar of Roses. 69 Faintness and heat in the night, dip a cloth in Rose
water, and half as much vinegar, and hold it in thy hands, and apply it to thy
wrists and soles of thy feet. 70 Eyes hot, wash them with Rose water. 71 Eyes
bloody, sees Roses in water, and wash therewith. 72 Eyes swollen, sees
Frankincense and Roses in white wine, and wash therewith often. 73 Gout, apply
Rose water with linen clothes. 74 Nose bleeding, apply Rose water all about
thy head and neck with linen clothes cold. 75 Prick to draw out, stamp the
root of red Rose tree, and apply it with linen cloth. 76 Frenzy, (See
Camomile.) 77 Head ach, stamp a piece of a Rose cake with oil, and heat it
on a tyle, and apply it to the nape of the neck, to bedward. 78 Stomach
fevers, and all hot evils therein, use conserve of Roses. 79 Heart weak,
drink Rose water with sugar, and powder of pearl three or four days: or
drink the water only, and cast thereof in thy face. 80 Swooning, take powder
of Roses with a rear Eg. 81 Consumption, make a confection with the flowers of
Borage and Roses, with Aromaticall spices, and use it. 82 Swooning, sees
Basell in Rose Water and drink it, (See Rosemary.) 83 Eyes bruised and rupture
of the tunicles, seethe red Roses in water, and apply them. 84 Matrix with
congealed blood, seethe red Roses in red wine in summer, but in winter take the
roots of the tree, and seethe it in water with Bursa Pastoris, and apply it
often hot in a cloth. 85 Put young buds of Roses when they begin to open into
a reed as it grows, and let it grow still, and so the Roses may be kept
till you need to occupy them, and then take it out, and put it into lukewarm
water, and it will be fresh as in May. 86 Flowers to stop, mix honey with red
Rose leaves, the juice of Planten and wheat flower, and apply it plasterwise
to the shares. 87 Eyes inflamed, beat the white of an Egg with Rose Water and
use it. 88 Syrup of Roses, take Rose Water three pintes, Sugar, two pound,
boil them with a gentle fire till it rope, and keep it in a glass with some
Sallet oil powered on it. It slaketh thirst and drought in hot fevers, and
comforeth the heart, stomach and liver, and suffers no corruption to remain
in the heart. 89 For a wind or chollike in the belly, toste a Rose-cake at the
fire, and sprinckle it with vinegar, and apply it as hot as may be suffered.
90 Sleep to cause, mix oil of Roses and Rose Water of each one ounce in red
vinegar half an ounce, and anoint therewith and apply it. 91 Headache, anoint
with the juice of Roses and honey of each like much. 92 Belly loose, boil
Rose Water with Cloves and Masticke in a double vessel, and drink thereof, or
use powder of Roses. 93 Fever ephemera, drink new Rose Water, and anoint the
pulses with oil of Roses. 94 Ache, or bruise or swelling, mix crummes of
sour bread with vinegar and Rose leaves, and apply it to heal it. 95
Backe-ache and heat, steep red Sanders and Rose-leaues in Rose Water one
night, and wash therewith. 96 To keep Roses all the year, gather them with a
knife at even, when they are half blown, and set them in the air abroad all
night, and in the morning put them into a earthen vessel well leaded, and stop
it well, and cover it with dry sand, or put them into a reed as it grows.
97 Vnguentum Rosarum, take oil of Roses iiii. ounces, white wax one ounce,
melt them together over seething water, and chafe them well together with Rose
water and a little white vinegar, and use it. 98 Stamp Roses with Rue and
bitter Almonds with vinegar, and rub the headache therewith that comes of
too much drinking. 99 Tetters, wash in the mornings with Parsley water, and at
night with Rose water. 100 Matrix sores or rent, stamp dried Rose leaves, and
wash them with wine, and anoint a suppositorie therewith made of hares hairs,
and put it in, and wash it with a sharp lotion. 101 Bruses and cuts about the
eyes, mix powder of saffron half a dram, with oil of Roses one ounce, and
the yolke of an Eg, and apply it. 102 Fundament chops, mix oil of Roses with
Vermilion, and anoint. 103 Nostrels stink, boil Roses with honey in wine, and
put them in. 104 Drink oil of Roses to moysten the belly, and cool the heat
of the stomach. 105 Apply Rose oil with vinegar to all hot aches of the
head, or else where, and to all outward heates. 106 Drop the oil into the ear
for the ache and hot apostumes thereof. 107 Drink Rose oil with Rose Water
to cure the bloody flux. 108 Apply to all outward wounds, apostumes and
heates. (See Cetony.) 109 Wounds to heal, wash them well, and put in the oil
hot as may be suffered morn and even iiii. days, and when it is well
cleansed, apply a plaster of Melrosate, to heal it up, (See Celondine.) 110
Digestion to cause, seethe a Rose cake in vergis, and apply it to the stomach
in a bag of linen. 111 Flux white, sees red Roses in water, and wash the belly
therewith. (See Frankincense, Lettuse.) 112 Tongue wheales or bladders, sees
Roses and Violets in Rose water, and wash therewith. 113 Whelks white or red,
anoint them with oil of Roses. 114 Face pimpled, anoint with Rose Water. 115 Head
ache, mix Rose Water, vinegar, and the gleire of an eg of each like much, and
apply it with flax herds. Rose Water comforts and restreineth flux and
vomit. 116 Sees it with cloves and mastike, and use it against fluxes and
feeblenes of virtue. 117 Rose Water is good for swooning and the cardiacke
passion, for sore eyes and ointments for ye face, and takes away ye wens and
superfluities. 118 Dry Roses smelled unto, comfort the brain and the heart.
For chollerike fluxes, seethe them in rain water, and drink it, or apply a
plaster of powder of Roses, vinegar, and the white of an Eg to the pit of the
stomach. 119 Swooning, drink water that Roses have been sodden in. Or take
the powder of Roses with a rere egg. 120 To make oil of Roses, sees 2. li.
of oil with 1. li. and a half of Roses in a double vessel till the third
part be wasted, and streine it and use it. Some put Rose water in a glass,
and put Roses thereto with their dew, and boil them in a double vessel, and
son it, and this is the best way. 121 Head scaulde mix oil of Roses Linseed
and Olives of each like much, with powder of Lytarge, and apply it. 122 Face
salsflegme, eat powder of red Roses or drink the water thereof. 123 Swellings
of great heat, beat the white and yolke of an egg (the strening put out)
with oil of Roses, and apply it with flax hards. 124 Oil of Roses, gather
the brodest Roses in the morning before the dew be off of them 1. pound, clip
them small, and put thereto one pound of the greenest oil Olive in a glass
fast stopped with lether, and hang it in the Sun ten or twelve days, then
streine it and let it rest 24. hours, then power out the water, and put the
oil in a glass, and every ninth day stir it in the morning. But if you
would make it cold, then hang it in water so long as it should have been
sunned. 125 The yellowe in the midst of Roses stops the whites. 126 Piles,
anoint with oil of Roses and frankincence. But if it be for a Lord, put myrre
thereto, anoint therewith to heal it easily. 127 Sugar rosat, dissolve sugar
in Rose Water, and sees it well and cast it on a marble stone till it be cold
and hard, then cut it in great pieces and keep it. The like may be done with
Violets, Borage, Buglosse, Rosemary flowers, etc. 128 To take away heat of the
face, beat the whites of 2. eggs, two spoones full of sallet oil, and two
spoones full of Rose water together, and anoint therewith. 129 Eyes dull, put
in water of Rue and of Roses. 130 Iulep of Roses, take Rose water 3. pound,
sugar sodden and clarified 2. pound, boil them with a soft fire. It quenches
thirst in hot fevers, and the heat of the heart and liver, it resists
corruption of ill humors, and preserves health. 131 Conserve of Roses, stamp
them with thrice so much sugar. It comfort ye stomach, heart and al
principal parts. It mollifieth those parts that be hard, and purges
melancholy. 132 Mel Rosarum, sees the juice of Roses with as much honey. It
comforts the stomach, and does digest and purge phlegm in the stomach or
veins. 133 Manus Christi, melt sugar in Rose water half a pound, sees it til
a sugar be hard, then put in powder of pearls or precious stones, and lay it
on a marble anointed with oil of Roses or of Violets, or Rose Water, and use
it. 134 Vnguentum Galeni, take white wax one pound, oil of Roses three pound,
melt them together, and wash it well and often in cold water till it be white,
but rather with vinegar which is better. 13 Mell Rosarum is made of seven pound
of honey, and one pound of Roses boiled meanly together, till it have a sweet
odor and red color: it does comfort and cleanse, and may be given in summer
or winter after it is three days old: for cold humors, take it with water
that Fenell seed and three grains of Mastike have been sodden in. 136 Sugar
Rosat, stamp one pound of new gathered Roses with four pound of Sugar, and
sun it in a glass thirty days, it may be kept three years. 137 Flux to
stop, eat one dram of Sugar Rosat with as much Mastike, and then drink
Rose Water sodden with Mastike and Cloves. 138 Oil of Roses, fill a glass
with oil and Roses, and boil it in a vessel of water, or stamp ye Roses,
and sun it with the oil four days: it helps the chafing of the liver and
hot ache of the head, there must be two pound of Roses, and three pound of
oil. 139 Vinegar of Roses, gather them before they be full blown in dry
weather, lay them on a boarde half a day, then put them into vinegar close
stopped 24. hours, then stamp them and set them in glasses in the sun all
summer, then streine it and use it: if it be renewed with Roses every tenth day
it is the better, it may be made with wine either white, red, or claret. So
make vinegar of Eldren flowers or Violets. 140 Conserve of Roses or other
flowers, gather them before they spread, cut the red part from the white,
grind ye red in a stone mortar, with a wooden pestell with thrice the weight
of sugar, keep it close stopped, it comfort the stomach, heart, and all the
bowels, and is good against black choler and melancholy. 141 Conserve of
white Roses does loosen the belly more then red: do so with all conserues of
flowers.
