Rose-campian.
ROse-campian: the seed with the flower, or either of them drunk, are good
against the stinking of scorpions. 2 The seed, flowers, and whole herb of
wild Campians both red and white, are very good to the same effect. 3 Drink
two drams of the seed to purge down hot chollerike humors.

Biting venom. 1. 2 Purgation 3 Stinging 1. 2
Rubarbe.
RVbarbe: the root is good against the windiness, wambling, and weakness of
the stomach, and all pain thereof, and it is good against crampes, the
griefs of the liver and milt, gnawing and griping of the belly, kidneis, and
bladder, the ache of the breasts and mother, the sciatica, spitting of blood,
sobbing, hickit, the blooddy-fluxe and laske, the fittes of Fevers, all
stingings and venomous bitings, one dram, taken in a Fever with Hydromell for
the same purposes: and with Syrupus Acetosus, against the griefs of the liver
and milt. 2 With honied wine against the griefs of the breast. 3 And dry
without moisture, for the weakness and looseness of the stomach. 4 Rubarbe
may be taken to purge one dram with wheye, or any cooling drink or potion to
help hot Fevers, obstructions of the liver and milt, the Iaundies, all issues
of blood, inward burstings and bruises, crampes, and shrinkings of the synowes.
5 Being tosted and dried at the fire, and drunk with the juice of Planten or
thick red wine, it cures the bloody-fluxe and all laskes. 6 Eat one scruple
of Rubarbe tosted at the fire fasting every morning, against spitting of blood.
7 Rubarbe purges choler and phlegm from the stomach and liver, cleanses the
blood, takes away obstructions and griefs coming thereof, as the Iaundies,
the Dropsy, swelling of the milt, rotten Fevers, and pritching in the sides. 8
The oil of Rubarbe is good for bruises, and ache, and shrinking of the
synowes. 9 Rubarbe may be preserved in good Honey, or in Fleawoort, or in
Turpentine and Wax, or in Wax alone, or in Millit, or Hyrsse, or in Flax
seed. 10 It may be taken with the pap of an Apple or Warden. It helps the
Dropsy and Tympanie. 11 Flux red, mix Rubarbe and Sumache with the juice of
Planten, and drink it. 12 Bloody-fluxe, eat every morning half a dram of
tosted Rubarbe. 13 Take Rubarbe with as much Scamony with Ale or white Wine to
purge the body. 14 Liver corrupt, stamp Liuerwoort, and seethe it in good
strong Ale with some Rubarbe, and use to drink thereof. 15 Life and health to
preserve, use to eat Rubarbe daily.

Ache 8 Backach 1 Bellyach 1. loose 3. bound 4. 7. 13. Bitings venomous 1
Bladder griefs 1 Blood to cleanse 7 Bloody flux 4. 5. 11. 12 Breast griefs 2
Breast ach 1 Bruise 4. 8 Bursten 4 Cholicke 7 Choler 7 Crampe 4 Dropsy 10
Fevers 1 Phlegm 7 Flowers to stop 4 Fluxes 1. 5. 11. 12 Health 15 Hicket 1
Iaundies 4. 7 Liver griefs 1. 4. 7. 14 Milt griefs 1. 4. 7 Mother griefs 1
Obstruct. 4. 7 Preservative 15 Purgation 4. 7. 13 Sinowes shronke 4. 8 Sciatica
1 Sickness genesis 1. 15 Side griefs 7 Spitting blood 1. 6 Stinging 1 Stomach
griefs 1. 3. 7 Timpanie 10
Rue.
RVe or herbegrace, both the leaves and seeds serve in medicine. The seeds
are gotten in harvest, and may be kept five years, the dried leaves may be
kept one year. 2 Eat of the herb to mend the sight, and to put away wind,
but it dulleth the veneriall act. 3 Eat the leaves with dry figs and walnuts,
as the surest remedy against deadly poison, if it be taken in time: or take
Rue one ounce, Figs half an ounce, Juniper berries half an ounce, Walnuts two
ounces, Vinegar four ounces, mix them all together, and swallow down a
little fasting, to be free from poison and pestilent air that day. 4
Belching, sees Rue in vinegar and drink it. 5 Sees Rue with figs in wine, to
the one half, and drink it: it does mightily help the dropsy, the pains
of the breasts, sides and loins, the Cough and griefs of the lungs, liver and
kidneis, so that thou have no ague. 6 Sees Rue in oil, and take it in a
glister against the pain of the matrix and fundament. 7 Stamp Rue with oil,
and apply it to the fundament or matrix against the strangling thereof, and the
swelling of the great gut. 8 Seethe Rue, Hysope, and Aniseedes in wine, and
drink it, and also foment therewith the grieved place to put away gripings. 9
Stamp it with oil and apply it to the navel to kill worms, 10 Eat it after
Garlike and Onions, to put away their smell. 11 Seethe it in oil, and anoint
the body therewith before the coming of the fit, or else take it in
glisterwayes to avoid the ague, and put thereof into the ears to kill the
worms therein. 12 Sees it with Myrrh in wine, and drink it to put away the
water between the skin and the flesh. 13 Mix the juice with oil of Roses
and vinegar, and anoint the head therewith for the beating pain thereof. 14
Seethe it in Fumiterie water, and give it children to drink for the small
pockes. 15 If children having the measels be not already blinded with them,
hang the root of Rue and Scabious about their necks to defend them. 16 Mix
Rue with oil of Roses, vinegar, and ceruse into an ointment to heal all
skabs, holy fire, running sores, and hot blisters. 17 Apply Rue with Garlike,
Salt, and Walnuts to the biting of a mad dog, or adder, to heal it. 18 Eyes
dull, steep it in thy wine, or other drink. 19 Mix Rue with Rose Water, and
apply it to bleare and bloodshotten eyes, to cleanse and heal them
merueilously. 20 Teeth-ache, seethe it in wine, and apply it, or burn the
stalk a little, and put it into the hollow tooth. 21 Stomach cold, and for
the palsy, seethe it with Castory, and drink it. 22 For stopping of the liver
and milt, and streitnesse in making water, seethe Rue and Fenell roots in
wine, and drink it, or powder of Fenell roots with the juice of Rue. 23
Bloody flux, and straitnes of urine, seethe it in wine and oil, and apply it
to the root of the yard. 24 Teeming women may not eat Rue for hindering
their conception. 25 Anoint thee with the juice of Rue, and carry the herb
about thee, and no venomous thing shall bite or sting thee. 26 Plant Rue near
Sage, and Todes will not sit under the Sage, where they delight to be. 27
Sprinckle water with Rue about the house to expel flies and gnats. 28 Sprinckle
Pultrie with the juice, and the Wesels and such like vermin will not come at
them. 29 Weed not Rue with bare hands while the dew is on it, for it causes
dangerous blisters and sores, itche, and swelling, the remedy is to anoint
them with Salet oil, or the juice of Hemlocke to heal them in short time. 30
Rue eaten green, quenches lust in men, and provoke lust in women, and
sharpeneth the sight and wit. 31 The water of the decoction thereof kills
fleaes being sprinkled. 32 Eat Rue and figs with sweet Almonds in the
morning to withstand poison. 33 Eat two dry Walnuts, ii. figs, i. grain of
salt, and xx. leaves of Rue to preserve thee both from poison and pestilence.
34 Seethe Rue and Dill seed in wine, and drink it against the torments of ye
intrals: the water does the like, and so does the oil thereof in glisters. 35
Sees it in rain water, and drink it to stop the white flux. 36 Sees it
with oil, and drink it to kill worms. 37 Sees Rue and figs in wine, and
drink thereof, and also anoint therewith for the dropsy. 38 Stamp Rue with
Bay leaves, and apply it to the swollen priuities both of men and women. 39 Put
the juice into the ears to cease their ache. Mix the juice with alome, salt
peter and honey, and anoint all breaking out, whelkes, pushes, scabs, and
tumors. 40 Anoint the head with oil of the seeds of Rue, to cause a good
memory when it is weakened by humiditie or cold. 41 Seethe Rue with dried
Dyll, and drink it for the gnawing in the belly, the ache in the sides and
breast, pursinesse and shortness of breath, coughes, inflammations of the
lungs, the sciatica, and pain of the joints, and cold that comes by fittes
and courses. 42 Stamp it with honey, and put it up a good way into the matrixe
against the suffocation of the mother. 43 Apply it with honey to aches, and with
Figs to the dropsy, and also drink it for the same, or seethe it in wine to
the one half, and rub it on for the same purpose. 44 With flower of parched
Barley, it swageth the ache of the eyes, with Rose oil and vinegar it helps
headache. 45 Bruise it, and put it into the nose against the bursting out of
blood there. 46 Rub the white morphue with Rue, Salt, Niter, Wine and Pepper to
heal it. 47 Apply it with Honey and Alome to heal the skuruie evil. 48 Heat
the juice in the rind of a Pomegranate, and power it into the ears for their
ache. 49 With the juice of Fenell and honey, it helps dull hearing. 50 Apply
it with vinegar, Rose oil, and white-lead, to hot chollerike running sores,
and inflammations, tetters and running sores to heal them, and running sores
in the head. 51 Drink ye parched seeds of Rue vii. days against pissing in
bed to do so no more. 52 Rue is good for ye windy and watery dropsy, for them
yt have drunk Opiu^, or ye poison called Aconitu^, and for ye chollike being
also taken in a glister beneath. 53 Sees it in oil, and bathe ye bladder
therewith against ye stopping of water, being also taken in a glister, and also
drunk. 54 It is good for the Lethargy and forgetfulness, for the gout or
pain of the knees of watrish humors: it strengthens the guts, but it is not
good for the chollerike folks, nor for women with child. 55 Boil it in water
and drink it to provoke urine and terms, and to stop the laske. 56 Stamp it
and eat it, or drink it with wine, against all poison and venomous bitings,
todestooles, mushroomes. The juice is good for the same purpose, and against
bitings or stingings of serpents, scorpions, bees, horners, and waspes, with
wine, or stamp the leaves and apply them. 57 Put the juice with clear honey
into the eyes to clear the sight. 58 Stamp Rue with oil of Roses, and apply
it somewhat thick to the crown of thy head when thou art sick: if thou
sneesest within vi. hours after, thou shall escape, or else not. 59. Take
black soap and aqua vitae, of each one pound, sallet oil half a pound, the
juice of Rue a quarter of a pound, seethe them with a gentle fire, and stir
them till it be somewhat thick, and apply it plasterwise upon lether to the
sciatica, three days and nights, and then apply new if need be, and be
whole. 60 Sees Rue and Rosemary of each two handful with Malmesey and common
oil, of each a quart half an hour, and bathe therewith any lame member,
half an hour every night when thou go to bed three weeks together, and
then lay thereto the woolly side of a lambs skin, and be whole. 61 Put the
juice of Rue and of red Docks into ye nose to cleanse ye brain. 62 Stamp Rue,
red Fenell, and Wormwood, and streine them with small white wine, and drop it
into the eyes when thou go to bed to expel the superfluous blood, and to
clear them. 63 Put the juice of Rue with aqua vitae into thy ear, and bind
thy head hard with a cloth, and lie down with that ear to take away the
pain, and to draw out the humor that causes the pain. 64 Chewe Rue, and put
it into hollow teethe to take away their pain. 65 Let women drink ye juice
of Rue with wine to purge them after their deliverance and to expel the
secondines, the dead child, and unnatural birth. 66 Rue eaten a certain
space, dries up natural seed in man, and the milk of women's breasts. 67
Rue boiled in wine to the one half and drunk, is good for such as are falling
into the dropsy. 68 Eat it raw, or candited otherwise with salt or in
meats, to clear and sharpen the sight, so does the juice put into the eyes
with honey, and the juice of Fenell, or by it self. 69 The leaves stamped with
Barlye meal, swageth the pain of the eyes. 70 Mix the juice with oil of
Roses, or of Bays, and honey, and use it against the sounding or noise in the
ear, being dropped in warm. 71 Stamp the leaves with oil of Roses and
vinegar, and apply it to the headache. 72 Stamp it with Baye leaves to cure
the swelling of the genitors. 73 Mix Rue with Pepper, Niter, and wine, to
void all spots of the face and skin. 74 Mix it with Honey and Alome to
cure the foul skab and tetter. 75 Stamp the leaves with swines grease, to
cure the ruggedness of the skin, the skurfe of the head, the Kings evil, or
hard swellings about the throat. 76 Mix Rue with honey to mitigate the pains
of the joints, and with Figs to void the swelling of the dropsy. 77 Smell to
the juice with vinegar to quicken thee in the Lethargy and drowsiness. 78
Mix powder of the root with honey, to dissolve congealed blood and black
bruises, being well rubbed therewith. 79 Sees Rue in oil, or else steep it
long therein, and use it to warm and chafe all cold members being anointed
therewith. 80 And anoint the region of the bladder to provoke urine, 81 And the
swelling and hardness of the spleen being anointed therewith. 82 And in
glisters it drives out windy gripings of the guts. 83 Stamp the leaves and
apply them outwardly to the nose, to staunche the bleeding of it. 84 Mix
powder of the seeds with fresh clarified butter and pitche melted together,
and drink it for inward bruises. 85 Make powder of the seeds and of long
Pepper, and sweet Calamus, and seethe it in white wine, and drink it warm
for the wind in the small guts. 86 Set Rue in the midst of September.
Backe-ache, stamp Rue, Wormwood, and Sage, ana one handful with Barowes
grease, and frye it and apply it, or strain it and anoint. 87 Belly griping,
drink the decoction of it. 88 Chollike, boil Rue in Oil or Butter, and
receive it in by glister, or eat Rue often, or use the decoction thereof,
especially with some Camamile. 89 To cause deliverance of a dead child, drink
Betony, Rue, and Hysope in hot water. 90 Ears griefs, put in the juice of
Rue, or punne Eeles blood, with the juice of Rue, and put it in. 91 Falling
evil, put the juice of Rue into his nose, and he will rise straightwayes. 92
Fever quarten, stamp Rue, Sage and Tansy, of each like much with wine, and
drink it morn and even. 93 Gout, stamp Nep, Rue, Amydum, and powder of
Pepper, and Euphorbium, and apply it warm, or stamp one handful of Rue with
a great deal of salt, and put honey or mustard thereto, and stir it well till
it boil, and apply it in a cloth. 94 Headache, stamp Rue with honey and salt,
and apply it, or seethe Rue and Fenell in water, and wash thy head therewith.
95 For the hot evil, drink the juice of Rue with stale ale. 96 Knees swollen,
stamp Rue with honey and salt, and apply it. 97 Lethargy, boil Castory in
water with the juice of Rue and white vinegar, and make it an ointment, and rub
the hinder part of the head well therewith, and fret it well in. 98 For
alienation of the mind or madness, drink the seeds of Rue with vinegar, and
put the juice of Rue into thy nostrels. 99 Nostrels stink, put in the juice of
Rue and Mints, it does also help the brain. 100 Noli me tangere, incorporate
Myrrh with the juice of Rue, and anoint therewith. Palsy, anoint with oil of
Roses, Rue, and vinegar. 101 Reins ache, stamp Rue with salt and honey, and
apply it often. 102 Sciatica, stamp Rue and Nep of each like much, with a
little Amidum, and the yolke of an Eg, and put thereto powder of Pepper, and of
Euphorbium, and apply it. 103 Shingles, mix Rue and mints with oil and
vinegar, and anoint to help it the same day. 104 Speech to cause, put ye juice
of Rue into thy nose. 105 Spiders biting, or crept into the body, drink Rue
with thine own urine, it helps all stingings of serpents. 106 Stomach
griefs, drink the juice of Rue and Sage twice a day. 107 Knees ache and
swelling, apply Rue and Mints with salt often. 108 Venom or poison, drink the
juice of Rue. 109 Worms, drink Laurel, Rue, and Stonecrop with Ale or Wine.
110 Hickit, drink the seeds of Rue. 111 Eeares deaf, seethe Rue in vinegar,
and receive up the fume thereof. 112 Pockes and Measels in children, seethe
Fumiterie and Rue in water and drink it. Eyes dull, drink ye juice of Rue.
113 Teeth hollow, chewe Rue and fill them with it. 114 Hands worms, anoint
with ye juice of Rue. 115 Breasts hard, sees Rue and wheat, and apply it. For
unkind heat in ye stomach, eat Rue every morning. 116 Belly great, (See
Arsmart.) 117 Sides impost. drink Rue often. 118 Cods swollen, stamp Rue and
Wormwood with honey, and apply it raw, and after wash it with vinegar. 119 Oil
of Rue, cut ye leaves small, and put them in oil 10. or 12. days, then sees
it to ye third part, and streine it and use it. 120 Treacle to make, See
Betony, Selondine, Fenell.) 121 Eyes watring, drop in the juice with honey. 122
Ears dull, boil Rue long in water, and streine it and drop it in, and dip
therein a tent, and cast on it powder of Castory, and Piretrum, and put it in
warm, and lie up therewith 3. or 4. hours, and be whole, or put in the juice
with Eeles grease, or drop in the juice 7. times warm. 123 Speech lost, mix
the juice with powder of Castori Piretrum, black Pepper, and Euphorbium, and
hold little pellits thereof under thy tongue. (See Cummin.) 124 Cough, sees
wormwood two handful, Rue one handful in good wine, and drink it. 125
Reins ach, drink powder of ye seeds with water and honey. 126 Gout pain,
seethe the juice with white honey, then put thereto the white of two Eggs, and
streine it, and anoint therewith. 127 Gout to soften, stamp Rue, red Brier
crops, and Broom flowers, of each like much with Gilts grease, and boil them
well together and streine it, and anoint therewith. 128 For ache and swelling
in the knees, stamp Rue and Louage with honey, and apply it. 129 Skabs
general, anoint with the juice of Rue, Celondine, Centory, and wormwood. 130
Worms, stamp Wormwood, Arsmart, and Rue, and frye them with butter or
grease, and apply them, or drink the juice of Centory, Rue, and Wormwood with
milk. 131 For biting or stinking of an adder, stamp Rue with oil, and apply
it to the wound. 132 Vomit to stop, mix Mastike, Cummin, and Bays with the
juice of Rue, and apply it, (See Garlike.) 133 Cods swollen, stamp Rue and
apply it to have present help. 134 To heal a sore leg, stamp Rue and Sage
very finely with the yolke of an Eg new laid, and as much black soap as ye
yolke, and apply it: proved. 135 Worms crept into the body, drink the juice
of Rue. 136 To be delivered of a dead child, drink water of Rue, with powder
of two Date stones. 137 Belly-ache, eat Rue, Tansie, and Sothernwood with
salt. 138 Belly swollen, drink the juice of Rue with wine or ale: proved. 139
Headache, heat Rue and Sage between two tyles or brickes, and apply it warm
to thy temples, See in Planten, Mints.) 140 Falling evil, use Rue and
Aniseedes in thy meats. If thou would rise quickly, put the juice or
powder of Rue into thy nose. 141 Heart griefs, stamp Rue with Bean flower
and Ginger, and put it into a glass 30. days, and then anoint therewith. 142
Hands itche, anoint with the juice of Rue. 143 Nose stink, put in the juice of
black Mints and Rue into thy nose. 144 Stitche, stamp Rue, Sage, and
Wormwood, of each a handful, seethe them in ale till it be thick, and apply
it hot in bags one after another. 145 Headache of much drinking, stamp Rue
and Roses with vinegar, and bitter Almonds, and anoint therewith, or rub thy
temples therewith, and thy forehead. 146 Head skurfe, seethe a handful of Rue,
and half an ounce of quick Brimstone in good old wine, and wash thy head
therewith, being first washed with lukewarm water, (See Fenell.) 147 Pissing
blood, drink powder of Rue with ale. 148 Stinging, drink Rue with thine own
urine. 149 Lethargy and forgetfulness, (See Mints.) 150 Eyes dasling, use Rue
in broths. 151 Eyes dull, put in the juice with scommed honey, (See Cummin.) 152
Eyes tears, put in the juice with vinegar and honey. 153 Eyes blood, seethe it
in wine to the third part, and drop it in. 154 Teeth-ache, seethe it in wine,
and apply it to the gummes. 155 Nose-bleeding, put in the juice. 156 Squincy
and loss of speech, seethe it in vinegar, and then put thereto light Wheat
Branne, and seethe it to a pulse, and suppe thereof. 157 Plurisie, drink Rue
to heal it quickly. 158 Chollike and Iliake, (See Bay, Cummin.) 159 Tenasmus,
seethe Rue, and apply it. 160 Fundament riftes and sores, stamp the stalks
with ordure of a man, and the yolke of an Egg, and apply it. 161 Mother
suffocate, seethe Rue, and stamp it with Hens grease, and Goose grease, and
apply it to the navel and share, or seethe it and stamp it, and put it in as
a pessarie, or take up the fume thereof. 162 Gout, seethe Rue and Sage with
oil, and stamp it and apply it hot. Or stamp it with Salt and Honey, and
apply it. 163 Sees ix. handful of Rue in sufficient wine, and drink it
before the fittes of any Fever one hour. 164 Apostume to break, stamp Rue
with Nuts, and apply it. 165 Headache, put the juice warm into the nose, or
with as much white wine to purge the head. 166 Eyes dull, use to drink Rue.
167 For stopping of the liver and milt, the strangurie and flux, sees Rue in
wine with Fenell roots, or powder of Rue with the juice of Fenell and drink
it warm. 168 Ache and fretting, stamp Rue with powder of Cummin, and apply
it. 169 Venom, drink the juice. 170 Bitings venomous, stamp it and apply it.
171 Eyes dull, distill it with Roses, and put thereof into the eyes. 172 An
ointment for the eyes, stamp Rue with as much Fenell by weight, and mix them
with Honey and Eyebright, and anoint the eyes therewith. 173 Grind Rue, Cummin,
and Pepper, of each like much by weight with Vinegar and Honey, and use it for
the ache in the breast and in the reins. 174 Headache, seethe Bay leaves and
beries with Rue and Heyhoue in wine and water, and anoint therewith, or with
Rue and vinegar. 175 Breath stinking, drink the juice of Rue with vinegar
morn and even, and put the juice of Rue and black Mints, of each like much
into the nose. 176 Eyes cleansing, stamp Rue and streine it with wine, and
drink it daily, and also use it in meats. 177 Ears dull, put in the clear
juice of Rue. 178 Ache, stamp Rue and as much Louage with honey, and apply it
to void the ache and swelling in the knee or else where. 179 Palsy, boil
Rue, Pellitory, Sage, Cammamile, Mustardseedes, and salt in oil to ye one
half, and anoint therewith, it will restore speech. 180 Dropsy, sees Rue and
Figs in wine and apply it often about the belly. 181 Impost. to break, drink
the juice of Rue and Scabious with powder of Coral a good draught, or drink
the juice of Rue often with wine. 182 Burning and skalking, stamp Rue and apply
it. 183 Venom of all sorts drink ye juice of Rue with thine own urine, or with
fasting spittle and urine. 184 Biting of an adder or dog, drink Dragons, Rue
and Betony. 185 Biting of a man, stamp Rue and garlike with honey, and flower,
and apply it. 186 Worms crept into ye body, drink Arnament and Rue with thine
own urine, or with fasting spittle and urine. 187 Biting of an adder, sees
Rue, Fenel and Betony in butter and drink it. 188 Speaking in sleep, drink ye
seeds of Rue with vinegar, and put ye leaves into thy nose. 189 Biting of a mad
dog, stamp Rue with honey and salt, and apply it. 190 Mad, mix Gentian seed,
and Rue with vinegar, and drink it hot. 191 A sovereign medicine for aches,
bruises or wounds of the legs, stamp Rue, Parsley, and Housleeke, of each like
much, and put thereto good store of whites of eggs, and apply it without
seething. 192 Cough, sees Rue, Centorie and Wormwood with good ale and Honey
to the one half, and streine it and drink it: use some Gentian therewith, if
you can have it. 193 Rue is good for the stomach, it represseth lust, kills
the kanker, and provoke terms. 194 Sees Rue with water, and a fourth part
of vinegar, and drink it for the fretting in the belly. 195 Rue helps the
griefs of the lungs, breasts and ribs, and the sciatica. 196 Drink Rue
against fevers. 197 Worms, sees it in ale, and eat it. 198 Dropsy, sees it
in drink, and anoint with the juice. 199 Sees it with the juice of Fennel,
and as much Honey as Rue, and use it for the dropsy. 200 Headache, mix the
juice with oil of Roses and vinegar, and anoint the forehead therewith. 201
Hicket, stamp Rue, sage and wormwood, of each like much, and sees them with
vinegar and May butter, and apply a plaster thereof to thy breast, and let it
lie four and twenty hours, and do so thrice: if you have no May butter,
take fresh butter without salt. 202 To heal a kanker after it is cleansed,
stamp Rue, and boil it with Honey, and apply it. 203 Headache, stamp Rue and
Iuy, with vinegar and oil Olive, and apply it. 204 Tongue palsy, boil Rue
with powder of mustard seed and salt in oil to the one half, and anoint the
tongue therewith 205 For swelling of the Knee, or hurt with a knife, stamp Rue
with Honey and salt, and apply it till it be whole. 206 Appetite to cause, sees
Rue with vinegar, and drink it. 207 Ears deaf, put in the juice of Rue and
sage. 208 Nose bleeding, put in powder of Rue seeds. 209 Stitch, clarify a
quart of ale, and put thereto sage and Rue, of each half a handful, and boil
them well, then take out the herbs, and make it hot of Pepper, and put
thereto a spoonefull of red saunders, and brew them well together out of one
pot into another, and drink it as hot as may be suffered. 210 Green
sickness, stamp Rue one handful, red sage two hands full, and streine out
the juice, and put it to a pint of hot Honey well clarified, and put thereto a
great spoonefull of gross Pepper, and stir them well together, and give
thereof one spoonefull and a half blood warm, morn and even, and let her
eat four or five times every day six or seven Raisins of the sun at a
time, this will cure it, though it appear not at the first: if the patient
mend not at the end of ten weeks, give her this receipt again. 211 Belly
ach, stamp Rue with stale ale, and drink three spoonesful at once: or stamp
Rue with salt, and drink it with ale or water, and be whole. 212 Urine to
cause, stamp Rue, Parsley and Gromell, and temper them with white wine, and
drink thereof, and be whole. 213 Headache, sees Rue and Fennel in water, and
wash thy head therewith, and apply the herbs plaster wise. 214 Worms to kill
and expel, stamp Rue with thine own urine, and drink it. 215 Ach from the
girdle downward to under the feet, stamp Rue with black Soap, and a red
Onion, of each like much, and apply it. 216 Teeth ach, stamp Rue seeds and
sees them with wine, and apply it. 217 Belly ach, stamp one handful, and
sees it in oil and butter, and apply it in with a Glister. 218 Breast to
cleanse, sees it in vinegar, and drink it with sugar. 219 Gout, sees sage
and Rue in oil, and stamp it, and apply it, to take away the pain by and by,
and keep thy body soluble. 220 Headache, put the juice into thy Nose. 221 For
the plague, and for worms, take every morning a top of Rue, a Garlike head, or
half a quarter of a walnut, and one corn of salt thirty days together, and
be merry. 222 A preservative in the plague time, eat every morning three
little branches of Rue, a walnut, and a fig. 224 Cods swollen, stamp Rue and
apply it. 225 If one have taken Todestooles, let him drink Rue or Organy with
Honey, or Organy with Honey and treacle, or mithrydate, with strong vinegar, or
oximell squillitike, or aqua vite, or eat raw garlike. 226 Ear betle or wig,
put in the juice of Rue with aqua composita, and lie down therewith, and bind
a cloth fast about thy head. 227 Mithridates medicine against the plague, mix
twenty leaves of Rue with two figs, two wall nuts, and a little salt, and be
sure for that day. 228 Skurfe to void, sees a good handful, with half an
ounce of quick brimstone in good old wine, and wash thy head therewith, being
first washed with warm water. 229 Eat the leaves with vinegar, to preserve thee
from the plague. 230 Hicket, stamp it and dissolve it in white wine, and
drink it. 231 Vomiting in children, drink powder of Rue, and half as much
incense with wine, or syrope of Roses. 232 Vuula fallen, boil powder of Rue
and Colyander seed in water of Mints, and hold thereof cold in thy mouth. 233
Joints griefs, stamp pulp of Reisins with green Rue, and apply it. 234
Senowes shrunk, stamp Rue and apply it. 235 Blackness of wounds or sores,
anoint with the juice of Rue and Honey. 236 Matrixe suffoc. stamp Rue with Honey,
and dip woll therein, and put it into the fundament. 237 Head giddy, (See in
Horehound.) 238 Stomach belching, and wind in the body, distill the leaves in
the midst of May, and drink three ounces of the water morn and even. 239
Chollike, drink the iuce with the fat of a Peacocke and Honey, of each like much
with wine. 240 Burning by occasion of cold, boil the leaves of Rue in oil,
and anoint. 241 Falling evil, mix half an ounce of the juice, with i. dram
of Castory, and put thereof into the Nose with wool, when the party is fallen.
242 Stomach ach and swelling, and the belly likewise, sees Rue and Mints in
sweet milk, and drink it. 243 Ach and Gout of the feet, stamp it green
with oil, and anoint therewith against fire often. 245 Side and breast ach,
sees it in wine, and drink it. Eyes dull, put in the juice of Rue and
wormwood. 246 Nost bleeding, burn it and blow it in. 247 To kill lice and
fleaes, wash the place with the juice, and they will soon die. 248 Eyes
bloody, sees Cummin in white wine, and put thereto the juice of Rue, and apply
it. 249 Belly ach, drink the juice with wine or ale: or eat the crops of it,
or boil it in wine, and apply it. 250 Emerods, stamp it with louage, of each
like much, and frye them with Honey, and apply them. 251 Senowes or veins
bruised or hurt, or shrunk, boil it with wax and oil Olive, and anoint
therewith, and also apply it with wool, (See Cummin.) 252 Breast stopped with
much fatness, stamp a good quantity, and sees it long in vinegar, and
drink thereof morn and even. 253 Ears worms, put in the juice of Rue,
Sothernwood, and wormwood, of each like much five nights, and lay the substance
on the ear. 254 Belly swollen, stamp Rue and drink it often with wine or
ale. 255 Head giddy, and turning, stamp it with vinegar, and anoint. 256 Eyes
tears, mix dry Rue with Honey, and anoint. 257 Flowers to cause, stamp it
with as much Mugwort, with oil de Baye, and put it in as a Pessary: proved.
For poison drunk, or any venomous biting, drink one dram of the seeds and
leaves with wine. 258 Eyes dull, make an ointment of the juice of Rue and
Fennel with Honey, and anoint therewith, or eat them, and let thy breath go
into thine eyes. 259 Fleaes to avoid, sees it in water, and sprinkle the house
with it. 260 Bursten, use the juice of Rue and of Elecampana. 261 Ach, heat
Rue and sage on a hot tyle, and apply it hot, (See Elecampana, Gentian,
Betony, Figs.) Belly worms, stamp it with salt and streine it with ale and
drink it. 261 Hands itch and worms, wash them with the juice of Rue, water
and salt. 262 Falling evil, use to smell to Rue. 263 Belly ach, eat it with
Tansy, Sothernewood and salt, (See Mallows, Mints, Rosemary.) 264 Belly
swollen, drink the juice with wine or ale, (See Betony, Cummin.)

Rush.
RVsh: The seed of the common Rush parched and steeped in wine, stops the
laske and the terms, and provoke urine, but being taken too much at once, it
causes headache. 2 The same seeds cause sleep. 3 Oxen sick, seethe the
roots in water, and give it them to drink.

Flowers to stop 1 Flux to stop 1 Oxen sick 3 Sleep to cause 2 Urine to
cause 1
Rosemarie.
ROsemarie: Ach, sees the flowers and leaves in water, and bathe therein. 2
Appetite to cause, distill it with the flowers thereof, and use the water in
thy sawses with powder of Cloves and Cubebs. Sees the leaves in water, and
drink it with thy wine. Sees the leaves in water, and when it is cold, put
as much white wine to it, and make sops therein, and eat them, it helps
feebleness, and unkind sweats. Sees it in water or wine, and drink it. 3
Belly ach, boil the herb with Pellitorie in wine, and drink it. Sees it
with the flowers in wine, and drink it morn and even. 4 Belly bound, sees it
with Pellitorie in wine, and drink it. 5 Bitings venomous, sees it with
pellitorie in wine, and drink it. 6 Blood to comfort, use the decoction with
the flowers, or use them with rere Eggs. 7 Brain cleansing, (See Head reume.)
8 Brain to comfort, seethe it in wine, and drink it. Sees it in wine with a
few Cloves, and then drink it, (See Stomach.) 9 Breast cleansing, seethe it
in water, and drink it, for all the griefs of the breast, breath and lungs.
10 Grind Rosemarie leaves finely, and drink it before the fit, for the fever
quarten. 11 For itch and skab, drink the juice with water or wine nine days,
and be whole. 12 For the web and dullness of sight, anoint with the juice and
Honey. 13 To bring the flowers, and comfort the thing conceived, use fomentation
therewith, and also put it into the Matrixe. 14 For tooth ach, rub them with the
root, or apply the juice. 15 Sores cold, sees the flowers and leaves with
common oil, and anoint therewith. 16 Sees Rosemarie with white wine, and
drink it, for the feebleness of the brain and stomach: or seethe it with
white wine and Masticke, and Time, and use it for the stomach. 17 For the
Strangury, and stopping of the urine, stamp the leaves and flowers in white
wine, and apply it to the shares. 18 The juice, flowers, leaves, or rind
drunk in water or wine, cleanses the stomach from corruption, and keeps
the body in good order and state. 19 Make a Pasty of the flowers and leaves
with Grains and Pepper, and break it into a gallon of new ale, and after it
is three days old, drink thereof at even hot, and at morn cold, to help
the cough and hoarsenesse, Chollike, and Iliake. 20 Use the same drink with
Sage, Vinegar, Cloves, Galingale, Grains, long Pepper and Setwall: it helps
the Yexing. 21 Rosemary helps all cold diseases in the body, the body being
first purged, drink the decoction of the flowers in wine or water first and
last. 22 Seethe it in white wine, and wash the face therewith, to make it
whole, clear, fair, and ruddie. 23 Carry powder of the flower about thee, to
make thee merry, glad, gracious, and well-beloved of all men. 24 Keep a cole of
the tree in a linen cloth, and rub thy teeth therewith, to avoid all worms
and filth. 25 For the cold, pose, and stopping of the head, take up the fume
of the bark, at the mouth and nose. Seethe the root in vinegar or wine, and
let a thief wash his feet therein, and he shall neither rob, steal, fear,
nor fright any man. 26 Eat the flowers with bread and Honey fasting, against
the falling sickness. 27 Lay the flowers on thy bed, to keep thee from all
evil dreams. 28 Seethe much Rosemary, and bathe therein, to make thee lusty,
lively, joyful, likeing, and yongly. 29 Sees it in milk with Sage, Margerom,
Auens, Eyebright and Honey, and when you are bathed, anoint your face and body
therewith, to comfort the veins, sight, mind and heart, and for many other
griefs. 30 Distill it when it flowreth, and use it in the sawse with cubebs in
powder, to cause appetite. 31 Stamp the leaves and apply them to a kanker, to
destroy it for ever. Make a spoone of the wood, to give thy broth a fine taste,
and thy body health. 32 Anoint any venom, or poison, or stinging, with Rosmary,
to avoid it, or to preserve the place from hurt thereby. 33 For the cold
cough, and the pose, Sees it in water, and take up the fume at thy nose, and
wash thy head and mouth therewith. 34 To provoke appetite, and avoid loathing,
seethe the leaves in water, and drink it with thy wine. 35 Stomach griefs,
use mises thereof. 36 Flux, seethe it long in vinegar, and apply it
hote-thrise, plaster-wayes. 37 For any sore or ach, seethe the flows and
leaves in water, and bathe therein. 38 Burn it and the smoke thereof will
drive adders out of their holes, or kill them. 39 For grief and heat of the
stomach, seethe the leaves in Well water, and drink it cold with a little of
a Pomegranate: it so takes away thirst. 40 For the breath, and to open the
pipes and cleanse them, burn the wood and take up the fume. 41 The flowers
laid among clothes, keeps them from mothes. 42 For the cough and pose, seethe
the leaves in water, and drink it, or make a syrrop thereof and use it. 43 For
the cardiake and swelling at the heart, make a drink thereof with Rose water,
or white wine: or else a syrroppe with Rose water or white wine, with the juice
of Parsneps, sugar, and the bone of a Stags heart, and use thereof. 44 Worms:
use the juice with honey. 45 To comfort the heart, seethe Rosemarie, and the
flowers with Rose Water, and drink it. 46 Skin cleansing, seethe the flowers
with white wine, and wash therewith, and drink thereof. 47 Fever: seethe
yssop, sage, Rosemarie, and the roots of Polipodie ana three ounces in a
pottell of ale or beer to the one half: then streine it, and drink a little
before thy fit as often as need is. 48 Itche: Seethe half a pint of white
vinegar with Rosemarie and Celondine ana one handful, streyne it, and while it
is hot, put in some white coprosse and use to wash therewith. 49 Mouth
kanker: Seethe a sprigge of Rosemarie in half a pint of ale, and scumme it,
and put in as much Alume as a nutte, honey one spoonful, and two spoonefull of
Honiesuckle water, and use it. 50 Face to be fair, and breath to be sweet,
seethe the flowers in white wine, and wash therewith, and drink thereof. 51
Emerods to heal, apply a plaster of ye leaves, the same helps the swelling
of the fundament. 52 Fever quarten, and Intermissiue, drink the juice before
the fit and be whole: or drink the decoction of Rosemary, Sage and Lauender
before thy fit. 53 To cleanse and comfort the brain: seethe it in white
wine, and receive up the fume thereof at thy nose and mouth, and hold a cloth
over thy head. 54 Ears dull, (See Camomile. 55 Head megrim, See Primrose. 56
Hair to grow, anoint with the juice of Rosemarie, and let it dry in of it
self. 57 Iaundies: seethe Rosemarie in clarified Ale, and streyne it, and put
in yellowe turmericke, saffron and sugar, and drink thereof morn and even. 58
Sores: receive Rosemarie stripped from the stalks, seethe it in running water to
the one half, and then streyne it, and put in allume at your discretion, and
use it after it is sodden a little more, and wash therewith: and when you will
heal it up, put in English honey, and use it daily: proved. 59 Kings evil:
Steep it with Hearts tongue a night in wine, and drink thereof to put it away.
60 The juice of the root and herb mixed with honey, and drunk, helps the
dullness of sight, and purges grossness of humors. 61 Ulcers hard: the
root bruised and mixed with honey, and applied, softeneth them speedily. 62
The root boiled with Pellitorie in wine, and drunk, softeneth the belly,
helps the pain thereof, and helps the bytings of venomous beasts and
worms. And in the same manner tempered with Mugwort, it provoke urine and the
menstrues. 63 The flowers tied in a fair linen cloth, and sodden in wine and
drunk morn and even, auoydeth many griefs of the body, but especially of
the pappes. 64 The powder of the flowers drunk in warm wine, makes the mind
merry, comfort nature and blood, and preserves many from diseases, which
otherwise would come. 65 The smoke of the bark stops the rewme, if the
head be holden over it. 66 Appetite to cause: boil it in water, and drink it
alone, or with Wine. 67 The powder of the flowers eaten with rear potcht eggs
does greatly strengthen nature, and amendeth the blood. 68 Drink a good
draught of wine made of Rosemarie morn and even to cleanse the blood, and
provoke appetite, to expel all inner humors, and to help a great weakness.
69 Boil Rosemarie with wild Peniroyall or Mints, in wine and oil olive, and
anoint therewith to cause sweat, and help the dropsy. 70 Boil it in wine
with Rue and a little pepper, and drink it to help the falling sickness. 71
Boil it in wine with Pellitorie, and some gargle therewith to help the
greatness of the Vuula. 72 Seethe it with the flowers in wine, and drink it
morn and even three hours before and after meat to help the Kings evil,
the hard fetching of breath, to open the pipes of the lungs, to cause easy
spitting forth, to help digestion, to cease the gripings of the body, and to
cleanse the blood. 73 Flux to stop, Boil the flowers in the strongest
vinegar, and bind it to thy Nauill. 74 The decoction of Rosemarie helps the
Iaundies, provoke urine and menstrues. 75 Rosemarie helps the Cough being
taken with pepper and honey. 76 The fume of it being burned, resists the
Pestilence. 77 The green leaves of Rosemarie being bruised and applied do
stop the Emerodes. 78 Drink wine of Rosemarie morn and even three or four
hours before meat to stop the whites, and to heal the gnawing of the
secret parts, the Iaundies, shortness of breath, and to open the pipes of
the Lunges, to help digestion, to resist poison, to purge the blood, and
avoid stinking sweat, and cover thee well, and lie still: the like does the
herb with the flowers sodden in wine. 79 The conserve of the flowers
comfort the heart maruellously. 80 The water drunk, restores the speech,
and serves almost for all the diseases aforesaid. 81 Rosemarie in drink, or
applied, takes away swooning, trembling, swimming of the head, clears the
color of the face being washed therewith, and clears the thin filmes that
cover the eyes. 82 The decoction thereof with Dittander, or the water cleanses
and heals rotten sores and wounds, as creeping sores, and Fistulaes, etc. 83
Seethe Rosemarie in water and drink it before exercise, and enter into a
bathe, and drink vnwatered wine after it to heal the Iaundies. 84 The seeds
thereof drunk in Wine, helps the falling sickness, and pain in the
breasts. 85 Rosemarie comfort the brains, sinews, heart and memory. It
is good against shaking, and the Palsy. 86 For the griefs of the stomach:
eat thereof daily with bread and salt fasting. 87 To cleanse and comfort the
stomach, and to make a sweet breath: take Rosemarie with the flowers, or
without the flowers a handful or more, Seethe it in good white wine a good
space, and drink it with a little Cinamome. 88 To comfort the stomach, seethe
a good handful with a quarte of Wine, and a few cloaues therewith, until it
be ready to burn, and use often to drink thereof. 89 Stamp thereof and
streyne it with Wine, and drink thereof to open the obstructions of the Liver
and milte, it preserves and keeps health, being taken a week together at
the Spring and fall of the leaf. 90 An Electuarie to comfort the stomach and
brain, and to make a sweet breath: Take Sage two drammes, Rosemarie flowers
one ounce and a half, of Cloves five ounces, Cinamom one ounce and a half,
Nutmegs a scruple: Stamp them well with honey or sugar, make an Electuarie
thereof, and take half a spoonefull in the morning, and drink a little red wine boiled with a little Sage after it, and use the same daily until you
have your purpose. 91 An ointment for the stomach against the Cough: stamp
three handfulles of Rosemarie striped downewardes, and boil it with four
ounces of Capons grease till it be green, and the stronger it is, the better
it is: then streyne it and put thereto half an ounce of fine powder of Maces,
and use it to the mouth of the stomach warm. 92 The ashes of Rosemarie does
fasten loose teeth, and beautifieth them being rubbed therewith. 93 Headache:
Seethe Willowe tops with a little Rosemarie in vinegar, until the third
part be wasted, and wash the head therewith. 94 Eyes to be clear: stamp
Rosemarie one handful, Balm one great handful, streyne them with a quarte of
ale, and drink thereof morn and even to consume the vapors that hurt the
brain and sight. 95 Brain cleansing, and Nose stinking: chewe good store of
Rosemarie leaves half an hour together before dinner and supper, and hold
down thy head. 96 Headache: Seethe balm and Rosemarie ana one handful,
green or dry in a quarte of milk as it comes from the Cow, and drink it
hot with powder of Nutmegges. 97 To preserve from sweat: steep balm,
Rosemarie and burrage in ale or beer twelve hours or more, and drink thereof
morn and even. 98 Heart to comfort, and to open the pipes, and to expel
melancholy: use conserve of Rosemarie flowers, put the flowers into a linen
cloth, and boil them in fair water to the one half, and cool it and drink
against all evils of the body. 99 To be merry and joyful, bind the flowers
to thy right arm. 100 To withstand all evil swellings of the body, eat the
flowers with honey fasting. 101 For the Ptisicke, boil the flowers in Goats
milk, and let it stand all night fair covered under the air, and drink
thereof. 102 To keep the face from breaking out: Seethe the leaves with white
wine, and wash therewith. 103 To avoid evil dreams, put the leaves under
the beds head. 104 To slay a kanker: apply powder of the leaves. 105 For
feeblenes and unkind sweates, boil the leaves in water, and when it is cold,
put thereto as much white wine and make soppes therein, and eat them. 106
Flux to stop, boil the leaves in strong vinegar, and apply them to thy
womb. 107 Legs swollen with the Gout, boil the leaves in water and apply
them. 108 To be delivered from all evils, boil the leaves in strong vinegar,
and apply them to thy stomach. 109 For the Cough, Boil the leaves in white
wine, and drink thereof. 110 For the Pose, Drink powder of the rind. 111
Youth to preserve, make a box of the wood, and smell to it. 112 To withstand
the danger of Serpents, put thereof in thy doors, or within thy house. 113 To
withstand poison, make a barrel of the wood, and drink all thy drink out of
it, and no poison shall hurt thee. 114 For loss of good smelling, and for one
that cannot draw his breath, Make fire of the wood and draw in thy breath
therewith. 115 Fevers of all sorts: Drink the juice of Rosemarie, Sage,
Mustarde, Vinegar, and Triacle, ana like much before thy fittes thrice. 116
Seethe Rosemarie and Rue, ana like much two handfulles in common Oil and
Malmesey, of each a quarte, half an hour, and chafe any lame member well with
a hot cloth, and then wash it therewith half an hour, and apply the woollie
side of a Lambeskinne, and do so three weeks at the least to bedwarde, and
be whole. 117 Fundament swollen: Stamp Rosemarie and apply it warm in a
cloth. 118 For the Chollicke and pain in the side, Seethe one handful in
water, and temper your wine therewith, and none other water. 119 Face spots:
Fill a glass with the flowers and bury, half in sand, being stopped with
new wax, and cover the upper part, and let it rest so thirty days: then
streyne it, and keep the water as a thing precious for this purpose. 120 To
preserve from the Gowte, Seethe the roots well in vinegar, and wash therewith.
121 Head cold: take up the fume of the bark at the Nose. 122 Madness and
foolishness: Boil the leaves and flowers in water, and bathe therein. 123
Thirst great: seethe the leaves in water, and drink it with wine of
Pomegranates. 124 Ptisicke: Boil the flowers in Goats milk, and let it
stand all night in the open air, and drink it. 125 Brain weak and cold:
Seethe it in wine and drink it, and keep thy head covered. 126 Toothach:
chewe the root, or hold the juice in the mouth. 127 Fever quarten: stamp the
flowers and leaves, and take them before thy fits. 128 Flowers to cause, seethe
it in white wine, and drink it, and apply pure honey and woman's milk to the
matrix as hot as may be suffered. 129 For all griefs, Seethe the flowers in
water in a bag to the one half, and drink it. 130 Milk to cause, sees it
in broths and drinks, and use it. 131 Stitch: seethe it with sage and Rue, ana
one handful in white wine, and drink it.

Youth to preserve 112
Saffron.
SAffron is good in medicines against the diseases of the breast, lungs, liver
and bladder. 2 And in meats it is good for the stomach, and causes good
digestion. 3 Sodden in wine and drunk, it preserves from drunkenness, and
provoke lust. 4 And taken in sweet wine, it causes one to be long winded,
and easy. 5 Mix it with woman's milk, and apply it to the eyes to preserve
them from the falling down of humors, and from the small pocks and mesels,
and to stop the flux of blood of the same, or bloodshooting. 6 It is good also
to be laid upon inflammations, choleric impostumes, and wild fire: and is
good to be mixed with all medicines for the ears, to mollify all hardness,
and to ripen all raw swellings. 7 The root drunk in wine, provoke urine
that is stopped, and comes forth by drops, and expels the gravel and
stone. 8 If a woman anoint the corners of her eyes with ointment of Saffron,
and that her spittle do afterward savor thereof, she is not barren. 9 For
the pocks in the eyes, and to preserve the sight: steep Saffron in a sawser
full of fair water, and when it is yellow, drop thereof into the eyes. 10 Mix
three drams of Saffron, and one dram of Opium with the yolks of four new laid
eggs, and apply it to griefs of the Gowte to assuage it. 11 Mix fine powder of
English Saffron with fine black soap, and apply it to the navel with a piece
of lether to expel the urine within one hour. 12 Drink fine powder of half a
peniworth of Saffron, with a spoonful of Malmsey often to help the chollicke.
13 Smell to Saffron in the frenzy to provoke sleep: and use it also in meats
to provoke sleep. 14 Apply Opium, Saffron and Mandrag. to thy head to provoke
sleep. 15 For turning and dasling in the head: take Opium and Saffron, of each
a dram, of roses 4 drams, apply the same as a plaster with vinegar. 16 Saffron
strengthens the heart and intrals being taken with measure, and so it is
profitable for the stomach, and helps digestion. 17 It purges the blood,
withstandeth poison, and is good against the plague. 18 Some roast it in an
egshel with triacle, mustard, and other spices, and make it into an Electuary
to be taken to drive out the plague and inward poison. 19 Use Saffron in
meats and drinks to provoke urine, help the Iaundies, and drive down the
terms, but especially the root thereof with Malmesey or Muscadell. 20 Saffron
is good for the vlceration of the stomach, breast and kidneys, the
inflammation of the liver, lungs and bladder. 21 Saffron is good for the palsy
members, and all hardness of the sinews: and therefore is Oxycroceum made
thereof for all the aforesaid. 22 Saffron, with woman's milk anointed,
stops the running of the eyes. Put powder of Saffron with oil of bitter
Almonds into deaf ears to help the hearing. 23 Take powder of Saffron ten
grains, walnuts 20. grains figs 2. drams, sage six leaves, sta^p them
together, with one dram of pimpernel water, and 3. grains of Mythridatum, and
keep it in a close glass, and take thereof in ye morning 12. grains, as a
defensive against the plague. 24 Many goodly medicines be made of Saffron, as
Diacucurma against the Iaundies, and it is put into many antidotes and
plasters, as Oxycroceum, etc. and with ointments against the palsy and gowte.
25 Saffron, Opium, milk and Rose water tempered together, does make a goodly
medicine against the pain of the feet. 26 Stamp Saffron with beete leaves,
and apply it to the forehead to provoke sleep. 27 Saffron is good against all
manner of swellings in the breast, wind in the belly and guts, and stopping
of the mouth of the Matrix, either in ointment or drink. 28 It is a good
cordial to be used in meats of melancholy persons, to make them merry and
glad: it causes a good color in them that use it. 29 The root drunk in
sack, provoke urine well. 30 Saffron, with the white of an egg drives away
all inflammations, but especially of the eyes. 31 It helps the suffocation of
the mother, it is excellent good for the exulceration and going off of the skin
of the stomach, lungs, liver, breast, kidneys and bladder: it is also good for
the Cough and the Plurisie. 32 It takes away itch. 33 It is good for weak
brains that cannot well bear drink. 34 It provoke sleep. 35 It heals
flegmatike diseases, and the drowsiness of the Letargie. 36 It is not good to
take of it too much at once, but used moderatly, it profits much. 37 Warm
honey, and Cowes milk, of each half a pint, with six grains of wheat
flower, and two penie weight of beaten Saffron, and apply it to the stitche of
the side to have present help. 38 For a great pain and stitche in the side:
Seethe half a pound of milk, with two ounces of honey, one ounce of Wheat
flower, and one penie weight of Saffron, and apply it. (See Whinne.) 39
Chollicke: Make powder of Saffron, the root of Five leaf, and long pepper,
and drink them with ale hot. 40 Dropsy: stamp goose dung and Saffron, and
streine it and drink it first and last. 41 Mix Saffron with horse grease, and
anoint the hot Gowte therewith. 42 Drink whole Saffron sodden in Wine, to
preserve from death, and to drive away sickness at the beginning. 43
Swellings: seethe Cummin, Oatemeale, and Saffron in sweet milk, and apply it
to all swellings. 44 Sweat to cause, Drink powder of dried salt with Saffron,
a good quantity with white wine. 45 Headache of melancholy, use Saffron in thy
meats. 46 Headache of phlegm, to dry the moisture of the brain, and to warm
the stomach, take aqua vitae six drammes, buglosse water four drammes,
beaten Saffron and Cinamome, of each one penie weight, steep them together
four and twenty hours, and drink it. Lamenesse, use beaten Saffron in thy
meats. 47 Drink a penie weight of beaten Saffron with strong drink fasting,
to comfort the brain and stomach, and to stop vomiting. 48 Heart feeble, and
emptiness, use hot Saffron in thy drink, especially with aqua vitae, and
every day about two a clock after noone, put to the yolke of a rear roasted
egg, a little Saffron and salt, and suppe it of to comfort the heart and the
whole body. 49 To strengthen the heart, and all the whole body and members,
quench fine gold nine times in the best aqua vitae, put thereto Saffron one
dram, and Cinamom two drams in powder, and let it stand four days in a close
vessel, and shake it often: then drink half an egge-shell full every day with
as much good wine morn and even. 50 To refresh the body, stew an old hen
with a goblet of wine, and a dram of beaten Saffron in a pottell pot in a
vessel of seething water, and use it. 51 Iaundies, drink powder of Columbine
seeds, and Saffron, of each a penie weight with wine, water and vinegar, of each
one egge-shell full, and drink it first and last. 52 Side stitch, drink
Saffron. 53 Eyes hurt, grind Saffron with woman's milk, and apply it. 54 Host
of the lungs, drink Saffron and sugar with the juice of coleworts, (See in
Coleworts.) Teethach (See Garlic.) 55 Liver chafed, stamp marigoldes with
Saffron, and drink it with wine morn and even. 56 Flowers to cause, (See in
Germander.) 57 Soreness in the flesh, (See Eggs.) 58 Bloody flux, (See
Onion.) 59 Belly bound, mix as much May butter as a walnut with Saffron, and
anoint the belly therewith, and apply it to the nauel. 60 Flowers to stop,
drink powder of coliander, sanders, and Saffron with red wine in the morning.
61 Gowte, (See in Flax.) Iaundies, (See in Rosemary, Milt griefs, (See in
Hearts tongue. 62 Saffron in all meats provoke sleep. 63 Iaundies, dissolve
Saffron in water, and drink it to heal it by and by, or apply Saffron to the
nauil. 64 Cough, (See in Apple.) 65 Stomach weak, take an halfpeniworth of
Saffron in powder with Malmesey morn and even, or with sallet oil, triacle,
and malmesey, of each a halfpeny worth. 66 Chollick, drink a halfpeny worth
with a spoonefull of malmesey in powder, (See Bays, Garlic. 67 Ptisick,
dissolve Saffron one scruple, and musk half a grain in good wine, and drink
it. 68 Apost. to ripen, mix the yellow part of cocks dung with the yolke of an
egg, and a little Saffron, and apply it. 69 Plurisie, and Ptisick, take gum
Armoniack, a dram and a half, Saffron half a dram, make it into fifteen
pills, with Oximel squillitike, and take every morning one. Eyes bruises, (See
Rose.) 70 Eyes red, and tears, steep Saffron in Rose water 24. hours, then
heat it, and cleanse it, and use it. 71 Belly swollen, (See in Aloes.) 72
Flowers to cause, (See Grains.) 73 Eyes bolning (See Cummin. 74 Iau^dies,
drink wormwood, celondine, Saffron and Iuory in ale. Purgation, (See Laureall.
75 Saffron causes a good color, resolves apostumes, and is good to be
anointed on the shingles, but it causes headache, and hurts the head: it
causes an easy breath, and comfort the heart and stomach, and is good for
the milt, and provoke lust and urine: a certain woman drunk two drams in her
travel, and had speedy deliverance. 76 Gout, mix Saffron with yolks of
eggs, rosewater, and oil, and anoint therewith cold with a feather. 77 Poison
to expel, drink two drams of it. 78 Eyes dim and dropping, drop it into the
eyes with rosewater and woman's milk. 79 Mix it with rosewater, woman's milk,
and Opium to take away the pain of the feet. 80 Stamp it with beet leaves
and apply it to the forehead, to cause sleep. 81 Saffron is good against all
swelling in the breast, wind in the belly, and guts, and stopping of the mouth
of the matrix in ointment or in drink. It is a good cordial, and helps them
that are melancholy, and rejoices the heart. 82 Side stitch, drink Saffron.
83 Iaundies black, green, or yellow, make fine powder of Iuory four drams,
turpentine six drams, Saffron four penny weight, and drink thereof with stale
ale morn and even: but for the black Iaundies, purge melancholy first. 84
Chollick, stamp Saffron and thyme, and streine it and drink it with good ale
to have present help. 85 Rising under the stomach, seethe powder of long
pepper, grains, Saffron, ginger, anniseeds, lycoras, and sugar in good ale,
till it be thick, and drink it, and be whole.

Sagapenum or Serapinum.
SAgapenum, or Serapinum: drink one dram to purge tough and slimie humors,
and all gross phlegm and choler. 2 It is also good against all old and cold
diseases that are hard to cure, it purges the brain, and is good against all
griefs of the head, the Apoplexia and falling sickness, cramps, palsies,
shrinkings of the sinews, taken in the same sort, and for shortness of breath,
the cold, and cold cough, pain in the side and breast, and cleanses the
breast of all cold humors: it cures the hardness, stoppings and windiness
of the milt, being also applied outwardly in ointment or plaster: and is good
against the shaking off old and cold fevers drink it with honied water to
provoke terms, and to expel the dead birth. 3 Drink it with wine against all
venomous bitings and stingings. 4 Smell to it against the strangling of the
mother. 5 Soke it in vinegar to scatter and dissolve all hard, old and cold
swellings, tumors, botches, hard lumpes, etc. about the joints. 6 Mix it
with all ointments and plasters that are made to mollify and soften. 7 It
clears the sight, and at the beginning it takes away the haw or web, and all
spots or blots in the eyes, being dropped in with the juice of rue, and for
their bloodshooting and dimnesse, coming by gross humors. 8 It is a precious
gum, the best shines through dark in color yellow without and white within.

Apoplexia 2 Apostumes 5 Bytings venomous 3 Brain griefs 2 Breast griefs 2
Breath short 2 Botch 5 Cold 2 Cough 2 Crampe 2 Dead child 2 Eyes griefs 7
Falling evil 2 Fevers cold 2 Flowers stopped 2 Hardness 5. 6 Joints griefs 2
Milt griefs 2 Mother suffocat. 4 Obstruct. 2 Purgation 1 Sinews griefs 2
Side griefs 2 Swellings 5 Windiness 2
Sage.
SAge sodden in wine and drunk, stays excessive Fluxes, and the terms
staying, it draws them down, but too much running, it stays them. 2 Seethe
it with wormwood, and drink it to stop the bloody flux. 3 Vrin and terms
stopped, sees the leaves and stalks together and drink it. 4 Palsy: sees it
in wine and drink it, or apply it. 5 Sees it in water, and drink it for the
gout and falling sickness, and especially for the dropping of the urine, being
both drunk and applied to the belly, and foment with the decoction of it, for
the strangurie, bloody flux, and to cleanse the matrix. 7 Boil it in wine with
mullin, and sit over it hot in a close stool, to send up the fundament that
is fallen: 8 Sees the leaves and stalks in wine, and wash ye itch of the
priuities therewith, and sit over the hot broth for the itch of the fundament. 9
Mix the juice with honey, and wash filthy wounds therewith to cleanse the^. 10
Distill it when it bears flowers and drink 2. or 3. ounces of the water morn
and even to amend ye griefs of the liver, to avoid the cough, and to send down
the dead yongling. 11 Bath therewith ye members yt be shrunk and astonished. 12
Drink it with wine to procure appetite, and to strengthen the stomach and
women's natural places. 13 Drink it by it self for the pain in the sides, the
shaking of the hands and the palsy: and also bath them in the same water. 14
Drink 3. or 4. ounces of it morn and even to break any inward impost. to
comfort the brain, to take away ye distillings of the head, to comfort a hot
liver, and put away the frensy. 15 Mix ye same water with peacoks dung to stay
the fresh bleeding of wounds, being bound about with moss and cotton. 16 Eat
iii. leaves of Sage in the morning to be free that day from al evil air. 17
Sees Sage in wine and drink it for the health of the whole body, to expel
poison, the cough, the plurisie, to warm the liver and matrix, and to drive out
the stone and menstrews. 18 Use the decoction of it to cleanse the intrals and
to help the bloody flux. 19 Use powder of it as a sawse with meats, it is better
then al strange spices and aromatikes. 20 Sees Sage in water, and wash thy
head therewith to make thy hair black, and to heal the skurf, ulcers, and
venomous bitings. 21 Sit in the decoction of it to help the strangury, and to
provoke vrin, and take away the pain in the bloody flixe and other diseases:
and for the skab and swelling of the priuities. 22 Wash thy hands in a lauer,
wherein is put some Sage, and let it dry in without wiping against their
shaking. 23 Sees Sage in wine and drink it to provoke urine, and break the
stone, to comfort the heart, and assuage headache. 24 Let women with child eat
it to close up ye matrix, to cause their fruit to live, and to strengthen ye
same. 25 Let women drink the juice to become fruitful in procreation of
children. 26 Drink the juice with honey against spitting of blood, and vomiting
of blood, for it stops the flux and blood incontinent, being taken 2.
glasseful at once. 27 Sees it in water, and drink it to cure the cough, the
stopping of the liver, and pain in the side. 28 Boil it with wormwood to stop
the bloody flux. 29 Apply Sage to bitings and wounds to heal them. 30 Sees
Sage in wine, and bathe or wash thee for the manginesse and skurfe, and itch of
the privy parts. 31 Bake a loaf full of Sage, and apply it to the ears to
hear well. 32 Seethe Sage and drink it to provoke the flowers, and apply it
also to the Matrix. 33 Sage is good for the palsy, it comfort the sinews
and brain. 34 Use to eat 7. or 8. leaves in the spring and summer with bread
and butter, but in winter use as many leeke blades unset, and drink a good
draught of ale after it to preserve health. 35 Use Sage in sawses of veale,
pigs and porke. 36 Bruise Sage and put it into a little bag, and put it into a
quart of wine all night, and then strein it and use it as Sage wine to consume
phlegm, and to comfort the brain and sinews. 37 Make Sage ale in like manner,
or wash Sage leaves, and put them into the bottom of a vessel at the clensing,
and drink thereof after it is three or four days old: for every gallon two
handful of Sage is sufficient, and it is as good as Sage wine. 38 Sage and Rue
steeped in drink, are good against the infection of the plague. 39 The perfume
of Sage stops the flowers. If a woman drink a little Sage with a little
salt and sugar four days before and after the use with her husband, and the
man doing the like before procreation, without doubt conception follows. 40
Mix half an ounce of Sage with clarified honey, and eat it fasting to stop
vomiting or spitting of blood coming from the breast, lunges or stomach. 41
Sage provoke urine, cleanses phlegm, expels wind, dries up the Dropsy,
helps the Palsy, strengthens the sinews, and purges the blood. 42 Seethe
Sage with running water, roch allom and woodbine leaves, to kill the kanker in
the mouth, to quench the great heat, and burning, stink, filth, and matter
that comes often through corruption of nature or Meretrix manner, in the
secret parts of men and women, which is helped by putting thereto a little
Aristolochia rotunda in powder. 43 The broth wherein the leaves and branches
are sodden, drives forth vrin, the terms and birth. 44 Drink two cyaths of
the juice with an ounce of honey fasting, to stop the spitting of blood, and
for the Ptisick and exulceration of the lungs, which is a consumption. 45 Take
spikenard ii. drams, of the seed of sage parched, beaten, and searsed,
fourteen drammes, of pepper twelve drammes, mix altogether with the juice of
sage, and make pills thereof, and take three fasting, and as much at night, at
each time a dram, and drink water after it for the griefs aforesaid. 46
Women that have been long without children by drinking ten ounces of the
juice with a grain of salt, a quarter of an hour before accompanying with
their husbands, have conceived at that time: proved. 47 Dropsy: distill Sage,
centorie, and water cresses, of each like much, and drink the water first and
last. (See Rye, Ruc. 48 Flowers stopped: drink Sage with Malmesey or honied
wine. 49 Frenzy: drink the juice of Sage, Sothernwood, and marigoldes five
days. 50 G^wte: stamp Sage leaves with anniseeds, and sees them in white
wine and apply it. 51 Mad: seethe Sage, marigolds, sothernwood, and branne,
and drink the broth: if a man be mad suddenly, let him drink Sage, marigolds,
and sothernwood with wine five days. 52 Palsy, use the decoction of Sage and
Castorie. 53 Speech lost: drink Sage with water, or dry Sage in an oven, and
use the powder with brothes, and drinks. 54 Preservative: seethe Sage in wine
and drink it. 55 Speech lost: stamp Sage with wine and drink it. Voice to
be clear: drink Sage with ale fasting. 56 Hickit: take Sage with vinegar. 57
For any gathering of impostumes or humors: drink triacle with the decoction
of Sage or yssope. 58 Palsy: use the water. 59 Lame members: hold them over
ye decoction of Sage. 60 Sage in bathes causes sweat, especially with
peniroyall, mugwort and fennel well sodden: and then the water also applied
with cloth, and so it heals cold members. (See in Wormwood. 61 Tongue hot
and bitter in the Iaundies: lay Sage in cold water three hours, and stroke
thy tongue therewith. Mad, (See Marigold. 63 Ears dull: fill a loaf full of
Sage, and bake it, and cut it through the midst, and apply it hot three or
four times. 64 Teeth stink, bake Sage with as much salt in paste to coals,
and rub them with the powder of it. 65 Mouth canker, (See Lauender-Cotton.) 66
Speech to cause, (See Primrose.) 67 Teeth-stinke, rub them with a Sage leaf.
Speech lost, (See Pimpernell.) 68 Appetite, (See Mints, Parsley.) Hands-ache,
(See Fenell.) Heart griefs, (See Mints.) 69 Side pain and belly dropsy, and
palsy, drink Sage with wine a little warmed. 70 Fever, (see Nettles,
Feuerfue.) 71 Canker, (see Briony.) Dropsy, (see Ysope.) 72 Gout, (see
Planten.) 73 Hair falling, (see Nettle.) 74 Host, (see Cu^min.) 75 Hickit,
eat or drink Sage with vinegar. 76 Iaundies, sees a hen that has yellow feet
in white wine with Sage, Cummin, and saffron, and eat ye flesh and drink the
broth. 77 Dropsy, bake Sage great store with hysope chopped small in wheat
paste, and break it into ii. or iii. gallons of ale that is good, or else good
wine, and after it has stood 24. hours, drink thereof daily. Headache, (see
Feuer-fue, Fenell.) Sores, see Rue.) 78 Biting of a mad dog, stamp Sage with
one peniworth of Treacle, and drink it with milk or ale, and use it, and be
letten blood. 79 Liver to restore, drink Aloes epatica with Sage and sugar. 80
Ringwormes and tetters, seethe Sage and alome in smithes water, and wash
therewith. 81 Stitch, (See Rue.) 82 Teeth-ache, sees Sage and Piretrum in
vinegar, and hold it in thy mouth hot as may be suffered. 83 Fever (see
Rosemary.) 84 Itch, seethe it with Egrimonie in rain water, and wash
therewith. 85 Head-giddy, use Sage in broth. Teeth-ache, apply the leaves. 86
Yard pushes, seethe it in wine, and wash therewith. 87 Flowers and seconds
stopped, seethe it and drink it, or apply it. 88 Gout, boil it with Rue, and
stamp it and apply it. Fever quarte^, (see Rue.) 89 Palsy, sees the leaves
in wine, and drink it, and apply leaves daily. 90 For the strangury, the
flux, and to cleanse the matrix, use Sage in sauses, and sit over ye decoction
thereof sodden in water. 91 Poison and venom, sees Sage in wine or ale, and
drink it 3. days. 92 Stomach griefs, and to cleanse ye body, drink ye juice
of Sage with water and honey, or use to eat it. 93 Itch, wash with the juice of
Sage. 94 Ach of the stomach, sides and belly, drink Sage in wine with a little
wormwood, it is good also for the palsy and dropsy. 95 Ache of the head and
stomach, drink the juice of Sage with ale. 96 Hoarsenes, stamp ye crops of
Mints, Sage, and Fiueleafe with Ginger and Licoras, and sees them in stale
ale, and streine it and drink it. 97 Speech lost, stamp Sage and Primrose, and
anoint under ye tongue. 98 Palsy, stamp Sage, Rue, Pellitory, Mustardseede,
Camamile and salt, and boil them in oil to ye one half, and anoint
therewith: it will restore speech. 99 Head and hands quaking, take the leaves
and roots of Sage and Primrose, of each like much, Mustardseede and Bay
leaves, of each like much, stamp them and mix them with May butter, and fry it
and streine it, and anoint the neck, sinowes, joints, veins, and hands
therewith. Palsy taking one side, drink good store of Sage water, and rub thy
temples and veins therewith, and look that thou have great store of mustard
and Sage leaves stamped together, Fenell seed burned, and a little vinegar, and
make them lukewarm, and apply them to thy side, head, temples, armepits, and
wash thrice a night, and on the morrow eat Sage and sharp mustard together,
till thy eyes water: if any thing help this will: but if the palsy be in one
side of the head only, apply it thereto all night, or to any other member,
there is no better medicine. 100 Dropsies of all sorts, take ix. red Mints, ix
crops of blind Nettles, and ix. crops of Sage, stamp them and drink them
with stale Ale morn and even, ix. days. 101 Palsy, seethe Sage, Rue, and
Castory in wine, and drink it. 102 Apost. stamp Sage, and apply it. 103 Yard
chafed, wash it with wine that Sage was sodden it. 104 Fevers, (See in
Rosemary.) A plaster for the fever, stamp ii. shiuers of sour bread tosted
with a pint of vinegar, Sage and Aniseedes of each a handful, heat it and
apply it to thy stomach hot as may be suffered. 105 Yard sores, wash with
wine of the decoction of Sage. 106 Frenzy, stamp Sage, Marigolds, and
Sothernwood, and drink it with ale or wine morn and even vi. days. 107 For
all evil about ye heart and stomach, seethe Sage and Mints of each like much
in white wine, and drink the wine and apply ye herbs, and do so vi. days
morn and even. It is excellent, and causes great appetite. 108 Digestion to
cause, seethe Sage, Rue, Pepper, and Cummin with honey, and eat every day one
spoonefull fasting. 109 Stitch, sees ii. or iii. handful of red Mints, and one
handful of Sage crops in running water to the one half, and apply it hot in a
bag as often as need is. 110 Fever, sees Sage and Bay leaves of each half a
handful in a quart of clarified o^^e to the one half, then streine it and put
half a sponefull of pepper to it with sugar, and drink it before ye fit:
proved, (see Rue.) 111 Breath stinking, rub Sage between thy hands, and put it
into thy nose, and let it rest there a good while a fortnights space,
especially in the mornings. Green sickness, (see Rue.) 112 Gums impost. chop
red Sage and Rosemary small, and heat them with a little honey, and apply them
to the sore tooth to ease the pain. 113 Speech to restore, put ye juice of
Sage and Primrose into his mouth. 114 Falling evil, drink the juice of Sage
and herb John gathered on midsommer morning before sunrising, and anoint ye
temples therewith, and fast bread and water on midsomer even. 115 Felon, stamp
Sage with Castile soap, and apply it as a plaster, and when it is broken, stamp
great reasins, the stones taken out, and apply them. 116 Teeth-ach, stamp ye
leaves of Sage and Rosemary with a little honey and apply it warm: proved. 117
Chollike, boil aqua co^posita and vinegar, ana vi. sponefull with Sage and
Rosemary, ana one handful between ii. dishes, then dip a great dry tossed
therein, and lay the herbs on it, and a cloth on it, and so apply them a little
under ye grief as warm as may be suffered, and lie down i. hour: proved.
118 Flowers and seconds to cause, sees Sage and drink it and apply it to ye
matrix. 119 Biles, felons, and vncomes, stamp Sage with May butter, bores
grease, and wheat flower, and fry it, and apply it to ripen, break, and draw
it, (see Rue.) 120 Hands shaking, (see Bay.) 121 S. Ant. fire, stamp Bur roots
with Sage leaves and apply it. 122 Chollike, (see Mugwort.) Lethargy, (see Agnus
Castus.) 123 Speech lost in sickness, hold ye root of Sage and Primrose in thy
mouth. 124 Sinowes to comfort, use Sage inward and outward. 125 Palsy, use
Sage, Primrose, Castory, Lauender and Tansy with a good piece of green coprose
and a little honey, and streineit and use it, (see Primrose, Bursa Pastoris. 126
Fever in ye stomach, sees a good handful of Sage with as much Otemeale in water
yt runs Eastward, and i. sponeful of honey, and scum it and make it into
pottage with a half peniworth of whole saffron, and when it is thick, eat a
good mess without bread, and drink not of ii. hours after, and do so morn and
even. 127 Pissing bed, (see Garlike.) 128 Teeth yellow, chop one handful of
Sage with as much salt, and put them into past and bake them dry, and rub thereof
wtin a linen clout. 129 Sweating sickness, clarify a quart of ale, and put
thereto Sage and Sorrel of each vi. crops, stamped and streined, and put to it a
qz. of a li. of sugar, and sees ii. or iii. walmes and no more, and drink
thereof as hot as may be suffered, and now and then when thou feel thy self
faint, take as much Treacle as a bean: proved. 130 Ache, wash ye place with the
decoction of Sage and Auens often sodden, of each like much in water. 131
Burnings, stamp Sage royal with salt bacon, and apply it, (see Betony,
Rosemary.) 132 Cough, see Cummin.)

S. James wort.
SAint James wort, it has a special virtue to heal wounds, wherefore it is
good for all old wounds, fistulaes, and naughty ulcers. 2 The juice gargled,
helps all inflammations or swellings and impostumes of the throat. 3 It
heals felons, fistulaes, moist sores, venomous scabs, tetters, cankers,
ringwormes, etc. It is called Fellon-weede.

Fellon 3 Fistula 1 Impostume 2 Inflammation 1 Kanker 3 Mouth griefs 2 Ring
worm 3 Skabs 3 Sores 3 Swellings 2 Tetters 3 Throat greefes 2 Venom 3 Ulcers 2
Wounds 1
S John's wort.
SAint John's wort with the flowers and seeds boiled and drunk, provoke
urine, and helps the stone in the bladder, expels the terms, and stops
the flux. 2 Boil it in wine and drink it for the fever tertian and quarten.
3 Drink the seeds 40. days to cure the sciatica. 4 Stamp the leaves, and
apply them to burnings. 5 Cast the powder of it into naughty wounds, ulcers
festred, old and rotten sores to cure them. 6 Use the water, juice, syrup or
powder, for the sciatica. 7 It is good for cut sinowes and casting of blood.
Drink the seeds with wine to drive forth the stone, and it is good against
poison. 8 The water is good against the falling sickness. 9 Of the herb is
made a precious Baulme. 10 Great S. John's wort, or square S. John's wort, or S.
Peter's wort, drink ii. drams of the seed with honied water a long space, it
cures ye sciatica. 11 Burnings, stamp it and apply it. 12 Wounds to heal up,
seethe the leaves in wine, and wash them therewith. 13 Drink S. John's wort
with wine to cure ye plurisie. 14 Shingles, bruise it and apply it till it
look white or red. 15 Worms in sores, apply the juice. Madness and melancholy,
burn it with green Juniper and Frankincense in thy chamber. 16 Bewitched, or
enchanted, or forespoken, apply it with Treacle to the reins of the back: it
stops fluxes. 17 Drink the herb or decoction of it in wine or water,
against all flux of the belly white or red. For carbuncles, and poison, and
venomous bitings, stamp it and apply it to draw out the poison. 18 A balsam,
take oil olive one pint, S. John's wort, Betony, Centory, and Selfeheale, ana
one handful, stamp them and mix them well together, and let them distill in
a glass all summer long, then press it out. It is most noble to cure wounds
of all sorts, by only anointing them morn and even. It expels humors, and
is wonderful in fractures, bruises, and all such like. 19 Drink water of it
ii. or iii. ounces at morn, noone, and even, with powder of the root of Peony
for ye falling sickness. 20 Burnings and fretting sores, stamp it and apply
it. 21 Navel of children coming out, stamp it and apply it. 22 Restoratiue,
drink the juice with Treacle 3. or 4. times. 23 It stops al bloody fluxes, and
kept in ye house, it suffers no wicked spirit to come there. 24 Bewitched
from coeating with the wife, eat or drink S. John's wort with Treacle vi.
days, and also apply the herb with Treacle to the back and genitors.
Falling evil, (See in Sage.)

Balsam. 18 Bewitched 16. 23. 34 Biting venom. 17 Bloody-fluxe 23 Bones broken
