12. 18
Sallow, willow, or withie.
SAllow, willow, or withy: the leaves and bark do stay the spiting of blood,
vomiting of blood, and all other fluxes of blood and the terms, being boiled
in wine and drunk, and so they appease the pain of the synowes, and restore
again their strength, if they be nourished with ye fomentation or natural
heat thereof. 2 Stamp the green leaves very small, and apply them to the
privy parts to take away the desires to venus. 3 The ashes of ye bark mixed
with vinegar, causes warts to fall off. It takes away ye hard brawnes or skin
of the hands or feet that comes by labor, and ye corns in the toes or
fingers, being laid to. 4 Stamp the leaves and streine them with wine, and
drink it with a little pepper against the Iliake passion. 5 The long buds or
cats tails that hang down being sodden in wine and drunk, are good against
spitting of blood, and so is the bark. 6 The juice gathered when the tree
flowreth, is good to clarify the eyes, and to take away the darkness of them.
7 The juice of the leaves and bark mixed with oil of Roses and warmed in the
rind of a Pomegranate, is good to be put into payned ears. It cleanses away
skurfe, and mendeth ye defaults of ye skin. 8 The seed broken is good against
spitting of blood, and so is the bark. 9 The broth of ye leaves and bark is
good to bathe the gout withal, and to drive away skurf and scales. 10 The juice
is to be gathered by cutting of ye bark when it flowreth. 11 The leaves glewe
wounds together. 12 The flowers are much used in drying plasters. The dried
juice thereof is most excellent for the same purpose. 14 The bark has like
power with the flowers and leaves, and is of a drier complexion. 15 The ashes
of the bark serve for all things that need a mighty dryer. 16 Eyes to
comfort and clarify, put in the milk of the rindes of Sallowe, when it
bears flowers. So does the ashes of the tree made into a lee, and the eyes
washed therewith. 17 The dust of Sallowe coals clears them from all filthy
blood. 18 Flux to stop, dissolve Culuer doung in water of the decoction of
Sallowe, and wash thy feet therewith. 19 Milt to loosen and mollify, seethe
the rind in water and honey, and drink it. 20 Lust to void, eat the flowers
of Willowe, or Sallowe, or Popler. 21 Gout, mix the juice of the roots of
Willowe, or Sallowe, with oil of Roses, and apply it. 22 Sees the leaves of
white Willow in water, and wash thy feet therewith up to the knees, and go to
bed and thou shall sleep. Mix fine powder of the velvet colored moss that
grows at Willowe roots, with the liquour of shoomakers shreads, and anoint
any sores, cankers, or wounds of legs therewith to heal them. 23 To kill
worms that eat the hairs off, anoint with the mussilage of Willowe leaves.
24 To cause deliverance of a dead child, drink iiii. ounces of water of
Willow leaves distilled in the midst of May. 25 The juice of the leaves helps
the hurts of the eyes. 26 Sees Willow twigs in water, and drink it to consume
the spleen utterly. 27 The flowers of a Sallow or Willow, makes cold all
heat of carnal lust. 28 The juice of the roots of Willowe or Sallowe, with
oil of Roses, is wonderful good for the gout. 29 Hair to grow, seethe
Willowe leaves in oil Olive, and anoint therewith. 30 Eyes griefs, put in the
juice of Willow leaves. 31 Milt ache, stamp the leaves with a little Salt, and
apply them to avoid the ache. 32 Liver chafte, chop Willowe leaves and sees
them in water with some honey in an earthen pot, and when it is cold, drink it
fasting and lie on thy left side. 33 Head balde, boil Willowe leaves in oil
and apply them. 34 Eyes bruised, apply ye water that comes out of Willowes
when they be cut or burned. 35 Wounds to close up and heal, stamp the leaves
and apply them. 36 Lust to void, stamp Sallowe flowers yt hang over a river,
or ye juice of ye branches with vinegar, and drink it x. days, it stops
the terms, and causes barennesse.

Agnailes 3 Barrenness 26 Bloody flixe 1 Chollike 4 Dead child 24 Deliverance

Salsaperilla.
SAlsaperilla has the virtues of Guiacum, and the root China, (See Guiacum.)

Sampere.
SAmpere: The leaves, seeds, or roots, or altogether boiled in wine and drunk,
provoke vrin and terms, and is good against the Iaundies. 2 They preserve
the leaves and branches in brine or pickle, as Capers, to be eaten as Capers,
because they be good for the stomach, and do open the liver, milt and
kidneys. 3 It is eaten raw, or sodden in sallads, or otherwise. 4 It is best to
sees it in white wine, or in water, till it be tender, then put it into so
much white vinegar or vergis, (but vinegar is best,) as will cover it, and then
take it out as you need: if it be too sharp of the vinegar, then steep it a
while in white wine or warm water, to take away the sharpness. 5 The use of
it makes a man to look fresh. 6 And the broth that it is sodden in, looseneth
the belly, and draws moisture from the kidneys.

Belly bound 6 Flowers stopped 1 Kidneys moist 6 Sawse 2. 34 Urine stopped 1 Youth
to preserve 5
Sanders.
SAnders white, red, and yelowe: The yelowe is good for the trembling of the
heart. 2 The red hinder the flowing of humors to the parts of the body, and
strengthen the gummes and stomach. 3 All the kinds are good for the trembling
of the heart, joined with an agewe, especially being laid to the heart. 4 Red
Sanders are good with cold herbs, to be laid to the gout, and for the headache
in a hot cause, and they stop humors that flow into the eyes, especially with
Rose water, and likewise to the liver. 5 Sanders are good against itching, if
the place be bathed with the liquor that they are sodden in. 6 They are
wholesome to stop fluxes, and wounds: being applied with Rose water and a piece
of a Rose cake, they are good for the headache: mix the juice of Solarium and
Purslen, with Sanders, and oil of water Lillies, and anoint the raging pain
of the gout, to do it away. 7 Abhorring meat, mix powder of red and white
Sanders with oil of Roses, and apply it to the stomach. 8 All kind of
Sanders comfort the Liver. 9 Frenzy, apply the three kinds of Sanders, with
oil of Roses and vinegar to the forehead. The same is good also for the gout.
10 Liver to cleanse, use the wood Sanders. 11 Liver chafed, use Sanders in thy
brothes, with convenient herbs. 12 Flowers to stop, (See Saffron.) 13
Headache, mix powder of red Sanders, with Sanguis Draconis, and the white of an
Egg, and apply it to the forehead and temples: proved. 14 Wounds to heal
apply Sanders and Coprose in powder, of each like much, over the wound. 15 Back
ach and heat, (See Roses.) 16 Fevers general, (See Lycoras.)

Abhorring meat 7 Back ach and heat 15 Eyes humors 4 Fevers general 16
Flowers to stop 12 Fluxes 6 Frenzy 9 Gummes griefs 2 Gout 4. 6. 9 Heart
trembling 13 Head ach 4. 13 Itch 5 Liver griefs 8. 10. 11 Lothing 7 Stomach
raw 2 weak 2. 7
Wounds 6. 14
Sanicle.
SAnicle: The juice drunk, makes whole and sound all inward and outward
wounds and hurts, so that he that has Sanicle, needs no Surgeon. 2 Boil it
in wine or water, and drink it to stop the spitting of blood, the bloody
flixe, and to cure the vlcerations and hurts of the kidneys. 3 The same or the
juice thereof drunk, cures burstings, the herb also being applied, either raw
or sodden. 4 The leaves and root boiled in water and Honey, and drunk, heals
the perished lungs, and all malignant ulcers, and rotten sores of the mouth,
gums and throat, being often washed therewith: it has in manner the same
virtues that Tormentill has. 5 Being sodden in wine or water and drunk, it
helps ruptures and inward wounds, spitting of blood, griefs of the kidneys,
torments of the back and belly, and the bloody flux, both in men and women,
and is good for all inward griefs, as Tormentil is. 6 The herb gleweth up
green wounds, and is to be used amongst wound medicines, especially the root
thereof, as also ye roots of Comfery, (See Tormentile, Comfery.) 7 Apply Sanicle
hot to any swelling, to assuage it speedily. 8 it stops ye immoderate
running of the reins. 9 Drink it with Pimpernell and Bugle, to heal wounds:
drink it with any liquor, to heal all ruptures. 10 Ladies mantell does the
like. 11 The juice of Sanicle binds al looseness of ye belly. Wounds to
heal without salve, stamp it with Yarow and Buglosse, of each like much, and
streine it with wine, and drink it daily, at morn, noone and even. 12 Sanicle
heals, Yarowes cures, and Bugle keeps the wound open, (See Planten, Ladies
mantel. 13 Horse stung with an Adder or Snake, stamp three hands full, and
streine it with new milk, and give it him with a horn. 14 Cattle, horses, or
kine, bruised or wounded, let them drink the juice, and apply ye herb to ye
place.

Back griefs 5. 8 Belly griefs 5 loose 11 Bitings venomous 13 Bloody flux 5
Bursten 3. 9. 10 Cattle hurt 13. 14 Horse stinged 13 wounded 14
Kidneys griefs 2. 5. 8 Lungs wasted 4 Mouth griefs 4 Reins running 8
Sickness general 5 Spitting blood 2. 5 Stingings 13 Swellings general 7
Throat griefs 4 Wounds genesis 1. 5. 6. 9. 11. 12. 14
Sarasins.
SArasins consound, or Solidago sarasenica: it heals all wounds and ulcers
both inward and outward, in drinks, oils, ointments, and plasters. 2 The same
boiled in water and drunk, stays the wastings of the liver, and helps the
stopping thereof, and of the gaul and the bladder, and is good against the
Iaundies and fevers of long continuance, and such as are falling into the
Dropsy. 3 The decoction thereof is good against the ulcers and stinking of the
mouth, and vlcerations of the gums and throat.

Bladder griefs 2 Dropsy 2 Fevers general 2 Gaul griefs 2 Gums griefs 3
Iaundies 2 Liver stopped 2 wasting 2 Mouth griefs 3 Throat griefs 3 Ulcers 1
Wounds 1
Satyrion.
SAtyrion provoke lust, nourishes and strengthens the body. 2 Sees it in
potage, to restore nature that is lost. 3 Drink it with tart red wine, against
the bowing back of the neck: the herb is of like nature as the root. 4
Satyrion royal, or Palma Christi bruised and drunk in wine, provoke vomit,
and purges the stomach and belly, by means whereof it cures the old fever
quarten, after convenient purgation, if as much as ones thombe of the root be
taken with wine before the fit come, (See Orchis.)

Consumption 12 Fever quarten 4 Neck bowing back 3 Purgation 4 Vomit to
cause 4
Sauery.
SAuery eaten with Cream, purges a cold stomach: drink of the herb, to
defend thee from swooning. 2 Take it in wine for the stopping and other griefs
of the milt and liver, and lungs, and to cleanse the matrixe: but women with
child must refrain the drinking and smelling of it. 3 Sees the herb in
wine, and apply it to the Palsy members, to avoid their pain. 4 Stamp it and
apply it to the belly, to expel the dead yongling, and to provoke urine. 5
Drink it in wine against the Lethargy and drowsinesse, and also bathe the head
often with vinegar. 6 Eat powder thereof with an egg, or drink it with wine
to stay vomiting. 7 Drink the herb against the stinging of venomous beasts.
8 The use of Saueric in meats, does long preserve the body in health: it
helps swellings and gripings in the body, it helps digestion, it expels
the superfluities of the stomach, provoke vrin and terms, and sharpeneth
the weak sight that is dulled with evil moisture, moves carnal lust,
quickens the wits or brain: it helps the griefs of the lungs or breasts,
and is much of like nature to Thime and Penyroyall, and with wheat meal, it
is good for the sciatica. 9 Sees green Sauery in white wine or water, and
drink it, to make the liver soft, to cleanse dropsies, cold coughs, to
cleanse women's diseases, and to drive out a dead child 10 It purges phlegm.
11 Stamp it and sees it with vinegar, and apply it to the hinder parts of the
head against the Lethargy and forgetfulness. 12 Winter Sauery is good in
meats as Thyme, and Sauery has the virtues of Thyme. 13 Woman's belly swollen
as if she were with child, stamp Sauery and streine it with ale, and drink
it with powder of Iet and white Amber, and frye Sauery, Isope and leekes in
fresh butter, and apply them to the back and belly. 14 Biting of a mad dog,
stamp it with bread, and apply it. 15 Sciatica, apply the juice with wheat
flower. 16 Lothing, take the powder of it fasting, with a rere egg. 17
Congealed blood in the body, drink it or Thime. 18 Breast and stomach ach,
drink it with wine and butter after supper. Dead child to cast out, drink it
with wine. 19 Deliverance to cause, drink it and Mugwurt with hot water. 20
Milk to cause, use it in brothes and drinks. 21 Sees it in wine or water,
and drink it to purge the reins, bladder, bowels, and terms, and the lungs.
22 Sees it in wine or vinegar, and drink it, to have a good stomach. 23
Gather it when it flowreth, and boil the powder of it with clarified Honey, and
drink it, to loosen tough phlegm in the breast. 24 Belly fretting, drink
powder of it with wine warm, and be whole. 25 To cleanse all the spiritual
members, make grewell with water, wheat, and powder of Sauery, and eat
thereof. 26 Boil the juice with a good quantity of Honey on a gentle fire, and
put thereto fine powder of Pepper, and stir it well, and keep it in a box,
and use it as an electuary for many cold and windy griefs.

Sauin.
SAuin: The leaves boiled in wine and drunk, provoke urine so strongly that
the blood follows, and drives down the terms, seconds, and dead births,
and so does the perfume of it. 2 The leaves stamped with Honey, and applied,
cures ulcers, and stays spreading and eating sores, and takes away all
spots, freckles, and deformities from the face and body, and causes warts to
fall off about the yard and secret parts. 3 The wood mixed with oils and
ointments, is good. 4 And it may be mixed in stead of Cinamome, taking the
double weight. 5 The berries are gathered in the harvest. 6 Sauin helps all
painful sores, byles and pushes, being stamped and applied. 7 Matrixe suffoc.
burn it and smell to it. 8 Tempered with Honey, it breaks pestilent sores. 9
Pissing blood, drink it with wine. 10 Mix it with hot ointments, for the
coldness of the joints and senowes, and for Palsies. 11 When it is used in
medicine, it is good to put Cinamome to it. 12 Kings evil, stamp it and apply
it, or use it in plasters or ointments. 13 French Pocks, use the fume of it. 14
The powder of it with Honey anointed, heals all painful sores which consume
the flesh, and creep from place to place, Impostumes, inflammations, and
gatherings of humors. 15 The same powder mixed with Cream, helps the skabs of
childrens heads, and so does the herb sodden in Cream. 16 The fresh leaves
bruised and applied, heals the creeping kanker or pocke, that runs from
place to place, and such like. 17 Flowers stopped, sees Sauin and the roots of
Smallach, Parsley and Fennel in wine, and drink it. 18 Flowers to stop, lay
Ginger, Sauin, and Bay leaves on hot coals, and take up the fume thereof
through a funnell or close chair. 19 Morphue, drink Sauin with water when the
evil comes on thee. 20 The juice heals the holy fire. 21 Skabs, stamp
Sauin, and sees it well in water, and wash there with often. 22 Matrixe
suffoc. steep it in wine and drink it with treacle: but if the matrixe fall,
use the things beneath. 23 Costiuenesse, seethe it in water with Hogs grease,
and make it an ointment, and anoint the Navel. 24 Warts, apply powder of Sauin
with the juice of Marygolds. 25 Ears deaf, take up the fume of Juniper
berries and Sauin, in good wine.

Apostume 6. 8. 14 Belly bound 23 Byles 6. 8. 14 Dead child 1 Deliverance 1
Ears deaf 25 Face deformed 2 Flowers stopped 1. 17 to stop 18 French pocks 13
Head sores 15 Holy fire 20 Inflammation 14 Kanker 16 Kings evil 12 Matrix
suff. 7. 22 falling 22
Morphue 19 Palsy 10 Plague sore 8 Pocks 16 Pushes 6 Pissing blood 9 Seconds 1
Senowes cold 10 Skabs 21 Skin to cleanse 2 Sores 2. 6. 14 Ulcers 2 Urine stopped
1 Warts 2. 24
Sausalone.
SAusalone: It is used of some instead of Garlike: some ignorant Apothecaries,
do use it in stead of Scordium: but not without great error. 2 It is good for
a cold stomach, and to be mixed with cold herbs, to take away their
coldness: but it is not good for them that are of a hot nature, or be
disposed to the headache.

Saxifrage.
SAxifrage: The seed or root drunk in wine, or the decoction of it in wine,
provoke urine, breaks the stone in the kidneis and bladder, and is singular
against the strangury, and stoppings of the kidneys and bladder. 2 The root
taken in the same manner, expels the terms, seconds, and dead birth. 3
Powder of the root taken with Sugar, comfort and warmeth the stomach,
helps digestion, cures the gripings and gnawings of the belly, and the
chollike, and expels windiness. 4 The same with the seeds, are very good
for any convulsion or crampe, apoplexia, cold fevers, all venomous bitings, or
any inward poison. 5 The same drunk with wine and vinegar, cures the plague:
and holden in the mouth, it preserves from the same, and purifieth the corrupt
air. 6 The same chewed, purges the brain, swageth the toothach, restores
speech, and is good against the Apoplexia: and so it does, being boiled in
vinegar alone: or with some water put thereto, and after holden in the mouth. 7
The juice of the leaves cleanses all spots and freckles, beautifieth the face,
and leaves a good color. 8 It cleanses rotten sores, being put into them:
and so do the leaves, bruised and applied. 9 The distilled water alone or with
vinegar, clears the sight, and takes away all darkness, being put into the
eyes. 10 The roots have the nature of Parsley roots. The same dried, may be
used in stead of Pepper. 11 The same used any way, in powders, potions, or
electuaries is very good for the gross and viscus humors in the stomach, and
the cold distemperance of the same, and for the passions of the chollike and
matrixe, all poison, and ache of the bowels, the stone of the kidneys, and to
drive down the urine and terms. 12 The seed also does all the aforesaid, and
so does the distilled water being drunk three or four spoones full at once.
13 And the same drunk with Castorie, is good for the Palsy and many cold
griefs. 14 The juice applied, heals the sores of the head. 15 Wash the face
with the water daily, to avoid the deformities thereof, and to make it fair
and clear. 16 The roots may be condyted in sugar, being first sodden and used
for the coldness of the stomach, the chollike and stone. 17 The roots and
seeds are better then the distilled water. 18 Make a plaster of the grease of
Hens, Geese and Hedghogs, with the seeds of Gromell and Saxifrage, and Gotes
blood, and apply it for the strangury and stone. 19 Drink four ounces of the
water, with two drams of powder of burned Turpentine, twice a week early in the
morning, to break and expel the stone in the bladder. 20 Stone, sees it in
strong wine, and drink it continually. 21 Stone in the reins and bladder,
make a syrope with the water of the leaves and sugar, and eat thereof:
proved. (See Parietarie.) 22 Chollike, stone, and strangury, sees the root
in wine, and drink it, or use the powder of it with rere eggs. 23 Stone,
stamp Filipendula, and Saxifrage, and drink the juice morn and even. 24
Pissing blood, stamp Saxifrage, Ambrose, and Parsley, of each like much, and
drink if with Cowes milk.

Apoplexia 4. 6 Belliach 3. 11. 12. 16 Bitings venomous 4 Brain to cleanse 6
Chollike 3. 11. 12. 22 Crampe 4 Dead child 2 Deliverance 2 Eyes dull 9 Face
deformed 7. 15 Flowers stopped 2. 11. 12 Fevers cold 4 Head sores 14 Matrixe
suffoc. 11. 12 Palsy 13 Plague 5 Poison 4. 11 Seconds 2 Skin deformed 7. 15

Scala celi.
SCala celi, or Poligonatum: It is very good for wounds, and to skowre away
spots and freckles from the face. 2 Some make ashes of the root, and thereof
make Lee to the same use. 3 The root stamped, closes up new wounds. 4 The
juice takes away freckles, spots and bruised blood: but it is not to be taken
into the body: it is called white root, or Salomons seal. 5 Sleep to cause,
seethe the leaves well, and wash well thy feet therewith, up to the knees. 6
The juice put into the eyes, helps many infirmities thereof. 7 Eyes burning
hot, anoint them with the juice, and the milk of a Bitch. 8 Lice to kill,
(See Broom.)

Bruises 1. 2. 4 Eyes griefs 6. 7 Face deformed 1. 2. 4 Freckles 1. 2. 4 Lice
to kill 8 sleep to cause 5 Spots 1. 2. 4 Wounds 1. 2
Sea moss.
SEa moss is good to be laid to hot tumors or swellings at the beginning, and
upon all kinds of gouts that require cooling. 2 The powder thereof taken,
kills worms presently, and expels them mightily: it is Calcorolina.

Apostumes 1 Gouts hot 1 Swellings hot 1 Worms 2
Sebestens.
SEbestens by themselves or in decoction, are good for burning fevers and for
worms in children, for the dry cough, to supple the breast, and to dry up
the hot Reume, and also for heat of the Urine, and the sharpness of choler
in the bladder and kidneys, the strangurie, and burning of the urine.

Bladder griefs Fever hot Kidneys griefs Reume hot Cough Strangury Urine
hot Worms
Seen.
Seen: The cods and leaves taken one dram, does purge phlegm, choler and
melancholy, with the broth of a chicken, pease broth, perry, or other like
liquor. 2 The leaves taken in this sort, are good for them that be sad,
melancholy, pensive, dull, or them that have the falling sickness, the
stopping of the liver and milt, headache, maundge, skurfe, itch and leprie, and
all diseases that come of melancholy or choler adust: it must be taken with
Aniseedes, Ginger, and some salgem: or boiled with Aniseeds, Ginger and
Raisins, and so it works quickly, and without griefs: or corrected with
Masticke and Cloves, or with Cinamome. 3 Seen purges gently from the heart,
stomach, lungs, liver and milt, and is good against all agewes: it causes
mirth and good color, and opens the stoppings of all the inward parts. 4 The
broth of the leaves of Seen and Camomile, does strengthen the brain and
senowes, being washed therewith. 5 The same used any way, strengthens the
sight and hearing. 6 It would be taken with a good deal of broth of a Cock
or a Hen, or wether mutton, or veale: or steeped in wheye with spike of
India, and after sodden, and so streined and taken. 7 Or the powder may be
taken which sweet milk. 8 There may be put half an ounce or more to every
gallon of Beer before the tunning up, for them that be melancholy. 9 It may
be mixed with syrope of Roses solutiue, and so drunk. 10 But the best way is,
to steep it in cold wine or wheye, or distilled water with a piece of sugar
and some Aniseedes all night in a close pot, and in the morning to streine it
and drink it. 11 But if it be sodden with herbs agreeable for the sickness
that it is taken for: then the herbs must be sodden tender before it be put
in. 12 Or use it thus: Take Seen six drams, white Ginger one dram, the flowers
of Buglosse two drams, put them into a clean pot with a pint of wheye of
goats milk close stopped, and let it into a vessel of seething water two
hours, then cool it and streine it, and drink it in the morning against all
griefs of the the head and brain, and so to the bottom of the bladder, and
to help all the senses, hearing, seeing and smelling, and to strengthen all
the body, and to take away all hurtful humors, and to cleanse the blood. 13
Seen is the best of all purging medicines. 14 Wash one dram and a half of the
leaves, and sees them in a new earthen pot with wine or water, as the disease
requires, with twelve cloves, and one raze of Ginger sliced, Aniseedes and
Fenell seeds, of each two drammes: boil more then the third part away, then
streine it, and put sugar to it, and drink thereof morn and even a reasonable
draught four hours before and after meat, it works without danger in all
men, women and children, and women with child, and of all ages. 15 Some put
thereto a little bruised Rubarbe, to make it work more effectually. 16 One
dram of the powder taken with the broth of a Hen, works the same effect. 17
Heart feeble of replection, take two drammes of powder of Seen with Pease broth
blood warm morn and even twice a week, it helps also the fever quotidian.
18 Stomach and belly windy, take Seen three ounces, Ginger half an ounce,
Aniseedes and Cumminseedes ana three penny weight, mix their powder, and take
thereof one spoonefull daily. 19 Costinenesse, sees it with Raisins the stones
taken out, in white wine or wheye, and streine it and drink it, six spoones
full at once: or steep one ounce and a half in a quart of white wine four
and twenty hours, and sees away the third part, then streine it, and put
thereto one dram of powder of Ginger, and drink thereof a pretty draught in
the morning. 20 Itch, sees a handful in water of Roses and smallach, and a
little vinegar, and wash therewith. 21 Steep eight ounces in three pintes of
white wine four and twenty hours, then streine it and put thereto Currants
two pound, fine sugar one pound, boil it till the wine be consumed, and take
one ounce or a little more of the Currants before meat when the body is
stiptike. 22 Chollike, Stone, Dropsy, Strangurie and Iaundies, take Seen half
an ounce, Ginger, Aniseedes, Licoras, Nettle seed, Iet and Saffron, of each
one penny weight, seeds of Fennel, Carway and Spinnel, of each one penny weight,
Cinamome three peniweight: use the powder of them when need is, in possit ale
or potage: proved. 23 Sees two drams of good Seen, and one dram of bruised
Aniseedes in half a pint of the broth of a chicken or pullet, till the better
half be wasted, then streine it and drink it in the morning warm, to purge
the body: or take one dram of the powder, with half a dram of Aniseede with
potage, and eat your dinner upon it. 24 Seen is good for the falling
sickness, the snicopye, the griefs of the milt, the Emerods, and the fever
quarten, being boiled in water, and made into a syrope with sugar, or with the
juice of Borage, made into a syrope or oximell made therewith, with vinegar and
Honey, for all the griefs aforesaid.

Beer 8 Belly bound 19. 21 Belly windy 18 Blood to cleanse 12 Brain grief 4

Setwall.
SEtwall, garden Valerian, or Phue: The decoction of the roots provoke vrin
and terms, and helps the ach of the side and stomach, and so does the
powder drunk in wine. 2 They are used in Antidotes and medicines against
poison and the plague, as in treacle and mithridate. 3 The leaves and roots of
the great wild valerian boiled in water, do heal the vlceration of the
mouth, and the inflammation and roughness of the throat, being washed and
gargarised therewith, and it is good for the^ that be bursten inwardly. 4 The
Greek or small Valerian is good for cuts and wounds. 5 Setwall does heat and
drive forth water, used in broth or powder: it is called of some Herba
benedicta, and is not much inferior to Nard of India: but for the stone it is
better. 6 Sees it in wine with Fennel seeds and Masticke, and drink it for
the chollike and stone. 7 Phue drunk in wine, is good against venomous bitings
and the plague, not only drunk, but also smelled unto. 8 The decoction
drunk, helps the strangury. 9 And sodden with Aniseedes, Lycoras and
Raisins, it is good against the straitness of the wind. 10 The root chewed,
drives away windiness. 11 The whole green plant bruised and anointed on the
head, takes away ache and pritching thereof. 12 The wine wherein it is sodden,
dropped into the eyes, is good against their griefs. 13 It is good in potions
against inward wounds. 14 The dried roots laid among clothes, gives them a
sweet smell. 15 Drink powder of the root of Phue or Valetian, to provoke
vrin and terms, and for the pain in the back: or sees it in wine, and so it
helps also the strangury, and dropping of the urine. 16 Sees the root with
Aniseedes, Fennelseedes, and Lycoras, and drink it against shortness of
breath and the cough. 17 Stamp the herb and root, and apply it to the
headache, and to Byles or red apostumes, ulcers, sores, pyles, wounds and such
like, to heal them. 18 Eyes griefs and diseases of the head and brain, use
Valerian in broths and drinks. 19 Belly griefs, chew Setwall, and swallow it
fasting. 20 Fistula, put in powder of Setwall and spurge roots, to heal it
speedily. 21 Iaundies, sees Setwall in white wine, and drink it. 22 Flowers
to stop, stamp it and streine it with ale, and drink it: seven leaves the
first day, five the next day, and three the third day, fasting. 23 Palsy, to
kill it, drink powder of the root of Valerian, and forbear swines flesh. 24
Sees Setwall in wine and drink it, to help the swelling in the flank. 25
Brain moist, chewe Setwall. 26 Heart weak, use Setwall in thy meats and
brothes in powder. 27 Valerian is good to be used in baths, to cause sweat. 28
Fever quotidian, hang the green root of Valerian about thy neck, till it be
dry. 29 Chewe Setwall with Reisins and a little Lycoras, to preserve thee from
the plague. 30 Pricks to draw out, whether it be iron or wood, put in the
juice, and stamp the herb, and apply it as often as need is. 31 Pricks in
wounds, put in the juice with cents, and apply the substance. 32 Setwall
takes away the smell of Garlike, Onyons, Leekes, etc. 33 Valerian sodden in
wine, and drunk fasting, helps the Iaundies, and the griefs of the Liver
and Milt. 34 Setwall roots preserve from the plague. 35 Eyes spots, boil the
flowers and roots of Valerian in wine, and drop it into the eyes: distill it in
the midst of August in a Lymbecke, and apply it hot with linen clothes to the
plurisie, and also drink thereof. 36 Falling evil, drink Valerian fasting.
37 Vomiting, drink it with Yarowe, (See sores in Broom.) 38 Sores to skin,
anoint with the juice of Valerian.

Shepherds needle.
SHepherds needle, or wild Cheruile, called Scandix: being eaten, it is good
for the stomach and belly. 2 The same boiled and drunk, opens the stopping
of the liver, milt, kidneys and bladder, and is good for all the inner parts
and bowels of man, and provoke urine.

Belly griefs 1 Bladder griefs 2 Kidneys stopped 2 Liver stopped 2 Milt stopped 2
Sickness general 2 stomach griefs 1 Urine stopped 2
Skirwits.
SKirwits: The roots boiled, are good for the stomach, provoke appetite, and
expel urine. 2 The juice of the root drunk with Goats milk, stops the
laske. 3 The same drunk with wine, expels wind, and helps the gripings
of the belly, and the Hicket.

Appetite 1 Belly ach 3 Flux 2 Hicket 3 Urine stopped 1 Windiness 3
Skabious.
SKabious boiled by it self, or with the root in wine or water and drunk,
does cleanse the breast and lungs, and is good for the old cough and
impostumes of the breast and other inward parts, in cleansing, ripening, and
sodring them: and so do the conserve of the flowers made with sugar, being used
daily. 2 It is good against all itch and skurfe, being stamped and applied, or
mixed with oils or ointments fit for it. 3 The Lee wherein it has been
boiled or steeped, does cleanse the hair from all branne and white skurfe,
the head being washed with it. 4 The decoction of Iacea nigra gargled, or the
mouth often washed with it, does waste and consume the apostumes in the mouth
and throat, that are fresh and new, and does ripe and break them that are
old. 5 The broth or juice of Scabious, used inward or outward, heals skabs
and itch: it is good for all diseases of the breast and lungs, and to be
applied to pestilent sores, to ripen them and break them with speed. 6 Drink
the water in the plague time with Mithridate in the mornings to preserve thee.
7 It stops the bloody-fluxe and the Emerods. 8 Eye pricked, or bleeding, drop
in the juice to heal it. 9 Ear moist and running, drop in the juice. 10 Sees
it in wine, and drink it to dry up superfluous moisture. 11 Frogs delight to
be under it. 12 Sees it in wine and drink it to help the plurisie, the
griefs of the breast, impostume, the cough, and all griefs of the chest. 13
Take a handful of dried Scabious, Licoras scraped and bruised one ounce,
Aniseedes and Fenell seeds ana one ounce, Figs xii. Irios half an ounce,
steep them twelve hours in a pottell of water, then sees it till ye third
part or somewhat more be wasted, then streine it and put thereto sugar or honey
of Roses, and drink thereof hot morn and even to ripen and soften
impostumes, and to cause them to be easily spit out with coughing. 14 The juice
is good for all manner of scabs, skurfe, mandge, and all such like, being washed
therewith. 15 It is good in glisters against the bloody-fluxe. 16 The leaves
stamped and applied, represseth the Emerods, and the bruised wound, or mystie
eyes, and dry up the blood of wounds. 17 The juice kills worms. 18 Sit over
the fume of the decoction thereof in wine to help the Emerods. Plague sore,
anoint it with the juice. 19 Bruises to cure, drink ii. spoonefull of the
juice of Comfrey and Scabious morn and even. 20 Heart griefs, stamp
Scabious, and streine it with stale ale, and drink it morn and even ix. or x.
days. 21 Morphue, distill water of Scabious and Fumiterie, and use it. 22
Pockes and measels in children, if you fear blindness thereby, hang Scabious
and Rue about their necks. (See in Pimpernell and Rue, Dock, Fumiterie.) 23
Squincie, mix one pound of Scabious water with one ounce of aqua vitae, and
apply thereof to the grief as often as need is. 24 Impost. boil the juice
with as much strong ale, and drink thereof warm: proved. Or drink the juice
with as much aqua vitae, and some powder of Coral. Or wash one pound of the
roots and stamp them and streine them with ale, and drink it with powder of
Coral. 25 Impost. general, drink one sponefull of the powder, with adraught
of small ale. 26 Squincy, mix one pound of Scabious water withone ounce of
aqua vitae, and apply it, and also gargle therewith to be whole in iii. hours.
27 Emerods, stamp it and apply it, or boil it with the root of Mullin, and
apply it. 28 Scabs, boil the juice with vinegar and oil, till it wax thick,
and use it. 29 Emerods, sees it in water, and sit over it. 30 Stamp it and
seethe it in wine, and drink it to destroy humors in the stomach. 31 Drink
it daily fasting with Eye bright, and the pestilence shall never breed in thee
while thou do use it. 32 Liver griefs, sees it in wine and drink it. 33
Scabs general dry and moist, mix the juice with vinegar and ashes of garlike,
and seethe it together and anoint. 34 Impost. to break, drink the juice of it
and Rue with powder of Coral a good draught. 35 Water imperial, precious above
all others, take Scabious, Dittany, Pimpernell, and Tormentill, of each like
much, distill it, it helps all poison and the plague being drunk. 30 For the
plague if one be infected, mix water of Betony and Scabious of each like much
with good Treacle, and drink thereof to expel the poison from the principal
parts, and to save life, (see Matfelon.)

Sloes.
SLoes, (see Plum, Acatia.) Belly-ache, drink the juice with wine. 2 Breast
pain, stamp good store of ripe Sloes, and put them in an earthen pot, and
fill it with new ale, and so drink it. 3 To avoid dead flesh, boil the
bark in water till it be black and thick, and put thereto Rye meal and
honey, and apply it. 4 Eyes tears, stamp ye green bark with a little vinegar,
and put thereof into the eyes, and be whole in iii. days. 5 Urine to stop,
seethe the bark in water and drink it. Fleaes to void, seethe it in water,
and sprinckle the house with it. 6 Canker, sees ye bark in water tender till
it be thick and black, and mix it with Rye meal and honey, and apply it,
(see Rye.) Sees a quart of Sloes in a pottell of vinegar, till it be wasted,
then dry them and put thereof into wine, and it will be vinegar presently. The
moss with Swines grease draws out pricks.

Belly-ache 1 Breast pain 2 Dead flesh 3 Eyes tears 4 Fleaes to void 5
Kanker 6 Pissing bed 5 Pricks 6
Smallache.
SMallache, or Marsh Parsley, the seeds and roots in working are like to the
seeds and roots of garden Parsley. 2 The juice does cleanse corrupt and
festring sores especially in the mouth and throat, mixed with other things fit
for ye same purpose. 3 Frenzy, sees it in wine and wash thy head therewith. 4
Eyes griefs, put in the juice with the white of an egg at night. 5 Eyes itche
and hawe, mix the juice with soote, and the white of an egg, and let it stand
24. hours, and then anoint therewith, and wash thine eyes. 6 Teeth-ache, hang
ye root about thy neck. 7 Worms, drink the seeds. 8 Emerods, dip a cloth
in pitch, and cast thereon powder of the root and Masticke, and apply it. 9
Flowers to stop, put in powder of Ceruse and Smallache. 10 Paps swollen, apply
the juice with crumbs of bread. 11 Cough dry, (See Fenell.) Bladder griefs,
(see Fenell.) 12 Belly grinding, (see Peniroyall.) 13 Iliake passion, boil
wheat branne with the juice of Smallache, gylts grease, and butter, and apply
it to the pain of cold cause. 14 Fever cold, stamp one dram of the seeds,
and steep it all night in iii. sponefull of cold water, and drink it when the
fit has taken thee. 15 Apost. (see Barley.) Fester, (see Hempseede, Rye.) 16
Wounds ache, make little cakes of ye juice of Smallache, honey, and wheat flower
and oil, and fry it in a pan, and apply it, or mix the juice with honey and
wax, whites of eggs, and wheat meal, and use it. 17 Stomach griefs, (See
Flax.) 18 Gout ache, (See Otes. 19 Backe-ache, (See Egrimonie.) 20 Breast
griefs, stamp one handful of Smallache with as much sour bread by it self,
or with vinegar, and apply it iii. or iiii. times to the breast to avoid heat
of the breast, thirst, and stopping of the head. Breast strait. (See Centory.)
21 Burnings, (See Eldren.) Headache, (See Betony.) 22 Sleep to cause, (See
Lettufe.) 23 Belly-ache, See Peniroyall.) 24 Fever, bruise Smallache one
handful with as much Bay salt, and as much Olibanum as a Walnut, and divide it
into iiii. parts, and apply them one after another to ye bought of the arm
iiii. times before the fit. 25 Breast griefs, seethe the seeds with Licoras
in small ale or water, and drink it, (See Rye.) 26 Fry sheep suet, or
deares suet with sheep doung, and the juice of Smallache, for any burned
place. 27 Falling evil, drink the juice of Smallache, and thou shall not fall
that day, (See Sauine.) 28 Gout, mix Smallache with oil of Roses and milk,
and anoint. 29 Impost. eat Auens and Smallache till it break, and the matter
come forth, See Mustardseede.) 30 Matrix suffoc. apply the juice of Smallache,
Hysope, Wormwood, hot to the nauel with a cloth to be whole: proved. 32 Mouth
griefs, eat Smallache often: proved. 33 Nose bleeding, drink the juice of
Smallache. 34 Pappes swollen, mix honey and powder of Cummin with the juice of
Smallache, and of Onions, and crummes of Ote bread, and apply it. 35 Swelling,
apply the juice of Smallache with wheat meal. 36 Reines-ache, drink the
seeds fasting with hot wine. 37 Side grief, drink the juice. 38 Strangury,
drink the juice with red wine, (See Fenell,) 29 Or sees ye roots of
Smallach, Parsley, Fenell, and Watercresses in white wine, and drink the
broth, and apply the roots with Watercresse leaves. 30 Urine stopped, drink the
decoction of the seeds of Carway and Smallache. 31 Sleep to cause, dip a
spondge in the juice of Smallache and woman's milk, and apply it to the
temples. 32 Wounds to cleanse, apply ye juice with beane-meale and honey 33
Wou^ds-ache, apply the juice with old swines grease and Rye meal. 34 Sweat
to cause, use Smallache in bathes. Liver griefs, sees Liuerwort with the
juice of Smallache in wine or water, and drink. 35 Urine to cause, stamp
Parsley, Smallache, and Fenell, of each like the reins and greines, or chop
Smallache small, as much as two fistes, with as much Wheat branne, and seethe
it in water till it wax dry, and apply it to the bladder as often as need
is. 46 The herb and seed is good for the strangurie. (see Parsley.) 47 Fever
flegmatike, make an Electuarie of the juice of Clary, Smallache, and Fenell,
and use it. 48 Stomach hot and swollen, stamp the roots, and seethe it in
wine or ale, and streine it and drink a little of it every morning ix. days
fasting, (see Fenell, Betonie.) 49 Spitting blood, drink Smallache, Betony,
Mints, and Rue with Goats milk hot as may be suffered. 50 Breast ranckled,
(see Flax.) 51 Liver stopped, (see Eldren, Aloes.) Bladder grief, (see Betony.)
52 Ache, stamp it and streine it, and boil it with aqua vitae, and bores
grease, and stir them well, and anoint therewith by the fire morn and even:
proved. (see Fenell.) 54 Eyes running, stamp it with the white of an Eg, and
apply it, (see Feuerfue.) 55 Bladder pain, seethe it in wine, ale, or broth,
and drink it with powder of wild Cummin. 56 Bruises about the ears, stamp
the seeds, and as much Ceruse with honey and apply it, or anoint. 57 Chollike,
(see Mugwort.) To dry up milk in the breasts, use Smallache, or ye seeds of
it in thy meats, (see Agnus Castus.) 58 Ache in the shoulder blade, stamp the
seeds and drink them with wine. 59 To void wrath, and cause joy, drink
Smallache often. 60 Bleeding to stop, drink the juice. 61 Frenzy, wash thy
head often times of the day with the juice of Smallache and vinegar, but most of
the vinegar. 62 Eyes bloody, apply the juice with the white of an Egg. 63 Eyes
itche, mix the juice with good wine, and let it stand a day, and then wash the
eyes therewith. 64 Throat apostume or swollen, apply the juice with crumbs of
bread and honey. 65 Sores, (see Broom.) 66 Black Iaundies, (see Celondine.) 67
Stomach hot and swollen, stamp the root, and steep it 24. hours in good
wine, and streine it and drink a little oil of it 8. or 9. mornings, (see
Betony.) 68 Wounds and cuts to heal, mix ye juice of Smallache with ye white
of an Egg, wheat flower, and powder of incense till it be thick, and apply
it once a day daily. 69 Stomach griefs general, drink the seeds of
Smallache, Linseedes, and Cummin with hot water. 70 Belly windy, drink
Smallache seeds with wine fasting. 71 For cold humors in the stomach and
griefs of the liver and lungs, drink powder of the seeds of Smallache, of
Rue, and pepper with wine. 72 Smallache heals wounds, cease burning aching
and ranckling of wounds, and is good for the fever tertian. 73 Wounds of al
sorts, apply the juice of Smallache and Planten with wheat flower, 74 Dropsy,
seethe the roots of Smallache, Fenell, Parsley, of each like much, and make
thereof a syrup with sugar, honey, and wort, and drink it morn and even
daily. Vncome, (see Rue.) 75 Fever quotidian, (See Feuerfue.)

Smirnium.
SMirnium: The leaves and root do appease the cough and difficulty of
breathing: they stop ye belly, and are very good against all venomous bitings,
and the stopping of the urine. 2 The seed is good against the diseases and
stopping of the milt, kidneis, and bladder. It expels the terms, seconds,
and urine. 3 The leaves applied do dissolve wennes and hard swellings that be
new. It dries up sores and exulcerations, and gleweth wounds together. 4 The
seeds drunk in wine, are good against the sciatica and stays windines of ye
stomach, provoke sweat, and is very good for the dropsy and fevers that
come by fifts: it is called wild Alisander.

Biting venom. 1 Bladder griefs 2 Breath short 1 Cough 1 Dropsy 4 Fevers 4
Flowers stopped 2 Flux 1 Hardness 3 Kidneis griefs 2 Milt griefs 2 Sciatica 4
Seconds 2 Sores 3 Stomach windy 4 Swellings 3 Venom 1 Urine stopped 1. 2 Wennes 3
Wounds 3
Soldanella.
SOldanella purges down all kind of watrish humors, and opens the stoppings
of the liver, and is good for the dropsy, but it must be boiled with the broth
of fat meat or flesh and drunk, or else dried and taken in powder with
Aniseedes, Cinamom, Ginger, and great store of sugar. 2 The leaves applied do
bind and close up wounds, and drive away broad inflammations and swellings.

Dropsy 1 Inflammation 2 Liver griefs 1 Purgation 1 Swellings 2 Wounds 2
Sorrel.
Sorrel, (See Alleluya.) Drink Sorrel with Smallache or small wine to help
the Iaundies to quench burning Fevers. 2 The leaves eaten fasting in ye
mornings in ye plague time, is most wholesome. 3 Liver chafte, knead thy bread
with the juice of Sorrel and Liuerwort, and eat it and apply the dross of the
same herbs to the place. 4 Vomit to stop, drink Sorrel, 5 Liver and stomach
hot, the hot fever, and to cause appetite, drink the juice or water of
Sorrel. 6 Thirst great, sup ye juice. 7 Headache, stamp it with oil of
Roses and apply it, see Barley.) Liver, (see Fenell.) 8 Liver and milt stopped,
and for the Iaundies, use the juice or syrup of Sorrel and Wormwood. 9
Breasts sore and running, apply Sorrel de Boys roasted in a Wortleafe with
vinegar and honey. 10 Fever burning, drink Sorrel possitale, hot as may be
suffered. 11 Iaundise of hot cause, drink the juice. 12 Ringworme or tetter,
cut ye roots very small, and steep them in strong white vinegar 48. hours,
and rub therewith iii. or iiii. times a day, and keep them in the vinegar. 13
To heal the itche, boil the roots and wash therewith. 14 Gomor passion,
carry the seeds on thee gathered by a chaste boy. 15 Phlegm to void, (see
Betony.) 16 Iaundies, seethe it and the root thereof in white wine and drink
it. 17 Plague, (see Pimpernell.) Drink the water with one dram of ye root of
Tormentill, and half a dram of Treacle. 18 Bloody-fluxe, drink the juice with
wine. Sweating sickness, (see Sage.) 19 Flux red or yellowe, eat the seeds
with roasted Eggs. 20 Fevers hot, use Sorrel. Wild fire, and S. Ant. fire,
roast it in a wet cloth half an hour, and grind it finely with clarified honey
and apply it. 21 Bitings venomous and rancklings, stamp it and apply it, and
also drink it. 22 Sores hot with dead flesh in them, roast it in a paper, and
apply it thrice to heal it. 23 Iaundies, drink ye juice of Sorrel and
Yarrowe with good ale and saffron iii. or iiii. times to cure it. 24 Sneesing
in children to stop, anoint their hand with the juice of Sorrel. 25 Eyes
yellow by the Iaundies, put in the juice of Acedula or small Sorrel. 26 Liver
hot, use Sorrel. 27 Mix Sorrel with hearts grease and barley meal, and
apply it to the temples for the headache. For the stopping and wasting of the
liver, use Sorrel with some Wormwood in brothes and drinks. 28 Liver
wasting, sees Sorrel, Water cresses, and red Fenel with a chickin in an earthe^
pot, and use it ix. days. 29 Knees-ach and swelling, apply Sorrel and
Smallach with vinegar and sheep suet boiled together. 30 Fevers, drink
Sorrel possitale made by putting the juice to milk when it begins to
sees. 31 Vomiting to stop, drink the juice or water, it helps ye
inflammation of ye liver, and quenches great thirst. 32 Botch to break, roast
it in a Wortleafe and apply it. 33 Bloody-fluxe, drink ye juice with wine. 34
Stone to break, and to help the Iaundies, and to expel urine and the terms,
use the roots.

Sothernwood.
SOthernwood, the seed either green, or dry, in powder, or boiled in wine or
water, and drunk, helps shortness of breath, streitenesse of wind, and
hardness, burstings, and shrinkings of the sinews, the sciatica, stopping of
the urine and terms, and all cold moisture, tough phlegm, and stopping of the
milt, kidneis, bladder and matrix. 2 And drunk in wine, it is good against all
poison and venom, and destroys worms. 3 The perfume or smell of it drives
away all venomous beasts, 4 The ashes mixed with oil of Palma Christi, or of
rapes, or of raddish, or old oil olive, restores hair, the head being
anointed with it twice a day against the sun or fire, and causes the bearde
to come forth speedily. 5 Stamp Sothernwood with a roasted quince, and apply
it to all inflammations of the eyes. 6 Stamp it with barley meal, and seethe
them together, and apply it to dissolve all cold humors and swellings. 7
Steep it in oil and anoint all members taken or benumbed with cold, and
bruises, and shiuerings of agues. 8 Lay it under thy bed, pillow or bolster, to
provoke carnal copulation. and resist all enchantments letting the same. 9
Eyes burning, and swelling, Seethe with white bread in water, and apply it, 10
The juice mixed with oil of Dill, causes hair to grow in any place of the
body. 11 The juice drunk with Wine, defends from the Apoplexia. Palsy,
anoint with the juice. 12 Boil the herb with Quince kernels to dissolve
apostumes and flegmatike humors. 13 Boil it in oil Olive and anoint the head
to avoid all intemperate coldness of it. 14 Boil it with with Wine and
Sugar, and drink it to heat the stomach. Boil it with Parsley and sugar,
and drink it to break and expel the stone of the bladder and kidneys. 15 The
oil of it anointed beneath the nauill, expels urine. 16 The herb drunk
with Wine helps against poisons, and bytings of venomous beasts and worms.
17 The root drunk often, kills the worms, and so does the juice drunk
with a little milk. 18 Seethe the herb with ysope, licoras, or sugar in
Wine, and drink it for the griefs of the lungs and breast. 19 Bruise the
herb with oil and salt, and apply it to the pulses of the hands, as a
remedy against the fever. 20 Seethe the tops of the flowers in Wine, or
water, with honey or sugar, and drink it three or four times a day to help
shortness and straitenesse of the breath, to cleanse out the griefs of the
breast, to help the Cardiacke passion, and the Cough, to cleanse out the
humors of the lunges, kidneys, matrix and bladder, to help the dropping of
the urine, and to cease all inward griefs. 21 Stomach weak, apply the
herb in a linen bag somewhat dried, to comfort it. 22 Sciatica and Gout
in any place, bruise it with butter or oil, or both, and seethe them in wine
till the wine be consumed, then streyne it, and anoint therewith, or drink
the juice of Sothernwood warm with wine. 23 Breath short, seethe it in wine
and drink it. 24 Forehead ache, and Vertigo, stamp it with honey and vinegar,
and drink it. 25 Mouth ulcers, stamp it with honey and anoint both inward
and outward. 26 Speaking in sleep, drink it with wine. 27 Flowers to stop,
stamp it and drink it with red wine. 28 Backe-ache, stamp it with vinegar
and salt, and apply it hot. 29 Ears worms, put in the juice. 30 Hair
falling, seethe the bark in water, and wash therewith. 31 Speech lost, (See
Irios) Women's secret griefs, use it with ale. 32 Chollicke, apply a plaster
of it and Wormwood with vinegar, honey, and barley meal. 33 Stone, (See
Parietarie.) Hair to grow, wash with Lee of the ashes of it. 34 Head giddie,
drink it. Prick, stamp it with fresh grease, and apply it. 35 Hair to
restore, mix the ashes with oil of raddish, and anoint the balde place. 36
Speaking in sleep, and for the Vertigo, and swimming in the head, drink it to
bedward with wine and a little honey. (See Betony, Rue. 37 Wits lost, drink the
juice with stale ale. Belliach, (see Rue. 38 Drink powder of the seeds against
al venomous bitings, and of the herb to kill worms. 39 Powder of the herb
with barley meal, breaks hard apostumes. 40 Headache, stamp it with vinegar,
and honey, and apply it. 41 Face salseflegme, eat tansie and Sothernwood. 42
Frenzy, stamp Marigold, Sothernwood, and sage, and strein it, and drink it
with Wine or ale six days morn and even. Worms, drink it and tansie with
posset-ale. 43 Sothernwood is good for the Cough and gnawing in the belly and
breast, griefs of the bones, and stopping of the urine, the seed being
stamped with water and drunk. 44 Sides grief, stamp it with Betonie and
drink it. 45 Bitings venomous, and for the cold Fever, drink it with wine.
46 Teeth-ach, seethe it in vinegar, and hold it in thy mouth.

Sowbread.
SOwbread, drink a dram or a dram and a half of the powder of the root with
Hydromel to purge gross and tough phlegm, and other sharp humors. 2 Bitings
venomous, and all poison, apply it, and also drink it with wine. 3 For the
stopping of the liver, the Iaundies, and to avoid the yellow color, drink it
with Hydromel, and cover thee well to sweat. 4 To expel the flowers and dead
child, drink it, or use it as a pessary. 5 Belly bound, struck the nauel and
the belly with the juice, or put it into the fundament with wool. 6 Fundament
fallen, anoint it with the juice and vinegar to settle in the natural place it.
7 Eyes spots, pearls, hawes, and al other impediments, and to clear the
sight, put in the juice with honey. 8 The root makes the skin fair and clean,
and voideth all naughty skurf and maunge, the falling of the hair, the marks
and spots of the pocks and masels, and all other blemishes. 9 The same or the
juice mixed with ointment or oiles for the same purpose, wastes the hardness
of the milt. 10 Apply it with oil and vinegar to heal wounds. 11 Ioints out,
heels kibed, Gout in the feet, and skurf of the head, wash with the broth or
decoction of the root. 12 The oil wherein the root has been boiled, closes
up wounds, and with the same and a little wax, a good ointment is made for
kibes, chilblains, and griefs coming of cold. 13 The root hanged upon women in
travel, causes speedy deliverance. 14 In what sort soever this root be
taken, it is dangerous for women with child, or if it be but carried about them,
or that they tread over it. 15 If it be put into wine, it makes a man
drunken, a juice is pressed out of the root, and sodden to the thickness of
honey, and so kept. 16 The root is sliced and laid up as Squilla is. 17 Head
sores, or whelks, use the decoction thereof. 18 Iaundies, stamp the root of
Sowbread and gladen, and drink the juice, or sit in the decoction of them. 19
Emerodes, mix the juice with powder of Agaricke, and hot oil, and apply it.
20 Nose stink, put in the water of Sowbread.

griefs 8. 17 Iaundies 3. 18 Joints out 11 Kibes 11. 12 Liver stopped 3 Masels 8.
9 Milt hard 9 Nose stink 20 Poison 2 Pocks 8. 9 Skin griefs 8 Wounds 10. 12
Sowthistle.
SOwthistle, Stomach pain, drink the juice. It also provoke urine, breaks
the stone, and is excellent good for the strangurie, and the Iaundies, it
ingendreth good store of good milk, and causes the child that sucketh it to
have a good color, and so does the broth wherein it is sodden, being drunk.
2 The juice does cool the heat of the fundament, and privy parts, being
applied with cotton, and of the ears being dropped in. 3 Stamp the green
leaves, and apply them to all hot swellings, and apost. especially of the
stomach. 4 Bitings venomous, stamp the leaves and roots, and apply them. 5
Great hawkweed, wild cicorie, yellow devils bit be of the same operation, and
are good also for the eyesight, the juice being dropped in, especially devils
bit.

Apostume hot 3 Bitings venomous 4 Eyes dull 5 Ears heat 2 Fundament heat 2
Iaundies 1 Matrix heat 2 Milk to cause 1 Stomach apostume 3 Stone 1
Strangurie 1 Swellings 3 Urine stopped 1
Sparewort.
SParewort, stamp it and apply it in half a walnut shell seven or eight
hours to the sciatica, to rear a blister, then let it out, and apply a leaf
of burre or colewort. 2 To avoid dead flesh, apply it with honey and rye meal.
3 Ach in the arm, shoulder or leg, blister it with Sparewort, and lay on an
Iuie leaf, to draw out the humor. 4 Anoint the pulses with the juice to cure
the fever. 5 It breaks botches and biles. (See Crowfoot.

Apostume 5 Arm ache 3 Ach general 1. 3 Byle 5 Botch 5 Dead flesh 2 Fever 4
Leg ache 3 Shoulder ache 3 Sores 2
Sperage.
SPerage helps the kings evil and the strangurie and palsy. 2 The seeds and
fruit are used in medicine, and will be kept in virtue four years. 3 Eat
Sperach with meat for the stopping of the liver and hardness of the milt. 4
Seethe the root in wine, and drink it for the shedding of the gall. 5 Wash the
mouth often with the decoction of Sperage to cease al ye pain of the mouth and
teeth. 6 Eat Sperage with cummin for swelling of the stomach, the chollicke, to
mend the sight, to losen the belly gently, to purge the breast, bowels and
reins, and to cause a good savor in all the body. 7 Seethe it in wine, and
drink it for the pain in the loins and reins. 8 Drink the root in white
wine for pain of the stone, and for pain of ye matrix. 9 Seethe the root in
vinegar to help the swelling, spots and leapry of the skin. 10 Parboile the
young springs and eat them with vinegar and oil, to provoke vrin, soften the
belly, and for the strangurie. 11 Sees it with cy^^pease, and drink the broth
to open the liver and kidneis, for the Iaundies, strangury, gravel, and stone,
to ease the pain of the sciatica, and members out of joint. 12 Bitings
venomous, boil the root in wine, and drink it. 13 Let barren women boil the
berries, and eat them with vinegar, sweet oil and sugar to become fruitful.
14 The water of the herb clears the eyes. 15 The syrop causes natural
seed. 16 The decoction with vinegar helps the white leprie. 17 No herb is
sooner converted into good blood, then Asparagus. 18 Roasted or sodden it
asswageth the strangurie, the difficulty in making water, and the bloody
flux. 19 The root sodden with vinegar or wine helps members out of joint.
20 And sodden with figs and cyches, it heals the iaundies, the sciatica,
and strangury. 21 Teeth ach, stamp the root and apply it. 22 Fever quarten,
seethe the root in water and drink thereof seven days.

Spinach.
SPinach, Loins ache, use pottage made with barley, and Spinach, and butter. 2
Seethe it and eat it with meat to soften the belly, and to avoid the pain
of the breast and lungs, to qualify choler, to cleanse the body, and
strengthen the stomach. 3 Drink the decoction of it to expel evil humors,
to cause easy breathing. 4 But too much use of it, and lettise breeds
melancholy: drink the broth against grievous pain of the back, and for the
pain of the throat, coming of Choler and blood. 5 Spinach softeneth the
belly, helps the roughness and hoarsnesse of the throat, and the dry
cough. 6 Drink the juice or water to quench heat, and mitigate the gnawing of
the stomach. 7 Apply the bruised herb to the stomach and liver, against
their ach and inflammation. 8 The same is good against stingings of venomous
beasts, (See Beets. 9 It is evil for flegmatike people. 10 Apply it to hot
swellings to dissolve them.

Splenwort.
SPlenwort, or Lonchitis, is very good against the hardness, stopping, and
swelling of the milt, being drunk, or applied with vinegar. 2 Apply it to
wounds to keep them from apostumation and inflammation.

Spurge.
SPurge, (See Palma Christi, Tithimal. 2 Six or eight seeds of it do purge
choler, phlegm, and watrish humors mightily, and so does the juice, but it
is stronger in operation, it is of the very nature and faculty of Tithimal,
and must be used as is said of Tithimal. 3 Seven seeds taken with figs or
dates purge the belly, and so does the leaves sodden with a cock. Fistula,
and hollow ulcers, Seethe it in wine, and put it in. (See Setwal, Tithimal. 4
Teethach, mix the milk thereof with wheat-floure, and fill the hollow tooth
therewith, and seethe the root in wine and wash therewith morn and even, every
month once, and you shall have no pain. 5 Take nine crops pulled upward in
powder with ale to purge upward, and drink some warm ale soon after it, and
after use some restoratiue. 6 The milk with wheat-meale makes the skin white.
Teeth, (See Iuie.) Drink three grains with sugar clean pilled, to loosen the
belly, three or four leaves seeds with warm water cause vomit, and so
does the juice.

Choler 1 Fistula 3 Phlegm 2 Purgation 2. 3 Skin to cleanse 6 Teethach 4
Ulcers hollow 3 Vomit to cause 5
Squilla.
SQuilla, being first covered round about with dowe, or lapped in paste, and
baked in an oven, or roasted in the embers till it be tender, and a spoonefull
thereof taken with an eight part of salt, purges downewarde plenty of tough
and clammie humors, and use the same so prepared in medicines, to provoke
urine, for the dropsy, Iaundies, belching, or woorking of the stomach, and
gryping of the belly. 2 Take it with honey and oil to drive out worms, both
long and round. 3 The same so prepared, is good for the old cough, shortness
of breath, stuffing of the breast, and to cleanse the breast. 4 Mix it with
honey to losen the belly very gently, and so does the seeds taken with
figs or honey. 5 A scale or twain of the root, being yet green and raw,
is good to be laid under the tongue to quench thirst in the dropsy. 6 Seethe
Squilla in vinegar till it be tender, and stamp it, and apply it to all
venomous bytings being stamped. 7 Boil the inner part of Squilla in oil or
turpentine, and apply it to chappes or riftes of the feet, to kibed heels,
and hanging warts, especially being roasted under the embers, and so it heals
all running sores of the head, and the skurfe, scales, or branne of the head,
being laid to. 8 The leaves do dissolve and waste the Kings evil, and
kernels about the throat, being applied four days. 9 Squilla hanged over
the door, or chief entry of the house, keeps the same from all mishap,
witchcraft and sorcerie. 10 When the flowers of Squilla be of a brownish
color, and do not soon fall or vade away, that year shall be very
fruitful and plentiful of corn. 11 Squilla may not be taken inward raw
but roasted, baked, or sodden, half a dram is sufficient to be taken at once
with honey, for the Iaundies, the old Cough, shortness of wind, and gnawing
in the body. 12 It is good for the headache, the falling sickness, disinesse
of the head, griefs of the sinews, breast, lunges and joints, especially
licked in with honey, it makes a clear voice, and so does the vinegar and
Oximel thereof. 13 It helps the hardness and and stopping, and swelling of
the milte. 14 It withstandeth putrefaction in the body, and therefore keeps
a man in health, and makes his body continue still in young state, but they
make a man lean. 15 The Squilla helps loose gummes, and the vinegar makes
the teeth fast, the mouth being washed therewith, voydeth stink of the mouth,
and causes a sweet breath, it stancheth ache of the stomach, it helps
digestion, and causes a good color. 16 It makes a loose body fast, and
compact howsoever it be taken. 17 The sodden drink of it may be taken from
ten drammes to three ounces. 18 The use of Squilla quickens the sight,
being taken with vinegar and honey, it kills worms. 19 Lick three half penny
weight of it with honey for the griefs of the stomach, when the meat
swimmeth therein, the dropsy, Iaundies, old cough, shortness of breath and
vomiting. 20 The vinegar, Oximel, and Loch. are good for the same purposes, and
to kill all manner of worms, to expel melancholy, to help the apoplexia, to
break and expel the stone, to cleanse the matrix, and to help the sciatica. 21
Where Squilla is placed, it keeps trees and plants from noyance. 22 Hickit,
take a spoonful of the vinegar of it. For ruptures in the feet or hands
through the French disease, divide it, and boil it in old oil till it be
tender, then grind it, to an ointment and anoint therewith. 23 Emerodes,
steep raw onions in Acetum Squilliticum, and apply them. 24 Milt hard, mix
the fat of a Crane with the vinegar, and anoint therewith after the coming
out of a bath.

Squinant.
SQuinant, which is like Date straw, the herb, flower, or root drunk with
pepper, does help the Dropsy, and is good for the lungs, milte, and reins
being used. 2 The root is good against the wind Chollicke, phlegm, and raw
matter in the body, or any member of the same, the powder thereof being drunk
with wine. 3 Drink one dram of the root with as much pepper a few days
against the loathing of the stomach, the dropsy and crampe. 4 The flowers are
good against voyding of blood, and pain of the stomach, lungs, liver, and
kidneys. 5 It makes the head heavy. 6 Matrix griefs general, use Squinant.

Stauesacre.
STauesacre, fifteen seeds taken with honied water causes to vomit gross
phlegm, and slimie matter with great violence. 2 The seed mixed with oil,
drives away lice, and cures all skuruie itche and maunginesse. 3 The seed
boiled in vinegar, and holden in the mouth, swageth the toothache. 4 The same
chewed in the mouth, purges the head and brain. 5 With vinegar it kills
lice, being rubbed on the apparel. 6 The seeds must be steeped in vinegar,
and dried, and the powder drunk with honied water, and the receiver of it must
walk continually, and drink honied water often, when he feels any kind of
choking, and so it will work without danger. 7 Mix the pap of sodden
Stauesacre with wine lees, and wash the head therewith against the ulcers and
skabbe, etc. 8 The seeds mixed with oil kills nits, and with oil and vinegar
it kills lice. 9 Stamp it with oil, and anoint swellings therewith,
especially about the nails, and all skurfe, skabbe, and leaprie, and to kill
Lice and nits both in man and beast. 10 Seethe it it in vinegar, and wash the
teeth therewith for their ach and losenesse, and to stopp rhewme. 11 With honey
it heals the sores of the mouth. 12 It cleanses the matrix being applied
plaisterwise. 13 Teethache, put in powder of Stauesacre, long pepper, and
Piretum into a linen bag, and chewe it between thy teeth, or use Stauesacre
only. 14 Dropsy, seethe it in water and drink the water. 15 Ears dull, seethe
it with raddish seeds, and wormwood, and dip tents therein, and put them in.
Fistula in the ear, boil powder of Stauesacre and Brionie in vinegar, and put
it in. 16 Gummes rotten, seethe Stauesacre in vinegar, and wash therewith. 17
Lice to kill, mix powder of it with black soap, and anoint therewith. 18 Head
to purge, hold the powder of it in a linen bag, and chewe it sometimes.
Head sores, seethe it in water with wine lees, and wash therewith. 20 Lice to
kill, mix it with oil and quicksiluer, and anoint. 21 Morphue, mix the
powder of it and Lytarge, and make a bathe, and wash therewith. 22 Dropsy;
seethe it with yssop in wine, and drink it. 23 Teethache, put the powder in a
cloute, and dippe it in aqua vitae, and apply it.

Stinking Horehound.
STinking Horehound: Dogbiting, stamp it with salt, and apply it. 2 Roste
the leaves in a Colewort leaf, and apply it to the swelling lumps in the
fundament. 3 With honey they purge filthy and found wounds, and cure rotten
ulcers. (See Horehound.

Spikenard.
SPikenard, (See Lauender.) It drives forth water, and causes to piss well,
it it be drunk: it stops the Belly. 2 If it be laid to, it stops the
coming out of matter from the matrix. 3 Taken with cold water, it helps the
gnawing of the stomach, it expels wind, helps the liver, the Iaundies,
and griefs of the kidneis, being sodden in water, and sitten over, it is good
for the inflammation of the matrix, it is good to restore hair to the eye
liddes, and to be cast upon bodies that sweat too much, and are moist. 4 It
is put into antibodies, and triacles, and it is commonly laid up in a new
earthen vessel for eye medicines, being first made into powder, and then into
round cakes, or trochiskes with wine. 5 French Spikenard is good for the
purposes aforesaid, it drives forth water more mightily, and is better for
the stomach, it helps inflammations of the Liver, and the Iaundies. 6 Drink
it with wine against the griefs of the milt, kidneis and bladder, and against
all venomous bytings. 7 Stomach windy, drink it with broth of Worm wood. 8
It is somewhat weaker then Nardus Indie, or else of like virtues in all things.
9 Use Spikenard to dry up the moisture of the dropsy. 10 Heart weak, sick,
and swoning, seethe it in wine, and make a syrop, and use it.

Belly loose 1 Bitings venomous 6 Bladder griefs 6 Dropsy 9 Heart griefs 10
Hair to grow 3 Iaundies 3. 5 Kidneys griefs 6 Liver griefs 3. 5 Matrix flux
2 inflamed 3
Milt griefs 6 Stomach ache 3. 7 Sweating much 3 Swooning 10 Vrin stopped 1
Windiness 3. 7
Stitchwort.
STtchwort: If a woman drink the seeds of it three days fasting, after she
has had her natural course, and that she happen to conceive within forty
days after, it shall be a manchild. 2 Sodden in wine, it breaks the stone, and
is good against the hardness of the milte, and stopping of the liver and gall,
it cleanses the reins, bladder, and passage of the urine. 3 The seed does
vehemently purge the urine, and stops vomiting. 4 Drink Stitchwort for
stitches. 5 Use it with other medicines for the dropsy. 6 It heals wounds
and sore eyes.

Back griefs 2. 3 Bladder stopped 2. 3 Conception 1 Dropsy 5 Eyes sore 6 Liver
stopped 2 Milt hard 2 Stitch 4 Stone 2 Vomiting 3 Urine stopped 2. 3 Wounds 6
Stoncrop.
SToncrop, (See in Housleeke. Small Stoncrop, Stonhore or wall-pepper, causes
vomit, taken with vinegar, and so voideth gross, slimy, and hot choleric
humors, and is good against fevers, and all poison in the body, but none must
take it, but they that are strong and lusty. 2 Mixed with Swines grease, it
dissolueth and drives away wennes, the kings evil, and swelling in the
throat, and hard swellings. 3 Being applied alone on the bare skin, it
causes wheales and blisters. 4 Stoncrop for an Impostume, stamp it with
Laureall and streine it, and drink it with stale ale twice a day, it kills
worms.

Blister to make 3 Fevers 1 Impostume 4 Kings evil 2 Poison 1 Swellings hard 2
Throat swollen 2 Vomit to cause 1 Wennes 2 Worms 4
Stecados.
STecados, or French Lauender sodden with the flowers, or the flowers alone,
and drunk, opens the liver, lungs, milte, kidneys, mother, bladder, and all
inner parts, cleansing and expelling all evil and corrupt humors, and is good
against headache, and griefs of the breast and lunges, and expels the
terms. 2 The flowers are good in medicines to expel poison. 3 Smell often to
the leaves and flowers to comfort the brain, memory, and inward senses: It
strengthens all the senses and the whole body, and delivers from all
obstructions, and helps the griefs of the stomach.

Bladder stopped 1 Breast griefs 1 Brain weak 3 Headache 1 Liver stopped 1 Lungs
griefs 1 Matrix griefs 1 Milt griefs 1 Obstructions general 3 Poison 2
Sickness general 1. 2. 3 Stomach griefs 3
Strawberrie.
STtrawberrie, The juice of the leaves with wine of Pomegranates, and a little
Rose water applied, is good for hot Apostumes in their beginning and increase.
2 The leaves used in a bathe, do greatly help the Stone. 3 Stamp three or
four handful of the leaves, and seethe them in water, and bate therewith the
hips upward, and then anoint with this ointment: take Dealthea one ounce, honey
half an ounce, wax one dram, and melt them together and use it both for the
Sciatica to soften hardness, and to provoke vrin. 4 The berries take away
unnatural heat, and do cool and moisten dry Chollericke men. 5 The herb
eaten in meat is good for the milt and the griefs thereof, and so is the
juice drunk. 6 The juice with white pepper helps them that are short winded.
7 The berries slake thirst, and are good for the stomach. 8 The decoction of
the roots drunk morn and even, does qualify the Liver. 9 And the decoction
of the herb and root together, does qualify the heat of the Liver, and
does cleanse the reins and bladder. 10 The best distilling of the berries, is
when they be ripe, but not over soft, and they which grow in hilly Woods are
best. 11 The water drunk, or mixed with somewhat, and drunk, qualifieth
unnatural heat, and slaketh thirst. 12 Drink iiii. ounces morn and even to
help the leapry. 13 To purge the blood, drink it with wine, or otherwise
eat it with bread to cleanse the foul skab of the body. 14 Drink it in the
same manner to help the liver, the Kings evil, to loosen the breast, to
comfort the heart, to purge the blood, and for the stone of the kidneis and
bladder. 15 Gargle therewith to help the ulcers and grievous swellings and
stink of the mouth and throat. Let women drink it to cleanse them and send
down their terms. 16 Wash the filthy corruptions and skabs of the legs
therewith morn and even, and also apply it with linen clothes. 16 Drink
thereof and also wash filthy wounds therewith to heal them. 17 Wash the face
therewith for the swelling thereof. 18 Mix it with salt, and distill it over
again, to cool and clear the eyes. 19 Strawberies or the water of them, is
good for all inward heat of the liver and lungs, the inflammation of the whole
body, to quench thirst, and to help the rednes of the face being daily drunk,
and ye face washed therewith. And likewise it comfort the heart, helps the
griefs of the breast, cleanses the blood, and helps the Iaundies. 20 The
water helps the ulcers of the mouth and the squincy being gargarised. 21 The
same takes away the spots and rednes of the face and legs. 22 The beries put
in a brazen vessel with salt in a low seller viii. days till it turn to a
green water, is very good for the pain in the eyes. 23 The decoction of the
plant drunk, stops the task and the terms. 24 The same holden in the
mouth comfort the gummes, and cures the ulcers and sores of the mouth and
stink of the same. 25 The juice of the leaves cures the rednes of the face.
26 The continual use of the beries is good for a hot stomach. 27 The leaves
eaten in meats, or the juice drunk with honey, helps ye griefs of the milt,
and with pepper it helps shortness of wind. 28 There is a juice pressed out
of Strawberies, which in time increases strength, and is a present remedy
against the sores and wheales of the face, and bloodshotten eyes. 29 Use the
leaves with Borage and Buglosse in meats to engender good blood. 30 Mix the
juice of the leaves and of Planten, of each iii. drams, with one dram of Ash
leaves, and seethe them together to a plaster, and apply it to a broken leg
or any other member to knit the bones speedely. 31 Water of the decoction
thereof is good to be drunk against the ache and heat of the head, and for
sweating and inward heat. 32 The juice taken with Cummin, is good against a
stinking breath. 33 And taken with Borage, it is good against the ache of the
head and heart. 34 And with the juice of Planten, it stops ye terms. 35 The
water dropped into the eyes, helps their rednes, itche, and inflammation. 36
They may be made in conserve as Barberies. Voice to be clear, drink the
juice. 37 Heap Strawberies on one ounce of Salgem iiii. or v. days, then
streine it and put it in a box, and use it to the web of the eyes. 38 Eyes
pain, distill the berries with white wine, and use it for the pin and the
web. 39 Teeth and gummes foul, rub them with Strawbery leaves. 40 Stone to
break, distill Strawberies with their leaves, and drink the water as other
drink. 41 Teeth-ache, chewe the leaves. 42 They are good for bleared eyes. 43
Conserve of Strawberies, set a quart of them on the fire till they be foft,
streine them and put thereto twice their weight of sugar, and seethe it till it
be incorporated. It is good against a hot liver, and burning of the stomach,
especially in hot fevers. 44 Face leprous, wash with the water being first
putrified in a glass before they be distilled. 45 Iaundies, use the leaves and
roots in pottage certain days. 46 Mix the juice with honey and a little
white Pepper, and use it for the pain of the milt and the ptisike. 47 Face
pimples, put ripe Strawberies into a leap of green rushes, and hang it
against a wall where the sun has most power over a glass, and anoint with
the water.

Tamarinds.
TAmarinds scowre away choler, and hold down the rage of it of the heat of
blood. 2 They are very good for the burning of the liver and stomach, thirst,
all kinds of burnings, and the Iaundies. 3 They stop vomitings, and help hot
and hasty agues that had need of purgation. 4 The dose is one ounce of the
flesh streyned, and some are suffised with half an ounce. It is good to put to
it almost as much Cassia, and so may the Cassia be the better taken. And some
Spikenard or Mastike, or Maces, are good to be put to it to mitigate the
coldness of it. 5 It will work more strongly with the juice of hops, or of
Parsley, or of Fenell, or of Endive. The best are black, shining, fresh, and
not dry. 6 They are good to be used for the griefs of the head.

Head-griefes 6 Hot griefs 1 etc. Iaundies 2 Liver hot 2 Stomach hot 2
Thirst 2
Tamariske.
TAmariske: it is a medicine of excellent power and virtue against the stopping
and hardness of the milt, if it be but drunk out of, being made into a vessel
to drink it. 2 The decoction of the leaves and young springs boiled in wine
with a little vinegar and drunk, does heal the stopping and hardness of the
milt, and so does the juice drunk with wine. 3 Teeth-ache, seethe the branches
and leaves in wine, and hold it hot in thy mouth. 4 Flowers to stop, sees the
leaves in water, and sit in it hot. 5 Lice and nits, seethe it and wash
therewith to kill them. 6 The fruit of the great Tamariske, is good against
spitting of blood, to stop the flowers and the laske, and against venomous
bitings. 7 The same fruit is used in stead of galls in medicines for the
griefs of the mouth and eyes. 8 The bark is of the same virtue that the
fruit is of. 9 The leaves, wood, root, and juice sodden in wine and drunk,
helps the griefs of the lungs, milt, kidneis, and bladder: it drives forth
melancholy, it helps spitting of blood, and the excessive flowing of terms
and all other fluxes, the Iaundies, and all other griefs that come of
obstructions. 10 The root sodden with Reasins and drunk, helps the Leapry,
because it cleanses and heals the milt, whereof the Leapry comes. 11 A
pyggin made of the branches thereof, is good for them to drink in that be
splenetike. 12 The decoction of the leaves is good for women that be pale to
sit in, when they are troubled with the whites. 13 Lee made of the ashes
kills lice and nittes. 14 The ashes cast upon spreading sores does dry them
up, and helps burnings with fire. 15 Use powder of it in bread for the
quarten Fever and the Dropsy. 16 The fruit is like Galls, and may be used
for them. 17 A plaster thereof swageth swellings. 18 The bark is good for the
same purpose. 19 The ashes of the wood applied to the convenient place,
stops the outrageous flowing of the matrix. 20 The broth of the leaves is
good to sit in for women that have a loose mother in peril of falling down.
21 The bark of the roots of heath may be used in stead of the bark of the
root of Tamariske, rather then the bark of quickebeame. 22 The perfume of
Tamariske is good for cold apostumes. 23 The broth of it sodden with Reasins
drunk, is good for the Leapry. 24 Tamariske dressed after the manner of Guiacum
for the French pockes, is thought to have the like virtues. 25 Milt griefs,
stamp the leaves with vinegar and apply them.

Apostumes 22 Biting venom. 6 Bladder griefs 9 Burnings 14 Dropsy 15 Eyes
griefs 7 Fever quarten 15 Flowers to stop 4. 6. 9. 19 Fluxes 6. 9 French
pockes 24 Iaundies 9 Kidneis griefs 9 Leapry 10. 23 Lice 5. 13 Lungs griefs 9

grief 7 Nits 5. 13 Obstructions 9 Sores 14 Spitting blood 6. 9 Swellings 17
