Tansie.
TAnsie: the seed is singular good to kill worms and expel them howsoever it
be taken. 2 Sinowes ache and swollen, stamp it with oil and apply it. 3
Fevers, anoint with the juice of oil of Roses to put away the fits. Bladder
pain and pissing by drops, drink it with wine. 4 The root condited or
preserved with sugar, is good to be taken for the pain of the gout in ye
feet. Seethe the seeds in wine with honey, and drink it to kill worms. 5 The
same has also the nature of Camamile, it cease ache, and provoke sweat. 6
It is one of the kinds of Mugwort. 7 Tansie is good for the palsy, for it
voydeth phlegm, and dries the sinowes. It kills worms, and voydeth the
matter whereof they breed, and is good for the stone and stopping of the
urine. 8 Stamp Sage, Rue, and Tansie, of each like much with wine and drink
it for the fever quarten. 9 Teeth worms, stamp it, and put it in. 10
Belly-ache and swelling, stamp Tansie, Sothernwood and Rue with salt, and
apply them hot. 11 Eyes bleared, put in the juice. 12 Iaundies of cold cause,
and for pissing of blood, drink the juice. 13 Worms, drink the juice of
Tansie, and Goose tansie. 14 Belly-ache, eat Tansie, Rue, and Sothernwood with
salt. 15 Cough, fill dry Figs with Tansie seeds, and seethe them in white
wine with one ounce of Licoras, with a soft fire to the one half, and drink
thereof every night. 16 Worms, (See Camamile.) 17 Pockes, (See Peniroyall.) 18
To purge the matrixe, stamp half an ounce, and streine it with wine and
drink it. 19 Boil Tansy and wild Tansy with salt, and drink it for inward
bruises. 20 Matrix to cleanse, drink half an ounce of the powder of it with
good white wine. 21 Fluxes general, mix the juice with yolks of eggs, and
the fatness of wheat, and bake small cakes of it, and eat them two or three
days. 22 Flowers to stop, drink the juice, and apply the substance. It
helps also burstings or ruptures, especially with Planten. 23 Worms, drink
the juice. 24 Iaundies, drink it often with ale. 25 Belly-ache, (See Rue.)
Face sause-flegme, eat Tansy and Sothernwood. 26 Drink the juice of Tansy to
void urine speedely. Worms, stamp it and seethe it in water and drink. 27
Ache in the back, kidneis, and lymmes, stamp Tansy with sheep tallow, and
frye it and apply it. 28 Fever quarten, stamp Sage, Rue, and Tansy, of each
like much, and drink it with wine.

Ache 5. 27 Backe-ache 27 Belly-ach 10. 14. 25 swol. 10 Bladder pain 3 Bursten
22 bruised 19 Cough 15 Eyes bleared 11 Face deformed 25 Fever 3 quarten 8. 28

Tarragon.
TArragon is good in Sallads with Lettuse as Rocket is, and is sharp and salt
enough of it self, without the help of vinegar and salt.

Tar.
Tar, or liquid pitch, taken with Honey, does cleanse the breast, and helps
shortness of wind. It does mollify and ripen all heart swellings, and is
good to anoint the squincie or swelling in the throat, and is an anodine to
take away ach or pain. 2 Applied with Barley meal, it softeneth the hardness
of the matrixe and fundament. 3 Mixed with quick Brimstone, it represseth
fretting ulcers, skabs, and skurfe. 4 With salt, it is good for venomous
bitings and stingings. 5 It cures the riftes and chaps of the fundament,
hands, and feet. 6 And with fine powder of Frankincense, it heals hollow
ulcers or fistulaes, and fills them up with flesh. 7 It is good to be put
into fistulaes, with a tent of Bacon. 8 Matrixe rent, stitch it up and anoint
it with Pix liquida. 9 To cause a siege in Tenasmus, or streyning to void the
excrements, take up the fume of Tar, or Turpentine. 10 It is good against
poison, spitting blood and matter. With Rose oil, it helps the mattering of
the ears. 11 With as much Wax, it helps the rough nails and the impetigo,
ringworme, tetter, skabbe, and itch. 12 Sodden with Barley meal in the urine
of a chaste boy, it breaks strumes, wennes and swellings. 13 And with Raisins
and Honey, it heals carbuncles and rotten ulcers, and breaks them. 14
Fundament fallen, anoint it with Tar, and put it in. 15 Head skalde, mix it
with salt, foot, and sallet oil of each like weight, and anoint it daily and
be whole, it brings also plenty of hair. 16 Matrixe fallen, cast on powder
of Eg-shels wherein Chickens have been hatched, and then lay on Tar. 17 To
bring a Canker out of a sore old or new, mix one spoonefull of Tar with as
much new cream, and apply it with a cloth thrice if need be. 19 Put it into
a hollow tooth to break it, and cease the ach. 20 It takes away blewenesse
under the eyes. 21 It breaks apostumes. In a glister it kills worms. 22 It
heals the leapry. 23 Pyles, apply the reddest Tar upon new lockrome, and
thereon lay bolsters, and do so once a day, and bind them to.

Tasell.
TAsell: the root boiled in wine, and stamped to the thickness of an
ointment, heals chaps, and rifts, and fistulaes of the fundament: but to
preserve this ointment, it must be kept in a copper vessel. 2 The small worms
that are found in the heads worn about the neck or arm in a thin leaf, do
cure the quarten fever. It is also good for all kinds of warts. 3 The water
that stands between the leaves and stalks does the same. 4 Frenzy, apply
the leaves to the head. 5 Ears worms, put in the juice. 6 Use the distilled
water of the leaves for rottenness of the mouth and gums, and chaps of the
fundament, especially the root sodden in wine to pappe, and then mixed with
wax and put into a copper vessel, and so it helps chaps, fistulaes, and
creeping sores, shingles, pimples, and hanging warts. 7 The water that stands
in the leaves, is good for red eyes, spots of the face, especially under the
eyes. 8 Dropsy, stamp the roots of Tasell and Danewurt, and sees them in
wine, and drink it. 9 Gout, sees Tasell in red wine, and drink it morn and
even nine days. 10 Spitting blood, seethe Tasell and Planten in rain water,
and drink thereof with sugar at morn, noone, and even. 11 Flowers to stop,
drink two drams of the powder of it with a Poringer full of pease broth, or
stamp it and boil it in vinegar, and apply it under the Navel. 12 Wounds
moist and hard to heal, stamp it and apply it. 13 Flux and excoriations of
the belly, drink powder of it with good wine. 14 Yard kanker, stamp the
leaves and apply it often.

Chaps 1. 6 Dropsy 8 Ears worms 5 Eyes red 7 Face deformed 7 Fever quarten
2. 3 Fistula 1. 6 Flowers to stop 11 Fluxes 13 Frenzy 4 Fundament griefs 1. 6
Gums rotten 6 Gout 9 Kanker 14 Mouth griefs 6 Sores 6 Spitting blood 10 Warts
2. 3. 6 Wounds moist 12 Yard kanker 14
Thapsia.
THapsia, Mesnes, Turbith: The bark of the root one dram or somewhat less,
purges phlegm and choler from the stomach and all parts, and is good against
shortness of breath, stopping of the breast, the cholike, pain in the sides,
shrinking and drawing of the senowes, the gouts and ach of the joints. 2 Laid
too with oil, it is good against foul skurfe of the head, and causes hair
to grow again. 3 With Frankincense, it disperseth congealed blood of bruises.
4 The juice of the root with Honey, takes away Lentiles, spots, and skurfe of
the face or elsewhere. 5 The juice with sulphur, dissolueth all swellings. 6
The root with oil and wax, is good for the old pain of the head, and ach in
the side and outward parts. 7 It must be corrected with Ginger or long Pepper,
and a little Sugar, when it is taken inward. 8 Tripolium, serapious, turbith:
two drams taken of the root, Purges watrish humors, and helps the dropsy.
9 It is good in medicines against poison. 10 The leaves or juice heal all
wounds. 11 Ranker to heal, apply powder of the root of Turbith with Honey.

Ash 1. 6 Breast stopped 1 Breath short 1 Bruise 3 Dropsy 8 Face deformed 4 Head
ach old 6 skurfe 2
Hair to grow 2 Joints ach 1 Kanker 11 Purgation 18 Poison 9 Senowes griefs
1 Side ach 6 Skin deformed 4 Swellings 5 Wounds 10
Thlaspi.
THlaspi seeds eaten, purge choler both upward and downward, provoke
terms, and breaks apostumes both inward and outward. 2 and taken with a
Glister, it helps the sciatica, and is good also to be applied outwardly, as
Mustard seed. 3 It seems to be that which we call penny weed among grass
on lays and balkes.

Flowers stopped 1 Impostume 1 Purgation 1 Sciatica 2 Vomit to cause 1
Thistle.
THistle: the wild Thistle, that, especially with the black long root boiled
in wine and drunk, provoke by urine, and expels all superfluities of the
blood, and causes the urine to stink, and so makes the body and arme-pits
free from such strong smell. 2 The same applied with vinegar, heals the wild
skurfe and naughty skab. 3 Some use to eat the buds and roots, but it gives
no good nourishment, but watrish and naught. 4 Lady Thistles, the roots drunk
in wine, is good against spitting of blood and feebleness of the stomach, and
looseness of the belly: it provoke urine, and expels it out. 5 Teeth ach,
sees it in wine and use it to the teeth. 6 Stamp it to cold and soft
swellings, to consume them. 7 The seed is good for the crampe in children, or
the drawing awry of any member, and the bitings of any venomous beast. 8 Eyes
blemish, put in the juice of Lady Thistle. 9 Botch to break, stamp sow
Thistle and apply it. 10 Dropsy, drink the juice of sow Thistle morn and
even, or seethe the leaves of Lady Thistle in wine or water to the one half,
and drink thereof morn and even nine days. 11 Dropsy in the belly and
Iaundies, seethe sow Thistle and the root thereof in ale, from a gallon to a
quart, and drink thereof. 12 Face sauseflegme, stamp the sharp Thistle, and
drink it till thou be whole. 13 To avoid all ill humors out of the stomach
and other parts of the body, make broth of Saint mary Thistle, water Cresse,
Eldren buds, Auens, Parsley and Isope, and use it. 14 Urine stopped, stamp the
root of Thistle, and boil it in wine and drink it. 15 Pricks, apply the
leaves or roots of the Thistle with Pitch, Rosin, and the white of an egg. 16
Stone, gather Thistle roots in saying the Lords prayer, and wash them eight
times, and put thereto eighty one grains of Pepper, and so streine it and
drink it. 17 For biting of a mad dog, and madness that comes thereby, 18
Dry the flowers of wild Thistles in the shadow, and drink a Wall nut shell
full of the powder of them with white wine, and be whole at thrice taking of
it. 19 White cotton Thistle, the leaves or roots drunk, are good for the
Crycke and shrinking of the senowes, by means of the crampe, (See Caltrope.)

Apostume 6. 9 Back cricke 19 Belly loose 4 Bitings venomous 7. 17 Botch 9
Crampe 7. 19 Dropsy 10. 11 Eyes blemish 8 Face sauseflegme 12 Iaundies 11 Mad
17 Mad dog 17 Pricks 15 Purgation 1. 13 Senowes griefs 7. 19 Skab 2 Skurfe 2
Spitting blood 4 Stinking sweat 1 Stomach weak 4 Stone 16 Swellings 6 Teeth
ach 5 Urine stopped 1. 4. 14
Throughwaxe.
THroughwaxe boiled in water or wine and drunk, heals wounds, and so do the
green leaves bruised and applied, mixed with wax, oil or ointments fit to
heal wounds: it heals burstings of young children. 2 Stamp it with meal and
wine, and lay it to the nauels of young children, to keep up their bowels, and
draw them to the Natural place and settle them, and to slake them when they
are too much windy and swollen. 3 The like does the powder of the seeds
applied in like manner. 4 Stamp it with wax or glewe, and apply it to the
swelling of the Cods, burstings, inflammations and wennes. 5 The herb or the
water thereof, is good for the holy fire and the shingles, and it cools a
hot stomach. 6 The whole herb is very meet to heal both inward wounds,
sores and burstings, especially of children, and the going out of the navel
and great gut, and so does both the seeds and leaves. 7 The powder of the
leaves drunk with wine, helps the herneyes. 8 The herb applied to the
navel, heals the vlceration thereof. 9 Children bursten, stamp it, and lay
it to the navel: or take the powder of the seeds with wine or milk.

Belly swollen 2 windy 2 Bursten 1. 4. 6. 7. 9 Cods swollen 4. 7 Fundament
fallen 2. 6 Holy fire 5 Inflammation 4 Navel out 6 sore 8 Shingles 5 Sores 6
Stomach hot 5 Wennes 4 Wounds 1. 6
Thyme.
THyme: Running Thyme provoke the terms and urine, and stops the
distillings of the head proceeding of a cold stomach being drunk in wine. 2
And helps the headache and frenzy being sodden in Rose water and applied.
Lethargy, apply it to the head with vinegar. 3 Vomiting blood, drink two
drams of the juice with vinegar. 4 Urine stopped, drink the seeds with wine. 5
Drink the herby part daily with wine, to break and expel the stone, both of
the kidneys and bladder. 6 Apply the herb to the stinging of a Be, to heal
it. 7 Sees the herb in wine with the juice of sweet Lycoras, and drink it,
to help the cough and purge the breast. 8 Sees it with Aniseeds, and drink it
to heat the stomach, to void wind in the Guts, and for the strangurie.
Seethe it in vinegar and Honey, and drink a cup-full at once, to help the
spitting of blood: or drink four drams of the juice with vinegar, for the same
purpose. 9 Sees it in wine and Honey, and apply it to the squincy, to help it.
10 Sees it in wine and drink it, to open the stoppings of the liver and milt,
and to provoke urine. 11 Drink three ounces of the distilled water morn and
even, to strengthen and amend the head and brain, and stomach, and to provoke
appetite, to avoid rumbling in the belly, to soften the hardness of the
stomach, to provoke urine, to comfort the sight, and to consume the
distillation of the head. 12 Drink ye said water with water of wormwood, to
heal the fever quotidian. 13 Drink three ounces of the water at once, to
amend the cold liver and milt, and for the exulceration of the guts, to open
the stoppings of the nostrels and ears, to restore hearing, to help the
giddiness of the head, to stay vomiting, to avoid the gripings in the belly,
to break the stone, and to provoke urine. 14 Apply the water with linen
clothes, to bruises, to heal them. 15 Stamp the herb with Honey, and apply it
to senowes shrunk, or joints out. 16 Sees it in wine and drink it, for the
ach and griefs of the stomach, gravel in the reins, and to increase milk. 17
Drink it with vinegar, to abate lust. 18 Stamp it and apply it to the head,
to stop reume. 19 Sees it in wine or water and drink it, to drive down the
terms, gravel and stone, and to provoke vomit, to stop the laske, to our
gripings and cramps, and the drawings or shrinkings of the senowes. 20 Use it
in meats and broths against all poison and venomous bitings and stingings of
serpents. 21 Apply it with oil of Roses and vinegar, to the forehead and
temples, to avoid headache, rauing and frenzy. 22 It is called wild Thyme,
running Thyme, Puliol mountain, and grows also on banks in fields. 23 The
perfume of it drives away all venomous beasts. 24 Sees it in wine with Honey,
Aniseeds and Lycoras, for the dry clammy cough, to comfort the stomach, and
to help the strangury. 25 Use it for a pot-herbe, as Parsley. 26 Garden Thyme
drunk with wine, provoke urine and terms, and purges the bowels. 27 Sodden
with Honey, it helps shortness of breath, and most griefs of the breast, by
spitting out of the corrupt matter. 28 Drink four drams of the fine powder
with oximell, to purge choler, and to cleanse the bladder. 29 Drink i. dram of
the powder with Mellicrate, one spoonefull fasting, to ease the pain of the
bowels and loins. 30 Drink three drams of the powder, with one spoonefull of
oximell, to avoid the wind of the breast, sides and flanks: and so it purges
melancholy humors, and helps the dullness of the senses coming of
melancholy, clears the sight, and helps the pain of the eyes, being taken
fasting. 31 Drink the powder with wine, for the pain of the gout. 32 Use not
Thime to much, because it is hot, and breeds choler: the whitest is best,
and the blackest the worst. 33 Sees Thyme in wine, and drink it against
wheasing, straitness and shortness of breath, small worms in the belly,
bruised blood, to drive down the flowers, seconds, and dead yonglings, and to
resist poison: use it in meats and sawses, and for all things that running
Thyme serves for. 34 Apply it with vinegar, to bruises, congealed blood and
warts: it may be used for wild Thyme or Sauery. 35 Drink it with vinegar and
salt, to purge phlegm. 36 Sees it with Honey or Mede, to cleanse the lungs,
breast, reins, matrixe and bladder, and to kill worms: use the powder in
potage, to comfort the eyesight. 37 The Bees profit most by it, of all herbs,
so that plenty of Thyme flowers, brings plenty of Honey. 38 Drink i. ounce of
dried Thyme, with iiii. drams of oximell, with an empty stomach before dinner
or supper, to help the stomach, guts, matrixe and bladder red eyes, and for
the gout. 39 Mix the powder with Honey, and lick it in, to cleanse the breast.
40 Apply it in a plaster, to new swellings. 41 Take it with vinegar, to
dissolve lumpes of bruised blood. 42 Apply the tops to hanging warts and
kernels. 43 Apply it with wine and parched barley meal, to the sciatica. 44
Gather it when it flows. 45 Eyes reume, eat Thyme. 46 Chollike and wind in
the stomach, sees it with Licoras in wine, and drink it. 47 Liver, milt,
kidneys and bladder, sees wild Thyme in wine or ale, and drink it. 48 Belly
ach, sees it in wine and oil, and apply it. 49 Chollike, stamp it with
saffron and streine it with oil, and drink it. 50 Ears dull, (See Camomile.)
51 Stitch, (See Cummin.) Reume, stamp it and apply it to the head. 52 Eyes
watrings and tears, seethe wild Thyme in water, and wash therewith. 53 Eyes
dim, eat Thyme. 54 Breath short, sees it in water, and when it is cold,
streine it, and put Mel-rosat to it, and skum it, and drink thereof to
bedward. 55 Gout and sciatica, stamp it with the white of an egg, and apply
it: or apply the ashes thereof, with the white of an egg. 56 Fistula and
hollow sores, stamp Thyme with salt, and apply it. 57 Stone, (See Parsley.) 58
Knees swollen of cold cause, sees one handful in a quart of Malmesie to the
one half, then put a piece of sweet butter to it, and boil it, and bath
therewith to bedward, and also apply it with a cloth. 59 Reins running, (See
Parietarie.) 60 Bruises, distill wild Thime in a Limbecke, and apply it with
linen clothes. 61 Spitting blood, sees wild Thyme in vinegar and Honey, and
take four ounces every day, or take half an ounce of the juice and vinegar.
62 Chin-cough, sees wild Thyme in wine, and drink it. 63 Chollike, stamp a
good handful of unset Thyme, with three cloves of Garlike, and then streine
them with ale, and make a possit, and drink the ale of it.

Tythimall.
Tythimall: The juice opens the belly, and sometimes causes vomit, and
brings forth tough phlegm and cholerike humors: and so do the seeds and
roots, especially the bark thereof: and are good for them that fall into the
dropsy, being well corrected and prepared: the same mixed with Honey and
anointed in ye sun causes hair to fall off: the same put into hollow and
rotten teeth, swageth the toothach: but put none of the juice upon any sound
teeth, but cover them with wax to preserve them from it. 2 The root boiled in
vinegar and holden in the mouth, is good for the same intent. 3 The same does
cure all roughness of the skin, maundge, leprie, wild skurfe, and spreading
skabs, the white skurfe of the head, and causes all kinds of warts to fall
off: it takes away the knobs and hardness of Fistulaes, corrupt and fretting
ulcers, and is good for hot swellings and carbuncles: it kills fish being
mixed with any bayt, and given them to eat. 4 The bark of the roots of the
Tythimalles soked four and twenty hours in vinegar, and then dried and made
into powder with Aniseedes or Fenell seeds, or Dragagant, or masticke, and
taken with some cooling liquor, as of Endive, Cycorie, or of Oringes, it will
work without trouble or pain. 5 The powder of spurge or Tythimall supped up
with a little Cinamome, in the broth of a Chicken or a rere egg in the
morning, will purge gross phlegm very gently, and so it will being taken with
Honey of Roses. 6 Seven seeds taken in a Fig, will purge melancholy and water.
Twenty seeds drunk with pure sweet water, helps the dropsy. 7 A dram of
the root drunk with Hydromell, purges phlegm downwards. 8 The outward bark
of the roots of Tythimall or Esula steeped four and twenty hours in vinegar
or milk, and then dried and powdered, and half a dram of it drunk with wine,
or Hydromell, or mellicrat, expels all kind of watrish humors and choler,
and is good for the dropsy. 9 The seeds of all Tythimalles, are of like
virtue, but more hot and sharp troubling the belly and provoking strong
vomites. 10 The milkie juice may be mixed with the flower of Beans or Peason,
and made into little cakes, and dried in the sun and kept for all purposes
that it is good for. 11 Mix the juice of it with wheat flower, and fill
hollow teeth therewith, to help the toothach, or sees the root thereof in
wine, and wash therewith every month once, and you shall have no toothach,
(See Spurge.) 12 For swelling and aching of the cheeks and teeth, sees it in
water, and wash therewith, and apply the substance. 13 Tooth to draw out,
apply the milkie juice with wheat flower. 14 To kill a Fistula or kanker
quite, mix the milkie juice with fresh swines grease, and melt them and put
thereto a little myrrh, and dip tents therein, and put them in deep enough:
proved. 15 Warts, apply the milk juice. 16 Teeth to fall out, mix the milk
with wheat flower, and dry it in the sun till it be hard, and so keep it
and lay thereof upon the tooth and upon none other: for swelling and aching of
the cheek, and for tooth ach, sees it in water, and wash with the water, and
apply the substance, (See Spurge, Esula.)

Carbuncles 3 Dropsy 1. 6. 8 Fistula 3. 14 Fish to kill 3 Phlegm 7 Hardness 3
Head griefs 3 Hair to fall 1 Kanker 14 Knobs 3 Leprie 3 Maundge 3 Melancholy
6 Plague sore 3 Purgation 1. 4. 5. 6. 7. 8. 9. 10 Skab 3 Skurfe 3 Sores 3 Teeth
ach 1. 2. 11. 12 to fall out 13. 16
Ulcers 3 Vomit to cause 1. 9 Warts 3. 15
Tormentill.
TOrmentill: the leaves and roots sodden in wine, or the juice drunk,
provoke sweat, and thereby expels all venom from the heart. 2 And eaten
or drunk, they are good against all poison and pestilence: the same virtue
has the powder of the dried roots drunk in wine. 3 The root drunk with wine
when there is no fever, or with water wherein Iron has been often quenched, in
a fever, cures the bloody flux, and all other fluxes of the belly, and
stops the terms, and all issues of blood. 4 The decoction of the leaves and
root, or the juice used both inward and outward, is good for all wounds, it
opens and heals the stoppings and hurts of the liver and lungs, and the
Iaundies. 5 Eat the powder of the root with the white of an egg, to stay the
desire to vomit, and against choler and melancholy. 6 Boil it in water, and
wash the mouth therewith, to cure all evil ulcers, and the sores thereof. 7
Stamp the herb with oil, to heal the soreness of the feet and skabs in
three days. 8 It closes up new wounds, and cleanses the eyes. 9 Drink
powder of the root with the juice of Planten, against the stopping or skalding
of the urine. 10 It is good against poison, the plague, and the bloody flux.
11 One dram of the root, or one handful of the herb or root sodden in wine
and drunk warm, expels poison and the plague. 12 The herb, root, juice
or powder, opens the passages of the liver and lungs, and helps the
Iaundies, especially the juice thereof. 13 If any man be taken with sudden
sickness, and cannot tell what it is, let him take one dram of treacle with
wine of the decoction thereof, and cover him well, to sweat out all the venom,
fever and pestilence. 14 The root used any manner of way, is good for all
fluxes, both white and red. 15 The powder thereof drunk with red wine, cures
the bloody flux, if the party have no fever, but in a fever one dram of it,
with the distilled water twice a day drunk, does help it. Mix the powder with
the white of an egg, half a nutmeg, and as much Ote flower, and bake it in a
frying pan, and turn it now and then, and eat it, to heal all fluxes: or
bake the powder with the white of an egg, on a hot brick or tile, and take
one dram thereof with water of red Mints, for the same purpose. 16 The herb
and root stamped and applied, takes away all hardness, swellings, and
gatherings of humors, wennes, knots, kernels, and takes away the pain of the
hips. 17 And with vinegar, it helps the running skab, emerods, piles, and
such like. 18 The water or juice stops the terms. 19 The powder heals
cuts and wounds. 20 One part of the root drunk in rain water, and another
part bruised with vinegar, and applied to the reins, will hold the birth, that
it can not fall before the natural time. 21 It is good to be taken with
Planten water, of them that cannot hold their water. 22 Let women sit in the
broth of it up to the navel, to stop their flowers: or kneade the powder with
Honey and spikenard, and lay it to the nethermost part of the belly. 23 Stomach
full of gleym, use powder of Gentian and Tormentill. Teeth ach, apply a piece
of the green root. 24 Sight to restore, sees it in wine and drink it daily
and no other drink, and apply the sodden herb every night over the eyes three
or four months. 25 Bruise the root and seethe it, and drink the broth for
the chollike and pinching grief of the belly. 26 Fever quarten, drink
Tormentill before the fit. 27 Chollike, drink two parts of Tormentill, and a
third part of Ginger with hot wine. 28 Tooth to draw out, apply a piece of
the green root. 29 Flux, drink powder of the root with Planten water. 30
Impostumes general, drink Tormentill often. 31 Fistula to heal, put in the
juice with a tent. 32 Eyes dull, and yet clear, sees it in wine, and drink
it first and last sixteen days, and shut thine eyes together, and apply the
herb every night warm, (See water imperial in Pimpernell, or Scabious.) 33
Tormentill comfort the sight, and cleanses the body from diverse maladies.
34 Put the powder into the eyes. 35 Sees the herb and root in white wine,
till the third part be wasted, and drink thereof nine mornings cold, and nine
nights a little warmed, to recover ye sight: but if the eye be hurt, stamp it
and sees it in white wine and a little water, and bind it to the eyes. 36
Stamp it and the root of it, and put it into a little vessel of wine three
months, and then drink the wine to recover the sight. 37 Belly ache, stamp
the roots and drink it with a little white wine or ale. 38 Eyes red and
dropping, wash them with water of Tormentill, with a little Tutia prepared put
into it. 39 Sciatica, take powder of the root in winter, with Iuie water, but
in summer with conserve of Roses, (See Sorell.) 40 Bloody flux, take i. dram
of the root often, with good red wine. 41 Itch and swelling of the Emerods,
stamp the leaves and roots, and boil them in vinegar and wash therewith. 42
Consumption, boil powder of Elecampana and Tormentill with Honey, and use it.
43 Flux to stop, eat the root.

blind 8. 24. 32. 33. 34. 35. 36. red and running 38

Tragium.
TRagium or stinking motherwurt, growing by sandy ways: Smell unto it, or
bind it to the navel, for strangling of the mother.

Turpentine.
TVrpentine: The clear Rosin of the fur tree, which is liquid, or Venice
Turpentine, taken about the weight of half an ounce, loses the belly, and
drives forth hot cholerike humors: it cleanses the kidneis, provoke vrin,
and drives forth the stone and gravel, and is good for them that have the
gout. 2 The same taken with Nutmeg and sugar, as much as a Nut, cures the
strangury, and is very good against the going off of the skin, or flux of
the secret parts. 3 It is also excellent for all green wounds, especially of
the head: for it heals and cleanses much. 4 The Rosin of the Larch tree, is
as good as any of the other Rosins, to be put in Plasters and ointments, to
glue together, and to cleanse and heal wounds. 5 Licked in with Honey, it
cleanses the breast, loses the belly, provoke urine, and drives out the
stone and gravel taken inwardly: and to be short, it is of faculty very like
to the right Turpentine, and may be used for the same. 6 The Rosin of the
Turpentine tree, which is the right Turpentine loses the belly, opens the
stoppings of the Liver and milt, cleanses the kidneys, provoke urine, and
drives out gravel, being taken in quantity of a wall nut. 7 In an electuary
with Honey, it cleanses the breast and lungs, ripeneth phlegm, and causes it
to be easily spit out. 8 It is good for the wild skurfe and maundge, chaps and
clifts of the feet, and is used in emplasters to make smooth and soft. 9 Mixed
with oil and Honey, it is good to be put into the ears against the matter and
running of them, and against the itch of the priuities. 10 Among all Rosins,
the Rosin called Turpentine is the best, then the Masticke, then Rosin of the
Pine tree, then that of the red Fur tree. 11 Turpentine with Verdigreace,
Coprose, and natural saltpeter, is good against Leapries. 12 The
suffumigation thereof helps the Tenasmus. 13 Clear venice Turpentine washed
and tempered with Honey, will cleanse the lungs. 14 Taken with Sugar in Pills,
it will cleanse the reins, open the bladder, purge gravel, cleanse much
urine, and help the yard, and mollify the belly. 15 Take Turpentine two
ounces, often washed in water of Fenell or Thyme, then put to it powder of new
saffron and Hyera simplex, of each half a dram, keep it in a box for any
grief of the guts or reins. Take two drammes of it four mornings together.
16 The turpentine of the larch tree taken four spoonefull, or thereabout with
meat and drink, expels inward poison, it purges gently, and heals the
griefs of the breast, lungs, and liver. 17 The same is good against a
consumption, or leanness, the old cough, shortness of breath, spitting of
blood, and the Ptisicke. To cause deliverance, Drink Turpentine. 18 To expel
the seconds, smell to the smoke of Turpentine. 19 To make natural turpentine,
Take oil of Linseede one pound, the elder the better, Rosin of the cleerest
four ounces, Colophonie one ounce, dissolve them in a pot, set into a pot
of seething water, and clarify it into a clean vessel, all the corruption
will fall into the bottom, then put to it one pint of clarified honey, and
boil them all together till the third part be wasted, then power out the
cleerest of it, add that is natural Turpentine. 20 Tenasmus, sit over the
fume of Turpentine. 21 Flowers to cause, and to cleanse the Matrix, dippe
Cotton therein, and put it in as a Suppositor. Mother suffocat. Take the fume
thereof at the mouth. Fellon (See Oats.) 22 Take up the fume laid on a hot
iron into the fundament three or four days, to avoid great pain and gnawing
in the belly and guts. 23 Stone to avoid, burn four ounces on a red
hot plate, and drink two drammes of the powder with four ounces of Saxifrage
water twice a week at the break of day two months together, or wash
Turpentine ten times in water, and make little balls, or boli thereof, with
Saxifrage juice, and a little Sugar, and use it as aforesaid. 24 Worms,
spread Venice turpentine on alomed leather, and lay it from the pit of the
stomach to the top of the nauill in the wane of the Moon. 25 A salve for a
green wound, take one ounce of Turpentine washed in Woodbine water, and the
yolks of two new laid eggs, and beat them well together: then put in two
blades of Saffron, and mix them all together, and keep it in a box, it will
be good one year. 26 Nails cloven, apply Turpentine and virgins wax.
Whites, and running of the reins, Use pills of Turpentine rolled in ginger
and Cinamome, and use them morn and even. Matrix loose after travail,
swallowe Venice Turpentine with Sugar, and use Comferie with Alebrewes. 27
Corns, pare them, and lay to Turpentine and red wax boiled together. 28
Blood to stop, apply Turpentine which Bole armoniacke. 29 Wounds to heal,
use Venice Turpentine with half as much yolks of eggs. 30 Turpentine is
abstersive, attractiue, mundificatiue, and resolutiue, good for the breast,
provoke urine, laxeth the belly, and heals skabbes. 31 With brimstone it
cures the Leaprie, skabbes, tetters, and ringwoormes. 32 Wounds, use it with
the yolke of an egg and oil of roses. 33 For hardness, and stopping of the
belly, to purge the lunges, liver, milte, and kidneys, and to comfort all the
spiritual members, use it with honey resolved in a sawser. 34 For the falling
of the fundament, take up the fume of Turpentine and pitche, and sit long on
a boarde of Juniper or Cedar. 35 Head skabbed, anoint with the gall of a Bull,
Turpentine and honey. 36 Bruise, or wound, apply the yolke of an egg with
Turpentine and Saffron. 37 Turpentine is good for the wounds of the sinews
and muskles. 38 Ears mattering, put it in with as much honye. 39 Sinews
pricked or cut, boil salt in oil, and put Turpentine to it, and apply it,
or apply Turpentine with the leaves of Centorie. 40 For the flux and great
pain of the fundament, lay one ounce of Turpentine on a hot iron in a close
stool, and receive up the smoke of it. 41 Stone in the bladder, burn four
ounces on a red hot iron, and drink two drams of powder, with four ounces
of saxifrage water twice a week, eight weeks together. 42 Wash an ounce with
borage water, or other cordial water nine or ten times, and put thereto three
ounces of fine sugar, and when need is, make pills thereof, and roll them in
Cinamome and Sugar, and take thereof at any time for many inward infirmities
and passions, especially coming of choler and phlegm, and to cause appetite.

Agneyls 27 Appetite 42 Belly ach 15. 22 bound 1. 5. 6. 14

Rosin.
ROsin, (See Turpentine.) Gout, anoint the place with clear Honey, and then
apply a plaster of Rosin with a linen cloth, till it fall off of it self. 2
Rosin with Tartar, helps Leprie. Bruise, boil Pitch, wax, Rosin and swines
grease, of each like much, and apply it iiii. or v. days unremoved. 3 To
consume an impostume in the stomach without breaking of it upward, take powder
of Rosen with one spoonefull of Ale or Beer, or mix it with Treacle, and take
as much as a great Nut, and drink after it to wash it down. It is good to
drive any infection from the heart, and will cleanse any stuffing or tough
phlegm about the heart and stomach, and is good with Treacle for any bruise.
If one take it sometimes when he is well, it will keep the body in good state
and from corruption and impostumation. (See salues and plasters.)

Breast griefs 3 Bruise 3 Phlegm 3 Gout 1 Heart griefs 3 Health to keep 3
Impostume 3 Leapry 2 Stomach impostume 3
Tutsan.
TVtsan: Gomor passion, boil Castory in the juice of it, and drink it. Drink
two drams of powder of ye seeds to purge choler, and to help the sciatica,
but water must be taken after it. 2 The heat be heals burnings, and stops
blood being applied, and so does the wine wherein it is sodden, (See S. John's
wort.)

Bleeding 2 Burning 2 Choler 1 Purgation 1 Sciatica 1
Vergis.
VErgis, (See Vine.) Flux to stop, drink possitale of Vergis, and keep thee
warm and close. 2 Vergis is good for all faint cattle, as kine, bulls, and
oxen, so that they drink it and go presently to pasture. Or give every one a
pint with a small handful of Bay salt, first rubbing their tongues therewith.
3 Vergis represseth hot humors. 4 Burning and skalding, wash quicklime with
Vergis ix. or x. times, then mix it with oil and use it. 5 Mouth excoriate,
use Vergis of wild grapes with honey. 6 Ears noise and headache, take up the
fume of Vergis from a tin vessel. 7 Sees Vergis with as much rain water to
the one half, and while it seetheth, fill it with the juice of Limons, and
when it is cold, put to it the whites of iiii. eggs beaten together, and use
it against all sun burning, and other filthiness of the skin. 8 Vergis
comfort a weak and faint heart, and swoonding.

Burnings 4 Cattle sick 2 Ears noise 6 Face deformed 7 Flux 1 Heart grief
8 Headache 6 Mouth blistred 5 Skalding 4 Skin deformed 7 Swooning 8
Vinegar.
Vinegar: mouth stink, swallowe Vinegar when thou go to bed. 2 Hickit,
hold thy hands in hot water, and then apply Vinegar to thy stomach with a
spondge. 3 For all fevers, seethe a quart of white Vinegar, with Sanders and
Licoras, of each one peniworth to the one half, then streine it and drink a
spoonefull or two at once, and be whole. 4 Burnings, apply the dregs of Vinegar
with an Eg. 5 Swelling, boil Bean meal in Vinegar till it be thick, and
apply it. 6 Bleeding, ^p thy yard in strong vinegar. 7 Breath stinking, steep
tostes of bread in strong Vinegar and eat it. 8 Face pimpled and red, wash it
nine days with good Vinegar. 9 Face salseflegme, seethe Elecampana in a pot
with Vinegar till it be dry, then grind it with Brimstone, Swines grease, and
Quicksiluer, and anoint therewith, (see Eg, Alom.) 10 Head megrem, toste the
nether crust of a brown loaf, and soke it in Vinegar, and heat it again and
apply it to the temples as hot as may be suffered, or drink Sage royal,
Betony, and Wormwood thirty hours with Vinegar. 11 Ringwormes and tetters,
dissolve gum of a Plumtree or Cherritree in Vinegar, and anoint therewith. 12
Stomach grief, stamp Wormwood with crumbs of bread and Vinegar, and apply it
warm to the stomach. 13 Thirst, use Sirupus Acetosus with Barley water.
Warts, stamp Egrimonie with Vinegar and apply it. 14 Sirupus Acetosus,
clarify v. pound of sugar with iii. pound of water over a soft fire, and skum
it and put thereto three pints of the best white Vinegar, and boil it till it
rope. It is good for all hot diseases coming of choler, and all cold
diseases coming of phlegm. It comfort the liver, heart, and stomach, and
slaketh thirst: it may be taken before and after meats. 15 Face salsflegme,
mix one peniworth of white Coprose, with one pint of white Vinegar, and wash
therewith to bedward every night. 16 Itche, seethe Rosemary and Celondine of
each half a handful in half a pint of white Vinegar, and streine it, and
put in a quantity of white Coprose while it is hot, and wash often therewith.
17 Ache, beat the yolks of two new laid eggs, with iii. spoonefull of white
Vinegar, and one spoonefull of Roses, and put thereto Bean flower, and heat
it and apply it on a linen cloth, but for a swelling put thereto vi.
spoonefull of Barme, and apply it cold. 18 Backe-ache, stamp Sothernewood
with Vinegar and salt, and apply it hot. 19 Bleeding, apply smoothe trodden
earth with Vinegar, or red Nettles stamped with Vinegar. 20 Headskalde, shave
off the hair and wash the head with Vinegar and Woodashes, and be whole. 21
Hair to fall, touch the place with Vinegar and ashes of Horseleches, (see
Worms.) 22 Morphue, put powder of Brimstone into a cloute, and dip it in
Vinegar and anoint. 23 Mouth heat in sickness, boil white Vinegar with as
much Honey, and a little Alome, and anoint with a fether, and also wash the mouth
often therewith, and also take up the vapor thereof. 24 Lice to kill, drink
wheye that is preast out of cheese with Vinegar certain days first and last,
and they will dry. 25 Ptisike and weakness of the stomach, seethe white
Vinegar long, and put in good store of sugar, and stir it well till it wax
thick, and use it first and last daily. 26 Fluxes general, seethe the yolke
of an Egg hard in Vinegar and eat it. 27 Teeth-ache, sees Betony, Sage, and
roche Alome in Vinegar, and hold it in thy mouth. 28 Steep an Egg iii. or
iiii. days in Vinegar, and it may be drawn through a ring: and steep a
whetstone therein 7. days, and it may be driven to powder. 29 An ointment for
all sores, sees i. pound of honey with half as much Vinegar, and half a
peniworth of Verdigrease, and use it. 30 To make Vinegar by and by, power pure
Wine half sodden into a new earthen Vessel, and stop it close, and set it in
hot skalding water. 31 Skin to be white, heat litarge of silver in distilled
Vinegar, and wash therewith. 32 Morphue, skurfe, and leapry, take powder of
quick Brimstone and black Soap, of each two ounces, and hang it in a pint of
strong wine Vinegar in a linen cloute ix. days, and wash with the vinegar,
and let it dry in by it self. 33 Flints laid in Vinegar seven days, may be
rubbed into powder. 34 Lethargy, rub the plants of the hands and feet with
Mustard and Vinegar. 35 Fluxes general, apply Doves doung with Vinegar to the
navel. 36 Face salsflegme, seethe a pint of Vinegar with as much milk, and
one handful of Barley flower and anoint therewith, and after wash it with
woman's urine sodden with the juice of Houseleeke. 37 Flowers to stop, seethe
new horse doung in Vinegar, and apply it hot to the navel. 38 Frenzy, apply
Vinegar to the forehead with a cloth. 39 Fundament fallen, sees eggs in
Vinegar, and mix their yolks with oil de Bay, and sit thereon till thou
be well. 40 Gout, apply Vinegar with Wheat branne cold, and it will flee
down from the plaster, then break it with Sparewort, and after lay on a
plaster of honey and barley flower, or anoint it often with honey, and seethe
Ambrose in wine, and drink it. 41 Headache, anoint with the juice of Rue and
Vinegar. 42 Canker in the mouth or lips, stamp Sage with Vinegar and Salt, and
apply it. 43 Memory to preserve, mix the juice of Smallache with a little
Vinegar and Castory, and apply it to the hinder part of the head. 44 Nails to
fall off, apply Brimstone or Arsenicke with Vinegar. 45 Face rank or red, put
iii. new laid eggs into a pint of Vinegar, and stir them well together, and
let it stand iiii. days and nights, and then drink thereof first and last,
and also wash therewith for the saltflegme, and heat of the liver and lungs,
though the scabs be as great as a Walnut. 46 Teeth-ache, stamp wild Dasy
roots with Vinegar, and apply them. 47 Headache, seethe Puliol and Hilwort in
Vinegar, and apply it. 48 Teeth to be white, rub them often with powder of
Brick and Vinegar. 49 Cods swollen, apply Bean meal with Vinegar cold. 50
Corns, apply ashes of the rind of Willowe, or Sallowe with Vinegar. 51
Headache, seethe Vinegar with running Thyme and oil of Roses, and apply it.
52 Itche, use salt with oil of Vinegar. 53 Nose bleeding, apply Vinegar with a
cloth to thy cods or paps. 54 Plague, a defensive, drink v. spoonefull of
Vinegar, iii. spoonefull of running water, half a spoonefull of Treacle, and
as much Bole Armoniake as a small nut first and last at morn and even. 55
Ringwormes, anoint with glewe dissolved in Vinegar, or grind one ounce of
Verdigrece with v. ounces of Vinegar, and put thereto iii. ounces of honey, and
boil them to the thickenesse of honey, and use it. 56 Heat outward, mix
Vinegar and milk with Coprose, and apply it with cloutes, or hurds. 57 Hickit,
stamp Sage with Vinegar and swallowe it. 58 Burning, mix five parts of the
juice of Lilly leaves with one part of Vinegar and a little honey, and use it. 59
Lice to kill, anoint with Mustard, Vinegar, and a little Saltpeter, or with
Stauesacre, Brimstone and Vinegar. 60 Teeth-ache, seethe a little Camphere in
Vinegar, and hold it in thy mouth, or seethe Henbane roots in Rosewater and
Vinegar, and hold it in thy mouth. 61 Teeth to be white and fast, rub them with
Vinegar of squilles. 62 Mouth stink, wash it with Vinegar, and chewe Mastike a
good while. 63 Heart beating, trembling, or cardiake, use Vinegar of Roses. 64
Heart swooning, cast cold water with Rose Water, and Vinegar into his face. 65
Vinegar to make, put wine into a vessel that Vinegar has been in, and set it
in the sun or by the fire, and put thereinto new brickes or tiles hot. 66
Nose bleeding, put Vinegar into the ear on the same side that bleedeth. 67
Ears sounding, put in Vinegar with oleum Irinum, that is of Flowerdeluce, or
Ellebore sodden with Vinegar. 68 Leave to be, drink iiii. ounces of Vinegar
with powder of Pepper fasting as often as need is. 69 Eyes sore, put Plumtree
flowers into Vinegar in a clean basin covered iii. days, then put it in a
box, and anoint therewith. 70 Nose bleeding, drink the juice of Fiueleafe,
and wash thy face with Vinegar. 71 Breast stopped, sees Rue in Vinegar, and
drink it. 72 Morphue, anoint with black soap and Vinegar and Brimstone, of
each like much. 73 Head pushes, wash it often with Vinegar, or seethe Tartar
in Vinegar and wash therewith. 74 Head skurfe, use Tartar with oil and
Vinegar. 75 Drowsinesse, forgetfulness, or Lethargy, burn thine own hair
and apply it to thy nose with Vinegar and Pitch, or apply Rue and red Mints
with oil and strong Vinegar to thy nostrels, or stamp Sauery and seethe it in
Vinegar, and apply it to the hinder part of thy head. 76 Frenzy, anoint thy
temples with ye juice of Planten or of Morrall and Vinegar. 77 Ringwormes,
stamp the roots of Burres, and seethe them in Vinegar, and anoint therewith,
or stamp Planten roots with Vinegar and salt, and anoint therewith warm. 78
Morphue and foulness, anoint with Doves dongue and Vinegar ground together.
79 Teeth-ache, seethe Coloquintida in Vinegar and hold it in thy mouth, or
boil Hysope in Vinegar and wash therewith. 80 Nosebleeding, apply a plaster of
clay, Vinegar, and whites of eggs to thy cods, or put in Hares hair with
Vinegar and water, or seethe Beans in Vinegar and eat them, or use them
plasterwayes, or sees Pears with Vinegar and drink it with Mastike. 81
Bloody flux, sees the livers of any beasts in Vinegar, and eat them, or
apply Doves doung stamped with Vinegar. 82 Chollike, seethe old oil with
butter and strong Vinegar of each like much, till it be thick, and apply it
often to the belly. 83 Milt swollen, stamp Docke leaves, and seethe them in
Vinegar and apply them. 84 Mother rising, squirt rain water and strong Vinegar
into her nostrels. 85 Fever quarten, drink the rindes and leaves of a Nut tree
with Vinegar. 86 Burnings and wild fire, apply Vinegar. 87 Pricks, apply
ashes of Swallows with Vinegar. 88 Drunken, rub the plants of the hands and
feet with Vinegar and salt. 89 Dropsy, apply Goats doung with Vinegar one
night. 90 Ears ache, take up the fume of Vinegar, or seethe one dram of the
root of black Ellebore in one pound of Vinegar, and take up the fume of it,
and also put thereof into the ear. 91 Eyes ache, seethe Roses in Vinegar, and
apply it. 92 Eyes web, mix Doves doung with Vinegar and oil of Roses, and
streine it, and anoint therewith with a feather. 93 Headache great and heavy,
mix powder of Aloes, Masticke, Frankincense with Vinegar and whites of Eggs,
and apply it with stuphes to the temples, or stamp green Mints with Vinegar
and anoint, or anoint with ashes of garlike and Vinegar, or apply Goats doung
with Vinegar vii. days to cure it for ever, or rub the place with a Spiders
web, and oil, and Vinegar, or seethe Wormwood in Vinegar and apply it, or
anoint with the juice of ground Iuie, oil, and Vinegar. 94 Head ache and
vertigo, stamp Sothernwood with honey and Vinegar, and drink it, or anoint
with Rue and Vinegar, or with the juice of Cicory, oil of Roses and Vinegar.
95 Canker, wash it iiii. or v. times a day with warm Vinegar, and sprinckle on
some powder that is good for it. 96 Wash thy gums with Vinegar, then mix alome
with it, and keep it in a box, and anoint therewith iiii. or v. times a day.
97 Leapry, anoint with the gum of a Plumtree dissolved in Vinegar, or with
Aspaltum and Vinegar. 98 Lethargy, shave thy head or nape, and anoint it with
the juice of Smallache, oil of Roses, and Vinegar, or apply the juice of
Smallache with Vinegar, and powder of Mustardseede. 99 Mad, drink Rue seeds
with Vinegar, or Gentian with honey and Vinegar. 100 Mother rising, put Vinegar
into her nose with a feather. 101 Paps swollen, apply Vinegar with earth, or
mill dust. 102 Face pimples, stamp Planten roots with Vinegar and salt, and
wash therewith. 103 Backe-ache old, seethe salt in strong Vinegar, and chafe
it well therewith iii. days against the fire, but if the matter be broken,
wine will serve in stead of Vinegar. 104 Sciatica, apply a plaster of Rye
flower and Vinegar. 105 Sores and swelling of the legs, mix Goats doung with
Barley meal and Vinegar, and apply it, or apply gross meal of Oces with the
white of an Eg and Vinegar. 106 Teeth-ach, sees galls in Vinegar, and hold
it in thy mouth. 107 Teeth to be white, kneade a cake of Barley meal and
Vinegar, and burn it on the coals, and rub thy teethe with it, or the powder
thereof. 108 Thighache, anoint with sheep doung and Vinegar often. 109 Sleep
to void, seethe Rue with Vinegar in a close vessel, and smell to it, and put
thereof into thy nose with a feather. Peniroyall dipped in Vinegar does the like.
110 Hoarsenesse, drink hot water at morn, noone, and even, and dip a linen
cloth therein with as much Vinegar, and bind it warm about thy neck often,
and forbear cold and cold things. 111 Vomiting, steep a piece of bread in
salt and Vinegar, and bruise it and apply it to the pit of the stomach, and
strike some of it on thy mouth. 112 Stomach wambling, drink an Egg shell
full of springing water with as much Vinegar. 113 Fever general, take half a
spoonefull of Vinegar, with as much juice of the green bark of Eldren. 114
Head frenzy, and lethargy, anoint with Vinegar and oil of Roses. 115 Blood
casting, drink half an ounce of Vinegar with wine. 116 Lethargy, seethe
Castory in strong Vinegar, and put thereto powder of Anacardium, and anoint the
hinder part of the head therewith. 117 Teeth-ach, sees Henbane root in
Vinegar, hold it in thy mouth, and chewe the root. 118 Speech lost, drink
Peniroyall with Vinegar, and also apply them to the stomach hot. 119 Appetite
to cause, use Vinegar in meats and sauses, especially with Sage, Mints,
Parsley, and Pepper. 120 Vinegar on a full stomach softneth the belly, but on
an empty stomach it binds it. 121 For weakness in sickness or after it,
weete tostes of bread in Vinegar, and rub thy mouth and nostrels therewith, and
bind it to thy pulses. 122 Swellings of wounds in the hands, seethe wheat
branne with Vinegar, and the juice of Wormwood, and apply it. 123 Spitting
blood, use honey and Vinegar boiled together. 124 Breasts swollen with too much
milk, boil honey with Vinegar, and spread it on a cloth, and cast thereon
powder of Cummin, and apply it. 125 Liver and milt chafed, mix yellowe
Rubarbe, and Barley meal and Vinegar, and apply it to the right side, and
bleed in the milt vein, and in summer drink Scabious, but in Winter sugar
Roset, (See Bread.) 126 Corns, quench vnslecked lime in strong Vinegar, and
when you will occupy it, pare the corn, and mix it with Rose Water, and
apply it. 127 Fever, stamp iiii. handful of Groundswell with Bay salt and
Vinegar, of each iii. spoonefull, and boil it till it be almost dry, and
bind it to the wristes an hour before the fit. 128 A skinning water for a
Fistula, steep one pound of fine powder of Litarge of gold, in a quart of
strong white Vinegar iiii. days, and streine it well twice a day, then let it
settle and use the clearest of it, and so have you the mother. 129 Morphue
white and black, stamp Mustardseede with Vinegar and salt, and anoint. 130
Plague, take water and Vinegar of each one sponefull, Treacle as much as a
Walnut, and drink it luke warm within 24. hours after the infection. 131
Bones broken, stamp Dasy, Comfery, and Egrimonie with Vinegar, and apply it.
132 Hoarsenesse, seethe a pint of white Vinegar with as much honey, and use it.
133 Ioints out, stamp Mugwort with Vinegar and swines grease, and apply it.
134 To know which gout is hot and which is cold, apply a plaster of Rye
meal with Vinegar: if it comfort, it is the hot gout, if it grieve, it is
the cold gout. 135 Speech lost suddenly, drink Puliol with Vinegar, and
also apply it to the nostrels. 136 Maidens milk, put litarge of silver into
fine Vinegar 24. hours, and it will turn white, and is good for the skurfe
and falsflegme. 137 To make old wax fair and new, and good, boil fair
Vinegar in an earthen pot, and put in the wax till it melt and boil, then let
it cool, after take the wax and clarify it, and put therein a little oil
Olive, and then work it. 138 Wash any grievous sore with possite Ale made with
white Vinegar, and apply the curd. 139 Stomach hot, drink possite ale made
with good red Vinegar with sugar. 140 Vinegar of Roses, gather the Roses before
they be full blown in dry weather, lay them on a boarde half a day, and then
put them into the Vinegar close stopped 24. hours, then stamp them and set them
in glasses in the sun all summer, then streine it and use it, if it be
renewed with Roses, it is the better: it may be made with wine either white, or
red, or claret. And so make Vinegar of Eldren flowers or Violets, etc. 141
Backe-ache, stamp Egrimonie, and Mouseare, and fry them with Vinegar and
Bores grease and apply it. 142 Headache, seethe Willow tops with a little
Rosemary in Vinegar till the third part be wasted and wash therewith. 143
Thorns in the fingers, stamp Sothernwood with Vinegar and apply it. 144
Teeth-ache, scrape a Henbane root and slice it and seethe it in a good
quantity of wine Vinegar, till it be almost wasted, with three spoonefull of
Rose Water, and hold of the root between the teeth, and hold the liquour in
thy mouth iii. or iiii. times. 145 Nose bleeding, apply red Vinegar to the
navel.

Vomiting 111. 115 Warts 13 Wax to renew 137 Weakness 121 Wild fire 86 Wounds
swollen 122
Veruine.
VEruine, the root or leaves, or both together sodden in water, are good for
sores and ulcers of the mouth and jaws being often washed therewith. 2 It
helps the toothache, and fastneth and strengthens them and the gums. 3 And
being drunk v. days continually, it cures the gripings of the belly. Veruine
mixed with oil of Roses and vinegar, or boiled in oil and laid to the
forehead, cures the headache, and so does a garland of it worn round about
the head. 4 The leaves stamped with swines grease or oil of Roses applied to
the matrix, does mitigate the pain thereof. 5 The same stamped with vinegar,
helps Saint Antonies fire, and old rotten sores, and stamped with honey it
cures green wounds, and closes up old wounds. 6 It is good for the tertian
and quarten fever. 7 Drink i. dram of the herb with three halfepenie weight
of Olibanum in ix. ounces of old wine 40. days together fasting to help the
Kings evil, and pain in the throat. 8 The leaves laid to with Rose oil and
fresh swines grease, takes away the pain of the mother. 9 Appetite to cause,
eat it or apply it to the stomach, it also heals gatherings and apostumes.
10 Belly gripings, drink Veruine with sugar. 11 Deliverance to cause, drink
it with wine, or the juice thereof with water. 12 Flux, sees it in white
wine, and drink it. 13 Kernels, seethe it with honey in water and drink it,
and apply the rest. 14 Lust to void, bear it about thee, or use it in thy
drink, and it is best that thou carry Veruine about thee next thy body, and so
thou shall be effeminate, and whosoever thou touthest often therewith, shall be
unapt to ye act of venery. 15 Head megrem, seethe Betony, Veruine, Horehound,
and Hysope in white wine, and wash therewith, and apply the rest as hot as may
be suffered. 16 Milk to cause, drink the juice of Veruine. 17 Seconds to
cause, drink ye juice warm and provoke sneesing. 18 Stingings, drink the
juice. Warts, drink Veruine. 19 Mischief in child bearing, stamp good store
of Nep with a little Veruine, an streine it with stale Ale or white wine, and
drink it hot first and last till you be whole. 20 Squincie, stamp Veruine and
apply it hot. 21 Headache, wear a garland of Veruine about thy head night
and day, or seethe two handful chopped small in a quart of Wine with a little
Sack, and apply it warm. 22 Mad, seethe Camamile flowers and Veruine of each
one handful in a quart of water or lee, and wash thy head therewith. 23 Eyes
spots, tie the whole herb, and root about thy neck. 24 Fever cold,
seethe three roots and three leaves of Veruine, and drink it before the cold
fit. 25 Stamp it with wine and drink it, and also apply it against all
stinging venom and poison. 26 Stamp three roots and drink it for the fever
tertian, and four for the fever quarten. 27 Stone, drink it with Saxifrage
and Betony, of each like much with wine. 28 Bear it about thee to have love
of great men, and to have thy request if it be good and right. 29 Gather it in
the first day of the new moon before sun rising, and bear it about thee,
and thou shall have no lust to women, or drink the juice to avoid lust for
vii. years. 30 Belly ache, drink powder of Veruine gathered about Midsommer.
31 Vein broken, drink ye juice of Veruine, Betony, and Fiueleafe, boiled with
as much Goats milk warm vii. days in the increase, and seven days in the
wane of the moon. 32 Falling evil, gather it while is in, and drink it with
white wine and powder of Peony seeds. 33 Mouth stink, hold the juice long in
thy mouth. 34 Piles, (See Burre.) Bitings venomous, bear it about thee, and no
serpent will hurt thee. Or seethe ii. or iii. handful and wash therewith, and
apply the herb with honey to heal it. 35 Bile to remove, (See Oculus
Christi.) 36 Crampe, stamp it with Brimstone and apply it. 37 Hoarsenesse,
seethe it with Licoras in water and streine it, and use no other drink till
you be well. 38 Eyes watring, stamp it with the white of an Eg, and apply it
at night on the eyes. 39 Eyes bleared, stamp it with wine and salt, and apply
it night and day. 40 Nose bleeding, be not strait girded, and hold thy hands
full of Veruine, and look up to the Sun. 41 Squincie, stamp it and apply it
hot. 42 Appetite to cause, eat Veruine. 43 Flux, seethe the root, and
drink the broth. 44 Deliverance to cause, stamp it and drink it with water.
45 Fever tertian, stamp iii. leaves and iii. roots, and dissolve them in
water, and drink it before the fit. 46 Fever quarten, stamp iiii. leaves and
iiii. roots, and sees them in wine, and drink it before the fit. 47 Kings
evil, hang the root about thy neck. 48 Deliverance to cause, stamp it and
streine it with wine, water or vinegar, and drink it. 49 Seethe it with
Draconitum in water, and let it stand till it be clear, and anoint any edge
tool therewith to make it hard and sharp. 50 (See Hysope, Dittany.) 51
Chilblaines, stamp it with Swines grease and apply it. 52 Ptisike and
difficulty of breathing, drink Veruine water. 53 Fundament falling, seethe it
in wine, and mix it with a little lee and wash it therewith warm. 54 Eyes
blooddyshot, stamp the leaves with a little salt, and apply it in the nights,
and be whole. 55 Matrix sores, wash with the water distilled in the end of
June. It helps also the griefs and dullness of the eyes being often dropped
in. 56 Deliverance to cause with speed, drink it with cold water. 57 Eyes
swollen, dim, and bloody, stamp it with the white of an egg and apply it, or
the juice of it. 58 Hold it privily in thy right hand, and ask the sick how
he does, but let him not see it, take him by the right hand, and as his answer
is, so shall he do, whether it be to live or die. 59 Dead child, drink it
with wine or water. 60 Milk to cause, drink it with water, or rather with
wine. 61 Mouth stink, hold the juice close long in thy mouth. 62 It is good
for the stone, liver, and lungs. 63 Stone, stamp Veruine, Betony, and
Saxifrage, of each like much, and drink it with wine. 64 Blood to stop, put
in powder of Veruine. 65 Biting of a mad dog, stamp it with as much Planten,
and streine it with red wine or stale ale, and drink it with Treacle, and
apply one of the same herbs, stamped with salt to draw out the venom.

Appetite 9 Apostume 9. 42 Belly-ache 3. 10. 30 Biting venom. 1. 34. 65 Bile 35
Bleeding 64 Breath stink 33. 61 Chaste to be 14 Consumption 52 Chilblaine 51
Crampe 36 Dead child 59 Deliverance 11. 44. 48. 56 Eyes bloodshot 54 bleared
39 griefs 55 spots 23. swollen 57 watring 38 Emerods 34 Falling evil 32 Fever
tertian 6. 26. 45 quarten 6. 26. 46. cold 24 Flux 12. 43 Fundament fallen 53
Gums loose 1 Headache 3. 15. 21 megreme 15 Hoarsenesse 37 Kernels 13 Kings
evil 7. 47 Liver griefs 62 Lungs griefs 62 Lust to void 14. 28 Mad 22
Matrix pain 4. 8. 19 sores 55 Milk to cause 16. 60 Mouth sores 1. 33 stink
33. 61 Nose bleeding 40. 64 Piles 3. 4 Pissing blood 31 Poison 25 (see venom.)

Violets.
VIolets: gather them in March, and dry them in a shadowy place in the air. 2
Stomach windy, drink the flowers. 3 Squincie, gargle with the decoction of
the flowers. 4 Swellings hot, apply the juice of the herb. 5 Flowers stopped,
drink two drams of the seeds with wine. 6 Milt swollen and the hot gout,
seethe the root in wine and apply it. 7 Dead child to expel, and to cleanse
the matrix, and void the swelling of it, boil white Violets and apply them. 8
Matrix to cleanse and to provoke the terms, foment with the decoction of it. 9
Headache hot and to cause sleep, apply Violets to ye forehead. 10 Syrup of
Violets helps the headache, causes sleep, softneth the breast and throat,
and helps the falling of the Pallat and the Squincie. Headache, smell to
Violets. 11 Milt swollen and for the gout, seethe the root in Vinegar, and
drink it and apply the root. 12 Cough in children, boil the herb and root
and apply it. 13 Ears pain, drop in oil of Violets. 14 Headache, anoint
with the oil. 15 Belly worms, mix the oil with Wormeseede, and anoint. 16
The Syrup helps the burning Fever, loses the belly, and qualifieth the
hot liver. 17 The purple Violet drunk in water loses the belly, quenches
choler and thirst, helps inflammations, and puts away the Iaundies, and
so does the Conserve of Violets. 18 Cut off the green part of the flowers,
and pun them small, and put thereto twice so much Sugar, but to all other
flowers thrice so much Sugar, and keep it in a gally pot, it will last one
year, and is very good for a hot stomach and liver, it cools the head,
procures sleep, and tempereth the heart, and all other parts of the body:
the leaves in brothes are good for the same purposes. 19 The decoction of
Violets is good against all hot Fevers, and all inward inflammations, and
drives out by siege hot chollerike humors, and so does the syrup, and
conserve, and juice. 20 The syrup is good against the inflammation of the
lungs and breast, the plurisie and cough, and also against Fevers, especially
in children: it cures all inflammations and roughness of the throat being
holden in the mouth, and so does the sugar of Violets, or the conserve, or
juice. Ears running, drop in the juice. 21 Head ulcers and sores, stamp the
leaves with honey and anoint therewith. 22 Frenzy and watching, make a
suppository of oil of Violets and Opium, and use it. 23 Stamp Violets alone
or with oil, and apply it to the extreme ache of the head and to abate the
heat, to provoke sleep: for melancholy, to moysten the brain. 24 Stame
Violets with Barley meal, and apply it to hot apostumes and carbuncles,
inflammations of the eyes, hot ulcers and inflammations that come with the
falling down of the fundament. Drink the seeds with wine or water against
the stingings of Serpents or Scorpions. 25 The yellowe which is in the midst
of the flowers boiled in water and gargled, is good for the Squincie and
swelling in the throat, and is good to be drunk of children for the falling
sickness. 26 The herb or plant is very good against all hot Fevers, the
inflammation of the liver, and to loosen the belly. 27 Take two or three
sponefull of the Syrup to take away sharp Fevers, to soften impostumes, and
to strengthen the heart for the plurisie and all hot griefs. 28 The syrup
taken with spring water, is good to quench thirst. 29 The oil, water, and
vinegar of Violets applied, is good for the head ache and inflammation of the
liver. 30 Violet water and Sallet oil of each one ounce drunk, cleanses
rotten matter in the lungs and stomach, and helps cough and pain of the
lungs. 31 The broth of Violets is given from iiii. ounces to viii. ounces. 32
The syrup from ii. ounces to iiii. ounces, the conserve from one ounce and a
half to iii. ounces to purge the body. 33 Drink one dram of the powder of
Violets with the broth of a Capon, or of peason before meat to purge the
belly. 34 Seethe Garden Violets, and stamp them and apply them to the bottom
of the belly, against the stopping of the urine in a fever. 35 For hot aches
of the head or else where, apply Violets. Tongue wheales, (See Roses.) 36 Eyes
blasted, stamp the roots with Myrrh and Saffron, and apply it at night. 37
Head wounded, stamp the leaves with vinegar and honey, and apply it. 38 Sleep
to cause in sickness, seethe it well in water, and soke well thy feet therein
to the ancles when thou go to bed, and bind the herb to thy temples. 39
Eyes sore, ache, and swelling, stamp Violets with Myrrh and Saffron, and
apply it. 40 The water is good for the apoplexia. 41 Sleep to cause when
choler is the cause, seethe the leaves in water, and wash thy head therewith.
42 Breast suppuration or mattering, use the syrup. 43 Cough of hot cause and
for thirst, and roughnes of the throat, drink the syrup with a little water
blood warm. 44 Head pushes, stamp the leaves with honey and apply them. 45
Ears running, put in the juice with clarified honey. 46 Teeth-ache, seethe
Violets in wine, and hold them in thy mouth. 47 Nose bleeding, gargarise with
the juice of the roots.

Aches hot 3. 5. 6. 11 Apoplexia 40 Apostume 24. 27 Belly bound 33 Breast
griefs 10 inflamed 20. 42 Carbuncle 24 Conserve 18 Cough 20. 30. 43. 12 Dead
child 7 Ears pain 13 run. 20. 45 Eyes blasted 36 inflamed 24 sore 39 ulcers
24 Falling evil 25 Fevers hot 16. 19. 20. 26 27. 34 Flowers stopped 5 Fundament
griefs 24 Frenzy 22 Gout 6. 11 Heart griefs 18. 27 Headache 9. 10. 14. 18.
