Melancholy 23 Milt swollen 6. 11 Nose bleeding 47 Plurisie 2. 7. 20 Purgation
19. 31. 32. 33 Sickness general 18 Sleep to cause 9. 10. 18. 23. 38. 41
Squincy 3. 10. 25 Stinging 24 Stomach hot 18 windy 2 Swellings hot 4 Teeth
ach 46 Thirst 17. 28. 43 Throat griefs 10 rough 43 swollen 25 Tongue blisters
35 Venom 24 Urine stopped 34 Vuula fallen 10 Windiness 2 Wounds 15
Virga aurea.
VIrga aurea: It heals wounds, and has the virtues of Sarasins consound:
boil it in wine, and drink it against the stone in the reins, and to provoke
urine, and so does the water of it: drink one spoonefull of the powder with a
rere egg four hours before meat, to provoke vrin within half an hour, and
so taken, it expels the stone in ten or twelve days without pain, (See
Solidago.)

Stone Urine stopped
wal barley.
Wall barley, Waybent, or red Darnell, drink it with red wine, to stop the
flowers and fluxes. Bind the herb to the body in Crimson lether, to stop
bleeding.

Bleeding Flowers Fluxes
wall nuts.
WAlnuts new and green, are better to be eaten then dry nuts, yet they be hard
of digestion, and nourish very little. 2 The dry nuts nourish less, and yet
are of harder digestion, they cause headache, and hurt the stomach, and cause
cough and shortness of breath. 3 A dried nut or two taken fasting with a fig
and a little Rue, withstandeth poison. 4 And mixed with figs and Rue, they cure
old ulcers of the Paps and other cold apostumes. 5 Apply dry nuts with salt,
honey and onyons, to the biting of a mad dog. 6 Stamp old oily nuts, or the
oil of them, and apply it to blew marks and bruises, and skurfs and skales. 7
The decoction of the green husks with honey, is good to gargle against al
tumors and ulcers of the mouth and throat. 8 The leaves be almost of the same
virtue, ( Poison, See Figs.) 9 Mad dogs biting, chew a kernel fasting, and
apply it. 10 Some gather the green husks about midsummer, and dry them into
powder, and use them in their meats in stead of Pepper: it is much better to
put dried sage thereto. 11 The tender leaves that are reddish, dried, are good
for the same purpose. 12 The young nuts are gathered about midsummer, and
condyted with sugar or honey into a sucket, for many purposes. 13 Walnuts mixed
with a little honey and Rue, are good for the inflammation of the Paps, 14
Apostumes and loose joints: and with honey, an onyon and salt, it is good for
the biting of a dog, of a man, or of an ox, and for blackenesse coming of a
bruise. 15 The water distilled out of Walnuts about midsummer, is good for the
inflammation of the Paps and loose joints. 16 Walnuts burned with their shells,
and mixed with oil or wine, and applied to the navel, is good for the torments
of the belly. 17 The shells burnt and mixed with oil and wine, nourishes and
restores hair that is fallen. 18 The kernels burnt and mixed with wine,
heals carbuncles, and so does the oil pressed out of the nuts. 19 The oil
with honey, or the green nut rindes, will kill the kanker, the place being
anointed, and also bring hair, and withstand baldness. 20 They are fit to be
taken fasting, of them that would vomit. 21 If they be eaten in great plenty,
they kill broad worms. 22 Walnuts mixed with Garlike, takes away the
sharpness. 23 With Rue and oil, they are good to be said to the squincie. 24
And mixed with sugar, they nourish temperatly. 25 The pills taken off, they are
good for the stomach, and do somewhat loosen the belly. 26 The water of green
nuts distilled about midsummer two or three ounces drunk, cools and resists
poison and the plague. 27 And ye water of ye utter husks, distilled in
September and drunk, is a sure experiment against the plague. 28 Lay Walnuts
with Chestnuts, to preserve them from moulding. 29 A Walnut put into a Chicken,
makes it to roste the sooner. 30 Walnut leaves with bores sewet, restores
hair, and so do the ashes thereof. 31 Steep the leaves in cold water, and at
night spring off the water and apply them one after another as they dry, to
running eyes. 32 Make powder of they flowers when they bloome, and take two
drams of it with an egg roasted till it be hard, with oil three mornings
fasting, (See Filbeard, Hasell.) 33 The leaves with Bores grease, cause hair
to grow. 34 Plague, (See Rue.) 35 Stamp green husks, and anoint dogs
therewith, no fleaes shall anoy them, his ears especially being anointed. 36
Hair falling, chewe the meat of them well in your mouth, and apply it
presently to the place. 37 Poisoned, pare away the uttermost of the bark, and
steep powder of the rest all night in water, and streine it and drink it
fasting, to cast up the venom. 37 Hairs to be yelow and shining, sees well
the husks of the nuts, and the bark of the tree in water, and make Lee
therewith, or stamp them with ashes, and make Lee therewith, and wash the
hairs. 38 Stamp as much bark of a Wall nut tree as thy finger, with woman's
milk, and anoint the headache therewith, and put thereof into thy ear. 39
Fever cold and shaking, take the rind of the root, scrape off the upper
part, and make powder of the middle part, and grind it with vinegar, and
streine it two or three times, till it be somewhat thin and clear, and
drink thereof a good quantity, to avoid the sickness, and to purge thee
clean.

Apostume cold 4. 13 Belly ach 16 bound 25
Bitings venomous 5. 9. 14 Breasts sore 4. 13. 15 Bruises 6 Carbuncle 18 Eyes
running 31 Fever cold 39 Fleaes 35 Headache 38 Hair falling 17. 19. 30. 33. 36
to be yelowe 37
Joints loose 13. 15 Kanker 19 Mad dog 5. 9. 14 Mouth sores 7 Plague 26. 27
Poison 3. 8. 26 Poisoned 3. 7 Skales 6 Skurfe 6 Spots 6 Squincy 23 Sucket 12
Throat sores 7 Vomit to cause 20. 37 Worms 21
Water cresses.
Water cresses are good in sallads, either by themselves or with other herbs,
it provoke urine, and expels gravel and stone, and is good for the
strangury, and all stoppings of the kidneys and bladder. 2 The lesser Water
cresse takes away the spots and freckles of the face, and all such blemishes,
being applied morn and even. 3 The wild Passerage or Cuckoo flower boiled in
Lee, drives away Lice of the head, being washed with it. 4 Kine that feed
where plenty of Cuckoo flowers are, give very good milk. 5 Cough, sees the
juice of Water cresse, with as much water, and good store of Honey and sugar
candy, and use it: proved. 6 The juice is very good for the dropsy, and so is
the water distilled with Sage and Centorie, of each like much, and drunk first
and last. 7 Eat every day three crops of Water cresse, to take away all the
swelling of the dropsy, but drink not after it. 8 Impostumes, stamp Water
cresses, and apply them hot. 9 Strangury, drink the juice with wine, or sees
the roots of Parsley, Fenell, and Smallach, with Water cresses in white wine,
and drink the broth, and apply the rest. 10 Urine stopped, drink wine of the
decoction of Water cresse. 11 Headache of a murre or reume, draw in the powder
of Water cresses dried in an oven into the Nose. 12 Sees a quart or a pottell
of Water cresses chopped small, with as much branne in a bag, in a kettle of
water, and anoint the Navel and loins with butter, and apply the bag round
about thee hot as may be suffered, at morn, noone and even, and lie on thy
back for the most part, to mollify the body, to avoid pain, and to cause
urine. 13 Urine to cause, seethe Water cresses in a new pot with wine, and sit
over it. 14 Strangury, seethe red Water cresse in water, and apply them to thy
womb: but let a woman use the suffumigation thereof. 15 Worms of all sorts,
boil the juice with swines grease, or May butter, and anoint, or frye them,
and apply them, (See Otes.) 16 Plurisie, spread honey on a cloth, and cast
thereon powder of the seeds of Water cresse, and so apply it. 17 Legs and
feet swollen, chop Well-cresses small, and seethe them in an earthen pot with
dregs of white wine, wheat branne, and weathers tallowe, of each like much,
and apply it hot four and twenty hours, and then renew it. 18 Back ach,
(See Nettles, Polypody.) 19 Swellings, seethe Water cresses in white wine, and
bathe well the place therewith, and keep it to four and twenty hours, and
hot, and do so two or three days, then cut large Figs the broadest way, and
steep them in woman's milk one day, and bind them to with a cloth three or
four days without remoouing. 20 Dropsy, make potage with Water cresse,
Borage and red Mints, with a red Cock or Capon, or with Porke and use them,
(See Nettles, Polypody.) 21 Senowes drawn, (See Camomile.) 22 Horsenesse, (See
Fenygreke, Horehound.) 23 Boil Water cresse in water, till they be tender,
make them in balls, and dry them, and apply one of them to the Emerods, as
hot as may be suffered nine days, if need be. 24 Urine stopped, sees it and
apply it, and sit in the decoction of it. 25 Emerods, streine the juice into
hot water, and of the herb and juice, make a plaster, and apply it. 26 Skall
to heal, seethe the juice with Bores grease and brimstone, and anoint
therewith. 27 Sees Water cresses with water, or with flesh, and sup the broth,
to cleanse the inward members, and for the flux, and the strangury. 28
Dropsy, eat Water cresses, Mints and Parsley daily, 29 Bruise, (See Dockes.)

Aches 12 Apostume 8 Back ach 12. 18 Bladder stopped 1 Bruise 29 Cough 5 Dropsy
6. 7. 17. 20. 28 Emerods 23. 25 Face deformed 2 Feet swollen 17 Flux 27
Gravel 1 Head ach 11 skall 26
Hoarsenesse 22 Impostume 8 Kidneys stopped 1 Legs swollen 17 Lice 3 Milk to
cause 4 Plurisie 16 Reume 11 Senowes drawn 21 Skall 26 Skin to cleanse 2
Strangury 1. 9. 14. 27 Swellings 17. 19 Urine stopped 1. 10. 12. 13. 24 Worms
general 15
Water Betony.
Water Betony, or Brown wurt: The leaves, stalk, seed, root or juice, does
waste and dissolve all swellings and hardness, being stamped with vinegar, and
applied at morn, noone and even. 2 Stamp the leaves and apply them to old
rotten corrupt spreading and fretting sores and pockes, to heal them: and with
salt to kankers. 3 Face red, wash with the juice. 4 Emerods, eat the root to
dry them up, or stamp it and apply it outwardly. 5 Worms to kill, drink the
seed. 6 Stamp the whole herb, and drink the juice of it against spitting of
blood, the flux and excess of flowers and bleeding at the nose. 7 Bruise the
leaves or seed cases, and apply them on fresh wounds to heal and skin them,
and to rotten sores, figs of the fundament, swellings and leprie: the juice
does the like. 8 Drink the seeds with wine, against all venomous bitings. 9
Drink one dram of it, to expel great worms. Drink the seeds with myrre
and Pepper with wine, to help the sciatica excellently well. 10 Take the juice
of the whole herb and root in May: keep it in a close glass: when need is,
take thereof with wax and oil, of each like much, boil it till it be an
ointment, and use it for all skabs and leprie. 11 The distilled water, takes
away all pimples and redness of the face. 12 The water or juice with brimstone
and saltpeter, takes away the ach of the eyes. 13 The seed mixed with honey
and applied to the forehead, stops the running of the eyes. 14 The powder of
it helps the Pyles and Emerods. 15 The herb alone sodden in well water,
quenches all unkind heates without danger, and exceeds all others for the
marmall, leprie, skab, itch, etc. wheales, pushes, etc. 16 Eyes dull, put in
the juice of it and of Comfery. 17 Botch in the throat or else where, drink
the juice, to drive it out.

Apostume 17 Bitings venomous 8 Bleeding 6 Botch 17 Eyes ach 12 dull 16 running
13 Emerods 4. 14 Face deformed 3. 11 Fig in ano 7 Flowers to stop 6 Flux 6
Fundament fig 7 Hardness 1 Itch 15 Kanker 2 Leprie 7. 10. 15 Marmall 15 Nose
bleeding 6 Pyles 14 Pocke 2 Pushes 15 Sciatica 9 Skabs 10. 15 Sores 2. 7
Spitting blood 6 Swellings 1. 7 Wheales 15 Worms 5. 9 Wounds 7
Water Pepper.
Water Pepper or Culerage: The leaves and seed do waste swellings and
hardness, and dissolueth congealed blood of bruises. 2 The powder of the dried
leaves may be used for Pepper in meats, like as our Dittany and Passerage. 3
Mixed with salt, it will season flesh.

Bruise 1 Flesh to season 2. 3 Hardness 1 Swellings 1
Water Planten.
Water Planten: Dropsy, apply good store of the leaves to the shankes, to
draw out the water from the belly: it has the nature of Planten.

Wheat.
Wheat raw chewed, is good to be laid to the biting of a mad dog: whole
Wheat is good for the pain of the gout, if a man sit therein up to the knees.
2 The meal with the juice of Henbane, applied to the senowes, is good against
the falling of reumes and subtle humors into them. 3 The same with oximel
cleanses away all lentilles and spots from the face. 4 The meal of March or
summer Wheat applied with vinegar, helps venomous bitings. 5 The same boiled
like to paste or pap and licked, is good against spitting of blood. 6 And
boiled with Honey, butter and Mints, it is good against the cough and roughness
of the throat. 7 And boiled with Honey and water, or with oil and water, it
dissolueth all tumors and swellings. 8 The branne boiled in vinegar, is good
against the skuruy, itch, and spreading skab, and dissolueth the beginnings of
all hot swellings. 9 The branne boiled in the decoction of Rue, does slake and
swage the hard swellings of women's breasts. 10 The leaven of Wheat meal,
draws out shiuers, splents and thorns, especially in the soles of the feet,
and does ripen, open and break al swellings and impostumes, being applied with
salt. 11 Wheat bread boiled in Honied water, does swage and appease all hot
swellings, especially if good juices of herbs be put thereto fit for the same
purpose. 12 Wheat bread new baked, soked in brine or pickle, does cure all old
and white skurfe, and the foul creeping and spreading skab. 13 The amyll and
starch of Wheat, is good against the falling of Reumes and humors into the eyes
being applied: and it cures and fills with flesh, wounds and hollow ulcers.
14 The same amile drunk, stops the spitting of blood. 15 And mixed with
milk, it swageth ye roughness or soreness of the throat and breast, and
causes easy spitting. 16 Mix Wheat meal, incense and doves dung, with the
white of an egg, and apply it to the forehead, to avoid all headache. 17 Take
as much Wheat flower as will lie on three french crowns, mix it with as much
well or spring water, as will make it of the thickenesse of milk, and give it
to a child to kill worms. 18 Mix Wheat branne with Pigeons dung, and the
white of an egg, and apply it to the contrary side of the grief to take away
all giddiness and dassing of the head. 19 Wheat meal with the juice of
Henbane takes away the inflammation of the guts. 20 Wheat bread that is
leauened, is better then the meal in Plasters for the stomach. 21 The juices
of Rue, Mints, Sage and wormwood mixed with Wheat meal or Wheat bread-crums
and vinegar, is good in plasters for the pain in the stomach. 22 A plaster of
the branne with vinegar, and the juice of sower Pomegranates applied warm to
the belly, does stop the flixe and swelling of the guts. 23 Bread that has
much Wheat branne in it, makes the eater thereof lean. 24 And the pure meal
nourishes and makes fat. 25 The oil pressed out of Wheat betwixt hot irons,
heals ulcers and wounds, and all chaps of the hands, lips and feet. 26
Plasters of Wheat meal leaven, and salt, vinegar, butter and oil of Roses,
are good against all bruises, to heal them, if they be curable, the same being
applied and the patient drinking Vnguentum Potabile, and rolled in a long
towell. 27 Wheat, or meal thereof used in brothes, is both comfortable and
restoratiue. 28 Wheat flower well sodden in water or milk with butter, is good
against the cough, hoarsenesse, and spitting of blood, and all griefs of the
breast. 29 The same sodden with Honied water, drives away all inflammations.
30 The branne sodden in water or Honey, heals the exulcerations of the throat,
and being gargarised, it helps the swelling and inflammation of the jaws. 31
Sees the branne in vinegar, and foment the members and senowes that are loose.
32 The same sodden in vinegar with Rue, is good for creeping sores, pockes,
wheales, inflammations and swellings, especially of the Paps and priuities: it
helps also the stingings of vipers. 33 The leaven of Wheat meal, is good to
draw, to ripen and heat the knobs and Agnailes of the feet: and with salt, it
helps fellons, vncomes and such like. 34 Apostumes, frye Wheat branne with
dregs of wine and sheep sewet, and apply it. 35 Bloody flux, kneade a cake
of Wheat meal with the juice of Motherwurt, and bake it in the fire, and eat
it hot. 36 Botches, sees Wheat meal, with oil in water, and apply it. 37
Cods swollen, sees the branne with Parietarie in sweet wine, and apply it. 38
Kanker, mix Honey with Wheat meal and Ribwurt, and apply it. 39 Wounds to
heal, apply white bread crumbs stamped with water and the white of an egg, and
apply it. 40 Swelling of wounds, apply the pith of bread of Wheat with the
juice of Smallach. 41 Bruises, gouts, wounds and such like, apply a plaster of
Wheat branne, sheep tallowe and white wine. 42 Pushes to avoid, stamp
Wheat with wine, and apply it. 43 Tenasmus, sees a bag of Wheat branne in
water, if the disease be hot, or else in wine, if the disease be cold, and
sit upon it. 44 Swelling of blood letting, stamp white bread crumbs with wine,
and apply it. 45 Stones apostumed of cold cause, sees the branne, and apply
it. 46 Squincy, apply a plaster of white bread, wine and Honey, to ripen and
break it, and use butter. 47 For the ach and Apoplexia of the liver and milt,
boil Wheat meal, and the branne thereof, with the juice of woormewood, till
it be thick, and apply it. 48 For inflation of the stomach and belly, stamp
Planten with Wheat bread, and apply it. 49 Botch, apply a red Onyon roasted with
Wheat meal. 50 Head skalfering, cast seething hot water into Wheat branne,
and let it stand four and twenty hours, then streine it, and put a little
vinegar to it, and struck the head therewith, as often as need is. 51 Spitting
blood, sees Wheat in butter and water, and eat it three days as potage, it
helps also the cough of the lungs. 52 Nails to grow soon, apply Wheat
flower with Honey. 53 Breasts hard, (See Rue.) 54 Pricks to draw out, seethe
Wheat flower and apply it, it helps the ach, voydeth the venom, and heals
it again, and is good to heal a byle, vncome or fellon, or whiteflaw. 55
Freckles, wash with the decoction of Wheat branne, or crummes of bread and
water. Ears apostumed, (See Cummin.) 56 Teeth to draw, (See Tythimall.)
Hicket, (See Masticke, Mints.) 57 Reins ache, (See Calamint, Cummin.) 58
Flux, bake cakes of Wheat flower and the juice of Yarow, and eat them hot.
59 Bloody flux, sees Wheat till it be broken, then streine out the juice, and
sees it in a posnet and eat it, or knead cakes of Wheat flower and the juice
of white Tansie and yolks of eggs, and bake them and eat them, and drink a
little after it. 60 Belly grinding, bake Wheat cakes sowred, and use them as
Ote cakes, (See Otes.) Or boil Wheat in wine, and apply it plasterwise. 61
Isiake, (See Smallach.) 62 Gouts general, make powder of dried salt, put
thereto as much Honey, and as much Wheat meal, as it comes from the mill,
boil it till it be thick, and apply it. 63 Fellon, boil good ale dregs with
Wheat meal, and apply it. 64 Apostume, (See Barley.) 65 Apostume flegmatike,
boil oil Olive, Honey, Butter and Wheat meal, and anoint therewith, (See
Figs, Cummin.) 66 Apostume to draw, apply Wheat flower with common oil. 67
Ranker, (See Radish, Elecampana.) Fester, (See Garlic.) Wounds ach, (See
Smallach.) Vomiting, (See Mints.) 68 Flowers to stop, (See Planten, Roses.)
Soreness in the flesh, (See Saffron.) 69 Skabs, boil Wheat leaven in good ale
dregs, and apply it. 70 Swellings, (See Watercresse.) Ach by breaking of any
thing, apply Wheat meal with wine. 71 Flux, boil clarified Honey and white
bread crummes with red wine, and drink thereof two or three times. Flowers to
stop, sees Wheat flower in milk and Honey, and apply it to the navel hot.
72 Senowes drawn, (See Camomile.) 73 Sores, boil Wheat flower with Honey, and
use Plasters thereof. 74 Stomach heat, stamp smallach with the finest Wheat
bread, and apply it to the chest and stomach three days together, fresh every
day. 75 To make fine Wheat cakes, Take fair Wheat flower a pottle, Rose water
half a pint, Cinamome half a stick, powder of Aniseeds two spoones full,
sugar i. pound, whites of eggs iiii. salt a quantity, butter ii. or iii.
peniworth, but no barme: make cakes thereof, etc. 76 Eyes humors and tears,
streine Wheat flower with water, and put it into the eyes, (See Rue.) 77 Gout,
sees salt and sifted Wheat branne, Honey and red wine, till it be thick, and
apply it. Fever tertian, (See Radish.) 78 Apostume, masels pocks, etc. apply
leaven of Wheat. 79 Ach or bruise, sees Wheat bread crummes in water till it
be thick, and stir it well and apply it, to restore the color again, (See
Fenigreke, Lilly, Planten, Chickeweede, Leekes.) 80 Falling evil, kneade cakes
of Wheat meal, with the deawe on midsummer morning, and bake it and eat it.
81 For women's breasts that be hard, and for all venomous bitings, sees the
branne with the juice of Rue, and apply it. 82 Sciatica, apply the juice of
sauery with Wheat flower. 83 For itch and worms in any place, steep Wheat
in wine, with powder of Olibanum, and apply it. 84 Arm swollen by blood
letting, apply the meal with honey and milk. 85 Headache continual, make a
cake of the flower and vinegar, and apply it, (See Spurge, Tythimall.) 86
Skabs, anoint with the oil of Wheat. 87 Prick in the senowes with needle or
such like, sees the flower in white wine, till it be thick, and apply it
hot, (See Branne, See Housleeke.) 88 Yard griefs, (See Olive.) Wounds, (See
Planten.) 89 Pyles, sees Wheat branne in Lees of white or claret wine, and
apply it as often as need is, hot. 90 Sores, (See Dasie.) 91 Blood to stop,
apply Wheat flower with Raddle and whites of eggs. 92 Breasts curded milk,
make pellets with Wheat flower, water and swines blood, and apply it to bring
out all filth. 93 Laske to stop, bake cakes of Wheat flower and yolks of eggs
on a tylestone, and eat them morn and even. 94 Byle to break, apply wheat
flower with Honey, the yolke of an egg, and a little salt. 95 Amyl, amidum, or
starch: Tongue blisters or bladders, mix starch with Rose water, and apply it.
96 It is good in eye medicines, for wounds, roughness, and reumes of the eyes,
and is an excellent help for spitting of blood being drunk: and with milk it
stops fluxes, it is good for apostumes of the spiritual members and the
cough, sodden in Barley water, and Almond milk, with some Penides. Taken with
milk, it helps the roughness of the throat. 97 It helps all fluxes,
pushes and ulcers of the ears, (See Leaven, Branne, etc.)

White Saxifrage.
White Saxifrage, with the grains and berries of the same boiled in Wine, and
drunk, provoke urine, cleanses the kidneys and bladder, breaks and
expels the stone, and is excellent against the Strangurie, and all the
griefs of the reins. 2 The powder of the roots in an Electuarie with honey,
has the same virtues, and so has the water distilled in May.

Stone 1 Strangurie 1 Urine stopped 1
Wintercresse.
VVIntercresse or Herba S. Barbarae, is good in sallads, and is used in Winter
for sallads, and does as well as Cresses or Rocket. 2 It cleanses corrupt
wounds or ulcers, and consumes dead flesh that grows too fast, being
applied, and the juice dropped in. 3 The seed provoke vrin, and drives forth
gravel, and cures the Strangury. It is green most commoly al Winter.

Dead flesh 2 Gravel 3 Strangury 3 Ulcers 2 Vrin stopped 3 Wounds 2
VVithwinde.
VVIthwinde black, the juice loses the belly. 2 The herb stamped, dissolueth
swellings. 3 Pluck up hairs, and anoint with the juice, and it will grow no
more.

Belly bound 1 Hairs to void 3 Swellings 1
VVoad.
VVOad: the garden or sown woad, is good to be laid upon the wounds of mighty
strong people that use daily labor, and to stanch bleeding, and to fretting
sores and rotten ulcers, and to all cold apostumes, to dissolve them. 2 The
Wild woad may supply the want of it. 3 The leaves applied as a plaster,
stops all swellings, join green wounds, stop blood, heals S.
Anthonies fire and all hot apostumes, consuming, rotten, and spreading sores.
4 The Wild woad both drunk and applied, helps the milt.

Apost. 1. 3 Bleeding 1 Milt griefs 4 S. Ant. fire 3 Sores rotten 1. 3
Swellings 3 Ulcers 1. 3 Wounds 3
VVoodlillie.
VVOodlillie, or Lilly conuaile, the flowers drunk in new wine, do
strengthen the heart, brain, liver, and all the spiritual parts, panting of
the heart, giddines of the head, the falling sickness, the Apoplexia, and
frenzy, pain and trembling of the heart, and stops the passages of the
leaprie, that it spread no further. 2 And being anointed, it auoydeth the
skabbe and ringworme, and that the sooner, if they be washed first, sundry
times with the water. 3 The water also asswageth the swellings of the stingings
of Bees and waspes. 4 And being distilled in wine, the water helps the
inflammation, and mist of the eyes, and it is thus made: take the flowers and
steep them in new wine thirty days, then take them quite out of the Wine,
and distill the wine five times over in a Limbecke, or body of glass. This
wine is more precious then gold, for if any drink thereof with six graynes
of Pepper, and a little Lauender water, they shall not need to fear the
Apoplexia that month. 5 The Wine may also be made thus: Fill a gallon glass
with good old Wine, and one pound of the flowers, and set it to sun forty
days, then distill it in a Limbecke of glass twice over, and put thereto a
little Lauender water and Pepper, or else the flowers of Lauender and of
Rosemarie, and other good spices, and distill it over again, and keep it
close stopped in a narrow mouthed glass, a spoonefull of it taken at the
point of death, does revive and prolong life: it comfort the brain,
ceasseth the Chollicke, and helps the Impostume in the hinder patte of the
brain, and helps the Apoplexia, it gives good memory and ready wit, by
anointing the head before and behind with it. 6 The water of the flowers six
ounces drunk, helps them that are poisoned, and helps the biting of a
mad dog, the birth of children, it comfort the brain, heart, and
senses. And being drunk forty days, it puts away the falling
sickness. 7 The same water drunk, helps the Strangurie, the pricking about
the heart, and inflammation of the liver, and staieth the excessive menstrues.
Drink one spoonefull of the water of the flowers distilled in good strong
Wine, to restore speech in the Apoplexia, and for the Palsy, and the gout,
and to comfort the heart, to strengthen the memory and restore it. 8 Drop it
into the eyes against their inflammation and watering. (See Monophyllon.)

Apoplexia 4. 5. 7 Bitings venomous 6 Brain weak 1. 5. 6 Chollicke 5
Deliverance 6 Eyes dull 4 inflamed 4. 8 watring 8
Falling evil 1. 6 Flowers to stop 7 Heart griefs 1. 7 weak 1. 6. 7

VVoodbine.
VVOodbine, the fruit drunk i wine forty days together, does heal the
stopping and hardness of the milt, and makes it less, and purges by urine
the corrupt humors so strongly, that after the daily use thereof eight or
ten days together, it will cause the urine to be red and bloody, and is
good for shortness of breath, or any dangerous cough, it helps women in
travel, and dries up the natural seed of man. 2 The leaves have like virtue
as the fruit. 3 And being sodden in oil, and stamped, and the ridge bone
anointed therewith before the fit, preuenteth the shaking of Agues. 4 The
same heals wounds and corrupt ulcers, and takes away hurtes and spots of
the body and face. 5 The juice of the leaves and fruit are evil for women
with child. 6 For the breaking out of the head, with ringwormes, etc. wash it
with strong vinegar, and cast thereon ashes of the rind of Woodbine. 7 For
Impostumes, and webbes of the eyes, mix the juice of Honisuckle, with pure
honey, and put it into the eye. 8 Take Woodbine leaves one handful, white Wine
a pint, powder of Ginger four ounces, seethe them till it be somewhat
thick, and anoint thy face therewith five or six times to avoid the pimples,
and to make it fair. 9 Stamp the leaves, and apply them to wartes six times,
to destroy them. 10 Gather the seed when it is ripe, and dry it in the
shadow, and drink one dram in wine forty days to melt away the milt, to
void weariness, for shortness of wind, for the hickit, and to expel urine:
the leaves have the same virtues. 11 leaves drunk seven and thirty days
together, so dries up the natural seed of man, that he shall get no more
children. 12 The oil thereof is very good for all cold griefs and
numbednesse. 13 The water is good against pissing of blood. 14 The syrop is
good for the lunges and the sores of the mouth and throat. 15 If women drink
it much, they become barren. 16 The berries are good against pissing of blood,
and to hasten deliverance, but the water is better and more pleasant, which
also helps the hot griefs of the eyes, and of the liver. 17 Apply a
Woodbine leaf to chappes, till they be whole. 18 Eyes web, seethe ribwoort,
Woodbine, and Planten, with May butter, and streine it and use it. 19 Stomach
sore, stamp fifteen leaves, and streine them with stale ale, and drink it
nine days first and last. 20 Tongue palsy, stamp the leaves and hold them
under thy tongue. 21 Woodbine heals cankred sores, wounds, bladders, and
toothach, sores in the toes, and is good against swelling in the body, coming
of venom or poison. 22 Skin to grow where it is raw, stamp the leaves, and
seethe them in a quart of good ale, and streine it, and put thereto honey and
allome, and seethe it to one half, then dippe graye paper therein, and apply
it. 23 Eyes to clear, (See Planten.) 24 Mouth canker, (See Cheruil.) 25 Skall,
(See Planten, Rue.) Kanker, (See Fiueleafe.) 26 Ears worms, put in the juice
hot. Eyes pin and web, (See Rue, Smallach.) 27 Mouth kanker, mix the juice
of Woodbine and Fiueleafe with honey and allome, and apply it. 28 Sores, (See
Sage. 29 Ringworme, wash it with strong vinegar, and cast on ashes of the
rind, it heals all skabs of the head, or else where. 30 Eyes blemishes, put
in the juice with woman's milk. 31 Nose bleeding, (See Raddish.) Face read,
take white Wine one pint, Woodbine water, two or three ounces, a handful of
the leaves, and four ounces of ginger in powder, sees them till it be
somewhat thick, and anoint the redness and pimples five or six times. 32
Face spots, red pimples and wheales, distill the flowers and wash often with
the water, and also drink four ounces morning and evening. 33 Wounded, drink
Woodbine with wine and honey three days. 34 Flux to stop, sees it in water
till it be soft, and wash thy body and feet therewith. 35 Kanker, mix burnt
alom with the juice of Woodbine, vinegar and honey, and anoint. 36 A salve for
a green wound, wash one ounce of turpentine in Woodbine water, and mix it with
the yolke of two new laid eggs, and put thereto two blades of saffron, and
mix them well and keep it in a box, it will last good one year.

VVoodrowell.
VVOodrowell, It is a good healer up of wounds. 2 Being put into wine, it
rejoices the heart, and comfort the diseased liver, and so it does being
sodden in wine. 3 Sees it in old ale and drink it against pissing of blood.
4 Stamp it and drink it with wine to heal sores of the mouth. 5 Stamp the
seed and drink it with strong vinegar to help the bloody flux.

Bloody flux 5 Heart grief 2 Liver grief 2 Mirth 2 Mouth sores 4 Pissing
blood 3 Wounds 1
VVolfthistle.
VVOlfthistle, the juice drunk with wine is good for the liver.

Wardens.
Wardens: to enlarge breath and open the pipes, shread iiii. pound of wardens,
the roots of Elecampane and radish of each ii. pound, put them into a pot with
as much honey as will cover them, cover it with paste and bake it with a batche
of bread, and take thereof one spoonefull morn and even.

VVormewood.
VVOrmewood, drink the juice ten days, drink half an ounce at once with
sugar to help the Iaundies, the water between the skin and the flesh, to
drive out many noisome humors of the liver and milt. 2 It comfort the
stomach and liver, and moves appetite to meat, helps the diseases coming
of obstructions, as the dropsy and such like diseases. 3 And it kills worms
in the belly, and expels them mightily, in this sort: take Wormwood four
ounces, Euphorbium half an ounce, hearts horn burnt one ounce, a hares gall
one ounce, and some honey, work them together and apply it to the belly. 4
Drink the juice with Sugar against old agues. 5 Bruise it and boil it in
water, and dip a linen clothe therein, and wash the head therewith gently for
the headache, and to procure sweet sleep. 6 Boil it in wine and drink four
ounces at once, to preserve the blood from putrefying in the body. 7 Drop the
oil into the ear to restore hearing. 8 Boil Wormwood in vinegar, and wash
the mouth therewith to amend the evil savor thereof. 9 Drink the decoction
of it to put away the swelling of the milte. 10 Boil it in oil olive, and
anoint therewith about the breast, to help the weakness of the stomach, and
malice of the liver. 11 Sees it in lee with sothernwood, to help the shedding
of the hair. 12 Stamp it with as much rue, and a little pepper, and boil them
in wine, and drink it to comfort and purge the stomach. 13 Lay it among
clothes to defend them from mothes. 14 Lay it under the boulster to procure
sleep. 15 Seethe the leaves or flowers in meat or drink: they are good for
the stomach, help digestion, and cease ache, expel poison, choler, and the
terms, being sodden in wine and drunk. 16 Sees it in wine, and drink it with
Cummin, to warm the stomach, and to help the torment and ache thereof, to
expel worms, to help the Iaundies, to expel the terms, and all manner of
poison or venom. 17 And sodden with vinegar, it helps the strangling of
mushromes. 18 The flowers dried and stamped with salt and given to cattle to
eat, helps their inward griefs, and drives away all noisome things within
them. 19 The juice or water applied to the temples, takes away the headache
that comes of cold cause, and dropped into the ears or eyes, it takes away
their pain, and cleanses them. 20 The herb stamped with saltpeter, and
honey, is good for the squincie. 21 The vapor thereof is good for the ache of
the ears, being received through a tunnill. 22 Seethe it in wine, and apply
it to the stomach to take away the loathing belch and ach thereof. 23 Steep a
branch or two in half a pint of good white wine in a close vessel all night,
and drink it in the morning warm with sugar to have a good color, and to be
free from worms. Make Wormwood wine thus: take aqua vitae and malmesey, of
each like much, put it in a glass or bottell with a few leaves of dried
Wormwood, and let it stand certain days, and streine out a little spoonful,
and drink it with a draught of ale or wine: it may be long preserved.
Wormwood used of them that be lean and evil colored, restores their
liking and color. 24 Wormwood taken, and also applied with honey, provoke
urine and the terms. 25 The water thereof heals watring sores in the corners
of the eyes. 26 With honey it is good for the brusings and darkness of the
eyes, and for the mattering of the ears. 27 The broth with Malmesey is good to
anoint the aching eyes withal. 28 The smoke of it drives away gnats. 29 The
juice kills itche, and put to ink, mice will not eat the paper that is
written with it. 30 Take the broth or infusion of it from v. ounces to viii.
ounces. The juice from iii. drams to iiii. drams, the powder from ii. drams to
iii. drams with wheye or with reasins the stones taken out, or with Roses, or
with Fumiterie to purge the body. 31 In stead of Wormwood wine, mix one good
spoonefull of it made with Malmesey and aqua vitae, as before is said, with a
good draught of wine and drink it. 32 Headache, wash it thrice a week with
lee of Wormwood. 33 Ears deaf, put the juice into the ears. 34 Headache,
stamp it and apply it to the temples. 35 Eyes red and bloodshot, stamp it
with the white of an Egg and apply it. 36 Lay it in chestes to withstand
breeding of mothes. 37 Steep it in the wine vinegar or water that ink is made
withal against eating with myce. 38 Ears worms, put in the juice with the
juice of Rue, and of Southistle, and be whole. 39 Clarify one pound of May
butter in the sun, and stamp two pound of green Wormwood, and set them in
the sun ix. days, then sees it one hour and a half, and streine it and
keep it in a Gally pot, and therewith anoint the navel at the full of the
moon to kill worms. 40 Wormwood purges by siege and urine chollerike humors
from the veins of the liver, wherefore the decoction or infusion thereof taken
daily, cures the Iaundies. 41 If it be taken fasting, it preserves from
drunkenness that day. 42 With Anniseedes it is good against windiness and
pain of the belly and stomach, wambling and desire to vomit. 43 Drunk with
vinegar, it is good against the sickness that comes by eating of Todestooles.
44 With wine it resists all venom and poison, chiefly of humblocke, and all
venomous bitings and stingings of spiders, and other venomous beasts. 45 Apply
it with honey to the dimnesse of the eyes that are bloodshotten, or have black
spots in them. 46 Boil it in Bastard or other sweet wine, and struck
therewith painful bleared eyes. 47 Stamp it with figs, salt, pepper, and
Darnell meal, and apply it to the belly, sides and flanks to help the
dropsy, and griefs of the milt. 48 The oil thereof rubbed upon any place,
keeps away fleas, flies and gnats. 49 Woormewood wine serves for all the
diseases aforesaid. 50 Seethe it in vinegar and apply it to sores that breed in
the ears. 51 The syrrop thereof eaten before wine, withstandeth drunkenness. 52
Bound to the belly, it heals the bloody flux. 53 It helps a cold
stomach drunk two spoonefull ten mornings, and is good for the dropsy. 54
The wine thereof is good against dropsies, coldness of the stomach, wind,
and swelling. 55 Seethe a handful in a gallon of clean water, or wine, in a
vessel of silver, glass, or stone, with some calamus Aramaticus, squinant,
cinamome, and the flowers of Cassia, and some spikenard, and dates of each four
ounces, beaten all together, or else put them into a vessel of new wine, with
a linen bag, and keep it close two months, and then drink thereof for the
yellow Iaundies, pain in the reins, loathsomeness of the stomach, stopping
of the terms, swelling after meat, continuance of vomiting, cold passions of
the heart, etc. 56 Stamp one pound of the leaves finely, and put thereto four
pound of the best white sugar, till it be well incorporated, and keep it in a
close glass, or gallie pot, and use it to help the dropsy, by taking every
day one ounce three hours before meat. 57 The oil thereof is good against
ache, noise, and deafness of the ears. 58 Wormwood Roman is singular
against all inflammations, and heat of the stomach, and liver, and for that
purpose is better then all other kinds of Woormewood. 59 While it is young, it
is eaten with other sallade herbs to strengthen the stomach, to open the
liver and milt, and so to preserve health. 60 The Wormwood wine at the
Stilliard is good for the same purposes. 61 Wits lost, (see Marigolds.) 62
Headache, (See Betony.) 63 Ears pain, and worms, put in the juice of
Wormwood. 64 Eyes bloodshot, (See Celondine, Cummin.) 65 Stomach griefs,
(See Betony.) 66 Vomiting, (see Mints. 67 Hands wounded, and swollen, boil the
juice with vinegar and wheat bran, and apply it. 68 Breasts swollen, (see
Calame^t. 69 Liver griefs, (see Sorel.) 70 Worms, (see Aloes.) 71 Mother
griefs, or suffocat. drink a dram of mithridate with an ounce and a half of
Wormwood water 4. hours before meat. 72 Piles, (see Dasie.) 73 Impost. (see
Mallows.) 74 Apost. inward or outward, drink the juice of Wormwood. 75
Backach, stamp rue, Wormwood, and sage, of each a handful, with barrowes
grease, and fry it, and streine it, and keep it in boxes, and use it. 78 Bones
ach, stamp it with sage and sothernwood, of each a handful, of rue 3. handful,
mix them with oil olive and malmesey, of each a pint, and let them stand five
days in an earthen pot close stopped, then seethe it till the wine be
consumed, then strein it, and keep it in boxes, and use it. For all sudden
swellings, boil Wormwood in wine, or in vinegar, and apply it. 79 Ears ach
and dull, boil the seeds of stauesacre, raddish, and Wormwood, and strein it,
and dip tents therein, and put them into the ear. 80 Eyes griefs, seethe
olibanum and Wormwood in wine, and drink it with sugar, and a little ale first
and last. 81 Eyes spot or web, bruise Wormwood with woman's milk, and strein
it, and put in one drop of the juice. 82 For rednes and blood in the eyes,
bruise new gathered Wormwood with the white of an egg, and apply it. 83 Gout,
boil VVormewood in a little oil, and apply it. 84 Headache, seethe it with
veruiue and betonie in water, and wash therewith, and also grind the herbs with
wheat bran, and apply it with a cloth to ye mould of the head thrice, as hot as
may be suffered: proved. 85 Mix Wormwood with ground iuie, whites of eggs, and
honey, and apply it to ye head for ye ach thereof. 86 Eyes ach, and swelling by a
bruise, heat dried wormwood on a tile, and apply it. 87 Headache, sees
Wormwood in vinegar and apply it to the forehead. 88 Iaundies, drink the
juice of planten and Wormwood, of each like much with sugar. 89 Impost. seethe
it with cummin in wine, and apply it. 90 Itch, wash with the decoction of
Wormwood. 91 Liver ach, boil the meal and bran of wheat with ye juice of
wormwood til it be thick, and apply it to the liver or spleen. 92 Matrix
suffoc. apply the juice of Wormwood, smallach and ysop, hot to the nauil with
a cloth and be whole. 93 Mouth ulcers, stamp Wormwood with honey, and hold it
in thy mouth, it is a singular remedy. 94 Speech lost, stamp it with water,
and put in a spoonful into his mouth. 95 Milt griefs, sees the roots of young
ash plants, with as much wormwood in a gallon of wine, to the one half, and
drink thereof at even hot, and at morn cold. 96 Milt hard, apply
Wormwood. 97 Stitch, stamp mallows and Wormwood with new butter, and apply
it. 98 Stomach swollen, use Wormwood. 99 Warts, anoint with ye juice of Eldren
flowers and Wormwood. 100 Worms in children, stamp Wormwood, and apply it
to the navel. 101 Vomiting, stamp Wormwood and Rose cake of each one
handful, and seethe them in red wine, and apply it to the stomach, or quilt
Wormwood, Mugwort, and Hyrsse, or Millit, of each iiii. drams in a bag, and
seethe them in wine and water, and press it a little, and apply it warm to the
breast to comfort the cold stomach, and to stay vomiting. It helps also
women with child, and them that have the stone engendered of cold cause, and
for gripings. 102 Stomach evil after meat, seethe vinegar with Wormwood,
and rub thy feet therewith when thou go to bed, and so thou may perhaps
sweat to do thee good. 103 Liver cold, use Wormwood in thy meat to comfort
and warm the stomach and liver, to unstop the liver, the yellowe Iaundies and
the dropsy, or take as much as a Chestnut daily at morn, noone, and even. 104
Belly griefs, if the body be mistempered and hard, and the urine stopped, chop
two handful of Wormwood small, and put it in a bag, and sees it in wine with
as much water, and apply it to the body as hot as may be suffered half an
hour, and heat it again as often as need is in the same liquour. 105 Belly
worms, mix two ounces of the juice of Wormwood, with one ounce of an Ox
gall, and struck it upon the belly. If you put thereto half an ounce of Aloes
Epatica, and Euphorbium, it will be much the better, the gall of a Hare is
better then the gall of an ox. 106 Fever quarten, sees a handful of Fenell,
with iii. or iiii. leaves of Wormwood in half a pint of wine, till the third
part be wasted, and drink it warm before the fit with half an ounce of honey
of Roses, half a glassefull at once, and when the cold fit is past, lie down
to sweat, and sleep if you can, if you be thirsty, drink more of it and use
it in the mornings fasting v. days, or sees one handful of Fennel with
half as much Wormwood in strong ale or wine to the one half, then streine it
and put to it some honey of Roses, and drink thereof a glassefull before the
fit, and walk after it as long as you can, and then lie down and cover you
well to sweat, and eat nothing of iiii. or v. hours before the fit. 107
Corns in the feet, anoint them with the juice of Houseleeke, and then apply
Wormwood warmed on a tile, and sprinkled with vinegar, and do so three or
four times. 108 Ears dull, (See Aloes, Onions, Leekes.) 109 Ears clensing,
seethe Wormwood in vinegar, and the urine of a boy under 7. years old, and put
it in with tents of linen, and lie up therewith. 110 Teeth-ach, apply the juice
with honey. 111 Stomach windy, apply the juice or herb. Breasts kanker, (See
Flax.) 112 Stomach cold, and want of digestion, mix the juice with as much
honey, and twice so much good wine, and boil them together, and take every day
a good spoonful morn and even. 113 Stomach swollen, seethe iii. handful of
Wormwood, and a handful of rue in good wine, and drink it. 114 Illiack
passion, boil powder of hot seeds with Wormwood in wine, and apply it. 115
Kanker, (see Flax, Holy-oke. 116 Fundament falling, of terms in man or woman,
take up the fume of Wormwood sodden in white wine, and anoint it with black
ink. 117 Ache and swelling in the feet, legs or thighs, take the roots of
Wormwood, do off the uppermost, and boil it in water well, and stamp it with
horse grease, and apply it in a cloute. 118 Leapry, boil the juice with swines
grease, till the juice be consumed, then streine it, and put thereto
quicksilver mortified, and use it also for all salseflegme. 119 Skab, (see
Celondine.) 120 Worms, (see Arsmart, Centory.) 121 Apost. (see Barley,
Mallows, Holioke. 122 Head broken, (see Mallows. 123 Bruises, (see Cummin.
124 Scab, (see Celondine, Dock. 125 Worms in the hands, (see Docks. 126 Worms,
(see Mints. 127 Belly swollen, seethe a handful of Wormwood in a pint of
malmesey to the one half, then streine it, and drink it, and boil fine
powder of coliander, with butter, till it be an ointment, and use it. 128 Agewe
cake, (see Mintes, Nettles.) 129 Heart burning, seethe it in fair water, and
streine it, and drink it daily: proved. 130 Head skurfe, seethe it, and wash
therewith, and apply the herb to help it by and by, and to make the hair
fair, clean and even. 131 Hair falling, make lee with the ashes of
Wormwood, and powder of Doves doung, and wash the head therewith. 132 Milte
griefs, (see Ash.) Take the roots of young Ash plants, and a good quantity
of Wormwood, seethe them in a pottell of Wine to the one half, and drink
thereof at even hot, and at morn cold, and use the ointment of Ashen ashes,
and do these things nine days and be whole. 133 Stitch, (See Rue, Sage.) 134
Stomach griefs, (See Cummin, Mints, Rosemary.) 135 Whites to stop, sees
wormwood and mallows in sack, and apply it plaisterwise to the belly, as hot
as may be suffered. 136 Women's griefs, use Wormwood with ale. 137 Squincie,
(See Flax.) 138 Chollicke, (See Barley, Sothernwood.) 139 Eyes bloodshot,
running and rhewmatike, stamp it with the white of an egg, and rosewater, and
apply it when you go to bed, and be whole. 140 Headache, stamp it and apply it
to the temples, or the juice thereof, (See Cucumber.) 141 Eyes red and bloody,
stamp it with the white of an egg, and apply it. 142 Morphue, (See Barley,
Mallows.) Vomit to cause, (See Fennel.) 143 Mother, (see Fearn, Ysope.) 144
To defend from the stinking vermin called pulices, anoint with the juice and
oil olive. 145 To void fleas, sprinkle the juice or decoction. 146 Vomiting
on the sea, to prevent it, drink the juice of Wormwood. 147 For old pain of
the liver, and sides, sees it in wine, and put thereto oil of nuts, or of
spikenard, and apply it or anoint. 148 To void headache, and cause sleep,
stamp it and boil it in water, and apply it. 149 Steep the leaves in water
ten hours, then take them out, and seethe the water to the one half, and take
four ounces of it, and cover thee well to sweat, to avoid old fevers that
come by fits. (See Camomile.) 150 Eye spots, put in the juice well strained. 151
To heal the disposition that comes before the dropsy, and the obstructio^
of the meseraicall veins, take the juice of Wormwood and sugar ana half a
pound, spikenard a dram, cinamom 2. drams in powder, mix them well, and take two
ounces with wine or broth morn and even. 152 Breasts sore, seethe sage,
margerom and Wormwood, of each a handful in white wine, and wash therewith, or
apply powder of black beans with honey. 153 Eye bruised, apply it with honey.
154 Head giddie, and swimming, seethe it in vinegar, and stamp it and apply
it. 155 Wounds to heal, stamp it with groundswell and old Swines grease, and
apply it to wounds and rotten sores. 156 Eyes dull, put in the juice of Rue
and Wormwood, (See Mallows.) 157 Stomach cold, and not digesting, take the
juice of Wormwood and honey, of each one cuppefull, wine as much as them both,
boil them, and take one spoonefull morn and even, (See Horehound, Elm.) 158
Nostrels stink, drink Wormwood with honey and wine. 159 Ach in the hands,
wristes, feet or sinews, seethe it in oil olive, or in oil of linseede, and
streine it, and anoint therewith. 160 Heart-burning, seethe it in water, and
drink it, (See Barley.) 161 Iaundies, seethe it in water, and wash therewith
thrice, and drink Iuorie with wine, (See Auens. 162 Breasts sore, (See
Mallows.) Sweat stinking, (See Camamile.) 163 Belly ach, Wormwood anoint with
the oil, (See Peach,) or seethe it in water with galls, and bathe therein.
164 Head megrem, (See Betonie.) 165 Stomach weak, (See bread.) 166 Black
iaundies, (see Celondine.) 167 Besch, (see Mallows.) 168 Wormwood comfort
the heart, cleanses the stomach. 169 Drink it with spikenard against the
windiness of the stomach and belly, 170 With honey it helps the swelling
in the mouth. With the gall of a bull it clears the sight, and helps all
the impediments of the eyes. 171 Clarify a pound of May butter in the sun,
and mix it with two pound of green Wormwood well stamped, sun it nine days
in May, then boil it an hour and a half, and streine it, and keep it in a
gallie pot, and anoint the belly therewith to kill worms. 172 Cough, seethe
Rue, Wormwood, and Centorie with good ale and honey to the one half, and
strein it, and drink it: some use Gentian therewith. 173 Hickit, stamp
Wormwood, sage and rue, and seethe them with vinegar and May butter, and apply
a plaster thereof to the breast four and twenty hours thrice, for want of
May butter, take fresh butter without salt. 174 Water of Wormwood is good for
the stomach, liver, and milt, to kill worms, itch, and emerodes, and to
withstand drunkenness. 175 Wormwood fried with butter, and applied to the navel
kills worms. 176 Piles, drink the juice of Wormwood fasting, with powder of
garlic, and apply ye drests. 177 Belly-wormes, drink the juice with sweet
milk, or seethe it in wine and apply it to the belly, or make powder of
Wormwood, Centorie, and betony, of each like much, and use it in pottage and
brothes. 178 Milt cold and swollen, seethe it in wine, and drink it, and apply
the herb warm. 179 Vomiting, stamp it with vinegar, sour tosted bread, and
the juice of mints and planten, and apply it to the mouth of ye stomach. 180
Worms, serpents, or earwigs in the ears, put in the juice. 181 Dropsy, seethe
it with wine, and drink it morn and even. 182 Take as much of the juice as a
bean to stay the breeding of choler and melancholy. 183 The decoction of it
dries the stomach, and helps the inflammation of the lungs, liver, and
milt, purges the bowels and stomach, and the salt thereof likewise. 184 The
strengh thereof increases, by being sodden in whay, with fumiterre and
reasins. 185 Breasts sore, (See Mallows.)

Ysope.
YSope leaves stripped from the stalks, may be kept a year. Seethe Ysope in
Spring water with figs, honey, and rue, and drink it for the griefs of the
lungs, shortness of breath, the old cough coming of Rhewme, wheasing, and to
kill all manner of worms in the belly. 2 Drink the juice with oximel to
loosen the belly. 3 Drink the juice with chesse seeds to loosen the belly
gently, and to cause a good color. 4 Boil Ysope with pure ducks grease, and
figs, and apply it to the milt for the swelling thereof. 5 Boil Ysope with
figs and salt niter, and apply it to the swollen and hard milt, and to the
belly that has the dropsy, and water between the skin and the flesh. 6
Seethe Ysope in water, and wash the mouth therewith to swage the swollen gummes.
7 Seethe Ysope in wine, and drink it to cleanse the breast. 8 Sees Ysope in
wine with fennel seeds, and drink it for the pains of the stomach, or foment ye
stomach with the decoction thereof, and apply the herb, the same foment beneath
does cleanse the matrix. 9 Sees it with figs, and gargle therewith, to help the
squincie. 10 Sees it in vinegar, and wash the gums and teeth therewith for the
toothach. 11 Drink Ysope wine for the griefs of the breast, sides, lungs,
shortness of breath, old cough, to provoke urine, to help the gripings of the
body, to cease the cold shakings of the agew, and to draw down the terms. 12
Seethe Ysope with Iris and Cardamome to purge Choler mightily. 13 Seethe Ysope
with rue, honey and figs in water, and drink it for any obstruction of the
breast, shortness of breath, or old cough, or lick in the powder with honey. 14
Take Ysope with syrop of vinegar to purge tough and clammie humors, and to kill
worms, and drive the^ forth. 15 Apply ye decoction of Ysope to congealed blood
and blew bruises, and to al itch, skurf, and maunge. 16 Roste Ysope in the
embers, and apply it to the head to stop rhewme. 17 The vapor of Ysope drives
away the wind in the ears, being holden over it. 18 The powder of Ysope is
good against the dropsy, and causes a good color, abateth toothache, and
kills worms. 19 Seethe Ysope in Wine, and drink it against any poison. 20
Seethe it with Sugar and honey in wine, and drink it against ruptures,
burstings, or bruisings, and to expel Melancholy, and for all things that
Organie is good for. 21 Use Ysope in epithimes, foments, bathes, and glisters,
for the Chollicke. 22 Seethe it in water, and wash all skurfe, skabbes, and
pockes. 23 Steep two handful of Ysope with one ounce of sliced licoras in a
gallon of ale when it is cleansed, and use it after it is three or four days
old, for the griefs of the lungs and chest. 24 Cough, Seethe a handful of
Ysope well in water, then put in powder of Licoras, dry figs, and raisins,
and boil them again in red wine, and drink it for all kinds of coughes.
For all kinds of coughs, take running water a gallon, lycoras scraped, one
handful, great raisins, Ysope, barley, and violet leaves ana one handful,
seethe them all to a quarte, then strain it, and drink thereof five or seven
spoonefull first and last, at even hot, and at morn cold, nine, eleven, or
thirteen days for the purpose aforesaid. 26 To cause deliverance of a dead
child, Drink Betonie, Rue, and Ysope in hot water, or drink the juice of
Ysope in ale. 27 Drink the decoction of Ysope for the Dropsy. 28 For the
falling sickness, Seethe Ysope and Piretrum in wine, and use it. 29 For the
suffocating of the mother, Apply the juice of Smallach, Ysope, and Wormwood
hot to her navel, with a cloth dipped therein, and she shall be whole:
Proved. 30 Plurisie, drink Triacle with the decoction of Ysope. 31 Iaundies,
drink Ysope water. 32 Lunges cough, and consumption, with pain in the left
side, and about the breast, take four ounces of Licoras, Anniseedes, and Ysope
ana one handful, seethe them in a quarte of water, and strain it, and put
thereto five or six ounces of Sugar, and drink thereof, but if thou have any
great heat, drink milk. 33 Hair not to fall, seethe the ashes of Ysope in
strong lee, and wash therewith. 34 Breast, (See Figs. 35 Cough, and
stoppings, make powder of Ysope, Ginger, Annniseeds, and Licoras, with honey,
and use it. 36 Breast pains, stamp Ysope, Parsley and Sage, and apply them.
37 Breast and lungs griefs, seethe Ysope and sothernwood in wine and sugar it,
and drink it, (See Barley.) 38 Belly great, See Arsmart. 39 For the griefs
of the stomach, Liver, and Lunges, to kill woormes, to comfort the sight, and
to cause a good color, Drink the juice of Ysope fasting. Receive Ysope,
Sage-royall, and water Cresse, of each two handful, bake their juice in
Wheat paste, and then break it into two gallons of Ale, and drink it daily,
but keep it close. 40 For the host and stopping of the breast-seethe the juice
of Parietarie, Ysope, and Planten with swines grease, and streine it, and
anoint the chest. 41 Breast phlegm, seethe Ysope, fat figs, and licoras, with
barley in water, and drink thereof. 42 Reins impostume, seethe the roots of
lillies and leekes, with Ysope in milk, and drink it. 43 Breast pains, and
short winded, anoint with the juice of Ysope and honey, or drink the juice of
Ysope, horehound, and bull-foote, with some sugar, or seethe a handful of
Ysope in a pottel of good white wine to the one half, then strain it, and put
sugar candy to it, and drink thereof at even hot, and at morn cold daily.
44 Cough, drink the juice of Ysope with syrop of licoras, and fine sugar, or
boil half a pint of licoras water, with three sticks of lycoras and sugar candy, and drink thereof morn and even daily. 45 Mouth stinking, make a
syrop with the juice of Ysope and mints, and take thereof morn and even. 46
Stomach cold griefs, seethe Ysope in white wine, and streine it, and put
sugar candy to it, and drink thereof at even hot, and at morn cold. 47
Belly worms, incorporate Ysope with honey and niter, and use it. 48 Ears
ach, put in ye juice withoile blood warm. 49 Squincie, seethe it in vinegar,
and gargarise therewith: if the pallat be fallen, apply the powder of the
flowers with thy finger, or dippe wool in the decoction of Ysope with oil and
apply it. 50 Dropsy, Seethe it in wine and drink it. 51 The juice of Ysope
holden in the mouth, heals all the evils thereof, it slays worms, and
loses the belly. 52 Breast ptisicke, fry the juice of Ysope, planten, and
parietarie with swines grease, and streine it, and anoint therewith the chest.
53 Ysope, (See Bursa pastoris, Figs.) 54 Dropsy, seethe it with staueseacre
in wine and drink it. 55 Swelling of toothach, seethe a good handful in a
pint of vinegar to the one half, then streine it, and seethe it a little more,
and hold thereof often in thy mouth. 56 Stamp Ysope with honey and niter to
kill woormes in the body. 57 Cough in children, seethe Ysope in wine with
Serpillium, or sauerie, and drink it with sugar candy, 58 Ysope, (see Figs.)
59 Gummes putrified, seethe Ysope in water, and wash therewith, and be whole.
60 Ysope, (see Fenegreke, Horehound.)

Agewe cold 11 Belly bound 2. 3. 51 Belly great 38 Blood congealed. 15 Breath
short 1. 11. 13. 43 Breast griefs 7. 11. 13. 23. 36. 37. 40. 43 Bruises 15. 20

14. 18. 39. 47. 51 Worms in the body 56
Oak.
Oak: The leaves and bark, with the cups of the Acornes, do stop and cure the
spitting of blood, pissing of blood, and all other flux of the blood, the
bloody flixe and laske, being boiled in red wine and drunk. 2 Powder of the
leaves does heal and close up wounds, and stops their bleeding. 3 Powder of
the bark given to young children, helps their laske, the flux of blood, or
other humors. 4 The Acornes do provoke urine, and are good against all poison
and venom. 5 And boiled in milk, they be excellent to be eaten, against the
bitings and stingings of venomous beasts. 6 The powder of them is very good to
be laid to the beginnings of hot apostumes and inflammations. 7 And stamped
with salt and swines grease, they cure hard ulcers and consuming sores. 8 The
Gaul is also very binding and stiptike, they be good against all fluxes of
blood and laskes, howsoever they be taken inwardly: or mixed with oils,
ointments or implasters, and laid too outwardly. 9 They are good in the
excessive moisture of the gummes, and all swellings and blistering sores within
the throat or mouth. 10 They stop the terms, and cause the matrixe that is
fallen down, to return to the natural place, if women sit in the decoction
thereof. 11 The same steeped in vinegar or water, makes the hair black. 12
It does eat and consume superfluous flesh being laid on. 13 The same burned
upon the coals and quenched in wine or viniger, or with brine ma^e of salt and
vinegar, stops all issues of blood or flux. 14 The powder of Gauls,
cleanses the mouth from filth. 15 Gaul applied, takes away the ach of the
teeth quickly. 16 The decoction of the inner bark and the cups of Acornes put
in, is good against all the fluxes of the belly and matrixe, the Gomor passion,
spitting of blood. 17 The water of the young shootes and young acornes, is good
for the same purposes, but especially in children. 18 The leaves do heal
wounds being applied. 19 The tender and reddest leaves or buds sodden in wine
and gargarised, helps the tooth ach. 20 Gauls sodden in water, and meats
made therewith, helps the bloody flux and all other fluxes, and helps all
things that the inner bark is good for. 21 Powder of Gauls is good for the
fluxes of the Jaws and Vuula. 22 Acornes eaten, breed wind and headache. 23
Raw Acornes are good for hot burnings, being stamped and applied. 24 They are
good with salt and swines grease, for very sore hard lumpes, and sores hard to
be healed. 25 The Gaul sodden by it self, and then stamped and applied, is a
good remedy against the inflammation or burning heat of the fundament, and for
the falling down thereof. If the matter require great adstriction or binding,
sees it in wine, if less, in water: if more, in vinegar. 26 Sees Oak leaves
and the middle rind in water, and wash the sores and fistulaes of the head
therewith, to have present redress. 27 Sees the middle rind in water, and
bath any sore therewith, old or new: and then anoint it with butter and
brimstone, and do so ten days together if need be, and be whole. 28 Mix
the ashes of burned Acornes with bores sewet, to make hair to grow. The bark
is constrictiue. 29 For a fistula, make powder of blood suckers, Oak coals and
salt, and put it into the bottom of it nine days, yea, though there be a
bone in it: or take out the bone with an instrument, and mix flower of Acornes
with honey and wheat flower and apply it, it heals marueilously: or mix
powder of Oak bark with vinegar, and the juice of Planten, and apply it. 30
Pissing bed, drink powder of the bladder of a goat, or ox, or hog, with the
decoction of Acornes, to have speedy help. Stomach wambling, chewe a green
leaf, or a dry leaf soked in water. 32 Liver inflamed, apply bags of Oak
leaves, and when they wax hot, apply other. 33 Belly loose, apply a bag of
meal of Acornes one quart, with whites of eggs and vinegar round about thee
from the navel downwards, and renew it with whites of Eggs and vinegar, as
often as need is, thrice or more. 34 Childrens vrin stopped with gravel or
stone, stamp a handful of Acornes and sees them in a quart of water, till the
third part be wasted, then streine it, and let him drink thereof as much as he
will. 35 Strangury, drink powder of Acornes and Peach kernels ana with wine:
if that help not, then thou have the stone. 36 Woman's breasts swollen, apply
powder of the apples with oil of Roses. 37 Morphew, (See Eldren.) Wounds
general, apply the juice of green Oak leaves, with the gleere of an Egg. 38
The kernels of the Acornes in powder, do help the power retentiue, weakness
of the brain, the pissing evil, called diabetica passio, the bloody flux,
the stone and strangury, and is good for them that cannot hold their urine. 39
The cups are good against vomiting of choler and sneesing, and it dries and
consumes phlegm in the mouth of the stomach. To make fruit black, put powder
of the Gauls into a hole bored in a tree, and the fruit will be black. 40
Powder of the leaves put into the nose, stops the bleeding thereof and
spitting of blood. 41 The leaf is good against ach of the heart, the
oppilation of the liver and milt, head ach, ach of the stomach and belly, the
chollike, ach of the flanks, it breaks the stone of the reins and bladder,
it helps neesing, it is good for women that be cold, and disposes them to
be able to conception: it is wholesome for all creatures of all ages for all
diseases, to be taken at all times of the year. 42 The leaves laid on, heal
all wounds, the kanker, fistula, Saint Anthonies fire: a bane made of the water
of the Oak, heals the dropsy, and all Leaprousnesse. 43 He that eats one
of the leaves once a week, shall never have stinking breath, nor tooth ach,
nor putrefaction of his gummes, nor ears. 44 Emerodes to stop, use powder of
Acornes, Ash keys, and a little Bol Armoniak in warm broth or drink, or a
rere Egg. Bloody flux, make powder of Acornes-cups, and drink it with red
wine, yolks of hard Eggs and Cinamome. 46 Hair falling, make Lee with the
ashes of the middle bark and leaves, and wash therewith, or sees them in
water, and wash therewith. 47 Apostumes and swellings at the roots of the
nails, stamp an Acorne with black soap, and apply it. 48 Eyes running, hold
them over the fume of the decoction of the leaves. 49 Cough and hoarsenesse,
and stopping of the liver, use to drink Lee of the ashes of a great Oak. 50
Flux, drink the water distilled of the leaves. 51 Flowers to stop, drink
water that stands in an hollow Oak with rain water: or use the decoction of
Acorne shales. 52 Bloody flux, and all other fluxes, distill the red leaves of
the young springs of Oaks that have been lopt, and take three or four spoones
full of the water for a child, but more for an old body with an Alebrew, or
such likewise, twice or thrice a day. 53 Flux red or yelowe, seethe powder of
a Gaul, seethe it in water, and temper the water with Barley meal, and apply
it to the belly. 54 Tongue bladders, or wheales, anoint it with the juice of
pety Morell, Purssen and Letuce, with red wine, and cast on powder of Gauls. 55
Teethach, mix powder of Gauls Masticke and Coral ana like much with Honey, and
rub therewith, to kill the ach and worms. 56 Squincy, apply Gauls, with Sal
Armoniak. 57 Fundament fallen, cast on powder of Gauls, Frankincense and
Myrrh, and Aloes, of each like much. 58 Gomer passion, to heal the vessel
wherein nature lies, drink a spoonefull of the powder of the cups, with warm
ale one hour or two before thou risest. 59 Reume, and to cleanse the head and
brain, tie many leaves to a little stick, and hold it between thy teeth
deep in thy mouth, and hold down thy head, then wash them in fair water,
and hold them in again as often as need is, it is the best help for Reume.
60 Urine running, seethe the small ends of the leaves in claret wine, and
stamp them, and apply them hot on the yard. 61 Hair to grow, burn Acornes,
and mix them with Bores grease, and anoint. 62 To stop the flux of blood of
the matrixe, and of urine, and of wounds, and to heal black pimples or
wheales in the legs, distill the leaves in a L^mbecke in the midst of May, and
drink thereof six ounces at once, and bathe also therewith: it helps all
inflammations of the legs. 63 Whiteflawe and apostumes of the nails, stamp
the leaves with Soap, and apply it. 64 Wounds to heal, apply powder of the
leaves. Flowers to stop, drink the feces which come out of an Oak with rain
water. 65 Flux to stop, distill the leaves, and drink the water cold.

FINIS.
A Table containing the effects of all the simples, set down in this book, by
the order of the Alphabet.
Abhorring meat.
HOllioke. Housteeke. Saunders. Sauery.

COleworts. Cresses. Flowerdeluce. Tar.
